title: A MAPS Detector for High Resolution Low Dose EBSD
authors: Barnaby D. A. Levin, Kalani Moore, Nicolò M. Della Ventura, McLean P. Echlin, Tresa M. Pollock, Daniel S. Gianola
abstract: The use of highly sensitive pixelated direct detectors has dramatically improved the performance of high energy instrumentation such as transmission electron microscopy. Here, we describe a recently developed monolithic active pixel sensor designed for low energy scanning electron microscopy applications. This detector enables electron backscatter diffraction (EBSD) at lower energies and dose than are accessible with existing scintillator-coupled detectors, expanding grain orientation mapping capabilities to materials such as ceramics that are poor electron conductors. The high detector sensitivity allows collection of rich diffraction information - providing dislocation defect contrast that is otherwise not accessible via EBSD. Indeed, even the energy of single electron interaction events can be measured with this detector, which we demonstrate to energy filter diffraction patterns revealing details of how diffraction occurs at low energy.

title: On Quivers Satisfying Quantum Yang-Baxter Equation, and Hecke Condition
authors: Cody Gilbert, Ashish K. Srivastava
abstract: In this paper we initiate the study of quivers satisfying quantum Yang-Baxter equation. By considering quivers with quantum group like relations such as quantum Yang-Baxter equation, Hecke condition, we follow RTT construction to produce examples of Leavitt path algebras that contain quantum matrix algebra as subalgebra. Furthermore, we show that the quantum Yang-Baxter equation, and Hecke condition for our RTT construction can be generated intrinsically from the adjacency matrix of certain quivers.

title: Thermodynamical study of N$_2$ clathrate hydrate from DFT calculations
authors: L. Martin-Gondre, V. Meko Fotso, C. Métais, A. Patt, J. Ollivier, A. Desmedt
abstract: Thermodynamic stability of N$_2$ clathrate hydrates in the sI and sII structures is investigated using density functional theory with several exchange-correlation functionals, explicitly accounting for composition (cage occupancies) and pressure at T = 0 K. Among the tested functionals, revPBE-D3(0) best reproduces experimental lattice parameters and bulk moduli B$_0$ . Energetic analyses confirm the strong impact of large cage double occupancy on sI, whereas the convex-hull results show that sI with single occupancy remains thermodynamically stable up to $\sim$ 0.8 GPa alongside sII with single occupancy. Increasing pressure then stabilizes sII with double occupancy, consistent with its larger large-cage volume and lower framework strain. These results provide a coherent, first-principles thermodynamic framework for N$_2$ hydrate stability and a baseline for finite-temperature extension.

title: DenseBEV: Transforming BEV Grid Cells into 3D Objects
authors: Marius Dähling, Sebastian Krebs, J. Marius Zöllner
abstract: In current research, Bird's-Eye-View (BEV)-based transformers are increasingly utilized for multi-camera 3D object detection. Traditional models often employ random queries as anchors, optimizing them successively. Recent advancements complement or replace these random queries with detections from auxiliary networks. We propose a more intuitive and efficient approach by using BEV feature cells directly as anchors. This end-to-end approach leverages the dense grid of BEV queries, considering each cell as a potential object for the final detection task. As a result, we introduce a novel two-stage anchor generation method specifically designed for multi-camera 3D object detection. To address the scaling issues of attention with a large number of queries, we apply BEV-based Non-Maximum Suppression, allowing gradients to flow only through non-suppressed objects. This ensures efficient training without the need for post-processing. By using BEV features from encoders such as BEVFormer directly as object queries, temporal BEV information is inherently embedded. Building on the temporal BEV information already embedded in our object queries, we introduce a hybrid temporal modeling approach by integrating prior detections to further enhance detection performance. Evaluating our method on the nuScenes dataset shows consistent and significant improvements in NDS and mAP over the baseline, even with sparser BEV grids and therefore fewer initial anchors. It is particularly effective for small objects, enhancing pedestrian detection with a 3.8% mAP increase on nuScenes and an 8% increase in LET-mAP on Waymo. Applying our method, named DenseBEV, to the challenging Waymo Open dataset yields state-of-the-art performance, achieving a LET-mAP of 60.7%, surpassing the previous best by 5.4%. Code is available at https://github.com/mdaehl/DenseBEV.

title: Exponential plateaus and inflation in metric-affine gravity
authors: Antonio Racioppi
abstract: We propose a new mechanism for inflationary model building in the framework of metric-affine gravity. Such a mechanism involves an inflaton non-minimally coupled with the Holst invariant. If the non-minimal coupling function has a zero point and it is very steep at that same point, then the canonically normalized inflaton potential always features an exponential plateau, regardless of the shape of the original inflaton potential. The inflationary predictions in such a region are equivalent to the ones of Starobinsky inflation.

title: A short introduction to boundary symmetries
authors: Simone Speziale
abstract: Support material for lectures at the Mai '25 Galileo Galilei Institute school on asymptotic symmetries and flat holography. Contains an introduction to Noether theorem for gauge theories and gravity, covariant phase space formalism, boundary and asymptotic symmetries, future null infinity in Bondi-Sachs coordinates and in Penrose conformal compactification, BMS symmetries and their charges and fluxes. Includes an original and pedagogical derivation of the BMS group using only Minkowski, and an original derivation of an integral Hamiltonian generator for a scalar field on a null hypersurface.

title: Exfoliation and Cleavage of Crystals from a Universal Potential
authors: Tom Barnowsky, Carsten Timm, Rico Friedrich
abstract: Exfoliation and cleavage create two-dimensional (2D) materials and surfaces with physical and chemical properties distinct from their bulk parents. The rising class of non-van der Waals (non-vdW) 2D materials derived from non-layered crystals provides a fascinating new platform - greatly expanding the landscape of low-dimensional materials. Current computational models, however, provide limited guidance: existing descriptors are largely tailored to vdW layered systems. Here, we introduce a general framework predicting crystal cleavage and exfoliable 2D subunits directly from bulk structures. At its core is a universal eXfoliation and Cleavage Potential (XCP) enabling large-scale screening of diverse materials at negligible computational cost. Applying this approach, we obtain 37,208 cleavable surfaces and candidate non-vdW 2D materials from which we investigate 2,377 likely exfoliable ones using high-throughput density functional theory. We identify sheets with square and rectangular lattices, semiconducting systems exhibiting an indirect-to-direct band-gap transition upon exfoliation, and first non-vdW 2D metals. Our study thus opens a systematic route to explore and design new 2D materials with unprecedented chemical and structural diversity.

title: Landscape Analysis of Excited States Calculation over Quantum Computers
authors: Hengzhun Chen, Yingzhou Li, Bichen Lu, Jianfeng Lu
abstract: The variational quantum eigensolver (VQE) is one of the most promising algorithms for low-lying eigenstates calculation on Noisy Intermediate-Scale Quantum (NISQ) computers. Specifically, VQE has achieved great success for ground state calculations of a Hamiltonian. However, excited state calculations arising in quantum chemistry and condensed matter often requires solving more challenging problems than the ground state as these states are generally further away from a mean-field description, and involve less straightforward optimization to avoid the variational collapse to the ground state. Maintaining orthogonality between low-lying eigenstates is a key algorithmic hurdle. In this work, we analyze three VQE models that embed orthogonality constraints through specially designed cost functions, avoiding the need for external enforcement of orthogonality between states. Notably, these formulations possess the desirable property that any local minimum is also a global minimum, helping address optimization difficulties. We conduct rigorous landscape analyses of the models' stationary points and local minimizers, theoretically guaranteeing their favorable properties and providing analytical tools applicable to broader VQE methods. A comprehensive comparison between the three models is also provided, considering their quantum resource requirements and classical optimization complexity.

title: Numerical reconstruction of Schrödinger equations with quadratic nonlinearities
authors: Khaoula El Maddah, Matti Lassas, Teemu Tyni
abstract: We introduce a numerical framework for reconstructing the potential in two dimensional semilinear elliptic PDEs with power type nonlinearities from the nonlinear Dirichlet to Neumann map. By applying higher order linearization method, we compute the Fourier data of the unknown potential and then invert it to recover $q$. Numerical experiments show accurate reconstructions for both smooth and discontinuous test cases.

title: Online Resource Allocation via Static Bundle Pricing
authors: Dimitris Fotakis, Charalampos Platanos, Thanos Tolias
abstract: Online Resource Allocation addresses the problem of efficiently allocating limited resources to buyers with incomplete knowledge of future requests. In our setting, buyers arrive sequentially demanding a set of items, each with a value drawn from a known distribution. We study environments where buyers' valuations exhibit complementarities. In such settings, standard item-pricing mechanisms fail to leverage item multiplicities, while existing static bundle-pricing mechanisms rely on problem-specific arguments that do not generalize. We develop a unified technique for online resource allocation with complementarities for three domains: (i) single-minded combinatorial auctions with maximum bundle size $d$, (ii) general single-minded combinatorial auctions, and (iii) a graph-based routing model in which buyers request to route a unit of flow from a source node $s$ to a target node $t$ in a capacitated graph. Our approach yields static and anonymous bundle-pricing mechanisms whose performance improves exponentially with item capacities. For the $d$-single-minded setting with minimum item capacity $B$, we obtain an $O(d^{1/B})$-competitive mechanism, recovering the known $O(d)$ bound for unit capacities ($B=1$) and achieving exponentially better guarantees as capacities grow. For general single-minded combinatorial auctions and the graph-routing model, we obtain $O(m^{1/(B+1)})$-competitive mechanisms, where $m$ is the number of items. We complement these results with information-theoretic lower bounds. We show that no online algorithm can achieve a competitive ratio better than $Ω((m/\ln m)^{1/(B+2)})$ in the general single-minded setting and $Ω((d/\ln d)^{1/(B+1)})$ in the $d$-single-minded setting. In doing so, we reveal a deep connection to the extremal combinatorics problem of determining the maximum number of qualitatively independent partitions of a ground set.

title: Global universal approximation with Brownian signatures
authors: Mihriban Ceylan, David J. Prömel
abstract: We establish $L^p$-type universal approximation theorems for general and non-anticipative functionals on suitable rough path spaces, showing that linear functionals acting on signatures of time-extended rough paths are dense with respect to an $L^p$-distance. To that end, we derive global universal approximation theorems for weighted rough path spaces. We demonstrate that these $L^p$-type universal approximation theorems apply in particular to Brownian motion. As a consequence, linear functionals on the signature of the time-extended Brownian motion can approximate any $p$-integrable stochastic process adapted to the Brownian filtration, including solutions to stochastic differential equations.

title: Feedback Cooling and Thermometry of a Single Trapped Ion Using a Knife Edge
authors: Hans Dang, Sebastian Luff, Martin Fischer, Markus Sondermann, Gerd Leuchs
abstract: We report on the first feedback cooling of a single trapped ion below the Doppler limit of $\hbarΓ/2 k_\mathrm{B}$. The motion of a single ion is monitored in real-time and cooled up to 9-times below the Doppler cooling temperature by applying electronic feedback. Real-time motion detection is implemented by imaging the fluorescence photons emitted by the ion onto a knife edge and detecting the transmitted light, a method used so far to cool trapped nanoparticles. The intensity modulation of the fluorescence resulting from the ion motion is used to generate and apply the feedback signal and also to determine the ion temperature. The method benefits from a high rate of detected scattered photons, which can be a challenge, and which we address by using a parabolic mirror for collecting the fluorescence.

title: Expanding Horizons - Transforming Astronomy in the 2040s Time-Domain Multi-Messenger Astronomy in the 2040s: EM Follow-up of LGWA Sources
authors: F. Patat, S. Piranomonte, S. Benetti, A. Bonforte, R. Della Ceca, G. Di Rico, A. Frigeri, J. Harms, M. Olivieri, A. Perali, P. Severgnini, A. Stallone, the LGWA Collaboration
abstract: The coming decades will see gravitational-wave (GW) astronomy expand decisively into the mHz-Hz frequency range, opening access to a population of compact binaries that are currently invisible or only detectable moments before merger. The Lunar Gravitational Wave Antenna (LGWA) concept is designed to probe this gap, enabling continuous observation of compact binaries over months to years prior to coalescence, and detecting sources inaccessible to both space-based mHz detectors and current ground-based >10 Hz facilities. This new GW window fundamentally alters the landscape of time-domain multi-messenger astronomy. Rather than reacting to mergers after the fact, LGWA enables predictive, scheduled electromagnetic (EM) follow-up, transforming how compact-object mergers, their environments, and their astrophysical channels are studied. However, fully exploiting LGWA discoveries requires EM capabilities that do not exist today and are unlikely to be available by the 2030s, particularly for wide-area, rapid, spectroscopically rich follow-up at optical and near-infrared wavelengths. This White Paper identifies the key science cases enabled by LGWA that motivate new ground-based capabilities in the 2040s.

title: Performance Evaluation of DOI Capable Dual Layer Detector for a Dedicated Breast PET/MRI Insert
authors: L. U. Rauscher, M. Judenhofer, J. Hohnholz, I. Zaubitzer, E. Olyaei, H. P. Vo, M. Rafecas, B. Pichler, F. P. Schmidt
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Our group develops a PET/MRI insert for enhanced breast imaging with a 3T clinical whole-body PET/MRI scanner. The small-bore diameter of 175 mm is susceptible to parallax errors, resulting in variable spatial resolution across the field of view. To mitigate this effect, we designed a depth-of-interaction capable PET detector based on a clinical detector platform. The detector employs a 4×4 SiPM array coupled to a stacked crystal block design (crystal pitch 1.6 mm) with ESR reflector. The top and bottom layer consist of 9×9 (length 5.2 mm) and 10×10 (9.8 mm) crystals. Point sources containing Ba-133 (356 keV), Na-22 (511 keV) and Cs-137 (667 keV) were used to obtain floodmaps and energy spectra. Timing performance of the detectors was assessed with a centered Na-22 point source between two aligned detectors facing each other. Furthermore, we centered a point-like volume of F-18 (207.8 MBq) with a distance of 100 mm to each detector to assess stability with respect to count rate by performing measurements at different time points. The detector showed a good crystal identification capability with a peak-to-valley ratio of 3.54 | 3.44 (x | y direction) and an energy resolution of 12.9 | 13.0 % (top | bottom). Comparison of the photopeak positions showed high linearity beyond 511 keV, with R2 values of the corresponding linear fits ≥ 0.997. The block-to-block timing resolution was 310 ps without any correction applied. The performance metrics remained stable for count rates beyond 300 kcps with standard deviations below 0.21 %, 2.5 keV and 13.5 ps for energy resolution, peak position and CTR, respectively. These preliminary evaluations demonstrate the suitability of the clinical detector platform for its use with small crystals in complex configurations for the breast PET/MRI insert. Current work focuses on optimization of operational parameters and implementing corrections to further improve the performance.

title: Estimating Proton Stopping Power and Range with Photon-Counting Computed Tomography
authors: K. Larsson, T. Näsmark, J. Andersson, M. Persson
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Proton therapy for cancer is believed to offer improved dose precision and sparing of normal tissue due to the dosimetric properties and the Bragg peak. Estimation of accurate proton stopping power ratios (SPR) is a prerequisite for minimizing range uncertainty and treatment margins. Photon-counting computed tomography (PCCT) can provide more information on the composition of patient tissues, which may improve the SPR and range estimation accuracy. With more than two independent energy measurements, it is possible to decompose a tissue into multiple basis materials and thereby reduce the bias in the tissue model. On the other hand, estimating more independent components from the same data is expected to increase noise. This work aims to investigate the trade-off between bias reduction and noise increase in SPR estimates resulting from higher dimensionalities in material decomposition with PCCT. Using Cramér-Rao Lower Bound, the basis image noise is estimated and propagated to SPR level for 1,2,3, and 4 basis materials. The SPR bias is also evaluated. SPR image volumes corresponding to the calculated statistics are generated for range simulation in RayStation. For the proton energy and test tissue example in this work, the optimal dimensionality for SPR and range is concluded to be 2. The expected accumulation of systematic error and simultaneous averaging of random error in the particle transport suggests that a higher dimensionality may be optimal at greater tissue depths.

title: Thermal Stability Analysis of Energy Response in Timepix4 Detector
authors: P. Burian, O. Ruzicka, M. Farkas, P. Smolyanskiy
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper presents an experimental study of the temperature dependence of energy calibration in a Timepix4-based hybrid pixel detector with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$300 \sim \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> silicon sensor. The detector was exposed to a controlled thermal environment ranging from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-10 \sim^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$+50 \sim^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex>, and irradiated with an Am-241 source and X-ray fluorescence targets to evaluate the stability of its energy response. The measurements show a pronounced and repeatable shift in peak positions with temperature, most notably a gradient of approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-0.17 \sim \text{keV} /{ }^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> for single-pixel gamma events at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$59.54 \sim \text{keV}$</tex>. The observed variations are attributed to temperature-induced changes in the analog front-end operating points and threshold levels. These results confirm that energy calibration in Timepix4 detectors is sensitive to temperature and emphasize the need for correction strategies in applications requiring stable spectroscopic performance under varying thermal conditions.

title: Quantitative SPECT Imaging of the Alpha-Emitter ${ }^{225}$ Ac in Hepatocellular Carcinoma
authors: X. Luo, B. He, J. R. Nedrow, R. Krimins, A. G. Cortez, E. Frey, Y. Du
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Hepatocellular carcinoma is the most common primary liver cancer and the fifth most frequently diagnosed malignancy worldwide. Advanced-stage presentation in most patients restricts management to non-surgical palliative therapies. Alpha-emitter radiopharmaceutical therapy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha$</tex> RPT) has emerged as a highly effective targeted therapy for liver cancer. Accurate quantification of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha \text{RPT}$</tex> in vivo remains a major hurdle for dosimetry optimization. In this study, we evaluated a quantitative reconstruction framework, QSPECT for simultaneous quantitative SPECT/CT imaging of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{225} \text{Ac}$</tex> and its daughter radionuclides in an orthotopic rabbit VX2 liver tumor model. Longitudinal SPECT/CT data were acquired at 24, 72, and 144 h post-injection using an energy window centered at 218 keV for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{221} \text{Fr}$</tex> and 440 keV for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{213} \text{Bi}$</tex>. QSPECT reconstruction substantially reduced contamination from scatter and crosstalk compared to Siemens Flash3D OSEM and increased lesion contrast. QSPECT also yielded higher tumor-to-liver and tumor-to-kidney ratios at each time point. We also observed that the tumor-to-liver and tumor-to-kidney ratio for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{221} \text{Fr}$</tex> consistently exceeded that of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{213} \text{Bi}$</tex>, which reflects differences in kinetics between the parent and long half-life daughter radionuclides. These findings highlight the critical role of quantitative SPECT imaging for accurately characterizing both parent and daughter radionuclide distributions.

title: An Empirical Method of Effective Atomic Number Estimation for Dual-Energy X-Ray System
authors: H. Jo, C. Oh, S. Cho
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In this paper, an empirical method of effective atomic number estimation for dual-energy x-ray system is proposed. The proposed method calibrates a mathematical model that calculates the effective atomic number of scanned objects from the physical quantities in the acquired dualenergy x-ray images. In this study, R -value, which is the ratio of high-energy attenuation coefficient to the low-energy attenuation coefficient was used as the physical quantity for the effective atomic number estimation. Based on the dominant photon interactions and their relationships between the effective atomic number, the calibration coefficients for the mathematical model were found. In order to handle the beam hardening effect, a process called thickness binning was conducted. The test of the proposed method was done upon dual-energy xray images acquired using real inspection system. As a result, the proposed method accurately estimated the effective atomic numbers of the objects with arbitrary shapes with small percent differences. The image of the estimated effective atomic number and corresponding pseudocolorized image are given in the paper. We expect the application of the proposed method expands to other various forms of inspection systems.

title: Prediction of Tumour Hypoxia by Range-verification PET in Particle Therapy: Proof-Concept in Rats
authors: C. Toramatsu, H. Wakizaka, H. Tashima, H. Sudo, G. Akamatsu, T. Ishikawa, H.G. Kang, C. Seki, I. Kanno, T. Yamaya
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Tumour hypoxia, highly influenced by tumour vasculature status, has an important implication for tumour response to radiation therapy. While tumour hypoxia status is changing during a treatment period, hypoxia PET is impractical to perform in every fractionated irradiation. On the other hand, there is a chance to extract tumour hypoxia information from the biological washout in range-verification PET, by detecting irradiation-produced positron (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\beta^{+}$</tex>)-emitting nuclides. However, it is not clear whether the blood flow supply and washout can reflect the tumour oxygen status. Therefore, this study aimed at obtaining conclusive evidence in hypoxic tumour rat models by comparing results for range-verification PET and hypoxia PET. Glioma C6 cancer cells were transplanted into nude rats. Tumours were irradiated with a <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">12</sup>C ion beam, and range-verification PET was performed by a high sensitivity total-body small-animal PET system. Then the rats underwent PET imaging with a hypoxia tracer, <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">18</sup> F-FAZA, for tumour diagnosis. The parametric maps of washout rate obtained with range-verification PET were in good agreement with <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">18</sup>F -FAZA-PET images. This study demonstrated the biological washout-based diagnosis for tumour hypoxia in routine range-verification PET.

title: Dynamic Criticality Estimation for Fuel Debris Removal at Fukushima-Daiichi
authors: C. Kostelac, G. McKenzie, R. Weldon, N. Whitman, J. Hutchinson
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: During future fuel debris removal at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant (1F), the movement of fuel, structural materials, and water will affect the criticality of the melted cores. Inadvertent re-criticality events are undesirable, as they can produce bursts of radiation hazardous to personnel and equipment, and generate additional fission products. To address this, we assess the use of neutron noise measurements to estimate the time-dependent criticality of a subcritical system undergoing reactivity perturbations. Using a water-moderated, UO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> fueled critical assembly, we experimentally demonstrate that certain events-such as flooding-can significantly increase system criticality while simultaneously reducing the neutron count rate at a detector. Neutron noise measurements were conducted with varying numbers of fuel rods during water filling and dumping cycles. Our results highlight the limitations of relying solely on gross neutron count rates to assess criticality, and demonstrate the feasibility of performing neutron noise diagnostics in dynamic, time-varying conditions with changing detector efficiency.

title: Performance Characterization of a Compton Camera Prototype Based on a Novel Epitaxial-Quenching-Resistor SiPM
authors: C. Li, Z. Yuan, H. Wang, R. Liao, J. Hua, Y. Hou, W. Hu, D. Han, J. Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: A Compton camera prototype was developed and characterized, utilizing a novel epitaxial-quenching-resistor Silicon Photomultiplier (EQR SiPM). The SiPM, with dimensions of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.75 \times 3.55 \text{mm}^{2}$</tex> and an effective area of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.00 \times 3.00 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>, was configured into a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \times 6$</tex> array. The array, with horizontal and vertical spacings of 0.58 mm and 0.82 mm respectively, formed a total size of 25.4 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\times 25.4 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>. Both the scatterer and absorber were constructed from identical Lutetium-yttrium oxyorthosilicate (LYSO) crystal arrays, each comprising <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$24 \times 24$</tex> crystals with dimensions of 0.98 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\times 0.98 \times 10 ~\text{mm}^{3}$</tex> in 1.0 mm pitch. Coincidence events were acquired using an 8-channel data acquisition card (DAQ). Image reconstruction was performed using a filtered back-projection (FBP) algorithm with a Shepp-Logan filter, optimized for multi-graphics processing units (GPUs) processing. Calibration results demonstrated an energy resolution (Full Width at Half Maximum, FWHM) of 11.89 % at 662 keV. Imaging experiments with a point source yielded an angular resolution of 8.95° (FWHM) at a scatterer-to-absorber distance of 50 mm. Additionally, successful imaging of a V-shaped tubing phantom confirmed the system's ability to accurately image distributed sources. Future work will focus on optimizing the system design, including studying the effects of temperature and bias on SiPM gain, to enhance the camera's performance for various applications.

title: Measuring $3 \gamma$ Ortho-Positronium Decay in a Long-Axial FOV PET/CT Scanner
authors: W. M. Steinberger, Y. Zheng, J. Cabello, J. Breuer
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Positronium (Ps) lifetime imaging has the potential to add additional diagnostic information to clinical positron emission tomography (PET) scans because Ps lifetimes depend on the chemical composition and void structure of the surrounding material. Measuring these lifetimes directly requires an isotope that emits a prompt gamma ray, which greatly limits the potential application since the vast majority of PET scans use <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{18} ~\mathrm{F}$</tex> as the radiotracer. Ortho-Ps (o-Ps), however, can be directly measured by its characteristic decay into three photons <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(3 \gamma)$</tex>. These <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \gamma$</tex> decay rates can be used to infer the o-Ps lifetime and extract the same chemical information. This work details results from Ps measurements performed in a long-axial field of view PET/CT scanner using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{22} \text{Na}$</tex> positron sources and the following materials: quartz glass, polycarbonate and aluminum. A methodology was developed for classifying <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \gamma$</tex> events from o-Ps and results presented show a direct correlation between the measured o-Ps count rate and the o-Ps lifetime of the corresponding material.

title: Simulation and Experimental Studies of Charge Transport Modeling in Gaas:Cr Photon Counting Detector
authors: T. Zhong, H. Li, B. Wang, Y. Yang, X. Lai
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Gallium arsenide compensated with chromium (GaAs:Cr) has emerged as a promising material for radiation detection due to its high electron mobility, resistivity, and stopping power. However, detector performance is limited by intrinsic defects such as the EL2 trap, which captures electrons under non-equilibrium conditions and distorts the electric field. This study establishes a comprehensive charge transport model for GaAs:Cr detectors, incorporating carrier dynamics, defect trapping, and boundary conditions. The model is employed to simulate detector response under varying temperatures (270-300 K) and illumination conditions (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$640 ~\text{nm}, 1 \mu ~\mathrm{W} / \text{cm}^{\wedge} 2$</tex>), revealing temperature-dependent transient behaviors. For experimental validation, trap energy levels and capture cross-sections are characterized via photo-induced current transient spectroscopy (PICTS), while carrier mobility-lifetime products are measured by time-of-flight (ToF). We will establish a quantitative relationship between current distortion mechanisms and defect-related trapping effects.

title: Radiation Imaging and Spectral Response of SiC-Timepix3 Detector to Sensor Bias
authors: A. Sagatova, M. Balusik, S. Stryckova, C. Granja, T. Slavicek, M.B. Mosbah, A. Lyoussi, N. Kurucova, E. Kovacova, B. Zatko
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Semiconductor hybrid pixel detectors have found applications in many fields like biomedical imaging, material analysis and space weather monitoring. Their ability of particle tracking enables analysis of mixed radiation fields useful around accelerators and fusion or fission reactors. These harsh environments require hard materials. The SiC is very perspective semiconductor material providing high radiation hardness and wide temperature operation. The first hybrid pixel detector with SiC sensor, the SiC-Timepix3 detector, was prepared in 2022 [1]. There, the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$80 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> thick epitaxial layer of 4 H - (four-hexagonal polytype) SiC on <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$350 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> thick substrate creates detector sensitive layer. The 4 H-SiC sensor pixelated structure of Schottky electrodes bump-bonded to Timepix3 read-out chip create the depletion regions defining individual detection zones. Their depths increase with reverse biasing of the structure through Timepix3 chip adjusting the active thickness of sensitive epitaxial layer. The capacitance-voltage measurement on single diode detectors from the same 4 H-SiC material have revealed the exact penetration depth of depletion region with applied reverse bias. Half of the layer is depleted with −55 V, for full depletion −220 V is needed. In this paper we examine the detector spectral response to fast neutrons and gamma rays at different detector biasing. The detection efficiency of the 14 MeV neutrons from D-T neutron generator and gamma and X-rays from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{241} \text{Am}$</tex> with SiC-Timepix3 detector biased to various reverse voltages was in agreement with responsible active thicknesses calculated from capacitance measurements. Moreover, the ability of Timepix detector to make spectral particle tracking [2] was utilized to filter events corresponding to the neutron interaction with the SiC material.

title: Spectrum Estimation from Transmission Measurements of Inverse Compton Scattering Gamma Rays Based on a Modified Expectation Maximization Method
authors: J. Lin, H. Ding, H. Zhang, X. Zhang, Z. Zhang, Z. Chi, Y. Du, C. Tang
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The energy spectrum estimation of an inverse Compton scattering (ICS) source is not only a key indicator for assessing whether the system is operating normally, but also serves as the foundation for further application studies. Spectrum estimation from transmission measurements using the expectation maximization (EM) method has been widely applied for X-ray spectra or Bremsstrahlung spectra. However, for quasi-monochromatic gamma ray spectra of ICS sources, the low rate of change in the attenuation coefficients of materials causes the traditional EM method to converge too slowly, making it ineffective for spectrum reconstruction. We proposed a modified EM method that significantly accelerated the convergence rate. The energy spectra of an ICS gamma ray source were obtained using Monte Carlo simulations. Numerical simulations were carried out to test the feasibility of estimating quasi-monochromatic spectra with mean energies of 530 keV (energy spread of 1.1 %) and 2853 keV (energy spread of 1.28 %) under various measurement error conditions. The results demonstrated that the modified EM method can provide better approximations of quasi-monochromatic gamma ray spectra with fewer iterations than the traditional EM method, but the transmission measurement accuracy were required to reach 10-4 and 10-5 respectively.

title: A Novel Rotational Torque Measuring Method Based on Double-Micro-Indentation-Shaft Sensed by Optical Coherent System
authors: Xiaodong Hong, Wei Liang, Dichang Huang, Zhenting Xu, Qiukun Zhang, Jiewen Lin, Shuncong Zhong, Tao Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: As industrialization advances and the global push for carbon neutrality intensifies, enhancing the efficiency of mechanical equipment has become essential. Accurate measurement of rotational torque plays a crucial role in monitoring efficiency and ensuring optimal performance. This paper presents a novel, non-contact measurement technique based on optical coherent displacement, integrating dual-optical-detector probes for simultaneous rotational torque and speed measurement. A sensing model that links optical coherent signals to change in rotational torque and rotational speed is established. Experiment demonstrates high accuracy of the system, with rotational speed error ranging from 0.25 % to 0.67 %, and rotational torque indication error between 0.03 % and 2.25 %. Furthermore, the experiments proved that the repeatability error is less than 1%, the hysteresis error is less than 1.6%, and the linearity error is in the range of 0.24%~0.57% for rotational torque measurement. The research further evaluates the influence of rotational speed on rotational torque measurement accuracy, revealing minimal impact at higher speeds. The findings suggest that the proposed method offers significant potential for precision measurement in rotating machinery, enabling the simultaneous measurement of both torque and rotational speed. This capability has important implications for improving system efficiency and supporting sustainable industrial practices.

title: Series Arc Fault Detection in Building Distribution Systems: Physics-Guided Feature Extraction and Entropy-Enhanced Weighted Decision Tree
authors: Zhipeng He, Hu Zhao, Da Li, Weilin Li, Zhongzheng Zhou
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Series arc fault (SAF) detection is crucial for mitigating electrical fires in building distribution systems and ensuring occupant and property safety. However, existing methods can only detect SAFs in limited or idealized scenarios, often suffering from false alarms and missed detections in more complex real-world systems. To address these issues, this article proposes a novel SAF detection method combining physics-guided feature extraction with an entropy-enhanced weighted decision tree. First, an experimental platform simulating SAFs in building distribution systems is constructed, and the effectiveness of the zero-sequence current coupling signal (ZSCCS) as a detection signal is verified through systematic analysis and comparison. Second, qualitative characteristics of pulses—including positional distribution, amplitude trends, and occurrence frequency—are analyzed, while theoretical correlations between arcing processes and ZSCCS waveform variations are established through RLC-based circuit modeling. Third, four time-frequency domain features are extracted to quantify fault characteristics in ZSCCS, and a detection algorithm is designed based on these features, an entropy-enhanced weighted decision tree, and arc fault decision criteria. Finally, the method’s effectiveness is validated through both offline and online experiments, as well as anti-interference tests. The results show that the proposed method achieves 98.91% detection accuracy (24 960 samples) under complex scenarios involving thirteen loads, four circuit topologies, and two arcgenerating modes, outperforming existing methods. Furthermore, it has been implemented in a self-developed arc fault detection device, demonstrating its potential for engineering applications in building distribution systems.

title: Positioning with LEO Satellites as Signals of Opportunity (SoOP): a Survey
authors: Peng Liu, Honglei Qin, Jun Lu, Ran Liu, Yong Liang Guan, Keck Voon Ling, Chau Yuen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Positioning is a critical service for modern societies, supporting many sectors including transportation, logistics, and agriculture. As reliance on accurate positioning continues to grow, the vulnerabilities of Global Navigation Satellite Systems (GNSS) to jamming and spoofing pose significant concerns. The Low Earth Orbit (LEO) satellite with high velocity and signal power is a robust and independent alternative. LEO communication signals are regarded as Signals of OPportunity (SoOP) for positioning. LEO SoOP positioning has flourished recently. This survey offers a comprehensive overview of the LEO SoOP positioning, presenting an in-depth review of the current literature. It evaluates the whole process of LEO SoOP positioning, including LEO constellations, instruments, signal processing, measurement sources, error corrections, positioning algorithms, and performance analysis. Furthermore, the survey explores the state-of-the-art strategies to improve positioning performance, such as multi-epoch Integration, multi-constellation combination, base station auxiliary, and multi-sensor fusion. Finally, it outlines challenges and future research.

title: Impact of System Matrix Model Accuracy in Fast TOF-PET Reconstruction
authors: T. Merlin, D. Visvikis
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Time-of-Flight positron emission tomography (TOF-PET) has seen substantial advancements over the past decade, largely driven by improvements in detector technology. These next-generation detector designs necessitate adaptations to iterative tomographic reconstruction algorithms in order to fully capitalize on the enhanced information they provide, such as the need for more accurate TOF kernel models. In this work, we investigate the impact of the accuracy of the system matrix model on TOF-PET image reconstruction performance, particularly in the context of systems with fast coincidence time resolution. Monte-Carlo simulations of a Jaszczack digital phantoms were performed to generate datasets with time-of-flight resolution varying from 250 ps to 50ps. TOF-OSEM reconstruction of these datasets were performed using system matrix model of varying accuracy, including Siddon and Joseph projectors, a uniform multi-lines projector, and a multi-lines projector including intra/inter crystal penetration and scattering effects. Qualitative and quantitative evaluation of the reconstructed images were subsequently conducted. The CRC versus noise trade-off indicates that, although improved timing resolution reduces image noise, it is also associated with a noticeable decline in contrast recovery. However, this degradation is mitigated when employing the most accurate projector models evaluated in this study. Consistent trends were also observed in the qualitative analysis of the rod section and in the resolution recovery measurements These results indicate that integrating more accurate projectors into the system matrix allow to fully leverage the benefits of enhanced timing information in fast TOF PET iterative reconstruction. Future work will investigate the influence of various TOF kernel models and evaluate the reconstruction performance for datasets comprising events with mixed timing resolutions.

title: Development of Super-MuSR's 960 Channel SiPM Detector Barrel
authors: D. Pooley, A. Abba, F. Akeroyd, P. Baker, F. Caponio, Z. Clark, P. Coode, S. Cottrell, A. Cusimano, J. Day, C. Evans, L. Galvin, A. Hillier, S. Howarth, A. Jones, D. Kirk, A. Lim, J. Lord, C. Macwaters, M. Moffat, D. Nixon, G. Olaofe, W. Perry, J. Preston, J. Prince, N. Rhodes, E. Schooneveld, G. Smith, R. Stewart, Z. Tam, D. Templeman, F. Zuddas
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Super-MuSR is a muon-spin spectrometer currently being built at the ISIS pulsed source in the UK and due for completion in 2027. This paper describes the development of the SiPM detector system; a pair of compact barrels containing 480 channels each, approximately half a meter long. The detector barrels are located inside a Helmholtz coil set, which can supply a magnetic field up to 0.65 T at the centre of the 350 mm bore. Signal characteristics, operational stability, environmental noise immunity and EMI isolation from RF sources have been experimentally investigated. These results will be presented alongside the instrument specification and the design optimisation process required. Optimisations include the use of a novel scintillator and wavelength shifting fiber geometry giving rise to the modular design of the optical front end. Selection of ESR as the reflector encapsulating the EJ204 scintillator and the coupling mechanism to the 1920 HAMAMATSU S13360-1325 SiPMs. The front-end electronics individually bias each SiPM, allowing them to be gain-matched and summed pairwise without distorting the pulse-height spectra and compromising the quality of our signal discrimination methods. Performance results from the first fully assembled barrel staves will be shown, along with technical insight into the practicalities of building and delivering such an instrument.

title: Integration of TlBr to a TimePix-3 Chip for Direct X-Ray Imaging
authors: J. F. Christian, M. S. Squillante, M. J. Breen, O. Maksimov, H. Kim, E. R. Weststrate, M. Dallimore, G. Pinaroli, A. S. Tremsin, M. R. Squillante, V. V. Nagarkar
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The direct detection of X-rays by semiconductors converts X-ray energy directly into electronic charge, avoiding potential limitations associated with light spreading in scintillation materials to provide potentially higher resolution with dense, high-Z material. Integrating the detector material with the imaging readout circuit poses a challenge for flip-chip bonding particularly for small pixel sizes and large pixel count arrays. Consequently, alternate methodologies to couple semiconductors to read out chips may prove attractive. In this paper, we present results on thallium bromide (TlBr), single and poly-crystalline films, coupled to the TimePix-3 (TPX3) readout chip connected to a readout system. The TPX3 chip provides an array of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$256 \times 256$</tex> pixels with a pixel area of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$55 \mu ~\mathrm{m} \times 55 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> for photon-counting of X-rays, or light pulses, with the conversion layer. This work compares characteristics of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 1-\text{mm}$</tex> thick single-crystal TlBr to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 0.4-\text{mm}$</tex> thick polycrystalline films grown with physical vapor deposition. A poly-imide polymer attaches the single-crystal TlBr to the readout chip, while a direct vapor deposition process grows the polycrystalline film on to the readout chip with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20-\text{nm}$</tex> thick ZnTe barrier layer. Neither approach requires precise alignment, and the growth of the polycrystalline film can be scaled to 2 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\times 2$</tex> arrays of TimePix3 chips. The resistivity of the single crystal is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>10^{10} \Omega \cdot ~\text{cm}$</tex> while that of the polycrystalline films is typically <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>10^{8} \Omega \cdot ~\text{cm}$</tex>. A top ITO contact enables the characterization of test devices with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$375-\text{nm}$</tex> light-emitting diode (LED) illumination. The interface layer currently limits the uniformity of the images from the single crystal devices; however, it successfully images the shadow cast by a tungsten rod irradiated with Am-241. The leakage current appears to dominate the images from the polycrystalline devices.

title: Development of Particle Flow Algorithm with GNN for the Future Higgs Factories
authors: T. Murata, T. Suehara
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper describes the development of a particle reconstruction method using deep learning techniques based on graph neural networks, specifically employing the GravNet architecture and object condensation, for application in future electron-positron collider experiments focused on precision Higgs boson measurements. Traditional pattern recognition methods used in particle flow reconstruction are limited by manual parameter tuning and rigid logic structures, which constrain their ability to handle complex detector responses and to integrate new types of input, such as fine timing information. In this study, we propose a deep learning model that simultaneously performs clustering and energy estimation of particles by learning geometric relationships among detector hits. The network takes as input the position and energy deposition of calorimeter hits and the momentum of charged particle tracks, and maps each hit to a latent point in an abstract coordinate space, enabling hit-level clustering through a learned condensation process. Charged particle tracks are incorporated as fixed reference points to guide the clustering and ensure proper separation of overlapping particle showers. The method is evaluated using simulated data from the International Large Detector concept, including tau lepton decays at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \sim \text{GeV}$</tex> and quark jets at the Z boson mass energy. Quantitative comparisons with a widely used conventional method show that the proposed approach yields comparable or improved clustering accuracy for major particle species, particularly for charged pions, which are the dominant component of jets. Energy estimation for charged particles is accurate, whereas neutral particle estimates remain more sensitive to clustering precision. Overall, the method demonstrates the effectiveness of graph-based deep learning in processing high-granularity detector data and motivates further development toward high-resolution jet energy reconstruction in collider environments.

title: High Spatial Resolution Microcapillary Plate-Organic Glass Scintillator Detectors for Nuclear Physics Applications
authors: A. Datta, A. L. Benin, S. Dhole, J. Fiala, P. Feng, S. Motakef
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper presents the development of high spatial resolution scintillator radiation detectors based on microcapillaries embedded with organic glass scintillators (OGS) for nuclear physics experiments and imaging applications. These detectors offer spatial resolution down to tens of micrometers combined with ultrafast timing response (>2ns) and excellent energy resolution. We demonstrate a novel fabrication technique that achieves uniform and crack-free incorporation of OGS in microcapillaries with diameters as small as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex>. Fluorescence imaging confirms effective optical confinement within individual microcapillaries, preserving the high spatial resolution of the capillary structure. Beta particle tracking experiments using 90Sr sources with different collimation configurations validate the detector's ability to resolve spatial details effectively. Additionally, a high spatial resolution Hamamatsu S13552 SiPM array ( <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$230 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> pitch) was employed to simultaneously acquire position, energy, and timing information from OGS sensors, demonstrating its potential for particle tracking in high luminosity nuclear physics experiments. Pulse shape discrimination capabilities with a figure of merit of 2.8 further enhance particle identification. These detectors present significant advantages over current technologies in terms of radiation hardness, timing resolution, and scalability, making them promising candidates for next-generation nuclear physics tracking detectors and beam monitoring applications.

title: Enhanced Detection of Low-Observable Maneuvering Targets Based on FDGRFT and Lévy Golden Sparrow Search Algorithm
authors: Yuxian Sun, Quanhua Liu, Yuanshuai Li, Ziming Zheng, Shaoqiang Chang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Low-observable maneuvering targets significantly challenge radar detection due to their low radar cross-section (RCS) and high maneuverability. Within the dechirp-receiving radar system, the conventional dechirp generalized Radon-Fourier transform (DGRFT) method can measure the motion parameters of low-observable maneuvering targets through grid-based matching, which imposes a substantial computational burden. Moreover, this method performs suboptimally when the actual motion parameters deviate significantly from the discrete grid points. To overcome these limitations, this article first introduces a novel frequency-domain formulation, termed fast-frequency DGRFT (FDGRFT), which achieves computational reduction by deriving an efficient frequency-domain filter bank structure for parameter measurement. Furthermore, to address the suboptimal performance of grid-based DGRFT for off-grid parameters and the limitations of prior optimization attempts, a newly developed metaheuristic, the Lévy golden sparrow search algorithm (LGSSA), is proposed and integrated with FDGRFT. This synergistic LGSSA-FDGRFT method enables more accurate and robust measurement of target motion parameters, while further reducing computational complexity. The effectiveness of the proposed detection method for low-observable maneuvering aerial targets is validated through both simulations and measured data.

title: Manufacturing and Assembly of the NeuroSphere PET Insert for the Human Dynamic NeuroChemical Connectome
authors: M. Scipioni, J. Corbeil, M. S. Allen, A. Mareyam, J. Kirsch, L. Byars, L. L. Wald, M. Judenhofer, C. Catana
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The Human Dynamic NeuroChemical Connectome (HDNCC) integrates a dedicated brain PET camera (NeuroSphere) with a 7-T MRI scanner to image dynamic brain processes with high temporal resolution. The 872 LSO+MPPC detector blocks are arranged in a partial sphere with a 32 cm inner diameter, a 25 cm front opening, and a 9 cm rear opening for the RF coil's cable routing. This yields an estimated 70% solid-angle coverage. The spherical gantry consists of 19 parallel rings manufactured using stereolithography 3D printing. Each detector block is pressfitted in position, with a soft silicone cushion protecting the MPPC from vibration. All custom electronics and components employ MR-safe materials and designs that minimize RF noise and ground loops. A dual cooling strategy manages thermal loads. A closed-loop water system, using flexible tubes routed through dedicated channels and encapsulated in thermal silicone on each support ring, maintains the PET modules at a stable temperature (currently set at ~30.5°C). Directed air cooling is used for the readout electronics and power supplies installed behind the PET gantry. 7T MR integration features a custom 16-ch transmit-receive RF coil using a sparse wire layout to reduce photon attenuation. A conforming RF shield, constructed from dielectric Kapton tape sandwiched between conductive Pyralux patches to form a capacitive network, extends to the 3 mm -thick carbon fiber protective enclosure housing the entire PET system. The NeuroSphere's gantry, with all the integrated detectors, readout electronics, and the watercooling system, is now fully assembled. Core PET functionalities are operational. Current efforts are focused on fine-tuning, calibration, and performance characterization. Subsequent steps will involve integrating the carbon fiber shell and conducting the first simultaneous PET/MR imaging tests in phantoms and humans.

title: Multimodal Imaging With EasyPET/CT
authors: R. G. Oliveira, P. M.C.C. Encarnação, A. L.M. Silva, F. M. Ribeiro, P. M.M. Correia, J. F.C.A. Veloso
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This work presents the implementation of a novel micro-PET/CT system, which uses an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{241} \text{Am}$</tex> radioactive source for CT acquisition while sharing the same scintillator detectors used for PET imaging. This approach aims to reduce system complexity and cost by eliminating the need for separate CT-specific detectors and X-ray tubes. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{241} \text{Am}$</tex> source emits low-energy gamma photons suitable for producing attenuation-based CT images, while PET component relies on conventional positron annihilation photon detection. To evaluate the performance of the dualmodality system, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{22} \text{Na}$</tex> point-like source was imaged using both PET and CT modes. The resulting CT reconstruction successfully captured structural information using the low-energy photons of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{241} \text{Am}$</tex> source while the PET image accurately depicted the expected distribution of annihilation events. These results show the feasibility of using a single detector system for both PET and CT imaging, highlighting the potential for more compact, cost-effective hybrid scanners. The work will be focused on system optimization, calibration, and evaluation using more complex phantoms and animal models, providing PET/CT fusion images.

title: A Neural Network-Based Cross-Bin Pileup Effect Correction Method for Photoncounting CT
authors: W. Qin, H. Liu, X. Yu, J. Zhou, M. Su, Q. Wu, T. Zhong, W. Wang, X. Ji, G. Quan, Y. Chen, W. Qin, X. Lai
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Photon-counting detectors (PCDs) with multiple energy bins have demonstrated significant clinical potential in spectral imaging for medical computed tomography (CT). However, the benefits of PCDs can be compromised by various physical non-idealities, particularly the pulse pileup effect. This effect arises when incident photons arrive in close temporal proximity, especially at clinically relevant high-flux rates, leading to decreased output counting rates, distorted measured spectra, and consequently, degraded image quality. Conventional correction methods employ precise physical detection models, such as the nonparalyzable model, to recover pileup-free counts from pileup-affected counts for individual energy bins; however, these approaches ignore the strong correlations among measured data across different energy bins. In this study, we propose a neural network-based approach to correct the pileup effect on measured counts across multiple energy bins of PCDs. Our method leverages a physics-guided detector model to restore spectral responses unaffected by pileup and to generate training datasets. Promising preliminary results demonstrate the feasibility of our approach.

title: Radiation Detection Properties of Dual Lithium Hafnium Bromide Scintillator
authors: C. Fujiwara, S. Kurosawa, A. Yamaji, N. Matsubayashi, T. Takata, H. Tanaka, A. Yoshikawa
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Both gamma-ray and neutron-sensitive scintillators are required to survey the dose rate in neutron and gamma-ray mixture fields, and the discrimination between gamma rays and neutrons is an important factor for the scintillator. We have developed Li<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>HfBr<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> scintillators with both sensitivities, and the details of their radiation properties were investigated in this paper. The results showed the sample had an emission wavelength of 570 nm excited by X-rays and light output of approximately 3,2000 photons/ MeV and 70,000 photons/(thermal neutron) excited by gamma rays and neutrons, respectively. The non-proportional response was within 20 % from 32 to 662 keV, and pulse height spectra showed that the gamma-ray and thermal neutron-derived peaks were well separated. Therefore, Li<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>HfBr<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</inf> was found to be a promising material as the scintillator for both neutron and gamma-ray detection.

title: Performance of High Spatial Resolution Hybrid and All-Inorganic Perovskite Direct X-Ray Imagers: A Comparative Study
authors: B. Dunham, S. Motakef, A. Datta
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper presents a systematic comparative study of solution-processed hybrid organicinorganic and all-inorganic perovskite-based X-ray imagers (PeroXIs) integrated onto identical active pixel arrays. Methylammonium lead iodide (MAPI) and cesium lead bromide (CPB) films were fabricated via blade-coating and characterized for direct conversion X-ray detection performance. The CPB-based imagers demonstrated markedly superior performance, achieving spatial resolution of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.9 \text{lp} / \text{mm}$</tex> at 20\% modulation transfer function compared to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.5 \text{lp} / \text{mm}$</tex> for MAPI-based devices, while maintaining a significantly higher contrast-to-noise ratio of 442 versus typical values of 11-147 for MAPI-based systems. Mobility-lifetime <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mu \tau)$</tex> product measurements revealed values of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8.0 \times 10^{-4} \text{cm}^{2} / \mathrm{V}$</tex> for CPB versus <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.3 \times 10^{-4} \text{cm}^{2} / \mathrm{V}$</tex> for MAPI, correlating with superior charge collection efficiency at equivalent electric fields. CPB-based detectors exhibited exceptional sensitivity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$55,400 \mu \mathrm{C}$</tex> Gyair <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$^{-1} \text{cm}^{-2}$</tex>, approximately four times higher than MAPI counterparts, with a remarkably low detection limit of 417 pGyair <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{s}^{-1}$</tex>. The all-inorganic devices also demonstrated enhanced operational stability with sensitivity variations below <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 1 \%$</tex> over eight months without encapsulation, compared to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 4 \%$</tex> for encapsulated MAPI devices. Integration with high-density <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.8 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> pixel arrays enabled unprecedented spatial resolution exceeding <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 \text{lp} / \text{mm}$</tex> while maintaining high detection efficiency ( <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\operatorname{DQE}(0) \approx 85.3 \%$</tex>), effectively resolving the longstanding trade-off between spatial resolution and detection efficiency in X-ray imaging. These results establish solution-processed inorganic perovskites as a scalable, high-performance platform capable of surpassing commercial standards for low-dose, high-resolution X-ray imaging across medical, industrial, and scientific domains.

title: SSTCAM: a Silicon Photomultiplier Camera for Observations of TeV Gamma Rays With the Cherenkov Telescope Array Observatory
authors: F. Wohlleben
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The Cherenkov Telescope Array Observatory (CTAO) will observe the very high-energy gamma-ray sky (20 GeV-300 TeV) with unprecedented performance in terms of sensitivity, angular and energy resolution. CTAO is constructed at two stations, one in each hemisphere for full-sky coverage. On the southern station at least 37 Small-Size Telescopes (SSTs) of 4.2 m diameter dish will cover the highest energy range (5 TeV-300 TeV).

title: Electronics System for a Plastic Scintillation Detector-Based Cosmic Ray Test Platform
authors: Y. Zhang, Y. Wang, X. Li, Z. Tang, Z. Liang, Z. Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The cosmic ray test platform is essential for performance evaluation of particle detectors in the laboratory environment. Based on a specially designed plastic scintillation detector, a cosmic ray test platform consisting of four X-Y position-sensitive detector layers with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 ~\text{cm} \times 50 ~\text{cm}$</tex> effective area is developed and performance evaluated in this work. Each position-sensitive detector layer is composed of 48 triangular plastic scintillator strips, and each strip is embedded with two wavelength-shifting (WLS) fibers for position readout. By a specially designed encoding module, four fibers are coupled to a silicon photomultiplier (SiPM), so that the 96 WLS fibers in a layer are coupled into 24 SiPMs, whose signals are further processed by a front-end electronics module. Therefore, the electronics system for the detector contains eight front-end modules and one coincidence module. One front-end module has 24 independent readout channels, each channel is responsible for digitizing the time and energy information of the detected event. Under the control of the coincidence module, every front-end module transmits the acquired data to the central computer through a network switch. The functions of the electronics system, such as the noise level, the time resolution, and the energy resolution, have been well evaluated. Combined with the detector, the test results show that the cosmic ray test platform achieves a time resolution of 6.5 ns and a position resolution of 1.2 mm, meeting the position requirements of performance evaluation for most detectors.

title: Performance of Pixelated CdZnTe Detector System for Secondary Particles Monitoring Tested with Clinical Carbon Ion Beams
authors: P. Wang, Q. Zhang, D. Guo, X. Mo, C. Huang, C. Shan, Q. Li, Y. Yin
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We assessed a pixelated CZT detector system designed for monitoring secondary particle emissions from a PMMA phantom irradiated by mono-energetic clinical carbon ion beams The system consists of four CZT detectors (each measuring <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$25.4 ~\text{mm} \times 25.4 ~\text{mm} \times 5 ~\text{mm}, 1.5 ~\text{mm}$</tex> pixels) coupled with ASIC readout. The detector reproduced the synchrotron spill structure, resolving 2s spill-on and 5s inter-spill intervals. Energy spectra showed clear 511 keV photopeaks with FWHM of 6.46 % (in-beam)and2.13%(off-beam). Post-irradiation count-rate decay followed a bi-exponential curve with half-lives of 122.4 s and 1228.4 s, matching expected production of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{15} \mathrm{O}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{11} \mathrm{C}$</tex>. Total counts rose linearly with delivered monitor units (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 10^{6}-1.5 \times 10^{7}$</tex>), enabling dose prediction within 2 % for high-dose fields. These results demonstrate that pixelated CZT detectors provide accurate timing, spectroscopy, and dosimetric information, supporting their integration into carbon-ion range verification and real-time dose monitoring workflows.

title: Development of a Sub-0.5 mm Resolution PET for Mouse Brain Imaging
authors: H.G. Kang, H. Tashima, H. Wakizaka, M. Higuchi, T. Yamaya
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In a previous study, we developed a mouse brain dedicated positron emission tomography (PET) scanner using a staggered 3-layer depth-of-interaction (DOI) detector employing a 1 mm crystal pitch to achieve high resolution while minimizing the parallax error. However, the resolution was limited to around 0.6 mm due to unoptimized crystal pitch and layer design. In this study, following our simulation study presented in IEEE MIC 2024, we developed a new small animal PET scanner to achieve sub- 0.5 mm resolution for mouse brain imaging. The developed small animal PET scanner had a 48 mm inner diameter and 23.4 mm axial FOV. The LYSO crystal array had the pixel pitch of 0.8 mm and total thickness of 11 mm. The PET scanner consisted of 2 rings each of which had 16 DOI detectors. Each DOI detector consisted of a 3-layer staggered LYSO crystal array and 5 × 5 SiPM array with a pixel pitch of 2.4 mm. The SiPM anode signals were multiplexed using a resistive network and then digitized by a custom-made DAQ. The respective measured spatial resolutions at the center and 5 mm radial offset were 0.68 mm and 0.71 mm for the FBP algorithm. The 0.45 mm rod structures of a resolution phantom were resolved using the OSEM algorithm. The in vivo mouse brain imaging showed detailed mouse brain structures, which were barely resolved with conventional preclinical PET scanners. In summary, we successfully developed the new mouse brain PET scanner that can provide sub- 0.5 mm resolution. In the near future, we will use the developed PET for neuroscience research with disease rodent models.
