title: Estimation of Proton-Induced SEU Rates of Sub-100 nm FPGAs for PEGASEUS Project on ISS
authors: R. Kiuchi, Y. Sunada, M. Tominaga, N. Uchida, Y. Hiroshima, H. Iwashita, T. Ikeda
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We are planning an exposure experiment project, the Payload for Evaluation of Guarding Against Single Event Upset in Space (PEGASEUS). This project is going to measure space-radiationinduced Single Event Upsets (SEU) for Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs) on the International Space Station (ISS). The payload is equipped with six types of Commercial Off-TheShelf (COTS) FPGAs manufactured with a wide range of sub- 100 nm technologies. The results will be used to evaluate the accuracy and margin of the SEU Rate (SER) in accelerated tests using particle accelerators on the ground. In this study, we measured proton-induced SEU cross sections for the FPGAs using a proton accelerator to estimate the SER on the ISS. Our results showed that the daily SER was below the order of 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−1</sup> for each FPGA, and our ISS exposure experiment would measure a total of 2215 SEUs across all FPGAs in a half-year.

title: Cryogenic Operation of Cmos Spads as Candidate Photodetectors for Lhcb Rich Upgrade Ii
authors: R. Dolenec, E. Charbon, D. Consuegra Rodríguez, F. Gramuglia, W.-Y. Ha, U. Karaca, P. Križan, S. Korpar, R. Pestotnik, A. Seljak, P. Singh, G. Taylor, M.-L. Wu, C. Bruschini
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In the planned LHCb RICH (Ring Imaging Cherenkov Detector) upgrade II, silicon photomultipliers (SiPMs) are considered as one of the most promising photodetector candidates. They can meet all of the performance requirements of upgraded RICH detector, except for the neutron irradiation hardness. During the whole experiment run time, the photodetectors are expected to receive accumulated dose of about 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">13</sup> 1-MeV neutron equivalent /cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>. For the SiPMs to keep sufficient performance after such a dose, a combination of mitigation steps will have to be taken, including cooling the photodetectors close to liquid nitrogen temperature. The spadRICH project is developing a CMOS single-photon avalanche diode (SPAD) based photodetector optimized for the application of the planned RICH detectors, with SPADs designed specifically for radiation hardness and cryogenic operation, including microlenses and on chip custom electronics. The latter is planned to include functions to mitigate radiation damage effects while meeting the other main performance requirements. A number of SPADs designed by EPFL AQUA in 55 nm, 110 nm and 180 nm CMOS technologies were characterized in a cryogenic experimental setup, measuring dark count rates, afterpulsing probability and response to low-level light illumination, from room to liquid nitrogen temperatures. Characterization was repeated with SPADs irradiated up to 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">12</sup> 1-MeV neutron equivalent/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, with high temperature annealing and effects of microlens materials also studied. The characterization results are being used to optimize the design of spadRICH digital SiPM.

title: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
authors: N/A
K. C. Mandal, S. K. Chaudhuri, R. Nag
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Metal-free (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{p}^{+}$</tex>) boron-doped diamond (BDD)/(n)4H-SiC heterojunction Schottky barrier device (HSBD) was developed for radiation detection under extreme conditions. The device comprises a nanocrystalline <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{p}^{+}$</tex>BDD layer deposited onto a low-defect n-4H-SiC epitaxial layer, forming a transparent, conductive interface. Conductive BDD films are used in place of metals, which often degrade in high-radiation or chemically aggressive environments. The HSBD exhibited a rectification ratio of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.7 \times 10^{6}$</tex>, exceeding the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5.3 \times 10^{5}$</tex> achieved by a benchmark nickel (Ni)/4H-SiC SBD. In self-biased mode (0 V), it showed a distinct alpha response and high charge collection efficiency. These detection capabilities enabled direct radiovoltaic power generation, outperforming recently reported 4H-SiC p-i-n converters. Radiovoltaic batteries, analogous to PV cells but powered by ionizing radiation, offer compact, long-lived energy sources for space missions and nuclear monitoring where sunlight is unavailable. Under alpha- and beta-particle exposure, the HSBD demonstrated carrier generation and collection within the 4H-SiC absorber. Betavoltaic measurements yielded a radio-to-dark-current ratio (RDCR) of 246 at 0 V and a higher open-circuit voltage (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{V}_{\text{OC}}$</tex>) than the benchmark, indicating enhanced power output. In alphavoltaic mode, the device achieved RDCR of 13 at alpha flux <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2,942 ~\mathrm{s}^{-1} ~\text{cm}^{-2}$</tex> and a maximum output power density <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.03 \text{nW} / \text{cm}^{2}$</tex>, corresponding to 1.16% conversion efficiency. The short-circuit current scaled linearly with source strength, while the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{V}_{\text{OC}}$</tex> remained stable. These results underscore HSBD's potential for durable radiation detection and integrated radiovoltaic energy harvesting.

title: Research on Muon Imaging Methods of the GeV-Energy Muon Sources Based on HIAF
authors: J. Zhai, L. Chen, Y. Xu, P. Yu, L. Deng
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The GeV beam muons provided by the High Intensity Heavy-Ion Accelerator Facility (HIAF), with their unique advantages in energy, flux, and directionality, can significantly enhance imaging capabilities in scenarios where traditional radiographic technologies fail to penetrate or where cosmic muon imaging suffers from poor quality. However, research on GeV muons remains limited. This paper explores the characteristics of these muons, calculates their range variations, analyzes the potential applications of transmission imaging, and performs scattering imaging and result analysis of a target object.

title: Flight-Ready: HPGe Detector Production for the COSI Satellite Mission
authors: J. M. Szornel, M. Amman, N. Hassan, A. Esparza, V. Negut
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The Compton Spectrometer and Imager (COSI) is an upcoming NASA Small Explorer (SMEX) mission that will deploy a Compton telescope based on high-purity germanium (HPGe) detectors. Advanced applications, like COSI, require not only exceptional energy resolution but also precise localization of photon interactions within the detector volume. This necessitates the use of position-sensitive detectors with finely segmented electrodes and excellent spatial and energy resolution. The COSI payload includes an array of 16 finely segmented HPGe double-sided strip detectors (DSSDs), enabling high-resolution tracking of gamma-rays. Each detector has approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 8 \times 1.5 ~\text{cm}^{3}$</tex> of active volume and is segmented into 64 orthogonal strips per side, with a 1.162 mm pitch. These detectors have been fabricated at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory (LBNL) using amorphous semiconductor contact technology pioneered at the lab. This technology enables fine segmentation, low leakage current, and full passivation of the detector surface while maintaining excellent stability and reproducibility over large crystal volumes.

title: Ultra-Fast Photon Counting with Monolithic Digital SiPMs in a 110 nm CMOS Technology
authors: T. M. Floris, M. Campajola, G. Collazuol, M. D.R. Rolo, G. Fiorillo, F. Licciulli, N. M. Mazziotta, L. Pancheri, L. Ratti, L. Rignanese, R. Santoro, C. Vacchi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: A monolithic silicon photo-multiplier, including 1024 micro-cells with a 30∼$\upmu$m pitch and a fill-factor of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 \backslash \%$</tex>, has been designed in a 110 nm CMOS image sensor technology. The SiPM takes advantage of a parallel counter to compute the number of hit pixels, providing the count in digital form with a latency time of a few ns from the time of arrival of the last photon. Careful design of a fast NAND/NOR tree, preserving as much as possible the signal path symmetry, minimizes fixedpattern related jitter so to ensure uncertainties in the time of arrival of the first photon below 10 ps. Noise mitigation is accomplished both by individually disabling hot micro-cells and by setting a threshold for the signal triggering the event timing circuitry.

title: 3D Mapping Using an Unmanned Ground Vehicle Equipped with a Coded-Aperture Gamma Camera and RGB-D Camera
authors: C. Ko, M. Song, D. Kim, J. Lee, S. Lee, H. Lyu, M. Jeong
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In this study, a radiation hotspot was visualized, and three-dimensional (3D) environmental information was reconstructed using an unmanned ground vehicle (UGV) equipped with a gamma camera and an RGB-D camera. The RGB-D data acquired in real time were processed through 3D simultaneous localization and mapping (SLAM) to generate a point cloud, which was subsequently denoised and converted into a 3D mesh via Poisson surface reconstruction. Measurements were conducted from three different directions with a stationary <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{137} \text{Cs}$</tex> radiation source. The estimated hotspot locations were transformed into the world coordinate system of the point cloud and subsequently aligned with the reconstructed 3D mesh. This alignment enabled intuitive identification of the contaminated region within the reconstructed environment. The results demonstrate the feasibility of a precise and unmanned platform-based radiation mapping system.

title: Challenges for Screening of Nuclear Fuel Debris by Innovative Spectral Imaging and Its Verification by LIBS Mapping: (3) Detection of Uranium in Simulated Fuel Debris Samples by Acoustic Wave-Assisted Microchip Laser-induced Breakdown Spectroscopy
authors: M. Batsaikhan, H. Ohba, T. Karino, Y. Iwata, K. Akaoka, I. Wakaida, C. Sakaguchi, K. Sakamoto, H. Muta
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Remote, real-time, accurate elemental analysis is essential at every stage of the safe and successful decommissioning of the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Station, from initial site characterization to storage of materials. This study presents the development of a novel acousticwave assisted microchip laser-induced breakdown spectroscopy technique for remote and realtime elemental analysis and explores the use of laser-induced plasma acoustic signal to optimize the lens-to-sample-distance which is significantly affect to the signal intensity and accuracy of measurement. The analytical performance of the developed system was tested for uranium in mixed oxide samples and the limit of detection was evaluated to be 0.7 wt.% with calibration curve method.

title: Numerical Bias Estimator for Spectral CT
authors: O. Sandvold, R. Proksa, A. Perkins, P. Noel
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Characterization via system modeling plays a key role in the design and refinement of spectral computed tomography (CT) systems. Whereas image noise has been effectively modeled using the Cramér–Rao lower bound (CRLB) under the unbiased estimator assumption, spectral bias–stemming from hardware/software limitations and quantum noise–continues to be a significant challenge in spectral CT research. To enhance the clinical utility of spectral data, such as the use of iodine as a biomarker, it is essential to minimize bias in clinical imaging protocols. This study introduces a statistical framework for quantifying bias in material decomposition basis domains derived in spectral CT. To demonstrate this method, we utilize a PMMA/iodine phantom to replicate a contrast-enhanced clinical protocol. A realistic x-ray source and two bin photoncounting detector (PCD) is modeled. To estimate the bias, we first generate line projections which deviate ±6 standard deviations from the expected values of each basis function and compute their probability based on the system parameters. The joint likelihood for every pair of biased projections is mapped into the two-dimensional base material space where the expected bias in each material can be measured. By applying the bias metric, system parameters such as bin threshold levels can be optimized to reduce bias either independently or together with noise. Our results highlight the ability to quantify spectral bias and underscore the distinction between bias estimation and the CRLB. Achieving optimal performance in clinical tasks necessitates a trade-off between noise and bias. The proposed bias estimator delivers a robust, quantitative framework for assessing and minimizing bias across various system configurations.

title: Design and Testing of a Cryogenic Analog Front-End Integrated Circuit for High Purity Germanium Detectors
authors: M. Turqueti, D. Gnani, W. Write, A. Papadopoulou, L. Schlueter, A. Drobizhev, C. Grace, A. Poon
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper presents the design, implementation, and characterization of a custom front-end integrated circuit (IC) optimized for the low-noise readout of high-purity germanium (HPGe) detectors, which are widely used in rare-event search experiments in nuclear and particle physics. The IC is specifically engineered to meet the stringent performance requirements of large-volume, high-capacitance detectors, such as inverted coaxial point contact (ICPC) high purity Germanium (HPGe) detectors employed in neutrinoless double-beta decay (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0 \nu \beta \beta$</tex>) experiments like LEGEND (Large Enriched Germanium Experiment for Neutrinoless <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\beta \beta$</tex> Decay). The circuit integrates a lownoise charge-sensitive amplifier (CSA), a low-dropout (LDO) voltage regulator, and a fully differential output buffer capable of driving analog signals over long transmission lines with minimal distortion or signal degradation. This integration minimizes parasitic elements and enhances signal fidelity while reducing overall system complexity and power consumption. The IC is fabricated using a low power, low-k dielectric, 65 nm CMOS technology well-suited for cryogenic environments. Operated at 80 K, the front-end achieves an equivalent noise charge (ENC) below 100 electrons rms for capacitances as high as 10 pF, satisfying the low noise demands of precision spectroscopy and rare-event detection. Comprehensive characterization of the IC includes detailed measurements of noise spectral density, charge linearity, power efficiency, dynamic range, and long-term stability. Performance metrics are benchmarked against both discrete component-based and other monolithic readout solutions currently in use or under development. The proposed IC offers a compact, scalable, and power-efficient readout solution, paving the way for next-generation germanium-based detector arrays experiments requiring exceptional energy resolution and robust signal integrity.

title: Leveraging Multi-Cycle Information to Improve Event Prediction in Time-Triggered Systems
authors: Dongchen Li, Daniel Onwuchekwa, Roman Obermaisser
abstract: In adaptive time-triggered systems, dynamic schedule switching in response to environmental and internal state changes is essential. However, existing approaches relying on offline-generated Multiple Scheduling Graphs (MSGs) often suffer from high memory overhead, whereas online schedule generation incurs adaptation latency. To address both limitations, proactive speculative scheduling with event prediction has emerged as a promising solution. Existing event prediction models rely on single-cycle input, which may lack sufficient temporal context. In this work, we argue that multi-cycle inputs capture richer temporal patterns, particularly periodic relationships, that can significantly improve prediction performance. We propose the Slack Time and Event Prediction Model (SEPM), a novel attention-based model designed to effectively learn from long multi-cycle inputs. Through extensive experiments, we show that SEPM substantially outperforms three baseline models in terms of prediction accuracy and stability. Moreover, we identify that the number of input cycles is a critical hyperparameter. Although exhaustive search yields optimal results, it is computationally expensive. To this end, we introduce a lightweight FFT-based slack time analysis method, which efficiently estimates the effective number of input cycles closely matching those obtained from experiments. On the test dataset, SEPM achieves a median event coverage of 80.02%, significantly outperforming its single-cycle variant at 74.81%, demonstrating the substantial benefit of multi-cycle inputs. These findings validate the advantage of multi-cycle inputs and attention mechanisms in event sequence prediction. This work establishes a practical foundation for building efficient and robust predictive components in adaptive time-triggered systems.

title: Self-Background Removal in $\text{LaBr}_{3}$ Using Machine Learning
authors: J. Zhou, P. Menge
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The feasibility of using a machine-learning model was investigated to discriminate external radiation from the self-background in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{LaBr}_{3}(\text{Ce})$</tex> scintillator detectors and improve its gamma-ray spectroscopy accuracy. Two <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{LaBr}_{3}(\text{Ce})$</tex> crystals with different sizes (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\varnothing 1^{\prime \prime} \times 1^{\prime \prime}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\varnothing 1^{\prime \prime} \times 6^{\prime \prime}$</tex>) were adopted to test our method. The self-background pulses from the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{138} \text{La}$</tex> decay with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 1.46 \text{MeV}$</tex> deposit energy were collected, and then the detector was used to measure an external <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{228} \text{Th}$</tex> source. Compton scatter radiation pulses were collected with the same energy deposition as the self-background. Thousands of pulses were digitized with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12.5 \text{GS} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> sampling rate. Then, the data trained a convolutional neural network (CNN) to distinguish self-background pulses from external radiation signals. After training, the model achieved an 80 % classification accuracy, which demonstrated the model could capture pulse features and identify their types in the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{LaBr}_{3}$</tex> detector. The robustness of the model was also studied. The two different sized <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{LaBr}_{3}$</tex> crystals and varied PMT voltages were used to collect a superset of pulses containing many permutations of crystals and PMT voltages. This superset then trained a new model, and its robustness versus crystal sizes and voltages was examined. After training, the model yielded a 78% classification accuracy (nearly as good as that from a single crystal and a single voltage). Thus, indications are that the model can use the intrinsic features of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{LaBr}_{3}$</tex> pulses to discriminate external radiation from self-background, and the features do not significantly depend on crystal sizes or voltage selections. Therefore, the machine-learning model has the potential to be adopted on <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{LaBr}_{3}$</tex> detection systems to remove its self-background events and prevent the misidentification of external radioisotopes.

title: LQR-Based Control for Standalone DC Microgrids with Photovoltaic and Battery Integration
authors: Obaid Aldosari
abstract: Photovoltaic (PV) systems are widely used, especially in rural and remote locations where traditional grid access is limited. A major challenge associated with PV systems is their variable power output, which fluctuates due to changes in irradiance and temperature. Additionally, the dynamic nature of load demands further complicates the management of these systems. To address these issues, battery storage is commonly used to smooth out power fluctuations resulting from the variable nature of PV panels. Control techniques for PV-battery systems must effectively manage power flows and stabilize bus voltages. This paper presents a control strategy for maintaining DC bus voltage in a PV /battery system using a Linear Quadratic Regulator (LQR). The proposed LQR-based controller is designed to effectively regulate the DC bus voltage, ensure power balance within the system, and minimize transients during disturbances. The performance of the proposed control approach is validated through extensive simulation-based analysis, demonstrating its effectiveness in stabilizing the system and managing power fluctuations.

title: Real-time load profiling and operational pattern recognition in a smelting industry
authors: Samrawit Bzayene Fesseha, Bin Li, Bing Qi, Songsong Chen, Feixiang Gong
abstract: This study presents a novel three-stage analytical framework, combining data preprocessing, load profiling, and operational pattern recognition, specifically designed for the high-power, nonlinear environment of silicon smelting substations. Unlike existing approaches that focus on equipment-level analytics or generic industrial loads, the proposed framework provides a unified, substation-level diagnosis capable of quantifying operational stability, variability, and functional roles within the smelting process. Application of the framework to four substations revealed distinct numerical performance signatures: Substation_1 exhibited highly stable behavior with Load Factor 1.0, and minimal variability; Substation_2 showed extreme volatility (Load Factor (LF) 0.22–0.35, Variability Index (VI) > 3000) and clear dual daily peaks at 10:00 and 14:00; Substation_3 demonstrated more efficient operation (Load Factor 0.55–0.72, Peak-to-Base Ratio (PBR) 2.5–4); and the Smelter Outlet operated as a continuous base-load unit with Load Factor 0.62–0.70 and near-zero Peak-to-Base Ratio while sustaining 20–22 MW during production. Variability-band and clustering analyses further distinguished the stable, furnace-driven load of the smelter from the flexible, schedulable auxiliary loads. The key novelty of this work lies in linking quantitative temporal load signatures to functional process roles, offering a structural view of energy behavior across smelting infrastructure. The findings provide actionable insights: flexible substations can support real-time demand response, substations with Power Factors fluctuations (0.3–1.0) require targeted reactive compensation, and grid operators gain improved visibility for forecasting and stability management, thereby strengthening grid–industry integration.

title: A Small-Gain Look at Cyber-Physical Security
authors: Sayan Chakraborty, Zhong-Ping Jiang
abstract: This paper studies the resilience of cyber-physical systems under denial-of-service attacks. We develop a novel framework for resilient control that avoids the need for detailed information about the system or attacker dynamics by treating the plant–attacker interaction as an interconnected system. Using small-gain analysis and switching systems theory, we derive explicit resilience conditions, and employ reinforcement learning to synthesize an optimal policy directly from input–state data, estimating the required small-gain bounds in a data-driven manner. A numerical example illustrates the effectiveness of the proposed approach.

title: Probabilistic Modeling and Control for multi-UAV Search Over Uneven Terrain
authors: Luka Lanča, Karlo Jakac, Stefan Ivić
abstract: This research addresses survey missions involving multiple Uncrewed Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) over complex, varying terrain. The methodology integrates a probabilistic model of target's position uncertainty with UAV flight dynamics, camera properties, and a machine learning-based detection system. It estimates undetected target probability and overall search performance, feeding into a feedback loop that combines 2D ergodic search with Model Predictive Control (MPC) of UAV altitude and velocity. Trial trajectory optimization accounts for sensing characteristics and operational constraints, producing terrain-aware, collision-free trajectories that balance area coverage with target detection. Simulations demonstrate the integration of MPC and ergodic search, enabling dynamic altitude adjustments to enhance the search performance. The control algorithm operates in real time and performs reliably under uncertainty. Field experiments provided training data, validated the method, and confirmed compliance with motion constraints. Detection rates closely match model predictions, demonstrating stable performance even under significant deviations from ideal conditions. The framework thus offers a reliable solution for autonomous multi-UAV search operations in real-world environments.

title: A Compact Multimode Detector for the Decommissioning of Irradiated Graphite
authors: N. Hunter, B. Seitz, F. Thomson, R. Harris, N. Tzelepi, M. Morisson
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The decommissioning of aging nuclear reactors is a global challenge. The processing and disposal of radioactive material from these reactors is a massive endeavour with far reaching environmental and economic implications. The classification and characterisation of these materials is vital not only for reducing the environmental impact of long-lived radionuclides but also in processing them in a fiscally responsible way. One material of particular interest is graphite used in construction of aging Magnox and AGR reactors. The long-lived radionuclides present in irradiated graphite, particularly <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{C}^{14}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Cl}^{36}$</tex>, present unique issues in their characterisation, processing, and disposal. A novel scintillation detector for this purpose was developed and tested in a series of experiments at Atomfa Trawsfynydd, a twin Magnox reactor site undergoing decommissioning works in North Wales. The prototype detectors were deployed in fuel channels from the reactor charge face, and a radiation survey was conducted at a series of fixed points throughout the channel. In this presentation, the properties of the prototype detectors are examined, particularly their efficiency, noise characteristics, and gamma sensitivity. The results from the experiment are presented and evaluated in comparison to a trepanning study which was conducted in July 2022. Preliminary analysis demonstrates that the detector system is capable of measuring <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\beta$</tex> activity as a function of depth inside the fuel channel and provide a pulse height spectrum at each position.

title: Properties of $(\text{Lu}, \mathrm{Y})_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}: \text{La}^{3+}$ Ceramic Scintillator
authors: J. Glodo, S. Kim, Y. Wang, S. R. Cherry, J. Du, S.I. Kwon, M. Muller
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: La doped <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Lu}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$</tex> has been recently proposed as a promising scintillator for medical imaging, in particular Positron Emission Tomography (PET) [1], [2] There are a few properties that this material exhibits that make it attractive for this application. It has high stopping power due to high density (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9.4 ~\mathrm{g} / \text{cm} 3$</tex>) and effective atomic number (71). It has good light yield, with values measured as high as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20,000 \text{ph} / \text{MeV}$</tex> (composition dependent), and good energy resolution (<10% at 511 keV). Although it has a longer decay time than typical PET scintillators, with components on the order of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1,000 ~\text{ns}$</tex>, it also has a very fast rise time (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<1 ~\text{ns}$</tex>), which contributes to good timing resolution (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<500 \text{ps}$</tex>). The material is produced using ceramic processing method, a potentially cost effective route. One of the challenges encountered in the manufacturing of this composition is the low solubility of La in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Lu}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$</tex>, which is limited to about 6 %. This is unfortunate, as higher concentrations of La yield brighter samples, but make their production more difficult, as secondary phase precipice. On the other hand, the solubility of La in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Y}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$</tex> reaches about 20 %. Therefore, we synthesized mixed samples of La doped <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{Lu}, \mathrm{Y})_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$</tex> with goal of improving production of the composition.

title: Applications and Development Trends of Computer Vision in Intelligent Robots
authors: Zhengbiao Xu, Sitong Chang, Guang Yang, Huanhao Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: This study employs VOSviewer and CiteSpace to perform a bibliometric analysis of literature at the intersection of computer vision and intelligent robotics from 2015 to 2025, based on the Web of Science Core Collection. Through co-occurrence analysis, we identify research hotspots and evolutionary trends, and examine core authors, institutional and national contributions, and keyword dynamics. Key findings include: (1) A stable collaborative network has formed around 51 leading authors, including Milford and Gallego, who drive theoretical and technological advancements; (2) Institutions such as the Chinese Academy of Sciences (CAS), ETH Zurich, and Queensland University of Technology (QUT) excel in publication volume, research depth, and cross-modal innovation, respectively. China, the United States, and Germany lead in output, though China exhibits a pattern of high productivity but relatively lower citation impact; (3) The research focus has evolved through three stages: object detection (2015–2017), multi-modal fusion (2017–2020), and reinforcement learning applications (2021–2023). Current efforts are concentrated on vertical applications such as marine robotics and precision agriculture, reflecting a continuous expansion of the field’s scope.

title: Web-Based Prodeacon Scheduling System: Digitalizing Operations at Alam Sutera Parish
authors: Farion Tekkry, Vincentius Kurniawan, Maria Irmina Prasetiyowati
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on New Media Studies (CONMEDIA)
abstract: Digitalization has become an important factor in streamlining complex administrative task across various fields, including religious organizations. There are many different cultures, ethnic groups, and faiths in Indonesia. Islam, Catholic, Christianity, Buddhism, Hinduism, and Confucianism are among the many religions practiced in Indonesia. There are 8,596,545 Catholics in Indonesia, which is 3.1% of the total population. In Catholic, one of the involved personnel is prodeacon. At the Alam Sutera Parish Catholic Church, the process of scheduling prodeacons remains manual, relying on traditional methods that may limit efficiency and scalability. This study presents the design and development of a web-based scheduling application developed for Prodeacon activities in Catholic churches, aimed at enhancing operational and user satisfaction from the traditional Excel-based scheduling.The system architecture was based on Javascript technology and designed to cater to two distinct user groups: the prodeacon administrator, responsible for managing organizational operations and scheduling tasks, and the members, who access the system only to view their assigned schedules. The system underwent the evaluation utilizing Likert Scale with the assessment being completed exclusively by one of the prodeacon administrator.

title: FedNash: A Nash Equilibrium-Based Federated Multi-Task Learning Framework for Internet of Vehicles
authors: Baizhe Li, Xiaoni Wang, Qiuxin Wu, Can Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: With the increasing demand for data privacy protection in IoV, federated learning (FL) has been widely adopted. However, traditional FL struggle to meet the practical requirements of IoV: vehicles must simultaneously handle dynamic and heterogeneous task combinations, while variations in sensor configurations lead to typically non-independent and identically distributed data characteristics. To address the dual challenges of task and data heterogeneity, we propose FedNash, a Nash equilibrium-based federated multi-task learning framework featuring an encoder-decoder decoupled architecture. FedNash utilizes the Nash bargaining agreement, and models multi-client collaborative efforts as a cooperative game problem, focusing on encoder aggregation to maximize the sum of clients’ logarithmic utility functions, thereby achieving a Pareto optimal solution. This approach ensures privacy and knowledge sharing while accomplishing a fair and efficient global feature representation learning. Furthermore, we employ a decoding aggregation mechanism that incorporates a hierarchical attention model to dynamically adjust the mapping of shared features to task-specific outputs, facilitating both knowledge transfer and isolation among heterogeneous tasks. Experiments on the PASCAL-Context and NYUDv2 datasets demonstrate that FedNash outperforms baseline methods in both single-task scenarios and cross-dataset heterogeneous task scenarios.

title: Client-Based Learning and Zero-Knowledge Proof Implementation in Social Media Recommendation Systems
authors: Kenneth Johannes Fang, Bryan Archie, Anderies Anderies, Andry Chowanda
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Social media platforms rely heavily on user interaction data to personalize content and advertisements, raising concerns regarding user privacy and data misuse. Although regulations such as the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) aim to address these concerns, enforcement remains under the control of the platforms themselves. To address these issues, this paper proposes a privacy-preserving recommender system that minimizes personal preference data exposure while maintaining the potential for equivalent personalization accuracy (including for advertisements) through local data processing, which could access the same amount or more of pure user data than server-side models. This system integrates a lightweight client-based machine learning model to infer user preferences locally, combined with Merkle tree-based Zero-Knowledge Proof (ZKP) scheme to anonymously authenticate user requests. The authors develop a working web app prototype and evaluate performance across a range of user devices. Results show minimal latency for the client-based model (under 5 milliseconds on most devices) and diverse proof generation times, ranging from 2.6 seconds to over 18 seconds, depending on hardware capability. Server-side verification remains consistent and fast under 250 milliseconds. Although proof generation latency remains a bottleneck for real-time applications, optimization strategies such as proof-caching, cross-application preferences synchronization, and native implementation provides a promising path toward privacy-preserving personalization in social media systems.

title: Vision-Based Lane Line Recognition System for Intelligent Mini-Vehicles
authors: Zihang Lv
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: Lane detection is of great significance. Traditional lane detection methods suffer from slow detection speed, low accuracy, and low robustness, necessitating an efficient detection solution. This paper proposes a lane detection method based on the OpenCV platform, employing the adaptive threshold Canny edge detection operator. First, the image is preprocessed by grayscale conversion. Then, lane features are enhanced using binarization. A threshold is set and the lane edges are extracted using the Canny operator. Finally, the camera’s region of interest is defined to complete the lane detection process. The processed image is then overlaid with yellow lines over the lane area. Experimental results demonstrate the method's high detection accuracy and robustness.

title: Application of ALA-FMD in Bearing Failure Diagnosis
authors: Hengfei Han, Hong Jiang, Xiangfeng Zhang, Zhijie Zhu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: This study proposes a bearing fault diagnosis method integrating the Artificial lemming algorithm (ALA) and the FMD. The ALA is a meta-heuristic optimization algorithm primarily used to address parameter optimization problems in complex scientific computations. The FMD algorithm performs modal decomposition on fault signals to identify fault characteristics. Experiments demonstrate that using the ALA to adaptively determine the three key parameters of FMD(filter length L, number of filters K, number of modes n) enables accurate identification of inner ring faults in bearings, providing an effective method for bearing fault diagnosis.

title: A Deep-Learning and Bio-inspired Vision Model-Based Approach for Automatic Coronary Arteries Segmentation
authors: Alberto Lopez-Figueroa, Jorge Brieva, Ernesto Moya-Albor, Sandra L. Gomez-Coronel, Diego Renza, Edgar I. Aguilera-Hernandez, Ivan Cruz-Aceves
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: The accurate segmentation of coronary arteries from X-ray angiograms is critical for the diagnosis and treatment of cardiovascular diseases. Yet, it remains a challenging task due to low image contrast and complex vessel structures. This paper introduces a novel hybrid methodology that combines a bio-inspired vision model, the Steered Hermite Transform (SHT), with a deep learning architecture for robust vessel segmentation. We leverage the SHT to decompose each angiogram into a rich, multi-resolution set of 15 feature maps that capture local image structures at different scales and orientations. These Hermite coefficients, along with the original image, form a 16-channel input tensor used to train a U-Net. This approach enables the network to learn from an enhanced feature space that explicitly represents vessel-like patterns. Evaluated on a public dataset of 134 coronary angiograms, our model demonstrates outstanding performance, achieving an Area Under the Curve (AUC) of 0.9872. The results confirm that enriching the input of a deep neural network with SHT coefficients significantly improves its ability to identify and segment complex vascular networks accurately.

title: Analysis of the Impact of Attacks Against Machine Learning Components of Intrusion Detection Systems
authors: Egor Ichetovkin, Igor Kotenko
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The widespread adoption of machine learning in intrusion detection and prevention systems has created a new class of vulnerabilities related to attacks on the machine learning components themselves. This study focuses on the practical implementation of evasion attacks on black-box classifiers. The approach is applicable to systems for analyzing application-layer protocol traffic. In particular, an implementation for the Hypertext Transfer Protocol is demonstrated. The presented method for generating adversarial examples, which has practical significance, is based on zero-order optimization and allows one to effectively bypass classifiers. The objects of the study were intrusion detection systems for detecting attacks on open-source web applications, designed based on the Naive Bayes, Deep Belief Networks, Quadratic Discriminant Analysis, Random Forest, Adaptive Boosting, Multilayer Perceptron, and k-Nearest Neighbors classifiers. The novelty of the study lies in the fact that it presents for the first time an approach that enables unifying attacks on the machine learning components of intrusion detection systems, with the aim of identifying common patterns for future research.

title: Proximal Policy Optimization in Turn-based Strategy Game MECH.AI
authors: Hanif Fahmi, Umi Rosyidah, Ardiawan Bagus Harisa, Hanny Haryanto
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: In strategy games, non-player characters (NPCs) are critical elements that impact game pacing and player experience. With advancements in technology affecting the game industry, artificial intelligence (AI) techniques offer efficient and practical ways to create enemy behaviours. Proximal Policy Optimization, a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) algorithm, has shown potential in addressing various agent and environmental issues by focusing on improving policies and optimizing AI agents in terms of reward mechanisms. In this study, we create a turn-based tactical strategy game, MECH.AI, and implement PPO on the NPC enemies. Our evaluation of MECH.AI demonstrates that the AI agent provides an enjoyable challenge to players, and the learning with curriculum is preferred. This indicates that the AI Agent can successfully learn strategies through DRL. While this study reveals the potential of DRL to provide significant advantages over classic AI techniques, we also acknowledge limitations related to environmental observation parameters and AI Agent statuses. This research contributes to the growing body of work exploring the use of DRL in game AI and provides insights into its potential for creating more adaptive and engaging gaming experiences.

title: Intrusion Detection System based on Machine Learning for Detecting Real-Time and Real-World DDoS Attacks from Heterogeneous Tools
authors: Altaf Defassya Abadi, Parman Sukarno, Aulia Arif Wardana
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) attacks pose a serious threat to network security due to their increasing scale and sophistication. This paper presents a lightweight Intrusion Detection System (IDS) developed using a custom dataset generated with Zeek and four DDoS tools—LOIC, HOIC, GoldenEye, and Slowloris—to simulate diverse attack scenarios. The system employs supervised machine learning via a Random Forest classifier, selected for its balance between computational efficiency and predictive accuracy. Four distinct models were created utilizing labeled Zeek connection logs, attaining classification accuracies of 99.98% for LOIC and Slowloris, and 100% for HOIC and GoldenEye. A cross-tool evaluation exhibited robust generalization, with detection rates varying from 81.12% to 100% across different tool combinations. The majority of models achieved over 99% accuracy in recognizing novel attack types, hence confirming their adaptability to various DDoS patterns. A prototype for real-time detection was developed utilizing Apache Kafka to disseminate Zeek data for immediate classification. The results validate the practicality of integrating Zeek telemetry with machine learning to develop an accurate, adaptable, and near real-time DDoS detection system.

title: A Millimeter-Wave Wideband and Out-of-Phase Filtering Power Divider Based on GaAs IPD Technology
authors: Yuan Ding, Sen Den, Chao Fan, Yongbing Luo, Le Zhang, Luqi Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: In this paper, a millimeter-wave (mm-wave) filtering power divider (FPD) based on Gallium Arsenide (GaAs) Integrated Passive Device (IPD) technology with wideband and phase-invert is proposed. The realization of filtering and power division functions is achieved by using an input coupled feeding line, an asymmetric stub loaded open-loop resonator and two output ports. By adjusting the coupling width and gap of the coupling line to control the external quality factor, the designed FPD can achieve good broadband filtering performance. When the length difference between two output ports and the input port is half a wavelength, the signals at the two output ports will have a phase difference of 180°. In addition, in order to improve the frequency selectivity of the designed FPD, stub loading technology is used to symmetrically load two open stubs at the end of the openloop resonator and introduce a controllable transmission zero at the passband edge. Simulation results indicate that the minimum in-band insertion loss is 2.5 dB, the 3 dB fractional bandwidth (FBW) is approximately 25.3%, the return loss is greater than 15 dB. The amplitude difference between ports is less than 0.9 dB, and the phase difference between ports is within $180^{\circ} \pm 7^{\circ}$. Keywords-GaAs; filtering power divider; wideband; phaseinvert; millimeter-wave

title: Skin Cancer Detection Using Convolutional Networks and Vision Transformers
authors: Davi Israel Abtibol Carvalho, Fábio Cavalcante Binatti, Marly. G. F. Costa, Cícero F.F. Costa Filho
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Skin cancer, affecting over 1.5 million in 2022, poses a significant public health concern. Traditional methods such as visual inspection and dermoscopy can lead to misdiagnosis due to the similarity of the pixels and textures of malignant and benign lesions. Faced with the challenges inherent in visual diagnosis, computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) systems have become increasingly relevant to improving diagnostic accuracy and efficiency. In this context, deep learning models, specifically convolutional neural networks (CNNs), have shown considerable progress in classifying skin lesions through complex feature extraction This study uses the HAM10000 dataset to investigate and compare the performance of different deep learning models, including CNNs, vision transformers and ensemble methods, in classifying skin lesions. The results obtained with an ensemble model of CNNs and vision transformers outperform the results previously obtained in the literature with the same database. An accuracy of 93.61% and an F1-score of 96.04% was obtained.

title: Warehouse Robot Path planning Based on Improved TD3 Algorithm
authors: Deguo Yang, Minghui Zhao
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning, Pattern Recognition and Automation Engineering (MLPRAE)
abstract: Aiming at the highly dynamic and interference-prone nature of the Warehousing environment, as well as the requirements for accuracy in Path planning, Obstacle avoidance efficiency, and Environmental adaptability of robots, this paper proposes an improved TD3 algorithm that integrates the Gated Recurrent Unit, Multi-head attention mechanism, and HER experience replay. Compared to Traditional algorithms such as A* and Dijkstra, it reduces overestimation of Q-values through TD3's dual Q-networks and Delayed update, thereby enhancing Policy stability; the Gated Recurrent Unit captures Temporal dependence to generate Feature sequence, the multi-head attention mechanism highlights Key information, and Hindsight Experience Replay converts Failed experience into Effective sample to improve the Utilization rate. Experiments show that this algorithm addresses the pain points of the Warehousing environment, including Spatial constraint, Dynamic interference, and Sparse reward. It fills the research blank in the synergistic optimization of "time series modeling, Key information fetch, swatch efficient utilization" for deep reinforcement learning (DRL) in dynamic partial observational warehousing scenes, providing theoretical support and technical solutions for engineering practice.

title: Studying the Generalized Coordinates and Torques in On-Line Signature Verification
authors: Moises Diaz, Miguel A. Ferrer, Cristian Rodriguez, Jose Francisco Lorenzo, Juan M. Gil, Rafael Rodriguez
publish: 2025 IEEE International Carnahan Conference on Security Technology (ICCST)
abstract: Biometric verification through handwritten signatures is a widely accepted behavioral approach in security systems. Traditionally, on-line signature verification has relied on kinematic data captured in Cartesian space. In this work, instead of using conventional spatiotemporal sequences, we employ the joint angle kinematics of a simple two-degree-of-freedom robotic model that performs the signatures. Additionally, we incorporate dynamic information by estimating the torques of the robotic arm using the Lagrangian formulation. We analyze the effectiveness of using generalized coordinates and torques as new feature spaces for on-line signature verification. Our experiments across several public databases demonstrate that combining these robotic features provides improvements over traditional timing-based features.

title: Construction of Deep Learning-Based Intrusion Detection and Classification Model for Computer Networks
authors: Zhendong Zhao
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Digital Management (ICAIDM)
abstract: In order to improve the accuracy and deployment utility of intrusion detection in complex network environments, a set of multi-task classification and anomaly detection models based on deep learning is constructed, and the system integrates traffic acquisition, feature engineering, deep representation and timing modeling modules to form an end-to-end detection framework. The design adopts a dual-channel structure to fuse convolutional residual block and Transformer encoder, joint attention mechanism to extract local protocol semantics and global context dependency, and consistency constraints and regularity strategy to optimize the model training process. Taking public datasets such as CIC-IDS2017, UNSW-NB15 and ToN_IoT as evaluation benchmarks, the experimental results show that the method significantly outperforms multiple existing baseline models in key metrics such as macro F1, PR-AUC and detection latency, and has good cross-domain adaptability and real-time performance.

title: Online Optimization of Cold Atom Experiment Parameters Based on Artificial Neural Networks and Genetic Algorithms
authors: Qufei Wang, Changwen Liang, Xiaoxiao Ma, Lingxiao Zhu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Cold atom experiments involve a large number of parameters, and there are even different degrees of coupling between these parameters. To achieve the optimal cooling effect, the optimization of experimental parameters is an indispensable step in the atomic cooling process. An online optimization scheme for atomic cooling experimental parameters based on artificial neural networks and genetic algorithms is proposed in this paper. First, the experimental setup and principle scheme used in the experiment are introduced, with emphasis on elaborating in detail on the laser system, cooling sequence, optimization steps, and algorithm flow. Then, the influence of different network structures on prediction performance is analyzed. Finally, the optimization scheme is verified on an actual atomic cooling experimental setup. Experimental results show that the optimization algorithm can accurately predict the optimal parameters of the experimental setup. Compared with manual optimization, the proposed scheme achieves a more significant cooling effect, with the temperature improved by approximately a factor of two in both horizontal and vertical directions.

title: Predicting Longitudinal Cognitive Decline via Multimodal Deep Learning Fusing Brain MRI and Clinical Data
authors: Tamoghna Chattopadhyay, Pavithra Senthilkumar, Rahul H. Ankarath, Christopher Patterson, Emma J. Gleave, Sophia I. Thomopoulos, Heng Huang, Li Shen, Lei You, Degui Zhi, Paul M. Thompson
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Predicting clinical decline in aging individuals, especially those with mild cognitive impairment, Alzheimer’s disease, Parkinson’s disease, or vascular dementia, is critical for guiding treatment and optimizing trials. We compared two deep learning methods for forecasting 2-year changes in the Clinical Dementia Rating sum of boxes (sobCDR), a key dementia metric ranging from 0 (no impairment) to 18 (severe). Our hybrid model combined 3D T1-weighted brain MRI with clinical and demographic data (e.g., age, sex, BMI, baseline sobCDR) using a convolutional neural network. We benchmarked it against AutoGluon, an automated multimodal ML framework. Our results highlight the value of integrating imaging and tabular data for personalized prognostics in dementia.

title: DSL-VINS: Real-Time Monocular Visual–Inertial SLAM with Point–Line Features, Denoising, and Layered Marginalization
authors: Zhiheng Guo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: This paper presents DSL-VINS, a monocular visual-inertial SLAM system tailored for complex environments. The framework enhances feature robustness through image denoising, improves geometric constraints via optimized line feature extraction, and boosts efficiency with a layered marginalization strategy. Experiments on the EuRoC dataset show that DSL-VINS reduces absolute pose RMSE by 13.33% and line feature processing time by 23% compared with PL-VINS, achieving higher accuracy and real-time performance for GPS-denied navigation.These results highlight the significance of DSL-VINS for reliable localization in challenging environments, providing a practical solution for autonomous drones and robots in real-world applications.

title: Automatic Penetration Testing for Intelligent Connected Vehicle Network Based on Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Guoli Cheng, Haoyu Zhang, Lei Yun, Jingwei Shang, Yanjiao Ma, Xin Gu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: With increasing technological complexity and system openness, intelligent connected vehicle communication networks face an unprecedentedly broad attack surface. Once weaknesses are exploited by intruders, vehicles will suffer serious security issues and even threaten human life. As an important means of proactively detecting network vulnerabilities and preventing cyberattacks, penetration testing can help identify vulnerabilities promptly in vehicle network. However, traditional manual approaches are plagued by high costs and limited coverage. This paper proposes an automated penetration testing method based on deep Q-learning, which applies agent to learn optimal penetration testing strategies autonomously. The proposal regards penetration testing as a Markov decision process and specifically designing the multi-dimensional state and action space, as well as reward function. Moreover, it employs the deep Q-network that combine experience replay and target network mechanism to train the agent. Experimental results demonstrate that our method achieves higher learning efficiency and enhanced exploration capabilities in complex vehicle network environments.

title: SAHNet: A Spectral-Aware Hashing Network for Large-Scale Fine-Grained Food Image Retrieval
