title: CAPNet: A Color-Aware Adaptive Perception Network for Low-Light Object Detection
authors: Yufan Zhang, Xin Tang, Chengkun Xiao, Mingying You
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Low-light object detection methods have made considerable progress, but there are still some difficulties in detecting objects because of poor visibility, loss of detail, and color distortion. Currently available detectors and decoupling improvement methods often struggle to extract discriminative features or introduce artifacts that interfere with detection. To mitigate the adverse effects of poor visibility and color degradation, we propose a novel CAPNet, which combines low light intensity and semantic feature fusion to achieve robust object detection under challenging illumination. An adaptive color recovery (ACR) module was designed for Retinex decomposition and reference-free statistical priors to achieve the recovery of natural chromaticity. To amplify the high-frequency structural details suppressed by insufficient lighting, we adopt a Dynamic Wavelet-Based Fusion (DWB) module for frequency domain analysis. A Feature Enhancement Gated Detector (FEGD) integrates the enhanced low-level features with high-level semantic representations. It can not only highlight the obvious information of the object, but also restrain the noise. Experimental results demonstrate that CAPNet achieves superior object detection compared with state-of-the-art methods under low-light conditions.

title: Adversarial Attacks on FinTech AI Models: Threats and Mitigation Techniques
authors: Veeramani Sampathkumar, Krishaa Veeras
publish: 2025 IEEE International Carnahan Conference on Security Technology (ICCST)
abstract: The fast acceptance of Artificial Intelligence technology by Financial Technology operations produced major changes in fraud prevention systems while simultaneously advancing credit evaluation practices and automated trading methods and customer service operations. FinTech systems became more susceptible to adversarial attacks because the recent technological advancement has introduced malicious input designs for deceiving AI models and altering their results. These malicious assaults cause severe damages to financial security while violating both privacy standards and the public belief in AI as a service provider. The research investigates future trends of adversarial attacks aimed at FinTech AI models by examining attack classifications which involve evasion and poisoning and inference attacks together with the specific vulnerabilities found in financial sector machine learning algorithms. Empirical evidence and real-world case studies demonstrate how harmful modifications in fraud detection methods and trading algorithms as well as credit rating assessment techniques become possible via malicious manipulations. An evaluation of contemporary defence approaches including adversarial training, robust optimization, input preprocessing and model uncertainty measures takes place in the paper. This paper evaluates how explainable AI (XAI) together with regulatory frameworks strengthens both transparency and resilience of systems. The research advances understandings about safeguarding financial services AI while delivering practical steps that FinTech practitioners and policy officials and academic researchers need to create reliable trustable AI environments in FinTech.

title: Generating diffusion MRI scalar maps from T1-weighted images using Reversible GANs
authors: Tamoghna Chattopadhyay, Gautam Mehendale, Sophia I. Thomopoulos, Himanshu Joshi, Ganesan Venkatasubramanian, John P. John, Jose Luis Ambite, Greg Ver Steeg, Paul M. Thompson
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Diffusion tensor imaging (DTI) provides valuable insights into brain tissue microstructure, but acquiring high-quality DTI data is time-intensive and not always feasible. To mitigate data scarcity and enhance accessibility, we investigate the generation of synthetic DTI scalar maps—specifically mean diffusivity (MD)—from structural 3D volumetric T1-weighted brain MRI using a reversible generative adversarial network (RevGAN). Unlike conventional pipelines requiring multiple steps, our approach enables a single-step translation from T1 to diffusion-derived measures. We assess the quality and utility of the synthetic maps in two downstream tasks: sex classification and Alzheimer's disease classification. Performance comparisons between models trained on real and synthetic DTI maps demonstrate that RevGAN-generated images retain meaningful microstructural features and offer competitive accuracy, underscoring their potential for data augmentation and analysis in neuroimaging workflows. We also examine how well models trained on these data generalize to a new population dataset from India (NIMHANS cohort).

title: Performance Analysis of YOLOv8 and YOLOv11 Models on Automatically Annotated Data for Localization of Biological Objects in Images
authors: Svitlana Kovalenko, Sergii Kovalenko, Olena Mikhnova, Natalia Marchenko, Anton Kovalenko, Narine Mamikonova
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The paper investigates the problem of detecting and localizing biological objects in microscopic images using deep learning methods. The main attention is paid to the automated creation of annotated datasets for training deep learning models, which is a relevant task in biomedical applications, where manual labeling is laborious and expensive. A method for automatically generating blood cell labeling using classical computer vision methods and the k-means clustering algorithm is proposed. The resulting dataset was adapted to the format of YOLO models (versions YOLOv8 and YOLOv11), which were used for cell detection and classification. A comparative analysis of the results of model training was performed using the metrics of accuracy, completeness, average accuracy (mAP), and speed. The YOLOv8 model showed higher accuracy and stability, while YOLOv11 was characterized by higher processing speed. The results demonstrate the effectiveness of using automatically annotated data for computer vision tasks in biomedicine and confirm the feasibility of further improving approaches to automatic image labeling.

title: Spatio-temporal CNN for Joint 6-DoF Pose Estimation in Indoor Visible Light Positioning
authors: Yijia Chen, Tailin Han, Jun Hu, Xuan Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Visible light positioning has emerged as a prominent solution for indoor wireless localization due to its high accuracy, immunity to electromagnetic interference, and cost efficiency. However, in complex indoor environments such as smart warehouses or automated guided vehicle navigation systems, VLP performance is frequently degraded by multipath interference, particularly the interplay between line-of-sight and non-line-of-sight signals that compromises positioning accuracy. Rapid environmental dynamics further challenge stable real-time localization and pose estimation. To overcome these limitations, this paper proposes a dynamic joint position-pose estimation method based on a spatio-temporal feature integration network. The framework incorporates a temporal convolutional network to extract spatio-temporal dependencies from received signal strength sequences, utilizing dilated convolutions and multi-scale feature extraction to capture dynamic variations across temporal scales. Joint learning of spatial and temporal features enhances positioning accuracy and robustness in dynamic scenarios. Experimental results in a $\mathbf{5 m} \times \mathbf{5 m} \times \mathbf{3 m}$ indoor environment demonstrate a RMSE of 6.79 cm, MAE of 5.98 cm, and mean pose angle error of 2.12°. The model exhibits strong generalization capabilities and achieves millisecond-level inference latency, confirming its real-time applicability.

title: Using an Uninterrupted Power Supply to Reduce the Operating Costs of an Autonomous Electric Generator
authors: Y. Titov, M. Kovalenko, I. Tkachuk, I. Kovalenko, O. Bazarov
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: An analysis of the use of an uninterruptible power supply in combination with an autonomous diesel/gasoline generator was conducted in order to reduce operating costs. Such systems can be used when using an autonomous power generating unit as the only power source for consumers, or in case of emergency or emergency power outages. An analysis of existing autonomous power supply systems was conducted and the relevance of this research direction was substantiated. Load schedules were constructed based on a specific example of an autonomous power generating unit and a certain list of equipment in a private house, depending on the time of day. The developed algorithms were used to assess the effectiveness of using a UPS in conjunction with an autonomous diesel/gasoline generator. The use of a UPS allows you to reduce operating costs by loading the generator to an optimal value of 75-80% of the nominal, saving fuel, reducing maintenance intervals and frequency, and harmful emissions into the atmosphere. The maximum amount of savings, depending on the system operating mode, load nature, and frequency of outages, is from 39% to 76%. Additional energy saving effect can be achieved if this system is additionally equipped with solar panels or a wind generator. This will allow for additional fuel savings and generator life. It is planned to evaluate the effectiveness of this technical solution in future studies.

title: Optimizing Barista Shift Scheduling in Multi-Branches Through System Development Using Design Thinking
authors: Walid Hanif Ataullah, Rahmat Yasirandi, Rahmat Panji Wirayudha, Arga Ramadhana, Rahmat Indra Pratama Anom, Kobthong Ladkoom
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: Efficient shift scheduling is essential for optimizing operations in multi-branch coffee shops. This study focuses on improving the barista shift scheduling system at Coffee Shop XYZ using a technology-driven approach informed by Design Thinking principles. The current rotation-based system fails to adapt quickly to fluctuating customer demands and staff availability, leading to inefficiencies and reduced staff satisfaction. This research introduces a flexible, user-centered shift scheduling system that accounts for individual barista preferences, branch proximity, and operational needs across multiple branches. The system incorporates a cloud-based platform that facilitates real-time scheduling, ensuring better communication and workflow management. Through iterative Design Thinking phases—Empathize, Define, Ideate, Prototype, and Test—this study designs and tests the system, achieving a high usability score of 87.3 on the System Usability Scale (SUS), indicating strong user satisfaction and operational effectiveness. This innovative system not only enhances scheduling efficiency but also significantly improves barista job satisfaction, offering valuable insights for operational management in the coffee shop industry.

title: Literacy and Readiness of Using Artificial Intelligence Among Pre-service Teachers
authors: Febe Jean A. Alalong, Maerie Rose A. Masicampo, Baby Princess O. Nuer, Trixie E. Cubillas
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: This study investigates the literacy and readiness levels in using Artificial Intelligence (AI) among pre-service teachers at Caraga State University. Employing a descriptive-correlational research design, the study involved 245 pre-service teachers with a Bachelor of Elementary Education and Bachelor of Secondary Education in English programs. Data were gathered through an adopted questionnaire covering four domains of AI literacy: knowing and understanding, using, evaluating applications, ethics and readiness. Findings revealed that pre-service teachers possess a moderately high level of AI literacy (M = 4.12) and readiness (M = 4.16), with ethics receiving the highest score among the literacy indicators. Regression analysis identified using, evaluating applications, and understanding ethics as significant predictors of readiness. Conversely, demographic profiles such as sex and academic program showed no significant impact on readiness, though differences in literacy levels were observed. Furthermore, real world application using AI tools and thoughtful analysis with ethical awareness are main drivers of pre-service teachers’ readiness to implement AI in classrooms. This study recommends the adoption of AI-related learning and development in teacher education programs, highlighting the integration of ethical awareness and group-based practices. Data highlight the need for an extensive AI skill development to better prepare future educators with the necessary tools for the demands of the fast-evolving digital learning environment.

title: The Evolution of Secure Access Service Edge in the Digital Landscape: Comprehensive Literature Review
authors: Vishal Gudhka
publish: 2025 IEEE International Carnahan Conference on Security Technology (ICCST)
abstract: Enterprises' IT environments are undergoing a fundamental transformation driven by widespread cloud adoption, an increase in remote and hybrid workforces, and rapid integration of Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine learning (ML) into business operations. These changes have exposed critical security flaws in the network environment due to a complex attack surface and introduced new, unanticipated vulnerabilities. Secure Access Service Edge (SASE) [3] solution materialized as a cloud-native framework that combines Software-Defined Wide Area Network (SDWAN) [15] and Secure Service Edge (SSE) [16]. The core components of SASE framework are Zero Trust Network Access (ZTNA) [1], Secure Web Gateway (SWG) [11], Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB) [10], Firewall-as-a-Service (FWaaS) [4], and Data Loss Prevention (DLP) [6]. This paper focuses on understanding how the SASE framework evolved through real-world deployments in many organizations. The paper covers the introduction of the SASE framework, its evolution with modern times, a clear definition of each core component, and the reasons behind its growing necessity. This paper will also delve into each core component of the SASE architecture, examining how they work together to deliver secure, agile, and scalable connectivity in today's digital landscape. This paper also discusses steps to extend the SASE framework to the AI Agents.

title: Modeling Young's Single-Photon Experiment Using Approximate Quantum-Mechanical and 1-Component Quasi-Classical Photon Wave Functions in Coordinate Representation for Spherically Symmetric Radiation
authors: Alexandr P. Davydov, Tatiana P. Zlydneva, Alexandr D. Shablovskii
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Single-photon interference in Young's mental experiment is explained using an approximate 6-component photon wave function in coordinate representation, describing spherically symmetric emission from a single-photon source. This interference is modeled by calculating the photon detection probability density at the corresponding point on the second screen at four selected time moments. It is illustrated for emission with wavelength of 633 nm, an emission duration of 0.667 ns per photon, a slit separation of 3 µm, and a distance of 10 cm from the slits to the second screen where interference is "observed." In addition to the purely quantum mechanical approximate 6-component coordinate photon wave function, a corresponding 1-component "quasi-classical" photon wave function is also used. The resulting interference pattern, which perfectly matches for both functions, suggests that single-photon interference phenomena can be adequately described within the framework of "primary" quantization of the electromagnetic field. It is emphasized that the traditional use of the essentially postulated Feynman transition amplitude to explain Young's experiment with individual particles is justified by the considered 1-component coordinate photon wave function (along with the 6-component quantum mechanical one), providing a richer description of interference not just in arbitrary units, but in units of calculable probability density, which can also be traced in terms of its evolution in space and time. Attention is also drawn to the fact that "measurable" (in some recent experiments) coordinate photon wave functions can only be associated with the 1-component quasi-classical photon wave functions, which are studied in detail in this article.

title: Cabled Electrically Controlled Ultra-High Temperature DC Carrier Communication Device and Method
authors: Xin Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: In the current offshore oilfield production operations, the running depth of intelligent well completion tools in subsea buried hills is usually around 3,000 meters to 5,000 meters. At this depth, the tools operate under a high temperature of approximately $175^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$, which poses significant challenges to the circuit stability of the intelligent well completion tools.DC carrier communication refers to a data transmission method using a single power line. This method can not only supply power to downhole instruments but also transmit signals, which offers advantages such as reducing the number of transmission lines, increasing signal transmission redundancy, and improving system reliability. It plays a crucial role in the reception and transmission of downhole data and is widely applied in underground exploration and downhole signal transmission scenarios.

title: PKRK: A High-Performance Parallel Block Randomized Kaczmarz Algorithm for Large-Scale Overdetermined Systems
authors: Minghui Xu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: The random Kaczmarz (RK) algorithm is an iterative method to solve overdetermined linear systems and serves as a representative example of row action methods. In this paper, we propose a novel block projection variant of the traditional RK algorithm. First, instead of updating the solution vector x using only a single row per iteration, our method selects and utilizes a block of multiple rows to perform each update. Second, to improve the convergence rate, we introduce a greedy-randomized strategy for hyperplane selection, combining the exploration of random sampling with the efficiency of greedy choices. In addition, an error estimation step is incorporated before complete error computation, which significantly reduces computational cost without sacrificing accuracy. To further enhance performance, we parallelize the algorithm by performing effective data partitioning and load balancing across computational cores. Experimental results demonstrate that the serial version of our proposed algorithm, referred to as PKRK (Randomized Kaczmarz with Parallelizable Blocks), achieves up to 59.85× speedup compared to the REK algorithm, and 32.37× speedup over the RDBK algorithm. Moreover, the parallel implementation of PKRK with 8 cores delivers up to 5.2× acceleration compared to its single-core counterpart.

title: Monitoring the UAV Flight Altitude Along Railways Using Computer Vision
authors: Artem Lebedev, Vitaliy Vasilev, Boris Novgorodov, Andrey Paulish
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: In this paper, based on the previously developed algorithm for controlling the unmanned aerial vehicle autonomous flight over a railway without using satellite navigation systems, the algorithm for monitoring the unmanned aerial vehicle flight altitude based on machine vision is proposed. This algorithm uses known quantities: the distance between the rails, the focal length of the camera lens, and the tilt angle of the camera's optical axis relative to the horizon. The research results showed that the accuracy of altitude determination is significantly affected by the camera lens distortion and the change in the tilt angle of the camera's optical axis during the flight, that is, the change in the vehicle pitch angle. If under stationary conditions the error in the flight altitude determining does not exceed 5%, then in a real flight the error reached 50%. To account for changes in pitch angle, a three-axis gyroscope was used, and the algorithm processed its data. As a result, the altitude determination error in a real flight was reduced to 12%, which is quite acceptable for using the proposed algorithm to control the altitude of an autonomous flight, without using satellite navigation systems and unmasking lidar systems.

title: D3EU-Net: A Diffusion and DeepSeek-aided Dual Encoder-based U-Net Model for Microscopic Medical Image Segmentation
authors: Saptarshi Pani, Asya Lyanova, Dmitrii Kaplun, Ram Sarkar
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Medical image segmentation plays a pivotal role in automated diagnosis and treatment planning. While deep learning models have shown strong performance in histopathological image analysis, they often struggle with noisy inputs and ambiguous structures. In this work, we present D3EU-Net, a multimodal segmentation framework that integrates diffusion-based denoising with semantic and spatial conditioning to address these challenges. The model employs a transformer-based text encoder to incorporate descriptive prompts generated by a large language model, and a lightweight convolutional spatial encoder to extract prior structural cues from binary masks. These embeddings are fused within a conditioned U-Net architecture through cross-attention modules, enabling context-aware and noise-robust segmentation. Our approach models noise through an iterative diffusion process, acting as a regularizer that improves generalization under diverse conditions. Experiments on TNBC, MoNuSeg and GlaS datasets yield that D3EU-Net achieves Dice scores of 88.46%, 83.16% and 98.67% respectively, surpassing several state-of-the-art (SOTA) results. These results suggest that multimodal guidance, combining textual and spatial priors with diffusion, can enhance segmentation quality and adaptability for microscopic medical images. Additional results are available at https://github.com/SaptarshiPani/D3EU-Net

title: Pixel-Wise Classification of Placenta Multispectral Images using Multilinear Spectral Unmixing and Res-U-Net
authors: Juan Nicolás Mendoza-Chavarría, Daniel Ulises Campos-Delgado, Omar Gutiérrez-Navarro
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Multispectral imaging (MSI) is a powerful tool across various disciplines to inspect an scene and extract quantitative information by a non-contact and non-ionizing approach. However, in biomedical applications, the limited availability of labeled data combined with the inherent challenges posed by its high dimensionality makes it difficult for deep learning models to accurately classify such images. This work proposes a classification scheme that combines spectral unmixing with a Res-U-Net, and applies this pipeline to ex-vivo placenta MSI data. The unmixing stage serves two main purposes: (1) to extract physically interpretable spatial features from the MSI data, and (2) to reduce dimensionality while preserving key tissue information. Spectral unmixing is computed using a multilinear mixing model to capture nonlinear optical effects. The resulting abundance and nonlinear interaction maps are then used as input to a Res-U-Net for classification. For comparison purposes, two extra approaches were evaluated: the raw-MSI data applied to a Res-U-Net, and a base U-Net with the unmixed data. Our cross-validation results demonstrate that the proposed pipeline achieves more stable generalization performance, with approximately 13.3% higher validation accuracy compared to the second-best method, along with a faster convergence in the loss function and the lowest training time.

title: Regional Automation Server for Distribution Points
authors: Dmytro Danylchenko, Andrii Potryvai, Vladyslav Tsiupa
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The article presents a comparative analysis of the reliability of relay protection of substations using decentralized microprocessor terminals and a centralized protection and automation server. The study focuses on the probabilities of failures and false alarms in various schemes: serial, parallel, and server-based, taking into account redundancy. The results confirm the relevance of the transition to centralized and software-defined protection systems for modern substations.

title: Affordable and Scalable IoT Sensor Nodes for Sustainable Smart Farming
authors: Md Shahriar Kabir, Khokan Kumer Sarker, Khalid Mahmud Niloy, Md. Ismail Hossain Mofazzol, M.G. Mostofa Amin, Chaity Sarker
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Smart agriculture (SA) technologies based on the Internet of Things (IoT) have the potential to improve resource efficiency and sustainability; however, their adoption in Bangladesh and South Asia remains limited due to high costs and limited availability of sensor devices. To address these challenges, an affordable design is developed to enable broader adoption of smart agriculture practices. The system’s cost was reduced by using locally available components, a custom-designed PCB, and in-house waterproof enclosures, avoiding imported parts. To ensure suitability for harsh outdoor environments, commercially available non-weatherproof sensor circuit boards were housed in custom 3D-designed enclosures. Performance was optimized through field testing to ensure the system’s reliability. Optimization of temperature, light, and humidity sensors achieved correlations of 0.99, 0.90, and 0.90, respectively, against calibrated handheld instruments used for lab and field validation. Soil moisture and electrical conductivity sensors, stabilized by duty-cycled sensing via a switching circuit, showed correlations of 0.80 and 0.90, respectively, with the same reference. The final cost to build the sensor-based system was $113, considering all possible expenses, which is even lower than the cost of an imported sensor probe (the TEROS-12 costs $450). The developed design can help local manufacturers and stakeholders develop cost-effective solutions that are affordable for small- and medium-scale farmers.

title: Optimization of Faster R-CNN With Mobilenet For Lung Disease Detection on X-Rays
authors: Muhammad Raya Taufik, Wikky Fawwaz Al Maki
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: This study developed an optimized Faster R-CNN model with MobileNetV2 and MobileNetV3 Large backbones to detect lung diseases normal, lung opacity, pneumonia, and COVID-19 in chest X-ray images, aiming to balance detection accuracy and computational efficiency for resource constrained devices. MobileNetV2 uses return layers {4: 0, 7: 1, 14: 2, 18: 3} with input channels (32, 64, 160, 1280), while MobileNetV3 Large adopts {4: 0, 7: 1, 13: 2, 16: 3} and channels (40, 80, 160, 960), leveraging squeeze-and-excitation and hard-swish activation for enhanced feature extraction. A publicly available dataset containing annotated chest X-ray images of the four lung conditions was used. Preprocessing involved pixel normalization to [0,1], data augmentation, and resizing images to 224×224 pixels. The model was trained for 20 epochs using SGD optimizer, StepLR scheduler, mixed-precision training with GradScaler, and hyperparameter tuning with Optuna. Evaluation employed mean Average Precision (mAP) at IoU 0.5:0.95. MobileNetV3 Large achieved AP@0.5 of 0.9734, mAP of 0.8595, and APl of 0.8690, showing strong performance on large lesions. In contrast, MobileNetV2 yielded better APm (0.8358 vs. 0.7890) for small nodules, with a slightly higher mAP (0.8602). Detection confidence for pneumonia reached 1 using MobileNetV3 Large. Training showed stable convergence, although strict IoU mAP was below 0.9, and limited COVID-19 samples suggest a need for broader evaluation. This study presents an efficient lung screening approach, with potential for further optimization via pruning and quantization.

title: Linguistics-Driven Prompt Engineering: Empowering Large Language Models for In-Depth Grammatical Error Correction and Pedagogy
authors: Kaixi Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Current automated Grammatical Error Correction systems often fail as pedagogical tools because their feedback lacks deep linguistic rationale. To address this, our study introduces Linguistics-Driven Prompt Engineering: a framework that uses expert-designed prompts to guide a pre-trained Large Language Model to simulate a linguist’s diagnostic process without costly fine-tuning. We validated the framework in a comparative experiment on 1,000 samples, using quantitative metrics including Precision, Recall, F1-Score, and a novel Fine-Grained Objective Evaluation for benchmarking against a standard prompt. This research establishes a lightweight and efficient paradigm for creating intelligent tutoring systems that offer both superior accuracy and significantly enhanced pedagogical value.

title: The Public Chatter Bureau - A Framework for Cyber Threat Early Detection and Triage
authors: Dippu Kumar Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE International Carnahan Conference on Security Technology (ICCST)
abstract: The modern enterprise is facing a crisis of scale in vulnerability management. With the number of new Common Vulnerabilities and Exposures (CVEs) on pace to exceed 40,000 in 2024 alone, security teams are drowning in a firehose of alerts, while the average time for an attacker to exploit a new vulnerability has plummeted to just 15 days. This catastrophic compression of the “golden hour” for defense means that traditional, high-latency threat intelligence workflows are no longer viable. The current model, which waits for official reports, is a recipe for being perpetually one step behind the adversary. This paper details the architectural blueprint for The Public Chatter Bureau: a framework designed to close this critical time gap. It functions as an open-source intelligence agency, systematically ingesting the real-time chatter of the security community to detect the earliest signals of exploitation, quantify the potential risk from the discussion, and triage the overwhelming volume of disclosures into a prioritized queue. The framework provides a blueprint for transforming high-volume, unstructured public chatter into a prioritized stream of actionable cyber threat intelligence.

title: Research on High-Accuracy Trajectory Association for Dimension-Missing Targets
authors: Hao Lang, Qilin Song, Xiaoyu Hu, Juntao Yang, Yuezhu Xu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Aiming at the problem of multi-target track correlation caused by system deviation, noise interference and dimension mismatch in multi-sensor systems, this paper proposes a high-accuracy track correlation method for missing-dimensional targets. The method constructs training samples by performing time alignment and dimensional unification on data from different sensors, then applies Kalman filtering for noise reduction. A dual-branch spatio-temporal feature extraction network is designed: one branch employs a Long Short-Term Memory-based model to extract historical trajectory information features, while the other uses a Graph Convolutional Network-based model to extract spatial topological features. Features extracted from these two branches are then fused and concatenated to form the spatio-temporal features of the trajectory. Finally, spatiotemporal features from radar and electronic warfare tracks are input into a multi-layer perceptron-based similarity calculation module. Combined with the Hungarian algorithm, this achieves global optimal matching. Experimental results on simulation datasets demonstrate that this method effectively improves track association accuracy and stability. Ablation experiments further validate the effectiveness of each module. This research not only provides a novel solution for associating tracks of missing-dimensional target trajectories but also offers valuable insights for future related studies.

title: Monte Carlo Model of Inverse Compton Scattering Sources for Microbeam Radiation Therapy at Thomx
authors: G. Paterno, H. Priestley, L. Wright, S. Bugby, J. Duffy, K. Dupraz, M. Jacquet, A. Bravin, J. Spiga
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Microbeam Radiation Therapy (MRT) has emerged as a powerful modality in preclinical oncology, delivering spatially fractionated, high-dose X-ray microbeams that spare normal tissue while effectively targeting tumours. However, its reliance on large-scale synchrotron facilities has confined MRT research to synchrotrons, which represents a barrier to clinical translation. Recent progress in compact X-ray source technologies such as inverse Compton scattering (ICS) sources offer a potentially transformative opportunity to facilitate MRT's advancement by providing beams with similar characteristics. This work presents the first results of a Geant4-based Monte Carlo application applied to MRT, to evaluate the potential of photon beams generated via ICS sources for use in radiotherapy. We developed a program that can simulate various ICS sources, among which the ThomX ICS source recently commissioned in Orsay, France. The beam spectrum and quality are investigated, together with dose distributions in tissue-equivalent phantoms. By providing a beam characterisation, this work supports the ongoing development of compact sources for clinical MRT applications and aids in bridging the gap between accelerator physics and medical physics requirements.

title: Quartz-Free Direct-Coupling of BGO to UV-Enhanced MPPC for Improved Timing Performance in TOF PET
authors: D. Lee, R. Ota, S. R. Cherry, S.I. Kwon
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: TOF PET enhances the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of reconstructed images by precisely measuring the time difference between coincidence <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\gamma$</tex>-ray events, enabling more accurate diagnoses than conventional non-TOF PET. The accuracy of this time measurement is highly dependent on detector performance. Recently, efforts have been focused on utilizing Cerenkov photons generated by 511 keV gamma interactions in BGO to significantly improve timing response. Although quartz was introduced in newer MPPC models due to its superior optical properties compared to epoxy, it still presents a key limitation. The quartz layer introduces an optical interface and causes photon loss due to a refractive index mismatch with BGO. To overcome this limitation, we propose a novel structure that eliminates the quartz layer and directly couples the BGO to the MPPC surface. This approach reduces photon loss at the interface and minimizes lateral photon escape caused by internal reflection within the quartz layer. Four MPPC models were fabricated and evaluated. For a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$75 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex>-SPAD MPPC model, direct coupling improved CTR by 35 ps and FWTM by 180 ps compared to a conventional quartz-layer MPPC when tested with a 5 mm BGO scintillator.

title: Galet: a Geant4-Based Monte Carlo Simulation Platform for Modeling Space Radiation Effects on Advanced Semiconductor Devices
authors: I.-C. Cho, T. Aso, S.-W. Hsiao, Y.-C. Lin, T.-C. Chao, C.-M. Tan
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: As semiconductor technologies scale into the deep sub-micron regime, the susceptibility of electronic devices to space radiation has emerged as a critical design challenge. Accurate modeling of particle interactions with nanoscale microelectronic structures is essential for developing radiation-hardened systems. In this study, we introduce Galet, a Geant4-based Monte Carlo simulation platform specifically designed to investigate radiation effects in advanced semiconductor devices operating in harsh environments such as outer space. The Galet supports GDML-based geometry input, allowing the direct import of realistic device models from electronic design automation (EDA) tools. It also integrates radiation environment data from platforms such as SPENVIS and OMERE, enabling mission-specific source spectra for space-relevant particle simulations. As a demonstration, we implemented and simulated a 14 nm FinFET structure to evaluate spatially resolved energy deposition at nanometer scales. Galet offers a flexible and extensible framework for studying total ionizing dose (TID), single-event effects (SEE), and radiation-induced degradation in emerging semiconductor technologies.

title: Development of a Miniature Gamma Camera Based on Pseudo-Random Pattern
authors: S. Lee, D. Kim, C. Ko, J. Lee, M. Song, H. Lyu, M. Jeong
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Energetic Particle Sensor for the Identification and Localization of Originating Nuclei-Gamma (EPSILON-G) was developed as a gamma camera in previous research. This gamma camera employs a coded-aperture mask based on a centered mosaic Modified Uniformly Redundant Arrays (MURAs). However, when the gamma-ray source is located outside the field of view, the MURA based mask produces artifacts on the opposite side of the actual source position. To address this issue, this study developed a coded-aperture mask based on a pseudo-random pattern. To validate the pseudo-random pattern, computational simulations were performed using Monte Carlo NPaticle eXtended (MCNPX)-PoliMi. The source term, defined to emit 662 keV gamma rays, was positioned 100 cm away from the coded-aperture mask at three separate locations: in front of, to the left of, and to the right of the mask. Computational simulations were conducted separately for two types of coded-aperture masks, and the results were compared. In addition, the two types of coded-aperture masks were implemented on the actual gamma camera to comparatively evaluate their performance. In this study, a miniature gamma camera composed of a Ce-doped 11 × 11 Gadolinium Aluminum Gallium Garnet (GAGG(Ce)) scintillator array, an 8 × 8 silicon photomultiplier (SiPM) array, a data processing board was used. Each gamma camera equipped with a different coded-aperture mask was evaluated in terms of image quality, field of view, angular resolution, and imaging sensitivity.

title: In Vivo Gold Nanoparticle Imaging in Mice for Tumor Detection Using SiPM-Based Photon-Counting CT
authors: Y. Furuta, M. Arimoto, F. Lucyana, M. Oshima, S. Kobayashi, H. Kawashima, K. Okumura, N. Ohno, K. Murakami, T. Tomoda, J. Kataoka, R. Minagawa, T. Ro, S. Terazawa, Y. Maeno
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: X-ray computed tomography (CT) is a technology for nondestructively visualizing the internal structure of a subject and is widely used in various fields, including the medical field. Photoncounting computed tomography (PC-CT), the focus of this research, detects X-rays on a photon-byphoton basis, allowing acquisition of energy-resolved information. This enables identification of substances within the body and quantitative evaluation of their density, offering the potential for new diagnostic and therapeutic applications. In recent years, attention has been drawn to the combined use of PC-CT and the enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect, which facilitates the accumulation of nanoparticles in tumor tissue, as a promising approach in cancer treatment. We developed a PC-CT system incorporating high-speed scintillators (YGAG:Ce) and silicon photomultipliers (SiPMs), specifically multi-pixel photon counters (MPPCs), which are optical semiconductor devices. In this study, we transplanted cancer cells into mice and conducted in vivo imaging experiments to evaluate the distribution and accumulation of gold nanoparticles (AuNPs) using our PC-CT system. These AuNPs, which tend to accumulate in tumor regions, were used as X-ray contrast agents due to their excellent imaging contrast. CT scans were performed after AuNP injection, and the resulting images across multiple energy bands were analyzed. The results revealed a clear trend of gold accumulation in certain regions of the liver, indicating the potential of PC-CT for tumor detection using AuNPs.

title: Deep Learning-Guided Image Reconstruction for a Dedicated Dual-Panel Prostate PET Scanner
authors: A. Saberi Manesh, M. Amini, Y. Salimi, K. Doroud, C. Williams, T. Williams, H. Arabi, H. Zaidi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Prostate imaging with limited-angle PET scanners poses challenges in spatial resolution and artifact suppression, particularly when compact geometries are used. This study proposes a hybrid image reconstruction framework designed for a dual-panel, movable PET scanner developed specifically for prostate imaging. The scanner features two opposing modules composed of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 4$</tex> detectors, operating in three sequential acquisitions to extend the field of view while preserving a compact form. The proposed reconstruction pipeline integrates conventional Time-of-Flight Maximum Likelihood Expectation Maximization (TOF-MLEM), a deep learning enhancement stage using a 3D convolutional neural network (CNN), and a final refinement using Maximum A Posteriori Expectation Maximization (MAP-EM) guided by CNN-predicted priors. List-mode reconstruction was conducted on synthetic datasets derived from real <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{68}$</tex> Ga-PSMA PET/CT images, cropped to match the scanner geometry. The CNN was trained using MLEM images (after 10 iterations) as input and corresponding reference images, employing a combined loss of MSE and MAE. The deep learning model significantly improved spatial detail, and its predictions served as priors in MAP-EM reconstruction with a regularization factor of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\beta=0.5$</tex>. The proposed method was quantitatively assessed using PSNR, SSIM, and NRMSE metrics. PSNR improved from 18.4 dB using TOF-MLEM to 25.8 dB with MAP-EM reconstruction, Compared to TOF-MLEM, MAP-EM showed marked improvements, SSIM increased from 0.37 to 0.74 and NRMSE was reduced from 0.13 to 0.06, demonstrating that integrating learned priors can effectively suppress elongation artifacts, enhance structural accuracy, and improve robustness in such challenging geometrical constraints.

title: Alpha Response of Microchannels in a Diamond Detector
authors: P. Parshi, W.-T. Hsu, C. V. Patricelli, C. R. Webb, L. Harrill, B. K. Canfield, E. Lukosi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Diamond-based alpha detectors are highly effective for detecting alpha particles due to their exceptional properties, including a wide bandgap, high radiation hardness, and fast charge carrier mobility. These characteristics contribute to excellent energy resolution, low noise, and reliable operation in harsh environments, making them suitable for applications in nuclear research and security. This study presents the fabrication and preliminary testing of a diamond-based detector with integrated microchannels (MCs) designed to enhance geometric efficiency by minimizing alpha particle displacement prior to detection. The detector was fabricated using femtosecond laser processing and reactive ion etching on a diamond substrate, followed by chromium/gold metallization for signal collection. A low-activity uranium source was electroplated onto a tungsten probe and aligned into one of the MCs. Monte Carlo simulations using MCNP were used to estimate expected alpha counts, which showed reasonable agreement with measured spectra, validating the detector design and demonstrating its feasibility for low-activity alpha spectrometry.

title: Novel Multi-Channel High-Current Led Calibration Light Source for the Intensified Camera of the Herd Calorimeter
authors: C. Zhao, Y. Hu, Z. Wang, J. Han, X. Liu, Y. Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In the High Energy comic-Radiation Detection facility (HERD), each intensified camera of the calorimeter (CALO) reads out over 7,000 wavelength-shifting (WLS) fibers. Given the 10 -year operational lifetime of HERD, precise calibration of the gain for each fiber pixel and the crosstalk between pixels across a wide dynamic range is critical. To achieve these goals, a novel multichannel high-current light emitting diode (LED) calibration light source is presented. The calibration system features cascaded shift registers with AND-gate buffering to independently control multiple LED channels using a shared trigger signal, enabling precise adjustment of LED activation duration and frequency. A single-pole double-throw analog switch (SPDT) converts two direct current (DC) voltages into a pulsed signal for LED driving. The combination of a digital-toanalog converter (DAC) and a DC-to-DC converter (DC/DC) ensures accurate brightness adjustment. Moreover, energy storage capacitors are incorporated to supply high transient currents during LED activation. A 138-channel prototype has been developed and tested, exhibiting a wide light intensity range equivalent to 0.7 to 320,000 minimum ionizing particles (MIPs), a uniformity exceeding 99% and negligible electrical crosstalk. The modular design allows for channel expansion without additional inter-board cabling or increased power supply capacity.

title: Simulation of the Performance of the Neurosphere Pet Insert for 7T-MRI
authors: P. Galve, J. M. Udias, J. L. Herraiz, F. Arias-Valcayo, M. Scipioni, M. S. Allen, L. Byars, M. Judenhofer, C. Catana
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The Human Dynamic NeuroChemical Connectome (HDNCC) scanner is a novel braindedicated scanner that integrates a high spatio-temporal resolution PET insert (the NeuroSphere PET) with a 7T MRI scanner. The spherical scanner design offers a solid angle coverage of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{\sim 7 0 \%}$</tex> around the human head, which increases PET sensitivity improving signal-to-noise ratio, the ultimate limit to the minimum frame duration in dynamic studies. The PET system is composed of 872 detector blocks made of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 0 x 1 0} 1.6 \times 1.6 \times 26 ~\text{mm}^{3}$</tex> LSO crystal arrays read by a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4$</tex> array of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex> MPPCs (S13546H-2009, Hamamatsu Photonics). A light guide of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$380 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> thickness has been applied to the entry face of each block, enhancing light sharing between crystals to allow DOI identification. The detectors achieve energy resolution below <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 3} \boldsymbol{\%}$</tex> and DOI resolution of 7 mm, sufficient for achieving a homogeneous 1.5 mm spatial resolution across the brain. In this work, we have evaluated the system performance of the NeuroSphere PET based on simulated results with UMC-PET. Following the NEMA protocol, we have estimated the expected system spatial resolution, count rates of prompt, random, scatter, and true events, and the noise equivalent curves (NEC). Further estimations of sensitivity in specific regions of interest, like the whole brain or cortex, have been evaluated, achieving more than 30 % of detected coincidences. The estimated sensitivity values show potential for pushing the temporal resolution of dynamic PET imaging close to functional MRI performance.

title: Redesign Towards Upscale of a Pixellated 65-nm ASIC for UV With 20 e– Noise
authors: L. Nassi, A. Ciavarella-Ciavarella, G. Borghi, M. Carminati, S. Farina, M. Uslenghi, C. E. Fiorini
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Spectroscopic observations in the far and extreme ultraviolet (FUV/EUV) spectral regions are of great interest in various scientific fields, such as Solar Physics, interstellar medium physics, and planetary exospheres studies. In this work, we present an improved version of MIRA (MIcrochannelplate Readout ASIC), an Application Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) designed to be coupled with a microchannel plate (MCP) for photon counting in future UV spectrometers and imagers operating in the 55-200 nm range. While the first MIRA prototype demonstrated low noise (ENC <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=20 \mathrm{e}{-}$</tex>) and high spatial resolution with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$32 \times 32$</tex> pixel matrix and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$35 \times 35 \mu ~\mathrm{m} 2$</tex> pixel pitch, its scalability was limited by power consumption. In the new version, we redesigned the analog front-end and pixel architecture to reduce power dissipation per pixel by a factor of five, enabling higher integration density and larger detection area. The updated ASIC maintains the low noise performance and implements a new adaptive biasing stage that allows pixels to adapt to power supply drops. We present the design innovations and simulation results from the updated prototype, confirming its suitability for compact, high-resolution MCP readouts with extended scalability for future space missions.

title: Self-Supervised Early Stopping for End-To-End PET Reconstruction With Implicit Regularization Through Neural-Network Architectures
authors: N. Taheri, Y. Moussaoui, S. Moussaoui, D. Mateus, S. Stute
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Neural networks (NN) can serve as implicit regularizers in unsupervised PET image reconstruction by encoding prior information through their architecture. However, such methods are prone to overfitting if training continues too long, leading to noise amplification. In this work, we study the variability of end-to-end PET reconstruction using Deep Image Prior and SIREN architectures, and evaluate a self-supervised early stopping (ES) strategy based on the windowed moving variance (WMV) of the reconstruction sequence. We design experiments to isolate the effects of weight initialization, random input, and PET simulation variability, and demonstrate that the WMV-based ES method yields reconstructions close to the optimal stopping point. Our results show that self-supervised ES is feasible and enables implicit regularization through NNs without being altered by using explicit priors.
