title: Privacy-Preserving Cross-Client Recommender Systems With Fully-Separable Graph Neural Networks
authors: Yuhao Zhang, Weiwei Zhao, Changhui Hu
abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) effectively model long-range dependencies by capturing high-order relationships in user-item graphs, emerging as a mainstream paradigm for building personalized recommender services within distributed service environments. However, interaction data contains highly sensitive user behavior, and centralized modeling faces significant leakage risks. While existing privacy-preserving schemes aim to address this, they lack balance in privacy-utility trade-offs and comprehensive protection. To this end, we introduce PRGNN, a privacy-preserving framework based on a fully-separable GNN, which achieves effective protection of graph structures and node features through cross-client collaborative learning of distributed subgraphs. We first propose a high-order neighborhood aggregation module (HAM), which adopts functional encryption to realize secure multi-hop propagation through self-aggregation of local adjacency matrices, protecting the privacy of the graph structure. Then, a cross-domain secure sharing module (CSM) is designed to achieve secure feature data sharing from client domains to the cloud domain based on the output of HAM. Finally, the privacy-preserving training module (PTM) integrates HAM with CSM to achieve parameter updates. Experiments on three benchmark datasets show PRGNN achieves accuracy comparable to centralized GNNs. Compared with similar privacy-preserving schemes, its modeling efficiency is improved by at least 22.06%, and the communication overhead is reduced by at least <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$1.62\times$</tex-math></inline-formula>.

title: Multi-Temporal Resolution-Guided 3D Imaging for Array-Based Single-Photon LiDAR
authors: Kai Qiao, Yu Chang, Zefang Xu, Fei Yin, Chang Su, Liyu Liu, Tianye Liu, Chunliang Liu, Jinshou Tian, Xing Wang
abstract: Using a 1550 nm array-based single-photon LiDAR system, we demonstrated depth profiling of both static and dynamic targets up to a distance of 10 kilometers. The system comprises a 1550 nm pulsed laser source, a bistatic optical transceiver system, and a 64×64 InGaAs/InP Single Photon Avalanche Diode (SPAD) array camera, with an angular resolution of 20 μrad. By employing a recovery optimization algorithm guided by multi-scale time resolution, we utilized unsupervised learning methods to achieve three-dimensional (3D) image segmentation. Subsequently, we accomplished pixel-level algorithm matching, facilitating efficient long-range 3D imaging reconstruction with significantly reduced binary frame data. Notably, after offline processing of real point cloud data collected by our system, we obtained depth images of various targets within a 4 to 10 km range. Furthermore, we successfully captured dynamic 3D video of targets at a frame rate exceeding 50 fps. The video was reconstructed using offline processing with an average of fewer than 2 photons returned per pixel. These depth results highlight the potential of the proposed system and reconstructed method for depth profiling, feature extraction, and target recognition of distant static and dynamic targets.

title: Attenuation Map Synthesis from Histoimages with Varying Axial-FOVs
authors: C. Jiang, C. Sun, Y. Li, Y. Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Deep learning (DL) for synthesizing attenuation maps (μ-maps) from PET data-such as non-attenuation-corrected (NAC) images and histo-images- offers a promising CT-less attenuation correction. Histo-images, derived directly from raw PET data, bypass iterative reconstructions required for NAC images, enabling faster preprocessing. DL-based method typically struggles to generalize across different tracers and scanners with varying axial lengths. In this work, we propose a mixed-training strategy that jointly optimizes a 3D U-Net model on multi-axial-length (50-150 cm) and multi-tracer <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$({ }^{18}$</tex> F-FDG, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{18}$</tex> F-FAPI, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{18}$</tex> F-PSMA, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{68}$</tex> Ga-DOTATATE) datasets, using histo-images derived from PET raw data as inputs. Results demonstrated that the mixed-training strategy outperforms conventional method in all axial-FOV configurations, offering a scalable solution for clinical environments with heterogeneous PET protocols.

title: Water Luminescence Under Electron-Beam Irradiation Below the Cherenkov Threshold: Insight Into the Source
authors: K. Enomoto, Y. Nagao, T. Yabe, M. Tsuda, M. Sakai, M. Yamaguchi, S. Yamasaki, S. Kano, N. Nagasawa, N. Kawachi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This work describes a chemical approach to identify the source of luminescence emitted during the irradiation of water at 245 keV electrons, below the Cherenkov threshold. The method involves nitrate scavenging and luminescence energy transfer processes. Scavenging techniques are used to reveal the roles of excited and ionized states formed during the initial ionization of water, resulting in the deactivation of the luminescence source, its precursors, or both. A decrease in luminescence intensity yields with increasing nitrate concentration; however, residual luminescence persists even at high nitrate levels. We propose two distinct luminescence pathways-chemical and physical: radiative decay of a highly excited state of water and electromagnetic emission via dipole interactions, independent of Cherenkov-type phase matching.

title: Validation of Simulation Models for Seafood Radioactivity Inspection Systems
authors: D. Lee, J. Shin, H. Seo, S.M. Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The discharge of treated radioactive water from Fukushima in 2023 has raised concerns about radioactive contamination in seafood, increasing the importance of radiation monitoring in Korea. In previous research, we developed rapid seafood radioactivity inspection systems (RS-RISs) using NaI(Tl) and PVT (polyvinyl toluene) scintillators, respectively, to monitor radioactive materials in seafood. These devices are capable of determining the concentration of radioactivity in a sample, and the parameters required for the calculation were derived from Monte Carlo simulations. In this study, the accuracy of the simulation models of the developed devices was evaluated by comparing experimental and calculated results obtained under the same measurement conditions. Three test items (i.e., oyster, dried laver, and fishcake) were used for the model validation, and a Cs-137 point source (⌼ 18 μ Ci, depending on the experiment date) was positioned within a sample container at the center and the corner of the bottom, and the center of the sample (8 cm, 14.5 cm, and 18.5 cm from the bottom for oyster, fishcake, dried laver, respectively). The background radiation was also simulated based on the measurements and included in the source spectra. The differences between the measured and simulated spectra within the ROI were found to be less than 5% for all samples and source conditions. Hence, it was concluded that the parameters calculated by the simulation model to determine radioactivity concentrations were reliable.

title: Optimization of FPGA Core for MEMS-Based Terahertz Detection at Room Temperature
authors: M. Cautero, B. Bertoni, L. Alborghetti, D. Giuressi, G. Cautero, S. Zanotto, A. Pitanti
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Room temperature detectors based on microelectromechanical systems (MEMS) offer significant advantages in size, cost, and integration compared to cryogenic alternatives, but require highly efficient readout electronics to achieve competitive sensitivity and dynamic range. This work presents the design and optimization of a field-programmable gate array (FPGA) core tailored for the readout and signal processing of MEMS sensors designed for terahertz (THz) detection at room temperature. We developed a modular and reconfigurable FPGA architecture that interfaces directly with an array of MEMS resonators characterized by a frequency addressing scheme. The core includes signal generation using a numerically controlled oscillator (NCO) for actuation and demodulation, digital lock-in amplification, and a proportional-integral (PI) feedback control for automatic resonance tracking through a phase-locked loop (PLL) architecture. Furthermore, the core is responsible for the completely automated search of the resonances, exploiting the finite number of bits of integral component within the PI. The number of multipliers is optimized through a time-multiplexed scheme that can be configured according to the number of sensors in use. The system was implemented on an Intel Cyclone V GX and validated using a linear array of eight MEMS bolometric sensors. Depending on the parameters used, both high responsivity (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>100$</tex> Hz modulation bandwidth) and sensitivity sufficient to detect black-body radiation from the human body under ambient conditions have been demonstrated. This FPGA-based approach provides a scalable and versatile solution for portable array-based THz imaging systems.

title: A calibration method for the relative orientation between camera and two-axis turntable
authors: Mingkun Liu, Guangkun Feng, Fulin Liu, Zheng Gong, Zhenzhong Wei
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The calibration of relative orientation between the camera and the two-axis turntable directly affects the measurement accuracy of the aircraft’s attitude and position for the aircraft pose visual measurement system (APVMS). Conventional hand-eye calibration methods exhibit limited precision due to the camera’s extrinsic parameter errors. The upright-inverted mirror method is incapable of calibrating the roll angle, and it becomes unsuitable when there exists a significant displacement between the camera and the turntable rotation center. Therefore, we propose a method based on the upright-inverted mirror and plumb lines. Firstly, based on the 3D marker corresponding to the principal point in the upright mirror as a reference, we calibrate the yaw and pitch angles between the turntable inner frame and the zooming camera by calculating the pixel displacement of the 2D marker between the upright mirror and the inverted mirror. In addition, we calibrate the roll angle by identifying the plumb line whose inclination angle is independent of the pitch angle of the turntable. To obtain image features robustly, we employ an affine transformation method based on keypoint matching to extract the 2D marker in the inverted mirror and use the Gaussian curve fitting technique to extract the centerline of the plumb line. Through simulation, we analyze the impact of different error factors on calibration accuracy and determine the number of plumb lines and the times of turntable pitching. Furthermore, we validate the superiority of the proposed method compared to the hand-eye calibration method on noise robustness in calibrating the rotation angles within the APVMS. This proposed method can be applied to calibrate the rotation angles between the inner frame and the camera simply and effectively.

title: Feature Fusion Transformer for Tumor Segmentation With Multimodal Medical Images
authors: Z. Zhu, Y. Li, C. Lu, G. Mok
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Accurate tumor delineation in nuclear medicine (e.g., PET, SPECT) and MRI is crucial but challenging due to lesion variability across organs and modalities. This study develops <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F}^{3}$</tex>ormer, a transformer-based model to enhance multimodal (PET/CT, MRI) tumor segmentation for reliable detection and characterization.The proposed Feature Fusion Transformer (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{F}^{3}$</tex>ormer) segments tumors by fusing combined imaging modalities through two key attention mechanisms: spatialwise (capturing multiscale features) and channel-wise (adaptively weighting features across channels). These components are fused to combine metabolic and anatomical information for precise lesion delineation. Evaluated on autoPET 2022/2023 (whole-body FDG-PET/CT) and BRATS (brain MRI) datasets, our model achieved state-of-the-art performance, surpassing prior methods in Dice scores and lesion detection. On autoPET (utilizing both PET/CT), it obtained a tumor Dice of 81.86 %, FPV of 1.4426, FNV of 3.7734, HD95 of 0.4260, and MSD of 0.5391. On BrsTS, it achieved Dice scores of 78.84 % (NCR), 87.28% (ED), and 86.22% (ET), representing improvements up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$+0.90 \%$</tex> over prior methods. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{F}^{3}$</tex>ormer demonstrated robustness across modalities and tumor types, excelling in challenging whole-body and brain segmentation. By improving multimodal imaging fusion via attention, it enhances lesion quantification and supports diagnostics/therapy planning (e.g., radiotherapy targeting). Enabling consistent, automated delineation, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{F}^{3}$</tex>ormer advances personalized oncologic management.

title: Ultrafast Timing Performance of Hybrid Perovskite-Based Metapixels for ToF-PET Applications
authors: R. Latella, G. Niu, A. J. Gonzalez, P. Lecoq, G. Konstantinou
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Developing novel scintillator materials is key to surpassing the performance limitations of current Time-of-Flight Positron Emission Tomography (ToF-PET) systems, especially regarding Coincidence Time Resolution (CTR). In this work, we evaluate the timing behavior of several hybrid scintillator pixels that include 2D lead bromide perovskite compounds in both vertical and horizontal configurations, referred to as metapixels and flatpixels, respectively. Despite the mechanical fragility and suboptimal optical coupling of these first-generation prototypes, we report promising results with CTR values approaching the ones of our <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 3 \times 5 ~\text{mm}^{3}$</tex> LYSO:Ce,Ca reference pixel detector. Furthermore, a small subset of events acquired with a horizontal singlelayer Perovskite structure yielded an unprecedented CTR value of 43 ps, outperforming our reference pixel. This finding highlights the timing potential of the perovskite compound, confirming this material's ultrafast radioluminescence decay time and high light yield.

title: Effects of Dark Counts and Optical Crosstalk in SiPMs Coupled to BGO Crystals
authors: D. Lee, S. Dolinsky, M. Yi, S. R. Cherry, S.I. Kwon
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The dark counts of a silicon photomultiplier (SiPM) are a crucial factor affecting detector performance, especially when used in conjunction with moderate light yield scintillators such as bismuth germanate (BGO). Compared to Lu-based scintillators, BGO exhibits a longer primary decay time constant of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 300 ~\text{ns}$</tex>, making it more susceptible to the influence of dark counts and optical crosstalk. In this study, we investigate variations in total count rates by altering the crosssectional area and length of BGO and compare the effects of different reflector materials, including Teflon, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{TiO}_{2}, \text{BaSO}_{4}$</tex>, and ESR. The experiments were carried out using a Broadcom NUVMT SiPM. Signal acquisitions were performed using an oscilloscope, and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{22} \text{Na}$</tex> point source was employed to obtain the energy spectra of BGO crystals with different reflector conditions. The energy resolution of the 511 keV photopeak was calculated to evaluate the influence of reflector type. Through this study, we analyze the relationship between BGO cross-sectional area, reflector type, and SiPM total noise characteristics, providing valuable insights for optimizing detector performance for BGO.

title: C-CTX: Cubic-Checkerboard Context Entropy Model for Learned Image Compression
authors: Shiyu Feng, Linwei Zhu, Yun Zhang, Na Li, Shiqi Wang
abstract: Learned Image Compression (LIC) has achieved superior performance in recent years, of which the context entropy model is an important component. However, in the context entropy model, there is no deterministic correlation between neighboring channels, and it is difficult to capture inter-channel correlation as well as spatial correlation for further improving the performance. To address this issue, a Cubic-Checkerboard conTeXt entropy model (C-CTX) for LIC is proposed in this work, which is able to refer uniformly across the channel domain and maintain the correlations in the spatial domain. To make neighboring channels have more similar distribution, Cubic Checkerboard Mask (CCM) with channel- wise mask convolution is utilized to achieve uniform distribution in different domains and Channel Wise Re-Arrangement (CWRA) is performed in terms of entropy. Based on CCM and CWRA, two Feature Disentangle Modules (FDMs) are designed in C-CTX to project the context information within sub-spaces for catching spatial correlation and channel correlation separately. Extensive experimental evaluations show that our method outperforms the state-of-the-art works on six datasets, i.e., Kodak, Tecnick, CLIC'20, CLIC'21, CLIC'22, and JPEG-AI.

title: Development of a Low Temperature Drift SiPM Power Supply Unit
authors: X. Liu, G. Gong
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Silicon photomultiplier (Sipm) as a type of solid-state photosensor is widely used in radiation detection. It has the advantages of high gain, compact size, compatibility with magnetic fields, and low operating voltage (approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30-50 ~\mathrm{V}$</tex>). However, its temperature sensitivity affects the stability of the gain. For the peak position of measurements in portable spectrometers, it will drift by about <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pm 10 \%$</tex> with temperature range from 0° C to 50° C. The common laboratory equipment operates within a temperature range of 0° C to 40° C. Our company now requires a radiation measurement device that can operate at a temperature range of 40° C to 50° C. Therefore, we have developed a programmable Sipm power supply unit. We tested the accuracy of the SiPM power supply voltage output under the temperature range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-30^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$</tex> to 60° C, and the maximum deviation was less than 1 % overvoltage. We also used four common manufacturers' SiPMs to compare the peak position of the 662 kev full-energy peak of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{137} \text{Cs}$</tex>. The maximum drift was less than 4 %.

title: 3D Reconstruction of Anatomical Changes in Patients Undergoing Carbon-Ion Radiotherapy(CIRT)
authors: P. Schlegel, R. Kirchgässner, P. Ochoa-Parra, E. Bartelme, R. Mikut, O. Jäkel, M. Martisikova
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Carbon-ion radiation therapy (CIRT) offers superior dose conformity and biological effectiveness compared to conventional photon-based radiotherapy. However, maintaining treatment accuracy throughout a multi-day therapy is currently based on CTs with a frequency determined by physician experience. Therefore, there is a clear need for tools enabling continuous and objective (semi-)automatic assessment. Our group has developed a custom multi-detector system using pixel-based Timepix3 detectors to capture secondary charged particles during therapy, aiming at clinical in-vivo monitoring without added CT scans. The system is already in clinical evaluation in a trial at the Heidelberg Ion Beam Therapy Center (HIT) with skull-base and neck cancer patients. Building on our own work in secondary particle-based depth detection, we now extend the approach to enable full three-dimensional reconstruction of anatomical changes by analyzing variations in secondary emissions across treatment fractions. This study presents a robust method for detecting and 3D localizing anatomical changes solely from secondary particle data. We introduce a multi-perspective reconstruction approach that enables volumetric mapping of anatomical variation by combining spatial and frequency-domain analysis. This dual-domain strategy improves sensitivity to subtle anatomical shifts while ensuring robustness against patient variability and noise. The reconstructed changes can be co-registered with planning CTs, offering visual and quantitative insight into their potential impact on dose distribution. Validation using simulations and irradiation experiments with PMMA head phantoms demonstrates the method's accuracy and robustness, supporting its role in adaptive treatment strategies for long-term precision in dose delivery.

title: Effects of SiPM in-Orbit Radiation Damage on GRB Spectral Analysis in the Grid Mission
authors: X. Pan, Z. Yang, X. Zheng, H. Gao, Q. Liu, Q. Wang, C. Li, C. Wang, L. Li, M. Zeng, H. Feng, Z. Zeng
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The Gamma-Ray Integrated Detectors (GRID) mission utilizes compact gamma-ray detectors on nanosatellites in low-Earth orbit (LEO) to monitor gamma-ray bursts (GRBs) and other transient sources. The detectors are based on silicon photomultiplier (SiPM) arrays coupled with GAGG:Ce scintillators. Although SiPMs offer advantages for space applications, their in-orbit radiation damage results in performance degradation that may affect gamma-ray spectral reconstruction. To address this challenge, this study investigates the effect of SiPM radiation damage on GRB spectral analysis in GRID detectors. We first quantify the radiation-induced deterioration in energy resolution and then integrate these effects into the detector response matrix (DRM). To study its influence, we compare spectral fitting results with deteriorated and non-deteriorated DRMs using detected GRB data. Our results demonstrate that, for detectors in the GRID mission with two years of in-orbit operation, while radiation damage significantly influences the energy resolution and causes deviation in the DRMs, the resulting biases in spectral fitting results (photon index and cutoff energy) are less than their own 1σ uncertainties, indicating a statistically insignificant impact on scientific conclusions. This finding confirms the feasibility of SiPM-based detectors for long-term GRB monitoring missions in LEO. Furthermore, the proposed methodology for incorporating radiation effects into spectral analysis provides a reference for other SiPM-based space missions in the future.

title: A Study of Efficiency Calibration for a Complex Source-Detector Geometry Using 3D Scanner in Gamma Spectrometry
authors: J. Lee, S. Cho, H. Kim, J. Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We present a new method for gamma spectrometry efficiency calibration using 3D scanning-based modeling of source-detector geometry. In conventional efficiency calibration, accurate efficiency calibration requires the sample to replicate the geometry of certified reference material (CRM). However, when the sample has a complex shape, reproducing an identical geometry becomes difficult of infeasible. To address this issue, we utilize 3D scan data to extract the relative positions of the source and the detector. These spatial relationships are implemented in Monte Carlo simulation to calculate detection efficiency under the actual measurement geometry. The proposed method was experimentally validated using CRM-filled sources with irregular shapes. The calculated activities showed agreement within a 5 % significance level. This proposed method is particularly advantageous when source-detector geometry is complex or when the geometry is not fixed. It eliminates the need for physical repositioning and allows rapid modeling of the actual measurement geometry. Moreover, it offers the reliability and applicability of gamma spectrometry by modeling the source-detector geometry more accurately across a wide range of measurement geometries.

title: Large-Scale Constrained Multiobjective Optimization Based on Variable Adaptive Optimization and Population Reconstruction_supp1-3641668.pdf
authors: Kangjia Qiao
abstract: Constrained multiobjective evolutionary algorithms (CMOEAs) have been proposed to address constrained multiobjective optimization problems (CMOPs), and they have shown promising performance on small-scale problems. However, for CMOPs with large-scale decision variables, complex coupling relationships among variables and the huge search space make the algorithm converge slowly and difficult to find feasible solutions. Therefore, this study proposes a large-scale CMOEA based on variable adaptive optimization and population reconstruction to better solve large-scale CMOPs. First, a variable adaptive optimization strategy is developed in the global search stage, where convergence-related and diversity-related variables are adaptively selected for optimization. This strategy reduces the variable optimization difficulty caused by complex coupling relationships and explores the entire search space to locate regions near the constrained Pareto front (CPF). Then, in the local search stage, an archive-assisted population reconstruction strategy is proposed to generate an initial population by using promising solutions from the global search stage to rapidly guide the population towards the CPF. The experiments are conducted on 43 benchmark problems with up to 1000 decision variables and five real-world problems. Results show that the proposed method has better performance than other latest algorithms.

title: Critical Current Properties of FST on Simple Coated Conductor Architecture
authors: A. Angrisani Armenio, A. Masi, L. Piperno, G. Celentano, A. Mancini
abstract: Coated conductors (CCs) based on iron-based superconductors (IBS) represent a cost-effective alternative to high-temperature superconductors (HTS). Among them, the FeSe<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0.5</sub>Te<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0.5</sub> (FST) compound is the simplest in the IBS family, demonstrating excellent properties as an epitaxial film. These characteristics make it highly suitable for low-temperature and high-field applications, providing advantages over low-temperature superconductors. Present studies have demonstrated the feasibility of a simple architecture that provides a single metallic buffer layer for the subsequent growth of the superconductor film. From the analysis of the critical current density (J<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">C</sub>), these films exhibit excellent superconducting properties both in temperature and in an applied magnetic field, even compared to similar samples grown on single crystals like CaF<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sub>, with a value of around 2 MA/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> at 4.2 K in self-field, and greater than 0.1 MA/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> at 4.2 K up to 17.5 T. Moreover, the angular behavior of J<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">C</sub> at different applied magnetic fields shows an almost isotropic behavior, thanks to a large peak when the field is applied perpendicular to the crystallographic ab-plane. This effective pinning landscape may be related to nanostructured grains with a high density of low-angle boundaries, as evidenced by microstructural analysis.

title: Study on Aluminum Melting by Superconducting DC Induction Heating
authors: Tomonori Watanabe, Satoshi Fukui, Mitsuho Furuse
abstract: Direct current (DC) induction heating using a superconducting magnet to supply molten aluminum efficiently and in a short time was investigated. In the DC induction heating system, aluminum samples in the sample holder are rotated around a rotation axis orthogonal to the magnetic field. To apply a strong magnetic field to the samples, the conduction-cooled split coil pair consisting of eight rectangular REBCO double pancake (DP) coils with an inductance of about 200 mH each was fabricated and confirmed to generate the designed magnetic field. Observations of molten aluminum samples in previous experiments and analysis using Hartmann numbers indicate that the movement of molten aluminum in the holder reduces the velocity of rotation in a magnetic field. Wrapping the aluminum samples with stainless-steel sheets and fixing them in the sample holder, the molten samples were able to rotate smoothly with the holder in the magnetic field. A melting test was performed by rotating the aluminum sample at 1,115 rpm in a magnetic field of about 900 mT using a split coil pair, and it was confirmed that the aluminum sample could be completely melted. Measurements of the motor input revealed that this is a highly efficient melting method and enables aluminum melting in a short period of time.

title: From Deserts to Hubs: A Data-Driven Framework for Mapping Innovation Productivity in the U.S.
authors: Inam Ullah Khan, Khaled Abdelghany, Terrance Pohlen, Gautam Das, Eric Griffin, Victor Fishman
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Innovation is a fundamental driver of economic growth, regional competitiveness, and societal well-being. Nonetheless, its benefits remain unevenly distributed, with many regions, so called “innovation deserts,” struggling to translate potential into productivity due to systemic barriers and limited insight into the drivers of innovation. Motivated by this disparity, this article presents a novel data-driven framework for analyzing and benchmarking innovation productivity across the U.S. counties, identifying key determinants that drive regional innovation performance. The study covers over 3200 U.S. counties and includes 108 attributes spanning innovation outputs, demographics, education levels, STEM participation, internet connectivity, business sizes, and economic indicators. The framework comprises three integrated modules: 1) a hybrid feature selection mechanism combining random forest importance scores with mutual information criteria to identify influential factors; 2) a nonlinear dimensionality reduction module employing kernel-based principal component analysis to mitigate the curse of dimensionality; and 3) a particle swarm optimized XGBoost model (PSO-XGBoost) enabling sensitivity analysis and scenario-based forecasting. The framework demonstrates superior predictive performance (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> >0.81) compared to five other state-of-the art boosting algorithms. The analysis uncovers nonlinear relationships between key attributes and innovation outcomes, facilitating benchmarking of innovation productivity and quantifying targeted interventions to foster inclusive innovation ecosystems. The proposed framework offers policymakers interpretable, actionable insights for evidence-based regional innovation development. In particular, this study contributes a novel framework to identify innovation deserts and benchmark regional performance at a national scale.

title: Dynamic Graph Convolutional Network With Spatiotemporal and Multiscale Feature Fusion for Multistep Traffic Flow Prediction
authors: Youcai Cheng, Shumei Bao, Yuhao Ke, Jiaxin Chen, Mengyang Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: Accurate multistep traffic flow prediction is crucial for intelligent transportation systems (ITS). Existing graph convolutional networks (GCNs) still have limitations. They struggle to capture the complex dynamic relationships between adjacent nodes in road networks, to model long-term dependencies, and fully mine cross-layer feature expressions. These limitations make long-term predictions challenging. To address these challenges, we propose a GCN based on dynamic spatiotemporal and multiscale feature fusion (DGCN-STMSF). The model adopts a shared and independent stacked architecture, taking into account cross-layer feature sharing and personalized modeling, this architecture enables better characterization of the complex dynamic relationships between nodes. We introduce an exponential smoothing attention mechanism (ESA). It embeds the exponential decay mechanism into graph-structured temporal modeling. This improves the unique feature representation between layers and enhances temporal stability and trend perception. Furthermore, a fine-grained correlation enhancement module (FGCE) is proposed, featuring a dual-layer mechanism design, combined with spatial location enhancement learning (SLEL) and cross-spatial integration learning strategy (CSIL), which are used to characterize the instantaneous changes of adjacent nodes and the interactive effects between different road sections, respectively, and dynamically model complex local and global spatial dependencies. Extensive experiments on four real datasets show that the DGCN-STMSF model demonstrates superior effectiveness and performance. On various datasets, mean absolute error (MAE), root mean square error, and mean absolute percentage error are reduced by up to 2.14%, 5.34%, and 3.12%, respectively, demonstrating good generalization ability and application value.

title: A Novel High-Performance Deep-Learning-Based Approach for the Detection of Arsenic Poisoning
authors: Norbert Moenks, Pascal Penava, Ricardo Buettner
abstract: Arsenic poisoning remains a serious public health problem that affects millions of people worldwide. Early detection is crucial to prevent severe long-term complications and implement mitigation strategies as recommended by the World Health Organization. While traditional assessment methods require specialists and laboratory equipment, deep learning methods have shown potential for fast and automated analysis of skin images to detect its dermatological manifestations, also called arsenicosis. However, existing approaches suffer from insufficient validation and suboptimal detection performance. To address this problem, we present a novel deep learning-based approach to classify skin images into two categories: healthy and arsenic affected, using a compact EfficientNet backbone with a novel pre-processing step that suppresses irrelevant high-frequency artifacts while retaining lesion morphology and lesion-to-skin transitions characteristic of arsenicosis. With a balanced accuracy of 99.93%, our work sets a new benchmark for the binary classification of arsenicosis, reducing the error rate by 79.5% compared to the previous benchmark. These results indicate that combining specific image enhancements with deep learning can improve the analysis of arsenic-affected skin images. The pipeline is lightweight, easily reproducible, and transferable to real-world scenarios such as mobile or telemedical applications, enabling reliable, non-invasive screening and monitoring in arsenic-affected populations.

title: Deep Learning-Based Indirect Attenuation Correction in Spect Mpi Using Multireconstruction Inputs and Novel Loss Optimization
authors: G. Hajianfar, Y. Salimi, M. Amini, X. Hong, M. Chehreghani, Z. Mansouri, R. Nkoulou, A. Sanaat, A. Bitarafan Rajabi, I. Shiri, H. Zaidi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: CT-less attenuation correction (AC) in myocardial SPECT imaging is highly desirable, enabling hardware simplification and mitigating artifacts propagating from CT and SPECT-CT misregistration. In this study, we explored deep learning models for SPECT myocardial perfusion imaging (MPI) AC using both direct and indirect AC approaches (i.e. via attenuation map (ATM) generation), introducing novel input strategies and loss function design. A dataset consisting of 940 SPECT/CT MPI scans was collected from one center. Images were reconstructed using the PyTomography package with ordered-subsets expectation maximization (OSEM), applying three iterations/subsets settings: 4I/4S, 6I/6S, and 8I/8S. The SwinUNETR model was trained with 5 -fold cross-validation (CV) across all experiments. In the direct strategy, three single-input models were trained with a direct loss (calculated between generated and true AC images). In the indirect strategy, in addition to a single-input model, a multi-input model (OSEM_3) was trained using two losses: ATM loss (predicted ATMs vs. true ATMs), AC loss (reconstructed AC using predicted ATM vs. reference AC). Four voxel-wise metrics within the body contour were reported for both ATM and AC domains, along with polar map analysis across 17 segments. Direct models showed inferior performance in all comparisons. The model with OSEM_3 input, trained with AC loss and reconstructed with 4I/4S, achieved optimal results in CV. This resulted in a mean relative error (MRE) of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12.49 \pm 23 \%$</tex> on ATM images and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.10 \pm 5.6 \%$</tex> on AC SPECT images. Polar map analysis yielded a MRE% of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.15 \pm 0.07$</tex> in AC images. Our proposed framework, based on multireconstruction input and AC loss optimization, outperformed all other approaches.

title: Event-Triggered CIO Optimization for Cellular-Connected UAVs via Deep Reinforcement Learning
authors: Tong Liu, Yimeng Shang, Jian Ma, Nan Hu, Lijun Dong, Wenying Yang, Wenzhi Li
abstract: Cellular-connected unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) are increasingly being deployed in emerging Internet of Things (IoT) applications, where reliable handover management is critical to ensure uninterrupted communication. Unlike terrestrial users, UAVs face frequent handovers due to antenna side-lobe coverage and fragmented aerial cell overlaps. Existing optimization strategies, however, are often limited to coarse-grained “whether-to-handover” decisions or unidirectional cell individual offset (CIO) tuning, resulting in degraded handover performance. To address these problems, this paper proposes an Event-triggered Bidirectional CIO Optimization with Hybrid prioritized experience replay based Deep Reinforcement Learning (EBCO-HDRL) algorithm. Under the A3 event-triggered mechanism, EBCO-HDRL jointly configures serving-to-neighbor and neighbor-to-serving CIOs, improving handover accuracy and reducing ping-pong events. An event-triggered optimization strategy adaptively reconfigures CIOs only when needed, mitigating computational overhead and enhancing training stability. To further improve sample efficiency, a Hybrid Prioritized Experience Replay (HPER) scheme is introduced, combining temporal-difference error and high-reward sampling, supported by a heterogeneous neural network design. Simulation results show that EBCO-HDRL significantly outperforms baseline algorithms in terms of precision, stability, and robustness, offering an effective solution for UAV handover management in cellular IoT networks.

title: Anomaly Detection Method for High-Speed Maglev Train Suspension System Based on Isolation Forest and Improved LSTM
authors: Xingyu Zhou, Hao Wang, Zhiqiang Wang, Xiaolong Li, Zhiqiang Long
abstract: External disturbances such as wind gusts and track irregularities can affect the suspension performance of high-speed maglev trains. Additionally, in long-term commercial operations, multi-source coupled factors such as track settlement, time-varying structural parameters, loosening of mechanical components, and degradation of controller performance can severely threaten the operational reliability, safety, and passenger comfort of the train. Therefore, monitoring abnormal states of the suspension system becomes crucial. This study first classifies potential abnormal states of the suspension system into three categories: low-frequency transient anomalies, high-frequency transient anomalies, and long-term anomalies. Different anomaly detection strategies are designed for each category to achieve comprehensive and accurate monitoring of abnormal states: the Isolation Forest algorithm is used for real-time monitoring of suspension data to quickly and accurately identify transient abnormal states without relying on pre-training or data labels; an improved Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) model integrating the Complete Ensemble Empirical Mode Decomposition with Adaptive Noise (CEEMDAN) method is developed to eliminate noise interference, reduce modeling complexity, and improve time-series prediction accuracy. Long-term abnormal states are further identified offline using steady-state metrics of the suspension system. Simulations and experimental verification demonstrate that the proposed anomaly detection method can accurately identify various abnormal states of the suspension system.

title: Analysis and Prioritization of Enemy Targets for Effective Strike UAV Mission Planning
authors: Oleksandr Prohorov, Yuliia Leshchenko, Oleksii Hubka, Leonid Malieiev
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: This study focuses on the analysis and prioritization of enemy targets to support effective mission planning involving strike drone swarms. The goal is to improve the validity of selecting relevant targets for their effective engagement using available UAVs. Various scenarios for conducting military missions using a swarm of drones and a set of possible targets for engagement are considered. A list of criteria for assessing target priorities is proposed in order to identify a subset of high-priority targets. A graphical diagram of an extended hierarchy of prioritization criteria and possible targets is developed. A software tool using the Analytical Hierarchy Process has been developed to prioritize targets for strike drone missions.

title: Improvement of Fuses to Increase the Efficiency of Medium Voltage Instrument Transformers Protection
authors: Oleksandr Grechko, Yevhen Baida, Oleksandr Sereda, Olena Sereda, Michael Pantelyat, Stanislav Dryvetskyi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The paper considers an improved design of a fuse for the protection of the medium voltage instrument transformer. The problem of switching off by fuses of small overload currents and the low efficiency of their use for protecting voltage transformers are analyzed. Thermal images of the temperature distribution of the studied fuse are presented and the time and temperature at which its operation occurs are established. The time-current characteristics of the developed fuse are obtained and a comparison is made with samples from well-known manufacturers. The competitiveness of the new fuse design is established and directions and prospects for further development are proposed.

title: Identification of Named Entities from Uzbek Historical Texts: A Multilingual BERT Approach
authors: Nodirbek Boltayev, Munisa Nayimova, Nodìrabegim Abubakirova, Alisher Abidjanov, Kamolova Madina, Sevara Berdimurotova
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This paper presents an algorithm for recognizing named entities in Uzbek historical texts dating back to 1928– 1940. To accomplish the task, we used the Multilingual BERT deep learning model, which was trained on a custom dataset. It should be noted that this dataset was formed from 5,500 sentences, each of which was annotated using the BIOES scheme. The authors argued that this annotation scheme was chosen because it is one of the most popular annotation schemes for named entity detection tasks. Organizations, persons, and locations were selected as categories of named entities. The model was trained using the early stopping mechanism, which allowed us to select the best metric weights obtained at the 11th training epoch. For an objective assessment, testing was conducted on various thematic historical texts and modern Uzbek texts, which once again confirmed the high efficiency of the model for historical data and revealed a significant decrease in accuracy on modern texts.

title: Research of the Force Loading Channel Gain from the Operating Mode of the Strength Test Bench
authors: Maksim V. Trubin, Valery D. Yurkevich
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This paper examines the properties of a force loading channel of strength test bench. In particular, it discusses the results of studies examining the dependence of the force loading channel gain from the bench operating mode. The feature of strength test benches is the complexity of their dynamic characteristics and their dependence from the force loading mode. This reduces the accuracy of the force loading cyclogram implementation and complicates the design of a control system. The known approach to overcoming these limitations is to develop adaptive control systems with additional identification of force loading channel parameters. This paper examines possible approach to solving this problem by identifying the dependence of the force loading channel gain from the bench operating modes, specifically, the dependence of this gain from the control signal and the magnitude of the load force. In this paper, based on experimental studies and the results of least-squares method processing of experimental data, analytical expressions were derived that reflect the dependence of this gain from bench operating modes. The obtained relationships can be used to construct an adaptive control system and will ensure the specified requirements for the accuracy of the implementation of the force loading cyclogram.

title: Multimodal Chain-of-Thought Reasoning via Visual Enhancement and Bidirectional Cross-Modal Fusion for Science Question Answering
authors: Rongji Wang, Lanfang Dong
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Multimodal Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning requires models to integrate visual and textual information for step-by-step inference. However, small- and medium-scale models often underutilize salient visual cues and rely on rigid, unidirectional fusion, leading to inaccurate reasoning. We propose a Science Question Answering approach that enhances visual encoding with an improved Triplet Attention module and introduces a Bidirectional Cross-modal Fusion (BCF) mechanism for dynamic semantic alignment. Within a stage-aware two-step framework, the model first generates rationales and then predicts answers. On the ScienceQA benchmark, our method surpasses the MM-CoT baseline by 1.16% average accuracy without increasing model size. Ablation studies confirm the complementary roles of visual enhancement and adaptive fusion, demonstrating improved semantic representation and more robust reasoning.

title: Benchmarking Distributed Learning for UAV Swarms
authors: Chen Hu, Hanchi Ren, Jingjing Deng, Xianghua Xie
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) swarms operate in data-rich, distributed environments where privacy and efficiency are critical. Federated Learning (FL) offers a solution by enabling collaborative model training without sharing raw data. However, non-IID data across UAVs poses significant challenges. This study evaluates four FL algorithms, FedAvg, FedProx, FedOpt, and MOON, on datasets representing various UAV applications: MNIST, CIFAR10, EuroSAT, and CelebA. While performance is comparable under IID settings, non-IID conditions lead to notable degradation. Our experiment results show that local update regularization in heterogeneous UAV scenarios is of great importance for stable performance.

title: Virtual Sensor of pH Measurement for Low-Cost IoT-Based Hydroponic System with KNN and Moving Average
authors: Pande Made Agung Dananjaya Krisna Cakra, Aji Gautama Putrada, Hassan Rizky Putra Sailellah
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: Intelligent hydroponics systems, incorporating IoT and machine learning, can become a precision agriculture solution. However, sensors such as water pH sensors are expensive, and a low-cost solution can be proposed using virtual sensors. Our research aims to propose a pH virtual sensor for Hydroponics IoT. The first step of our study involves utilizing secondary data from Kaggle. We employ random forest, extreme gradient boosting (XGBoost), and K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN) regression algorithms for the prediction. This model is built using data from the TDS meter and temperature sensor as input features. Some metrics for testing are the root mean squared error (RMSE), the mean absolute error (MAE), and the R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score. We also employ a moving average method to enhance the model’s performance and validate the data using the Pearson correlation coefficient (PCC) matrix. The test results show that the moving average with a window size of 181 can reduce the RMSE of the KNN regression model from 0.98 to 0.30, respectively. The benchmark results show that KNN achieves a more optimal R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score than the decision tree and XGBoost models, with values of 0.91, 0.91, and 0.57, respectively. Finally, virtual pH sensors with KNN regression are the most valid virtual sensors, as the correlation values of pH with TDS and water temperature are -0.34 to -0.35 and -0.44 to -0.31, respectively, when compared to the secondary dataset. This virtual sensor can be a low-cost solution in IoT hydroponics because it can reduce product costs from USD 400 to USD 10.

title: The Fastpulse Precision Sampler (FPS): A Multi-GHz Analog Readout ASIC for Ultrafast Ionizing Radiation Diagnostics
authors: T. Prakash, C. Grace, F. Martinez-McKinney, J. McDaniel, S. McHale, T. Morris, S. Mudford, M. Nizam, R. Padilla, E. Prebys, C. Rowling, B. Schumm, K.-W. Shin, M. Wilder
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Next-generation X-ray Free Electron Laser (XFEL) facilities require diagnostic instrumentation with unprecedented temporal resolution, analog bandwidth, and dynamic range to capture ultrafast transients from monocrystalline diamond sensors and similar photosensors. The FastPulse Precision Sampler (FPS) ASICs address this need through a compact, high-speed frontend readout solution designed for GHz-rate signal acquisition and sub-picosecond timing resolution.

title: Autonomous UAS Object Avoidance and Path Detection Using Neuromorphic Computing
authors: Brian Millikan, Lauren Reinerman-Jones, Daniel Barber
publish: 2025 IEEE International Carnahan Conference on Security Technology (ICCST)
abstract: Automation in Unmanned Aerial Systems (UAS) flight is becoming more and more necessary to handle flight patterns that cannot be pre-planned because of instantaneous changes that happen, which disrupt a flight path. To operate a UAS in a military application, the drone must be able to autonomously avoid an object or stop if an object gets in the way of the flight path. To implement this on a UAS, the solution must be low Size, Weight, and Power (SWaP) to minimize the impact on the UAS payload limitations and flight time. The present paper discusses the use of Neuromorphic Computing to implement flight path following and object avoidance in a closed-loop fashion to demonstrate the feasibility of having on-board intelligent control for challenging flight environments.

authors: Dingting Han, Libin Jia, Chao Tian, Hongbo Sun
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Semiconductor Devices and Integration Technology (ASDIT)
abstract: Silicon nitride (Si<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>) and silicon oxide (SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>) mulit-stack structures were widely applicated in semiconductor devices to breaking through the bottleneck problem of scaling technological nodes. Vertical trenches in Si<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>/SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> multi-stack structures were designed in 3D memory devices to meet the requirement of scaling. Normally, phosphoric acid (H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>PO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>)-based etchants were used to selectively etch Si<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf> sacrificial layers. During selective wet etching process, byproduct H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> was generated to prevent the loss in the thickness of SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> layers. Nevertheless, abnormal SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> redeposition phenomenon was found when the H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> concentration is supersaturated, which block Si<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf> layer etching and significantly deteriorates the remaining structure morphology. In this study, the composition and formation of SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> redeposition mechanism was investigated and discussed. Five tiers Si<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>N<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf>/SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> stack structures was designed to clarified the SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> redeposition mechanism and the chemical composition of redeposition SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> layer. The redeposited layer with average thickness of ~0.2x nm act as colloidal silica gel was formed when the H<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> concentration is supersaturated. In a phosphoric acid environment, the O-Si-O bond was broken by hydrogen bond, thus the redeposition SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> act as colloidal silica gel and adhere onto the original ALD SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> layers. The oxide redeposition phenomenon was related to the mass transfer rate of byproduct, the generation rate of the byproduct and the Si3N4 lateral etch rate. Our researches were very critical for the development of high density and scaling 3D memory devices.

title: Egress Accommodation for Factory Assembled Structures Revision Jan 2025
authors: Alan Clemenson, Alex Bresnan, Luca Magenes, Joe Coder, Mitchell Roegele
publish: 2025 IEEE IAS Petroleum and Chemical Industry Technical Conference (PCIC)
abstract: The National Electrical Code (NEC) is periodically revised to enhance efficiency, account for technology development, and to improve standard safety practices. Recent code changes made in the 2023 Edition significantly impact various industries, particularly regarding the use of prefabricated structures in brownfield applications. One key amendment is the egress requirement added to sections 110.26 and 110.33 for equipment under & over 1000V. This code requirement is to be treated independently from working clearance and specifically necessitates that 24 inches of egress are made available in all aisles while equipment doors are concurrently open. The implication is that buildings will be designed with larger footprints, additional shipping splits, and will likely become more expensive to construct. Engineers must adapt to provide innovative design methodologies to meet these demands. This paper reviews the egress code requirements, impacts to industries, and some of the devised strategies to meet standards and promote a safer electrical infrastructure.

title: Design of a High-Speed Acquisition Recording System for Klystron Body Overcurrent Transients
authors: Changsheng Zuo, Yong Yang, Handong Xu, Wendong Ma
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: The lower hybrid current drive (LHCD) system plays an important role in EAST experiments. Rapid detection of klystron overcurrent faults is essential for maintaining its operational efficiency. The existing protection system interrupts power but lacks waveform recording capabilities, making fault localization time-consuming. To address this issue, we designed a high-speed data acquisition system specifically for capturing klystron body overcurrent transients. The system employs STM32+FPGA architecture to achieve 20 MSPS sampling across four channels. A QT-based host application allows for threshold configuration, real-time waveform visualization, and data export. Validation tests show the system's capability to record transients with a maximum duration of 20ms. This system enables rapid fault analysis and significantly reduces the diagnostic downtime of the EAST LHCD system.

title: Experimental Study on Wireless Transmission Based on Resonance
authors: Li Chai, Hong Li, Mengyao Li, Chengxi Xia, Jie Zhou, Yinghan Yang, Ruiyuan Wang, Lee Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Based on the principle of magnetically coupled resonance, a study on wireless power transmission was carried out. The research combined theoretical analysis, simulation verification, and experimental circuit implementation to construct a wireless energy transmission system using a parallel resonant circuit as the core. By forming resonant units with inductors and capacitors, both actual debugging and simulation results demonstrated that the system operates in Class C amplification mode with low waveform distortion. A magnetically coupled wireless transmission model was further developed, enabling efficient energy transfer at medium distances when the transmitting and receiving coils were tuned to resonance and impedance-matched. The effect of power transmission was visually confirmed through changes in LED brightness. Frequency sweep analysis indicated that the system reaches maximum impedance at the resonant frequency, accompanied by a phase difference close to -180°, which aligns with theoretical resonant behavior. This paper offers practical insights and a experimental foundation for both educational instruction and engineering applications of magnetically coupled resonant wireless power transmission.

title: Hardware Security Evaluation of IoT Microcontrollers: Threats and Countermeasures
authors: Serhii Pohasii, Maksym Tkach, Serhii Holdobin, Natalia Brynza, Vadym Stetsenko, Olha Tiutiunyk
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: This study analyzes the susceptibility of IoT microcontrollers to reverse engineering, defined as unauthorized data access for replication, and proposes countermeasures. STM32F0 demonstrates superior resistance due to dense integration, rapid protection activation, and robust encryption, effectively countering attacks like Cold Boot Stepping, Glitch, Electromagnetic Analysis, and invasive methods. GD32 offers moderate security but is vulnerable to faster attacks. CH32 and MM32F0 show the least resilience due to weak protection. Architectural analysis highlights STM32F0’s secure interfaces, while GD32’s multi-chip design and CH32/MM32F0’s simpler cores increase risks. Security metrics confirm STM32F0’s lead, with GD32, CH32, and MM32F0 needing enhancements. Recommendations include hardware shielding, signal filters, and dynamic encryption, implementable in 2–14 days at $0.1–1.0 per device. STM32F0 suits high-security IoT, GD32 mid-level needs, and CH32/MM32F0 low-risk applications. Comprehensive hardware and software modifications are critical to mitigate reverse engineering threats across all microcontrollers.

title: Wasserstein Distributionally Robust Beamforming for Steering Vector Mismatch
authors: Haofan Lei, Hao Xiao, Cong Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: The mismatch between true and estimated channel state information (CSI) often causes severe degradation in adaptive beamforming performance. To mitigate this issue, distributionally robust optimization (DRO) has emerged as a powerful tool for designing robust adaptive beamformers (RAB) that can better tolerate CSI uncertainty. In this work, we introduce a new RAB framework based on Wasserstein-distance ambiguity sets, which provide a richer description of distributional shifts compared with classical moment-based approaches. This formulation yields a convex reformulation of the MVDR problem, making the method computationally efficient. Unlike existing designs, the proposed beamformer explicitly incorporates uncertainty in both the desired and interference steering vectors without assuming precise prior knowledge of their statistics. Simulation studies confirm that the approach achieves superior SINR and improved stability relative to conventional methods, highlighting its robustness and practical relevance in uncertain scenarios.

title: Frequency-Aware Adapter with Cross-Modal Attention for Audio-Visual Forgery Temporal Localization
authors: Hao Zhang, Zhihong Chen, Haiwei Zhang, Haitao Xu
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: Audio-visual forgery detection aims to identify manipulated content. Most existing methods treat this as video-level classification, overlooking temporal forgeries where brief edits alter meaning. We propose a frequency-aware Discrete Wavelet Transform adapter for temporal forgery localization. Our model integrates audio and video encoders, a DWT-based adapter, and a cross-modal attention fusion module to capture subtle traces and align modalities. A Low-Rank Adapter fine-tuning strategy further improves efficiency by reducing trainable parameters. Experiments on the LAV-DF dataset show 95.02% AP@0.5 and 79.11% AR@100, verifying the method’s effectiveness in forgery localization and deepfake detection.

title: Electrodynamic characteristics of ceramic materials research for the creation of protective avionics elements
authors: Olena Y. Fedorenko, Ruslan V. Kryvobok, Valentyna V. Voloshchuk, Yaroslav M. Pitak, Olena M. Lapuzina, Nataliya M. Shmatko, Nataliya A. Kryvobok
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The paper presents the results of experimental studies of the electrodynamic characteristics of ceramic materials obtained on the basis of the target phases of the RO - Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> - SiO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> (RO - SrO, BaO, ZnO). The main attention is paid to the analysis of the transmission, reflection and absorption coefficients for slawsonite, celsian, celsian-slawsonite and slawsonite-willemite ceramics in the frequency range of 26.5…38 GHz. It is established that the studied ceramic materials demonstrate the stability of electrodynamic parameters in a given frequency range and provide the required level of radio transparency. The possibilities of using the studied materials in the designs of aviation and rocket technology in the manufacture of individual structural and protective elements are assessed. The feasibility of using heterophase ceramics of slawsonite-willemite composition for the manufacture of products with optimal dielectric properties, increased heat resistance and operating temperature up to 1100 °C is established. The results obtained can be used in the development of new types of radio-transparent protective structures for avionics.

title: A Density Clustering and Dynamic Object Filtering Framework for Robust LiDAR Registration
authors: Shuheng Yu, Jie Luo, Linqiu Gui, Chuqiao Lu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Achieving robust point cloud registration in dynamic environments remains challenging. Conventional voxel downsampling often leads to loss of geometric information and shows limited adaptability to complex scenes. To address this, this paper proposes a robust registration framework that combines density-based clustering and dynamic object removal. Ground segmentation is first performed to eliminate ground influence; non-ground points are then clustered using DBSCAN, and dynamic objects are identified and removed via frame-graph cluster association to obtain a relatively static environmental point cloud. On this basis, the point cloud is divided into two categories: high-density and sparse. Point-to-plane ICP is applied to highdensity points to fully exploit local planar constraints and improve convergence stability; point-to-point ICP is applied to sparse points to preserve edges and fine structures, while down-weighting and outlier-suppression strategies are used to reduce noise interference. The two registration results are finally fused in a unified pose estimation, achieving more stable convergence and higher localization accuracy across diverse scenarios. Experimental results show that the proposed method attains higher accuracy and robustness than voxel-grid baselines on public datasets and real-vehicle tests, with particularly strong performance in dynamic urban scenes.

title: Research on the Construction of Student Behavior Recognition Model in Classroom Scenarios Based on Deep Learning
authors: Jingfeng Liu, Beibei Wang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Digital Management (ICAIDM)
abstract: A student behavior recognition model for classroom scenarios fuses three types of modal information, namely image, skeleton and audio, to construct a deep multimodal structure based on a 3D-CNN and an ST-GCN with an attention mechanism. The model achieves spatio-temporal feature extraction and modal fusion based on uniform timestamp alignment, which improves the ability to characterize complex behaviors. Compared to mainstream models such as 2D-CNN, C3D, and LSTM, the proposed model achieves 0.901 and 0.883 in Accuracy and F1-score, respectively, which are significantly better than 0.873 and 0.853 in ST-GCN, verifying the effectiveness and advantages of multimodal collaborative modeling in classroom behavior recognition.

title: FFRNet: Exploring Forgery Cues Via Adaptive Feature Scaling for Deepfake Detection
authors: Pengyu Jin, Shuwei Xu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: Driven by progress in generative AI, deepfake technology can now generate results indistinguishable from reality, thereby eroding public trust and enabling new forms of fraud and misinformation. At the same time, detecting such forged content is becoming progressively more difficult. In recent years, detection methods that fuse spatial and frequency domain features have drawn considerable attention due to their potential to compensate for the limitations of single-modal approaches. However, most existing methods rely on specific frequency patterns, resulting in limited generalization capabilities. Traditional frequency domain analysis, while effective at capturing global representations, struggles to integrate with spatial features, leading to the loss of critical fine-grained information. In this paper, we propose a dual-domain collaborative detection framework named FFRNet, designed to enable robust and efficient cross-domain feature modeling and fusion. Specifically, a Fourier Convolution Unit (FCU) is introduced to enhance frequency features for better perception of large-scale artifacts while preserving local spatial structures. Additionally, a Bidomain Nonlinear Mapping (BNM) module is developed to align spatial features with phase spectrum transformations, facilitating deep interactions between spatial and frequency domains. This framework systematically explores common forgery traces in the frequency domain and establishes a stable pathway for cross-domain interaction, thereby improving the overall perception of fine-grained forgery cues. Extensive experiments demonstrate that FFRNet effectively captures frequency-domain artifacts in generated images and fully leverages the complementary nature of spatial and frequency information. On multiple benchmark deepfake datasets, FFRNet consistently outperforms state-of-the-art methods, showing superior performance in both detection accuracy and cross-domain generalization.

title: Padlet Platform in Project Based Learning: Is It Effective in Improving Students' Reading Comprehension Abilities?
authors: Zaid Zainal, Ekma T. I. Permata, Wawan Krismanto
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: This research aims to determine the difference in the reading comprehension abilities of students who learn to integrate the Padlet platform in project-based learning (PjBL) from those who learn conventionally. The research used a quantitative approach with a quasi-experimental type in a nonequivalent control group design model. The population in this study was all 4th-grade students at SDN 3 Parepare, South Sulawesi, Indonesia. The sample was 36 students in class 4.1 for the experimental class and 35 in class 4.2 for the control class. Research data was obtained by giving a reading comprehension test. The data analysis technique is the independent sample t-test. Based on the inferential statistical analysis results, Sig (2-tailed) is 0.024 and less than 0.05, so H0 is rejected, and H1 is accepted. Thus, this research concludes that there is a difference in students' reading comprehension abilities in integrating Padlet in PjBL with conventional learning. Integrating the Padlet platform in learning can be an alternative strategy to improve students' reading comprehension abilities.
