                    /CdS/por-ZnO/ZnO Heterostructure Using Combined Chemical and Electrochemical Methods
authors: Yana Suchikova, Sergii Kovachov, Ihor Bohdanov, Ivan Kosogov, Dariya Drozhcha, Anatoli I. Popov
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The quest for effective solar energy conversion has led to the development of innovative photovoltaic materials. This study presents the creation of a new heterostructure, Cd<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">x</inf>Te<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">y</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">z</inf>/CdS/por-ZnO/ZnO, through an approach that combines chemical deposition and electrochemical etching. Structural and compositional analysis was conducted using Scanning Electron Microscopy (SEM) and Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopy (EDX), revealing a heterostructure with unique morphology and multi-element composition. Raman scattering spectra further elucidated the heterostructure’s structural integrity and phase purity, with distinct peaks corresponding to γ-TeO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> and β-CdO. Structural and compositional analysis by SEM/EDX and Raman spectroscopy confirms the successful formation of a CdxTeyOz/CdS/por ZnO/ZnO heterostructure with a multilayer architecture and mixed oxide phases. These results establish a fabrication route and structural baseline for subsequent optical and electronic characterization toward photovoltaic and optoelectronic applications.

title: RVO-Guided RL Framework with Multi-Head Attention for Multi-Uav Pursuit and Dynamic Obstacle Avoidance
authors: Lukai Chen, Weida Wu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Multi-Agent systems (MAS) have shown great advantages in complex tasks such as disaster response and UAV swarm control. However, problems such as the dynamic obstacle avoidance, real-time collaboration, and scalability still have not been addressed. To address these challenges, we propose the Attention-Based Reciprocal Velocity Policy Multi-Agent Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient (ARVP-MADDPG) algorithm, a multi-agent reinforcement learning framework that integrates Multi-Head Attention, Prioritized Experience Replay (PER), and curriculum learning. Notably, we include Reciprocal Velocity Obstacles (RVO) strategy into the reward function to support the multi-UAV cooperation in the dynamic environment. First, UAV kinematics and detection models are constructed, and dynamic obstacles with linear motion patterns are simulated to create a realistic testbed. Subsequently, a reward function integrating Approaching Reward, Distance-Based Safety Reward, RVO-Based Safety Reward, 3-Stage Round-Up Reward and Completion Reward is designed to guide the UAV for tracking, encirclement, and capture tasks. The Multi-Head Attention boosts the cooperation efficiency in the centralized critic and the Prioritized Experience Replay(PER) improves the policy convergence. Finally, curriculum learning divides training into two stages: dynamic obstacle avoidance and task-specific encirclement, ensuring progressive performance improvement. Experimental results show that ARVP-MADDPG outperforms traditional methods and other reinforcement learning models in task completion rate, collision avoidance, and path planning efficiency, validating its robustness and applicability in simulation environments that reference real-world conditions. Comparative experiments demonstrate that ARVP-MADDPG increases the task completion rate by 64.39% and 63.30% compared to MADDPG and MATD3, while reducing the collision rate by 6.36% and 4.24%.

title: Design and Implementation of a Deep Learning-Based Remote Sensing Image Defogging System
authors: Xing Yang, Licheng Zhang, Wenxing Tian, Yan Wang
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: Atmospheric haze severely compromises the quality of remote sensing imagery and its application effectiveness. This study designed and implemented a deep learning-based remote sensing image defogging system. Employing an improved atmospheric scattering model and multi-objective optimisation strategy, it established a front-end/back-end separated microservices architecture. Through the collaborative operation of three major modules—image pre-processing, deep learning defogging processing, and post-processing optimisation—the system significantly enhanced the clarity of remote sensing imagery. Experimental results demonstrate the system’s robust defogging performance and stability across varying weather conditions.

title: Modular Neutron Detector Array for Protein Crystallography
authors: N. Anastasi, J. Wang, C. Sosa, G. Velasco, M. Loyd, R. Riedel, L. S. Pandian, V. V. Nagarkar
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Neutron-based techniques are essential for advancing fundamental research in bioenergy, biosystems engineering for microbial and plant development, and environmental microbiome studies. In particular, neutron macromolecular crystallography (NMC) provides unique atomicresolution information on the location of hydrogen atoms in protein crystals-data that X-ray crystallography cannot capture. This capability enables detailed analysis of hydrogen-bonding networks and the protonation states of catalytic residues, which are critical for understanding biomass-degrading enzymes, the redox states of metalloenzymes, and ligand binding to proteins.

title: Application of the Dielectric Permittivity Parameter of Crude Oil during Its Processing
authors: Andrii Hryhorov, Nabil Abdel Sater, Alona Tulska, Oleksii Mardupenko, Mikhailo Nahliuk, Lyubov Yurchenko
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The article presents research on the prospects of using the relative dielectric permittivity (ε<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">t</sup>) of crude oil as a process parameter during its refining. It has been established that ε<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">t</sup> demonstrates a strong correlation with kinematic viscosity and Conradson carbon residue. Based on the conducted studies, a predictive criterion (PC) has been proposed, which enables the identification of rational oil refining schemes aimed at increasing the yield of valuable products and reducing production costs.

title: Parallel Frame-Based Signal Filtering on Shared-Memory Multi-Core CPU Using OpenMP
authors: Mekhriddin Rakhimov, Shakhzod Javliev, Sokhibjon Botirov, Makhliyo Turaeva, Ulugbek Turdiev
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: To achieve high speed and efficiency in digital data processing, it is important to choose the right computing resources. It is known that specialized digital signal processors and graphics processors for processing data such as signals exist, but these computing resources are not available in all studies. This study examines the possibility of maximizing the use of available resources in cases where specialized hardware resources for signal processing are insufficient. In this case, it is advisable to use a modern multi-core processor designed for general-purpose tasks. However, since the processors are adapted for sequential processing, parallel processing of signal filtering processes is performed in this processor. Since the processor can provide a sufficient level of parallel processing based on the L1, L2, and L3 cache memory systems, the Open Multi-Processing programming model, with its capabilities, can significantly accelerate signal filtering processes performed by parallel processing tools in processors with shared memory. In this case, the signal data is divided into frames of 8, 16, 32,... 2048, and each frame is evenly distributed among the processor cores using Open Multi-Processing, and parallel calculations are performed simultaneously. When implementing parallel filtering of the moving average and root mean square methods for signal filtering on a 4-core (8-thread) processor, the acceleration was ~1.2-2.5 times for small frames, ~3.5-3.8 times for medium frames, and ~4.4 times for large frames.

title: Analysis of Instantaneous Power of Higher Harmonics in a Diesel Generator-Based Electrical System with Grid Connection
authors: Maxim Oliynichenko, Olexii Bialobrzheskyi, Artur Postil
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: As a result of the analysis of existing studies, it was found that in the operation of a power supply system with a medium-capacity generator, insufficient attention is paid to the distribution of higher harmonic powers among system components. Using a microgrid model that includes a synchronous generator, an induction motor, a transformer, an external grid, and a current harmonic source, a series of experiments were conducted by introducing higher current harmonics and recording distortion levels and RMS power in individual branches. The analysis of the obtained results made it possible to es https://doi.org/10.5772/intechopen.87093lish regression relationships between harmonic currents and phase RMS power, as well as to assess their impact on power quality indicators, taking into account the type of load and the specific branch of the microgrid. It was found that in the studied setup, the third harmonic has the greatest impact on the transformer, while the fifth and seventh harmonics predominantly affect the generator and the electric motor..

title: Error Estimation of the Interferometric Method of Measuring the Spatial Parameters of a Laser Beam
authors: M. M. Dubinin, V. A. Maslov, K. I. Muntean
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: An interferometric method for measuring the spatial parameters of a laser beam is considered. The method implements the dependence of the beam wave front curvature on the distance to the waist in the far zone. The original laser beam is split into two beams interfering with each other. The period of the interference field carries information about the location of the waist. To determine the divergence angle, the width of the radiation beam in the plane of recording the period of the interference pattern is additionally measured. The location of the waist and the value of the divergence angle are calculated using the formulas of Gaussian optics. The results of experimental verification allow us to recommend this method as less labor-intensive and more accurate than known methods.

title: Improving the Efficiency of General Primary Frequency Control in Isolated Power Systems
authors: Viktoriya Fyodorova, Viktor Kirichenko, Gleb Glazyrin, Anastasiya Rusina
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The article proposes approaches to solving the problem of the inefficiency of general primary frequency control in isolated power systems in a number of emergency situations. Isolated power systems face particular challenges due to low inertia, lack of spinning reserve and high sensitivity to load disturbances. These factors exacerbate transient processes and can provoke undamped frequency oscillations during general primary frequency control – the first level of automatic response to frequency deviations. However, real-world experience shows that standard general primary frequency control algorithms may not suppress frequency oscillations with low damping, but rather create them. System operators around the world have recorded cases where regulator settings that nominally comply with standards for general primary frequency control don’t prevent oscillatory transient processes lasting several minutes. These cases highlight the importance of the general primary frequency control process in managing the stability of power systems. The paper proposes new adaptive methods for solving the operational problem of stability control and frequency oscillation suppression during general primary frequency control in isolated power systems.

title: HPC Acceleration of Recursive Least-Squares Sparse Spiking Neural Networks for Scalable Brain-Inspired Intelligence
authors: Liangsen Shao, Zhiwei Xu, Qiang Sun, Qi Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Spiking neural networks (SNNs) represent a biologically inspired computing paradigm capable of approximating complex temporal dynamics through sparse spiking activity. In this study, we investigate a sparse SNN trained with a recursive least-squares (RLS) learning rule to assess its ability to stabilize chaotic recurrent activity and reproduce target trajectories. Using layered analyses, we first evaluate the fidelity of spiking dynamics and decoder weight adaptation during learning, then benchmark runtime performance of conventional multilayer perceptrons (MLPs) and convolutional neural networks (CNNs) on baseline CPU and high-performance computing (HPC) accelerated GPU platforms. Finally, we extend benchmarking to RLS-based sparse SNNs, revealing that while ANNs consistently benefit from HPC accelerated parallelization, SNNs exhibit non-monotonic scaling. For RLS sparse SNN, while baseline execution outperforms HPC acceleration at small to intermediate network sizes, HPC acceleration dominates at larger scales. These findings highlight fundamental differences in computational scaling between matrix-driven ANNs and event-driven SNNs, and emphasize the need for optimized simulators and neuromorphic hardware to fully exploit brain-like intelligence.

title: Modeling the Influence of the Ultrasound Instrument Position and Heat Energy on Vein Occlusion During Endovenous Ultrasound Ablation
authors: Anna S. Borde, Diana Yu. Sokolova, Eugenia A. Titova, Irina V. Khaydukova, Mikhail S. Kostin, Nikita V. Belikov
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This paper presents a numerical approach to establishing the exposure parameters for a novel endovenous low-frequency ultrasound (LFU) ablation method for preclinical studies in an animal model. The objectives of this study were to evaluate the impact of the ultrasound instrument's position within the venous lumen and the delivered thermal energy on the efficacy of vein occlusion. A two-dimensional axisymmetric finite element model was developed including a rabbit ear vein (lumen diameter 1.5 mm, wall thickness 0.12 mm) and a needle-shaped ultrasound instrument (diameter 0.8 mm). Two key parameters were examined in the simulation: the pullback velocity (2 mm/s and 3 mm/s, corresponding to linear endovenous energy density (LEED) of 9.5 J/cm and 6.3 J/cm at 1.9 W power) and the gap between the instrument and the venous wall (0, 0.35, and 0.7 mm). The model solved coupled acoustic-thermal equations to simulate temperature fields and estimated thermal damage using the Arrhenius integral. The simulations demonstrated that for all combinations of pullback velocity and gap size, the peak temperature at the venous wall's inner surface exceeded the critical threshold of 70 °C required for collagen denaturation and vein occlusion, ranging from 77 °C to 130 °C. The results confirm that the proposed method is effective in achieving irreversible venous wall damage across a range of simulated ultrasound energy doses, ensuring reliability irrespective of the ultrasound instrument's centering within the vessel lumen. For preclinical study on an animal model, a pullback velocity in the range of 2 to 3 mm/s was selected.

title: One Implementation Strategy Of Wireless Low-power Communication Synchronous Acquisition Technology
authors: Shuoting Wang, Di Mu, Xiaofei Tan, Kaixin Li, Dongjing Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: In the LoRaWAN protocol, when the Class B low-power mode is applied in a multi-level network topology, it is difficult for sensor terminals at each level to wake up simultaneously to receive synchronization signals. To address this issue, this paper proposes a solution and verifies its feasibility through theory, software processes, and laboratory testing.

title: A Fault Diagnosis Approach for Gearboxes Using FMD and ISSA-SVM
authors: Chenyun Wang, Hong Jiang, Xiangfeng Zhang, Yihui Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Aiming at the difficulty of fault feature extraction of gearbox vibration signals under strong background noise, a fault diagnosis model that integrates feature modal decomposition (FMD) with an improved sparrow search algorithm optimized support vector machine (ISSA-SVM) is developed. First, the original vibration signal is decomposed by FMD to obtain the K modal components, and the optimal component selection is realized by taking the pulse energy factor (PEFI) value of the components as an index. Next, time-domain and frequencydomain features are extracted from the selected modal component to construct a feature vector sample set. Finally, the constructed sample set is input into an ISSA-SVM model for fault diagnosis. To verify the effectiveness of the proposed method, experiments were conducted using data collected from a gearbox fault diagnosis test bench. The results demonstrate that the proposed model integrating FMD and ISSA-SVM can effectively extract fault features under strong noise and significantly improve the diagnosis accuracy to 99.07%.

title: Development of a Method for Transmitted Multi-Model Augmented Reality Objects
authors: Matvieiev Mykyta, Heorhii Kuchuk
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The paper presents a modification of the basic method used to transfer multi-model augmented reality objects. The analysis of existing developments has proven the relevance of this task. A client application with augmented reality technology has been created using a combination of Angular, Node.js, Ar.js tools together with A-Frame. The loading speed of a 3D object using the basic and modified methods has been investigated. The limits of application of the modified method have been determined.

title: In-System Calibration of Gamma and Detector Positioning for High-Resolution PET Imaging: Demonstration on the Hypmed Scanner
authors: Y. Kuhl, J. Thull, E. Gegenmantel, B. Weissler, D. Schug, V. Schulz
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: A current trend in PET imaging focuses on high resolution and high sensitivity, driven by innovations such as total-body PET systems and organ-dedicated scanners. Both can be significantly enhanced through advanced light-sharing detectors featuring depth-of-interaction (DOI) capability and by precise detector alignment in the scanner. However, the integration of such detectors remains limited by complex gamma positioning calibration procedures and state-of-the-art benchtop calibration lacks the option of re-calibration. This imposes a significant financial risk for medical device manufacturers, particularly if detector characteristics drift over time or if measurement parameters need or want to be optimized to improve system performance.

title: A Combined Approach to Evaluating the Effectiveness of Deep Learning Models for Aerial Image Processing
authors: Vitalii Vlasenko, Andrii Dashkevych
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The work is devoted to the process of research and analysis of deep learning models for segmentation of aerial images. The article proposes to use a new method of combined evaluation of the efficiency of models, which combines standard quantitative metrics (loss function, accuracy, precision, recall, Jaccard index, F-measure, prediction time of one image) and weighting coefficients of priority of certain metrics, depending on the task. To evaluate the results, modern architectures U-Net, DeepLabV3+, FPN and PSPNet, which are most suitable for image segmentation problems, were used. The study was carried out using its own set of aerial images and their corresponding segmented images, on which seven classes of different objects were separated. The results obtained show the stability and generalizing ability of the combined evaluation when changing weight parameters, and also emphasize the advantages of some architectures when they are applied in different scenarios. Diagrams are used to visualize the studies carried out and the results, which further explain the proposed approach.

title: Optimal Robot Trajectory Planning via Artificial Neural Network Reinforcement Learning with Metaheuristic Optimizer
authors: Yuriy Romasevych, Volodymyr Nazarenko
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: An approach to robot optimal trajectory planning is developed in the study. The robot’s environment is filled with multiple obstacles, which must be avoided during the robot’s movement. The trajectory length was minimized, and a penalty function was developed to satisfy obstacle avoidance. The trajectory planner is an artificial neural network (ANN) fed with discrete time and generates discrete positions in the Cartesian coordinate system. Comparison with the DC-programming optimization method evidenced the superiority of the developed approach in terms of solution stability. The only revealed drawback of the ANN application is connected with the local optimality of the generated trajectory.

title: Detection and Isolation of Broken Conductors in Power Distribution Systems: A Key Wildfire Mitigation and Public Safety Strategy
authors: Tanushri Doshi, Rohit Sharma, Anthony Rahiminejad, Charlie Cerezo
publish: 2025 IEEE IAS Petroleum and Chemical Industry Technical Conference (PCIC)
abstract: Successfully detecting high-impedance faults due to downed or broken power distribution conductors in a timely manner has been a big challenge for decades. When an energized broken conductor makes contact with the ground, it may result in a high-impedance fault that may be a challenge to detect using traditional protection methods. This paper provides a review of the existing solutions to detect downed conductors that have made contact with the ground. It is important to highlight that these solutions detect and isolate the affected circuit section only after the energized conductor has been on the ground for several seconds or minutes. This creates a critical "race-against-time" scenario, posing wildfire risks and public safety hazards.This paper dives deeper into an innovative method that was developed and successfully implemented on 12 kV distribution circuits to detect and isolate broken conductors while they are in the air and before they touch the ground. The IEC 61850 Generic Object-Oriented Substation Event and IEEE Std. C37.118 synchrophasor-based falling conductor protection solution is designed to detect and isolate broken conductors well within 500 ms of the break. This protection-speed solution is applicable to three-phase circuits along with two-phase and single-phase laterals that may be in high fire risk areas. This paper further explores the implementation of the falling conductor protection solution using Ethernet radios, and direct fiber, as well as private long-term evolution communication networks, which form the backbone of the falling conductor protection solution.

title: Decision Tree Construction Method using Cuckoo Search for Computer System State Identification
authors: Viktor Chelak, Oleksii Hornostal, Yehor Chelak, Svitlana Gavrylenko
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: This paper proposes a method for constructing decision trees using a modified cuckoo evolutionary algorithm for the task of identifying the state of a computer system. Unlike traditional approaches, where the search for threshold values is determined by classical algorithms using Gini index or information gain, the proposed method employs the cuckoo evolutionary algorithm along with basic operators such as mutation and crossover applied to the threshold conditions at the tree nodes. This allows for the formation of an optimal tree structure with minimal depth and improved generalization. The model was tested on a dataset containing structured features related to the behavior of a computer system. Experiments demonstrated that this approach improves classification accuracy up to 94.5% and reduces the average tree depth by more than two levels compared to standard tree-building algorithms (CART, ID3). The obtained results indicate the potential of applying evolutionary strategies in constructing baseline models for tasks related to the security and monitoring of computer systems.

title: Automated Detection of Disinformation Routes Based on Vector Grouping of Social Media Posts
authors: Victoria Vysotska, Yaroslav Teplyi, Yulian Kuryliak, Vitalii Torshyn, Roman Romanchuk, Vitalii Danylyk
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The study presents an information system that performs automated analysis of arrays of publications from online media and social networks to identify primary sources and routes of disinformation spread. The methodology is based on the vector representation of texts using embedding models (local intfloat/multilingual-e5-base and OpenAI text-embedding-3-small), calculating cosine similarity, and building clusters of similar messages. A timeline graph that displays the chronology and distribution channels. Experimental testing of the system on three datasets showed the effectiveness of the approach. The OpenAI model detected clusters with high accuracy at a threshold of 0.6-0.7, demonstrating a clear visualisation of dynamics. The local model required raising the threshold to 0.85-0.9, but also provided the detection of groups of similar messages. For example, in cluster No. 6, a typical scheme of spreading a fake was recorded: from the initial Telegram post to retransmission on X and Facebook with a total delay of about 5 days. The system also allows you to detect attempts to hide the source (for example, by converting a repost into a new post) and visualise time intervals and platforms through which disinformation was spread. The results demonstrate that the proposed approach is promising for information analytics, allows you to identify fake messages, and can be integrated into cyber hygiene systems or information campaign investigations.

title: FLANet: Landmark-aware Global-Local Fusion for Fine-grained Bird Classification in Complex Backgrounds
authors: Jun Tang
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: Fine-grained visual classification (FGVC) under complex natural backgrounds is challenged by clutter, occlusion, and pose variations, especially for bird species where accurate recognition is vital for biodiversity monitoring. We propose FLANet, a framework integrating global semantics with landmark-aware representations and adaptive fusion. A Landmark-aware Representation Modulation (LRM) module emphasizes discriminative regions via landmark attention and learnable modulation, while the Global-Local Adaptive Convolution (GLAC) ensures semantic alignment by generating instance-specific kernels. To further enhance robustness, we employ multi-constraint training with concentration, orthogonality, and equivariance losses. Experiments on bird datasets with complex backgrounds show that FLANet achieves superior accuracy and interpretability, demonstrating its effectiveness for fine-grained recognition in natural scenarios.

title: Design and Practice of a Resume Screening Queue Scheduling Algorithm Based on Long and Short Queue Awareness and Dynamic Priority
authors: Lun Su
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: When processing resumes from multiple suppliers in the current enterprise human resources system, the use of chronological or random order often results in some resumes being put on hold and poor supplier experience, making it easy for enterprises to make mistakes and lose high-quality talents. This study designs a corresponding scheduling algorithm, with the core of constructing a task queue model, designing a dynamic calibration perception mechanism for long and short queues, proposing a multi factor dynamic priority calculation method, and a complete scheduling process. The experiment set up peak and non peak scenarios, and compared FCFS, polling scheduling, and SJF algorithms. The results showed that this algorithm was significantly better than traditional algorithms in terms of processing latency, throughput, supplier experience, and other indicators. Moreover, the delay fluctuation was small, the resume type adaptability was good, and the stability was excellent, effectively solving the pain points of traditional algorithms and enriching the application of queue scheduling algorithms in the field of human resources.

title: Signal Coding and Network Technologies for Signal Processing in the Method of Incoherent Scatter of Radio Waves
authors: Leonid Emelyanov, Valeriy Pulyayev, Nataliia Kuzmenko
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The procedure of choice and application of complex sounding signals for ionospheric studies by the radar method of incoherent scatter (IS) of radio waves is considered. It is shown that the solution to the problem of reliable estimation of ionospheric parameters in an extended altitude interval with a sufficiently short time interval consists in improving the structure of sounding signals. It is proposed to modernize the process of pulse coding to obtain signals with specified correlation properties that make it possible calculating the ionospheric parameters both in the lower and upper parts of the ionosphere during a single measurement session. When synthesizing individual elements of the sounding signal, not only a change in the direction of circular rotation of the polarization plane of the radio wave is used, but also a change in the frequency of its radiation. For this purpose, the sounding signal should consist of groups of discrete-frequency elements representing radio pulses with different parameters. We propose to use an identifying neural network that enables estimating the parameters of ionospheric plasma in real time based on the obtained experimental autocorrelation functions of the IS signal.

title: Privacy-preserving Semi-supervised Transfer Learning Method Based on Pseudo Feature Generation
authors: Ranxin Fang, Zhao Wang, Guangyue Guo, Dongdong Zhao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Transfer learning, which is widely applied in computer vision and natural language processing, enables the transfer of knowledge and experience from one domain to another related domain to build effective models. However, during the domain adaptation process, data from the source and target domains are often used jointly for training, which increases the risk of sensitive information leakage from the source domain and raises privacy concerns. To address this issue, we propose a Privacy-Preserving Semi-Supervised Transfer Learning model (PPSTL) that uses image pseudo-features instead of raw images. This design prevents data leakage at the visual level while resisting membership inference attacks. Specifically, the method employs a Gaussian Mixture Model (GMM) to generate pseudo-features from source domain data and utilizes a domain discriminator to align the extracted features of the target model with these pseudo-features, thereby enabling accurate classification. Experimental results on 12 transfer learning tasks across the four domains of the Office-Home dataset demonstrate that PPSTL not only resists membership inference attacks and prevents data leakage but also achieves classification accuracy comparable to non-privacy-preserving models.

title: FedCB: Joint Client Selection and Bandwidth Allocation for Unreliable Aerial Federated Learning
authors: Maomao Li, Tao Wu, Zhexian Shen, Hongjun Wang, Yimeng Huang, Haoxiang Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) have been widely used to perform search and tracking tasks in military and civil fields. As an emerging distributed learning paradigm, federated learning (FL) is more suitable for UAV networks with computing modules on board. UAVs train local models while a terrestrial base station (BS) aggregates the global model, forming an air-ground collaborative federated learning (AGCFL) system. However, UAVs typically face challenges such as unreliable communication links and limited onboard resources, adversely affecting overall FL performance. To address these issues, we propose a novel FL framework with joint client selection and bandwidth allocation strategy, called FedCB, which aims to minimize the global loss function. Specifically, the strategy mitigates the negative impacts of unreliable communication links by selecting UAVs with superior wireless channel conditions while rationally allocating bandwidth resources. We have designed an alternating iterative optimization-based algorithm to solve this problem. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that compared with other baseline schemes, our solution achieves significant improvements in model accuracy, fully validating its effectiveness and superiority.

title: Adoption and Implementation of Artificial Intelligence in Education: Insights from Science Teachers
authors: Grace T. Flores
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: This study examined the relationship between the level of artificial intelligence (AI) adoption and its implementation in science education. A descriptive-correlational research design was employed, involving 55 science teachers from three purposively selected public secondary schools in Butuan City, Agusan del Norte, Philippines. Participants were chosen through simple random sampling, and data were collected using a researcher-adapted and content-validated questionnaire with strong reliability (Cronbach’s alpha = 0.80). The instrument measured AI adoption dimensions, awareness, and readiness, institutional support, professional development, technological resources, and their correlation with AI implementation in instruction, assessment, and student engagement. Results analyzed using the Spearman Rank-Order Correlation Coefficient revealed strong and statistically significant positive associations across all dimensions. The overall level of AI adoption (ρ = 0.858, p <.001) emerged as the strongest predictor of implementation success, underscoring that effective AI integration requires access to resources, teacher preparedness, institutional commitment, and supportive leadership. These findings affirm that AI adoption is a multifactorial process, rooted in individual capacity and systemic support, and directly linked to improved teaching effectiveness, enhanced student outcomes, and greater instructional productivity. The study contributes empirical evidence to the growing literature on AI in Education, particularly within the Philippine context. It suggests that policymakers, school leaders, and teacher education programs should strategically invest in digital competencies, equitable access to AI tools, and continuous professional development to foster sustainable and inclusive AI integration in schools.

title: Intelligent Diagnosis and Optimization for Power Wireless Private Networks Driven by Dynamic Routing and Spatiotemporal Decoupling
authors: Pengyan Wang, Zhongping Xu, Yanru Wang, Zhentao Shen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: To address the challenges of intelligent analysis for massive spatiotemporal data in power wireless private networks, this paper proposes BM3, a deep learning architecture that deeply integrates Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit-Multi-Head Attention (BiGRU-MHA), dynamic routing with Mixture of Experts (MoE), and MLP-Mixer. The model achieves efficient feature mining through a three-stage collaborative mechanism. First, BiGRU-MHA captures long-term bidirectional dependencies in the temporal dimension to enhance the identification of critical features. Subsequently, a designed MoE gated routing layer adaptively selects expert networks to process diverse operational patterns (e.g., fault states, peak states) based on data characteristics, thereby improving feature specificity. Finally, MLP-Mixer is adopted to decouple spatiotemporal features, efficiently integrating spatial correlations and channel interactions through independent token-mixing and channel-mixing operations. Evaluated on a real-world power private network dataset, the BM3 model demonstrates superior performance over baseline models (including LSTM and Trans-former), achieving a 12.7% increase in F1-score for fault early-warning and an 18.3% reduction in RMSE for resource capacity prediction.

title: Geo-Ecological Factors, Mathematical Models, and Algorithms in Creating a Hybrid Neural Network Training Dataset for an Intelligent Groundwater Monitoring System
authors: Farxat Rajabov, Jamoljon Djumanov, Khudoyarkhan Jamolov, Shahzod Rakhmonov
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Ensuring food security in Uzbekistan and the wider Central Asian region requires sustainable water resource management under the pressures of climate change, population growth, and industrial development. Groundwater, which provides around 60% of drinking water and a significant share of irrigation supply, is of strategic importance. This study proposes the development of an intelligent computing system for groundwater monitoring, integrating sensors, networks, databases, and artificial intelligence algorithms. Due to the scarcity, fragmentation, and closed nature of groundwater data, the research emphasizes the generation of synthetic datasets that realistically reflect hydrogeological and geo-ecological variability. A hybrid modeling framework is established to simulate seasonal water level fluctuations, temperature cycles, pH dynamics, turbidity, pressure, and impedance spectra, incorporating the impacts of industrial activity and the Aral Sea. Statistical-process models and geo-ecological weighting functions are used to calibrate pollutant sources and anomaly scenarios. The synthetic datasets are validated through seasonal and anomalous test cases, ensuring distributional stability and training suitability for neural networks. The results provide a scalable approach for enhancing groundwater monitoring in Uzbekistan, supporting sustainable water management and contributing to ecological balance, agricultural efficiency, and food security.

title: Prediction of sea surface salinity in the Southern Ocean Based on CNN+ConvLSTM
authors: Dongdong Cheng, Xufeng Zheng, Junying Zhu, Zhonghua Zhao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: The salinity of the sea surface (SSS) is a pivotal component of the Southern Ocean’s dynamics, significantly influencing planetary-scale heat and carbon exchange processes.However, its variation mechanisms are complex, and observational data are scarce, making it difficult to accurately predict its spatiotemporal evolution using traditional methods. The applicability of existing prediction models for this region remains to be evaluated.This study employs daily-resolution SSS data from the Southern Ocean State Estimate (SOSE) for the period $2005 \sim 2010$ and the region $38^{\circ} \sim 78^{\circ} \mathrm{S}$ to develop a deep learning model that integrates a Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and a Convolutional Long Short-Term Memory network (ConvLSTM). The model aims to capture spatiotemporal features and achieve high-precision prediction of SSS one day in advance. The CNN component extracts spatial structures, while the ConvLSTM component captures temporal dynamics and enhances spatial feature recognition.The model demonstrated superior performance on the test set (year 2010), with monthly daily-average correlation coefficients (CORR) ranging from 0.901 to 0.919, mean absolute error (MAE) between 0.108 and 0.153 PSU, and root mean square error (RMSE) between 0.146 and 0.208 PSU. It significantly outperformed standalone CNN, LSTM, and hybrid CNN+LSTM models.The results indicate that the CNN+ConvLSTM model effectively identifies spatiotemporal variation characteristics of SSS in the Southern Ocean, particularly showing robust performance in capturing the seasonal migration of high-salinity subtropical and low-salinity polar water masses. This approach provides a reliable computational tool for predicting Southern Ocean salinity and studying associated climate feedback mechanisms.

title: Unsupervised Masking of Sedimentary Pores using K-Means and Fuzzy C-Means Clustering
authors: Lubna Mawaddah, Rizky Syah Gumelar, Muhammad Reesa Rosyid, Muhamad Akrom, Supriadi Rustad, Totok Sutojo
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: This study presents an effective methodology for identifying pore structures in rock images through image enhancement and clustering-based segmentation. The preprocessing stage utilized Contrast Limited Adaptive Histogram Equalization (CLAHE), which significantly improved image contrast and enhanced feature visibility. Segmentation was then performed using both K-Means and Fuzzy C-Means (FCM) clustering algorithms, evaluated across multiple cluster configurations. For K-Means, the optimal result was obtained at K = 4, with evaluation metrics showing SSE = 55,527,170.03, DBI = 0.53, and CHI = 2,731,977.85. For FCM, the best performance was achieved at K = 3, with PC = 0.78, PE = 0.39, and XBI = 0.13 averaged across the dataset. Binary pore masks were generated by converting clustered images to the HSL color space and selecting the darkest cluster as the pore region. When compared to the ground truth (10% pore), the proposed K-Means-Based method yielded a highly accurate pore proportion of 10.16%, outperforming the standard K-Means (10.73%) and FCM (14.65%) approaches. These results demonstrate the robustness of the proposed segmentation pipeline in accurately isolating pore regions, making it a reliable approach for digital rock analysis and related geological applications.

title: Simulation and Performance Analysis of Acoustic Direction Finding Systems for Small UAVs
authors: Yiyang Luo, Vladyslav Lutsenko, Oleksandr Soboliak, Iryna Lutsenko, Vitalii Trifanov, Ihor Popov
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: This paper explores the need for effective acoustic detection of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), focusing on mitigating background noise interference and enhancing signal-processing algorithms. Simulation modeling evaluates acoustic direction-finding systems under varying noise conditions, demonstrating high detection accuracy at favorable signal-to-noise ratios (SNR), with performance degrading as noise increases.

title: Research on QoS Prediction Method Based on User Location Features and Reputation
authors: Weicheng Li, Shunshun Peng, Taolin Guo, Hongbing Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: The explosive growth in web services has made Quality of Service (QoS) prediction a critical research topic in service computing. Existing QoS prediction methods often suffer from insufficient utilization of contextual information and lack robustness against outliers. To address these issues, this paper proposes a QoS prediction method that integrates user location information with reputation values. The method first employs the HDBSCAN density clustering algorithm to group similar users based on location features, utilizing a genetic algorithm to optimize clustering parameters. Next, it introduces a Dirichlet model to assess user reputation, distinguishing reliable from unreliable users. Finally, it integrates location-based clustering information with user reputation values into a matrix factorization framework to predict missing QoS values. Extensive experiments on the real-world WS-Dream dataset demonstrate that this method achieves significantly higher prediction accuracy compared to existing mainstream approaches.

title: VLTSR: Visual-Layout Multi-Modal Fusion for Table Structure Recognition
authors: Taogong Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Table Structure Recognition (TSR) is a crucial task in document understanding to extract structured table information from images. High-quality table structure recognition models depend on three essential capabilities: extracting and utilizing visual and layout information, global context modeling, and local detail encoding. However, existing methods face challenges in incorporating all these capabilities simultaneously. Consequently, we aim to enable table structure recognition networks to efficiently utilize multi-modal table data, high-quality global context modeling, and local detail encoding. This paper introduces VLTSR, a novel table structure recognition model composed of a state space model-based table image encoder, a layout feature fusion module, and an autoregressive decoder. We evaluated the proposed methods on several public datasets, and the experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach.

title: Analysis Of The Impact Of Some Clinical Blood Parameters On The Severity Of COVID-19 Disease
authors: Ibrahim Younouss Abdelhamid, Yuliia Svitlychna, Nataliia Shushliapina, Yana Nosova, Bohdan Pryvalov, Oleg Avrunin
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The aim of the study is to substantiate the diagnostic impact of clinical blood parameters in patients with COVID-19. The retrospective analysis covered 370 medical records of patients of the center for medical care for patients with COVID-19 in Kharkiv. The analysis included the evaluation of individual clinical blood parameters, the severity of the disease, the presence of general otolaryngologic symptoms and olfactory disorders. Statistical analysis included discriminant analysis with the calculation of the normalized Euclidean distance to determine the diagnostic significance of clinical blood parameters. The statistical analysis showed that clinical blood counts do not have a significant diagnostic contribution to the discrimination model, which already contains COVID-19-specific markers. Thus, olfactory impairment, as associated with acute rhinosinusitis in COVID-19, can serve as a prognostic marker for a more favorable course of pneumonia in hospitalized patients.

title: Research on Optimization Methods for Sorting Paths in Logistics Warehouses Based on Reinforcement Learning
authors: Xinfeng Yang, Jingxue Xia, Jialing Zhou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Aiming at the path optimization problem of multi-autonomous mobile robots (AMR/AGV) in cooperative sorting within a dynamic logistics environments, this paper proposes a path optimization framework based on multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL). By constructing a state space that integrates local observation and the global environment, a cooperative strategy containing discrete and continuous actions is designed, and the real-time decision of AMR/AGV is optimized by multi-objective reward function, which provides theoretical support for intelligent sorting in large-scale logistics centers.

title: Research on the performance of a neural network for recognizing combat vehicles
authors: Mariia Nazarkevych, Victoria Vysotska, Vasyl Lytvyn, Oleh Faizulin, Oleksii Kuziv, Andrii Nazarkevych
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: the performance of the neural network for recognizing combat vehicles in an intelligent visual surveillance system has been investigated. The system is mobile and built with real-time motion and the ability to detect, classify, and track objects. The system captures and recognizes video images from a camera installed on the vehicle. In the proposed system, moving object detection is carried out using an adaptive background subtraction scheme, which we propose to use in combat. It is shown how to identify moving objects. We present object detection schemes, temporal difference models, and adaptive background difference models to compare the efficiency and quality of detection. The study implemented a method for detecting moving objects based on adaptive background difference models.

title: Is One View Enough - Biomatter Threat Identification in 3D CT Scans
authors: Ivan Koptev, Cameron Walker, Andreas W. Kempa-Liehr
publish: 2025 IEEE International Carnahan Conference on Security Technology (ICCST)
abstract: Effective baggage screening is crucial for biosecurity, requiring accurate detection of biomatter threats in 3D computed tomography (CT) scans. This study introduces a novel approach that transforms 3D volumetric data into 2D representations using signal processing techniques and feature extraction. Feature selection and dimensionality reduction techniques, including Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Partial Least Squares Regression (PLSR), are applied to enhance classification performance. The results show that the choice of projection view significantly influences detection accuracy, with the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(z, x)$</tex>-view achieving the highest mAP@0.5 score of 0.810. Precision-recall analysis further reveals variability in detection performance across biomatter classes, highlighting the challenges posed by similar density profiles. The findings demonstrate the effectiveness of 2D representation learning for biomatter detection while acknowledging limitations due to information loss. Future work will explore hybrid 2D-3D models to further enhance detection capabilities.

title: HAOM-UNet: Hybrid Attention and Omnidirectional Mamba UNet for Accurate Cardiac MRI Segmentation
authors: Yue Wu, Wei Sun
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: Segmentation of cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is crucial for the early diagnosis and treatment of cardiovascular diseases. However, it faces challenges such as complex cardiac anatomy, dynamic changes in the cardiac cycle, and artifacts, particularly blurred myocardial boundaries, thin wall rupture of the right ventricle (RV) and small target loss. In this paper, we propose HAOM-UNet (Hybrid Attention and Omnidirectional Mamba UNet), an enhanced version of MSVM-UNet that introduces a hybrid attention mechanism and omnidirectional selective scanning module. Specifically, the framework upgrades the SS2D module to eight-directional OSS2D for better long-range dependency modeling, addressing issues like RV thin wall rupture and boundary blurring. It also incorporates HAOM-FFN, combining channel and spatial attention to improve small target feature extraction and suppress artifacts. Experimental results in the ACDC dataset show that HAOM-UNet outperforms MSVM-UNet, achieving an average DSC improvement of 1.09% and a significant reduction in Hausdorff distance (HD). This method effectively balances local detail preservation with global context modeling and provides an efficient, robust solution for high-precision cardiac MRI segmentation, with strong potential for clinical application.

title: USTAD: Unified Spatio-Temporal Anomaly Detection in High-Concurrency Serverless Edge Computing
authors: Hao Xi, Hao Fan, Chenhong Cao, Si Chen, Hai Wan, Xibin Zhao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Serverless edge computing is rapidly gaining traction due to its cost efficiency, flexibility, and capability to provide low-latency services by deploying compute resources closer to end-users. However, this distributed, highly concurrent paradigm expands the attack surface, presenting novel security threats and challenges for anomaly detection. Current approaches remain insufficient in dealing with the interleaved requests and complex temporal-spatial behaviors characteristic of high-concurrency edge environments, resulting in the lack of unified models that can detect anomalies both at the trace and function-internal levels. To address these challenges, we propose USTAD, a system specifically designed for serverless edge computing environments, which leverages graph attention networks to capture spatial and temporal behavioral features under high concurrency. USTAD employs advanced log partitioning techniques to maintain isolated request logs, thereby avoiding log interleave. Furthermore, an enhanced provenance graph is constructed to extract crucial spatial and temporal information regarding request behaviors. For robust feature extraction, a Paired Graph Attention Network (PGAT) processes the enhanced provenance graphs, and the Local Outlier Factor (LOF) algorithm clusters the PGAT outputs for effective anomaly detection. We evaluated USTAD on 10 real-world serverless edge computing attack scenarios and achieved an average F1 score of 94.20%, substantially outperforming existing detection methods.

title: On Access Control to Ontologies
authors: Darya Gavrilina
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Recently, systems for knowledge representation and processing have found increasing application in information systems and apps. This is due to the development of artificial intelligence (in particular, the development of the concept of AI agents), as well as methods of high-level development of information systems based on declarative descriptions of the subject domain. In particular, the bSystem platform for building intelligent applications is based on the use of semantic modeling methods and object ontologies as the basis for application development. In this regard, a fundamentally new task arises: managing the security of the use of logical systems and access to the information contained in them. For example, the bSystem platform is actively used to develop applied projects in the field of business management and fintech, where the critically important issue is the management of system security and policies for access to logical data. In this work, a model for access control to logical data is constructed and it is shown that this model itself can be represented as an object ontology. At present, the access control model is being implemented in the bSystem platform.

authors: Victor Busher, Valerii Tytiuk, Oleksii Chornyi, Oksana Glazeva, Valeriy Druzhinin, Lubov Melnikova
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The research is devoted to synthesize a controller with a fractional-order integral component to achieve the order of astaticism of the closed-loop speed BLDCM higher than 1 and with a neural network to improve the static and dynamic control accuracy. The control object is identified by a fractional-order differential equation. Four types of controllers are synthesized: a classic PID to provide settings close to the modular optimum (IntPID); a controller with a fractional-integral component that provides the order of astaticism of the loop 1.8 (FrPID), and – what is the scientific novelty of the work – hybrid controllers based on the first two, supplemented by neural networks of direct signal propagation NN–IntPID, NN–FrPID. FrPID compared to IntPID allowed to reduce the mean square error by almost 5 times, and the neural controller with a fractional integral component provided the best results: overshoot with a jump in the reference signal was reduced from 2.98% to 0.35%, the mean square error with a linearly changing reference signal was reduced by 11 times and the relative speed error decreases from 0.00801 to 0.00022, more than 35 times. The proposed algorithm for fast learning in each cycle of the control program also ensures the adaptation of the controller when the parameters of the control object change, what makes the possibility of using neural controllers with a fractional integral component for other objects, such as universal collector motors, electromagnetic brakes with adjustable torque.

title: Finetuning the Sample Points in Gaussian Filters Via Neural Networks_supp1-3645187.pdf
authors: Xiucong Sun
abstract: Gaussian filters with deterministic sample points, such as the Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF), Cubature Kalman Filter (CKF), Gauss– Hermite Quadrature Filter (GHQF), etc., have been widely employed for nonlinear state estimation. However, these filters utilize a fixed set of sample points irrespective of the system's nonlinearity. While various studies have explored data-driven approaches to optimize the three parameters of the UKF, these methods do not generalize well to other Gaussian filters with a greater number of sample points. In this letter, we propose a novel neural network-based unified framework for finetuning sample points across all Gaussian filters with deterministic sample points. Specifically, we first pretrain a Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) to approximate the mapping from the state's mean and covariance to the sample points of the original Gaussian filter. The MLP then replaces the sample points generation strategy in the Gaussian filter and is further refined by maximizing the marginal likelihood of the observed measurement data. Simulation results demonstrate that the Gaussian filters leveraging the well-trained MLP as the sample point generation strategy achieve higher filtering accuracy compared to their original counterparts.

title: Industrial Camera Calibration Using Synthetic Data Augmentation and FSC-McCNN in Froth Flotation Process
authors: Jin Luo, Zhaohui Tang, Hu Zhang, Ying Fan, Yongfang Xie, Zhien Dai, Weihua Gui
abstract: Accurate camera calibration is essential for obtaining precise three-dimensional information of a target. However, in the froth flotation process, it is challenging to position the calibration board support surfaces correctly. This difficulty makes it hard to capture high-quality calibration images from various angles, ultimately impacting the accuracy of the calibration results. To address this issue, we propose a planar template camera calibration method based on convolutional neural networks and synthetic data augmentation. Initially, we establish a virtual imaging scene to map the relationship between the feature map and camera parameters. Then, we conduct coarse camera calibration and apply synthetic data augmentation within specific range constraints to create a comprehensive calibration dataset. After that, we develop a deep calibration network named FSC-McCNN to facilitate the correspondence between the calibration feature map and camera parameters. This network comprises feature spatial coding (FSC) and multichannel convolutional neural networks (McCNN). The proposed approach effectively compensates for changes in camera focal length and requires only a single calibration image, thereby reducing the calibration workload at flotation sites. Experiments conducted on synthetic and real flotation datasets demonstrate the effectiveness and robustness of the proposed method.

title: System Design and Performance Evaluation of Alpha-SPECT: A Full-Body CZT-Based SPECT Scanner for Quantitative Imaging of Alpha Emitters and Their Daughters
authors: S. Mandot, E.M. Zannoni, C. Yang, G. Sgouros, Y. Du, E.C. Frey, L.-J. Meng
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Targeted Alpha Therapy (TAT) offers significant therapeutic potential in oncology, leveraging the high linear energy transfer (LET) and short path length of alpha particles to selectively eliminate micro-metastases and single cancer cells while sparing healthy tissue. However, clinical translation is limited by the lack of imaging tools capable of monitoring in vivo biodistribution and dosimetry of alpha-emitting isotopes. To address this gap, we have developed the Alpha-SPECT system—a high-sensitivity, high-resolution whole-body clinical SPECT scanner integrated with advanced CZT imaging spectrometers, specifically designed for simultaneous imaging of therapeutic alpha-emitters (such as Ac-225, Pb-212 and Ra-223) along with their decay daughters (including Fr-221, At-217, Bi-213, and Po-213 from Ac-225) in patients. The system integrates 496 micro-pinhole cameras across 31 detector panels in a cylindrical geometry, each comprising 16 CZT detectors <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 \times 20 \times 6 \text{mm}^{3}$</tex> with pixelated anodes and HEXITEC ASICs. A novel dual-FOV configuration is enabled by a precision CT-derived rotating gantry that switches between a large-field-of-view mode and a high-resolution mode. The system achieves sub-10-um gantry accuracy and a de-magnification ratio of 1:11, enhancing spatial resolution and angular sampling. Energy calibration with Ba-133 and Co-57 sources demonstrated average resolutions of 4-6 keV at 122 keV , further improved to 2.5-3 keV with machine learning-based charge-sharing correction. Ongoing geometric calibration and future NEMA-compliant performance evaluations aim to establish the Alpha-SPECT as a robust platform for clinical TAT imaging.

title: Determining Electron and Hole Drift Velocities in Thin 4H-SiC Diodes Using a High-Frequency Readout
authors: A. Gsponer, J. Burin, S. Gundacker, M. Knopf, S. Onder, D. Radmanovac, S. Waid, T. Bergauer
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Silicon carbide (SiC) has experienced a renaissance in high-power electronics due to its high temperature stability, high breakdown field and low power dissipation. Its high band-gap also makes it an interesting candidate for radiation hard particle detectors in high-energy physics and medical applications. Further, a high electron and hole mobility promises devices suitable for ultra-fast particle detection and timing applications. However, currently the front-end readout constitutes a bottleneck when investigating these devices. We developed a high-frequency readout board with an intrinsic bandwidth of 10 GHz. With this readout we recorded the current transient signals of a small 4H-SiC PiN diode with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$140 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> diameter and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> thickness upon UV-laser, alpha particle and high-energy proton beam excitation. In all three cases we clearly can separate between electron and hole drift, which enables the extraction of the charge carrier drift and saturation velocities. These velocities, directly measured with transient current techniques, provide a valuable comparison with literature values and constitute an essential input for dedicated TCAD simulations. We will conclude on a complete picture of the readout electronics, electrical and TCAD simulations and possible future applications.

title: Development of Sdd Array for Ultra-Fast Measurement
authors: D. Matsunaga, K. Ishikura, Y. Okubo, S. Ikawa, J. Aoyama, N. Zorzi, F. Ficorella, M. C. Vignali, A. Samusenko, G. Pepponi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The performance of Silicon Drift Detectors (SDD), including the pre-amplifier, is constantly improving. Recently the energy resolution was improved even at short shaping time, allowing high throughput measurements in X-ray analysis [1][2]. As a direct consequence the measurement time becomes shorter and industrial applications are expanding. To reduce the measurement time further, the active area and hence the solid angle of the detector also can be increased. However, in a SDD with large active area, the drift time of the signal charge becomes longer, and it makes the rise time of the signal longer, and then the signal processing time longer. Although using multiple detectors simultaneously is one of the good solutions, the aligned detectors have dead space in peripheral areas of the respective detectors. In a SDD array, multiple SDD elements are fabricated monolithically to achieve both high throughput and large solid angle [3][4]. In such a SDD array if X-ray photons come into the boundary area between the different channels, generated charges divide and travel towards different adjacent anodes (charge sharing), or parts of the charges is not collected because of weak electric fields near the border areas. This phenomenon causes an unexpected tailing and background in the acquired spectrum. We're trying to reduce these boundary areas with weak electric fields. We add electrodes (drift rings) in these border areas on the radiation-entrance side to enhance a high electric field which drives signal charges to the read-out electrode swiftly. Our preliminary results from a single SDD prototype indicated that the added drift rings on the entrance side improve the tailing of the spectrum by 12%. Effects and technical problems of the drift rings on the entrance side will be reported and discussed.

title: Concept, Development, and Testing of Local Digital Excore Nuclear Instrumentation System
authors: T. Azuma, M. Sasano, R. Konishi, S. Nakamura, T. Yamane, K. Higashimura, R. Tanaka, M. Hayashi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper describes the development of the excore nuclear instrumentation system (EIS), one of the instrumentation and control (I&C) systems, for the small modular reactor (SMR). Mitsubishi Electric Corporation is involved in the development of the SMR, specifically the “SMR-300”, which is being developed by Holtec International in the United States. The I&C system for SMRs requires a reduction in construction costs and operation and maintenance (O&M) costs. This EIS aims to reduce the number of specific cables through local placement, assuming installation near the exterior of the reactor containment vessel, and to achieve miniaturization, reduction of material quantity, and improvement of maintainability by expanding the scope of digitalization. The following sections will introduce the concept of the developed Local Digital EIS and the test results of the prototype using UTR-KINKI.

title: Development of an Onboard Edge-AI Processing System for Particle Classification
authors: A. Takeda, Y. Sasaki, R. Takagi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Recent advancements in CPU-embedded FPGAs, such as the Xilinx Zynq UltraScale+, have made Edge-AI technologies more accessible for real-time onboard data processing. Leveraging this trend, we have developed a quantum imaging camera capable of performing onboard inference using deep learning. As a demonstration, we implemented a system that classifies particle types-specifically X-rays, electrons (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\beta$</tex>-rays), and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha$</tex>-particles-using a deep neural network deployed on the Deep Learning Processing Unit (DPU) of the Zynq UltraScale+. The implementation was conducted on a Xilinx evaluation board, “ZCU102,” interfaced with the SOICMOS pixel detectors. When the SOI-CMOS pixel detectors detect particles, they output information on the detection timing, coordinate address, and rough spatial distribution. From this, we extract <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$16 \times 16$</tex> pixels of energy values and input them to a TensorFlow-based deep learning model that outputs the probabilities of each particle class. The particle with the highest probability is selected as the final classification result. The model, trained with data from the SOICMOS pixel detectors, achieved a classification accuracy exceeding 98%. We are currently in the stage of integrating the whole system for real-time testing with live sensor data.

title: Verification of Moderators for On-Site Detection System of Concealed Highly Enriched Uranium
authors: K. Tanabe, M. Komeda, Y. Toh, Y. Kitamura, Y. Takahashi, T. Misawa, K. Tsuchiya
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: A non-destructive assay (NDA) technique for on-site detection of gram quantities of highly enriched uranium (HEU) makes a significant contribution to strengthening international nuclear security. Effective prevention of nuclear material smuggling will be possible through widespread dissemination and deployment, including border control and airport baggage inspection. We have developed a compact and transportable NDA system consisting of a <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">252</sup>Cf rotation device and a water Cherenkov neutron detector (WCND). Suspicious objects are enclosed with a moderator and placed between the rotation device and the WCND, followed by measurement of the time distribution of neutron counts to determine the presence or absence of nuclear material, including lead shielded HEU. The moderator increases the number of induced fission neutrons and improve the nuclear material detection performance. In the present study, the contribution of moderator type and thickness to the detection performance was examined using numerical simulations.

title: Segmentation of Dynamic PET Imaging Using An Adaptive Clustering Algorithm
authors: F. Gu, Q. Wu, X. Meng, Z. Xie, Z. Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Segmentation of dynamic PET imaging remains a challenging task due to high noise levels, limited spatial resolution, and temporal variability in tracer uptake. To address these issues, we propose a novel adaptive clustering algorithm that efficiently processes large-scale, patient-specific datasets without requiring cross-subject training data or manual annotations. The algorithm dynamically adapts to temporal patterns in tracer distribution and enables robust segmentation of physiologically relevant regions. We evaluated the method using baseline PET-FLT imaging data from breast cancer patients, obtained from the ACRIN dataset in the National Cancer Institute's Cancer Imaging Archive. Results demonstrate accurate and consistent segmentation of the heart, validating the algorithm's effectiveness under realistic clinical conditions. This approach significantly enhances downstream quantitative analyses, particularly in image-derived input function extraction and kinetic modeling, and holds strong potential for application in the state-of-the-art whole-body PET scans, supporting more precise and sophisticated quantitative assessments.
