title: Characterization of Shielded Plutonium Samples Using Neutron Spectroscopy
authors: S. D. Clarke, R. Lopez, F. B. Darby, S. A. Pozzi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Identification and characterization of plutonium samples is an important safeguards challenge. The work investigates the impact of shielding on the characterization of various plutonium samples, specifically metal and oxide forms, using neutron spectroscopy with a trans-stilbene detector. This study expands on previous work by simulating various plutonium sources, including the BeRP ball, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{PuO2}$</tex>, and PuBe, shielded with high-density polyethylene. A trans-stilbene detector was simulated 30 cm away from these sources using the MCNPX-PoliMi and MPPost codes. Simulation results show that the spectral shape remains consistent at low light output but changes at higher light outputs, depending on the shielding and type of source. Source characterization is performed using spectral integral ratios: for the BeRP and PuO2 sources, the ratio increases with more shielding, as polyethylene moderates fission neutrons and hardens the detected spectrum. Conversely, the PuBe source shows a decrease in the ratio with increased shielding due to the higher energy of PuBe neutrons. The results demonstrate that a spectral ratio approach effectively discriminates these plutonium sources with up to 7.6 cm of polyethylene shielding. Experiments have been performed with these plutonium source and shielding configurations. At the conference, we will present results based on these experiments as well as simulations with a wider range of shielding thicknesses.

title: Characterization of a Sub-10Ps Ring-Oscillator-Based Time Measurement Circuit
authors: X. Li, C. Wang, Q. Zhu, X. Wang, X. Yan, J. Ye, L. Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Accurate time measurement is crucial for time-of-flight positron emission tomography and highenergy physics experiments. In this paper, we present a prototype timing circuit designed in a commercial <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$55-\text{nm}$</tex> CMOS process for high-resolution timing measurements. The circuit integrates a ring-oscillator-based delay line, a bypassable delay-locked loop, a passive timing interpolation, and a phase-locked loop for clock generation. A circular interpolation strategy is employed to combine the ring oscillator and the interpolation technique, achieving high resolution. Initial test results confirm that the circuit's functionality and power consumption closely align with simulations, demonstrating a nominal bin size of approximately 5.2 ps. However, the time precision is degraded by abnormal bubble occurrences. These issues are likely attributed to the large setup time of the quantization D-flip-flops, insufficient signal driving capability, and propagation delay mismatches caused by layout imperfections. Further analysis and design optimizations are currently underway, with an optimized version expected to be submitted in 2025.

title: A Multi-Fingered Robotic Hand With Fiber-Optic Force and Tactile Sensing for Remote Manipulation
authors: Jaehyun Yi, Wook Joon Chung, Jeongwon Lee, Hamza Muzammal, Jeonghun Park, Young Soo Park, Yong-Lae Park
abstract: Underactuated robotic hands are extensively used in remote manipulation due to their ability to adapt to various object sizes and shapes. Their structural simplicity and small number of actuators required for operation make them highly versatile and responsive, which is crucial for effective teleoperation. In addition to grasping performance, haptic feedback, which integrates force and tactile sensing, is essential for dexterous manipulation. This study proposes a solution using fiber-optic tendons embedded with fiber Bragg gratings (FBGs), combining sensing and actuation to simultaneously perform power transmission, along with force and tactile sensing. Each finger employs a fiber-optic tendon with three FBGs: one measures tendon tension, and the other two at the fingertip detect contact force and temperature. The tendon is placed on the volar side of the finger and routed to an actuation module with a servomotor at the wrist for power transmission. This tendon enables finger flexion, while a passive extension mechanism with linear springs on the dorsal side facilitates extension. Experimental results demonstrate the feasibility of this approach, showing the hand's multifunctional capabilities, including haptic feedback and power transmission, as well as its potential for teleoperation. This approach improves the robotic hand's ability to provide real-time feedback, improving dexterity in remote manipulation.

title: Robust $H_\infty$ Uncertainties-Tolerant Observer-Based Reference Quantum Trajectory Tracking Control for Lindblad Master Equation
authors: Shin-Yi Wen, Bor-Sen Chen, Chun-Liang Lin
abstract: Robust output feedback reference quantum trajectory tracking control design is proposed by the simultaneous continuous weak measurement of non-commuting observables. Using the robust <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$H_\infty$</tex-math></inline-formula> uncertainties-tolerant observer-based reference quantum trajectory tracking control (UTOBRQTTC) design strategy, the proposed method can robustly estimate the quantum trajectory and robustly track a sequence of any reference quantum states against undesired uncertainties and potential unavailable fault signals. Smoothed signal models are embedded into the augmented bilinear quantum system derived from Lindblad master equation. With the regression of unavailable system and sensor fault signal by smoothed models, the proposed <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$H_\infty$</tex-math></inline-formula> UTOBRQTTC design of the augmented bilinear quantum system can proactively compensate for the corruption of fault signals. Therefore, robust quantum trajectory estimation and reference quantum trajectory tracking can be achieved simultaneously via the proposed robust <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$H_\infty$</tex-math></inline-formula> UTOBRQTTC design strategy. Furthermore, the nonlinear Hamilton-Jacobi inequality (HJI)-constrained optimization problem of optimal robust <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$H_\infty$</tex-math></inline-formula> UTOBRQTTC design strategy can be treated as an LMIs-constrained optimization problem by the upper bound of spectral radius of augmented bilinear quantum system and the proposed two-step procedure, which can be efficiently solved with the help of MATLAB LMI TOOLBOX. Finally, several simulation examples of two-level bilinear quantum systems represented by the Lindblad master equation are provided to demonstrate the estimation performance of quantum trajectory and fault signals and any arbitrary signal tracking performance for more practical applications of bilinear quantum systems.

title: A Performance-Controllable Neural Network Guided Backstepping Predictive Control for Interconnected systems
authors: Wenpu Cao, Keke Huang, Dehao Wu, Yishun Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Automation Science and Engineering
abstract: Due to the inherent structural complexity, dynamic behavior, and strong nonlinearities of interconnected systems, conventional control and existing data-driven methods such as T–S fuzzy models and SINDy often struggle to simultaneously ensure modeling accuracy, structural interpretability, and real-time adaptability under dynamic operation modes. To address these limitations, this paper proposes an affine-structured performance-controllable neural network guided backstepping predictive control framework. Unlike conventional black-box data-driven models, the proposed approach embeds the affine nonlinear system structure into the neural network and adopts a Lyapunov-based training strategy, enabling both accurate dynamic approximation and explicit control law design. Meanwhile, a backstepping predictive control scheme is developed to effectively handle interconnection-induced coupling and multivariable constraints with reduced computational burden. Furthermore, a performance-controllable integrated neural network adaptive update method is introduced by reformulating model adaptation as a control problem, allowing near-real-time model updating using only finite data and guaranteeing stable and rapid convergence of prediction errors. Rigorous theoretical analysis and extensive experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves superior control performance under dynamic operation modes.

title: Estimation of the Caged Object's Posture under Forces Using Stepwise Geometric Calculations_supp1-3645660.mp4
authors: Ryota Yokomura
abstract: In pin-hole assembly processes, precise alignment or compliance mechanisms are typically required. This paper proposes a method for connecting objects by utilizing caging to constrain their motion, enabling the insertion of a pin into a hole to adjust the allowable relative pose for assembly. This approach eliminates the need for force control, even with low-degree-of-freedom manipulators, and reduces deflection caused by misalignment during connection. Although previous research has extensively studied appropriate finger configurations for caging, the behavior of caged objects under external forces remains insufficiently investigated. Furthermore, when connecting caged objects by contact, pose estimation often requires complex collision computations that account for intricate object geometries, which are computationally expensive and may fail to converge when small gaps are present. To address this issue, we propose a geometric method that approximates pose changes of caged three-dimensional objects under external forces as rotations about contact points. As a representative case, we focus on objects composed of cuboid elements. The estimated results for simple objects, including caged objects with small clearances, were consistent with geometrically derived theoretical solutions, and are obtained within 0.6 seconds, indicating a practical computation time.

title: Filament Sliding Linear Potentiometer-based Data Glove (FLiPo) for Precisely Annotating Human Finger Poses_supp1-3645653.mp4
authors: Zhigang Wu
abstract: Data gloves offer excellent portability and a strong ability to handle occluded movements, making them more advantageous over other methods for capturing complex hand motions in unstructured environments. However, the majority of existing hand-motion-capture gloves do not preserve visual features of the hand, which critically hinders their applicability for automatic pose annotation in RGB images. Here, we propose a data glove based on filament-sliding linear potentiometers (FLiPo), which can maintain finger appearance and ensure high accuracy as well as robustness, paving the way for automatic annotation. In FLiPo, fine filaments (Φ.1 mm) are deployed on finger skin to transmit joint arc length variations as well as preserve the hand's visual features, while linear potentiometers used to capture filament length changes are positioned on the arm. Simultaneously, a quantitative occlusion scoring metric is proposed to evaluate the degree of finger occlusion caused by the device. Further, we experimentally analyze the nonlinearities induced by biaxial joint coupling and skin tissue artifact (STA)-related hysteresis, and employ a fully connected neural network to map arc length to joint angles with an MAE of joint angles of 2.15°. Meanwhile, tests under challenging environmental conditions, including heat, moisture, and magnetic interference, are conducted to evaluate its stability. Finally, the system's capability for real-time pose capture with high accuracy, robustness, and low occlusion was demonstrated.

title: SIGN: Safety-Aware Image-Goal Navigation for Autonomous Drones via Reinforcement Learning
authors: Zichen Yan, Rui Huang, Lei He, Shao Guo, Lin Zhao
abstract: Image-goal navigation (ImageNav) tasks a robot with autonomously exploring an unknown environment and reaching a location that visually matches a given target image. While prior works primarily study ImageNav for ground robots, enabling this capability for autonomous drones is substantially more challenging due to their need for high-frequency feedback control and global localization for stable flight. In this paper, we propose a novel sim-to-real framework that leverages reinforcement learning (RL) to achieve ImageNav for drones. To enhance visual representation ability, our approach trains the vision backbone with auxiliary tasks, including image perturbations and future transition prediction, which results in more effective policy training. The proposed algorithm enables end-to-end ImageNav with direct velocity control, eliminating the need for external localization. Furthermore, we integrate a depth-based safety module for real-time obstacle avoidance, allowing the drone to safely navigate in cluttered environments. Unlike most existing drone navigation methods that focus solely on reference tracking or obstacle avoidance, our framework supports comprehensive navigation behaviors, including autonomous exploration, obstacle avoidance, and image-goal seeking, without requiring explicit global mapping. Code and model checkpoints are available at <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://github.com/Zichen-Yan/SIGN</uri>.

title: Co-NavGPT: Multi-Robot Cooperative Visual Semantic Navigation Using Vision Language Models_supp1-3645650.mp4
authors: Bangguo Yu
abstract: Visual target navigation is a critical capability for autonomous robots operating in unknown environments, particularly in human-robot interaction scenarios. While classical and learning-based methods have shown promise, most existing approaches lack common-sense reasoning and are typically designed for single-robot settings, leading to reduced efficiency and robustness in complex environments. To address these limitations, we introduce Co-NavGPT, a novel framework that integrates a Vision Language Model (VLM)as a global planner to enable common-sense multi-robot visual target navigation. Co-NavGPT aggregates sub-maps from multiple robots with diverse viewpoints into a unified global map, encoding robot states and frontier regions. The VLM uses this information to assign frontiers across the robots, facilitating coordinated and efficient exploration. Experiments on the Habitat-Matterport 3D (HM3D) demonstrate that Co-NavGPT outperforms existing baselines in terms of success rate and navigation efficiency, without requiring task-specific training. Ablation studies further confirm the importance of semantic priors from the VLM. We also validate the framework in real-world scenarios using quadrupedal robots. Supplementary video and code are available at: <uri xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">https://sites.google.com/view/co-navgpt2</uri>

title: Fully Distributed Path Planning and Bipartite Formation Tracking for Multiple Euler-Lagrange Agents with Faults and Input Saturation
authors: Zhi-Kui Wang, Teng-Fei Ding, Ming-Feng Ge, Xiao-Shan Guo, Zhi-Wei Liu
abstract: This paper addresses the path planning and bipartite formation tracking (BFT) problem for multiple Euler-Lagrange agents (MELAs) subject to actuator faults and input saturation. A fully distributed three-layer framework is proposed. In the decision layer, a safe path-velocity Q-learning (SPV-Q-learning) algorithm is proposed, which ensures the rapid generation of reliable paths by introducing a decay mechanism and safety constraints. In the estimated layer, a time-base generator (TBG)-based observer is introduced to reconstruct the leader’s state using only local interactions, then, all followers acquire the leaders state under the fully distributed estimator. In the local layer, an anti-saturation fault-tolerant law is designed to handle model uncertainties, actuator degradation, and bounded inputs, thereby ensuring high-precision trajectory tracking for all agents. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves both efficient path planning and robust BFT performance, significantly improving resilience under actuator faults and input constraints.

title: Hybrid Reputation Aggregation: A Robust Defense Mechanism for Adversarial Federated Learning in 5G and Edge Network Environments
authors: Saeid Sheikhi, Panos Kostakos, Lauri Loven
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Communications Society
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) in 5G and edge network environments faces severe security threats from adversarial clients. Malicious participants can perform label flipping, inject backdoor triggers, or launch Sybil attacks to corrupt the global model. This paper introduces Hybrid Reputation Aggregation (HRA), a novel robust aggregation mechanism designed to defend against diverse adversarial behaviors in FL without prior knowledge of the type of attack. HRA combines geometric anomaly detection with momentum-based reputation tracking of clients. In each round, it detects outlier model updates via distance-based geometric analysis while continuously updating a trust score for each client based on historical behavior. This hybrid approach enables the adaptive filtering of suspicious updates and the long-term penalization of unreliable clients, countering attacks ranging from backdoor insertions to random noise and Byzantine failures. We evaluate HRA in a large-scale proprietary 5G network dataset (3M+ records) and the widely used NF-CSE-CIC-IDS2018 benchmark under diverse adversarial attack scenarios. Experimental results reveal that HRA achieves robust global model accuracy of up to 98.66% on the 5G dataset and 96.60% on NF-CSE-CIC-IDS2018, outperforming state-of-the-art aggregators such as Krum, Trimmed Mean, and Bulyan by significant margins. Our ablation studies further demonstrate that the full hybrid system achieves 98.66% accuracy, while the anomaly-only and reputation-only variants drop to 84.77% and 78.52%, respectively, validating the synergistic value of our dual-mechanism approach. This demonstrates HRA’s enhanced resilience and robustness in 5G/edge federated learning deployments, even under significant adversarial conditions.

title: Design Simulation of a Brain-Dedicated Whole Gamma Imaging System for Simultaneous SPECT and PET
authors: R. Abe, G. Akamatsu, H. Tashima, T. Yamaya
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Positron emission tomography (PET) and single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) are both useful in the diagnosis of dementia, for example, amyloid PET and Cerebral blood flow SPECT, but each requires a separate imaging device. A whole gamma imaging (WGI) system, currently under development at QST, enables Compton imaging of single gamma rays and PET simultaneously, by using a double ring structure with an additional scattering detector inside a PET ring. In the previous small WGI prototypes, both scatterer and absorber detectors were optimized for radionuclides that emit high-energy gamma rays, such as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{44} \text{Sc}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{89} \text{Zr}$</tex>. On the other hand, for the major radionuclides often used in SPECT, detecting their single gamma rays as Compton events was difficult because the gamma rays were low energy, and most of the scattered gamma-rays were absorbed at the scatterer itself. In this study, we investigated the scintillator material and thickness of the scatterer detector of WGI to be suitable for Compton imaging of the low-energy gamma rays of 141 keV and 159 keV as the measurement target, assuming a braindedicated geometry with a 250 mm inner diameter and 210 mm axial length. We evaluated the detection sensitivity of Compton events using a Monte Carlo simulation with Geant4. As a result, a Compton sensitivity of 0.4 % for 141 keV and 0.6 % for 159 keV was achieved using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{LaBr}_{3}$</tex> with a thickness of 3.5 mm as the scatterer detector. These values exceeded those of conventional collimator-based SPECT systems. Future work will include image quality prediction through imaging simulation of WGI for low-energy gamma rays.

title: Noise-Level-Estimation Network for CT-Less Low Dose Total-Body PET Imaging
authors: H. Wang, C. Kong, G. Chen, X. Qiao, W. Ding, B. Li, Q. Huang
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Deep learning-based low-dose PET imaging has been extensively explored to minimize radiation exposure or shorten scan duration. However, the model's performance is often compromised by the variability and unpredictability of low-dose levels encountered in clinical practice. Furthermore, while CT scans acquired during the examination provide essential attenuation maps for PET reconstruction (enabling attenuation and scatter correction), they may contribute to radiation exposure comparable to or even exceeding that of PET itself. In this study, we propose a Noise-Level-Estimation Network to restore non-attenuation-corrected low-dose PET images to their full-dose, attenuation-corrected counterparts. The model was trained on 500 total-body PET scans from Ruijin Hospital and evaluated on an independent set of 50 scans. Quantitative results demonstrated that our method significantly enhances the image quality of CT-less low-dose PET scans. This approach presents a promising strategy to reduce radiation exposure in PET/CT examinations, potentially eliminating the need for concurrent CT scans in clinical scenarios.

title: Ultra Low-Noise Charge-Sensitive Amplifier Arrays for Direct-Charge Sensing Applications
authors: A. Papadopoulou, Y. Mei, T. Prakash, P. Sorensen
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Dual-phase liquid Xenon TPCs have been used for decades in diverse nuclear and particle physics experiments, including dark matter [1] and neutrino detection [2], thanks to their relatively low energy threshold for electron-ion pair production, and high scalability. However, a critical shortcoming arises from the high-voltage grids that provide electron amplification via electroluminescence in the liquid-vapor interface, causing parasitic photon and electron emission that significantly compromises rare-event searches. A promising solution is to implement a direct charge sensing plane featuring an array of CMOS charge-sensitive amplifier (CSA) readouts [3]. This approach eliminates the risk of hotspots and has the added benefit of potentially improving vertex reconstruction near TPC walls, where photon statistics and reflections currently limit resolution. To demonstrate feasibility, a 256-channel CSA array chip has been developed using a 180 nm CMOS process with an 1.8 V supply. The design accommodates a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$16 \times 16$</tex> pad layout, with a tight pixel pitch to meet vertex resolution requirements. Each CSA achieves an equivalent noise charge (ENC) of 3.2 electrons rms, at an 850 uA current consumption. These features are critical for dark matter direct-detection experiments, which demand high sensitivity to rare, low-energy events. This chip serves as a proof-of-concept vehicle with integrated testability features and design variations, paving the way for advanced heterogeneous integration. By stacking electron-focusing structures on the CMOS plane, entirely new detector architectures can emerge. This work highlights the potential of CMOS technology for constructing highly sensitive, low-noise, and compact front-end systems in next-generation TPC-based experiments.

title: Denoising SPECT Images Using Noise2Void Deep Learning Method: Comparison of Pre-Denoising and Post-Denoising Approaches
authors: Y. Hirosaki, T. Ono, K. Koshino, H. Watabe, T. Yuasa, T. Zeniya
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Our group has been developing a high-resolution SPECT system. Generally, in SPECT system, there is a trade-off issue and that the detection efficiency of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\gamma$</tex>-rays decreases as the resolution of SPECT images increases, resulting in noisy images. To solve this problem, we have applied Noise2Void (N2V), an unsupervised deep learning method, to improve the image quality of SPECT images. In our previous study we applied N2V as pre-denoising approach to projection images. The aim of this study is to compare pre-denoising approach to apply N2V to projection images (Pre-N2V) and post-denosing method to apply N2V to reconstruction images (Post-N2V) at different noise levels. Assuming our high-resolution SPECT system with parallel-hole collimator, numerical simulation was performed to evaluate two types of N2V approaches. We prepared projection images of brain numerical phantoms with multiple noise levels, and compared the images reconstructed with Pre-N2V and image reconstructed with Post-N2V. The results showed that the denoising performance of N2V depends on the processing method and noise level. PreN2V approach was more effective when the noise level was higher. On the other hand, the difference between Pre-N2V and Post-N2V approaches became smaller as the noise level decreased. This study suggested that when N2V is actually applied for denoising SPECT images, it is important to select an appropriate processing procedure (Pre-N2V or Post-N2V) according to the noise level of the image.

title: Fabrication of Strip-Type Transition Edge Sensors by Focused Ion Beam
authors: M.A. Choghadi, Y. Mitsuya, H. Takahashi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Transition Edge Sensors (TES) are widely being used in astrophysics for their high energy resolution. This high energy resolution enables the feature of photon number resolving capability that is essential in the field of optical quantum computing. However, TES timing jitter is typically much slower than that of superconducting nanowire single photon detectors (SNSPD) which are quite fast but unable to resolve the number of arriving photons. Since the principle of TES signal is based on heat conductance in ultra low temperature, a remedy to overcome its slow timing response is to reduce its size. The produced heat upon absorption of the photon would propagate within a smaller area and sensor becomes hotter which means higher signal to noise ratio and much sharper rise in the signal. It is very common to use <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9-\mu \mathrm{m}$</tex>-pitch fiber in telecommunications as well as optical quantum computing, therefore, by making the sensitive area smaller than that pitch, the detection efficiency degrades. In this research we kept the sensitive area of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \times 10 \mu \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex> and we divided it into several strips in parallel. Each strip performs as an individual TES which is smaller than the overall TES and provides a faster rise time. In this case, the detection efficiency is merely affected by the gaps between the strips. It is difficult to narrow the width of strips down to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> as well as the gap width to less than 500 nm through typical photolythography fabrication. For a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10-\mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> TES device with 5 strips (4 gaps), this results in a 20 % loss in the sensitive area. By using a focused ion beam (FIB) we were able to narrow down the gap width to 50 nm, which means that the detection efficiency of a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \times 10 \mu \mathrm{m}^{2}$</tex> TES even with 9 gaps would reduce only around 5 %. The fabricated devices became superconducting with critical temperatures around <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$250-300 \text{mK}$</tex> and showed faster rise time after being cut by FIB.

title: Hypergraph Neural Network Track Reconstruction Pipeline for HL-LHC Experiments
authors: R. Estevam de Paula, M. A.L. Leite, V. H. Nascimento
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This work describes a Hypergraph Neural Network (HGNN) pipeline for charged particle track reconstruction in High Energy Physics (HEP) experiments that will be operating at the High Luminosity Large Hadron Collider (HL-LHC). Extensive research is being conducted to develop reconstruction methods that provide the same efficiency as current adaptive filter methods, but with enough throughput to suit the increase in information density of HL-LHC events. Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) are the most promising substitutes due to their high-throughput when implemented in Graphics Processing Units (GPUs) while retaining high reconstruction efficiency. Most prominent works apply edge-classifying GNNs to determine whether a segment between two detector hits belongs to a particle track or not. We explore a HGNN approach, where hyperedges are defined as track candidates rather than just a segment between hits. This change in design allows modeling of relationships between hits that go beyond their pairwise connection. For graph construction, we developed a custom algorithm that follows the typical seeding stage, finding track candidates and building the hypergraph. Next, the HGNN is responsible for attributing scores to the candidates based on their likelihood to be a true particle track. This pipeline was evaluated using the ACTS (A Common Tracking Software) open-source framework to simulate HLLHC top-quark pair production events with 200 interactions per bunch crossing (pileup) on the Open Data Detector (ODD). Our pipeline achieved a global track efficiency of 92.9 % on the aforementioned events within a fiducial region, an important achievement that justifies continuing effort to optimize its throughput.

title: Sum Rate Maximization for Pinching Antennas Assisted RSMA System With Multiple Waveguides
authors: Peiyu Wang, Xueyun He, Hong Wang, Rongfang Song
abstract: In this letter, a pinching antennas (PAs) assisted rate splitting multiple access (RSMA) system with multiple waveguides is investigated to maximize sum rate. A two-step algorithm is proposed to determine PA activation scheme and optimize the waveguide beamforming. Specifically, a low complexity spatial correlation and distance based method is proposed for PA activation selection. After determining the PA activation status, a semi-definite programming (SDP) based successive convex approximation (SCA) is leveraged to obtain the suboptimal waveguide beamforming. Simulation results show that the proposed multiple waveguides based PAs assisted RSMA method achieves better performance than various benchmarking schemes.

title: Joint Activity and Attenuation Map Estimation for PET with TOF, Lu-176 Background and Back Scatter
authors: Z. Liu, T. Li, L. He, S. Tang, Y. Dong
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Maximum Likelihood Attenuation and Activity algorithm, which reconstructs attenuation map using 511 keV emission data, and the Maximum Likelihood Transmission Reconstruction algorithm that generates attenuation map through <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">176</sup> Lu-based background radiation or backscatter-induced photons are three purely physical, non-AI-dependent approaches for attenuation correction in CTLESS PET image reconstruction. Each method possesses distinct advantages and limitations. The MLAA-Tx algorithm presents an integrative approach that synthesizes the complementary strengths of these methods while effectively mitigating their inherent limitations. In this study, we adopt the MLAA-Tx algorithm to reconstruct the activity image and attenuation map, with emission data, <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">176</sup> Lu background data, and backscatter data all taken into account. The study was based on NX PET/CT scanner and performed with simulated NEMA-IQ phantom data. The algorithm demonstrated robust performance on the simulation dataset, indicating its potential for accurate <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu$</tex> -map and activity image reconstruction.

title: Temporal Stereo Matching From Event Cameras Via Joint Learning With Stereoscopic Flow
authors: Jae-Young Kang, Hoonhee Cho, Kuk-Jin Yoon
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Event cameras are dynamic vision sensors inspired by the biological retina, offering high dynamic range, high temporal resolution, and low power consumption. These qualities allow them to perceive 3D environments even in extreme conditions. Event data is continuously recorded over time, capturing pixel movements in detail. To leverage this temporal density, we introduce a temporal event stereo framework that continuously uses past information. The event stereo matching network is jointly trained with stereoscopic flow, which tracks pixel movements from stereo cameras. Instead of relying on optical flow ground truth, our method trains motion flows using disparity maps. The temporal aggregation of information via stereoscopic flow boosts stereo matching performance, achieving state-of-the-art results on MVSEC, DSEC, M3ED, and EVIMO2 datasets. Our method also demonstrates computational efficiency by stacking past data in a cascading manner.

title: Resilient Consensus Control for Heterogeneous Multi-agent Systems Subject to Two-channel Stochastic Deception Attacks
authors: Ghaznooq Ahmad Usmani, Muhammad Rehan, Xiaotai Wu, Ateeq ur Rehman
abstract: This paper explores the consensus control for heterogeneous multi-agent systems (MASs) subject to two-channel cyber-attacks over a directed network. A consensus control is a cooperative control scheme in which a group of multiple systems works collaboratively to reach similar final states in a finite time. Deception attacks targeting the input signal and the connections between agents have been considered by incorporating stochastic addition of the attack signals. The considered deception attacks are more complicated to deal with than conventional false data injection, owing to consideration of both blockage of actual signal and injection of false data. A state feedback control scheme using a dynamic estimator is proposed to achieve practical consensus among follower agents and the leader. Relevant conditions have been provided for attaining the stability and for designing the resilient controller for heterogeneous MASs to keep the consensus error uniformly ultimately bounded (UUB). Incorporating heterogeneous MASs, two-channel cyber-attacks, and stochastic nature of deception attacks has rendered the presented methodology more sophisticated, practical, and challenging compared to existing methods. Additionally, the proposed results have been expanded for the output feedback consensus through the incorporation of a Luenberger observer. In this context, a decoupling strategy has been utilized to ensure consensus among heterogeneous agents through resilient output feedback, considering stochastic attacks targeting two channels. The results of the proposed resilient consensus control for heterogeneous agents are verified through numerical simulations of circuits.

title: Removal of Projection Data Overlaps Using Deep Learning in Spect with a Large Number of Pinholes
authors: T. Akatsuka, K. Ogawa
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The multi-pinhole SPECT system has the potential to visualize the dynamic behavior of radiopharmaceuticals, as it can acquire the projection data required for image reconstruction without rotating the detectors. However, a major drawback of the pinhole collimator is its inherently low photon detection sensitivity, resulting in a significant impact of quantum noise. To enhance sensitivity, it is necessary to increase the number of pinholes. In this process, however, overlapping of pinhole projections may occur, potentially introducing artifacts into the reconstructed images. Therefore, multi-pinhole SPECT systems are generally designed to avoid overlapping projections. In this study, using a three-detector quasi-static data acquisition multi-pinhole SPECT system, we acquired projection data with overlapping projections using 22 and 33 pinholes, and separated the overlapping projections employing a convolutional neural network (CNN). To demonstrate the effectiveness of increasing the number of pinholes, we compared reconstructed images obtained from non-overlapping 11-pinhole projection data with those reconstructed after CNN-based separation. The results confirmed that separating overlapping pinhole projections using CNNs allows for improved image quality as the number of pinholes increases.

title: Retrieval Model for Surface Dead Fuel Moisture Data Based on Microwave Soil Moisture Content_supp1-3645258.docx
authors: Tongxin Hu
abstract: Wildfires are natural disasters that pose substantial threats to the environment. The accurate prediction of wildfire risk levels and timely implementation of effective mitigation measures are critical for wildfire prevention and ecological security maintenance. Fuel moisture content is an important factor affecting the spread and intensity of wildfires; however, there is currently a lack of large-scale data on surface dead fuel moisture content (DFMC). Therefore, in this study, we aimed to develop a more accurate method for retrieving DFMC by integrating multi-source satellite remote sensing data with machine learning algorithms. Evaluation of six retrieval models (extreme gradient boosting [XGB], linear regression [LR], generalized additive model [GAM], random forest [RF], convolutional neural network [CNN], and long short-term memory [LSTM]) confirmed the adaptability of XGB to four forest types, achieving an average R² value of 0.78. In addition, we used SHAP analysis to assess the importance of the model's influencing factors and identified the significance of soil moisture content (SMC) and evapotranspiration. Furthermore, comparative analysis of four input parameter combinations confirmed the pivotal role of SMC, with the integrated use of ERA5-Land reanalysis data and SMC data achieving optimal model performance while balancing large-scale applicability with accuracy. Additionally, a daily DFMC dataset for the Greater Khingan Mountains was constructed by integrating SMAP soil moisture data, ERA5 meteorological data, and the XGB model. In this study, we innovatively combined microwave remote sensing data with machine learning to provide a robust methodological framework for DFMC data retrieval via microwave remote sensing. Our results establish a foundation for enhancing the precision of forest fire risk early warning systems.

title: LR-PET: A Subspace-Based Dynamic PET Imaging via Explicit Non-Negative Low-Rank Factorization
authors: Y. Djebra, Y. Najmaoui, Y. Chemli, M. Normandin, G. El Fakhri, C. Ma, T. Marin
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Dynamic PET provides valuable insights by tracking tracer kinetics over time. Detected events are divided into T shorter frames, each with only a fraction of the total counts, and each frame is typically reconstructed independently. This approach, however, ignores the inherent spatiotemporal correlation of the data --- especially in brain studies, where motion is minimal and kinetic changes are dominant. To exploit this redundancy, we propose to model the dynamic images as residing in a rank-K lower-dimensional subspace with explicit low-rank factorization. The proposed method was validated on simulated data and on an [18F]-MK6240 dynamic PET study, demonstrating higher-quality images, lower variability at equal bias, faster reconstruction times by a ratio <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim \mathrm{K} / \mathrm{T}$</tex>, and reduced memory requirements; all within a compact and simple EM-based framework.

title: Design and Initial Evaluation of a Prototype Preclinical PET Scanner with Submillimeter Spatial Resolution for Highprecision Imaging
authors: C. Li, K. Wang, Z. Yuan, R. Liao, Y. Hou, Y. Chen, Y. Chen, J. Jiang
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This study presents the design and initial evaluation of a prototype preclinical PET scanner optimized for sub-millimeter spatial resolution. The system features a dual-ring coaxial architecture with a ring diameter of 6.5 cm, where each ring consists of eight identical detector modules, each with an overall dimension of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$26.8 \times 26.8 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>. Each module integrates a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$44 \times 44$</tex> array of lutetium-yttrium oxyorthosilicate (LYSO) scintillator crystals, with individual crystal dimensions of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.52 \times 0.52 \times 5 ~\text{mm}^{3}$</tex>. Adjacent crystals are optically isolated using a 0.08 mm layer of Enhanced Specular Reflector (ESR) to minimize optical crosstalk and enhance spatial resolution. The LYSO crystal arrays were coupled with a novel epitaxial-quenching-resistor silicon photomultiplier array and interfaced with the PETsys TOFPET2 ASIC front-end electronics. Flood image assessments demonstrated clear identification of all <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$44 \times 44$</tex> crystal pixels, indicating excellent detector pixel discrimination. The peak absolute sensitivity was measured at 18.6 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{kcps} / \text{MBq}$</tex> for an on-axis point source, and decreased slightly to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$17.4 \text{kcps} / \text{MBq}$</tex> at a 10 mm off-axis position. Monte Carlo simulations conducted with the Geant4 Application for Tomographic Emission (GATE) further validated the system's imaging capabilities. Image reconstruction was carried out using a multi-GPU-accelerated list-mode fully corrected ordered subsets expectation maximization (OSEM) algorithm. Reconstructions of the NEMA NU-4 image quality phantom yielded high-fidelity images, while scans of the micro-Derenzo phantom demonstrated the system's ability to distinctly resolve 0.5 mm rods with an average peak-to-valley of 1.275. These findings validate the sub-millimeter spatial resolution capability of the proposed PET system and highlight its potential for high-precision preclinical imaging applications.

title: Wide-Band X-Ray and Gamma-Ray Camera, Inspire, Onboard the 65 Kg Small Satellite GRAPHIUM
authors: S. Ogasawara, K. Yamamoto, A. R. Joshi, S. Kojima, K. Sato, K. S. Tanaka, J. Kataoka, K. Watanabe, M. Yasuda, H. Kobayashi, D. Kobayashi, A. Ohira, Y. Amaki, Y. Arai, K. Tashiro, K. Otsubo, Y. Ozeki, Y. Kawaguchi, D. Yoshimura, H. Yoshida, K. Takahashi, S. Masaki, N. Yamada, K. Oikawa, E. Zamami, K. Miyamoto, T. Chujo, H. Nakanishi, T. Tomura, S. Hayatsu, M. Fukuda, H. Seki, S. Joshima, Y. Yatsu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Waseda University and Science Tokyo are developing the 65 kg small satellite GRAPHIUM, which is planned for launch in FY2026. Its main detector, named INSPIRE, is a box-shaped hybrid Compton camera that supports both pinhole mode (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30-200 \text{keV}$</tex>) and Compton mode (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$200 \text{keV}-3$</tex> MeV). Simulations show that its sensitivity is comparable to that of COMPTEL. INSPIRE also possesses a wide field of view and is capable of simultaneously monitoring approximately onequarter of the sky. This feature enables the detection of transient phenomena such as gamma-ray bursts, whose locations cannot be predicted in advance. Should GRAPHIUM observe transient events originating from kilonovae due to neutron star mergers, it may provide vital insights into the currently unknown origins of heavy-element synthesis, including that of Au and Pt. In addition, we aim to observe steady sources such as active galactic nuclei (AGNs). In this study, we constructed an engineering model (EM). This EM partially replicates the actual INSPIRE, integrating real detectors in selected sections, with the remaining parts replaced by massequivalent dummy components. Using the EM, we performed imaging tests with various radiation sources, along with environmental and vibration tests. By conducting imaging tests with multiple radiation sources, we demonstrated that the angular resolution measure (ARM) cut, a simple and effective technique developed for Compton camera imaging, enables the successful extraction of spectra from multiple gamma-ray sources within a single field of view. Furthermore, we assumed the Falcon 9, recognized for its stringent vibration environment, for vibration testing and conducted a qualification test to evaluate the effects of launch conditions. The results confirmed that the detector's performance was unaffected by the test.

title: ANNA: a Reconfigurable and Programmable Analog Neural Network ASIC
authors: M. Ronchi, M. Amadori, S. Di Giacomo, M. Carminati, G. Borghi, C. Fiorini
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: As neural networks become increasingly integrated into all aspects of technology and everyday life, the need for faster and more energy-efficient computation has become essential. Analog Neural Networks (ANNs) have emerged as a possible solution, offering improvements in power efficiency compared to their digital counterparts. In front-end analog signal processing, embedding ANNs directly into the acquisition pipeline enables the elimination of bulky ADCs and FPGAs, reducing both power consumption and system complexity. This is beneficial in sensorintensive applications like PET and SPECT. Last year, we introduced the concept of ANNA, an ASIC designed to predict the interaction coordinates of gamma rays within a monolithic scintillator in radiation detectors. This year, we present the architectural advances that allow this new ASIC to be reconfigurable to accommodate a variety of applications. In addition, we report simulation results to validate the correct operation and demonstrate the practical feasibility of the proposed ASIC.

title: Time-Resolved 3D Imaging for Hard X-Ray Photon Detection Using Capacitively Coupled GaAs SAM-APD and Cross-Delay Lines
authors: N. Lusardi, M. Antonelli, F. Arfelli, G. Biasiol, F. Driussi, G. Cautero, M. Cautero, F. Garzetti, R. H. Menk, A. Costa, G. Fiumicelli, E. Ronconi, S. Paternoster, G. Bonanno, G. Brajnik, S. Carrato, D. Curcio, S. Dal Zilio, D. Ercolani, A. Geraci, A. Pilotto, L. Sbuelz, R. Sergo, L. Stebel
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Time-resolved ultrafast phenomena with hard X-ray radiation are key research areas for applications like pump-and-probe spectroscopy. The demand for higher performance drives advancements in detector technologies and multichannel acquisition techniques. This motivates our proposal for an innovative fully digital 3D (x-y-time) imager for hard X-rays. Key challenges in detector design include improving time resolution, spatial resolution (limited by the multipixel approach), and quantum efficiency, which is low for silicon detectors in the hard X-ray range. We propose using a Separate Absorption and Multiplication Avalanche PhotoDiode (SAM-APD) based on III-V semiconductors. GaAs-based alloys, with higher atomic number and mobility, offer significantly better efficiency and speed for hard X-ray absorption compared to silicon. Regarding acquisition systems, the shift towards multichannel methods and the need to minimize power and area per channel has led to the transition from traditional pixelated voltage-mode electronics to time-based acquisition systems, where both spatial (x and y) and timing information are linked to the detection event's time. By coupling a large-area GaAs SAM-APD (several mm in diameter) to two Cross Delay Lines (CDLs) and a 4 -channel 15 -ps precision FPGA-based Time-to-Digital Converter (TDC), we aim to achieve temporal and spatial resolutions of tens of picoseconds and hundreds of micrometers. This approach offers a powerful alternative to pixelated systems, requiring neither aggressive lithography nor one readout channel per pixel, using only four channels.

title: Graph Transformer for Tri-Beamforming in Pinching Antenna Systems (PASS)
authors: Jia Guo, Yuanwei Liu, Arumugam Nallanathan
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: As a representative backbone architecture of large artificial intelligence models, a Transformer-based architecture is proposed for learning beamforming in pinching antenna systems (PASS), which is called PASSformer. A joint tri-beamforming optimization problem is developed, i.e., the digital, analog, and pinching beamforming, for fully realizing the benefits of mitigating long-distance path loss. The PASSformer incorporates a graph-based architecture with permutation properties, enabling it to adapt to different system sizes (e.g., varying numbers of users, waveguides, or pinching antennas) without re-training. To improve the learning performance, the PASSformer is with a staged architecture to learn the highly-coupled tri-beamforming. A training algorithm is also proposed to cope with the highly non-smooth loss function. Simulation results demonstrate the flexibility and generalizability of the PASSformer to different system settings and problem scales, enabling it to be deployed across diverse communication scenarios, including single-/multi-cell fully digital and hybrid transmit beamforming. The performance gain over conventional multi-input-multi-output systems brought by the reduced path loss positions is also validated.

title: Feasibility Study on Imaging of Scattered High-Energy Photons for Detecting Changes in Void Size
authors: A. Okamoto, J. Kawarabayashi, T. Fujiwara, N. Hagura
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In external beam radiation therapy, it is crucial to deliver adequate radiation dose to the tumor while minimizing radiation exposure to surrounding normal tissues. However, the internal tissues within the human body constantly change their position due to breathing and cardiac pulsation, making it important to monitor tumor position externally during exposure. There are no established methods for detecting position changes of the tumor non-invasively caused especially by the movement of internal cavities (such as gas in the intestines) within the body. Therefore, this study investigated whether it is possible to monitor the behavior of internal cavities located between the tumor and a gamma camera by capturing the scattered high-energy X-rays emitted during radiation therapy. A 20 cm square acrylic block was irradiated by a beam of gamma rays from a Co-60 source that was collimated into a square column shape. A void was set at the position where direct gamma rays were not irradiated. Scattered gamma rays passing through the void were captured using a gamma camera consisting of a pinhole collimator and a phosphor plate. An increase in the amount of scattered gamma rays in the captured images was observed when the size of the void was changed from 1 cm square to 3 cm square. Experiments were also carried out with scattered gamma ray with angles of 45 degrees, 90 degrees, and 135 degrees relative to the incident gamma ray beam. The experimental results confirmed that the presence or absence of a void of several centimeters could be detected using scattered gamma rays at 45 degrees and 90 degrees. However, with scattering angle of 135 degrees, no change of scattered gamma ray intensity was observed. Although it is necessary to limit the scattering angle to 90 degrees or less, it has been confirmed that changes in the size of the cavity of several centimeters can be detected by monitoring the intensity of scattered gamma rays.

title: Impact of Lor-Dependent Randoms Energy Spectra on Energy-Based Scatter Estimation in PET
authors: S.A. Zaman Pour, A. Rezaei, J. Nuyts, G. Schramm
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In our previous work on energy-based scatter estimation (EBSE) methods in positron emission tomography (PET), random coincidences are modeled using an average energy spectrum of random coincidences, assuming uniformity across all lines of response (LORs). This study investigates the validity of that assumption by evaluating the variation in random energy spectra across LORs and its impact on EBSE performance.

title: Performance Evaluation of Digitizer-Based Compton Suppression System for PGAA at HANARO
authors: J. Kim, G.-M. Sun, K.-M. Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper presents the implementation and performance evaluation of a digitizer-based Compton suppression system for the cold neutron Prompt Gamma Activation Analysis (PGAA) facility at HANARO. High Compton background inherent in PGAA limits analytical sensitivity. To mitigate this, HPGe detector and an annular BGO scintillator operate in anti-coincidence. A CAEN DT5780 dual-channel digitizer acquires detector signals, enabling real-time digital pulse processing and coincidence tagging for background suppression. Performance evaluation used standard gammaray sources (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{60} \text{Co},{ }^{137} \text{Cs}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{22} \text{Na}$</tex>). Key metrics, including the energy-dependent continuum reduction factor, Compton Suppression Factor (CSF), Peak-to-Compton (P/C) ratio, and peak reduction, were quantified. Evaluation demonstrated significant background reduction, achieving a continuum reduction factor up to 6.5 and CSF values up to 5.9. Crucially, peak reduction remained below 0.5 %. These results show the system significantly improves background performance. This enhancement in spectral clarity is expected to improve peak identification and lower detection limits in PGAA measurements. The implemented system offers a robust solution for enhancing analytical sensitivity, providing a foundation for future studies with neutronirradiated samples.

title: Low-SNR Microseismic Source Localization via Multi-Scale Convolutional Network with Coordinate Attention
authors: Renjie He, Qinxu Zhang, Chunlu Wang, Zubin Chen, Yuxuan Zhang, Sebastian Bader
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Microseismic (MS) source localization is essential for mitigating rockburst hazards and optimizing the reconstruction of energy reservoir. However, conventional convolutional neural networks (CNNs) remain highly sensitive to noise, and LSTM-FCNN models fail to effectively capture the spatial–temporal correlations among geophone arrays, resulting in degraded performance under low signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions, typically below 0 dB. To overcome these limitations, This paper presents a multi-scale convolutional localization model with coordinate attention (MSCAR-Net). The model exploits the heterogeneous responses of noise and the correlated features of effective signals through multiscale convolutions, while a feature fusion strategy balances noise suppression and signal enhancement. In addition, the coordinate attention (CA) mechanism establishes spatial-temporal correlations between geophone positions and signal sequences, significantly improving localization robustness under low-SNR conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that MSCAR-Net achieves a stable localization error of approximately 7.9 m at SNR ≥ −5 dB, representing an 87% improvement over the baseline CNN and a 44% enhancement compared with the LSTM-FCNN. Field validation using known perforation locations in the S-H2 hydraulic fracturing project confirms an average error of 8.2 m, while real-time localization of 65 events further validates the method’s applicability as a measurement solution for low-SNR MS monitoring systems.
