title: A Fast System Modeling Method for a Highperformance Self-Collimating SPECT System Combining Deep Learning and Sparse Point-Source Calibration
authors: Q. Ye, D. Zhang, T. Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We have recently developed a self-collimating SPECT (SC-SPECT) system, where multiple sparsescintillator detector layers are used to replace part of the mechanical collimator for photon collimation, enabling simultaneous high-resolution, high-sensitivity SPECT imaging. A critical component for acquiring high-quality image is the generation of an accurate system matrix. However, due to the complex geometry of SC-SPECT, conventional system modeling methods are not directly appliable. In this work, we propose a deep learning framework-DMR2.5D-GAN-to estimate the full system matrix from sparse point-source calibration data (10k positions). The network incorporates dual inputs-sparse projection probability density functions (PPDFs) and Halton-sequence positional encoding-along with multi-scale convolutions and ROI-weighted discrimination. The network is trained and evaluated using datasets generated with Monte Carlo simulations. Results show high structural similarity between the predicted and ground-truth matrices. Moreover, MLEM reconstructions using the generated matrix achieve comparable normalized mean square error (NMSE) to those using the ground-truth matrix. This method demonstrates significantly reduced system calibration time (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>90 \%$</tex>) while preserving reconstruction accuracy.

title: Sub-Millimeter 2D Intrinsic Resolution Recovery in Semi-Monolithic PET Detector using Neural Networks - a Monte Carlo Simulation
authors: E. Elmoujarkach, N. Karakatsanis, J. Alamo, F. Pagano, D. Sanchez, A. Wang, M. Sabuncu, A. Gonzalez, S. Nehmeh
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Accurate localization of the annihilation gamma-ray photon interaction points within detector crystals is critical for achieving high spatial resolution in positron emission tomography (PET). PET systems have achieved sub-millimeter resolution by employing pixelated detector blocks with small crystal size of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 1 \times 1 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex> in cross-section. While effective, this approach becomes expensive and technically complex when scaling to larger systems. Semi-monolithic crystal detectors offer a promising compromise by reducing readout complexity while maintaining high resolution through signal-based position estimation. In this study, we present an in-silico evaluation of two neural network architectures for estimating the monolithic and depth-of-interaction (DOI) coordinates in a semi-monolithic LYSO detector block, the building component of the Ultra-High Performance Brain PET (UHB-PET) system. The dataset was generated using GATE v8.0 simulations. We implemented a multi-layer perceptron (MLP) using 8 SiPM row-sum features (mimicking the realistic readout architecture), achieving resolutions of 0.45 and 0.59 mm in the monolithic and DOI directions, respectively. To improve accuracy near crystal edges, where MLP performance degrades, we developed an attention-augmented 1D CNN (A1D-CNN) using the full <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8+8$</tex> summed SiPM signals projected along the monolithic and axial directions readout values. This model outputs probability distributions over spatial bins and computes estimates via expectation, achieving a 40 % reduction in the spatial variance of the prediction coordinates error. While the models perform well under ideal conditions, the lack of electronic noise and perfect ground truth limits generalizability. Future work will focus on evaluating the performance of this approach using experimental data, with the ultimate goal of achieving sub-millimeter resolution in UHB-PET system.

title: Exploring InAIN/GaN Detectors for Realtime Monitoring in Ultra-High Dose Rate Flash Radiotherapy
authors: S.Y. Choi, C. Anderson, I. Fratelli, Y.-C. Liu, Y. Tan, M. Bardash, G. Garty, A. Harken, I. Kymissis, S. Eisner
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This work presents the first characterization of gallium nitride (GaN) and indium aluminum nitride/gallium nitride (InAIN/GaN) heterostructure detectors under ultra-high dose per pulse (UH-DPP) electron beam irradiation for emerging FLASH radiotherapy applications. While FLASH radiotherapy offers potential for better patient outcomes, its higher dose rates (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>40 \sim \text{Gy} / \mathrm{s}$</tex>) and shorter treatment windows compared to conventional radiotherapy both present significant challenges to real-time dosimetry necessary to ensure safe and effective treatment. To address this dosimetry need, microfabricated GaN-based detectors with varying material stacks and geometry have been evaluated under 9 MeV electron beam exposure under FLASH-relevant conditions. Unpassivated Ni/Au metal-semiconductor-metal (MSM) and InAIN/GaN 2DEG interdigitated transducer (IDT) detectors demonstrated the best temporal response after cumulative 25 Gy irradiation. The 2DEG IDT detectors demonstrated individual pulse discrimination with rise times <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.57 \mu ~\mathrm{s}$</tex> and fall times <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2325.27 \mu ~\mathrm{s}$</tex>, with a bandwidth of 136 kHz and signal-to-noise ratio of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 1.6 \times 10^{3}$</tex> under DPP ranges from 0.05 to 0.5 Gy. A consistent relationship between signal intensity and dose per pulse was observed. We estimated sensitivities ranging from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 17.1-195.1 \text{nC} / \text{Gy}$</tex>. These results highlight the strong potential of small form factor GaN-based detectors for high-speed, real-time dosimetry in clinical FLASH radiotherapy settings.

title: High-Energy Imaging Capability of a State-of-the-Art Full-Ring CZT SPECT/CT
authors: Y. Huh, A. Devir-Wolfman, R. Zananiri, S. Du, Y. Seo
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: A full-ring CZT-based single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) is the current state-of-the-art for SPECT imaging. This modern clinical SPECT (e.g., StarGuide, GE HealthCare) is offered as SPECT/CT with 12 small rectangular CZT detector modules, allowing multiple degrees of freedom to focus and contour the imaging object. While this advance is a significant improvement from conventional NaI-based systems, there is a fundamental challenge to completely take over all applications of SPECT, i.e., lack of high energy photon imaging capability required for imaging radionuclides with high-energy photon emissions (e.g., <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{131} \mathrm{I}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{225} \text{Ac}$</tex>). This deficiency comes from the fact that it is not easily feasible to change collimators between scans. As a close academic-industry collaborative research effort, we have evaluated strategies to overcome this challenge by redesigning collimator geometries using validated Monte Carlo simulation tools and advanced image reconstructions. The validation step for the Monte Carlo simulation was performed using experimental data. First, we performed a NEMA body phantom scans with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{177} \text{Lu}$</tex>, and confirmed the imaging performance for both the low (113 keV) and high energy (208 keV) peaks of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{177} \text{Lu}$</tex> by both simulation and experimental data. Then, we tested if the current configuration of the collimator and detector shielding was able to image <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{131} \mathrm{I}$</tex> (364 keV) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{213} \text{Bi}$</tex> of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{225} \text{Ac}$</tex> decay (440 keV), which showed expected artifacts from septal and shielding penetrations. Using the validated simulation tool, we also designed a high-energy collimator that can offer the imaging capability for these radionuclides (i.e., <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{131} \mathrm{I}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{225} \text{Ac}$</tex>) assuming that there is a mechanism to adopt a second set of collimators for the imaging system. Our results indicate that the option of using two sets of collimators can provide the full imaging capability of existing SPECT applications including <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{131} \mathrm{I}$</tex> imaging and potentially <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{225} \text{Ac}$</tex> imaging.

title: Comparison Between Direct and Indirect Partial Volume Correction Methods Based on Diffusion Models
authors: Y.J. Seol, H.B. Yoo, E.J. Yoon, Y.K. Kim, S. Seo, J.S. Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Accurate quantification in brain 18 F-FDG PET is often limited by partial volume effects (PVE), particularly in small or functionally distinct regions. While conventional partial volume correction (PVC) methods such as the Region-Based Voxel-wise (RBV) approach rely on structural MRI for anatomical segmentation, MRI-based correction is not always feasible due to issues of availability, misregistration, and variable image quality. To address these limitations, we propose a diffusion-based framework that synthesizes high-resolution MRI from 18F-FDG PET and CT using a conditional Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model (DDPM). This synthetic MRI enables reliable segmentation and subsequent RBV-PVC. We further compare this approach with a direct PVC pipeline that predicts corrected PET images directly from PET/CT without using MRI. Our results demonstrate that the MRI-synthesis-aided approach provides improved quantification accuracy and interpretability compared to direct PVC methods.

title: HQF: Cost Estimation for Hybrid Query Workloads Using Feature Representation Optimization
authors: Kaijun Wen, Kun Chao, Jiaxu Guo, Tianyi Liu, Jiahao Li, Yanfei Ren
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: With the increasing complexity and diversity of application scenarios in big data environments, database queries are increasingly characterized by hybrid query characteristics, such as multi-table joins, multi-condition filtering, and multi-dimensional operations. These queries rely on accurate cost estimation to assist optimizers in selecting efficient execution plans. However, existing cost estimation methods mainly depend on static statistical information, have limited feature representation capabilities, and struggle to adapt to high-dimensional, heterogeneous hybrid queries, resulting in significant estimation errors. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a hybrid query cost estimation framework based on QueryFormer. The framework enhances feature representation through flexible histogram partitioning and adaptive sampling strategies, and introduces a distance-driven compression mechanism that maps high-dimensional feature vectors into scalar distance representations, enabling efficient modeling while preserving feature identifiability. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly improves the accuracy and generalization of cost estimation in both scalar and vector queries, achieving lower Q-error. These findings validate the effectiveness and practicality of the framework in complex hybrid query scenarios.

title: Fuzzy PID-Based Attitude Control for a Three-Wheeled Wall-Climbing Robot
authors: Dingkun Zhao, Lu Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: This research presents an optimized attitude control strategy for a three-wheeled, magnetic-adsorption, wall-climbing robot to address its slow response and low precision in challenging environments. These issues stem from environmental disturbances, variable wall friction, and dynamic load changes. Accordingly, a mechanical model of the robot was developed in a wall-surface coordinate system based on its structural characteristics and operational state. A thorough analysis of the critical conditions for slip prevention, anti-overturning, and required motor torque was also conducted. To improve the system's dynamic performance, a dual-closed-loop attitude controller integrating Fuzzy Control Theory with a conventional PID controller was proposed. The controller features an outer loop that employs a Fuzzy PID for adaptive yaw angle regulation and an inner loop that utilizes a conventional PID for speed control. The efficacy of the proposed controller was validated and benchmarked against a traditional PID controller through Simulink simulations and prototype experiments. The results show the Fuzzy PID control system achieves superior attitude tracking accuracy and response speed, significantly enhancing the robot's overall performance.

title: Robotic Assessment of in-Soil Elemental Carbon Via Inelastic Neutron Scattering
authors: F. Aziz, M. Fang, G. Gariazzo, N.K. Uppalapati, G. Chowdhari, A. Di Fulvio
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Signatures from neutron inelastic scattering have been used for the assessment of stable radionuclides, when a non-invasive procedure is needed. In this work, we demonstrated the combined use of the radiometric assay of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{12} \mathrm{C}\left(\mathrm{n}, \mathrm{n}^{\prime}\right)$</tex> reaction with an automated robotic system for the absolute assessment of in-soil carbon.

title: Structure-Aware 3D Gaussian Splatting Optimization with Geometry Priors for Transmission Towers
authors: Shengxue Ke, Haixing Shang, Zufeng Li, Zhao Zhang
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: We present a 2D Gaussian Splatting approach with geometry-aware priors for fast and accurate 3D reconstruction of transmission towers, essential for power grid digital twins. A line-segment prior preserves slender rods, while a plane-smoothness prior maintains large planar surfaces. Both are formulated via rotation–scale decomposition to directly regularize Gaussian positions and orientations. Our method achieves superior structural completeness and fidelity under sparse views, outperforming 3DGS, 2DGS, and GeoGaussian baselines. The results demonstrate its capability to meet the stringent accuracy–efficiency requirements of digital twin applications in power grid infrastructure.

title: Pseudo-random Number Generation Algorithm for Dynamically Perturbated Enhanced Chaotic Systems
authors: Mengdan Xia, Ying Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Aiming at the shortcomings of traditional pseudorandom number generation (PRNG) methods in high-security applications, this paper proposes a hybrid model based on the combination of Logistic mapping and Lorenz chaotic system to construct a new PRNG algorithm. The algorithm effectively improves the randomness and security of the output sequence by introducing dynamic parameter perturbation mechanism and periodic entropy injection strategy. Experimental results show that the designed pseudo-random number generator has low autocorrelation and inter-correlation, and the output of the system does not show significant statistical deviation, with the Lyapunov Exponent (LE) index reaching 17.42, which indicates that the generator possesses good uniformity, high entropy characteristics, strong chaos and high initial value sensitivity, and can effectively circumvent the problems of periodicity and predictability. The algorithm generates sequence Shannon entropy values of up to 7.9982 bits/byte, demonstrating resistance to typical cryptographic attacks such as brute force cracking, differential attacks, and periodic analysis. This method is suitable for security-sensitive scenarios such as key generation and encryption algorithms.

title: Segmentation of Pelvic Radiographs After Total Hip Arthroplasty Using U-Net Variants: Toward Morphometric Automation
authors: Elina Huerfano, Leonardo Flórez-Valencia
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Total hip arthroplasty (THA) is a cornerstone procedure in orthopedics, requiring serial radiographic evaluation to monitor implant positioning and detect complications. Manual interpretation of these radiographs is time-consuming and subject to variability. We propose a deep learning pipeline for automated multiclass semantic segmentation of postoperative anteroposterior pelvic radiographs. Our pipeline involved manual annotation of 740 radiographs, systematic preprocessing, and data augmentation. We implemented and compared four U-Net based architectures: Basic U-Net, Residual U-Net, EfficientNet-UNet, and Attention U-Net, to assess their performance across 17 anatomical and prosthetic structures. Although Residual U-Net achieved the highest mean global Dice Similarity Coefficient (DSC= 0.865), all models demonstrated comparable performance. Our class-wise analysis identified persistent segmentation challenges in small, thin, or infrequent structures, such as osteosynthesis hardware. The results confirm the feasibility of deep learningbased segmentation as a foundational step toward automated radiographic assessment in postoperative THA imaging. This work lays the groundwork for future automated morphometric analysis, which could improve clinical efficiency and standardize postoperative follow-up care.

title: Towards Individual Channel Classifiers and Ensemble Methods for Enhanced Motor Imagery BCI Performance
authors: Jaime A. Riascos-Salas, Hernan Villota, Marta Molinas
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: This study introduces a novel approach to enhance Motor Imagery Brain-Computer Interface (MI-BCI) classification by training individual channel classifiers and integrating them with a stacking ensemble. Our method was benchmarked against established techniques, including Filter Bank Common Spatial Patterns (FBCSP) and Minimum Redundancy Maximum Relevance (mRMR). While a full pool of 256 individual channel classifiers initially showed suboptimal performance, refining the approach by selecting only the 10 best-performing individual classifiers per subject yielded substantial accuracy improvements of over 20%. This curated selection consistently outperformed FBCSP and, for some subjects, even mRMR. The findings suggest that focusing on a personalized, high-performing subset of channels can effectively reduce inter- and intra-subject variability, offering a robust alternative to traditional optimization-based channel selection. This framework holds promise for developing more adaptable and effective BCI systems.

title: Application-Specific Optimization of Hybrid Post-Quantum Cryptographic Frameworks in Resource-Constrained Environments
authors: Timur Khudaybergenov, Temur Khudayberganov, Bahrombek Sabirov, Temur Turdiyev
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: the rapid advancement of quantum computing introduces substantial risks to classical cryptographic algorithms that rely on number-theoretic problems, such as the Rivest–Shamir–Adleman algorithm and elliptic curve cryptography. These cryptographic primitives are susceptible to polynomial-time quantum algorithms like those proposed by Shor and Grover, thereby endangering the security of contemporary digital infrastructures. In light of these emerging threats, the global cryptographic community is prioritizing the development and deployment of quantum-resistant cryptographic techniques. These include diverse algorithmic families such as those based on lattices, hash functions, error-correcting codes, and multivariate polynomials. Each approach exhibits distinct trade-offs in terms of computational performance, key length, signature size, and long-term resilience. This paper introduces a hybrid cryptographic framework optimized for specific application domains, particularly those with limited computational and energy resources. The proposed architecture strategically combines lattice-based encryption, hash-based digital signatures, and code-based key encapsulation mechanisms to form a unified model for secure data transmission. The architecture is implemented and evaluated across heterogeneous computing environments, including low-power embedded systems and Field-Programmable Gate Arrays. Experimental metrics such as execution latency, computational overhead, memory consumption, and energy efficiency are assessed and benchmarked against traditional single-algorithm deployments. The findings demonstrate that the hybrid approach maintains strong quantum resistance while significantly reducing performance penalties, making it suitable for mobile platforms, Internet of Things environments, and real-time communication systems. Future work should emphasize further fine-tuning for specific industrial domains, standardization of hybrid cryptographic protocols, and integration with artificial intelligence-based adaptive security layers to ensure sustainability in the approaching quantum era.

title: Electrochemically Switchable Multifunctional Device for Multiband Laser and Infrared Stealth
authors: Jiahao Hou, Shenghao Jin, Boxiang Wang
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Semiconductor Devices and Integration Technology (ASDIT)
abstract: We report a voltage-controlled dynamically switchable stealth device based on reversible silver electrodeposition and Tamm plasmon resonance, enabling switching between the compatibility of multiband laser and infrared stealth, and the compatibility of infrared stealth and heat radiation dissipation.

title: Cloud Scripts
authors: Kian Peng Ong
publish: Proceedings of the 18th International Symposium on Visual Information Communication and Interaction
abstract: None

title: An Automated Assessment Framework for Green Roof Potential Using Procedurally Generated Virtual Urban Imagery
authors: Kecen Yi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: This study presents an automated framework for assessing green roof potential, distinguished by its use of procedurally generated virtual urban imagery. The end-to-end workflow integrates data simulation and image processing to accurately quantify greenable areas by identifying roof types and accounting for rooftop obstacles, ultimately producing visualizations like density heatmaps for decision support. The research validates the use of synthetic data as a "digital sandbox," establishing a low-cost, high-efficiency, and fully controllable new paradigm for developing and testing geospatial analysis algorithms in complex urban environments.

title: Two agent scheduling with rejection cost budget in cloud computing
authors: Lei Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: We consider scheduling involving two agents with job rejection in cloud computing, and each agent has its job set on a single machine. Each of the agent has the budget of the rejection cost.We need to find a schedule to minimizes the objective function of agent A, and satisfy the objective function of agent B not exceed a given threshold. For the three objective functions, we show the problem complexity are weakly NP-hard, then give optimal pseudo-polynomial time algorithms to solve three problems, and we give an effective scheduling method in cloud computing.

title: A Simplified Physics-Informed Neural Network for Ionospheric Electron Density Modeling
authors: Zhongcheng Yang, Shikai Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Physics Informed Neural Networks (PINN) is a hybrid modeling method that introduces physical constraints during deep learning training, which can balance data-driven and physical consistency. This article constructs a simplified version of the PINN model(S-PINN) based on the Thermosphere Electrodynamics General Circulation Model physical model(TIE-GCM), and conducts comparative experiments with the Fully Connected Neural Network (FCNN). The results show that the proposed PINN model has higher overall accuracy than FCNN, but the error level has been significantly reduced. At the same time, it exhibits advantages in physical consistency and interpretability, verifying its feasibility and potential in ionospheric modeling.

title: Cross Attention Mechanism Based Multi-Modal Deep Learning Method for Space Electromagnetic Signal Recognition
authors: Yi Wei, Yanghao Wang, Yuan Qiu, Lili Cao, Shangrong Ouyang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: As the electromagnetic environment has become increasingly complex in near-Earth orbital space, severe threats are posed to the link stability of space-based communication systems in satellites. It is imperative to develop effective signal recognition technologies in a complex electromagnetic environment for further cognitive anti-jamming method. While existing deep learning approaches for signal recognition predominantly rely on single-modal inputs, this paper proposes CA3M-Former, a novel attention mechanism based multi-modal framework that synergistically integrates I/Q sequences, A/P sequences, and spectrograms to exploit complementary time-frequency features. The model introduces two key innovations: (1) a cross-attention fusion module to dynamically align and combine tri-modal features while preserving temporal coherence, and (2) a cascaded temporal-spatial attention mechanism in the encoder to capture global contextual dependencies. Performance evaluations show that the proposed method can outperform its counterparts in terms of recognition accuracy under various SNR.

title: Uzbek Public-Sector Text Classification: Naive Bayes, Logistic Regression and SVM Benchmarks
authors: Nilufar Abdurakhmonova, Nilufar Adizova, Dilnoza Sobirova
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The authors present an algorithm for classifying Uzbek-language documents in key public sector domains, including economics, legal texts, healthcare, housing and utilities, and energy. The study compares three established linear baselines—multinomial naive Bayes, logistic regression, and linear SVM—within a fixed, source-agnostic evaluation protocol. Texts are collected from government agencies and media outlets, cleaned of template text, normalized for spelling variants and apostrophes, and vectorized using TF-IDF at the word and character levels, including a hybrid representation. A cross-domain analysis reveals systematic confusions between the housing and utilities and energy categories, as well as between the legal and economic sectors, reflecting shared tariff narratives, outage/maintenance reporting, and regulatory language embedded in economic indicators. Error analysis also shows that character n-grams and script normalization are critical for robustness in agglutinative, mixed-orthography environments. In addition, the article also contains necessary information on the Uzbek language, its nature and features that must be taken into account when developing such tools.

title: Joint Self-Collimation Compton Imaging: A High-Resolution and High-SNR Solution for High-Energy SPECT
authors: P. Li, L. Lei, X. Zheng, Z. Lyu, Z. Yu, L. Liu, R. Yao, T. Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: High-energy gamma photon imaging is a critical application area of single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT), yet its performance is fundamentally constrained by mechanical collimators. To overcome this limitation, we have previously introduced the self-collimation concept, which achieves both high spatial resolution and sensitivity. However, its performance degrades when imaging high-energy photons due to increased photon penetration and scattering.

title: CTHDNet: A CNN-Transformer Hybrid Denoising Network Forinfrared Image Denoising
authors: Yanqiu Tang, Zheng Ma, Jiatong Liu, Mingqi Xia
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Infrared image denoising is essential for generating clean and reli-able images under noisy conditions. Existing approaches typically rely on either purely CNN-based or Transformer-based architec-tures, yet they often face limitations in balancing accuracy and com-putational cost.To address this issue,we propose a CNN-Transformer Hybrid Denoising Network (CTHDNet) within a symmetric en-coder-decoder framework.In our design, the encoder adopts large-kernel convolutions to effectively capture local structures and con-textual features, while the decoder integrates a Transformer-based module together with a Convolution Refine Module (CRModule) to progressively upsample and refine the feature representations. This hybrid architecture preserves the inductive bias of CNNs while ex-ploiting the global modeling capability of Transformers. Extensive experiments on multiple infrared image benchmarks demonstrate that CTHDNet achieves superior denoising performance with favorable efficiency compared to state-of-the-art methods.

title: Redefining Cyber Resilience: AI-Driven Metrics for Enhanced Threat Intelligence Systems
authors: Esther Eze, Gahangir Hossain
publish: 2025 IEEE International Carnahan Conference on Security Technology (ICCST)
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence (AI) into cybersecurity threat intelligence systems is reshaping the effectiveness and efficiency of modern cyber defense. However, traditional metrics such as Mean Time to Detection (MTTD) and Mean Time to Recovery (MTTR) are no longer sufficient to assess the performance of AI-driven security operations. This study proposes a novel framework for developing cyber resilience metrics tailored to AI-augmented threat intelligence platforms. Drawing on empirical data from 150 U.S. organizations in critical infrastructure sectors, the research introduces advanced metrics—AI-Assisted Detection Accuracy (AADA), Threat Intelligence Correlation Efficiency (TICE), and Adaptive Response Time (ART). Results show that organizations leveraging these enhanced metrics experience a 73% reduction in detection time and a 45% improvement in recovery speed compared to those using conventional systems. This work lays the foundation for new industry standards that more accurately capture the capabilities of AI-enabled cybersecurity solutions.

title: Prediction of Glucose Level Using Temporal and Frequency Parameters of ECG Signal
authors: Pedro Lucas Bezerra Mendes, Ronaldo Rodrigues Soares, Mikaela Kalline M. Serrão, Davi Israel Abtibol Carvalho, Marly. G. F. Costa, Cícero F. F. Costa Filho
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: The prediction of interstitial glucose levels is crucial for diabetes management, with most studies relying on complex feature sets. This study evaluates the effectiveness of traditional and deep machine learning models, including Random Forest, SVR, MLP, 1D-CNN, RNN, and TCN, using only ECG-derived features for glucose prediction. We employed cross-validation leaving three patients out method across time, frequency, and combined domains. The results show that TCN and 1D-CNN models outperformed the others, with RMSE values of 17.28 ± 3.60 and 18.33 ± 4.52, respectively. These models demonstrated that using either time or frequency domain features alone performed better than using combined features for accurate predictions. These findings highlight the potential of ECG-based models, particularly TCN and 1D-CNN, to offer an efficient, reliable, and personalized approach to glucose level prediction, with significant implications for more accessible and scalable diabetes management solutions.

title: Efficient Deepfake Detection Framework Based on Illumination Analysis and Self-Blended Images
authors: Yong Zhong, Jihui Li, Wenyin Yang, Baoyao Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Recent advances in deep learning have accelerated deepfake generation, creating substantial challenges for reliable detection. This paper proposes a detection framework that integrates facial illumination analysis into the self-blended image (SBI) paradigm. By introducing an illumination-sensitive channel based on gradient and Laplacian transformations, the method highlights inconsistencies between real and manipulated faces. EfficientNet-B4 is employed for feature extraction with focal loss to address class imbalance. Experiments on FaceForensics ++ and Celeb-DFv2 show consistent improvements over baselines in both intra- and cross-dataset evaluations. These results demonstrate that incorporating illumination features into SBI enhances detection accuracy while preserving computational efficiency.

title: Wood-Polymer Composite Modification Processes Researching For Achieve High Dielectric Characteristics
authors: Serhii Kopylov, Anna Cherkashina, Tatyana Berkutova, Kateryna Rudnieva, Oleksandr Bliznyuk, Ruslana Pavlenko
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The purpose of the article is to study the processes of modifying WPC in order to achieve high dielectric characteristics. The article investigates the dielectric properties of wood-polymer composites. Analysis of the obtained results indicates the superiority of the developed WPC samples based on a matrix in the form of secondary polyethylene (25 and 90 wt. %) and thermoplastic polyurethane (10 wt. %) compared to industrial samples. The proposed samples demonstrate the efficiency of the modification process of both the wood filler and the polymer matrix. The advantage of the proposed WPC samples with a modified wood filler compared to industrial samples ranges from 100% depending on the type of industrial WPC and the type of the proposed sample. The efficiency of simultaneous modification of both the wood filler and the polymer matrix of WPC samples based on a matrix in the form of secondary polyethylene (25 and 90 wt. %) and thermoplastic polyurethane (10 wt. %) was also established. The advantage of synergistic modification over the modification of any individual component of the wood-polymer composite is more than five times. From the results of the study of the influence of the modification of the DPC on the level of resistance to external conditions and the level of the dielectric loss tangent tg δ, it is clearly seen that the effective binding of free water in the DPC allows to increase the complex of dielectric characteristics.

title: Accelerating CNN Model Training and Real-Time Face Recognition on GPU Optimized with OpenCL
authors: Mekhriddin Rakhimov, Shakhzod Javliev, Khurshid Turaev
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Currently, it is proposed to use CUDA (Compute Unified Device Architecture) technology on GPU (Graphics Processing Unit) to accelerate tasks such as deep learning. However, the fact that CUDA supports only NVIDIA GPUs causes resource problems and additional costs for the user. In this article, a real-time face recognition system was developed. The system was built based on a lightweight CNN (Convolutional Neural Network) model and was trained on image samples of 160×160 pixels. When the model training process was performed on a device without an NVIDIA GPU, speed problems were eliminated using OpenCL (Open Computing Language). The CNN model training process built for face recognition was accelerated on GPU using OpenCL. The training speed, accuracy, and real-time face recognition performance were compared on CPU (Central Processing Unit), a regular GPU, and a GPU optimized with OpenCL based on FPS (frames per second) and latency (ms). According to the experimental results, the optimization performed on the GPU using OpenCL significantly increased the model’s performance to 17 FPS. This is a more effective result than the CPU (4 FPS) and GPU (9 FPS) benchmarks. The proposed approach allows for stable and fast face recognition even on devices with limited resources.

title: Analysis of Dynamic Characteristics of a Step-up Switching Capacitor Pulse Converter Topology
authors: Kirill Akhtyrskiy, Mikhail Khlystunov, Alexander Osipov, Ilya Shemolin
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The article presents the results of analysis of dynamic characteristics of a step-up switching capacitor converter topology intended for application in modular server power supply units. Using the state-space method, a nonlinear model of the converter was developed and linearized, allowing to obtain a transfer function suitable for frequency-domain analysis. The main focus of the work is on the influence of component parameter variations (inductance, capacitance, equivalent series resistance) and parasitic losses on the system’s frequency response and stability. The study found that deviations in inductor and capacitor values significantly affect the shape of the amplitude and phase characteristics, while parasitic resistances, often regarded as negative factors, can in fact improve stability margins of the system. The study highlights the existence of a design trade-off between energy efficiency, which requires higher inductance values, and dynamic robustness, which deteriorates under the same conditions. The conclusions were confirmed by simulation modeling in MATLAB Simulink, which verified the analytical trends obtained. Recommendations were formulated for developing reliable feedback control strategies that ensure stable operation of switching capacitor converters under real-world component tolerances in server power supplies.

title: Multiscale Mathematical Modelling of Dissociation Process in Hydrate-Saturated Reservoirs
authors: Sergey I. Markov, Ella P. Shurina, Natalya B. Itkina
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Gas hydrates are clathrates where gas molecules fill structural voids in the crystal lattice formed by water molecules. Under natural conditions, hydrates can form in gas and oil fields under certain thermobaric conditions. These deposits are in a metastable state. At insignificant change of thermobaric conditions their dissociation occurs. This may be one of the causes of technogenic accidents in the process of drilling production boreholes. Mathematical modelling allows to analyze the behavior of physical systems, as well as to obtain a qualitative and quantitative understanding of the process of hydrate decomposition in a permeable formation. For this purpose, phenomenological models using homogenized physical parameters are applied. In this paper, we propose a numerical method for mathematical modelling the process of methane hydrate dissociation in hydrate-saturated reservoir. We take in account an information of homogenized physical properties of sedimentary rock using laboratory measurements and results of X-ray microtomography of cores.

title: Easypet.3D Scanner: Enhancing Quality Assurance in Proton Therapy
authors: A. C.M. Magalhães, P. M.M. Correia, M. Grossmann, P. M.C.C. Encarnação, A. X. Pinto, J. F.C.D.A. Veloso, A. L.M. Silva
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Implementing effective pre-treatment beam quality assurance techniques is essential in proton therapy to optimize the dose delivery, ensuring maximum dose to the tumor while minimizing exposure to surrounding healthy tissues. PET imaging is one of the techniques being explored for this purpose. This study aims to evaluate the performance of the easyPET.3D system for quasi-real time monitoring of the proton beam in phantoms. The easyPET.3D is a dual-axis rotational system equipped with two sets of detectors (LYSO crystals coupled to SiPMs) that rotate around the object, enabling it to produce images that cover the entire Field of View (FOV) using fewer detectors, and thereby reducing overall costs.

title: High Precision Photonic Weight Bank Based on Microring Resonantor
authors: Cheng Xu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: We propose an analytic photonic weight bank using microring resonators for high-precision neuromorphic computing. By analyzing and modeling microring static responses, we achieve precise optical weight control compatible with 3-8 bit commercial DAC modules. Based on this bank, we build a photonic convolutional neural network (PCNN) architecture, achieving 97.7% classification accuracy on the MNIST dataset. We explore how different weighting precisions affect PCNN performance, showing our solution’s high robustness. Our solution, with small size, low power, low latency, and CMOS compatibility, is promising for next-gen high-performance computing architectures.

title: Gradient Boosting and Chi-Square for Advanced Ransomware Detection
authors: Fauzi Adi Rafrastara, Pulung Nurtantio Andono, Purwanto Purwanto, Pujiono Pujiono, Warusia Yassin
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Ransomware is a rapidly evolving cyber threat in the world today, characterized by its attempt to encrypt data and demand a ransom. These attacks cause significant financial losses and operational disruptions. Traditional signature-based detection systems are ineffective against zero-day attacks, making machine learning approaches a superior alternative. This study proposes the use of the Gradient Boosting algorithm for detection and the Chi-Square method for feature selection. Feature selection plays a crucial role here as ransomware datasets are considered high-dimensional data. The dataset utilized is the RISS Ransomware Dataset, comprising 1,525 instances and 30,966 features, with the target variable categorized into two classes: ransomware or goodware. Experimental results indicate that Gradient Boosting with Chi-Square outperforms other models, including algorithms proposed by different researchers (such as SVM and CNN-based algorithms), achieving an accuracy of 97.51% with the use of only 250 features. For future work, testing this algorithm combination on other ransomware datasets is crucial to ensure its robustness.

title: Improved NSGA-III and TOPSIS-Based Trajectory Planning Method for Liver Tumor Radiofrequency Ablation
authors: Kehui Yang, Hao Chen, Zhe Li, Bin Jin, Jingjing Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Computer Science and Network Technology (ICCSNT)
abstract: Accurate and safe trajectory planning is critical for liver tumor radiofrequency ablation therapy. However, existing methods are difficult to balance global exploration with convergence speed under multiple clinical guidelines. In this paper, we propose an automatic trajectory planning method for radiofrequency ablation of liver tumors based on the improved nondominated sorting genetic algorithm III (NSGA-III) and the Technique for Order of Preference by Similarity to Ideal Solution (TOPSIS). First, integrated and comprehensive clinical constraints are considered. The skin feasible domain is solved based on hard constraints, while the ablation trajectory is evaluated according to soft constraints. Then, to raise the diversity of solutions, NSGA-III is improved by introducing an adaptive differential evolution operator. Meanwhile, the TOPSIS method is utilized to automatically select the optimal trajectory from the Pareto solution set. Experiments show that the proposed method achieves complete tumor coverage and 45.53% ablation efficiency, and the automatically determined optimal trajectories are clinically safer and more effective.

title: Critical Path Optimization and Hardware Implementation for CKKS Key Switching Accelerator
authors: Hai Huang, Hanchun Wu, Bin Yu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: The CKKS homomorphic encryption scheme provides a robust theoretical foundation for privacy-preserving computations, however, the computational overhead associated with its key switching operations significantly impedes practical deployment. To address this challenge, this paper introduces a hardware-accelerated architecture through algorithmic process restructuring and resource reuse strategies. By optimizing the execution flow of the ModUp and ModDown phases, the critical path latency is effectively minimized. Additionally, developed a dynamic resource multiplexing strategy for the NTT/INTT computational units, enabling flexible scheduling of hardware resources across various computational stages, thereby substantially enhancing hardware utilization and reducing resource consumption. The proposed design is implemented on the Xilinx UltraScale+ FPGA platform, with experimental results demonstrate that the proposed architecture achieves superior resource efficiency compared to existing solutions. Specifically, the area-latency product is improved by 40.68% relative to HEAX, and overall performance is enhanced by a factor of $\mathbf{1. 5 8 x}$ to $\mathbf{3. 5 7 x}$ times compared to coxHE. This architecture offers an efficient and feasible hardware acceleration pathway for CKKS key switching in resource-constrained environments.

title: Multi Strategy Improved Crested Porcupine Optimization Algorithm
authors: Li Wang, Qiangwei Wu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: The Crested Porcupine Optimization (CPO) is a novel metaheuristic algorithm that achieves global search and local development by mimicking the four defense measures of the Crested Porcupine. It has excellent optimization performance. However, in practical applications, there are limitations such as slow convergence speed and susceptibility to local optima. To this end, this article proposes an Improved Crested Porcupine Optimization (ICPO). Firstly, in the initialization stage of the population, Latin hypercube sampling is used to obtain candidate solutions with stronger dispersion; Secondly, introducing adaptive t-distribution mutation and trigonometric random walk in the third defense stage and after the third defense stage of the algorithm can effectively escape local optima and improve convergence accuracy; Finally, dynamic reverse elite learning is introduced in the later stages of iteration to avoid local optima caused by population reduction and accelerate global convergence. Through comparative experiments using 20 benchmark test functions, the results show that the improved algorithm has better optimization performance.

title: Evaluating NGR Sizing In Medium-Voltage Systems: Is 400 A Always The Correct Answer?
authors: Cory A Helfrich, Rakan El-Mahayni, Ahmed Alhumoud
publish: 2025 IEEE IAS Petroleum and Chemical Industry Technical Conference (PCIC)
abstract: It is common industry practice to have 5 kV and 15 kV systems low-resistance grounded. These low-resistance-grounded systems are designed to limit ground-fault current to a range between 100 A and 1000 A, with 400 A being typical. One of the main purposes of using low-resistance grounding is to limit ground-fault currents to hundreds of amperes, instead of thousands of amperes. The damage to the equipment connected to the system, particularly rotating machines, is limited by reducing the ground-fault current. Since the damage caused by ground-fault currents increases with the magnitude of the current, it is desirable to limit the ground-fault current to a value as small as possible without compromising the ability of protective devices to detect the fault and without exposing the system to dangerous overvoltages. This paper presents a procedure to determine the optimum size of the neutral-grounding resistor (NGR) in medium-voltage systems commonly found in industrial plants and electrical-distribution systems.

title: Adversarially Robust Hybrid Sampling for Imbalanced Airworthiness Directive Assessment
authors: Xiaotong Guan, Zhida Song, Li Zhang, Jingbo Zhao
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning, Pattern Recognition and Automation Engineering (MLPRAE)
abstract: Accurate assessment of Airworthiness Directives (ADs) is vital for aviation safety. This paper proposes an Adversarially Robust Hybrid Sampling (ARHS) method to tackle severe class imbalance and enhance model robustness. ARHS combines hybrid sampling with adversarial training to generate balanced datasets and improve decision boundary stability. Evaluated on real AD data, ARHS significantly outperforms traditional methods like SMOTE and ROS, achieving higher recall and F1-scores while strengthening resistance to noise and adversarial perturbations. The method offers a reliable solution for safety-critical AD evaluation under imbalanced and noisy data conditions.

title: The Application of the Linearization Method to the Numerical Solution of the Inverse Kinematic Problem in Vertically Inhomogeneous Media Using Refracted and Scattered Signals
authors: Evgeny A. Putyata
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The linearization method is applied to solve the inverse kinematic problem in seismic exploration using refracted and scattered signals in vertically inhomogeneous media. Linearization provides a practical approach for approximate solutions, particularly in seismic and acoustic inverse problems, where exact solutions are often unattainable due to the ill-posed nature of the problem. However, when a priori information on the medium’s velocity distribution is available, an approximate solution with controlled accuracy becomes feasible. This paper presents the formulation of the inverse kinematic problem and derives the corresponding inversion formula for vertically inhomogeneous media, under the assumption that the velocity function allows linearization near a constant background. The method employs refracted and scattered acoustic waves as the probing signal. The developed algorithm, implemented in Python, is used in model numerical experiments. The results demonstrate that the linearized solution agrees well with the exact one under appropriate conditions, and support the continuation of this research direction.

title: 3D-SAF: Face Forgery Detection via Dual-Stream & Dual-Attention & Dual-Feature
authors: Rujia Qi, Yuxuan Xie, Hui Shi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Face forgery has given rise to a series of increasingly prominent problems, including personal privacy leakage, face-based payment security and visual communication security. Consequently, face forgery detection has emerged as a crucial task in the realm of information security. Nevertheless, existing face forgery detection methods often prove ineffective when dealing with complex image scene tasks, primarily due to implicit identity interference. To address these challenges, this study presents a novel scheme for face forgery detection. Especially, we introduce a novel Dual-Stream, Dual-Attention, and Dual-Feature network (3D-SAF). This framework initially establishes a Dual-Stream enhanced Simplified Linear Cross-Attention (DSLCA) network for shallow feature extraction, designed to selectively concentrate the network's attention on the low-level features of genuine faces. Building upon this foundation, we further develop a Dual-Stream enhanced Multiple Cross-Attention (DSMCA) network for deep feature extraction, which guides the network's focus towards the high-level features of forged faces. Ultimately, the integration of shallow and deep features facilitates effective face forgery detection. The detection accuracy on the C23 and C40 subsets of FaceForensics++ reaches 99.62% and 97.50% respectively, outperforming the optimal model in the mainstream by 2.74% and 8.58%. In the cross - database experiments, the Area Under the Curve (AUC) of this model reaches 83.81%, surpassing that of the optimal mainstream model by 0.95%. This result substantiates that the proposed 3D - SAF significantly outperforms other mainstream models in terms of face forgery detection performanc

title: Konrad Zuse and Operation Paperclip
authors: Raúl Rojas, Alexander B. Magoun
publish: IEEE Annals of the History of Computing
abstract: Inventor Konrad Zuse built Germany’s first computers between 1936 and 1945. Twice drafted to the front, he was able to return to Berlin to continue developing his machines and to work as a structural analyst for Henschel-Werke, a manufacturer of military aircraft and radio-controlled cruise missiles. After the war, some of Germany’s leading aircraft scientists were recruited by the U.S. military as part of Operation Paperclip. This article explains why Zuse was not recruited, although some of his superiors were.

title: A Worker Precision Evaluation Strategy Based on Bayesian Decision Theory in Crowdsourcing Systems
authors: Xiaocong Yu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: A significant number of applications adopt crowdsourcing as a solution, leveraging human intelligence. However, crowdsourcing data quality is pivotal, as the workers involved in crowdsourcing may have varying skill levels. In this paper, a worker precision evaluation strategy based on Bayesian decision theory is proposed. The precision of a worker is regarded as a random variable, and Bayesian decision making is used to evaluate whether the worker meets the precision requirements of the task. The evaluation process is designed to comprehensively assess the historical performance of the worker, the test scale, the test performance and the risk factors. The experimental results demonstrate that this method exhibits enhanced reliability in the evaluation of worker precision, as evidenced by its superior performance in comparison to alternative approaches.

title: The Automation of Appetite: Barriers and Enablers of Artificial Intelligence Driven Home Cooking Machines Among Urban Households
authors: Tanuj Mathur, Shiladitya Verma, Jitendra Sharma, Sujoy Sen
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: This study explores the barriers and enablers influencing the adoption of AI-driven home cooking machines among urban households, a domain that remains underexamined in technology adoption research. Specifically, the research aims to identify, rank, and compare barriers and enabling factors for AI-driven home cooking machine adoption among urban households, across gender and self-cooking preference segments. Data were collected through a structured questionnaire from 129 urban respondents, primarily aged 36–45, with 57.4% identifying as female and 77.5% married. Kendall’s W was used to assess consensus in rankings. Quantitative results show that ‘cost and affordability’ (Mean Rank = 1.19) and ‘convenience and time savings’ (Mean Rank = 1.83) are the most significant barrier and enabler, respectively. Significant subgroup differences were observed in the study, confirming the influence of user profiles on adoption preferences. The study is limited by its use of non-probabilistic sampling and reliance on self-reported preferences. The findings contribute to both theory and practice by emphasizing the importance of contextual and behavioral segmentation for the successful deployment of domestic AI technologies.

title: Multi-Tracer and Multi-Scanner PET Image Denoising Using an Efficient Diffusion Transformer
authors: Z. Zhou, F. Yang, B. Lei, T.-A. Song, J.Dutta Dutta
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Diffusion probabilistic models (DPMs) have been applied to PET image denoising. Due to the large number of sampling steps and the inherent randomness of the sampling process, DPMs typically suffer from slow training and inference, as well as variability in results. In this study, we propose a restoration model based on a diffusion transformer, which combines the global distribution modeling capability of transformers with the local detail recovery ability of a decoder based on a convolutional neural network. Our model is trained on a multi-tracer, multi-scanner brain PET and MR dataset comprising 150 subjects with FDG, tau, and amyloid PET images acquired from two different scanners (Siemens Biograph and Siemens HRRT). We demonstrate that our approach achieves superior and robust denoising performance compared to standard DPMs. Furthermore, our model requires only 10 diffusion steps to produce high-quality denoised images, in contrast to the hundreds needed by standard DPMs. These results indicate that our method is promising as a robust and efficient PET denoising approach.

title: Synthetic CT Generation for Rb-82 PET Attenuation Correction Using 3D Diffusion Models
authors: B. Yu, W. Qi, L. Yang, F. Hashimoto, J. Kolthammer, K. Gong
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Accurate attenuation correction (AC) using computed tomography (CT) is critical for quantitative PET imaging. However, respiratory motion compromises the accuracy of CT-based attenuation correction, while concerns about radiation dose from repeated CT during rest and stress scans, along with the lack of integrated CT in some organ-specific PET scanners, limit its feasibility. To address these limitations, we developed a 3D Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Model (DDPM) to generate synthetic CT images directly from non-attenuation corrected (NAC) PET data, enabling consistent attenuation correction without reliance on external anatomical imaging. The model was trained using paired Rb-82 myocardial perfusion PET scans and CT-derived attenuation maps. Quantitative evaluations showed that 3D DDPM outperformed both 2D DDPM and 3D UNet models in CT image synthesis. Error analysis of PET images reconstructed using different AC methods demonstrated that 3D DDPM achieved the lowest standard deviation among all methods. Notably, the synthetic CT images exhibited improved anatomical alignment with PET respiratory phases, which can reduce misregistration artifacts and potentially enhance PET quantification accuracy.

title: RadSim: An Open-Source Radiation Detector Simulator
authors: K. Nelson, D. Hangal, S. Labov, N. McFerran, C. Mattoon, B. Canion, B. Lahmann, V. Cheung
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: RadSim is a software tool that simulates radiation source emissions, interfaces with radiation transport tools to prepare incident flux, and models radiation detector response to rapidly produce synthetic radiation measurements. RadSim is being developed as an open-source simulation tool linking existing source generation libraries and radiation transport tools with a newly engineered detector response module to meet the increasing demand for spectral simulations, advanced radiation detection algorithms, and new detector development. The simulation methods and algorithms are transparent, and the underlying code is being published as a part of the opensource package. RadSim includes a source generation module with the capability to output relative abundances of radionuclides at a given time along with a list of emissions from the sources with their energies and intensities. For the transport module, RadSim includes APIs to interface with deterministic and stochastic transport tools for transporting the radiation from the source to the surface of the detector. Finally, RadSim provides a newly engineered detector response module to model a detector and output a measured spectrum from an incident flux. The detector response tool includes modules to both estimate the gamma-ray interactions within the detector material and the effects of subsequent readout that impact resolution and pile-up. The detector response module includes a novel machine-learning approach to accurately obtain the chord length distributions of gamma rays traversing the detector. The full RadSim package with the detector modeling capability is scheduled for a full release in September 2025.

title: 3D Trench Pixels, A Sensor Solution for 4D Tracking in HL-LHC Experiments and Beyond
authors: A. Lampis, M. Boscardin, A. Cardini, G. M. Cossu, G.F. Dalla Betta, L. La Delfa, A. Lai, A. Loi, S. Ronchin, S. Vecchi, M. Verdoglia
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The development of tracking systems for future high-luminosity colliders presents significant technological challenges, particularly in managing increased pile-up and radiation damage. To address these issues, new 4D tracking systems capable of measuring track timing are required. Among the most promising sensors for these systems, 3D trench pixel sensors, developed by the TimeSPOT INFN project, demonstrate exceptional time resolution (around 10 ps ) and nearly full detection efficiency even after exposure to radiation fluences of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \cdot 10^{17} 1_{\text{MeV}} \mathrm{n}_{\text {eq }} \text{cm}^{-2}$</tex>, achieved by increasing the operating bias voltage from 100 V to 300 V . A new irradiation campaign at the TRIGA Mark II Reactor at the Jožef Stefan Institute has just been concluded, reaching the extreme fluence of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1} \cdot \mathbf{1 0}^{\mathbf{1 8}} \mathbf{1} \mathbf{~ M e V} \mathbf{n}_{\text {eq }} \mathbf{c m}^{-\mathbf{2}}$</tex>. Preliminary measurements performed using a newly developed laser setup capable of mapping the charge collection efficiency of irradiated sensors with micrometric precision, indicate the needs to further increase bias voltage operation to recover the charge collection efficiency at these fluences. The complete characterization of the latest irradiated sensors using the laser setup, together with the results of a beam test conducted at the CERN SPS North Area beam facility, will be presented at the conference. This study evaluates the charge collection efficiency, time resolution and detection efficiency of 3D trench sensors irradiated up to a fluence of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \cdot 10^{18} 1 \text{MeV} \mathrm{n}_{\text {eq }} \text{cm}^{-2}$</tex> pushing the boundaries of radiation hardness in silicon sensors designed for 4D tracking in the extreme radiation conditions of HL-LHC and future colliders.

title: A 7-ps 16-channel Time-to-Digital Converter with Two-Dimension Vernier Interpolation
authors: J. Zhao, J. Qin, Z. Li, J. Li, L. Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In large-scale nuclear and particle physics experiments, high-precision time measurement is one of the important tasks. Combining amplification and discrimination with Time-to-Digital Conversion is a mainstream technical route of high-precision time measurement, while TDC is a key part. This paper presents a design of a multi-channel TDC Application Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) with high precision and large dynamic range. The design employs a coarse-fine measurement architecture: a two-dimension vernier structure is implemented for fine time measurement, while a coarse counter is utilized to extend the dynamic range. The twodimension vernier structure employs a 2D array of time comparators. By detecting signal timing across multiple nodes on the two delay lines, this structure enables a significant reduction of propagation delay line length while maintaining equivalent time quantization range, effectively decreasing propagation jitter and improving timing precision. To achieve a broad dynamic range, a coarse counter is utilized. However, for a specific high-frequency clock, the bit-width of the coarse counter is constrained. Conventional cascaded structures are prone to the metastability issue. To address this issue, this design adopts a cascaded gray code counter with a falling-edgetriggered parity bit combined with stage-by-stage calibration, effectively eliminating metastability. The ASIC is fabricated under a 180 nm CMOS process; the experimental results from multichannel testing demonstrate a timing precision better than 7 ps and a dynamic range exceeding 5 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu \mathrm{s}$</tex>. The total static power consumption is 280.4 mW for 16 channels and the dynamic power consumption is approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.1 \text{mW} / \text{MHz} /$</tex> channel.

title: Development of a Scintillation-Based Fast Neutron Multiplicity Counter for Nuclear Safeguards
authors: G. Chartier, B. Laurent, J. Dumazert, G. Lelaizant, N. Dufour, M. Labalme
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Nondestructive assay measurements in the context of nuclear safeguards aim to estimate the parameters that characterize neutron multiplication in an interrogated system. Typical devices utilized in these assays consist of arrays of He-3 proportional counters inserted in a polyethylene lattice for neutron moderation. This process significantly increases the neutron mean lifetime against detection due to scattering in the detector, and thereby, it obstructs the measurement of the multiplying system time characteristics. Recently, it has been demonstrated that this issue may be overcome through the development of scatter-based detector arrays, which are sensitive to fast neutrons and do not require thermalization. This paper outlines the development of a new scatter-based neutron multiplicity counter composed of stilbene crystals and presents early results of the study. Data post-processing algorithms were developed in order to generate the neutron detection timeline using pulse shape discrimination. Physical parameters related to multiplication are inferred from the timeline analysis using the Feynman-alpha method. We produced a first Feynman-Y curve from a simple measurement of a Cf-252 source, alongside an MCNP model of the setup that accounted for the said measurement, showing a 33 % mean deviation between the two curves. Approximations in the modeling of the detection efficiency, which translates into a deviation of the simulated convergence value (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\square^{\infty}$</tex>), properly explain this discrepancy. In addition, the simulation consistently replicated the experimental neutron prompt decay constant (◻). We could therefore validate the simulation model and its associated algorithms, which will be used to dimension the final multiplicity-counting device. The detector performance parameters, such as the false neutron-counting rate, will also be studied in a near future.

title: Dosimetry for FLASH Proton Radiotherapy via Organic Scintillating Fibers
authors: C. Olson, J. Strong, A. Paxton, G. Nelson, E. Cazalas
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Our objective is to study the design, development, and preliminary proof-of-concept testing of a dosimetry device intended for use in FLASH radiotherapy. We are working on a system that utilizes organic scintillating fibers in conjunction with a silicon photomultiplier (SiPM) and fieldprogrammable gate array (FPGA) to provide real time measurements of dose and pulse monitoring in-situ during radiotherapy treatment delivery. We include results of simulations utilizing GEANT4 aiding in discovering a geometrical design of the fibers with the scintillating material in place compared to measured values of a clinical proton beam with no in-beam material at the Huntsman Cancer Institute (HCI) at the University of Utah (UofU). We also include X-ray machine results that show a strong correlation between the measured charge integration of the system and actual dose provided by the X-ray machine and also indicated the possibility of response on a sufficient timescale (on the order of nanoseconds) to trigger a safety interlock. Conclusions include preliminary irradiations results performed with the proton beam at HCI which indicated the capability of the dosimetry system to provide individual pulse monitoring. We also discuss future work planned.

title: Democratising Parallel Compute: Triton 3D Joseph Projector Implementation
authors: I. R.D. Singh, G. Schramm, K. Thielemans
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Medical imaging often involves computationally intensive algorithms that process highdimensional, weakly dependent data; these data characteristics allow for parallel computation on dedicated hardware. The most common hardware used are Nvidia Graphic Processing Units (GPUs), and the language for writing highly optimised kernels is Compute Unified Device Architecture (CUDA) that is mature but proprietary. This restricts deployment primarily to Nvidia hardware. This Hackathon project aimed to investigate the viability of Triton as an alternative, focusing on implementing the computationally expensive Joseph projector in Triton. This was written within a day and in less than 500 lines of code; this demonstrates the productivity that is enabled by Triton's Python-based meta-programming interface, block-based programming model, and Just-In-Time (JIT) compilation capabilities. Further to this, the advantages of programming with Triton are: (1) mixed precision, (2) support for Nvidia and AMD graphics cards, (3) Triton's internal code optimisation, and (4) autotuning of block sizes to maximally utilise the GPU. The Triton-based Joseph projector revealed comparable performance as compared to ParallelProj, an open-source Joseph Projector written in CUDA. The code is available at https://github.com/Imraj-Singh/Triton_Joseph_Projector.

title: Dual-Domain Diffusion Iterative Framework for Benchtop X-Ray Fluorescence CT Imaging
authors: S. Pu, J. Song, L. Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: X-ray fluorescence computed tomography (XFCT) using high atomic number element-based agents holds significant potential for tumor-specific imaging, yet its sensitivity remains a limitation in biomedical applications. To address this challenge, we introduce a novel dual-domain reconstruction framework that synergizes a diffusion posterior sampling (DPS) model in the projection domain with a hybrid DPS and maximum likelihood expectation maximization (MLEM) approach in the image domain. In our method, projection noise is first suppressed using a diffusion model, after which DPS and MLEM reconstruction algorithms are alternately applied in the image domain to simultaneously enforce image priors and satisfy physical constraints of the imaging system. We validate the method on phantom experiments with gadolinium contrast: the proposed approach increases the contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR) of reconstructed Gadolinium (Gd) images compared to conventional reconstruction, enabling a minimum detectable Gd concentration below 0.1 mg/ml. Furthermore, we demonstrate in vivo imaging of gadoliniumbased nanoparticles in a mouse of orthotopic liver tumors under a sparse view scan. The dualdomain iterative framework successfully recovers the Gd signal while simultaneously reducing noise. These results indicate that the proposed method advances XFCT's capability for highsensitivity imaging, broadening its applicability in precise tumor imaging and nanomedicine.

title: Total-Body Low-Dose PET Denoising Using 3D Flow-Matching with Self-Conditioned Starting
authors: S. Yoon, S.Y. Yie, K. Kim, J.S. Lee, Q. Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Low-dose PET imaging suffers from high noise and degraded image quality, necessitating effective denoising techniques to recover diagnostic-quality images. Recent diffusion-based generative models have shown promise in PET denoising, but existing approaches are computationally intensive and often require simulating lengthy stochastic processes. In this work, We propose a 3D flow-matching denoising model for total-body PET, trained to learn a continuous velocity field that maps noisy to clean images without simulating stochastic processes. To further improve efficiency, we introduce Self-Conditioned Starting (SCS), which initiates denoising from a partially noised low-dose input, preserving anatomical structure while refining details. We train and evaluate the model on the public Total-Body Ultra-Low-Dose PET Challenge dataset (1/10-dose) and compare against a conventional flow-matching model. Quantitative results show that our SCS approach achieves superior performance (PSNR: 43.87 ± 2.02 dB; SSIM: 0.99 ± 0.01) compared to full-step flow matching model. Our findings demonstrate that combining flow matching with self-conditioned starting enables faster 3D denoising in ultra-low-dose PET image restoration.

authors: L. Zeng, Y. Li

abstract: In compress sensing, it is believed that the L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf> norm minimization is the best way to enforce a sparse solution. However, the L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf> norm is difficult to be implemented in a gradient-based iterative image reconstruction algorithm. The total variation (TV) norm minimization is considered as a good substitute for the L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf> norm minimization. This paper points out that the TV norm is not powerful enough to enforce a piecewise-constant image. This paper uses the limited angle tomography to illustrate the possibility of using the L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf> norm to encourage a piecewise. One of the drawbacks of the L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf> norm is that its derivative is zero almost everywhere, making a gradient-based algorithm useless. Our novel idea is to replace the zero value of L<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">0</inf> norm derivation with a zeromean random variable.
