title: Astronomical Observations With Gas X-Ray Detectors Onboard the Cubesat X-Ray Observatory Ninjasat
authors: T. Takeda, T. Tamagwa, T. Enoto, T. Kitaguchi, Y. Kato, T. Mihara, W. Iwakiri, M. Numazawa, N. Ota, A. Aoyama, S. Iwata, T. Takahashi, K. Yamasaki, S. Tuchiya, Y. Nakano, C.-P. Hu, H. Takahashi, A. Dohi, N. Nishimura, R. Hirai, Y. Yoshida, H. Sato, S. Hayashi, S. Watanabe, A. Jujo, Y. Zhou, K. Uchiyama, H. Odaka, T. Tamba, K. Taniguchi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We present an overview of the Gas Multiplier Counters (GMCs) onboard the CubeSat X-ray observatory NinjaSat, along with the results of astronomical observations. NinjaSat is the first Japanese 6U-size (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 ~\text{cm} \times 20 ~\text{cm} \times 30 ~\text{cm}$</tex>) CubeSat X-ray observatory, which was launched into a sun-synchronous orbit at an altitude of 530 km on November 11, 2023. NinjaSat is equipped with two GMCs, which are 1 U -size non-imaging gas X-ray detectors sensitive to 2-50 keV X-rays, to observe bright X-ray sources in the sky. GMC consists of a gas cell filled with a Xe-based gas mixture, a high voltage supply and analog signal processing board, a digital signal processing board, and an X-ray collimator of a 2.1° field of view. The most significant feature of the GMC is its large effective area of 32 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> at 6 keV, which is more than two orders of magnitude larger than the X-ray detectors onboard previously launched CubeSats. We have achieved this at a low cost and in a short development time by employing a gas detector that can easily expand its sensitive area at a low cost and does not require cooling for operation, unlike semiconductor detectors. By the end of April 2025, we successfully observed 28 X-ray sources using NinjaSat. This is a successful application of the gas detector to the CubeSat mission and highlights NinjaSat's pioneering role as a compact yet uniquely powerful observatory in time-domain astronomy.

title: Micro RI Cell Imaging System Using Eutectic Scintillator and Objective Lens
authors: F. Nishikido, K. Kamada, H. Wakizaka, A. Yoshikawa, Y. Usuki, S. Ito, T. Yamaya
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Single cell imaging is strongly required to study the properties and mechanisms of cells for the realization of regenerative medicines. Therefore, development of dynamic micro imaging techniques based on nuclear medicine is desired. On the other hand, conventional nuclear medicine imaging techniques are not suitable for cell regulation studies. For example, PET imaging cannot achieve spatial resolutions smaller than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex>. Autoradiography cannot obtain dynamic images. Therefore, we are developing a new micro radioisotope (RI) cell imaging system to realize dynamic cell observations. This system consists of a CCD camera and a plate eutectic scintillator which has a micro fiber structure smaller than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex>. Compared to previous imaging systems, an important feature of the new system is the ability of the eutectic scintillator to improve imaging resolution by suppressing the scintillation photon spread due to the micro fiber structure.

title: A Novel Single-Junction Double-Sided 3D Trench Electrode Soft X-Ray Detector
authors: H. Ji, M. Liu, Z. Li, J. Luo, B. Tang, B. Li, P. Zhang, K. Huang, R. Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: X-ray with an energy of 30 KeV can penetrate a depth of 863 μm in silicon substrate. To enhance the efficiency of charge collection, a single-junction double-sided 3D trench electrode detector (SJ-DS-3D-TED) is proposed in this work, which has been fabricated on the 8 -inch Complementary Metal Oxide Semiconductor (CMOS) process platform of the Institute of Microelectronics, Chinese Academy of Sciences (IMECAS). We use deep reactive ion etching (DRIE) and in-situ doping on the front side of the P -type substrate wafer to fabricate N -type trench electrodes. On the back side, P -type doping is carried out by using in-situ doping. Finally, we use metal magnetron sputtering deposition to achieve the connection of double-sided electrodes. The electrodes are added to both the front and back of the silicon wafer, which is equivalent to the entire silicon wafer (725 μm) being within the detection range of the detector. This device is expected to be widely applied in aerospace, nuclear medicine, large-scale scientific facilities, and X-ray spectrometers.

title: An Integrated Correction Method for Geometric, Atmospheric and Terrain Effects in Hyperspectral Remote Sensing Images
authors: Guorui Jia, Yujie Zhao, Shuhan Liu, Chenchao Xiao, Huijie Zhao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Reflectance inversion is a critical challenge in quantitative hyperspectral remote sensing, especially in rugged terrain. The under-/over-correction of reflectance caused by such terrain and its impacts on subsequent information extraction have not been well quantified or effectively eliminated. To improve surface spectral reflectance inversion under varying illumination, atmospheric, and terrain conditions, an integrated correction method for geometric, atmospheric, and terrain effects (ICGAT) is proposed. The method incorporates a coupled radiative transfer model that accounts for direct solar irradiance, diffuse sky irradiance, surface-atmosphere coupling irradiance, and irradiance from neighboring slope along the sun-terrain-target path. The geometric positioning and irradiance components are first computed, and followed by an iterative retrieval of reflectance, geometric resampling is subsequently applied to the reflectance, an uncertainty quantification is finally conducted in the process. Tests show that ICGAT significantly improves spectral consistency between neighboring shaded and sunny slopes, reducing the influence of terrain relief on reflectance, as well as retrieve high-accuracy surface reflectance in flat areas. Meanwhile, the uncertainty propagation analysis could reveal not only the fidelity of the retrieved reflectance but also the major sources of uncertainty.

title:

authors: J. Caravaca, B. Das, A. Bidkar, S. A. Naik, V. Negut, D. Goodman, M. Streicher, Y. Seo, R. Flavell
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Targeted alpha therapy with <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">225</sup>Ac is a promising modality for cancer treatment, as recently shown in pre-clinical and clinical trials. Achieving a precise understanding of the biokinetics of <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">225</sup>Ac radiopharmaceuticals is critical to leverage their potential in the clinic. Although this is typically achieved via gamma-ray imaging experiments, such imaging is very challenging for <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">225</sup>Ac due to the extremely low injected activities (<37 kBq), the unfavorable gamma-ray branching ratios (<26%), and the complicated decay chain. Standard SPECT with collimation struggles to achieve quality images and accurate quantification in pre-clinical experiments. In this work, we propose Compton imaging as an alternative solution for this problem. We leverage a commercial CZT Compton camera to achieve in-vivo imaging of <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">225</sup>Ac in mice at therapeutic activities below the microcurie. We compared the sensitivity of a single-head Compton imaging system with that of a standard collimated gamma camera to be 4.7 times greater for <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">213</sup>Bi and 7.5 for <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">221</sup>Fr. We successfully imaged <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">225</sup>Ac daughter biodistributions of <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">221</sup>Fr and <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">213</sup>Bi in a mouse in vivo with only 30 minutes scan time and a single bed position. Performance can be further improved by using more detector heads and via system optimization. Comparison between in-vivo and ex-vivo will be presented and discussed.

title: Numerical Simulation Study of High-Energy X-ray-Induced Photoacoustic Imaging in FLASH Radiotherapy
authors: Q. Wang, X. Hu, Y. Zhang, J. Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: FLASH radiotherapy is an emerging radiation therapy technique that delivers ultra-high dose rate irradiation (typically exceeding 40 Gy/s, far surpassing conventional radiotherapy's 0.03-0.1 Gy/s) to complete treatment in an extremely short time (on the millisecond scale). It utilizes high-energy radiation beams to deliver a high dose of radiation, rapidly damaging tumor cell DNA while minimizing normal tissue damage due to the extremely brief exposure time.X-ray FLASH radiotherapy stands out as one of the most clinically translatable FLASH technologies due to its deeper tissue penetration, broader equipment accessibility, flexibility in multi-field irradiation, and more established clinical translation foundation.To enhance the precision and safety of FLASH radiotherapy while reducing equipment cost and complexity, it is essential to develop high-speed, high-resolution, high-contrast imaging technologies with robust real-time tracking capabilities. During FLASH radiotherapy, high-energy X-rays induce strong acoustic signals in tissues, and by capturing these signals, high-precision images of target tissues can be reconstructed, optimized for FLASH radiotherapy applications. In this study, we employed Geant4 Monte Carlo simulations to model the interaction process of single-pulse 10 MV X-rays (generated by medical linear accelerators) with various materials. Subsequently, we used MATLAB's k-Wave toolkit to simulate the propagation and attenuation of the induced acoustic waves. The 128-element ring transducer array acquires acoustic signals, which are processed to reconstruct the target tissue image. Experimental results confirmed the feasibility of this online imaging technique for X-ray FLASH radiotherapy applications.

title: Tapped Delay Lines Model and Optimization for a Multichannel Time-to-Digital Converter in FPGA
authors: J. Rossignol, D. Lee, S.I. Kwon
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Time-to-digital converters (TDCs) are a critical part of the acquisition chain to produce precise time measurements for radiation detection in medical imaging and high-energy physics. Research on TDC design in FPGA is often focused on digital means to improve resolution, precision and nonlinearity, such as using wave union or multiple delay lines. Less scrutiny is given to making sure that the tapped delay line (TDL) circuit itself is optimized through careful placement and routing. This study provides a model linking FPGA design parameters, namely, the delay through the TDL and clock skew to precision and nonlinearity. From this model, design principles are identified and used to produce four different circuit optimizations for the TDL. The effects of these optimizations on bin width and precision were studied both in simulation and measured experimentally on an UltraScale+ FPGA. These optimizations remove all ultrawide bins from the TDL. This led to an improvement of the RMS precision of a two-channel TDC from 4.7 ps to 2.5 ps. The produced model and simulator facilitate design choices and accelerate the optimization and validation of TDL-based TDCs.

title: Toward an International Framework for the Standardization of Active Non-Destructive Nuclear Measurement Methods
authors: A. Sari
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Active non-destructive nuclear measurement methods are essential in homeland security and safeguards, contraband detection, and other applications such as radioactive waste characterization and materials analysis. However, the current landscape reveals the lack of homogeneity and consistency in how techniques are described and terminology applied—often complicating, or even preventing, proper positioning within the state of the art. Photon- and neutron-based techniques differ not only in the type of irradiation performed, but also in the nuclear reactions they induce, the materials they target, the particles detected and their measurement, as well as the instrumentation involved in both the irradiation and detection steps. The absence of standardized terminologies, methods and procedures leads to inconsistent results, limited reproducibility, and poor comparability across laboratories, hindering scientific progress, regulatory acceptance, and international collaboration. To address these challenges, this work proposes the foundation of international standards in active non-destructive nuclear measurement methods, focusing on photon and neutron techniques. Drawing on a comprehensive review of both historical and recent developments led by key stakeholders, this initiative aims to define common and modern practices in active non-destructive nuclear measurement methods. Preliminary results from inter-laboratory comparisons and expert consultations are presented, highlighting key technical challenges and outlining a path toward an international consensus. Ultimately, this effort aims to enhance confidence, transparency, efficiency and comparability in active nuclear measurements across both conventional and nuclear industries, as well as within the global scientific and regulatory communities.

title: Novel Sensor for Quality Control in Targeted Alpha Therapies
authors: E. Lukosi, W.-T. Hsu, P. Parshi, C. Patricelli, K. N. Bobba
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Currently, there is a lack of quality control testing for targeted alpha radiopharmaceuticals in the clinics. Unlike beta-based therapies, Ac-225 has several daughter products that, while contributing to the therapy, can also increase unwanted dose to healthy tissue due to daughter redistribution challenges. Furthermore, understanding the amount of bound Ac-225 versus free is vital to limit the dose to healthy tissue. In this presentation, we will introduce the concept of microfluidic alpha spectrometry. Here, the carrier fluid is placed in a continuous flow condition through small microfluidic structures that enable real-time alpha spectrometry for isotope identification and even concentration. The sensor provides transient data, such that the free and bound isotopes can be quantified as they exit an HPLC.

title: Counting Loss Correction of Energy-Resolving Photon Counting Detector for Medical Imaging Based on Simulation of the Energy Transportations of the X-Rays
authors: N. Kimoto, R. Nishigami, T. Asahara, D. Kobayashi, S. Goto, Y. Kanazawa, A. Katsumata, S. Yamamoto, H. Hayashi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Analysis of X-ray energies made available by energy-resolving photon counting detectors (ERPCDs) will derive novel quantitative X-ray images based on accurate material identification, in which information on true X-ray attenuation must be analyzed. However, in practical applications under high counting rates, this information is distorted by the counting loss caused by pulse pileup and dead time. In this study, we aimed to propose a counting loss correction algorithm. The correction is performed by converting the measured “counting rate values” into those expected in ideal measurement conditions. Because the degree of the counting loss relates to the shape of the energy spectrum, our algorithm considers X-ray penetration in objects with various effective atomic numbers <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(\mathrm{Z}_{\text{eff }} \mathrm{s}\right)$</tex> and the detector response. The expected counting rates were derived by simulating X-ray spectra by considering the beam hardening effect and the detector response. To consider the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Z}_{\text{eff }}$</tex> dependence, correction curves related to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6.5<\mathrm{Z}_{\text{eff }}<13$</tex> were virtually generated from experimentally obtained correction curves for polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Z}_{\text{eff }}=6.5)$</tex> and aluminum <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{Al}, \mathrm{Z}_{\text{eff }}=13)$</tex>. In the correction process, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Z}_{\text{eff }}$</tex> was firstly assumed, and the corresponding correction curve was tentatively applied to the measured counting rate of the unknown object. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Z}_{\text{eff }}$</tex> was then determined by a previously reported material identification algorithm. Finally, a properly corrected condition was determined based on the principle that the derived <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Z}_{\text{eff }}$</tex> should match the tentatively assumed <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Z}_{\text{eff }}$</tex>. Experimental verification was performed by measuring PMMA, Al, and their bilayer structures <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathrm{Z}_{\text{eff }}=8.5-10.5)$</tex> having mass thicknesses of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1-10 ~\mathrm{g} / \text{cm}^{2}$</tex> with our prototype detector. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Z}_{\text{eff }}$</tex> images can be derived with an accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{Z}_{\text{eff }}+/-1$</tex>. Our counting loss correction method will contribute to high-precision quantitative analysis using ERPCD.

title: Fast and Low-Noise Amplifying System for SiPM Characterization in a Wide Temperature Range
authors: P. Carniti, C. Gotti, G. Pessina, D. Trotta
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: RICH (Ring Imaging CHerenkov) detectors work by sensing single Cherenkov photons emitted by charged particles to measure their velocity. Due to the future need of increasing sensor granularity to avoid event pile-up, SiPMs (Silicon Photo-Multipliers) may replace vacuum-based PMTs (Photo Multiplier Tubes) as the baseline choice for next generation detectors. These sensors have, however, one downside, which is their high sensitivity to radiation, effect that can be counterbalanced by cooling the sensors down to cryogenic temperatures. To be sure that these sensors satisfy the requirements of future Cherenkov detectors in terms of signal gain, speed and time resolution, various SiPMs need to be characterized in a wide temperature range to find the best compromise between signal-to-noise ratio and cooling requirements. For this purpose, we designed a low-noise (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<1 \text{nV} / \sqrt{ } \text{Hz}$</tex>), high-gain (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 7500 \Omega$</tex>) and high-speed (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$700 \text{MHz}-1 \text{GHz}$</tex> closed-loop bandwidth) amplifier that can work in close proximity to the sensor during the entire characterization phase. The amplifier is made of two amplifying stages, the first is a HBT (Heterojunction Bipolar Transistor) whose collector node is connected to the positive input of a CFOA (Current Feedback Operational Amplifier), which has a local feedback forming a noninverting configuration. The whole system is then regulated with a resistor in a second feedback loop and is compensated for stability at the input node. The output is AC-coupled and can be either directly connected to an oscilloscope or to a second amplifying stage which operates at ambient temperature and has a gain of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.5 ~\mathrm{V} / \mathrm{V}$</tex> and 3 GHz bandwidth. This amplifier is being used by the LHCb RICH collaboration to characterize various SiPMs with different cell and pixel sizes, for use in the LHCb RICH Upgrade 2. The achieved FWHM time resolution of the amplifier alone is < 30 ps for typical single photon signals from a SiPM, depending on temperature and sensor size.

title: The Aladdin Detector at LHC
authors: M. Citterio, P. Gandini, N. Neri
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: ALADDIN (An LHC Apparatus for Direct Dipole moments INvestigation) is a proposed compact fixed-target experiment at the LHC, designed to enable precise measurements of charm baryon electromagnetic dipole moments. The experiment leverages an innovative storage-ring layout that redirects protons from the beam halo onto a solid target, coupled with a bent crystal. This setup produces forward-boosted charm baryons, which are then channelled through the crystal. By exploiting spin precession induced by the channelling effect in the bent crystal, ALADDIN aims to measure both the magnetic and electric dipole moments of charm baryons. The experimental apparatus consists of a 4.4 m -long spectrometer and a RICH detector for particle identification. It is designed for installation in the LHC Insertion Region 3 during Long Shutdown 3, requiring no civil engineering and having minimal impact on LHC operations, with data-taking planned for Run 4. A proof-of-principle test at the LHC, TWOCRYST, is currently underway to demonstrate the feasibility of the concept. The experiment's Letter of Intent has been submitted to the LHCC, which has approved the collaboration to proceed with a technical proposal in 2025. This contribution will review the pixel detector currently under development for the experiment.

title: Modular PET Sensors with Partly Segmented Light Guides and Single-Channel TCoG Readout
authors: H. Maa-Hacquoil, H. Poladyan, B. Baldassi, O. Bubon, F. Dodgson, B. Krauze, A. Reznik
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Many modular PET sensors detect gamma photons using scintillation crystals that are segmented into small pixels by applying a Center of Gravity (CoG) algorithm to the signals output by the sensor module. Such methods reliably reconstruct the positions of scintillation events when optical photons are symmetrically distributed about the point of gamma photon interaction. However, when scintillation events occur at the periphery of the scintillation crystal array, the sensor module boundary prohibits optical photons from spreading out uniformly. This biases the calculated scintillation coordinates towards the center of the module, causing the scintillation pixel signatures on crystal flood maps to overlap with neighbouring pixels. Solutions have been proposed involving modifications to hardware components or coordinate reconstruction software. These include segmented light guides, a greater number of readout channels and modified CoG algorithms. Trials of such changes have been met with varying degrees of success, however little attention has been given to combinations of these methods on coordinate reconstruction accuracy. This research evaluates the coordinate reconstruction accuracy of sensor modules from a low-dose PET camera using single channel readout, a truncated CoG (TCoG) algorithm and a segmented light guide design. Crystal maps and peak profiles show that a combination of TCoG, single channel readout, and a partially segmented light guide produces the most accurate coordinate reconstruction.

title: Performance Assessment of a Scintillator Detector for Helium Beam Fragmentation Measurements in Charged Particle Therapy
authors: A. C. Kraan, M. Morrocchi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Charged particle therapy is an external beam radiotherapy, where charged particles are used for cancer treatment. In the last years, there is an increasing focus on research that regards the clinical use of helium ions. Fragmentation of helium beams contributes to uncertainties dose distributions. The FOOT experiment aims at measuring double differential (in kinetic energy and angle) fragmentation cross sections of helium beam with therapeutic beam energies. A crucial subdetector in FOOT is the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\triangle \mathrm{E}-\text{TOF}$</tex> (Time-Of-Flight) detector, consisting of two layers of orthogonal scintillator bars, covering a surface of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$40 \times 40 ~\text{cm} 2$</tex>. The goal of this work is to assess the performance of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\Delta \mathrm{E}$</tex> - TOF detector for helium beams of energies, time-of-flight, and fragment charge resolution, and to test the detector for fragment identification in helium beam fragmentation events. The energy resolution for helium beams ranged from 5.0 % to 8.1 %, the TOF resolution ranged from 116 to 157 ps, and the resolution on Z for helium beams without target ranged from 2.7 % to 4.5 % for energies between 100 and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$220 \text{MeV} / \mathrm{u}$</tex>. In this work we present the first helium identification measurements with the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\triangle \mathrm{E}-\text{TOF}$</tex> detector.

title: Identifying Time-series Functions of regulated Measuring Instruments by means of advanced Deep Learning and Machine Learning
authors: Levin Ho, Marko Esche, Martin Nischwitz, Manuel Maue, Sabine Glesner
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: Smart measuring instruments encompass software systems that are subject to legal regulations and require conformity assessments to ensure compliance during use, such as in Legal Metrology. Continuous quality control of such systems, especially after introducing functional updates or software patches, remains an open yet critical challenge. In this article, we develop an extension in form of a text-event-parser to an established deep learning framework to interpret text-based system logbooks describing the metrological function of regulated measuring instruments, and compare the performance with a state-of-the-art approach. Results of implementing our proposed approach onto real-world devices reveal its ability to continuously monitor and identify regulated measuring instruments’ time-dependent behavior. The comparison study shows that our approach has an overall advantage, considering its performance and practical aspects such as required training costs. Additionally, we investigate combinations of the developed approach with other machine learning frameworks, including natural language processing and transfer learning, to evaluate and improve the overall scalability and robustness. Building on the results of the investigations, our approach facilitates the fully automatic quality control of modern software-driven measuring instruments.

title: Initial Performance Evaluation of SimPET-P: Simultaneous PET/MRI for Non-Human Primate Neuro Imaging
authors: D. Kwak, J. Lee, D. Kim, J.-W. Son, D. Hernandez, T. Nam, K.-N. Kim, G.B. Ko, J.S. Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: PET/MRI simultaneously provides functional and anatomical information, making it highly valuable for neuroscience research. To support non-human primate (NHP) neuroscience studies, a new MR-compatible PET insert, named SimPET-P, which is operable across a broad range of magnetic fields has been developed. In this study, we present initial performance and preliminary MR compatibility results of SimPET-P PET insert. Following the NEMA NU-4 2008 standard, spatial resolution, sensitivity, count rate performance and image quality phantom was evaluated. For image quality assessment, a micro hot rod phantom was scanned. All crystals in the detector block were clearly resolved in the flood map. The radial, tangential, and axial spatial resolutions at the center of the field of view based on 3D OSEM reconstruction were 1.24, 1.44, and 1.17 mm FWHM, respectively. The peak sensitivity was 5.86 % using an energy window of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$250-750 \text{keV}$</tex>. The peak noise equivalent count rate (NECR) was 174.45 kcps at 9.73 MBq. Image uniformity was 5.03 %, and the spill-over ratios in water- and air-filled chambers were 0.07 and 0.17, respectively. In the hot rod phantom image, rods as small as 1.6 mm in diameter were distinguishable. For MR compatibility assessment, no distortion in the pulse shape or flood map was observed during operation of a gradient-echo (GRE) sequence. Furthermore, no significant distortion was observed in the MRI images with PET insert operation. These results demonstrate that the developed system can play a significant role in high-resolution PET/MRI studies for NHP. Further optimization of MR compatibility and integrated PET/MRI imaging studies are planned.

title: RegR-PCQA: Deep Learning Based Colored Point Cloud Quality Assessment Using 3D-to-2D Regularized Representation
authors: Yun Zhang, Mao Cui, Na Li, Chunling Fan, Weisi Lin
abstract: Point Cloud Quality Assessment (PCQA) aims to accurately predict the visual quality of a point cloud, which is essential in optimizing and evaluating the point cloud compression, transmission and rendering. In this paper, we propose a deep learning based full reference PCQA using 3D-to-2D Regularized Representation (RegR-PCQA), where point clouds are projected to regularized 2D image representations and then measured with deep neural networks. Firstly, we propose a regularized representation module to project unstructured point clouds to 2D Regularized Geometry Images (RGIs) and Regularized Attribute Images (RAIs), which enhance the local adjacency and uniform distribution of points. An anchor matching is developed to build the correspondence of regularized images between the distorted and reference point clouds. Secondly, to exploit the visual features of the RGIs and RAIs, we propose a deep learning based two-branch PCQA network, in which vision transformer based Geometry Feature Extractor (GFE) extracts global structural features from RGIs and Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) based Attribute Feature Extractor (AFE) extracts local semantic features of the RAIs. Finally, based on the geometry and attribute features, the point cloud quality is predicted by the proposed quality regression module, where a spatial attention mechanism is exploited to assign different importance weights for the feature maps. Experimental results show that the Pearson Linear Correlation Coefficients (PLCC) achieved by the proposed RegR-PCQA are 0.8430, 0.9575, 0.7853 and 0.8576, respectively, on the SIAT-PCQD, SJTU-PCQA, WPC and WPC2.0 datasets, which are superior to the state-of-the-art PCQAs. Also, extensive experimental results on distortion types, sampling strategy and training rate show that the proposed RegR-PCQA achieves an excellent generalization.

title: Experimental Validation of a Front-End Stage for Future XFEL Detectors
authors: A. Ciavarella-Ciavarella, L. Nassi, G. Borghi, M. Carminati, M. Porro, C. Fiorini
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: New X-Ray pixel detectors are required to satisfy the challenging requirements from XFEL (X-ray Free Electron Laser) sources, including high frame rates, wide dynamic range, and low noise for single-photon sensitivity. In this work, we present a novel front-end architecture based on a Charge Sensitive Amplifier with predictive gain switching, and a Flip-Capacitor filter. The CSA is designed to achieve both a single photon resolution and a high dynamic range up to 10000 photons by employing an active control of the gain. The predictive gain switching circuit dynamically sets the proper gain by adding feedback capacitances in parallel. The predictive gain switching is based on the time instant at which the signal exceeds a specified threshold. When the CSA is in its highest gain configuration, a filter is connected to reduce the electronic noise and achieve the single photon resolution at 1 keV. To couple the CSA with the filter, a voltage-tocurrent converter has been designed. The filter is based on an architecture called Flip-Capacitor Filter and implements a fast trapezoidal weighting function. The first prototype of this front-end has been designed in 65 nm CMOS technology, and has already been submitted. We expect to show the experimental results at the conference.

title: Real-Time High-Accuracy Digital Wireless Time, Frequency, and Phase Calibration for Coherent Distributed Antenna Arrays_supp2-3639461.pdf
authors: Jeffrey A Nanzer
abstract: This work presents a fully-digital high-accuracy real-time calibration procedure for frequency and time alignment of open-loop wirelessly coordinated coherent distributed antenna array (CDA) modems, enabling radio frequency (RF) phase coherence of spatially separated commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) software-defined radios (SDRs) without cables or external references such as the global navigation satellite system (GNSS). Building on previous work using high-accuracy spectrally-sparse time of arrival (ToA) waveforms and a multistep ToA refinement process, a high-accuracy two-way time transfer (TWTT)-based time–frequency coordination approach is demonstrated. Due to the two-way nature of the high-accuracy TWTT approach, the time and frequency estimates are Doppler and multipath tolerant, so long as the channel is reciprocal over the synchronization epoch. This technique is experimentally verified using COTS SDRs in a lab environment in static and dynamic scenarios and with significant multipath scatterers. Time, frequency, and phase stability were evaluated by beamforming over coaxial cables to an oscilloscope which achieved time and phase precisions of ~60–<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathbf {\mathrm {70~\text {p}\text {s} }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, with median coherent gains above 99% using optimized coordination parameters, and a beamforming frequency root-mean-square error (RMSE) of 3.73 ppb in a dynamic scenario. Finally, experiments were conducted to compare the performance of this technique with previous works using an analog continuous-wave two-tone (CWTT) frequency reference technique in both static and dynamic settings.

title: MaLAM4Com: Multi-Agent Cooperative Large AI Models for Wireless Communications
authors: Ziheng Liu, Jiayi Zhang, Yiyang Zhu, Enyu Shi, Bokai Xu, Dusit Niyato, Shi Jin, Bo Ai
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Large artificial intelligence (AI) models for wireless communications have demonstrated remarkable success across a range of wireless downstream tasks. However, their high computational overhead, low training efficiency, and limited privacy protection pose significant challenges for deployment on resource-constrained terminal devices. To address this issue, we propose a novel distributed framework that utilizes a three-layer cooperative paradigm to effectively achieve cooperation among agents, namely Multi-agent cooperative Large AI Models for Wireless Communications: MaLAM4Com. However, two key challenges in MaLAM4Com are how to effectively extract knowledge from shared information and how to alleviate the significant complexity arising from high-dimensional information sharing. To address these bottlenecks, we introduce federated distillation and Lyapunov cooperation to achieve robust knowledge transfer and consistent dynamic evolution, enabling the agents to capture the intrinsic structure of wireless channels. Subsequently, we innovatively utilize low-dimensional embeddings to facilitate information sharing among agents, significantly reducing cooperation complexity by up to 94% while enhancing privacy protection. This breaks traditional cooperative paradigms that rely on wireless channels. Moreover, we further introduce dataset distillation to enhance training efficiency by synthesizing elite data instead of directly utilizing raw datasets. Numerical results demonstrate that MaLAM4Com significantly outperforms existing baselines, with gains exceeding 45% under low sampling ratios. Remarkably, low-dimensional embeddings have also shown significant advantages in downstream tasks, reducing inference complexity by over 96%.

title: Feasibility of Phoswich Gamma Detector for Eliminating Background Radiation in Robotic Surgery
authors: Y. Park, K. Jeon, M. Park, H.K. Kim, K.M. Kim, K. Lee, H. Lee, J. Yeom
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In cancer surgery, sentinel lymph node biopsy to determine the presence of metastasis around the tumor has emerged as a critical technique in minimally invasive procedures. Although fluorescence-guided tumor resection is currently employed for this purpose, it has limitations, including a high local recurrence rate and difficulty in detecting deep-seated tumors. To address this, our research team is developing a gamma camera for robotic surgery capable of detecting deeply located metastatic lymph nodes. However, due to the structural constraint of the 12 mm diameter trocar used in surgical robots, it is difficult to incorporate lateral shielding components, making the system vulnerable to gamma rays entering from the sides and rear. To overcome this limitation, we previously proposed a shielding method based on a phoswich structure using BGO, which has a high stopping power, as a replacement for the conventional light guide. Building on this method, the present study investigates the effectiveness of BGO by comparing the shielding performance according to its thickness and shape, with the aim of identifying an optimal structural configuration. Three detector types were evaluated: the conventional cylindrical glass light guide design (C-Glass), and cylindrical and truncated cone-shaped BGO-based phoswich designs (C-BGO and T-BGO, respectively). Simulation results showed that the C-Glass detector was highly susceptible to lateral gamma radiation within the 90° to 170° angular range. In contrast, the BGO-based detector (C-BGO, T-BGO) rejected about 88% of the background gamma rays in the same range, demonstrating significantly improved shielding performance. Notably, the T-BGO exhibited slightly superior shielding capability compared to the C-BGO, and it was confirmed that a BGO thickness of at least 1.5T is required to achieve effective attenuation.

title: Semi-Supervised Semantic Segmentation of Radar Sounder Data with Scribble Annotations
authors: Milkisa T Yebasse, Lorenzo Bruzzone
publish: IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters
abstract: Automatic semantic segmentation of radar sounder data is a critical task for analyzing subsurface structures in planetary and terrestrial studies. In this context, one of the major issues for the development of deep learning models for semantic segmentation is the lack of labeled data, which affects the training of neural architectures. In this study, we propose a semi-supervised learning method that leverages scribble annotations, including points, diagonal lines, and polygons, alongside pseudo-labels generated from unlabeled data. To ensure the reliability of pseudo-labels, we propose selecting them based on confidence and spatial proximity constraints. To validate our method, we performed extensive experiments on terrestrial and planetary datasets. The results demonstrate that our approach consistently outperforms existing semi-supervised methods when trained on scribble annotations. In particular, the proposed method trained on diagonal scribbles yields the highest overall accuracy of 99.4% on the terrestrial dataset and 94.7% on the planetary dataset. These findings indicate that the proposed method achieves performance comparable to those of the fully supervised methods trained on dense annotations, while significantly reducing labeling costs.

title: Hierarchical Group-Based Task Migration for Multiplex Networked Industrial Chains Under Hybrid Dynamic Environments
authors: Kai Di, Tianyu Zuo, Xianghui Hu, Yichuan Jiang, Pan Li
publish: IEEE Transactions on Computational Social Systems
abstract: In recent years, industrial chain cooperation has evolved into multiplex network structures where product agents are linked through diverse types of interdependencies. While such architectures enhance coordination flexibility, resource-sharing efficiency, and system-level resilience, they also introduce complex hybrid dynamics. These dynamics emerge from fluctuating task demands, continuous changes in network topology as agents join or leave, and variations in production capacities across agents. Their interactions generate cascading cross-layer effects that disrupt load balance and challenge conventional scheduling and resource management strategies. This work addresses the resulting complexity by proposing the hierarchical grouped task migration (HGTM) algorithm, which migrates tasks in groups rather than individually. Leveraging its hierarchical design, HGTM enables effective multilevel load balancing throughout the multiplex structure while keeping computational overhead low. Comprehensive theoretical analysis and experiments show that HGTM enhances task completion rates, improves execution utility, and reduces completion costs. The approach exhibits strong robustness and adaptability, particularly under increasingly dynamic and highly coupled operating conditions.

title: “The Computer in Motion”: Symposium Report From the 27th International Congress of History of Science and Technology (ICHST)
authors: Ksenia Tatarchenko, Barbara Hof, Arianna Borrelli
publish: IEEE Annals of the History of Computing
abstract: From 29 June to 5 July 2025, the 27th International Congress of the History of Science and Technology (ICHST) was held in a hybrid format, both at the University of Otago in Dunedin, New Zealand (Figure 1), and online. The event brought together scholars from around the world under the overarching theme “Peoples, Places, Exchanges, and Circulations.” A dedicated local team brought the stimulating and diverse program to life, ensuring a smoothly run congress.1 Representing the DHST/DLMPST Commission on the History and Philosophy of Computing (HaPoC), the “Computer in Motion” symposium explored the congress theme through the contributions of twenty-four scholars from diverse countries and career stages. The initiative came from Barbara Hof (University of Lausanne) and Ksenia Tatarchenko (Johns Hopkins University), who were joined by Arianna Borrelli (c:o/re RWTH Aachen, Germany) as the HaPoC president.

title: Traversability-Aware Legged Navigation by Learning From Real-World Visual Data
authors: Hongbo Zhang, Zhongyu Li, Xuanqi Zeng, Laura Smith, Kyle Stachowicz, Dhruv Shah, Linzhu Yue, Zhitao Song, Weipeng Xia, Sergey Levine, Koushil Sreenath, Yun-hui Liu
abstract: The enhanced mobility brought by legged locomotion empowers quadrupedal robots to navigate through complex and unstructured environments. However, optimizing agile locomotion while accounting for the varying energy costs of traversing different terrains remains an open challenge. Most previous work focuses on planning trajectories with traversability cost estimation based on human-labeled environmental features. This human-centric approach is insufficient because it does not account for the varying capabilities of the robot locomotion controllers over challenging terrains. To address this, we introduce a novel real-world learning pipeline that unifies offline demonstrations, online reinforcement learning, and multi-modal perception to achieve robust legged navigation. The framework employs multiple training stages to develop a planner that guides the robot in avoiding obstacles and hardto- traverse terrains while reaching its goals. We first develop a novel traversability estimator in a robot-centric manner. The training of the navigation planner is directly performed in the real world using a sample efficient reinforcement learning method. With the proposed method, a quadrupedal robot learns to perform traversability-aware navigation through realworld interactions in diverse offroad and unstructured environments. Moreover, the robot demonstrates the ability to generalize the learned navigation skills to unseen scenarios.

title: TinyML-Enabled Resource-Efficient Framework for Real-Time Network Security in Electric Vehicle Charging Networks
authors: Fatemeh Dehrouyeh, Ibrahim Shaer, Soodeh Nikan, Firouz Badrkhani Ajaei, Abdallah Shami
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Electric Vehicle Charging Infrastructure (EVCI) faces critical cybersecurity challenges due to its integration with external networks, making it vulnerable to attacks such as malware propagation, session hijacking, and Denial-of-Service (DoS). Traditional machine learning (ML) models for intrusion detection are computationally intensive, making them unsuitable for resource-constrained Electric Vehicles (EVs). This paper presents a novel multi-stage framework that enables real-time intrusion detection through TinyML models. The proposed framework combines advanced feature selection (FS) using SHapley Additive exPlanations (SHAP) values with hybrid pruning techniques to create efficient, deployment-ready models. Using the CICEVSE2024 dataset, the paper demonstrates significant improvements across multiple architectures: Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) achieves 95.9% reduction in inference time and 80.7% reduction in model size while maintaining more than 94% accuracy; Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) shows 69% reduction in inference time and 79.2% size reduction with more than 94% accuracy; and Extreme Gradient Boosting (XGBoost) delivers 15.7% reduction in inference time and 91.2% reduction in size while preserving more than 98% accuracy. We further evaluate the models on a Raspberry Pi 5 (8 GB) and observe that although inference times increase on the resource-constrained device, the pruned models consistently maintain real-time performance, using the same models as on the desktop to ensure identical accuracies for a fair comparison. These results establish the feasibility of deploying TinyML-based intrusion detection systems (IDSs) directly on EVs, enabling robust real-time cybersecurity without exceeding hardware constraints.

title: PET-Guided CT Axial FOV Extension for Attenuation Correction in uMI Panorama GS
authors: C. Sun, M. Xue, L. Zhang, Y. Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: While whole-body CT provides complete attenuation correction (AC) enabling maximum sensitivity for long axial field-of-view (AFOV) PET scanners, its routine use is often unnecessary and incurs excessive radiation exposure in some clinical applications, e.g., cardiac MPI and brain studies. Existing CT-free AC methods aim to resolve this problem in total-body PET/CT, but their computational cost and limited generalizability across multi-tracer datasets hinder clinical adoption. To address this, we propose a deep learning framework that extends diagnostic CT coverage <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\sim 35 ~\text{cm})$</tex> to full-body <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(148 ~\text{cm})$</tex> for the uMI Panorama GS system, avoiding whole-CT scans while maintaining diagnostic accuracy. Validated on [<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">18</sup>F]-FDG/PSMA/Amyvid datasets, our method achieves near-perfect alignment (<1.5% NMAE) within diagnostic regions and clinically acceptable extrapolation (<6% NMAE) in extended FOVs, with reduced noise compared to truncated CT-based AC.

title: Electrical Switching Safe Operation Area on GaN Bidirectional Switches Under Hard-Switching Conditions by Multiple Pulse Test
authors: Guangyu Wang, Huiqing Wen, Lanbo Dai, Yi Zhu, Xu Han, Zhichen Feng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Device and Materials Reliability
abstract: Due to excellent material properties, unique bidirectional current flow ability during the conductive process, and ability to withstand bidirectional voltage when turned off, gallium nitride bidirectional switches (GaN-BIS) have recently been widely studied. However, due to the dynamic resistance degradation phenomenon under high-frequency hard-switching conditions, the long-term operational reliability and expected lifetime of GaN-BIS have not been fully explored. To fill this gap, this paper presents a pulse-switching characterization method for GaN-BIS that incorporates multi-mode testing under various DC bus voltages, including single-pulse (SP) mode, double-pulse (DP) mode, and multiple-pulse (MP) mode. A novel clamping circuit was adopted to ensure high testing accuracy and bidirectional voltage withstanding capability of GaN-BIS. The effect of gate driving mode on the dynamic resistance degradation of GaN-BIS was also experimentally studied. Based on the testing stress pattern and experimental results, the lifetime and safe operation area (SOA) of GaN-BIS were analyzed.

title: Effect of nitrate-containing compounds on the morphology of black chromium coatings
authors: Viktoriia Shtefan, Anastasiia Shcholokova, Nadiia Kanunnikova
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: This study investigates the effect of nitrate-containing additives on the morphology and elemental composition of black chromium coatings. The coatings were deposited on AISI 304 stainless steel substrates, which are widely used as a structural material in nuclear power applications, using the galvanostatic electrolysis method. The synthesized coatings were characterized by scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). The results showed that increasing the concentration of aluminum nitrate in the electrolyte led to a noticeable increase in the size of surface cracks in the coatings. Specifically, when aluminum nitrate was introduced while sodium nitrate was excluded from the electrolyte, the crack size increased by a factor of 12.5. The addition of aluminum nitrate also reduced the average crystallite size within the coating by a factor of 3.5 to 7. Despite this reduction, the presence of large crystallites (600–800 nm) was observed across all examined samples. A specimen formed in an electrolyte containing 0.1 mol/L aluminum nitrate without sodium nitrate exhibited larger crystallites compared to one formed in an electrolyte with the same aluminum nitrate concentration but with added sodium nitrate. The crystallite sizes were 250 nm and 100 nm, respectively. Elemental analysis confirmed that all coating samples were composed of chromium and oxygen, with no detectable aluminum. Based on EDX point analysis, the likely chemical formulas of chromium oxides in various oxidation states were calculated and correlated with specific points on the coating surface. These findings indicate that the coatings predominantly consist of heat-resistant and hard chromium (III) oxide, along with contributions from chromium (IV) oxide and mixed-valence chromium (II,III) oxide.

title: Effect of Motion Artifact Components on Brain Tumor Region Estimation Using Deep Learning
authors: M. Akanuma, K. Usui, R. Tsuchiya, E. Maehara, H. Sakamoto, S. Kyogoku, H. Daida
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) provides high contrast resolution and is used in treatment planning for Adaptive Radiation Therapy (ART). However, motion artifacts caused by patient movement can reduce the accuracy of tumor regions. If artificial intelligence can recognize tumor regions despite these artifacts, it may improve the efficiency of MRI-based ART. This study investigates the impact of motion artifact severity on brain tumor region estimation.

title: Method of Measuring Acoustic Resistance by Acousto-Magnetic Method for Application in Medicine
authors: Igor Bondarenko, Oleg Avrunin, Yana Nosova
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: Among the problems of diagnostics and treatment of pathologies there are tasks that can be solved using new methods of interaction of the biological substance with physical fields. This paper examines methods and devices for determining the acoustic resistance of local areas of a model biological substance using acoustomagnetic action on it.

title: Muscle Strength Monitoring System for Neuromuscular Disease Patients
authors: Ana María Rojas Galvis, María Fernanda Gómez Cubides, María Paula Cortés Ávila, Hernan Paz Penagos
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: This project presents the design and implementation of a low-cost muscle strength monitoring system aimed at supporting clinical evaluation and rehabilitation of patients with neuromuscular diseases. The system utilizes a load cell sensor and analog signal conditioning, including an instrumentation amplifier and an operational amplifier, to convert mechanical force into measurable electrical signals. Data acquisition is performed using an Arduino board, enabling real-time visualization and analysis. The proposed solution enhances the objectivity and accuracy of muscular strength assessment, contributing to the development of more effective rehabilitation plans and improving patients' quality of life.

title: Development of a Methodology for Assessing the Effectiveness of a Frequency-Dependent Device for the Suppression of Switching and Lightning Overvoltages
authors: Sergey Korobeynikov, Valentin Loman, Alexander Ridel, Dmitriy Vedernikov, Nikita Sergeev
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The increasing share of wind power generation in the energy system highlights the growing importance of ensuring the reliability of wind farm equipment. This equipment is particularly threatened by lightning overvoltages with a high front steepness. Traditional protection means based on surge arresters are not always effective in suppressing the high-frequency components of such pulses. This article investigates the effectiveness of using a Frequency-Dependent Device for protecting wind power facilities. Full-scale experiments were conducted on a specially developed setup generating short pulses that simulate the impact of lightning overvoltages. The methodology involved recording pulse parameters at the input and output of the Frequency-Dependent Device, followed by computer modeling in the MATLAB Simulink environment to verify the results and evaluate the device's active resistance. The results demonstrate the high effectiveness of the Frequency-Dependent Device in reducing the front steepness and amplitude of high-frequency pulses (with frequencies above 200 kHz), with the device’s efficiency increasing as the frequency of the impacting signal rises.

title: Nonlinear Trajectory Tracking of Unmanned Vehicle Climbing Based on Model-Free Adaptive Control
authors: Yunhui Zhou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Aiming at the nonlinear trajectory tracking control in unmanned vehicle climbing scenarios, this paper proposes a scheme of the model-free adaptive control based on compact format dynamic linearization. Firstly, the pseudo-partial derivative is used to estimate the height dynamic characteristics in real time. On this basis, the anti-interference parameter update mechanism and the control law with dynamic constraints are designed, and the tracking accuracy and input change are balanced by weight factors. In addition, the closed-loop stability and error convergence of the system at a constant desired height are proved. Simulation experiments verify the robust adaptability of the proposed scheme under network disturbance.

title: Research Progress on Fullerenes and Their Derivatives in Electron Transport Layers of Tin-Based Perovskite Solar Cells
authors: Ninghai Deng
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Semiconductor Devices and Integration Technology (ASDIT)
abstract: Tin-based perovskite solar cells (TPSCs) represent a highly promising new generation of photovoltaic devices that have garnered extensive research in recent years. TPSCs offer advantages such as high theoretical limits, relatively simple fabrication processes, abundant raw material sources, and the potential for flexible device fabrication. However, their actual efficiency remains significantly below theoretical limits. To enhance the photovoltaic conversion efficiency (PCE), optimization of the absorber layer material is essential, and improvements to the electron transport layer (ETL)—a critical functional layer—are also necessary. ETLs demand excellent electron extraction and transport capabilities. Fullerene-based materials possess exceptionally high electron mobility, favorable electron affinity, and outstanding thermal stability. Furthermore, they can be further optimized through chemical modification, making them highly promising ETL candidates. Here, we summarize the general properties of fullerene-based materials and compile recent reports on their application as ETLs in TPSCs, following with an analysis of current challenges and potential future development directions, as well as a conclusion.

title: A Multi-Source Heterogeneous Shared Data Storage Framework for Multi-Entity Media Convergence
authors: Jing Gui, Yongbin Wang, WeiJian Fan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: With the acceleration of media convergence, media production and dissemination models are transitioning from single-medium approaches to multi-entity, multi-channel, and cross-platform collaborative paradigms. Current data sharing among multiple media entities faces challenges including storage fragmentation, multi-source heterogeneous data integration, and small-file storage bottlenecks. To address these challenges, this paper proposes a multi-source heterogeneous shared data storage framework specifically designed for multi-entity convergence. For the characteristic multi-source heterogeneity of shared data, we develop a multi-dimensional decision-making-based classification model to achieve adaptive storage optimization. To resolve small files storage performance bottlenecks, we implement small files consolidation combined with a metadata indexing method based on minimal perfect hashing. Experimental results demonstrate that the framework effectively enables cross-entity data sharing while improving memory utilization and reducing average read latency.

title: A Configuration-Driven Fault Injection Tool for Automated Testing of Satellite Software
authors: Yu Hong, Yuan Li, Zhijian You
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Traditional fault injection methods for satellite software testing are often inefficient, inflexible, and hardware-dependent. This paper proposes a novel configuration-driven tool with a “protocol-data separation” architecture to automate this process. The tool is implemented using a four-layer model and a cross-platform PyQt5 GUI. It leverages a protocol framework to automatically generate test cases and inject faults via UDP communication with a virtual satellite platform. Compared to manual script writing, the proposed method significantly reduces preparation time, improves test efficiency and coverage, and supports parallel testing, thereby enhancing the overall satellite software verification process.

title: The Research and Simulation Verification of the Link Quality Prediction Model for Free Space Optical Communication Based on BiGRU-FCNN
authors: Yu She, YiFeng Zhu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Free-Space Optical Communication (FSOC) has gained significant attention in integrated air-ground networks due to its advantages, such as high bandwidth, low latency, and spectrum license-free operation. However, its link quality is highly susceptible to atmospheric turbulence, rain and fog attenuation, and pointing errors, leading to significant fluctuations and posing challenges for dynamic routing and power control. To enhance network robustness, this paper proposes an end-to-end Bidirectional Gated Recurrent Unit-Fully Connected Neural Network (BiGRU-FCNN) prediction framework. The framework first employs Bidirectional GRU (Gated Recurrent Unit) to capture the sequential dependencies in both the forward and backward directions. It then extracts local-global correlated features through multi-scale 1D convolutions in parallel. Additionally, the remaining power of the optical terminal is integrated, and the link is classified into Bad, Marginal, or Good levels via a fully connected layer. Compared to traditional machine learning methods such as Support Vector Machine (SVM) and deep learning approaches like Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM), the average prediction accuracy is improved to $89 \%$. The results indicate that the proposed framework provides stable and accurate link quality predictions, offering reliable decision-making support for real-time routing reconstruction and power adaptive control.

title: Angular-Domain Power Distribution Control for BPSK/QPSK MIMO Radars
authors: Yury M. Meleshin
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Multiple-Input Multiple-Output (MIMO) radar systems are often employed for parallel target detection across a wide operational sector. However, such modes inherently result in uniform spatial power distribution, which limits efficiency when operating with a priori information about the target’s direction. Additionally, there is active development of MIMO radars utilizing simple modulation schemes such as Binary Phase-Shift Keying (BPSK) and Quadrature Phase-Shift Keying (QPSK), which significantly simplify radar architecture. This work proposes an extension of existing methods for angular-domain power distribution control in MIMO radars using Zadoff–Chu sequences, adapted for BPSK/QPSK-based MIMO radar systems, and develops a power distribution control algorithm accounting for constraints inherent to such systems. The paper presents the development stages, algorithm description, and results of its mathematical modeling. It is demonstrated that, for the considered BPSK/QPSK MIMO radar (16/32 Tx), an energy gain of approximately 2-5 dB can be achieved solely through the application of the proposed algorithm. This will increase the signal-to-noise ratio of signals during digital signal processing in operating modes with target direction information.
