title: Cluster job resource demand prediction method based on Transformer-Ekan
authors: Shaobin Geng, Tao Zhang, Shixin Xu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: In the job scheduling system of distributed computing clusters, accurate prediction of job execution resources is the core element to optimise scheduling efficiency. The current machine learning prediction methods for general-purpose cluster jobs still need to be improved in terms of prediction accuracy and practical application effect. In this paper, we innovatively propose a method combining cluster analysis and deep learning: firstly, we extract job type features by clustering historical job logs; then, we introduce the Transformer-Ekan model based on the attention mechanism, and select seven key dimensional features (based on the criteria of prediction relevance, data completeness and validity) to construct the prediction model. A time-series training strategy is adopted to process jobs hierarchically by continuous resources, which significantly improves the prediction accuracy. The experimental results show that the temporal neural network model outperforms traditional machine learning methods and BP neural networks on different types of job datasets, effectively improving the cluster resource utilisation and job scheduling accuracy.

title: Dialect-Adaptive Conformer Model: Application of Dynamic Parameter Adjustment in Multidialect Speech Recognition
authors: Ying Zhang, Boyi Duan, Jiahao Hui, Xuan Tong
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Computer Science and Network Technology (ICCSNT)
abstract: In response to the challenges of significant dialectal acoustic diversity and the uneven distribution of low-resource data, which limit the model’s generalization ability in multi-dialect speech recognition, this paper proposes a Dialect-Adaptive Conformer, DA-Conformer. By introducing a conditional parameter generation mechanism and a multigranularity feature interaction strategy, the model achieves dialect adaptation at both local feature extraction and global dependency modeling levels, enabling effective dialectal acoustic modeling. Dialect embedding vectors are utilized to guide the generation of frequency-domain sensitive convolution kernels, enhancing the ability to extract dialect-specific local features such as tone and plosive sounds. Additionally, a learnable bias matrix is introduced to correct attention weight distributions, strengthening the modeling of tonal boundaries and continuous pitch variation regions. Experiments were conducted on the Nexdata Chinese-dialect dataset (2500 hours), covering multiple Chinese dialects, as well as a self-built multidialect set (ZDialect, 120 hours). The results show that the average word error rate (WER) of the DA-Conformer is 14.5% persent, which is a reduction of 33.2% and 20.8% compared to Conformer-Base and UniSpeech-SAT-D, respectively. Ablation experiments further reveal that the dynamic convolution module and dialect-conditioned attention contribute 17.9% and 9.9% of the WER improvement, respectively.

title: AI-Based Primary Schools Teachers' Professional Competency Assessment Tool
authors: Vera Yuli Erviana, Wahyu Nanda Eka Saputra, Fajar Oktavia Rahma
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: In the era of Industrial Revolution 5.0 and digital transformation, Artificial Intelligence (AI) is known to play a crucial role in improving the effectiveness and efficiency of education, specifically in public and private elementary schools where teachers greatly influenced students' learning experiences. Therefore, the present research focused on developing an assessment tool to measure teachers' performance driven by AI. Professional competency centered on three dimensions, technical, pedagogical, and ethical. The use of a quantitative method was due to the presence of 150 elementary teachers from public and private schools in Yogyakarta, selected through cluster random sampling. The data acquired through a 10-item Likert scale questionnaire, was validated through expert review and field testing. The Rasch model was used to explore item suitability, difficulty level, and reliability. Additionally, the results obtained showed that the instrument was valid and reliable. This served as a useful tool to assess teachers' readiness and identify professional development needs. The novelty of the present research focused on the integration of AI in elementary education, addressing unique challenges and opportunities, especially in developing countries.

title: A Robust, Scalable Small-Signal Model for InP HEMTs
authors: Zijian Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: This paper presents a robust and scalable smallsignal modeling methodology for Indium Phosphide (InP) High-Electron-Mobility Transistors (HEMTs) for millimeterwave applications. The proposed approach integrates topologyindependent extrinsic parameter extraction via electromagnetic (EM) simulation with a novel hybrid analytical-optimization technique for intrinsic parameter determination. This method overcomes the limitations of traditional models, particularly in terms of noise robustness and geometric scalability. We validate the model through comprehensive experiments, demonstrating exceptional accuracy ($E|S|\lt 0.05$), unconditional stability ($\mu \approx 1.5$), and superior resilience to measurement noise, improving extraction robustness by over $40 \%$ compared to conventional analytical methods.

title: Tiered Architecture for Mission Planning Algorithm Framework of Mega Remote Sensing Constellation
authors: Hongliang Yang, Chang Liu, Donglei Yan, Haoyi Chen, Yan Bin Chen, Yue Gao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Focus on giant remote sensing constellation and massive mission planning problem, we proposed a 3-Tier Architecture that manages complex systems through a hierarchical model. The Architecture includes global mission optimization, local task planning, and specific satellite action scheduling. Each tier employs a facade pattern and interacts with others through unified service interfaces. A test data set was given Based on the Walker constellation model and targets selected from GADM. The results validate the feasibility of the tiered mission planning framework with the overall orderliness and scalability.

title: Research on Improved FMEA Based on Dynamic Social Network Opinion Evolution Model
authors: Lanbing Gan, Jia Huang, Mingshun Song, Mingyu Hu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: To address the deficiencies of the traditional failure mode and effect analysis (FMEA) methods, an improved FMEA method based on the dynamic social network opinion evolution model is proposed. First, the probabilistic language preference relation is used to describe expert evaluation information. Second, the concepts of group pressure and recency effect are incorporated, and a new trust relationship evolution formula is proposed. The consensus evolution of expert opinions is achieved by combining the trust relationship evolution method with the DeGroot opinion evolution model, leading the expert group to reach a consensus state. Finally, the expected risk values of each failure mode are calculated, allowing for the ranking of failure modes and the determination of risk priority results. Additionally, the improved FMEA model is applied to a risk assessment case in the blood transfusion process of the medical system, demonstrating the validity and reliability of the model.

title: Research on Cooperative Operation Technology of Unmanned Aerial Vehicle and Unmanned Tractor for Agricultural Applications
authors: Wei Li, Dekui Lv, Jie Fan, Da Huo, Jiawei Wen, Liang Liu, Yongyue Hu, Yishun Yu, Weiming Liu, Qiang Sheng, Zhaolong Zhang, Zhongxin Fan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: The rapid advancement of smart agriculture demands efficient unmanned solutions that integrate aerial perception with ground-level execution. While unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and unmanned ground vehicles (UGVs) have been widely studied independently, their cooperative potential remains underexplored. This paper proposes a UAV–UGV collaborative operation framework designed for agricultural applications. The UAV employs the LeGO-LOAM algorithm to construct an environmental map and generates an optimal trajectory between task-defined start and end points using the A* algorithm. The planned path is converted into GPS waypoints and transmitted to the UGV via robot operating system distributed topic communication. The UGV then performs path tracking through a pure pursuit control strategy. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, the Ackermann steering model is adopted to approximate vehicle kinematics. Results demonstrate that the integration of UAV-based aerial mapping with UGV-based ground execution enables accurate trajectory tracking and efficient task completion, highlighting the potential of UAV–UGV collaboration for advancing agricultural unmanned operations.

title: Combining Graph Neural Network with Attention Mechanism in Sequence-Based Music Recommendation System
authors: Rama Aulia Gemilang, Agung Toto Wibowo
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: Music recommendations have become an important part of everyday life. With the abundance of music available, it is becoming increasingly difficult to find suitable music content. To address this issue, recommendation systems have emerged as a solution to personalize song suggestions for users. Traditional recommendation systems often fail to capture sequential patterns of user interaction. To understand these patterns, recommendation systems are based on a sequential approach. However, traditional sequential recommendation system models do not sufficiently capture dependencies on long-term temporal patterns. In this study, we apply a combination of Graph Neural Network (GNN) with attention mechanisms to the Music4All dataset to address sequential music recommendations. This approach, which adapts the Graph-based Attentive Sequential model with Metadata (GASM), This model was applied for the first time to this music dataset, which has a wider diversity and distribution of users and can provide new insights into the effectiveness of this model. GNN capture the relationships between users and items, as well as between items themselves, while the attention mechanism captures user interest patterns over time within a session. We also incorporate long-term and dynamic preferences to enrich the context of user preferences. By applying this model to the Music4All dataset, the model can recommend the next music track with a Hit Ratio (HR) evaluation ranging from 32.69 to 49.16 and a Mean Reciprocal Rank (MRR) ranging from 23.34 to 30.71. These results show that our approach can effectively capture sequential patterns in music in large-scale datasets.

title: DARE-Gaze: Dual-Stage Adaptive Reconstruction and Feature Reorganization for Generalizable Gaze Estimation
authors: Gehang Huang, Suguo Zhu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Gaze estimation faces significant challenges in adapting to diverse eye morphologies, viewing conditions, and individual variations. Existing methods typically apply feature extraction directly to raw images, often struggling with suboptimal input quality and inefficient feature organization for gaze-specific tasks. To address these limitations, we propose DAREGaze, a novel dual-stage optimization architecture that enhances gaze-relevant information at both image and feature levels. Our approach consists of two key components: STARE (Spatial Transformation with Adaptive Rectangular Enhancement), a front-end adaptive image enhancement module, and PRISM (Perceptual Refinement through Integrated Similarity Mapping), a back-end feature reorganization module. STARE employs attention-guided rectangular sampling to adaptively reconstruct features based on eye structure characteristics, functioning as a sophisticated feature reconstructor. PRISM introduces a high-similarity feature reorganization network that identifies and preserves only the most relevant feature connections through soft thresholding operations. Extensive experiments demonstrate that DARE-Gaze achieves state-of-the-art performance across multiple cross-dataset tasks. Our method provides a new paradigm for gaze estimation through targeted optimization at different processing stages, offering both enhanced accuracy and improved adaptability to diverse scenarios.

title: Host Terminal Local Area Network Malicious Traffic Security Detection Integrating IPSO and LSTM
authors: Xiaolei Liu, Yang Yang, Lei Feng, Jinqiang Fan, Xizhi Li, Zhiqi Gu, Jifu Qiu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: In host terminal local area network traffic preprocessing, only simple traffic splitting is performed, resulting in low detection accuracy. Therefore, a host terminal local area network malicious traffic security detection method integrating IPSO and LSTM is proposed. The preprocessing stage includes traffic splitting, desensitization, cleansing, and multidimensional data vector generation. Improved encoding conversion and information gain-based dimensionality reduction methods are employed. For feature extraction, the LSTM model is optimized by combining IPSO, integrating local correlation and dynamic evolution characteristics, and introducing a correlation analysis module. Key vectors are input into the domain discrimination module, constructing a weighted composite loss function to address traffic class imbalance. A malicious traffic feature capture module is constructed, and finally, a detection mechanism is constructed using the captured patterns to achieve secure detection of malicious traffic in host terminal local area networks. Experimental results show that the designed method only increases the false alarm rate from $2.0 \%$ to $4.0 \%$, and can accurately distinguish between normal and malicious traffic. With the increase of malicious cache entries, the F1 score decreases minimally from 0.85 to 0.77, demonstrating its significant advantage in detection accuracy.

title: Humans Do Matter: Unpacking Facilitators’ Role in Technology Entrepreneurship Education
authors: Averina Nicole Sanjaya, Syafa Alizha, Helen Calista, Ari Margiono
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: In today’s era of technological disruption, there is a growing debate about whether humans will play a diminished role in helping students learn. In many schools, Artificial Intelligence has been deployed to help students learning complex subjects, e.g., via the introduction of AI tutors. This study found that human facilitators still play a pivotal role beyond content delivery, serving as the link between technical proficiency and entrepreneurial problem-solving among students who learn technology entrepreneurship subjects. This study investigates the extent to which facilitator involvement mediates the relationship between active learning strategies (Project-based learning and Problem-based learning) and academic performance, while also accounting for the influence of students’ prior knowledge. Grounded in constructivist learning and scaffolding theories, the study analyzes survey data from undergraduate students at a private university in Indonesia using Partial Least Squares Structural Equation Modeling (PLS-SEM). Results show that targeted facilitator support significantly enhances academic achievement and strengthens the indirect effects of project-based learning and problem-based learning on performance. Additionally, prior knowledge positively influences outcomes when paired with explicit instructional guidance. These findings underscore the importance of facilitator training and instructional design, and thus human-technology collaborations, that align active learning methods with students’ cognitive readiness, offering practical insights for improving technopreneurship education

title: A Lightweight Deep Learning-based Network for Partial Response CPM Detection
authors: Yiren Chen, Ning Cao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Continuous phase modulation (CPM) is a bandwidth-efficient signaling scheme due to its constant envelope and spectral efficiency. However, the optimal maximum-likelihood sequence detection (MLSD) for partial response CPM suffers from high computational complexity. To address this issue, this paper proposes a lightweight deep learning-based network designed to achieve a favorable trade-off between performance and complexity. Simulation results show that the proposed network achieves a considerable reduction in computational complexity, measured by floating-point operations (FLOPs), while maintaining competitive bit error rate (BER) performance compared to the MLSD benchmark.

title: A New Laminated Structure of MIM Capacitor with Low Capacitance Density Based on Semiconductor standard advanced process
authors: Xiaowei Chang, Dejin Wang, Xiaofeng Sun, Huihui Wu, Enhao Zhao, Fan Ye, Zhengyu Lin
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Semiconductor Devices and Integration Technology (ASDIT)
abstract: MIM capacitors are widely used in electronic circuit systems and integrated circuits because of their good quality factor, low parasitic capacitance, high capacitance accuracy, and low leakage. In this paper, a new laminated structure of MIM capacitor is designed by adding silicon oxide above and below the dielectric layer of traditional structure based on Semiconductor standard advanced process. Under the same size and area, the breakdown voltage is improved by 19%, the leakage current is reduced by 10%, and the reliability lifetime is increased by 409 times, which has a great application prospect.

title: Fault Association Semantic Diagnosis Method for Substation Equipment Combining GCN and BERT
authors: Wenhua Ouyang, Chao Tong, Fan Li, Yucong Mei, Zhiwei Xiong
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Fault diagnosis of substation equipment requires simultaneous processing of textual semantics and structured relational data. This paper proposes a fault association semantic diagnosis method that integrates GCN and BERT. BERT is used to encode semantic features of fault texts, while GCN is employed to model the topological structure of equipment associations. A joint training mechanism is designed to fuse semantic and graph-structure features. Experimental results show that this method outperforms traditional models in fault classification accuracy and association diagnosis performance, providing a more accurate and intelligent solution for fault diagnosis in power systems.

title: Design of Anisotropic Potentials and their Application to UAV Swarm Control
authors: Pavel A. Chertovskikh, Alexey A. Druzhinin, Andrey M. Boiko
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The concept of anisotropic potentials for modeling elongated particles is a well-established approach in molecular dynamics. The Gay-Berne model, introduced in 1981, serves as a prime example. This model describes orientation-dependent interactions between ellipsoidal particles and has been widely utilized in liquid crystal simulations, demonstrating the efficacy of such potentials in self-organizing systems. However, this paper adapts the potential-particle paradigm to unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) swarm control, where traditional control algorithms often struggle with scalability, environmental adaptability, and collision avoidance. Emerging decentralized control algorithms address these issues by leveraging potentials. In this context, the design of potentials is driven by swarm behavioral requirements, enabling new design approaches. We propose a new method for designing anisotropic potentials that offers a simple and flexible approach. As a demonstration, we construct a simple elliptical potential. Simulations of a system consisting of seven elliptical particles reveal stable swarm formations, a steady decline in fluctuations, and robust collision avoidance, thus validating the method’s practical applicability.

title: Software Visual Accessibility: Automated Compliance Testing for Color-Vision Deficiencies
authors: Volodymyr Savchenko, Oksana Mnushka, Sofiia Riabovolenko
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: This paper presents the results of a study on the feasibility of automatically testing software for compliance with accessibility standards. Such testing is typically performed during the functional testing phase. The relevance of this work stems from the need to ensure that a software’s visual elements adhere to accessibility guidelines, including those for users with color vision deficiencies. We analyze the problem, propose a mathematical model for evaluating images against accessibility criteria, and present a methodology for automatic testing using computer vision libraries (OpenCV). We also report the results of testing a prototype tool designed to assess visual elements for color vision impairments. Finally, we discuss how these results can be integrated into continuous integration (CI) systems to automatically detect potential accessibility issues.

title: CAMIL-A Class Activation Mapping Integrated with MIL-Attention
authors: David Córdoba-Vargas, Fabian Cano, Javier Revelo-Fuelagán, Eduardo Romero
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Gastric cancer shows high incidence and diagnostic variability in southwestern Colombia, hindering effective prognostic stratification. This work proposes CAMIL-A, a method that combines image-level attention maps with patch-level activation maps to identify regions within whole-slide images (WSIs) associated with clinical outcomes. The model uses deep representations extracted from patches selected based on high tissue content, which are processed through a multilayer perceptron trained with case-level survival labels. The attention weights identify the most relevant patches globally, while Grad-CAM highlights local features within each patch. By combining both signals, a weighted attention map is generated that emphasizes the most informative morphological regions. CAMIL-A achieved an F1-score of 0.857 and a concordance index (C-index) of 0.879, and its attention scores showed significant associations in a multivariate Cox regression analysis, providing a visual and quantitative tool to support clinical prognosis.

title: Machine Learning-Driven ROI Prediction Framework for Micro and Macro Influencer Marketing in Indonesian Food SMEs
authors: Sabar Aritonang Rajagukguk
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: This research develops a comprehensive machine learning framework to predict return on investment (ROI) for micro versus macro influencer marketing campaigns in Indonesian food small and medium enterprises (SMEs). With 76% of Indonesian users following at least one influencer and 68% having purchased items based on influencer recommendations, the Indonesian market presents significant opportunities for effective influencer marketing strategies. This study employed Random Forest, XGBoost, and Neural Networks to analyze 1,000 influencer campaigns from 300 Indonesian food SMEs collected between 2023-2024. Feature engineering incorporated engagement metrics, content characteristics, timing variables, and economic factors to predict ROI, sales conversion rates, and brand awareness lift. Results demonstrate that XGBoost achieved 82% accuracy in ROI prediction, with micro influencers showing optimal performance for budgets under $500, achieving an average ROI of 312% compared to macro influencers. The analysis reveals a performance sweet spot at 50,000-100,000 followers for balanced reach and engagement, yielding 245% ROI. Content authenticity and food aesthetics emerged as the strongest predictors with feature importance scores of 0.31 and 0.28 respectively. This framework provides actionable insights for SME budget allocation and influencer selection strategies in the rapidly evolving Indonesian digital marketing landscape.

title: Deep learning for Chagas disease: YOLOv8-based automatic detection of amastigote nests
authors: Daniela Sosa, Blanca Vázquez, Nidiyare Hevia-Montiel
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Chagas disease, caused by the Trypanosoma cruzi parasite, remains a global public health problem, with cases reported even outside its traditional endemic areas. Its primary clinical manifestation occurs at the cardiac level, characterized by the formation of amastigote nests. This work presents a deep learning algorithm for automatic detection of amastigote nests in cardiac histopathological images obtained from a murine model. For the nests’ detection, a YOLOv8-based architecture was trained on histological images performing a 5-fold cross-validation, while the final tests were carried out with data unseen by the YOLOv8 from four image groups of different post-infection days. In training stage, YOLOv8 achieved 97.9% in accuracy, 98.6±0.3% in precision, and 97.2±0.8% in recall, while in the final test, the best result identified was 78.6% in accuracy, 76.4% in precision, and 81.1% in recall on images at 100× magnification. These metrics reveal the model’s ability to generalize well and its high sensitivity to unseen data. The results of this study show that the proposed algorithm is capable of identifying amastigote nests, which may be useful in clinical areas to understand the damage caused by Trypanosoma cruzi infection.

title: Self-Supervised Labeling for IoT-Based Noisiness Assessment in Hospitals with PSO-K-Means Clustering and Spectral Flatness
authors: Nadya Widdy Astuti, Aji Gautama Putrada, Ryan Lingga Wicaksono
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: Several IoT systems for hospital noise assessment have released sound data for analysis. However, the challenge is to label sounds manually, so an optimum self-supervised method for labeling is a research opportunity. This study aims to use spectral flatness to assess noise in IoT-based hospital environments by applying the particle swarm optimization (PSO) method with a k-means clustering algorithm for unsupervised labeling. The process begins by collecting a hospital ambient noise dataset from Kaggle. The audio data undergoes preprocessing steps, including frame cropping, filtering, and normalization. Key spectral features—spectral flatness, Root Mean Square Energy (RMSE), and signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) are then extracted. PSO-K-means is subsequently applied to classify noise patterns based on their spectral characteristics. Finally, a system integration plan is developed to embed this method and conduct a hospital noise assessment. The use of PSO k-means with 100 particles and 40 iterations yielded three optimal metrics: RMSE, spectral flatness, and a cluster number of 3, along with a silhouette score of 0.54. This value is greater than the elbow method, which obtained the number of clusters of 6 and a silhouette score of 0.22 using five metrics. Through the chosen metrics and cluster numbers, we can analyze aspects of loudness, the presence of noise, and the differentiation of tone-like and noise-like sounds. The three clusters in the hospital’s ambient sound have very different characteristics, which leads to the conclusion that the hospital we assessed has noise levels above normal and requires special treatment.

title: 3D Brain Imaging Using a Rotating Flat-Panel PET Scanner with LYSO/SiPM-Based Detectors
authors: A. Shahi, B. Komarov, B. Baldassi, F. Dodgson, E. De Benetti, H. Poladyan, E. Anashkin, U. Metser, A. Reznik, O. Bubon
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Organ-targeted PET scanners offer improved spatial resolution, system sensitivity, and costefficiency compared to whole-body systems, and have shown promise especially in imaging breast cancer and Alzheimer's disease. While flat-panel scanners have enabled precise imaging of breast cancer lesions, their use in 3D brain imaging is constrained by the degraded axial spatial resolution due to incomplete angular coverage. Here, we present the first 3D image reconstructions of the Hoffman brain phantom acquired with a versatile LYSO/SiPM-based flat-panel PET scanner. We overcome the challenge of incomplete angular coverage by combining multi-angle acquisitions and performing composite image reconstructions.

title: A Novel Lightweight Deep Learning Algorithm Based on Attention Mechanisms for Gesture Recognition Using WiFi Signals
authors: Jiacheng Li, Yuanhang Hu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Human Activity Recognition (HAR) underpins applications in smart homes, healthcare, and human–computer interaction. Conventional video- and sensor-based systems face privacy, environmental, and usability constraints, motivating the use of WiFi sensing as a ubiquitous, robust, and cost-effective alternative. We present a lightweight deep learning model for WiFi-based gesture recognition that integrates the Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) into the InceptionTime framework. By jointly applying channel and spatial attention, CBAM enhances discriminative feature extraction with minimal overhead, while depthwise separable convolutions mitigate added complexity and reduce overfitting. Cosine annealing and L2 regularization further stabilize training and improve generalization. Evaluated on the ARIL dataset, the model achieves 97.12% accuracy while substantially lowering parameter count, training time, and inference latency. These results establish an efficient and robust approach to WiFi-based gesture recognition, offering strong potential for scalable deployment in smart environments.

title: Analyzing the Impact of AI Integration on Student Learning Performance: A Within-Class Meta-Analysis Moderated by AI Usage Duration
authors: Yulias Prihatmoko, Henry Praherdhiono, Nunung Nindigraha, Kevin Herdinata Cahyadi Firdaus, Deka Dyah Utami
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) integration in higher education has shown promising potential, yet empirical findings on its actual contribution to student learning performance remain inconsistent. Most existing studies focus on comparing AI-supported and non-AI-supported instruction, while little attention has been given to variations within the same learning context. This study aims to analyze the impact of AI integration on student performance using a within-class meta-analytic design, with particular attention to the moderating role of AI usage duration. Data were collected from 135 undergraduate students enrolled in an Educational Technology program who experienced uniform AI-based instructional interventions. Statistical analyses included Welch’s ANOVA and linear regression to examine whether weekly AI usage hours predicted academic outcomes. Results indicated no significant differences in performance across AI usage groups (p > 0.05), and duration of use was not a significant predictor of final grades. However, descriptive findings revealed high engagement with AI tools such as ChatGPT, Gemini, and Canva, primarily for summarizing readings, retrieving references, and answering content-related questions. These findings suggest that the quality of AI integration into learning design is more critical than the duration of usage. The study contributes to theory by highlighting the role of AI as cognitive support rather than performance determinant and provides practical implications for educators to focus on meaningful AI-based instructional design.

title: Neural Network Learning of Decision-Making Management Algorithms in Non-Invasive Smart Devices for Cardiovascular System Diagnostics
authors: Serhii Holdobin, Valeria Baranova, Vadym Tiutiunyk, Iryna Pyavar, Dmytro Pecherytsia, Mykhailo Zhyhalov
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: Cardiovascular diseases (CVDs) are the leading cause of death globally, necessitating the development of efficient and interpretable diagnostic tools for real-time and out-of-hospital monitoring. This paper presents a hybrid neural network model that integrates clinical diagnostic logic directly into its architecture to enhance explainability and accuracy. A formalized algorithm based on biosignals — such as electrocardiography (ECG), photoplethysmography (PPG), and heart rate variability (HRV)—was developed to emulate expert decision-making. The algorithm was embedded into a Rule Injection Layer (RIL), enabling the network to combine expert knowledge with data-driven learning. Experiments using synthetic and real datasets demonstrate high diagnostic performance (up to 97.1% accuracy) and robustness under varying signal conditions. The model is optimized for deployment in low-power embedded systems, providing a reliable solution for non-invasive CVD monitoring with interpretable outputs. Explainability is further supported using the LIME framework, which highlights feature contributions for clinical validation.

title: Modeling and Analysis of Multifrequency Piezoresonant Oscillatory Systems under Vibrational Destabilization
authors: Kostyantyn Horiashchenko, Serhiy Horiashchenko, Viktor Stetsiuk, Andrii Mazur, Pavlenko Volodymyr, Viacheslav Kharzhevskyi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: This paper presents an analysis of mathematical and numerical models describing multifrequency piezoresonant oscillatory systems. Multifrequency excitation is a fundamental physical property of quartz resonators, arising from anisotropic elastic coupling. However, in the context of highly stable self-oscillatory systems used as reference frequency sources, this property is generally undesirable and often mitigated through design and manufacturing constraints. A critical review of existing mathematical models reveals that none can comprehensively describe the dynamics of piezoresonant systems subjected to vibrational destabilizing influences. To address this limitation, a new modeling approach is proposed, incorporating nonlinearities, environmental disturbances, and discrete boundary constraints. The model is validated through simulations in COMSOL Multiphysics and SolidWorks, using a piezoceramic disk mounted on four supports. Simulation results confirm the presence of multiple closely spaced resonant modes and demonstrate the sensitivity of system dynamics to mechanical stress and excitation conditions.

title: Using Diffusion Transformers to Generate Synthetic Diffusion Scalar Maps for Data Augmentation
authors: Tamoghna Chattopadhyay, Chirag Jagad, Pavithra Senthilkumar, Sophia I. Thomopoulos, Julio E. Villalón-Reina, Paul M. Thompson
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Generation of high-quality synthetic brain MRI data could be beneficial for advancing neuroimaging research, particularly when access to large-scale, labeled datasets is limited. In this work, we leverage a pretrained Diffusion Transformer (DiT) architecture to synthesize 3D mean diffusivity (MD) scalar maps from the Cam-Can dataset. To adapt the DiT model—originally trained on 2D natural images—for 3D neuroimaging data, we implemented a preprocessing strategy that tiles 2D slices from 3D volumes into composite 2D images, enabling effective finetuning. The quality of the generated synthetic images was evaluated using Multi-Scale Structural Similarity (MS-SSIM) and Maximum Mean Discrepancy (MMD) metrics, demonstrating high fidelity and anatomical coherence. To assess the utility of synthetic data in downstream tasks, we conducted transfer learning experiments for dementia classification on the ADNI dataset. A sex classification model, trained on both real and synthetic Cam-Can data, was repurposed for this task, showing that synthetic samples can enhance model performance. These results highlight the potential of diffusion-based generative models for augmenting neuroimaging datasets and supporting clinical applications.

title: Laser-Microstructured Hexagonal Detectors for High-Sensitivity Quasi-Spherical Brain PET
authors: D. Perez-Benito, L. Batres, M. Vidal, J. J. Vaquero
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Sensitivity is a key parameter in positron emission tomography (PET), in efforts to minimize the administered radiotracer dose and scanning time. Common segmented detectors have dead space between crystals that reduces the detector's overall sensitivity. A solution to this issue involves the technique of subsurface laser engraving that creates optical barriers. In the context of the development of a high sensitivity quasi-spherical brain PET, this work presents the results of a flexible engraving method offering versatility in the exploration of non-conventional geometries. The method is optimized so that it completes a detector fabrication within a few hours. The brain PET features an innovative geometry that maximizes the solid angle around the subject thanks to its regular, uniform hexagonal LYSO scintillation elements, each with 17.6 mm edge and 13 mm thick. The detector modules have two depth-of-interaction (DOI) layers of 6.5 mm, constituted by two translated hexagonal grids of 181 and 183 crystals measuring 1.25 mm per edge. Flood field imaging demonstrates excellent pixel resolvability. DOI performance has been validated using collimated radioactive source. The detector achieves a global energy resolution of 14.7%. This engraving protocol outperforms current commercial solutions, which are typically limited to square pixel patterns and thin detectors. Furthermore, this technique reduces manufacturing costs and time. The ability to explore alternative geometric patterns and opens promising avenues for further enhancing DOI discrimination through advanced algorithmic methods.

title: 3D Diffusion Posterior Sampling CT Reconstruction
authors: P. Teng, X. Jiang, L. Cai, T.-C. Lee, J. Zhou, R. Zhang, J. W. Stayman
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Diffusion models have proven effective in generating high-quality images and are being applied in medical image formation through conditional generation. Diffusion Posterior Sampling (DPS) is one such approach that enables the combination of unsupervised prior learning and flexible application with different acquisition methods. Such flexibility is particularly important in x-ray computed tomography (CT) where acquisition protocols vary greatly depending on institution, anatomical target, patient size, etc. While most DPS research focuses on 2D image models, clinical CT reconstruction is inherently three-dimensional. Although extending DPS to 3D is mathematically simple, it is potentially computationally infeasible. This work proposes strategies for 3D DPS CT reconstruction using a 3D neural network to learn the prior, along with algorithmic modifications to reduce memory usage and accelerate sampling. The proposed approach was evaluated on clinical CT data to illustrate both performance and feasibility of 3D DPS for CT reconstruction.

title: Assembly and Initial Tests with a Siliconbased Compton Camera Prototype for Radionuclide Imaging
authors: L. Barrientos, K. Brzeziński, J.V. Casaña, N. Clinthorne, C. García, F. Hueso-González, H. Kagan, J. Pérez-Curbelo, C. Lacasta, M. Mikuz, A. Ros, C. Solaz, A. Studen, M. Strugari, I. Torres-Espallardo, R. Viegas, D. Zontar, G. Llosá
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Silicon detectors have excellent energy resolution which makes them excellent scatter detectors for Compton cameras. A prototype is under development by the IRIS group of IFIC (Valencia) for nuclear medicine imaging applications. The system is based on a silicon pad detector acting as the scatterer and a scintillator crystal coupled to a silicon photomultiplier as the absorber. This configuration aims to improve the spatial resolution of the system with respect to scintillationbased systems developed by the group, while maintaining compactness and high detection efficiency, in order to improve the performance for radionuclides emitting photons with energies around 200 KeV, such as Lu-177. Experimental tests have been conducted using a Ba-133 source, focusing on the 356 keV gamma line. The study includes energy spectra acquisition, coincidence measurements between both detection stages. Monte Carlo simulations have also been conducted to support the experimental results. Preliminary findings demonstrate the feasibility of the system and its potential for future application in gamma imaging. Imaging tests with different isotopes will follow.
