title: Evaluation of Cesium Lead Bromide Cherenkov Charge Induction Detectors with Pixel Electrodes for Gamma-Ray Applications
authors: L. Rebolo, I. Pandey, P.M. M. Correia, A.L. Silva, J. Palmer, G. Ariño-Estrada
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Cesium lead bromide (CLB) has attracted a lot of interest in the recent years as a high-Z semiconductor material for X- and gamma-ray detection with potential low production costs. The presence of lead in the compound gives it a high effective atomic number of 66 for 500 keV photons, greater than cadmium-zinc-telluride, thus achieving greater fraction of photoelectric interactions. CLB is also partially transparent to visible light, with a cutoff at approximately 550 nm. With such properties, CLB is an excellent candidate for Cherenkov Charge Induction (CCI) detectors. CCI detectors combine the conventional charge induction readout of semiconductor detectors with the detection of Cherenkov light generated by the photoelectron that results from the gamma interaction with the crystal bulk. In CLB, the high atomic number makes it a good Cherenkov emitter and the cutoff wavelength in the visible allows it to propagate through the crystal and be detected. We report on the study of the CCI detector concept with CLB on a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \times 5 \times 5$</tex> mm3 crystal with one single pixel electrode of approximately 1 mm2. Preliminary data consists of the presentation of the detector, the data acquisition strategy, and representative examples of events where light and charge readouts are combined. The complete study will resemble the same work previously done with CCI TlBr detectors, where the detection time resolution, energy resolution, and drift time measurement (by means of light and charge readout) were measured. Proving the feasibility of using CLB as a material for CCI can further raise the interest of this promising material for gamma detection.

title: Development of a Silicon Carbide Detector Array for Thermal and Fast Neutron Detection
authors: M. Pérez, J. J. Blostein, F. Zamorano, C. Fleta, C. Guardiola
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Silicon carbide (SiC) detectors offer key advantages such as high radiation hardness, low leakage current, and excellent thermal stability, making them ideal for neutron detection in harsh environments. We present the development of a SiC detector array for the detection of thermal and fast neutrons. The array consists of three SiC diodes fabricated at the Institute of Microelectronics of Barcelona (IMB-CNM-CSIC), each with an active area of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 3 \text{mm}^{2}$</tex>. For thermal neutron detection, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex>-thick SiC diode was used, covered with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex>-thick <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup> LiF layer, while for fast neutron detection, a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex>-thick SiC diode was employed, covered with polypropylene layers of different thicknesses <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(300-1200 \mu \mathrm{m})$</tex>. The detectors were tested with thermal neutrons at the RA-6 Nuclear Research Reactor, with power levels ranging from 50 to 500 kW . Fast neutron experiments were conducted using a 111 GBq AmBe source. The results demonstrated a lineal counting rate for thermal neutrons without saturation effects, and an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$800 \mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> polypropylene layer was identified as optimal for maximizing fast neutron detection efficiency. Additionally, PHITS simulations provided validation for the experimental data, showing good agreement. These findings highlight the potential of SiC-based detectors for reliable neutron monitoring in challenging environments with high gamma background, such as radiotherapy, nuclear reactors, and space applications, among others.

title: A Scintillator-Based Compton Camera Concept for BNCT Treatment Optimisation
authors: S. Lopez Martinez, R. Speller, R. Moss
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Boron Neutron Capture Therapy (BNCT) is an emerging targeted cancer treatment that relies on the selective accumulation of Boron (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{10} ~\mathrm{B}$</tex>) in tumors, which is followed by neutron irradiation. The ensuing capture of neutrons by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{10} ~\mathrm{B}$</tex> triggers a nuclear reaction, which releases a high-linear energy transfer alpha particle. This process enables precise tumor cell destruction while sparing surrounding healthy tissue. However, a major challenge in BNCT is verifying boron distribution inside the patient. Current indirect methods, like inductively coupled plasma spectroscopy of blood samples, can only calculate the boron concentration in the sample but not its distribution in the body. To address this, we present a three-stage Compton camera capable of simultaneously imaging the 478 keV gamma rays from boron neutron capture and the 2.22 MeV gamma rays produced by hydrogen neutron capture. With the maps of emission of both gammas, the boron concentration can then be established. The innovative design of the camera, composed of scintillator cylinders, bypasses the need for full particle absorption, improving event reconstruction efficiency. We evaluated detector performance through Geant4 Monte Carlo simulations. The initial results point to the camera's potential to improve BNCT treatment verification by providing direct boron concentration data. This advancement promises to improve dose delivery precision and pave the way for clinical translation, with further studies planned to optimize detector sensitivity and reconstruction efficiency.

title: MoEGAD: A Mixture-of-Experts Framework with Pseudo-Anomaly Generation for Graph-Level Anomaly Detection
authors: Jinyu Cai, Yunhe Zhang, Pengyang Wang, See-Kiong Ng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Graph-level anomaly detection (GLAD) aims to identify graphs that significantly deviate from the norm. Despite remarkable advancements in recent years, existing GLAD approaches struggle with the scarcity of labeled anomalies. Although some semi-supervised approaches leverage a small fraction of anomalous graphs during training, the limited diversity of these anomalies poses challenges in learning robust decision boundaries. Additionally, the detection of multi-task graph anomalies, a prevalent challenge in real-world scenarios, remains largely unexplored. To bridge these gaps, we propose MoEGAD, a novel framework leveraging a mixture of experts (MoE) architecture for GLAD. MoEGAD introduces an iterative anomalous graph generation module to produce pseudo-anomalous graphs, which facilitates the subsequent decision boundary learning. An early stopping mechanism is incorporated to ensure that the generated anomalies preserve sufficient dissimilarity from normal graphs. More importantly, we also propose a latent MoE module comprising multiple expert networks alongside a specialized gating network, which promotes cross-task adaptability for diverse GLAD problems. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work exploring the potential of MoE architecture in the context of GLAD. Extensive experiments across single-task, large-scale, and multi-task scenarios demonstrate that MoEGAD significantly outperforms state-of-the-art GLAD baselines.

title: SV-FBP for Non-Circular CBCT via Trajectory Standardization: Learn Once and for All
authors: C. Ye, L.-S. Schneider, Y. Sun, S. Bayer, A. Maier
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Differentiable shift-variant filtered backprojection (SV-FBP) is a fast and efficient reconstruction algorithm for cone-beam computed tomography with non-circular trajectories. While this method is significantly faster than iterative methods, its reliance on trajectory-specific training of Radondomain weights limits its ability to generalise and reuse it across different scanning geometries. In this paper, we propose a novel training framework that facilitates trajectory-generalizable learning for SV-FBP. The fundamental concept underpinning this methodology is a preprocessing pipeline that standardises a set of CBCT trajectories by reordering projections based on geometric continuity. This standardization decouples the learned SV-FBP weights from the absolute trajectory configuration, thereby making them invariant to projection order, allowing a single model to be reused across multiple trajectories. Experimental results show that the proposed method enables a single SV-FBP model to generalize across four distinct non-circular CBCT trajectories, achieving consistent performance with an average MSE of 0.1207, PSNR of 34.68 dB, and SSIM of 0.9177, without the need for retraining. This confirms the effectiveness of the standardization framework in enhancing flexibility and scalability.

title: Diffusion-Based Sinogram Interpolation for Limited Angle PET
authors: R. Yilmaz, J. Thull, J. Stegmaier, V. Schulz
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Modern Positron Emission Tomography (PET) is increasingly adopting flexible and applicationdriven detector designs that deviate from traditional cylindrical configurations, such as walkthrough geometries or partial rings. These designs, while advantageous for patient comfort and system integration, lead to incomplete angular coverage and consequently, severely undersampled sinograms. Such limitations result in artifacts and degraded image quality when conventional reconstruction algorithms such as Maximum Likelihood Expectation Maximization (MLEM) are applied. To address this, we propose a data-driven framework that uses conditional diffusion models to recover the missing sinogram regions for improved image reconstruction. Our method leverages the pretrained Stable Diffusion (SD) model, which we fine-tune to predict missing sinogram bins based on limited-angle (LA) inputs. Training is conducted on 2D sinograms derived via the Radon transform from a publicly available PET/CT dataset. The LA regions are simulated by randomly omitting consecutive angular bins. To integrate conditional inputs, we insert convolutional blocks at multiple scales before and after the original SD network, allowing the model to effectively incorporate the LA sinogram into its prediction. While these blocks are being trained, the UNet blocks of the SD are simultaneously fine-tuned to adapt the network, originally trained on natural images, to the domain of PET sinograms, thereby mitigating errors caused by domain shift. The model learns a prior over fully sampled sinograms while using the available partial measurements as additional information during the denoising process. When combined with the MLEM reconstruction, our approach yields an average improvement of approximately 8 dB in peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR), highlighting the potential of diffusion-based generative approaches for robust PET imaging in non-standard acquisition settings.

title: 3D-Printed PETG-PMMA Leuco Dye Dosimeters for Visualization of X-Ray and Carbon Ion Beam Dose Distributions
authors: T. Fujiwara, Y. Fujimoto, H. Kimura, G. Okada, M. Koshimizu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We present the design, fabrication, and preliminary characterization of 3D-printed PETG-PMMA radiochromic dosimeters doped with leuco-crystal-violet for simultaneous visualization and quantification of X-ray and carbon-ion dose distributions. PETG contributes high optical clarity (>90 % transmittance at 550 nm) and excellent printability, while PMMA-our original matrix-remains valuable for mechanical stability. By blending PETG and PMMA in controlled ratios we tune electron density from 3.14 × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">23</sup> to 3.32} × 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">23</sup> e cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-3</sup>, recreating soft tissue, cartilage, and low-density bone within a single phantom. These customizable, low-cost dosimeters enable patient-specific QA, heterogeneous phantom creation, and future wearable monitoring solutions for advanced radiotherapy.

title: Enhanced Modeling for Self-Supervised Monocular Depth Estimation
authors: Guanghui Wei, Laihua Wang, Shuai Li, Xingyu Gao, Sumin Qi, Yang Yu, Liehao Wu
abstract: Self-supervised monocular depth estimation has emerged as a focal point of research due to its elimination of the dependence on labels. Despite recent advancements, existing self-supervised methods still suffer from boundary blurring. In this paper, we propose a straightforward yet effective data augmentation method called Self-CutMix, which employs synthetic occlusion to enhance the capability for foreground-background modeling capability, thereby improving the performance of boundary prediction. The depth consistency loss and the self-distillation loss are developed for the proposed Self-CutMix during training. Additionally, we propose the MA-HRDecoder, which integrates a multi-scale technique and an adaptive weighting module for higher-accuracy depth prediction. Extensive experimental results show that the proposed model achieves state-of-the-art performance on KITTI, nuScenes, and Cityscapes while generalizing well to NYUv2 and Make3D. Code is available at https://github.com/GuanghuiWei/EM-Depth.

title: ADNM-UNet: An Asymmetric Dual-branch Non-causal Mamba U-Net with Multi-scale Attention Enhancement for Cloud Mask Nowcasting
authors: Mingzhou Li, Xiaohui Huang, Fu Wang, Xiaofei Yang, Jiangtao Peng, Yifang Ban, Nan Jiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Cloud mask underpins accurate precipitation nowcasting, which in turn is vital for understanding the hydrological cycle, supporting disaster prevention, solar energy forecasting and transportation. However, cloud mask nowcasting remains challenging because meteorological data exhibit irregular temporal and spatial variations, including fine-scale structures, and often suffer from highly skewed precipitation intensity distributions. Existing methods struggle to capture complex spatiotemporal dynamics and preserve fine-scale structures due to limitations in handling sparse data from numerical weather prediction (NWP) model. To address these issues, we propose an asymmetric dual-branch non-causal mamba U-Net (ADNM-UNet) featuring three key components: (1) The Asymmetric Dual-branch Non-causal Mamba (ADNM) implements a novel asymmetric bidirectional modeling framework that resolves directional bias in conventional Mamba architectures. This design preserves precise cloud boundary delineation while capturing long-range spatiotemporal dependencies in sparse data from NWP. (2) The Multi-scale Attention Enhancement Module (MAEM) enhances discriminative feature representation and suppresses spectral redundancy through anisotropic convolution kernels and hybrid pooling. This mechanism significantly improves edge retention in precipitation systems while attenuating atmospheric noise interference. (3) Complementing these advancements, the Wavelet Decomposition and Fusion Module (WDFM) maintains cloud contour integrity across scales through multiresolution decomposition. Extensive experiments demonstrate that ADNM-UNet outperforms existing methods across all metrics, achieving 27.96% improvement in CSI and 22.89% in HSS for metrics over the best performing baseline models at high intensity scenarios. Our project is open source and available on GitHub at: https://github.com/kanyu369/ADNM-UNet.

title:
Development of a 1D
                    <sup>3</sup>
                    He Curved Neutron Detector based on the Trench-MWPC Technology
authors: J. Marchal, J.-C. Buffet, S. Cuccaro, B. Guerard, J. Pentenero, N. Sartor
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The Trench-MWPC detector is an enhanced version of the traditional MWPC technology, which has been implemented on several neutron diffraction instruments at the Laue-Langevin Institute. This advanced technique offers significantly improved spatial resolution and counting rate compared to the standard MWPC. This article presents the most recent <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> He-filled Trench-MWPC development: a one-dimensional position-sensitive detector designed for the D20 high-intensity powder diffraction instrument. Preliminary measurements carried out with this detector on a test beamline are discussed.

title: Grounding X-Ray Simulations in Reality: Physics-Aware Calibration for X-Ray Models
authors: H. Ezzaoui Rahali, A. Corbeil Therrien
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The demand for larger datasets is growing as AI and machine learning become vital in signal processing for high-rate experiments. Yet, such sizable datasets are difficult to obtain through real-world setups, prompting the use of Monte Carlo simulation frameworks, such as Geant4, to generate synthetic data. However, accurately reproducing experiments through simulation poses a significant challenge: key parameters – including material properties, source distributions, and detector geometry – can be poorly documented or unknown. In practice, aligning simulation outputs with real-world measurements is time-consuming and often relies on expert intuition or brute-force parameter sweeps. To address this, we propose a physics-aware optimization approach that automatically calibrates simulation parameters to match experiments. Treating Geant4 as a black box, our method leverages derivative-free optimization techniques to minimize a data-driven loss between simulated and observed outputs. Physics-informed constraints are incorporated through clipping and penalty-based regularization to enforce plausible solutions. We evaluate our approach on synthetic X-ray imaging data, comparing recovered parameters to the known ground truth and a real-world dataset with unknown parameters. In both cases, we assess image quality using standard SSIM, demonstrating accurate configuration recovery while substantially reducing manual calibration effort. Our method generalizes to various experimental setups where simulation fidelity is essential but full system specification is unavailable.

title: Three-Dimensional Intraoperative Shape Mapping of Flexible Ferromagnetic Guidewires Using a Hybrid Magnetic-Fluoroscopic Approach
authors: Yiting Zhao, Liwei Shi, Wei Wei, Jun Wang, Yang Bian, Nan Xiao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: During vascular interventional surgery, challenges such as unclear device morphology and difficulty in identifying distal orientation are frequently encountered. To address these issues, this study proposes a novel method for 3D shape estimation of interventional devices. The approach utilizes a flexible ferromagnetic-tipped guidewire, which exhibits mechanical properties similar to conventional guidewires, to estimate its shape by correlating the magnetic field distribution with the guidewire’s geometry. Due to the nonlinear relationship between the magnetic field and the guidewire shape, image and physical constraints were applied to refine the estimation. Experimental results demonstrated high accuracy and stability, with root mean square error and Hausdorff distance both below 1 mm, surpassing existing methods. Notably, this technique requires no built-in sensors or additional wiring, and the fluoroscopic images used are standard in clinical practice, ensuring minimal interference with clinical procedures. This makes the method highly suitable for vascular interventional navigation.

title: Jitter Investigation and Simulation Methodology for PLLs in the IGNITE Chips
authors: S. Cadeddu, M. Chiariello, P. Ciambrone, G.M. Cossu, M. De Matteis, L. Frontini, A. Lai, V. Liberali, L. Pacher, L. Piccolo, L. Palini, A. Stabile
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper presents the design, simulation, and experimental validation of multiple phase-locked loops (PLLs) integrated into the IGNITE0 chip, developed in 28 nm CMOS technology for highprecision measurements in high-energy physics. These PLLs were designed to suppress the jitter of the reference clock and provide low-jitter outputs at frequencies ranging from 40 MHz to 640 MHz, supporting sub-50 ps time resolution required by the on-chip time-to-digital converters (TDCs). Pre-silicon simulations, performed across full PVT corners using transient noise analysis, indicated excellent jitter performance with values below a few picoseconds. However, postfabrication measurements revealed significant discrepancies, including increased jitter (up to 40 ps at 40 MHz) and sporadic loss of lock.

title: Fault Diagnosis and Adaptive Fault-Tolerant Control of Interturn Short-Circuit Fault in PMSM Drives
authors: Yun Zhang, Xueqing Wang, Jinjin Peng, Lei Kong, Zheng Wang, Yao Mao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: In this paper, fault diagnosis and adaptive fault-tolerant control (FTC) are proposed for the interturn short-circuit (ITSC) fault in permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) drives. The fault diagnosis is realized by extracting the speed fluctuation caused by the ITSC fault. The dq-axis current injection based adaptive FTC scheme is applied to gradually reduce the speed fluctuation and torque ripple caused by the ITSC fault. The proposed method can achieve excellent fault diagnosis and fault-tolerant (FT) performances without using any machine model or auxiliary circuit. The experiments are conducted to verify the effectiveness of the proposed fault diagnosis and adaptive FTC.

title: System Performance Characterization of United Imaging Healthcare's Micro-SPECT/CT Platform for Preclinical Imaging
authors: S. Tang, B. Gao, Z. Liu, B. Wang, Y. Huang, Z. Han, X. Cheng, Y. Dong
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The system performance of the first small-animal SPECT/CT system from United Imaging Healthcare was evaluated. The SPECT scanner is configured with twenty detectors mounted on a static ring gantry. Each detector comprises a CsI(Tl) crystal array coupled with a SIPM array. The CT scanner is a cone-beam CT consisting CMOS detectors. A tungsten multi-pinhole collimator is inserted into the detector ring. The collimator is replaceable and four collimators for different applications are offered. The FOV size is 12 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{m m}(\square) \times 5 ~\text{mm}(~\mathrm{L}), 12 ~\text{mm}(\square) \times 5 ~\text{mm}(~\mathrm{L}), 32.5 ~\text{mm}(\square) \times 11 ~\text{mm}(~\mathrm{L})$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$65 ~\text{mm}(\square) \times 21.5 \text{mm}(\mathrm{L})$</tex>, respectively. The geometry of the collimator is determined by theoretical analysis and simulation for the optimized spatial resolution, sensitivity, edge penetration and scatter fraction. The system matrix is measured using a high-precision translation stage and a specially crafted point source. In this study, we performed phantom and animal experiments to characterise the performance of the scanner. Reconstructed spatial resolution, point source sensitivity, energy resolution (@140keV) and image uniformity, were evaluated.

title: Identifying Robust Radiomic Features in CT Imaging for Predicting Object Contrast Variation
authors: M. Karimipourfard, D. Stocker, C. Sommer, S. Sina, S. Scheidegger
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Optimizing CT protocols is critical for enhancing diagnostic accuracy while minimizing patient radiation exposure, this work addresses a key challenge in medical imaging. Using an abdominal CT phantom, scans were performed at varying kVp, CTDI, and rotation angles. After image registration and segmentation, 107 radiomic features from shape, first order statistics, and texture matrices (GLCM, GLDM, GLRLM, GLSZM, NGTDM) were extracted using PyRadiomics and matRadiomics. Features were then analyzed for normal distribution using skewness, CV, and kurtosis coefficients, resulting in 59 remaining features. The reproducibility of these features was assessed using Intraclass Correlation Coefficient (ICC). The results showed that some GLRLM and GLDM features, especially Low Gray-Level Run Emphasis (LGLRE), Long-Run Low GrayLevel Emphasis (LRLGLE), and Low Gray-Level Emphasis (LGLE) displayed significant reproducibility. A Random Forest model utilizing Next Generation Texture Data Matrix (NGTDM) features achieved 91% accuracy in predicting object contrast, highlighting the importance of NGTDM-Contrast and NGTDM-Strength in differentiating contrasts. While the model demonstrated potential, challenges were encountered due to small objects and non-uniform noise, suggesting the need for further refinement. The study concludes that radiomics holds promise for object detection and characterization in CT images, and integrating feature analysis into machine learning workflows warrants further investigation, especially within patient databases and in conjunction with deep learning techniques.

title: Radiological Source Detection, Mapping, and Tracking with an Active Mask Imaging Multi-Sensor Mobile Platform
authors: C. Lamb, J. A. Hanks, B. Huang, I. A. Peña, G. Montepeque, B. J. Quiter, R. J. Cooper, K. Vetter
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Detecting, imaging, localizing, and mapping radiological materials at distances of 10 meters or more in complex environments continues to pose challenges in nuclear security and emergency response. We previously developed a gamma ray imaging system comprised of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$128(10 ~\text{cm})^{3} \text{NaI}(\text{Tl})$</tex> detectors arranged in a cylindrical configuration for a 360° azimuthal FOV. Installed within an electric van and complemented with a multi-beam rotating LiDAR system, multiple large FOV optical cameras, and several contextual sensor data streams, this combined system allows for the detection, identification, and mapping of radiological objects and the fusion with contextual, e.g. structural information. The developed system enhances current capabilities in nuclear security in the detection and localization of weak radiological signatures and the adjudication of associated alarms, it provides unprecedented capabilities in emergency response and consequence management due to the wide-area data fusion capabilities, and it informs the development and deployment of smaller and more agile manned and unmanned deployment platforms.

title: Secure Pinching Antenna-aided ISAC
authors: Elmehdi Illi, Marwa Qaraqe, Ali Ghrayeb
abstract: In this letter, a pinching antenna (PA)-aided scheme for establishing a secure integrated sensing and communication system (ISAC) is investigated. The underlying system comprises a dual-functional radar communication (DFRC) base station (BS) linked to multiple waveguides to serve several downlink users while sensing a set of malicious targets in a given area. The PA-aided BS aims at preserving communication confidentiality with the legitimate users while being able to detect malicious targets. One objective of the proposed scheme is to optimize the PA locations, based on which an optimal design of the legitimate signal beamforming and artificial noise covariance matrices is provided to maximize the network’s sensing performance, subject to secrecy and total power constraints. We demonstrate the efficacy of the proposed scheme through numerical examples and compare that against a traditional DFRC ISAC system with a uniform linear array of half-wavelength-spaced antennas. We show that the proposed scheme outperforms the baseline PA-aided scheme with equidistant PAs by 3 dB in terms of sensing reflected power, while it can provide gains of up to 30 dB of the same metric against a traditional ISAC system with half-wavelength-space uniform linear arrays.

title: Performance and Optimization of the ALICE Inner Tracking System 2
authors: J. Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The ALICE Inner Tracking System 2 (ITS2) represents a significant advancement in silicon tracking technology for high-energy physics experiments. Installed during LHC Long Shutdown 2, ITS2 consists of seven cylindrical layers covering <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 ~\mathrm{m} \$^{\wedge} 2 $</tex> at low material budget of 0.36 \% $X_0$ (innermost layers). The detector is based on the ALPIDE Monolithic Active Pixel sensor manufactured in 180 nm CMOS technology. During Run\~{}3, ITS2 has demonstrated high performance and stability in both pp and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Pb}--\text{Pb}$</tex> collisions. Compared to its predecessor, ITS2 has improved impact parameter resolution by more than a factor two for low-momentum particles. The stability of the detector despite has been maintained through a combination regular monitoring and automatic recovery systems.

title: High-Density Monolithic SDD Arrays for High-Throughput X-Ray Spectroscopy Applications
authors: B. Pedretti, C. Poletti, G. Ticchi, P. Barcella, G. Borghi, M. Carminati, C. Fiorini
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: X-ray spectroscopy experiments in new-generation synchrotron beamlines require detectors with high throughput capability and excellent energy resolution. The ARDESIA project addresses this need through the development of advanced X-ray spectrometers based on monolithic, highly segmented arrays of Silicon Drift Detectors (SDDs). In this work, we present a comprehensive spectroscopic characterization and design advancements of ARDESIA-64, a 64-channel detector featuring a high-density monolithic SDD array. ARDESIA-64 achieves a four-fold increase in Output Count Rate (OCR) compared to its predecessor, ARDESIA-16, while preserving the same compact footprint to facilitate seamless integration into synchrotron beamlines. The increased detector throughput enables handling of higher beam intensities, resulting in faster experiment times while maintaining energy resolution. In addition, we will present at the conference the results from both active and mechanical collimation approaches, highlighting their impact on detector performance and background suppression.

title: Microstrip Branch-Line Directional Couplers With Modified Layout for Efficient Compensation of Junction Discontinuities and Better Design Flexibility
authors: Arsen Kubyshkin, Dmitry Kholodnyak
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: Design of a branch-line directional coupler (DC) is associated with the need to compensate an impact of discontinuities of transmission line (TL) T-junctions manifested in the input mismatch and shift of the main characteristics (power division, isolation, and return loss) in frequency and with respect to each other. A modified layout of the microstrip branch-line DC is proposed, which is less sensitive to the effect of junction discontinuities and allows for its easier compensation compared to the known approaches. A simple and efficient design technique for the DCs of the modified layout is elaborated and shown feasible to design microstrip branch-line DCs with different power division ratio on substrates with different permittivity and thickness values. Using the modified DC layout and proposed design technique simplifies and accelerates design of the microstrip branch-line DCs to meet target specifications.

title: Efficient Low-Flux Muon Tomography Using the $\Mu$TRec Algorithm
authors: R. S. Ughade, S. Chatzidakis
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Muon scattering tomography (MST) has emerged as a promising imaging modality since the introduction of the point of closest approach (PoCA) algorithm by Schultz et al. in 2003. Since then, MST has been applied across a range of fields, including geology, civil engineering, archaeology, and nuclear security. Despite its widespread use, the PoCA algorithm has inherent limitations due to its underlying assumption of single scattering, which does not adequately represent the multiple Coulomb scattering (MCS) behavior of muons as they traverse dense materials. To overcome this limitation, a reconstruction algorithm that models MCS using a Gaussian approximation with a Bayesian framework is proposed. The resulting method, referred to as the muon trajectory reconstruction ($\Mu$TRec) algorithm, aims to more accurately estimate the curved trajectories of muons through matter. This enhanced modeling leads to improved resolution in tomographic reconstructions. For instance, when applied to the detection of a missing fuel assembly (FA) within a spent nuclear fuel (SNF) dry storage cask (DSC), $\Mu$TRec achieves comparable detection performance with nearly 20 times fewer muons than the PoCA algorithm.

title: Impact of Substrate Off-Angle on Device Performance for BGaN Neutron Detectors
authors: R. Saito, R. Kudo, T. Sakurai, E. Kokubo, G. Wakabayashi, Y. Honda, H. Amano, Y. Inoue, T. Aoki, T. Nakano
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In the high-temperature gas-cooled reactors (HTGR), new neutron detectors are expected to be developed because the reactor temperature is over 600° C. Boron gallium nitride (BGaN) is a wide bandgap semiconductor that can operate in harsh environments and is expected to be a novel neutron detection semiconductor. However, the crystallinity of conventional BGaN detectors is not enough for a high temperature tolerance device, and the improvement of crystallinity is required for application in high-temperature environments.

title: Timing Resolution of Particle Counting Detectors with Microchannel Plates
authors: A. S. Tremsin, O. H. Siegmund, J. V. Vallerga, J. B. McPhate, T. Curtis, D. T. Tercero, M. R. Dexter, R. R. Raffanti, S. Roy, S. Morley, A. Us Saleheen
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Event-counting detectors utilizing Microchannel Plates (MCPs) are widely used in applications requiring precise measurement of particle position and arrival time, including photons, neutrons, electrons, and ions. These detectors achieve spatial resolutions of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 6 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> and timing resolutions of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 50 \text{ps}$</tex>, though optimizing performance necessitates balancing resolution, counting rate, active area, lifetime, and other key parameters.

title: Development of High-Resolution Modular Detectors for Three-Dimensional Gamma Imaging
authors: P. Jha, S. Junnarkar
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This work presents a novel high-density pixelation sensor system designed to overcome challenges in radiation detection for applications such as SPECT, PET, and X-ray CT. Utilising a Cadmium Zinc Telluride (CZT) gamma detector with a 48x38 pixel matrix (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$640 \mu ~\mathrm{m} \times 500 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> pixels, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> gaps), the system employs a unique perpendicular arrangement of 19 readout substrates to achieve 1824 connections within a compact <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.4 ~\text{cm} \times 2.4 ~\text{cm}$</tex> area. Right-angled solder joints, formed via a solder reflow process with a custom self-aligning jig, enable efficient electrical connectivity without bulky connectors, while in-pad vias and short trace lengths minimise inductance and cross-talk, achieving a near-1 fill factor. Preliminary results demonstrate a near-order-of-magnitude improvement in pixel density over state-of-the-art systems, enhancing resolution for high-fidelity 3D imaging critical to nuclear medicine diagnostics. The design's flexibility, cost-effective manufacturing potential, and compatibility with diverse scanner geometries position it to revolutionise medical imaging and other sensor applications. Future work will focus on validating the solder reflow process and ensuring reliable electrical connections.

title: Medical Image Volume Generation Using 3D Conditional Diffusion Models
authors: J. Schaefferkoetter, P. Schleyer, M. Conti
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper presents a 3D diffusion model for generating medical image volumes. Various training and sampling techniques were investigated, and the generative performance of the diffusion model was compared to that of a conventional CNN for the task of synthesizing CT image volumes from PET image volumes. In general, the conditional diffusion model generated higher quality image volumes than that of the CNN, and accelerated deterministic diffusion sampling techniques were found to generate high quality outputs in relatively few steps. Moreover, single diffusion model was found to be capable of both unconditional and conditional generative sampling, demonstrating the decoupled relationship between the generative and conditioning processes.

title: Towards Robust and Real-Time State Estimation: A Neural Kalman Filter Framework with Mamba Architecture
authors: Jin Sun, Jiacheng Shen, Jinwu Tong, Tiantian Tang, Yue Yin, Tomoaki Ohtsuki, Guan Gui
abstract: The rapid advancement of intelligent perception systems and autonomous navigation technologies imposes increasingly stringent requirements on state estimation algorithms regarding modeling capacity, robustness, and real-time performance. While traditional Kalman Filter (KF) demonstrates computational efficiency and mathematical interpretability for linear Gaussian systems, their effectiveness diminishes in nonlinear, non-Gaussian, and non-stationary dynamic scenarios. Recent developments in neural state space modeling offer new perspectives for recursive estimation, yet existing approaches suffer from structural complexity, training difficulties, and inadequate real-time capability. This paper presents Mamba-KF, a novel state estimation framework integrating deep modeling with recursive filtering. Leveraging the cutting-edge Mamba state space neural network, our method dynamically generates state transition parameters while establishing a differentiable covariance propagation pathway, enabling end-to-end optimization. We further design a lightweight multi-modal fusion architecture tailored for high-frequency sensory data processing in real-time applications. Evaluated on the EuRoC Micro Aerial Vehicle (MAV) dataset, Mamba-KF attains the lowest errors across states, reducing position Root Mean Square Error (RMSE) by up to 33.3% relative to Extended Kalman Filter (EKF) and 24.1% relative to Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF) at 10 dB Signal-to-Noise Ratio (SNR), with an average velocity RMSE of 0.097 m/s and an orientation error of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$2.3^\circ$</tex-math></inline-formula>. It also achieves superior consistency, with a mean Normalized Estimation Error Squared (NEES) of 6.02 and 93.7% of estimates within the <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"><tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\chi ^{2}$</tex-math></inline-formula>-based 95% confidence interval. Under robustness evaluations, Mamba-KF yields the lowest RMSEs and suppresses divergence observed in EKF. Computationally, it maintains near real-time performance with 0.65 ms per step, offering a favorable accuracy-efficiency trade-off for visual-inertial navigation and autonomous systems, while providing significant theoretical insights and promising engineering applications.

title: Deep Learning-Based Scatter Artifact Correction in X-Ray Digital Radiography for Security Screening and Contraband Detection
authors: G. Chen, B. Liu, Y. Dang, B. Jiang, Y. Xu, C. Zong
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This study proposes a deep learning-based approach for correcting stripe-like scattering artifacts in high-energy X-ray digital radiography (DR) systems for cargo and vehicle screening. These artifacts, mainly caused by internal system structures and detector cross-talk, degrade image quality. Instead of relying on traditional scattering kernel-based corrections with limited adaptability, the method learns the spatial variation pattern of system-induced artifacts. Scattering-dominant images are acquired using high-density shielding to suppress primary transmission and highlight system artifacts. A lightweight convolutional neural network is trained to capture normalized spatial distribution patterns of the streaks. During inference, the input image's amplitude is convolved with the learned pattern to estimate the scatter component, which is then subtracted or compensated for accordingly. Experiments on real-world DR systems confirm effective suppression of system-generated stripes and improved image clarity, with strong generalizability across objects.

title: Cryogenic Performance of Single-Photon Avalanche Diodes for Neutrino Detection
authors: W. Ha, F. Gramuglia, E.H. Toh, P. Zheng, Y.T. Chow, A. Kish, H. Sun, A. Para, C. Escobar, D. Christian, P. M. Rubinov, F. Fahim, E. Charbon
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: CMOS single-photon avalanche diodes (SPADs) are regarded as highly promising photodetectors for studying neutrino interactions with liquid argon at cryogenic temperatures (CT). This paper shows the performance of CMOS-SPADs using GlobalFoundries 55 nm BCDLite technology at CT. SPADs with deep junctions were tested to determine their performance. We measured I-V characteristics, dark count rate (DCR), photon detection probability (PDP), and breakdown voltage at various temperatures ranging from CT to room temperature (RT). Measurements were conducted using a cryogenic probe station capable of reaching 4 K. The study explored the effects of CT on breakdown voltage and PDP, as well as the impact of tunneling and trap-assisted thermal generation noise on DCR. These findings offer new insights into SPAD performance at CT, supporting advancements in quantum sensing, high-energy physics, and low-temperature photon detection.

title: Understanding Trust and Fatigue Under Transparency Regulation in Air Traffic Control: A Multimodal Approach
authors: Changjie Jiang, Tong Zhou, Haoran Shen, Yanjun Wang
abstract: The integration of artificial intelligence and automation into safety-critical domains, such as air traffic management (ATM), raises new challenges in managing operators’ trust and fatigue under high-workload conditions. Although transparency regulation has been identified as a key factor shaping human–automation interaction, prior work has largely focused on driving or monitoring tasks. Little attention has been paid to managing complex work, such as air traffic control. Moreover, trust and fatigue are typically examined in isolation, with limited understanding of their dynamic interplay in human–machine collaboration. This article introduces a transparency-regulated ATM simulation platform that allows three fixed transparency levels (low, mid, and high) and a user-switchable (mix) mode, enabling controlled investigation of effects on operators’ trust and fatigue. Multimodal data were collected from eye tracking, electroencephalography, and system status logs under varying transparency and workload conditions. By applying machine learning and deep learning approaches, we compare unimodal and multimodal prediction of trust and fatigue. The results show that increasing transparency enhances operators’ understanding, trust, and willingness to rely on the system, while multimodal fusion achieves superior predictive accuracy compared with single-modality inputs. The findings reveal a positive but nonlinear coupling between trust and fatigue, suggesting that adaptive transparency can balance operators’ reliance and cognitive effort. In particular, temporal deep models exhibit strong sensitivity to eye tracking features. Overall, this article contributes a unified framework linking transparency regulation, multimodal state estimation, and adaptive interface design, offering theoretical and practical insights for building resilient ATM automation systems that maintain appropriate trust while mitigating fatigue risks.

title: Iterative Joint Detection of Kalman Filter and Channel Decoder for Sensor-to-Controller Link in Wireless Networked Control Systems
authors: Jinnan Piao, Dong Li, Yiming Sun, Zhibo Li, Ming Yang, Xueting Yu
abstract: In this letter, we propose an iterative joint detection algorithm of Kalman filter (KF) and channel decoder for the sensor-to-controller link of wireless networked control systems, which utilizes the prior information of control systems to improve control and communication performance. In this algorithm, we first use the KF to estimate the probability density of the control system outputs and calculate the prior probability of received signals to assist the decoder. Then, we traverse the possible outputs of the control system to update the prior probability to implement iterative detection. The simulation results show that the prior information and the iterative structure can reduce the block error rate performance of communications while improving the root mean square error performance of controls.

title: Electromagnetic Motion Tracking and Event-by-Event Motion Correction for Dynamic Tau PET Imaging
authors: W. Tan, Z. Wang, Y. Li, X. Zeng, X. Wang, Y. Li, A. Goldan
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Dynamic tau PET imaging enables real-time tracking of tau pathology in Alzheimer's disease, supporting early diagnosis, disease staging, and treatment monitoring. However, prolonged scan durations often lead to significant head motion, which degrades image quality and limits accurate tau quantification. To address this, we developed a high-resolution electromagnetic motion tracking (EMMT) system for PET-CT scanners, providing real-time motion tracking and event-byevent motion correction. We assessed head motion in 439 participants undergoing 60 -minute dynamic <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{18} ~\mathrm{F}$</tex>] MK6240 PET scans, observing rotation ranging from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$-10^{\circ}$</tex> to 5° and translation ranging from −5 mm to 10 mm. Additionally, we conducted a clinical [<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">18</sup>F]MK6240 PET scan using our EMMT system, demonstrating a substantial reduction in motion artifacts.

title:
Impact of Energy Window Selection and Collimator-Detector Response Compensation Methods for Quantitative
                    <sup>90</sup>
                    Y Bremsstrahlung SPECT
authors: C. Yan, H. Hu, F. Chen, R. Zhao, H. Li, Z. He, H. Liu, J. Wu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">90</sup>Y bremsstrahlung SPECT imaging faces challenges due to the continuous energy spectrum. In this study, we investigated the impact of energy window selection and collimator-detector response compensation methods for quantitative <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">90</sup>Y bremsstrahlung SPECT, based on Monte Carlo simulations. We used four distinct energy windows ( 0-400 keV, 90-160 keV, 105-285 keV, and 0-2300 keV ) and two collimator-detector response compensation methods (Gaussian-Center and Gaussian-Weight) for image reconstruction. Quantitative evaluation was performed using contrast recovery coefficient (CRC), background variability (BV), and contrast to noise ratio (CNR). Both visual analysis and quantitative evaluation showed that narrower energy windows generally correlated with higher image contrast (CRC), while wider energy windows generally correlated with reduced noise levels (BV) in reconstructed images. The 0-400 keV window may be a preferable selection when prioritizing CNR metrics alone, while Gaussian-Center and GaussianWeight methods exhibited negligible discrepancies in reconstructed images for this specific window. In conclusion, to achieve quantitative <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">90</sup>Y bremsstrahlung SPECT imaging, the energy window and collimator-detector response compensation method should be carefully selected based on specific application requirements.

title: Three-Dimensional Diamond Detector for Alpha Particles With Laser-Embedded Allcarbon Electrodes
authors: S. Sakurai, K. Oda, J. H. Kaneko, H. Umezawa, N. Hoshikawa
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Three-dimensional (3D) detectors have emerged as an effective structure for enhancing charge collection in radiation sensors by decoupling electrode spacing from detector thickness. This enables improved electric field control and shorter carrier transit paths without reducing sensitive volume. Diamond is a highly promising material for such devices, owing to its wide bandgap, high carrier mobility, radiation hardness, and thermal stability. These properties make diamond especially suited to 3D detector designs where charge transport efficiency and environmental resilience are critical. However, fabricating 3D electrode structures in diamond has typically required femtosecond lasers and specialized optical systems, increasing cost and complexity. In this work, we report a 3D diamond detector fabricated using a simple nanosecond-pulsed laser to embed conductive all-carbon electrodes directly into single-crystal CVD diamond. The embedded graphite patterns act as both charge collection electrodes and signal readout lines, eliminating the need for metallization. Under alpha irradiation, the detector achieved 94.0 % charge collection efficiency (CCE) at 60 V. The 3D layout enables narrow electrode spacing, enabled by successfully localized graphite electrode embedding. This contributes directly to the high CCE observed. These results demonstrate a simple and robust fabrication method for high-performance 3D diamond detectors suited for nuclear, space, and medical applications.

title: Learning Regularization Parameters for PET Image Reconstruction
authors: Y. Moussaoui, S. Moussaoui, D. Mateus, T. Carlier, S. Stute
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: PET reconstruction transforms sinogram data into images using algorithms that incorporate data statistics and regularization penalties. The type of penalty and its strength have a strong impact on the reconstructed image quality, as they control the balance between reducing noise and preserving important details. Defining appropriate values for these parameters is difficult due to the variability of clinical data properties and usage purposes. We propose a supervised deep learning approach, based on a residual neural network, that uses directly the raw sinograms to predict the optimal regularization parameters of the relative difference prior used with the modified BSREM algorithm. This network, trained on synthetic 2D sinograms paired with optimal values of regularization parameters, learns to map raw data to optimal settings. This approach allows for fast, automated parameter selection, avoiding manual tuning. It generalizes well across phantom types and consistently produces high-quality reconstructions, supporting more efficient and reliable PET imaging workflows.

title: Exploiting Cognition in ISAR Processing for Spectral Compatibility Applications
authors: Massimo Rosamilia, Augusto Aubry, Alessio Balleri, Antonio De Maio, Marco Martorella
abstract: This paper introduces and analyzes the concept of a cognitive inverse synthetic aperture radar (ISAR) ensuring spectral compatibility in crowded electromagnetic environments. In such a context, the proposed approach alternates between environmental perception, recognizing possible emitters in its frequency range, and an action stage, synthesizing and transmitting a tailored radar waveform to achieve the desired imaging task while guaranteeing spectral coexistence with overlaid emitters. The perception is carried out by a spectrum sensing module providing the true relevant spectral parameters of the sources in the environment. The action stage employs a tailored signal design process, synthesizing a radar waveform with bespoke spectral notches, enabling ISAR imaging over a wide spectral bandwidth without interfering with the other radio frequency (RF) sources. A key enabling requirement for the proposed application is the capability to successfully recover possible missing data in the frequency domain (induced by spectral notches) and in the slow-time dimension (enabling concurrent RF activities still in a cognitive fashion). This process is carried out by resorting to advanced methods based on either the compressed-sensing framework or a rank-minimization recovery strategy. The capabilities of the proposed system are assessed exploiting a dataset of drone measurements in the frequency band between 13 GHz and 15 GHz. Results highlight the effectiveness of the devised architecture to enable spectral compatibility while delivering high-quality ISAR images as well as additional RF activities.

title: YSBE-Based Target Detection via Multibeam Sonar on Velocity-Constrained AUVs: Toward Port Inspection
authors: Xian Yang, Sijie Yu, Junfeng Zhu, Jing Yan, Xinping Guan
abstract: Port underwater inspection is essential for ensuring maritime safety and operational continuity. However, low visibility and complex environments make it challenging to achieve reliable detection. This study addresses the issue of underwater target recognition based on multibeam sonar imagery. Specifically, we propose YOLO-ShuffleNet-BiFPN-EIOU, an enhanced YOLOv5 detection framework with three key improvements: first, the adoption of the lightweight backbone network ShuffleNetv2, second, the incorporation of a bidirectional feature pyramid network, and third, the optimization of the enhanced intersection over union loss function. Furthermore, we theoretically derive the maximum permissible velocity threshold for autonomous underwater vehicle (AUV), leading to a novel velocity-constrained controller that improves sonar imaging quality. A general transformation function is applied, and a functional dependence with quasi-linear characteristics between the independent and dependent variables is established, converting the partially constrained AUV system into an unconstrained one. Finally, experiments conducted in a pool and a real-world port demonstrate that the proposed method achieves significant improvements in accuracy and efficiency compared to YOLOv5m, with mAP@0.5 increasing by 3.4%, mAP@0.5:0.95 improving by 5.3%, giga floating-point operations per second reduced by 89.8%, and the velocity-constrained AUV operation effectively enhances detection performance.

title: A Passive Coherent Location Friendly 6G for Private Campus Networks
authors: Lukas Brechtel, Christoph Fischer, Hans D. Schotten
publish: IEEE Journal of Indoor and Seamless Positioning and Navigation
abstract: This paper proposes a novel 6G downlink waveform designed for passive coherent location (PCL) using orthogonal time–frequency space (OTFS) modulation. Targeting private campus networks, the approach enables passive sensing without active signal emission, addressing key challenges of energy consumption, interference, and cost in industrial automation. The OTFS framework operates in the delay–Doppler domain, allowing seamless integration of radar functionality into communication signals while maintaining synchronization-free operation through local signal processing. A comprehensive simulation-based analysis of OTFS grid configurations reveals fundamental trade-offs between sensing resolution and computational efficiency. Controlled ray-traced simulations support the theoretical framework, indicating high-resolution target detection capabilities that meet 3 rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) requirements for autonomous mobile robot (AMR) navigation. The proposed architecture offers power advantages through elimination of transmit amplification, the primary power consumer in active radar systems, and provides inherent privacy advantages through passive operation and distributed processing. Processing chain analysis reveals strong compatibility with multistatic extensions, requiring only evolutionary modifications rather than fundamental redesign. Simulation results suggest the feasibility of dual-use signaling in future 6G networks, with applications extending beyond industrial automation to smart cities, traffic monitoring, and public safety systems.

title: Development of a Time-of-Flight Spectrometer for a Cyclotron-Based Quasimonoenergetic Neutron Beam
authors: T.-H. Lin, H.-M. Lee, K.-Y. Chu, T.-S. Duh, H.-Y. Tsai, K.-C. Lan, M.-W. Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: To meet the growing demand for neutron-related applications, a quasi-monoenergetic neutron (QMN) beam has been established at the National Atomic Research Institute in Taiwan. To ensure quality assurance and support downstream applications of this neutron source, we developed a time-of-flight (TOF) spectrometer to experimentally verify the QMN beam spectrum. The spectrometer comprises two 2 -inch EJ-309 scintillation detectors, each positioned 20 cm away at a 45-degree angle from the neutron beam port to detect gamma rays emitted from the target, and a 3-inch EJ-309 detector located at a flight distance of 294 cm to measure neutrons. The QMN beam is produced via the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{9} \text{Be}(\mathrm{p}, \mathrm{n}){ }^{9} ~\mathrm{B}$</tex> reaction by irradiating a 1 -mm-thick <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{9} \text{Be}$</tex> target with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$30-\text{MeV}$</tex> proton bunches from the cyclotron. With an operating frequency of 73.13 MHz, the cyclotron produces proton bunches at 13.67 -ns intervals, resulting in repetitive gamma-ray and neutron bursts that produce periodic gamma-ray/gamma-ray and gamma-ray/neutron coincidence events in the measured TOF spectrum. A dedicated method was developed to extract the neutron spectrum from these repetitive distributions. An effective time window of 13.67 ns was identified to resolve neutron energies within a constrained range of 16.19 to 30 MeV. The measured neutron spectrum exhibits a quasi-monoenergetic distribution with a clear peak at 26 MeV, in excellent agreement with the spectrum simulated by a Monte Carlo model in prior work. This technique provides a reliable approach for implementing quality assurance of proton-cyclotron-based neutron sources.

title: DAS-Net: a Unified Framework for High-Quality Interior CT Region-of-Interest Reconstruction
authors: J. Wang, H. Kudo
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Interior computed tomography reduces radiation exposure by limiting the X-ray projection data acquisition solely to a region of interest (ROI). However, due to the truncation of projection data, traditional reconstruction methods often result in severe cupping artifacts within the ROI. Existing methods have attempted to combine differentiated backprojection (DBP, an analytic reconstruction method based on backprojection) with convolutional neural networks(CNNs). Nevertheless, these approaches have not fully resolved issues related to insufficient image detail, necessitating further optimization. To further address these challenges, this study proposes an improved deep learning framework named DAS-Net. Building upon previous methods, DAS-Net incorporates two major innovations: (1) introducing ASUformer, a novel CNN architecture integrating a Transformer structure, Atrous Spatial Pyramid Pooling (ASPP), and a Sparse Coding Block, significantly enhancing the recovery of image details; and (2) combining the Simultaneous Algebraic Reconstruction Technique (SART) with neural networks, and designing two reconstruction strategies: (a) applying SART before the neural network, and (b) applying the neural network prior to SART. To evaluate the reconstruction performance of the proposed framework across varying ROI sizes, we conducted multi-scale data training and testing. Experimental results demonstrate that DAS-Net consistently achieves superior robustness and reconstruction performance for different ROI sizes. Specifically, the “neural network followed by SART” strategy is particularly effective in enhancing image detail recovery and data consistency. Compared with conventional methods, DAS-Net exhibits significant advantages in artifact suppression and detail fidelity, highlighting its substantial potential for clinical applications.

title: Deep Convolutional Generative Adversarial Network for Reducing Truncation Artifact in Stationary Digital Tomosyntehsis
authors: S. Lee, B. Kim, Y. Choi, G. Han
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Stationary digital tomosynthesis (sDT) causes truncation effects in projections due to limited scan fields-of-view (sFOVs), and consequently, induce artifacts in reconstructed images, In this study, a deep convolutional generative adversarial network (DCGAN) was proposed to reduce truncation artifacts in sDT images. The generator was constructed with an encoder-decoder architecture, and dilated convolution layers were added into the generator architecture for aggregating contextual features. Global and local discriminators were used to separately determine the reality of restored and non-truncated regions, and binary mask images were additionally input into the generator for differentiating truncated regions from non-truncated regions. The results showed that the proposed network sufficiently reduced truncation artifacts in sDT images. Also, the noise property and quantitative accuracy of sDT images were improved by the proposed network. In conclusion, the proposed DCGAN can be potentially used for improving the quality of sDT images and overcoming the issue of the sDT system.

title: A Simplified Method for Growing Organic Single Crystals
authors: A. V. Krech, I. F. Khromiuk, I. V. Lazarev, S. V. Makhota, S. S. Minenko, Y. I. Polupan, O. A. Tarasenko
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This work describes a simplified method for growing organic single crystals using the modified self-seeding vertical Bridgman method. The approach employed in this work differs from the widely known methods, such as the self-seeding vertical Bridgman (SSVB) method. In the known method SSVB, the crystal grows from a single point due to the sharp conical bottom of the ampoule, or the growth begins from an oriented seed. In our proposed method, spontaneous nucleation of the single crystal occurs at the crystallization front plane. This method does not require complex growth ampoules, significantly reduces the risk of raw material contamination, and shows promise for producing organic single crystals with a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\pi$</tex>-stacked crystalline structure. Crystals of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p$</tex>-terphenyl were grown using this method. This work investigates the scintillation and optical characteristics of these crystals. The results of studies show that the single crystals of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p$</tex> terphenyl, which were grown by the proposed method, exhibit the same light output and energy resolution as those grown by the classic Bridgman method. The light transmittance was nearly identical for crystals that grew using both methods. Therefore, this method is promising for obtaining <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$p$</tex>-terphenyl single crystals and other organic single crystals as well.

title: LEAF++: Trait-Annotated Essay Feedback Dataset with Validation of Trait Scores via LLMs
authors: Haile Misgna, Byung-Won On, Ingyu Lee, Gyu Sang Choi
abstract: The limited availability of essay feedback datasets with trait-level annotations has led research in essay evaluation to focus primarily on either automated essay scoring (AES) or feedback generation. In this paper, we introduce LEAF++, an extension of the Learner’s Essay and Feedback (LEAF) dataset, enriched with trait-level scores alongside the original feedback. These trait scores enable a detailed analysis of essay aspects and provide a basis for validating their relationship with feedback. To assess the dataset, we propose four LLM-based validation approaches. Score2Feedback examines whether trait scores guide LLMs to generate feedback similar to the reference feedback. Feedback2Score evaluates whether using reference feedback to revise an essay improves trait scores. FeedbackviaReference iteratively refines feedback, guided by trait scores, until it meets a minimum similarity threshold with the reference. FeedbackviaScore iteratively revises feedback until the revised essay achieves a higher score than the original. These strategies allow us to validate trait scores by measuring their impact on feedback generation and essay revisions, highlighting the relationship between trait-level scores and corresponding feedback. Our experiments using prompting (LLaMA-3, Mistral, Falcon-3, Phi-3) and fine-tuning (LLaMA-3, Mistral, and GPT-OSS) show that trait scores effectively guide LLMs to generate meaningful feedback. The results demonstrate that the annotated trait scores are meaningfully related to the corresponding essay feedback. LEAF++ Dataset: https://github.com/misgna/LEAF-plusplus.

title: Cross-Tracer Synthesis of ${ }^{\mathbf{1 1}}$C-CFT PET Images from ${ }^{18}$F-FDG Using a 3D Improved Denoising Diffusion Model for Parkinson's Disease Diagnosis
authors: W. Yi, H. Sun, X. Sun, X. Hong, Z. Ye, X. Niu, L. Jiang, L. Lu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{18}$</tex> F-FDG PET and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{11}$</tex> C-CFT PET images provide complementary diagnostic information for the early detection of Parkinson's disease (PD). However, the clinical application of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{11} \mathrm{C}$</tex>-CFT tracer is constrained by its complex synthesis process and high cost, while <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{18}$</tex> F-FDG continues to be one of the most widely utilized tracers in clinical practice. Given the constraints of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{11} \mathrm{C}$</tex>-CFT, there is a pressing need for alternative methods to obtain comparable diagnostic information. To address this challenge, the present study employs deep learning methods to synthesize <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{11} \mathrm{C}$</tex>-CFT images from real <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{18}$</tex> F-FDG PET scans, offering a novel auxiliary tool for diagnosing Parkinson's disease. A total of 69 subjects who underwent both <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{11} \mathrm{C}$</tex>-CFT and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{18}$</tex> F-FDG PET/CT brain scans were included in this study. Improved Denoising Diffusion Probabilistic Models (IDDPM) was implemented to synthesize <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{11} \mathrm{C}$</tex>-CFT PET images. Quantitative analysis was performed to evaluate the quality of the synthesized images, including Peak Signal-to-Noise Ratio (PSNR), Structural Similarity Index Metric (SSIM) and Normalized Root Mean Squared Error (NRMSE). PSNR, SSIM, and NRMSE values of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$36.215 \pm 2.653,0.960 \pm 0.017$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.016 \pm 0.005$</tex> were obtained for the synthesized and real <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{11}$</tex> C-CFT PET images, respectively. The proposed method is capable of synthesizing highquality <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{11} \mathrm{C}$</tex>-CFT PET images from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{18}$</tex> F-FDG PET images, providing effective auxiliary support for the diagnosis of Parkinson's disease in the absence of real <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{11} \mathrm{C}$</tex>-CFT PET images.

title: Customized Multi-Subject Text-to-Image Generation with Causal Tuning
authors: Chaoyang Li, Xin Wang, Wenwu Zhu, Lingzhi Wang, Ning Hu, Qing Liao
publish: IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems for Video Technology
abstract: Subject-driven text-to-image generation aims to generate customized high-fidelity images based on text descriptions for specific subjects, which has gained increasing attention. Despite recent advancements in single-subject customization, existing methods often struggle with multi-subject scenarios, leading to distortions in subject identity. This challenge arises because entangled identity-relevant and irrelevant information can obscure subject identities, and inter-subject interference can cause confusion or loss of individual identities. To address these issues, we propose CausalT2I, a customized multi-subject text-to-image generation framework with causal tuning. First, we propose a subject-aware causal disentanglement method, which can self-adaptively distinguish causally relevant and irrelevant information for subjects through causal intervention and a causal disentangled objective. Then, we design a soft cross-attention guidance strategy to mitigate interference among different subjects by aligning the textual attributes of each subject with its identity-relevant visual attributes. Last, we introduce a causal denoising objective to optimize the denoising process using identity-preserved textual embeddings and identity-irrelevant visual embeddings. Extensive experiments show that CausalT2I has superior generation ability in subject-driven text-to-image generation over existing baseline methods and brings more flexibility and controllability for generating customized multi-subject images.

title: MRM: Improving Multihop Reasoning Capability for LLMs With Multistage QA Retrieval
authors: Wei Li, Yanqing Zhang, Guifang Sun, Chao Ma, Jipeng Qiang, Jiaxing Shen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Emerging Topics in Computational Intelligence
abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) continue to face significant challenges in improving their reasoning capabilities, particularly for knowledge-intensive multi-hop questions. Existing approaches attempt to address this hurdle through generating reasoning procedures or retrieving additional knowledge, while encountering limitations. Conventional prompting methods often produce undesired reasoning traces, while retrieving pertinent knowledge from external data sources remains problematic. In this paper, we introduce a novel approach to enhance LLM reasoning capabilities: the Multistage Retrieval Method (MRM). It comprises two key components: plan design and implementation with retrieval, utilizing four specialized stages: Plan Stage, Extraction Stage, Reasoning Stage, and Output Stage. The MRM process begins by constructing a prompt with demonstration examples and an instruction, guiding to design a logically coherent multi-step plan in a standardized format in Plan Stage. To acquire the necessary knowledge for reasoning, we employ an innovative question-answer strategy by generating a question at each step, followed by document retrieval using vector-based methods. The retrieved documents and the generated questions are then fed into the Extraction Stage to extract relevant knowledge, which are utilized to execute the next step with Reasoning Stage. It helps mitigate the risk of acquiring irrelevant information by performing retrieval prior. We repeat this process until the final step of the plan, whereupon we input all extracted knowledge and the original question into the Output Stage to generate the final answer. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of MRM over SOTA methods, achieving the highest accuracy scores across both common-sense and symbolic reasoning tasks in four public datasets.

title: Target Defense Using a Turret and Mobile Defender Team
authors: Alexander Von Moll, Dipankar Maity, Meir Pachter, Daigo Shishika, Michael Dorothy
abstract: A scenario is considered wherein a stationary, turn constrained agent (Turret) and a mobile agent (Defender) cooperate to protect the former from an adversarial mobile agent (Attacker). The Attacker wishes to reach the Turret prior to getting captured by either the Defender or Turret, if possible. Meanwhile, the Defender and Turret seek to capture the Attacker as far from the Turret as possible. This scenario is formulated as a differential game and solved using a geometric approach. Necessary and sufficient conditions for the Turret-Defender team winning and the Attacker winning are given. In the case of the Turret-Defender team winning equilibrium strategies for the terminal distance of the Attacker to the Turret are given. Three cases arise corresponding to solo capture by the Defender, solo capture by the Turret, and capture simultaneously by both Turret and Defender.

title: Robust Federated Video-based Remote Physiological Measurement for Heterogeneous Multi-source Data_supp1-3643851.pdf
authors: Feiyue Huang
abstract: Remote photoplethysmography (rPPG) is a technology that uses facial video to capture physiological signals, namely photoplethysmography (PPG) signals, enabling convenient and low-cost non-contact physiolog ical measurement.
