Although current rPPG methods have achieved remarkable performance through extensive data training, they often ignore the transmission cost and privacy concerns of rPPG data. Federated learning (FL) pro vides a promising solution to these issues. However, effective federated training remains challenging due to the cross-domain heterogeneity that arises when using multi source rPPG data. To address these challenges, we characterize the heterogeneity of multi-source rPPG data from both the input and output domain perspectives. Motivated by this analysis, we introduce pseudo-labeling techniques and propose a novel FL framework, FedGRC. Specifically, we incorporate automatic gradient regularization calibration to mitigate the impact of input domain discrepancies on model performance. Furthermore, we leverage pseudo labels generated by handcrafted rPPG methods to align the output domain and reduce label inconsistencies across datasets. Our approach is validated across six publicly available datasets, demonstrating significant advantages over other approaches and effectively addressing the challenges of privacy protection and heterogeneity of multisource data.

title: Development of a Deep Junction LGAD for Soft X-Ray
authors: F. Capocasa, G. Giacomini, G. Pinaroli, A. K. Rumaiz, G. Carini
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In recent years, the technological capabilities of X-ray facilities have advanced rapidly; however, detector systems have struggled to keep pace-particularly in the soft X-ray regime ( 200 eV to 2 keV ). While hybrid pixel detectors have become the standard for higher energies ( 2-20 keV), their potential for soft X-ray applications is now being explored, owing to their high frame rates, wide dynamic range, large area coverage, and excellent signal-to-noise ratio. Low Gain Avalanche Diodes have emerged as promising candidates for this endeavor due to their moderate internal gain (typically 5-10), which may help overcome signal-to-noise challenges inherent to soft X-ray detection. Nevertheless, significant obstacles remain in fully leveraging LGAD technology at these lower energies. In this study, we introduce a novel sensor architecture - the Deep Junction LGAD which features a specifically tailored charge-absorbing region designed to ensure complete absorption of soft X-rays. This is followed by a gain layer that enables uniform signal amplification above the noise threshold of the readout electronics. We present the device design, simulation results, and preliminary static characterization, highlighting the potential of DJ-LGADs as a promising solution for next-generation soft X-ray detection.

title: Real-Time Spatiotemporal Tubes for Dynamic Unsafe Sets_supp1-3645667.mp4
authors: Ratnangshu Das
abstract: This paper presents a real-time control framework for nonlinear pure-feedback systems with unknown dynamics to satisfy reach-avoid-stay tasks within a prescribed time in dynamic environments. To achieve this, we introduce a real-time spatiotemporal tube (STT) framework. An STT is defined as a time-varying ball in the state space whose center and radius adapt online using only real-time sensory input. A closed-form, approximation-free control law is then derived to constrain the system output within the STT, ensuring safety and task satisfaction. We provide formal guarantees for obstacle avoidance and on-time task completion. The effectiveness and scalability of the framework are demonstrated through simulations and hardware experiments on a mobile robot and an aerial vehicle, navigating in cluttered dynamic environments.

title: Documentation Technology Features In Professional Learning Communities For Effective Schools In Indonesia And Malaysia
authors: Teguh Triwiyanto, Desi Eri Kusumaningrum, Raden Bambang Sumarsono, Zuraidah Binti Abdullah, Dandy Aditya Satriatama, Zoulhijjah Harinda Akhoba
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: This study aims to determine the features of documentation technology in professional learning communities for effective schools in Indonesia and Malaysia. The type of research is multi-case. Data were collected through interviews, observations, and documentation. Data analysis was carried out based on thematic categorization. Integration of documentation technology features into PLCs in schools across Indonesia and Malaysia has significant potential to improve educational effectiveness. Educators can develop a more collaborative, data-driven, and reflective teaching environment by utilizing digital collaboration platforms, video documentation tools, data collection systems, cloud storage, and interactive tools.

title: Improving Waste Management Reporting: A Business Process Improvement Approach for Social Enterprises
authors: Ivan Effendy, Intan Sartika Eris Maghfiroh, Buce Trias Hanggara
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: Liberty Society, a social enterprise focused on waste upcycling, struggles with accurate impact reporting due to inefficient manual and unstructured data collection processes. This research aims to enhance the efficiency, accuracy, and traceability of its waste processing reporting system through a Business Process Improvement (BPI) initiative. The methodology employs Failure Mode and Effect Analysis (FMEA) to identify high-risk activities, Bizagi Modeler for process simulation, and the Dashboard Assessment Usability Model (DATUS) for evaluation. The redesigned client interaction workflow demonstrated a 9.89% improvement in time efficiency. Although the production process duration did not decrease, the intervention successfully enhanced data accuracy and process control. The designed dashboard artifact achieved a high mean usability score of 4.35 out of 5, validating its effectiveness for end-users. This research provides a validated, technology-enabled system that creates a foundation for credible sustainability reporting and data-driven decision-making for upcycling social enterprises.

title: Enhancing Enterprise Learning: Activity-Centered Redesign of the PIPD LMS in a Financial Company
authors: Fabian Wirawan Mahmudin, Ati Suci Dian Martha
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: Learning Management Systems (LMS) are crucial for managing e-learning and employee training. However, most in-house LMS platforms often suffer from low usability, inefficient task flows, and poor visual design. This research presents the redesign of an LMS called Platform Informasi dan Pengetahuan Digital (PIPD), implemented in a financial services company referred to as Company X. The redesign was guided by the Activity-Centered Design (ACD) methodology, which focusses on designing systems based on user activity rather than profiles, making it particularly suited for structured work environments. The redesign process involved two iterations: first, a low-fidelity wireframe prototype that addressed layout and navigation issues, and second, a high-fidelity interactive prototype that focused on usability, aesthetics, and branding. Usability was evaluated using the System Usability Scale (SUS), the Single Ease Question (SEQ), task completion times, and success rates. Prior to the redesign, the SUS scores were 35 (Teacher) and 39.5 (Learner), indicating poor usability. Post-redesign, the scores improved significantly to 80 and 91.5, with SEQ averages exceeding 6.6 and a 100% success rate in task completion. Finally, the interactive prototype was tested using the same scenarios, followed by additional SUS and SEQ evaluations. The results illustrate that ACD markedly enhances the usability of enterprise-level LMS platforms. This study contributes to the literature by providing empirical usability testing conducted in a real-world organizational setting, confirming the effectiveness of ACD.

title: MV ASDS Application Integration Takeaways from Feed to EPC
authors: Mustafa Alhadad, Gautami Bhatt, Jon Nipar
publish: 2025 IEEE IAS Petroleum and Chemical Industry Technical Conference (PCIC)
abstract: Traditional Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) facilities utilize large gas turbines for process compression that produce a considerable amount of carbon emissions. With an increased interest in reducing carbon emissions for their facilities, many users are applying electrical driven machinery train. Further, many end users are considering replacing gas turbines with medium voltage Adjustable Speed Drive System (ASDS) running electric motors to drive the compressor. Medium voltage applications are using ASD for starting or continuous control of the motor, depending on process control. Successful execution and integration of this electrical process train within the plant and the overall power system require careful consideration for the layout, cooling medium, compressor package supplier capability, original equipment manufacturer (OEM) capabilities and effective interface management.The paper will provide general recommendations and guidelines, from an Engineering Procurement and Construction (EPC) perspective, based on the authors' experience with large drive projects, covering key considerations throughout the life cycle of the package - from the early engineering stages to the detailed design phase.

title: Efficient and Verifiable Attribute-Based Fuzzy Multi-Keyword Searchable Encryption
authors: Tian Yin, Peishun Liu, XueFang Wang, Hongxin Feng, YaShi Huang, Rongjia Han
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Attribute-Based Encryption enables fine-grained access control for cloud data sharing. However, most existing schemes rarely integrate Searchable Encryption or support fuzzy multi-keyword queries, which limits retrieval efficiency and may risk plaintext leakage. We propose a scheme combining Locality-Sensitive Hashing and Bloom filters, where ABE enforces access control and trapdoor keys restrict unauthorized queries. Indexes and trapdoors are encrypted via secure KNN, embedding keyword weights. Top-k results are retrieved using encrypted inner products. A binary index tree enables sublinear search, and a Merkle tree ensures result integrity. The scheme achieves efficient, verifiable multi-keyword fuzzy search with strong security against ciphertext-only and known-background attacks.

title: Advancing Automated Nematode Classification: A ConvNeXtV2-Based Approach for High-Accuracy Genus Identification
authors: Dzawil Uqul, Adhitya Nugraha, Ardytha Luthfiarta, Ika Novita Dewi, Lutfi Azis Hafiizhudin, Najma Amira Mumtaz
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Accurate genus-level identification of nematodes is critical for agricultural and ecological monitoring but represents a challenging fine-grained visual classification task due to subtle inter-class morphological differences. Existing deep learning benchmarks on the public I-Nema dataset show limited performance and significant misclassification between specific genera. This study addresses these limitations by proposing and evaluating a model based on the ConvNeXtV2 Tiny architecture, a modern convolutional neural network enhanced with a self-supervised pretraining strategy (FCMAE). A crucial part of our methodology is a targeted data pre-processing step to identify and remove cross-class duplicate images, thereby resolving known dataset ambiguities. Evaluated on a prepared 40-genus subset of the I-Nema dataset, our proposed model achieves a new state-of-the-art overall accuracy of 95.63%, significantly surpassing the previous benchmark of 86.78%. This work demonstrates that the combination of an advanced architecture with rigorous data cleaning is highly effective for this task and establishes a new, more reliable performance benchmark for automated nematode identification.

title: Graph Neural Network Technology Fusion Prediction Framework Based on Pre-training and Prompt Tuning
authors: Yuxuan Zhao, Shengnan Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Link prediction is a crucial task in graph analysis, widely applied in scenarios such as technology fusion prediction and recommendation systems. However, existing methods based on Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) often suffer from insufficient generalization ability and high training costs when applied to new domains or in data-sparse scenarios. Inspired by the "pre-training and fine-tuning" paradigm in the field of Natural Language Processing (NLP), we propose a novel framework—PromptLP—which integrates pre-training and prompt tuning into heterogeneous graph link prediction tasks.The framework consists of two stages: First, pre-training is conducted on large-scale heterogeneous graphs through a meta-path-based self-supervised link prediction task. Second, in downstream tasks, the pre-trained model is frozen, and only the lightweight prompt module is fine-tuned to adapt to specific tasks. To verify the effectiveness of the framework, we conducted experiments on academic datasets such as ACM and DBLP. The results show that PromptLP significantly outperforms baseline models and exhibits excellent performance and generalization ability in few-shot scenarios, demonstrating its great potential in graph link prediction.

title: Construction of Weak Classifiers and Optimized Implementation of QBoost Ensemble Model
authors: Jiarui Liu, Xiaoxin Wu, Yiwei Liao, Hui Peng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: QBoost, a quantum-inspired ensemble learning algorithm, has performance that depends on the quality of weak classifiers and efficiency of the optimization process. Existing methods suffer from insufficient diversity among weak classifiers and low efficiency in handling nonlinear data patterns, leading to unsatisfactory generalization ability. This study proposes a new weak classifier construction method based on pruned random decision trees-combined with a multi-objective optimized QBoost model-to fix these problems. Weak classifiers are constructed using random subspaces with adaptive tree pruning; this enhances diversity while cutting overfitting. For QBoost, the study introduces a multi-objective optimization framework to minimize classification loss and maximize weak classifier diversity at the same time, and uses an improved AdamW algorithm to speed up convergence. Experiments on KDD Cup 99, IMDb, and Covertype datasets show the proposed method hits $96.8 \%$ classification accuracy on KDD Cup 99- $\mathbf{3. 3 \%}$ higher than Gradient Boosting ($93.5 \%$) and $2.6 \%$ higher than standard QBoost ($94.2 \%$). Compared with standard QBoost, its training time drops by $37 \%$, and it keeps $89.7 \%$ accuracy under $15 \%$ feature noise-proving better robustness. These findings confirm the proposed method effectively improves classification performance, efficiency, and diversity.

title: AI-Powered Intrusion Detection with SHAP Explainability and Feedback Loop: A Modular Pipeline for Cyber Threat Classification
authors: Raj Kumar Myakala, Akhil Reddy Jagirapu, Vinithya Reddy Podduturi, Praveen Kumar Nagata, Sampath Lavudya, Sanjeev Kumar Pedhapally
publish: 2025 IEEE International Carnahan Conference on Security Technology (ICCST)
abstract: Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) are fundamental to protecting digital infrastructure against increasingly sophisticated cyber threats. While conventional machine learning approaches for IDS often suffer from limitations including static decision-making pipelines, inherent model opacity, and difficulty in adapting to novel attack vectors, this work introduces a novel, modular, interpretable, and adaptive AI pipeline for robust threat classification. Leveraging the well-established CICIDS2017 benchmark dataset, we construct an end-to-end framework that integrates high-performance Random Forest and XGBoost classifiers with SHAP (SHapley Additive exPlanations) for comprehensive feature attribution. Crucially, the pipeline incorporates a feedback-driven closed-loop mechanism enabling dynamic model retraining and adaptation to evolving threat landscapes. This integrated architecture not only achieves exceptionally high classification performance, with the XGBoost model yielding 99.96% accuracy and a 0.92 Macro F1-score across 15 diverse attack types, but also significantly enhances the transparency, maintainability, and real-world adaptability required for modern security operations. We provide detailed insights into model behavior and data characteristics through extensive SHAP analysis, t-SNE clustering visualizations, and a comprehensive class-wise performance breakdown, demonstrating the system's effectiveness in handling significant class imbalance and improving generalization. The resulting pipeline is engineered to be deployable, inherently interpretable, and ready for integration into production-scale cybersecurity environments, offering a significant step towards trustworthy and resilient AI-powered IDS.

title: Predicting Property Prices Using MLR, Gradient Boosting, and Random Forest: A Case Study in South Tangerang, Indonesia
authors: Aditya Muhammad Saputro, Ririn Ikana Desanti
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on New Media Studies (CONMEDIA)
abstract: Accurate property price prediction is crucial for supporting property market stakeholders (buyers, sellers, and developers) in making informed decisions in the real estate market. The study explores the utilization of three machine learning algorithms—Multiple Linear Regression (MLR), Gradient Boosting (GB), and Random Forest (RF)—to predict residential property prices in South Tangerang, Indonesia. A dataset comprising 17,454 listings was gathered through web scraping from Lamudi.co.id. The listings included important housing information such as land area, building size, number of rooms, and location. The study adheres to the CRISP-DM methodology, covering data preparation, modeling, and evaluation phases. Model performance was assessed using the coefficient of determination (R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) and Root Mean Squared Error (RMSE) metrics. The Random Forest model did better than the others, with a R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of 0.8011 and an RMSE of 536 million IDR. This means that it was able to accurately capture complex nonlinear interactions in the data. The Gradient Boosting model came next, with a good level of accuracy. The Multiple Linear Regression model did the worst. The best-performing model was used in a web app so that people could estimate property prices in real time. This study introduces a robust, data-driven property valuation system employing ensemble learning techniques, functioning as a practical reference for stakeholders and demonstrating the potential of machine learning in the Indonesian real estate market.

title: Mr Hardware Visibility in Non-Tof Nac Pet: Simulations and Measurements
authors: N. Jurjew, D. Atkinson, K. Thielemans
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The attenuation of PET gamma photons by magnetic resonance (MR) hardware is often neglected in reconstructed images. Particularly, this is the case for flexible RF coils, as their position and deformation can not be determined using standard, MR-based attenuation correction (AC) methods. However, it has been shown that this affects quantification especially near the patient's surface. Previous work to resolve this includes aligning a template-based µ-map to the coil position, using e.g. optical markers or MLAA reconstructions to determine location. As both methods have practical limitations, this motivates the search for alternative strategies to detect HW position.

title: YOLOv8n for Home Flower Health Detection: A Computer Vision Approach for Indoor Flower Monitoring
authors: Imelda Maretta Putri, Moch. Sjamsul Hidajat, Dibyo Adi Wibowo, Ichwan Setiarso, Didik Hermanto, Tri Esti Rahayuningtyas, Choerul Umam, Eko Hari Rachmawanto, Noorayisahbe Mohd Yaacob
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: This study applied YOLOv8n for real-time monitoring of plant health in home environments, enhancing indoor botanical care through AI-driven systems. Leveraging breakthroughs in computer vision and deep learning, the research extends object detection capabilities to residential plant diagnostics, utilizing YOLOv8n's precision and efficiency for practical deployment. The system was assessed using a specialized dataset of indoor plants affected by various health issues, including blights, black spots, downy mildew, and fungal infection. After preprocessing via RoboFlow's framework and multi-label annotations, experiments yielded mAP@0.5 of 0.489. The model also achieved a precision of 0.543 and a recall of 0.421, resulting in an F1 Score of approximately 0.474. The processing speed analysis indicates a throughput of approximately 214.6 frames per second or 4.7ms per image. These results position YOLOv8n as an effective solution for automated plant health tracking within smart home infrastructures. The work advances research in AI-powered plant diagnostics and highlights pathways for facilitating the incorporation of AI systems into domestic settings, promoting sustainable plant management through accessible technology.

title: Road Pothole Detection and Spatial Position Identification with Additional Distance Parameter Using YOLOv11
authors: Farhan Muzammil Yusuf, Faqih Hamami, Nur Ichsan Utama
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: Road damage, particularly potholes, remains a significant cause of traffic accidents and vehicle damage, while conventional monitoring methods relying on manual inspections are inefficient. This study proposes a pothole detection system using the YOLOv11 model with additional spatial position classification and distance estimation features. The model was trained using three dataset scenarios: a project-specific dataset, a mixed dataset without augmentation, and a mixed dataset with augmentation, where the third scenario achieved the best performance with 88.1% precision, 79.4% recall, and 86.8% mAP@0.5. In position classification, a 10% margin yielded the most balanced results, detecting 996 potholes as Left, 405 as Center, and 1024 as Right. However, distance estimation was found to be inconsistent due to the fixed pothole width assumption of 0.5 meters, as observed from the output video. The novelty of this research lies in extending pothole detection beyond binary identification by incorporating lane-based spatial information and preliminary distance estimation, which are often overlooked in prior works. These enhancements provide more contextual awareness for drivers and authorities, supporting safer navigation and better-informed road maintenance decisions. While the current approach shows promising performance, limitations in distance accuracy highlight the need for dynamic width estimation, integration with depth sensors, and broader testing under diverse road and environmental conditions. Overall, the proposed system demonstrates the potential of computer vision, particularly YOLOv11, to contribute to smarter transportation systems and proactive road safety management.

title: The Development of Model for Forecasting the Parameters of Energy Systems
authors: Andrey Preobrazhenskiy, Yuriy Preobrazhenskiy, Tatyana Avetisyan, Yakov Lvovich, Yuriy Klimenko, Ivan Tikhonov
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This paper examines the development of a model for forecasting changes in distributed energy system parameters over a specific period of time. When analyzing a distributed energy system, it is taken into account that it consists of multiple modules characterized by various parameters that differ from one another. Forecasting requires using data on individual local objects of the distributed energy system when solving the problem of further analysis of larger objects. The behavior of smaller modules determines the behavior of larger modules of the system. It is necessary to determine the overall behavior of the distributed energy system as the parameters of objects change over time and the internal connections between its components change. To this end, it is proposed to develop a model for forecasting the parameters of system objects. This model takes into account that variable parameters in small modules will directly influence changes in the values of parameters of larger modules. By using difference equations in calculations, the most optimal forecast of changes in the parameters of system objects is obtained. The calculation was performed taking into account the time-varying mathematical expectation. Therefore, the calculation results in a minimum root-mean-square error. The design and actual system capacities are examined. An energy loss forecast is made. The error in this forecast of changes in distributed energy system parameters is determined.

title: Efficient Regulation Modes for Overcharging of Compensation Converter Capacitors
authors: Valerii Boiko, Oleksandr Shkardun, Mykola Buryk
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The issue of ensuring high energy performance of compensation-type electric energy converters is investigated. It is shown that the use of a new generation of fully controlled devices in the switching link of compensation converters significantly expands the energy capabilities of these means of conversion technology. However, achieving the maximum possible reactive energy generation requires the development and application of certain modes of recharging the capacitors of the commutating link. The result of the conducted research is the determination of regulation modes recommended for practical application.

title: Exploring the Relationship Between Digital Behaviors and Critical Literacy Skills: A Study of Digital Literacies Among Indonesian Undergraduate Students
authors: Nur Hidayah, Nandang Rusmana, Hendra Hidayat, M. Ramli, Nur Eva, Fitri Wahyuni, Husni Hanafi, Nanda Alfan Kurniawan, Mila Yunita
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: The need assessment process measures students' needs to formulate a guidance and counseling program. The assessment process carried out by the Guidance and Counseling teacher includes an environmental assessment and an assessment of student development. However, several Guidance and Counseling teachers indicated that they experienced difficulties developing digital-based assessments that expressly referred to ecological assessments. This study aims at the effect of Hybrid Training to Improve Online Psychological Assessment Skills for Guidance and Counseling Teachers in Kediri City. This study uses a quasi-experimental quantitative research method with a one-group-posttest-only design. The subjects of this study were 40 counselors from 53 SMA, MA, and SMK in Kediri City. Assessment in this study includes project assessment and skills assessment. Measurements focus on the process and results of training through project assignments, and posttest measurements through skills tests need online review. The study results showed that the participant's skills in the online assessment were quite good in the process of training and the skills of the online need assessment.

title: Research on Embedded Real-time Computer Bus Status Delay Anomalies
authors: Kui Chen, Jin Ji, Keying Huang, Tianjia Wang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: This paper presents an in-depth study and analysis of a time delay anomaly observed during discrete state uploads in a specific embedded real-time computer system. It begins by introducing the system interconnection and the observed fault phenomenon. Subsequently, through meticulous analysis of fault data and the mechanism of the 1553B bus Built-In Test (BIT), the root cause of the fault is deduced and pinpointed. To further validate this conclusion, a dedicated test environment was designed to replicate the fault. Systematic experiments successfully reproduced the issue, confirming the accuracy of the analytical conclusion. Finally, targeted corrective measures are proposed and implemented. Practical verification confirms that these measures effectively resolve the time delay anomaly, thereby enhancing the real-time performance and reliability of system communication

title: XLinear: Frequency-Enhanced MLP with CrossFilter for Robust Long-Range Forecasting
authors: Xiang Ao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Time series forecasters are widely used across various domains. Among them, MLP(multi-layer perceptron)-based forecasters have been proven to be more robust to noise compared to Transformer-based forecasters. However, MLP struggles to capture complex features, resulting in limitations on capturing long-range dependencies. To address this challenge, we propose the XLinear, a MLP-based forecaster for long-range forecasting. Firstly, we decompose the time series into trend and seasonal components. For the trend component which contains long-range characteristics, we design EFA (Enhanced Frequency Attention) to capture long-term dependencies by leveraging frequency-domain operations. Additionally, a CrossFilter Block is proposed for the seasonal component to keep the model’s robustness to noise, avoiding the problems of low robustness caused by the attention mechanism. Experimental results demonstrate that XLinear achieves state-of-the-art performance on test datasets. While keeping the lightweight architecture and high robustness of MLP-based models, our forecaster outperforms other MLP-based forecasters in capturing long-range dependencies.

title: Comparative study of methods for detecting QRS in ECG signals
authors: Jhon Olave, Alexander Cerón
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Detecting the QRS complex is fundamental in the analysis of electrocardiographic signals since it allows to evaluate frequency, rhythm, arrhythmias and cardiac variability. This work evaluates three artificial intelligence architectures, LSTM recurrent networks, convolutional networks with residual memory and a hybrid model combining both for detecting and classifying of QRS complexes, in electrocardiograms recorded from Lead II. The paper describes the complete process, from dataset preparation and model training to implementation and interpretation of results.

title: LightGlue Improvement for Feature Matching: A Framework Balancing Efficiency and Accuracy
authors: Ruoyu Zhou, Xiaoyang Wang, Shuaiyuan Li, Chenyue Huo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: This paper proposes a lightweight feature matching method based on the LightGlue architecture, aiming to improve reasoning efficiency and deployment friendliness while maintaining matching accuracy. Specifically, the multi-head self-attention mechanism of the original model is first reconstructed, and the attention calculation with reduced complexity from O(n<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>d) to O(nd<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) is introduced to reduce the feature interaction overhead; secondly, the dynamic depth mechanism of the AGNN module is replaced with a fixed 7-layer structure to improve the certainty and deployment efficiency of the reasoning path. At the same time, in order to improve the matching robustness in the scene of perspective difference, the CFI module is introduced for feature enhancement and spatial attention guidance. The proposed method is systematically evaluated on a public dataset. Experimental results show that the reasoning speed and accuracy of the improved model are better than the original LightGlue, and it has higher practical application potential.

title: Comparative Analysis of Cloud and Fog Computing: Performance and Suitability in Different Scenarios
authors: Mykhailo Hunko, Andriy Kovalenko, Vitalii Tkachov
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: In today’s world of information technology and computing science, one of the most promising areas is the development and improvement of computer networks. Over the past decades, significant progress in this area has been observed due to the constant expansion of computing resources, as well as the development of new methods and algorithms for data processing. One of the important branches of computing science is fog computing, which is studied as a tool for modeling and analyzing systems with fuzzy data. Fog computing finds its application in many areas, including artificial intelligence, pattern recognition, decision making, and others. In this paper the specifics of building systems with fog computing were analyzed in detail, and the specifics of using polling networks, in particular sensor networks, were also considered. Various approaches to the integration of polling networks in the context of sensor technologies have been studied, which allows to increase the efficiency of data collection and transmission. Based on the obtained results, a method of organizing fog computing was developed, which takes into account the specifics of modern network architectures. A new architecture of the method is proposed, which contributes to improving the performance and reliability of the system due to the optimization of computing resources and ensuring more efficient data management. Mathematical experiments were also conducted to verify the effectiveness of the proposed solutions, which showed significant improvements compared to traditional methods.

title: Deep Learning with Physics-Corrected Histoimages for Accurate Scatter Correction in Long Axial Field-of-View PET Systems
authors: X. Zhang, L. He, H. Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Accurate scatter correction (SC) is critical for quantitative PET imaging, especially for long axial field-of-view (LAFOV) systems. To address the computational overhead of Monte Carlo simulation based SC, we propose a deep learning approach using physics-corrected histo-images.

title: Intelligent Decision Support Tools for Trouble-Free Operation of Power Transformers
authors: Vladimir Levin, Alexander Zelenskikh, Sofia Zelenskikh
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The article presents a unique ensemble of related mathematical models that form an instrumental basis for decision support to ensure trouble-free operation of oil-filled transformer equipment. The developed tools are for complex application in performing a number of tasks on operational (predictive) assessment of equipment condition and detection of individual defects before selecting adequate measures for their prevention and elimination. The following methods were used to develop digital models: statistical Bayesian classification of defects in oil-filled transformers based on the results of oil-dissolved gas analysis; fuzzy-logical inference for the formation and rules of making operational decisions; synthesis and analysis of tree events to identify undesirable outcomes, ranking cause-and-effect relationships, and determining the accuracy of the consequences of impacts on oil-filled transformer equipment. The advantages of the complex application of the developed digital models are considered in the group of high-voltage electrical networks of oil-filled transformers. The obtained results demonstrate the effectiveness of the developed intelligent toolkit and allow excluding its use in the decision support system for trouble-free operation of oil-filled transformers.

title: A Fine-Grained Garbage Collection Scheme for ZNS-SSD Storage Architecture
authors: Yuyan Zhang, Ping Xie
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: With the widespread adoption of Zoned Namespace Solid State Drives (ZNS-SSDs) in high-performance storage systems, traditional garbage collection (GC) mechanisms reveal significant limitations under ZNS’s sequential write constraints and zone management-such as high migration overhead, increased write amplification, and severe tail latency. This paper proposes a fine-grained segment-level garbage collection method, incorporating a migration-cost-aware parallel scheduling mechanism and an efficient data structure (segment-linked lists) to optimize GC performance. By dynamically evaluating data temperature, migration cost, and space conditions, the method intelligently selects appropriate data migration paths (physical migration or address remapping), effectively improving space utilization and system responsiveness of ZNS-SSDs.

title: Research and Design on the Method of Joint SpaceBased and Ground-Based Monitoring and Control for the Separation of High-Orbit Satellites and the InOrbit Phase
authors: Shaoshan Wang, Zhiyuan Feng, Jiayi Qi, Tong Yang, Zhengrui Cao, Weibai Sun
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: A method was designed to simultaneously track and control high orbit satellites through using TDRSS and instrumentation ship, and complete the tasks of satellite-launch vehicle separation and orbit segment measurement and control. The satellite and launch vehicle separation attitude was designed to ensure simultaneous tracking of TDRSS and instrumentation ship. The tracking situation of the instrumentation ship and TDRSS was calculated, and an application plan was studied and designed.

title: Hydrogen Build up in Subsea Cables Causing Hazardous Locations Inside Enclosures - A Case Study
authors: Ryan Wilson, Jaime Garza, Irina Vaseva
publish: 2025 IEEE IAS Petroleum and Chemical Industry Technical Conference (PCIC)
abstract: Phenomenon where hydrogen is building up in the conductors of subsea cables. A chemical reaction occurs in the cable causing hydrogen release between the strands of the conductors. The hydrogen travels along the conductor and is entering topside umbilical termination units (TUTU's). Installation of barrier style cable glands will not stop the transfer of the hydrogen into the enclosure as it is between the conductor strands. With the hydrogen entry into the enclosure it creates a hazardous environment; Cl D1 or Zone 0/1, inside the enclosure. There have been real life examples of where this phenomenon has caused medium voltage 6.6kV, 11 kV and 13.8kV enclosures to rupture. This paper looks at a real life example where an enclosure exploded on an offshore installation causing damages the possible causes for the hydrogen release inside the conductor of the subsea cables and the steps that can be taken with the enclosures to ensure rupturing internally cannot occur.

title: Sigmoid Affine Projection Algorithm with Fourth-Power Error Function
authors: XueLian Chang, Ying Gao, JunYing Mu, ShiFeng Ou
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: To enhance the performance of adaptive filtering algorithms in impulse noise environments, this paper proposes the Sigmoid Affine Projection Algorithm with Fourth-Power Error Function (SAPA-4th) by performing a fourth-power operation on the error function and combining it with the sigmoid affine projection algorithm. Due to the upper bound of the sigmoid function, it can reduce the interference of impulse noise, and the improved cost function has a stronger ability to suppress impulse noise. To further improve the performance of the algorithm, the idea of variable step size is introduced into this algorithm, and the variable step-size Sigmoid Affine Projection Algorithm with Fourth-Power Error Function (VSS-SAPA-4th) is proposed. its step size update formula is derived by calculating the optimal step size and integrating the time-averaging method. Simulation results demonstrate that both algorithms outperform other AP-type algorithms in terms of convergence and tracking performance under impulse noise.

title: Hierarchical and Multiscale Intracranial Hematoma Segmentation Method Based on Attention Mechanism
authors: Qingzhou He, Kai Gao, Qiannan Li, Bo Gong
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: This paper presents a hierarchical and multiscale intracranial hematoma segmentation method based on the attention mechanism. The aim is to enhance the accuracy and reliability of the segmentation of intracranial hematoma CT images. The steps are as follows: constructing a network model, preparing a dataset, training the network model, evaluating the network performance, fine-tuning the model, and saving the model. This method integrates the local feature extraction ability of convolutional neural networks and the characteristics of the Transformer model, which is proficient in capturing long-range dependencies and global context. It effectively improves the accuracy and efficiency of the segmentation of intracranial hematoma CT images, providing a more reliable auxiliary means for the clinical diagnosis of patients with cerebral hemorrhage.

title: A Reversible Network Video Steganography Model Based on 3D Global Attention
authors: Qianhui Xu, Niu Ke, Shunzhe Zhu, Gao Bo, Yihang Lu
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: This paper proposes a reversible neural network video steganography framework, GAB3D-VSN, based on an enhanced 3D global attention mechanism (GAB3D). Addressing the insufficient expression of dynamic scene features in video steganography, GAB3D captures spatio-temporal key regions with intense motion and complex texture via joint modeling. It dynamically adjusts feature fusion between carrier and secret videos through adaptive weight allocation, suppressing redundant information and enhancing steganographic capacity. Experiments on small-scale datasets show that GAB3D-VSN improves PSNR, SSIM, and VIF metrics by 0.17 dB, 1.72%, and 2.89% respectively, compared to the baseline model, with excellent visual imperceptibility. Systematic ablation studies further demonstrate the synergistic optimization between the 3D attention mechanism and the reversible network architecture, validating the model's effectiveness.

title: Enhancing Neural Architecture Search with LLM-Based Autonomous Agents for Efficient Network Optimisation
authors: Qifan Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel Neural Architecture Search (NAS) framework powered by Large Language Model (LLM)-based autonomous agents. The method integrates self-consistent architecture generation, role-based agent collaboration, and a memory stream for iterative refinement. By simulating structured dialogues between a Strategic Director and a Technical Analyst, the system enables autonomous design exploration and decision-making without human input. A case study on short-term electricity load forecasting demonstrates the framework’s effectiveness, where the final model—developed through iterative reasoning—achieves a 9.2% reduction in MAE, 7.4% reduction in RMSE, and 32% fewer parameters compared to baseline architectures. The results highlight the framework’s ability to generate efficient, high-performing models while maintaining adaptability and interpretability. This approach offers a scalable solution for automated deep learning design and can be extended to other domains requiring efficient and context-aware model optimisation.

title: DTI versus NODDI White Matter Microstructural Biomarkers of Alzheimer’s Disease
authors: Kenny Liou, Sophia I. Thomopoulos, Hannah Yoo, Yuhan Shuai, Sasha Chehrzadeh, Arvin Arani, Bret Borowski, Robert I. Reid, Clifford R. Jack, Michael W. Weiner, Neda Jahanshad, Paul M. Thompson, Talia M. Nir
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Diffusion MRI (dMRI) is a powerful tool to assess white matter (WM) microstructural abnormalities in Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The fourth phase of the Alzheimer’s Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) now includes multiple multishell dMRI protocols, enabling both traditional and advanced dMRI model analyses. There is a need to evaluate whether multishell data offer deeper insights into WM pathology in AD than more widely available single-shell data by overcoming single-shell model limitations. Here, we fit single-shell DTI and multishell NODDI to dMRI data from 533 ADNI3/4 participants to assess their association with key clinical indicators of AD such as cognitive impairment, amyloid-beta and tau PET burden. Overall, we found that NODDI showed comparable associations with cognitive impairment and tau pathology, but somewhat stronger relationships with amyloid pathology.

title: Telecom Bank Card Fraud Risk Prediction Based on CNN-LSTM Model
authors: Xianhao Li
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Digital Management (ICAIDM)
abstract: With the development of the internet, telecom fraud methods are becoming increasingly common. To address the continued prevalence of telecom and bank card fraud, which causes financial losses to consumers, this paper proposes a telecom and bank card fraud risk prediction method based on the CNN-LSTM model. First, the correlation between indicators such as the distance between the bank card transaction location and the residence and whether the transfer was made via bank card was analyzed. Then, the data was predicted using traditional model and CNN-LSTM hybrid model. Comparative analysis of the traditional model and the CNN-LSTM model, including accuracy and other evaluation metrics, revealed that the CNN-LSTM model was more effective in predicting telecom fraud risk, achieving an accuracy rate of 99.69%.

title: Knowledge Distillation via View Alignment
authors: Lin Li, Jian Dong
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: Knowledge distillation (KD) stands out as an effective model compression technique, allowing the transfer of information from large, highly accurate networks to lightweight models that are more suited for real-world deployments. Despite considerable progress with logits-based and feature-based distillation approaches, challenges such as teacher overconfidence and confirmation bias still hinder knowledge transfer. Drawing inspiration from cross-view learning paradigms, this work introduces a novel view alignment-based KD method. By integrating both same-view and cross-view alignment strategies into the distillation process, we significantly alleviate the aforementioned issues. Experiments on benchmark datasets such as CIFAR-100 and ImageNet show that our method surpasses conventional KD techniques in terms of accuracy and robustness.

title: Analysis and Visualization of Earthquake Patterns (2021-2025) in the South Lebak Region Based on the Dataset from Gugus Mitigasi Lebak Selatan
authors: Gilbert Evan Tilung, Niki Prastomo, Anis Faisal Reza
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on New Media Studies (CONMEDIA)
abstract: This study investigates earthquake patterns in South Lebak, Indonesia, using the official dataset provided by Gugus Mitigasi Lebak Selatan (GMLS) covering April 2021–April 2025. Three key parameters—magnitude, depth, and epicentral distance to Panggarangan Village—were analyzed after a preprocessing stage to ensure data completeness and consistency. Visual analyses included bar charts, two-dimensional and three-dimensional scatter plots, and geospatial overlays with tectonic plate boundaries. The results showed that shallow earthquakes (<70 km) with micro-to-small magnitudes (M 2–4) dominate the seismic profile and are concentrated within 160 km of the reference point. Intermediate- and deep-focus events were infrequent, while moderate-to-strong earthquakes occurred sporadically but remained critical owing to their potential impact on nearby communities. Clustering patterns broadly align with the southeastward motion of the Eurasian Plate, although the 2025 distributions appeared more scattered. A key contribution of this study is the integration of interactive visualizations into the GMLS platform, enabling local stakeholders and communities to directly explore seismic data in real time. This approach not only strengthens earthquake risk communication but also provides a replicable model for community-based disaster preparedness in tectonically active regions.

title: Calibration of Deterministic Errors in Accelerometer Data of Commercial IMU System
authors: Gabriel Ramírez-Larrarte, Sebastián Jaramillo-Isaza, Jefferson-Steven Sarmiento-Rojas, Pedro-Antonio Aya-Parra
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: This paper calibrates deterministic errors in accelerometer data from 20 commercial Movella DOT IMUs across four institutions. Applying Jeff Ferguson’s calibration of deterministic errors through a six-point tumble test, we assess accuracy and precision. The results show fixed bias/offset as the dominant error, with larger errors in the z axis. Calibration significantly improves precision and accuracy for gravity-aligned measurements, regardless of institution or axis. Although less effective near-zero values due to sensor sensitivity, this research confirms the method’s effectiveness for enhancing IMU data reliability.

title: Dynamic Evolution Model of Multilayer Combat Network for Command and Communication
authors: Chenhao Ye, Shiluo Guo, Jinyin Bai, Peng Zheng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Modern warfare imposes more stringent requirements on the cross-domain collaborative speed of combat units, making it imperative to deeply explore the coupling mechanism of combat command and control (C2) and combat communication networks. Aiming to address the limitation that existing research fails to comprehensively depict the internal relationships between the two networks, this study constructs a C2-communication multilayer network evolution model, which is analyzed using metrics such as network density, average shortest path length, and average clustering coefficient. The findings reveal that: The average shortest path length of both networks increases with the rise in node addition probability and the decline in edge addition probability. The average clustering coefficient decreases as the node addition probability increases and the edge addition probability decreases. Meanwhile, the inter-layer similarity and edge overlap between the two networks remain essentially constant, suggesting that despite the differences between the communication network and C2 network, they exhibit a certain degree of synchrony during the evolutionary process.

title: Improvement Stock Price Forecasting with a Hybrid Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) and Transformer Model
authors: Muh Akhirudin Fajar Santoso, Guruh Fajar Shidik, Abdul Syukur, Farrikh Alzami
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: This research introduces an enhanced model for predicting stock prices by combining Long Short-Term Memory (LSTM) with a Lightweight Transformer. This hybrid model leverages the sequential pattern recognition capabilities of LSTM with the attention mechanism of the Transformer to improve prediction accuracy. In addition, the ReduceLROnPlateau scheduler is utilized to optimise the learning rate. The suggested model is assessed using stock price data from IBM, INTC, AMZN, and CSCO over a 20-year period. The results demonstrate enhanced performance assessed through Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), Mean Squared Error (MSE), and the R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> Score compared to conventional models. In comparison to standard forecasting models, such as standalone LSTM, CNN-LSTM, CNN-BiLSTM-ECA, and traditional Transformer, the proposed hybrid LSTM-Transformer model demonstrates superior performance [11], [16]- [18] with improvements of up to 29.2% in several evaluation metrics. The primary achievement of this research is the creation of an enhanced hybrid model that effectively captures long-term temporal trends and prioritizes significant aspects of the data, resulting in improved accuracy in predicting stock prices.

title: YOLOv8 based model for Ukrainian license plate recognition
authors: Andrii Podorozhniak, Roman Puhachov, Nataliia Liubchenko, Daryna Lisova
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: This work addresses the problem of automatic license plate recognition using computer vision and machine learning methods. An analysis of existing approaches to Ukrainian’s license plate recognition was conducted, an optimal neural network architecture was selected, and a software solution was implemented. The proposed system employs modern deep learning algorithms based on YOLOv8 for license plate detection in images and subsequent processing. Image preprocessing, license plate segmentation, and optical character recognition of characters have been implemented. The model was trained using a dataset containing real vehicle images. The proposed solution can be applied in automated parking control systems, road safety enforcement, and law enforcement agencies.

title: Model-Free Hybrid Position and Impedance Control for Upper Limb Rehabilitation Robot
authors: Mawloud Aichaoui, Ameur Ikhlef
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: This paper introduces a novel model-free hybrid position and impedance control strategy for a 2-DOF upper limb rehabilitation robot. The approach dynamically switches between precise trajectory tracking and adaptive compliance based on external interaction forces. Unlike conventional impedance control methods, our strategy employs an integrated switching mechanism that seamlessly transitions from model-free position control, ensuring accurate movement, to model-free impedance control for safe patient interaction. Validation through trajectory tracking simulations, compared with traditional impedance control techniques, shows that the proposed method maintains high precision under minimal external forces while adapting to higher interaction torques. This work offers a promising solution for rehabilitation robotics by simultaneously enhancing accuracy and safety.

title: UAVNet: Explore High-Resolution Semantic Segmentation for UAV
authors: Xing Gong, Jigang Lv, Xiaoman Zhang, Shijiao Han, Ye Huang, Lixin Duan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: Semantic segmentation is a fundamental computer vision task, enabling pixel-level understanding of visual scenes for applications ranging from autonomous systems to aerial monitoring. However, applying semantic segmentation to high-resolution UAV imagery presents unique challenges, including extreme resolutions, complex backgrounds, and severe class imbalance, which existing methods struggle to address effectively. In this work, we propose UAVNet, a novel architecture specifically designed for high-resolution UAV semantic segmentation. UAVNet introduces three key innovations: (1) a transformer decoder-enhanced classifier that dynamically adapts to complex aerial views by generating sample-specific classifiers during training; (2) a high-level feature guidance mechanism to prevent noise propagation during upsampling; and (3) A tailored training paradigm incorporating whole-image cropping and random rotation to address challenges posed by extreme resolutions and varying angles. Extensive experiments on the Semantic Drone dataset demonstrate UAVNet’s superiority, achieving state-of-the-art performance with an 82.65% mIoU, significantly outperforming state-of-the-art methods. Our work bridges the gap between ground-level segmentation models and the unique demands of UAV imagery, enabling fine-grained aerial scene understanding.

title: Adaptation of the Sophia Optimizer for Training Physics-Informed Radial Basis Function Networks
authors: Dmitry Stenkin, Vladimir Gorbachenko
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This study presents a methodology for simulating flow in a lid-driven square cavity using physics-informed radial basis function networks. The simulation is performed by means of three independent radial basis function networks: two for velocity components and one for pressure. These networks are coupled through a common error functional that incorporates the sum of squared residuals of the governing equations and boundary conditions. Gaussian functions are employed as radial basis functions. For training the physics-informed radial basis function networks, the Sophia optimizer has been adapted, which updates not only the network weights but also the parameters of the radial basis functions, using a simplified diagonal approximation of the Hessian. In addition, first-order optimization methods—gradient descent, Nesterov accelerated gradient, and ADAM—as well as the second-order Levenberg– Marquardt algorithm have been adapted for training. These methods also adjust both network weights and radial basis function parameters. The adapted Sophia optimizer demonstrated higher accuracy compared to first-order methods. Although it requires more iterations than the Levenberg–Marquardt algorithm, it achieves comparable computational efficiency by eliminating the need to solve linear systems at each step. Specialized extensions to the TensorFlow library have been developed to implement radial basis function layers, loss functions, and the customized training algorithm.

title: Document-Level Semantic Analysis of Uzbek Texts— Scheme, Benchmark, and Reproducible Results
authors: Saidbek Babayazov, Lola Samandarova, Mohira Matnazarova, Umidbek Babayazov, Khurshida Qodirova, Shukhrat Khudayberganov
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This work presents a practical document-level semantic annotation scheme for the Uzbek language and two target datasets of 1200 and 1500 documents designed for three tasks: topic classification (THEME/SUB), communicative function (FUNC), and concise abstractive summarization (one sentence). We release a reproducible pipeline (70/15/15 splits, training and evaluation scripts, report templates) and demonstrate reference results on a synthetic 2700-document stand that mirrors the size and class distributions of the intended corpora. Strong baselines based on TF-IDF+LR/SVM reach high accuracy for THEME and FUNC; a multilingual Transformer (XLM-R/DistilBERT) further improves performance on borderline cases. For summarization, we compare an extractive centroid against an abstractive mT5-small model constrained to a single sentence. Methodologically, our scheme relies on clear guidelines and a pilot double-annotation with Cohen’s κ; engineering-wise, it favors transparent protocols and low-cost baselines, making the solution appropriate both for production systems and for scholarly assessment.

title: News Recommendation System Using a Combination of Content-Based Filtering and Singular Value Decomposition to Improve the Relevance of Recommendations
authors: Maharani Salsabila Alysa Putri, Z. K. A. Baizal
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: Finding relevant news is becoming increasingly difficult for users. Currently, people often experience information overload due to the abundance of online news sources available, making it difficult for them to select news that interests them. To address this issue, a news recommendation system is needed to help users select news that aligns with their preferences. Based on previous research, the developed recommendation systems still have limitations, such as reliance on ratings or features without dimensionality reduction, text vector similarity measurement, or recommendations based solely on users’ previous behavior. Therefore, we propose a more comprehensive approach by combining Collaborative Filtering, which builds a model based on user behavior, and Content-Based Filtering, which builds a model based on item descriptions and preference profiles. We apply the Singular Value Decomposition method to find the latent representation of user interactions, as well as cosine similarity to measure the similarity between items or users. The evaluation results show that the hybrid method achieved a recall of 0.66, a precision of 0.40, and an F1-score of 0.46. Meanwhile, single methods such as Collaborative Filtering achieved a recall of 0.53, precision of 0.32, and an F1-score of 0.40, while Content-Based Filtering achieved a recall of 0.60, precision of 0.36, and an F1-score of 0.45. The results of this study show that the hybrid method is effective in news recommendation systems with good ability to identify relevant information.

title: Health Prediction for Main Reducer Gears of New Energy Vehicles Based on a CNN-LSTM Fusion Model
authors: Zhonghua Pang, Junhong Yang, Dongchen Qin
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning, Pattern Recognition and Automation Engineering (MLPRAE)
abstract: To address the difficulty in identifying early-stage faults in main reducer gears of new energy vehicles under variable load and high-speed conditions, a health prediction method based on a CNN-LSTM fusion model is proposed. Wavelet denoising is performed on the vibration signal to extract multi-domain features. A CNN extracts local features, and an LSTM captures temporal patterns, enabling collaborative prediction of remaining useful life (RUL) and fault level. Bench tests show that this method achieves an MAE of 2.1h and an RMSE of 2.8h in RUL prediction, representing reductions of 53.3% and 44.7% compared to the individual CNN and LSTM methods, respectively. The fault classification accuracy is 96.8% and 96.5%, significantly improving the SVM and BP networks. In noise robustness testing, the Accuracy (ACC) fluctuates by only 7% when the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) is reduced to 10dB. In small-sample experiments, the Accuracy (ACC) remains at 89.3% with only 20 samples per class, outperforming the competing models. The CNN-LSTM MAE fluctuation at different speeds is less than 15%, demonstrating its stability and application potential under complex operating conditions.

title: Design of Weather Station System for UAV Operation Orchard Based on RK3568B2
authors: Luyu Zhang, Shuangling Wang, Jianhang Zeng, Zeping Fang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: When UAV is working in orchard, it is necessary to monitor the meteorological data to ensure the safety and effectiveness of operation. Therefore, this paper designs a UAV orchard operation weather station system based on RK3568B2 and Android application. The weather station system has realized the functions of measuring and displaying meteorological data of wind speed, wind direction, temperature, humidity and pressure. It uses RK3568B2 development board as the core board, and uses a small ultrasonic integrated sensor to measure meteorological data. The system is equipped with a 5.5-inch display/touch screen for displaying meteorological information data and user interaction. In the Android Studio environment, the Android application software (APP) of the weather station is developed. The system provides accurate meteorological data support for UAV operation and assists UAV to adjust operation planning in real time. Therefore, the research content is of great significance not only in reducing the operation risk, reducing the failure rate and improving the operation efficiency, but also in promoting the popularization and application of UAVs in orchards.

title: IEEE RP 1017.4 - A Brand-New ESP Motor Standard
authors: Robert A Durham, Sean Cain, Pruitt Durham, M. O. Durham
publish: 2025 IEEE IAS Petroleum and Chemical Industry Technical Conference (PCIC)
abstract: The IEEE 1017 family of standards was the first group of IEEE standards sponsored by the PCIC. IEEE 1017, 1018 and 1019 (now 1017.1, 1017.2, 1017.3) were originally published in 1984 and covered standardized practices for manufacturing and testing electrical submersible pump (ESP) cable. Now, after forty years, a new standard covering the rating and testing of ESP Induction Motors has been completed. This paper contains an overview of the practices standardized in 1017.4, including topics such as electrical and mechanical measurements taken during testing, routine tests, motor design performance tests, efficiency tests, test equipment, motor model and design parameters, surge comparison testing, vibration analysis and dynamic balancing, thermal insulation rating and general characteristics of connected drives.

title: WS-SAM: Segment Anything with Sparse Prompts for Weakly-Supervised Medical Segmentation
authors: Tal Shaharabany, Lior Wolf
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Foundation models such as the Segment Anything Model (SAM) demonstrate strong generalization in natural image segmentation but underperform in medical imaging domains, where labeled data are limited and expensive to obtain. In this work, we propose a weakly supervised training framework that adapts SAM to medical images using only sparse point annotations. Our approach constructs foreground and background token banks from training images and generates pseudo-labels for new samples via similarity in SAM’s encoder space. We fine-tune the mask decoder while keeping the image and prompt encoders frozen. To guide training and checkpoint selection, we introduce a novel score that correlates with segmentation quality without requiring ground truth. Our method eliminates the need for dense annotations or prompts at inference time, enabling fast and automated segmentation. Experiments on microscopy datasets demonstrate that our approach significantly outperforms baselines and achieves competitive performance relative to fully supervised methods.

title: Plant Growth Prediction Using Machine Learning: TIS Case Study
authors: Gatot Santoso, Hilal Huda, Agung Toto Wibowo
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: This study investigates the development of an intelligent control system to optimize plant growth within Temporary Immersion Systems (TIS) by integrating Internet of Things (IoT) technology and machine learning (ML) algorithms. TIS has emerged as a promising approach for in vitro plant cultivation, offering improved nutrient uptake and aeration compared to conventional methods. However, its efficiency depends heavily on precise control of environmental and physiological parameters such as temperature, humidity, immersion frequency, and nutrient circulation. To address this challenge, the proposed system employs IoT-based sensors for real-time monitoring and data collection, which are then analyzed through ML algorithms to predict and regulate plant growth. Several algorithms were applied, including Gradient Boosting, Random Forest, K-Nearest Neighbors (KNN), and Support Vector Machine (SVM). Among these, Gradient Boosting achieved the highest prediction accuracy, with an R-square value of 0.8711 for node number, indicating its superior ability to model plant growth dynamics. The adaptive control enabled by this approach provides not only scientific insights into plant development but also practical benefits such as reduced cultivation time, enhanced plantlet survival, and increased growth rates. Beyond technical outcomes, the study highlights the broader implications of adopting IoT-ML integration in TIS, including economic efficiency, resource sustainability, and scalability for industrial and research applications. The ultimate objective is to establish a robust and intelligent cultivation framework that leverages real-time data and predictive modeling to accelerate plant propagation and improve overall plantlet vigor.

title: Medical Radioisotope Production with Laser-Driven High-Repetition-Rate Proton Sources
authors: M. Ricks, M. Gauthier
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We present a compact system for producing medical radioisotopes using high-repetition-rate laserdriven proton beams. While cyclotrons remain the clinical standard, they are infrastructure-heavy machines optimized for fixed-energy operation and a narrow range of isotopes. This rigidity restricts access to emerging, short-lived radionuclides critical for novel imaging and therapy procedures.

title: Enhancing LoRa Encryption with Post-Quantum Algorithms for IoT Security
authors: Andrii Storozhko, Sergii Kibitkin, Olga Vilkhivska, Dmytro Pecherytsia, Tetiana Andriushchenko
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The growing demand for secure, long-range wireless communication in the Internet of Things (IoT) has led to widespread adoption of LoRa technology. However, traditional LoRa implementations remain vulnerable to quantum computing attacks. This paper proposes the integration of post-quantum cryptographic algorithms, specifically Niederreiter encryption and LDPC codes, into LoRa systems to enhance their resilience. We explore the theoretical foundation of these algorithms, practical implementation strategies, and their impact on system performance. Experimental results and security analyses validate the feasibility of this approach, establishing a pathway for future-proof secure communication in LoRa-based IoT networks.

title: Modeling Visible Light Communication Channels for Reliable Data Transmission in Medical Monitoring Systems
authors: Svetlana Grigoryeva, Olga Shvets, Aslima Alimkhanova, Anar Bolatova, Smagzanov Nurzhan
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The rapid advancement of medical technologies is driving the demand for reliable, energy-efficient, and secure systems capable of real-time health monitoring. The widespread deployment of light-emitting diode lighting systems opens up opportunities for the implementation of promising wireless optical communication technology - Visible Light Communication. This technology transmits data via visible light and offers several advantages over radio-frequency solutions. In the context of medical applications, this is high throughput, data privacy, and the absence of electromagnetic interference on the operation of sensitive medical equipment. However, its implementation is constrained by the requirement for a direct line-of-sight between the receiver and transmitter, and high sensitivity to external optical interference. The study presents models in line-of-sight and no-line-of-sight conditions indoors to assess data transmission parameters and identify factors affecting communication reliability. Using the OptiSystem simulation platform, the effect of emission and incidence angles, along with multipath signal propagation caused by surfaces reflections, we analyzed. The results allowed the determination of optimal emission and incidence angles ranges, and the assessment of the influence of the receiver field-of-view on system throughput. The findings can be applied to the design and integration Visible Light Communication technology into medical applications, including mobile and stationary monitoring systems.

title: Detection of Optimal Echocardiographic Video Segments Using Deep Learning
authors: I. Perez-Ruiz, J. Perez-Gonzalez, A. Carrera-Pinzón, Romero E., Ruiz H., Benitez Y., Arambula Cosio F.
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: The identification of optimal echocardiographic video segments is a critical initial step for reliable cardiac function assessment. This study focuses on the development and evaluation of deep learning models for the automated classification of correct versus incorrect echocardiographic planes in a video sequence, specifically for Subcostal Four-Chamber (S4C) views. A dataset comprising 10 S4C studies was used, from which frames were extracted and preprocessed. Preprocessing included metadata removal, resizing to 224×224 pixels, and data augmentation. The resulting images were divided into training (2068 images per class), validation (517 images per class), and test (200 images per class) sets. Two convolutional neural network architectures, VGG-16 and Vision Transformer (ViT), were trained and evaluated. The VGG-16 model, trained for 30 epochs, achieved a test accuracy of 0.98 and an Area Under the ROC Curve (AUC) of 1.00. The Vision Transformer, trained for 30 epochs, yielded a test accuracy of 0.89 and an AUC of 0.97. These preliminary results demonstrate the potential of deep learning models, particularly VGG-16, to accurately identify optimal frames in echocardiographic video sequences.

title: Performance comparison and research of feature extraction algorithms for small sample electronic signature datasets
authors: Hongmei Cui, JiaJing Lin, Miao Li, Xinhong Jiang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: To address the typical difficulty of "many categories and few samples" in electronic signature scenarios, this paper systematically compares the recognition performance of three algorithms: random forest (RF), support vector machine (SVM), and multi-layer perceptron (MLP), using data from 104 users, with five signatures per user. Experiments show that RF achieves the best performance in terms of macro harmonic mean F1 (0.59) and accuracy (0.77), and is insensitive to feature scaling. MLP follows closely behind (0.71), leveraging its nonlinear representation capabilities, but requiring regularization and data augmentation. SVM suffers from both kernel parameter limitations and small sample sizes, with accuracy dropping to 0.37. This paper proposes an improved approach for the implementation of electronic signature handwriting identification in forensic authentication, providing a replicable paradigm for small-sample signature recognition.

title: DEA-based assessment of technical efficiency of Chilean hospitals before and during COVID-19
authors: Dominique Osswald-Dinamarca, José Lillo-Vidal, María Fuentes-Cofré, Benjamín Hernández-Méndez, Manuel Villalobos-Cid
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Health systems worldwide faced extreme pressure during the COVID-19 pandemic, revealing deficits in their capacity to manage limited resources, provide service continuity, and respond to changing healthcare needs. In publicly funded systems, where financial and structural constraints are significant, ensuring hospital efficiency is essential. Technical efficiency (TE) commonly refers to how effectively a hospital utilises its available resources to deliver healthcare services, either by producing the highest possible level of services with existing resources or by using fewer resources to deliver the same services. Although many studies have applied Data Envelopment Analysis (DEA) to evaluate TE and identify areas for improvement, most have focused on small samples or specific periods, and national-level assessments remain limited. This study analyses the TE of 152 public Chilean hospitals between 2014 and 2023, covering both pre-pandemic and pandemic periods. The DEA method was used to estimate annual efficiency scores, and a machine learning model examined over 7,000 hospital-level variables per year to identify the determinants associated with TE performance. Results indicate that efficiency remained generally stable, with a temporary decline in 2020 followed by a subsequent improvement, particularly among lower-complexity hospitals. Key contributing factors included emergency services, diagnostic activities, surgical care, and organisational coordination. These findings support the use of integrated analytical approaches to monitor hospital performance and inform evidence-based health policy decisions in Chile and similar healthcare systems.

title: Research on UAV Path Planning Strategies Based on Particle Swarm Optimization and Its Improved Algorithms
authors: Daran Deng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: In recent years, with the rapid development of UAV technology, path planning, a key challenge in autonomous navigation, remains a critical issue for the industry. UAVs often operate in complex environments, requiring a balance between safety, efficiency, path length, and other factors. Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) has been widely applied in this field due to its strong search capabilities. This study tested four algorithms— standard PSO, linear inertia weight PSO, PSO with added mutation particles, and Genetic Algorithm (GA)—in simulated mountainous terrains with 5, 10, and 20 peaks (representing simple, medium, and complex environments respectively), with 5 dynamic obstacles added in each environment to simulate real-world conditions. By analyzing the performance of these algorithms in terms of optimal fitness (reflecting path quality) and convergence speed (indicating computational efficiency), the research explored the applicability of traditional PSO and its improved variants in UAV path planning.
