The results provide a basis for selecting appropriate particle swarm algorithms for UAV path planning under different flight environments and mission requirements.

title: ECG-Driven Cardiovascular Risk Prediction
authors: Juliana V. Castilla Rios, Andrés F. Carrera-Pinzón, Jean C. Polo, JC Hurtado-Tobar, Yina Benitez, Carlos Órtiz Dávila, Eduardo Romero
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Several cardiovascular risk assessment models, such as the Framingham equation, SCORE or QRISK, are based on a set of covariate factors to estimate individual risk. However, their predictive performance is usually limited, especially because of their low adaptability to regional and population differences, which can lead to inaccurate or biased estimates. In view of this, the present study proposes to use the electrocardiogram (ECG) as a complementary indicator for cardiovascular risk stratification. ECG signals are extracted from digitized images and processed by a convolutional neural network (CNN) trained to classify cardiac pathologies. Latent vectors are obtained from this network before the fully connected layer, and with them, the risk of each patient is estimated using a Cox regression model based on the original criteria of the Framingham study. Finally, the latent vectors and risk levels are projected into a reduced space using UMAP, revealing distinct groupings of patients that differ from those identified by the Framingham model. These findings highlight the ECG’s potential to capture physiological patterns overlooked by traditional risk equations and to enable more personalized cardiovascular risk assessment.

title: Research and Strategies for Coordinated Energy Optimization in Low-Carbon Demonstration Parks with High Clean Energy Penetration
authors: Xu Zhang, Yang Li, Xianfu Gong, Yue Xing
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Carbon peak and carbon neutralization are the inevitable way to solve energy security, which shows China’s ambition and determination to unswervingly follow the green development path, and provides direction guidance and fundamental guidance for China to deal with climate change and promote green and low-carbon development. Firstly, this paper analyzes the energy development trend of low-carbon parks, by establishing a smart park model with ultra-clean energy supply, the energy demands of various low- and near-zero carbon demonstration parks-such as industrial parks, cultural tourism zones, and financial service areas-can be basically met. Finally, through the coordinated planning demonstration case of a park, based on the resource endowment and energy consumption characteristics of the park, the system framework and research are carried out, and the demonstration is carried out from the aspects of economic and social benefits, which shows the applicability of the collaborative optimization application of low-carbon energy in the park considering different scenarios, and provides thinking and direction for the subsequent large-scale application of “near zero carbon demonstration zone”.

title: Solution-Processed TIPS-Pentacene Memristors with Improved Resistance switching via PMMA Blending
authors: Qi Lei, Yonghua Tu, Yangyang Xie
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Semiconductor Devices and Integration Technology (ASDIT)
abstract: In response to the challenge that TIPS-pentacene is difficult to deposit into high-quality films via spin-coating at room temperature, thereby affecting the performance of related devices, we systematically studied the film formation process using a blend system of TIPS-pentacene and PMMA, and for the first time successfully fabricated a memristor with the structure Ag/TIPS-pentacene: PMMA/FTO at room temperature. The results show that the introduction of an appropriate amount of PMMA effectively improves the crystallization quality and film density of TIPS-pentacene, thereby enabling the device to exhibit excellent resistive switching (RS): an on/off ratio exceeding 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>, an endurance of over 200 cycles, and a retention time longer than 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> seconds. This work not only confirms the application potential of TIPS-pentacene in memristors, but also provides a new strategy for the development of low-cost, high-performance organic memristors compatible with large-area fabrication.

title: Improving the performance of multimodal large language models on histopathology images classification
authors: José J. Sierra-Molina, Andrés Rosso-Mateus, Fabio A. González
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Accurate diagnosis of lesions in histopathological images requires experts with extensive experience. In some cases, distinguishing between hyperplastic polyps (HP, benign growth) and sessile serrated adenomas (SSA, precancerous lesions) is difficult even for specialized pathologists. Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) currently achieve strong performance in binary classification tasks, but they lack explanatory capabilities to assist physicians in interpreting the images. Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs), such as Gemini, offer potential advantages in interpretability and contextual explanation. In this work, we evaluate Gemini-2.0-flash-lite on the MHIST dataset and improve its performance through five few-shot in-context learning strategies (including random-k, KNN, and KNN+distance), exploring the impact of providing contextual support images to Gemini. The results show that this multimodal approach enhances diagnostic accuracy, narrowing the gap with CNN-level performance while retaining the explanatory power of MLLMs. Code and results are publicly available at https://github.com/jjsierramo/SIPAIM.

title: The Laboratory Testing of Non-Contant Sensors System for Monitoring the Operating Modes of Overhead Power Transmission Lines
authors: Andrei Bramm, Stanislav A. Eroshenko, Polyna E. Storozeva, Ilya N. Storozev
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The paper describes the laboratory testing of a system of contactless capacitive and inductive sensors for monitoring the electrical modes of an overhead power transmission line. Testing was based on a physical laboratory model of 0.4 kV, implementing a prototype of a 10 kV overhead power transmission line. The test plan included four experiments: power shut down; phase A breakage; idle running; sequential switching on of the load in phases. A measuring unit of electrical energy quality parameters was additionally used to verify the data received by the contactless sensor system. The initial signals from non-contact sensors and the amplitudes of the main harmonic of these signals were used to analyze the results. The characteristic features of the response of noncontact sensors to disturbances during each experiment are described. The results obtained confirm the applicability of noncontact sensors for detecting typical events (shut-off, phase breakage, load asymmetry) on a laboratory overhead power transmission line model based on harmonic features, while simultaneously revealing limitations associated with interference in the measurement path. Based on the analysis of the experiment’s results, assumptions are made about the possibility of using a set of features for algorithms to determine changes in the operating modes of overhead power lines and further research directions are formulated.

title: SIGMA: A weather radar signal fluctuation descriptor for ground clutter identification_supp1-3645589.pdf
authors: Corentin Lubeigt
abstract: Weather radar signal fluctuation has been used to identify ground clutter (GC) from meteorological echoes for decades. Indeed, the fluctuation of a radar signal intuitively informs whether an echo comes from a static object (GC) or a random phenomenon (precipitation). Based on this intuition, Météo-France has implemented the clutter indicator, Ci, which proved satisfactory to correctly identify pixels affected by GC. In this study, a revision of the Ci, noted Σ, is presented. The theoretical statistics (mean and variance) of Σ are then derived in the case of meteorological echoes with large spectral width and verified with both simulated and real data. As an example this result is then used to set the false alarm rate of a GC detector.

title: Scout Monte Carlo: Preliminary Results of a Variance Reduction Technique for Photon Scattering Dose Calculation
authors: J. Bert, D. Benoit, C.-H. Pham, D. Visvikis
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: While AI-based solutions have demonstrated significant benefits in enhancing the efficiency of Monte Carlo Simulations (MCS), several challenges persist. One notable issue is the requirement for extensive MCS to achieve acceptable statistical uncertainty, particularly in regions far from the source. This study presents 'Scout Monte Carlo' (Scout-MC), a variance reduction technique (VRT) designed to improve AI model training and facilitate rapid simulations for medical applications, such as out-of-field dosimetry. Scout-MC builds upon forced detection approaches and extends their capabilities to estimate deposited energy specifically at the voxel of interest, regardless of its location within the phantom. The method focuses on a sampling approach to calculate the probability of a particle reaching a specific voxel. Using these probabilities and the mass energy absorption coefficient, it approximates both fluence and deposited energy. For evaluation, a voxelized multimaterial phantom was targeted with a photon beam. The results were compared with standard MCS using GATE, revealing an average relative error of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.4 \pm 32 \%$</tex>. Notably, Scout-MC demonstrated significantly lower and more uniform uncertainty (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.9 \pm 0.91 \%$</tex>) compared to standard MCS (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \pm 12 \%$</tex>). Scout-MC achieved these results in just 70 seconds, whereas GATE required 39 hours. Scout-MC can rapidly estimate the dose in any area of the image with low uncertainty and acceptable accuracy. Future work will involve extending the evaluation to more complex scenarios to further enhance accuracy and applicability.

title: Improved Yield and Performance of Handheld Radiation Detectors Using Waveform-Digitizing Application-Specific Integrated Circuits
authors: M. Petryk, K. Hinbern, W. Kaye, F. Zhang, S. Abraham, M. Streicher, A. Boucher, Z. He
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: H3D, Inc. has calibrated thousands of pixelated CdZnTe (CZT) semiconductor radiation detectors for use in its products over the last ten years. Standard quality devices achieve an energy resolution of under 1.1% full-width-at-half-maximum (FWHM) at 662 keV, while those H3D specifies as + grade reach under 0.8% FWHM. The performance of both grades of material can be improved through waveform sampling and digital filtering. H3D's newly developed detector architecture based on a waveform-digitizing application-specific integrated circuit (digital ASIC) enables alternative event reconstruction algorithms that are better tailored to the characteristics of a particular crystal. These optimizations result in energy resolutions of 0.44% for single pixel events and 0.59% for all events at 662 keV with a high-quality crystal. Compared to historical data measured for the same crystal with an analog ASIC, the digital ASIC improves full-width-at-half-maximum (FWHM) by 750 eV. It also improves the full-width-at-tenth-maximum (FWTM) by 4.5 keV, resulting in more Gaussian-shaped peaks that ease quantification analysis. The detailed corrections can better compensate for material variations compared to analog ASIC electronics, delivering higher quality results from a broader range of material. Tests with two poorer-quality CZT crystals improved FWHM by 2 keV and FWTM by 8-12 keV, bringing them within the threshold defined by H3D for +-grade material. Leveraging the flexibility of the digital ASIC and customizing event processing code to tolerate lower-quality material significantly improves the yield of crystals capable of under 0.8% FWHM resolution.

title: Feasibility of Site-Specific Volumetric Evaluation of Bone Mineral Density and Architecture with Spectral Photon-Counting CT
authors: B. Tariq, M. Alkatiba, M. Boitet, N. Maleej, A. Raja
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This study aims to establish the validity of using SPCCT to perform site-specific three-dimensional measurements of bone mineral density (BMD) and bone microarchitecture at ultra-high spatial resolution translatable to clinical application in humans. Calibration data were obtained using inserts with varied quantities of hydroxyapatite <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(49.2,102.4,201.5,406.9,809.8 \text{mg} / \text{cm}^{3})$</tex>, along with lipid and water. Four bovine bone specimens were then scanned using a spectral photoncounting CT scanner (Mars Microlab 5×120) at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$118 \text{kVp}, 80 \mu ~\mathrm{A}$</tex>, and 160 ms with 981 projections. A vendor-provided iterative reconstruction algorithm was used to reconstruct five energy bins <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(7-40,40-50,50-60,60-79,79-118 \text{keV})$</tex> with an <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$80 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> voxel size. Energy images were converted into material density images using Mars software. An automated segmentation algorithm was used to segment cortical and trabecular regions from hydroxyapatite density images, and results were compared with manual segmentation using the BoneJ. Parameters such as cortical BMD, cortical thickness, trabecular BMD, trabecular thickness, and trabecular spacing were quantified. A comparative analysis of bone parameters derived from SPCCT was performed against the Bruker Skyscan 1276 micro-CT <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(100 \text{kV}, 200 \mu ~\mathrm{A}, 395 ~\text{ms}, 0.25^{\circ}$</tex> rotation step, frame averaging of 2, and 10 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu \mathrm{m}$</tex> voxel size). The comparison between the manual and automated segmentation algorithms shows percentage differences of less than 5% for density parameters (cortical and trabecular BMD) and less than 10% for architectural parameters (cortical thickness, trabecular thickness, and trabecular spacing). The comparison between the SPCCT and micro-CT measurements shows percentage differences ranging from 3% to 11% for density parameters and from 3% to 23% for architectural parameters. The results show that SPCCT can visualize and quantify site-specific volumetric bone mineral density and three-dimensional micro-architecture in bone.

title: Final Draft of PETSIRD v1.0: A Proposed Standard for PET Raw Data
authors: K. Thielemans, E. Asma, M. Cook, M. Hansen, J. Jones, N. A. Karakatsanis, A. L. Kesner, C. Lerche, E. K. Leung, P. Markiewicz, J. Naegele, S. Prevrhal, A. Rahmim, H. Sabet, B. Saboury, M. Spangler-Bickell, J. Stairs, S. Stute, H. Tashima, K. Ziemons, R.G. Wells
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Standardization of unprocessed raw list-mode data for emission tomography (ET) is anticipated to enable the development and optimization of novel methods including machine learning. The Emission Tomography Standardization Initiative (ETSI) was founded in 2022 by an international consortium of academic and industry experts to define open, extendable, and vendor-agnostic ET data formats, currently focusing on the development of PETSIRD (“PET Emission Tomography Standardization Initiative's Raw Data“) open standard for Positron Emission Tomography (PET) list-mode raw data. The components of PETSIRD include (i) the description of data elements (coincidence events, geometry, correction factors, physiological signal etc.), (ii) a container of the data elements architecture and its access protocols built with the investigational prototype YARDL (Microsoft Research) meta-language, (iii) a simple higher-level software library to access the data elements and (iv) use-case software toolkit facilitating the basic utility of the standard.

title: The Czochralski Growth and Scintillation Properties of Ce and Mg Co-Doped $\mathbf{Y}_{\mathbf{3}} \boldsymbol{(} \mathbf{G a} \boldsymbol{,} \mathbf{A l} \boldsymbol{)}_{\mathbf{5}} \mathbf{O}_{\mathbf{1 2}}$ Single Crystals
authors: K. Kamada, H. Suezumi, L. Gushchina, M. Yoshino, K.J. Kim, R. Murakami, V. Kochurikhin, K. Shimazoe, H. Takahashi, A. Yoshikawa
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Complex garnet scintillators such as Ce doped <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\text{Gd}, \mathrm{Y}, \text{Lu})_{3}(\text{Ga}, \text{Al})_{5} \mathrm{O}_{12}[1]$</tex> have diverse range of applications such as environmental monitoring, industrial inspection, and medical diagnostics, as well as in high-energy physics experiments. Among of them, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Gd}_{3} \text{Ga}_{3} \text{Al}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{12}$</tex> (GAGG) have attractive scintillation properties such as the highest light yield of about 56000 photon <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$/ \text{MeV}$</tex>, a fast decay time of around 90 ns And the development of scintillator-based pulse-counting X-ray computed tomography (PCCT) using the garnet scintillators has considerably been focused on in recent years. In the case of GAGG, the K-absorption edge of Gd situated <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 50 \text{keV}$</tex> makes energy discrimination in this energy region of PCCT difficult. On the other hand, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Mg}, \text{Ce}: \mathrm{Y}_{3}(\text{Ga}, \text{Al})_{5} \mathrm{O}_{12}$</tex> (YAGG) grown was reported with a high light yield of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 36000$</tex> photon/ MeV and fast decay time of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 20 ~\text{ns}$</tex>. Since YAGG does not contain Gd and its Y K-absorption edge is as low as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 20 \text{keV}$</tex>, it has no adverse effects on PCCT. Alkali earth ions (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{AE}^{2+}$</tex>) co-doping enhance the light yield and accelerate the decay time and Mg, Ce: YAGG is promising scintillator for PCCT. In this research Mg and Ce co-doped YAGG single crystals were grown by the Cz method with a view to practical application. The dopants and host composition were optimized considering the segregation of each cation and the scintillator properties. Details of scintillator properties, segregation of the cations, and the effects of gallium oxide evaporation will be discussed in our presentation.

authors: K. Liu, S. Guo, Z. Yin, X. Zhang, T. Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The intrinsic background signals from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{138} \text{La}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{227} \text{Ac}$</tex>, as well as the deterioration performance in high temperature, have restricted <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{LaBr}_{3}$</tex>: Ce`s in logging or astronomical exploration. This work developed an effective purification protocol based on vacuum distillation to selectively remove <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{227} \text{Ac}$</tex> from raw materials, reducing intrinsic background signals in crystals by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$50 \%-60 \%$</tex> (minimum value is 0.0163 counts <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$/ \mathrm{s} / \text{cm}^{3} {@} 1.5-3 \text{MeV}$</tex>). Importantly, crystal grown by purified material significantly enhances the energy resolution (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2.47 \% {@} 662 \text{keV}$</tex>). Beyond background suppression, we investigated the temperature-dependent luminescence properties of Ce and identified their impact on self-absorption effect of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{LaBr}_{3}$</tex>: Ce, revealing a significant self-absorption effect at highenergy peak. The high energy peak's self-absorption coefficient of 0.76 is much higher than the total coefficient of 0.15, confirming that high quantum efficiency of Ce guarantees efficient secondary emission after self-absorption, thereby suppressing the overall self-absorption. The energy spectrum at variable temperatures show that the synergistic effect of carrier transport relaxation and self-absorption leads to the law of light yield increasing first and then decreasing. In general, the innovation of this study lies in the proposed key path for preparation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{LaBr}_{3}$</tex>: Ce crystals with low background, the physical mechanism of luminescence dynamics and performance changes at high temperatures.

title: Head-to-Head: Comparative Imaging Performance of PETcoil Gen II and Gen III TOF-PET-Inserts for Simultaneous PET/MRI Brain Imaging
authors: M.N. Ullah, S. Elgendy, J. Fisher, L. Lussier, C. Chang, C. S. Levin
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This study presents a comparative performance analysis of the PETcoil Gen II and Gen III Time-of-Flight (TOF) PET inserts for simultaneous PET/MRI brain imaging. Both systems were evaluated for PET performance in terms of energy resolution, coincidence resolving time (CRT), and image quality using a resolution phantom and a 3D Hoffman brain phantom. The Gen II system exhibited slightly better energy resolution (11.7 % vs. 12.05 %) and CRT (238 ps vs. 267 ps), with slight advantages in image fidelity as indicated by a higher Structural Similarity Index (SSIM) of 0.6115 compared to Gen III's 0.5903. Both systems demonstrated comparable overall performance, with Gen III showing slightly better spatial resolution based on peak-to-valley ratio (PVR) analysis of a profile through 2.8 mm hot rods of the resolution phantom (Gen II: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.003 \pm 1.246 \text{vs}$</tex> Gen III: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.504 \pm 2.952$</tex>). The PVR values indicate the contrast between the peaks and valleys in the profiles, with higher values suggesting better resolution. PETcoil Gen III has a slightly higher average PVR but with greater variability, while PETcoil Gen II offers more consistent and reliable peak-to-valley performance. These results suggest that both systems offer excellent capabilities for brain imaging, with differences likely arising from variations in detector design and reconstruction parameters. Both systems are currently conducting PET-only clinical studies, with results to be presented and compared in future work

title: Feasibility Study of a Scintillator-Based 3D Dose Measurement System Using a Conical Mirror and Single Camera for Radiotherapy Verification
authors: X. Yan, H. Jin, D. Li, H. Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In radiotherapy, precise three-dimensional (3D) dose verification is critical for the accurate implementation of dynamic treatment plans. The scintillator-based 3D dose measurement technology, currently the most promising approach, offers the potential for high-precision realtime measurements. However, challenges such as complex system design, significant errors in solving the system response matrix, and slow iterative reconstruction algorithms have hindered the achievement of expected accuracy and real-time performance. This paper investigates the feasibility of a scintillator-based 3D dose measurement system using a conical mirror and a single camera. The study involved the development of a conical mirror tailored for the measurement system, the selection of high-quality cameras and lenses, and the assembly of the measurement setup. Experiments were conducted on a radiotherapy platform, including square-field vertical irradiation (0°), square-field oblique irradiation (30°), and real-time variable-field vertical irradiation. Preliminary results demonstrate that the conical mirror and single-camera system can effectively perform 3D dose measurements in radiotherapy. Future work will focus on advanced 3D reconstruction algorithms to further improve results, offering a novel technical solution for dynamic radiotherapy dose verification.

title: SAHTI Environmental Radiation Detector System
authors: M. Väänänen, M. Kalliokoski, T. Hildén, L. Ahonen, R. Turpeinen
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The Scintillator Apparatus at Hyytiälä for Total Ionization measurements (SAHTI) is an environmental radiation monitoring system for measuring environmental and cosmic radiation spectra at the Station for Measuring Ecosystem-Atmosphere Relations II (SMEAR II) in the Hyytiälä forest station. The measurements are used to determine the effect of ionizing radiation on air ion formation. In this paper, we showcase the setup and first radiation measurements from the station. The time series collected so far is not long enough to draw any definite conclusions on the background and cosmic radiation activity and their contribution to air ion formation. Gamma measurements yield successful spectra, but longer measurements are difficult due to technical issues. Cosmic radiation measurements show expected variation in count rates.

title: LHC Run 3 Radiation Damage Measurement Results of the CMS-HF Fibers
authors: K. D. Basruh, B. Gonultas, Y. Onel, E. Gülmez
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The CMS-HF Calorimeter is designed to detect the forward going particles over an eta range of 3 to 5 with a high potential for discovery of new phenomena. The HF detectors are also useful for measuring the luminosity. However, usefulness of the detectors at each end of the CMS detector depends on the correct energy calibration. Energy measurement in the HF detectors is done by collecting the Cherenkov light produced in the fibers embedded in the iron absorber. Radiation damage caused by the particles produced in the collisions will increase the light attenuation in the fibers causing to underestimate the corresponding energy. Monitoring the radiation damage as a function of eta will provide correction factors for the calibration. The new HF Online Radiation Damage Monitoring System is commissioned at the end of Run 2. It is being used since then to monitor the radiation damage of the fibers in the HF detectors. Radiation damage measurement results will be reported for the year 2022-2024 and projections will be made for the rest of the Run 3. Possible implications for the Run 4 will be discussed.

title: ETROC2 as the Final Version for CMS MTD Endcap Timing Layer (ETL) Upgrade
authors: J. Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The ETROC2 is the first full-size full-functionality prototype design fully compatible with the final chip specifications for CMS ETL. The ETROC2 chips have been extensively tested and the results have been presented at IEEE NSS MIC RTSD 2024. We will present here new results including the bump bonding yield improvement study, the time walk correction (TWC) generality study with single pixel TWC applied to all pixels, the final SEU testing results using both heavy ion and proton beam, more beam test studies including different sensors and irradiated sensors, and readiness for the ETROC2 production for CMS ETL upgrade.

title: Design and Implementation of Postprocessing Software for Quantitative 3D Gamma-Ray Imaging
authors: C. G. Wahl, R. Sobota
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Performing Compton and coded aperture imaging in 3D, via multiple stationary measurements from different viewpoints or via a continuously moving detector system, can provide additional information relative to a single stationary measurement. Analysis of 3D image information, however, is significantly more difficult from user-interface and computation perspectives. We have extended existing post-processing 2D gamma-ray imaging software, Visualizer, to handle 3D point-cloud data to make Visualizer 3D. Visualizer 3D supports intelligently loading, aligning, navigating through, and selecting points on point clouds, then using this map to perform 3D Compton and coded-aperture imaging from detectors that have moved through the scene. 3D quantitative imaging algorithms will be discussed along with advances to the user interface to make interacting with the 3D scene more like a video game.

title: Investigating Timing Performance of Crossstrip Edge-on CZT Head and Neck PET Scanner
authors: G. Shoop, R. Herbst, P. G. Bharathi, M. Kupinski, L. R. Furenlid, M. A. King, S. Abbaszadeh
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Cadmium Zinc Telluride (CZT) based Positron Emission Tomography (PET) systems are attractive due to their excellent energy resolution as a trade-off for time-of-flight (TOF) PET capability. The high energy resolution of CZT allows improvement of signal-to-noise (SNR) by filtering scattered photons based on energy as well as increasing the number of lines of response (LORs) detected by reconstructing LORs from multiple photon interaction events (MIPEs) to increase system sensitivity. However, this requires optimizing the coincidence time resolution (CTR) in the electronic readout of CZT to accurately pair annihilation photons and related MIPEs. Here, we investigate the timing performance of the RENA-3 (Readout Electronics for Nuclear Applications) ASIC used for readout in a cross-strip edge-on CZT head and neck dual panel system built at UC Santa Cruz. Simultaneous 511 keV charge equivalent pulse injections to all channels within an ASIC show that the average relative channel-to-channel signal timing has a full-width at half-maximum (FWHM) of 15.72 ± 0.06 ns with time resolution as good as 7.93 ± 0.10 ns FWHM. Next steps for investigating, calibrating, and optimizing CTR involve improving quadrature signal sampling and signal recovery used to determine photon arrival time, as well as characterizing channel-to-channel constant delay due to signal path lengths in the system.

title: Radiological and Biological Dictionary of Radiomics Features: Addressing Understandable AI Issues in Personalized Prostate Cancer; Dictionary Version PM1.0
authors: M. R. Salmanpour, S. Amiri, S. Gharibi, A. Shariftabrizi, Y. Xu, W. B. Weeks, A. Rahmim, I. Hacihaliloglu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) has the potential to enhance medical diagnostics, but its clinical application is often limited by issues related to interpretability. This study bridges the gap by associating standardized quantitative imaging features, known as radiomics features (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{R F}$</tex>), derived from medical images with established clinical frameworks such as PI-RADS, ensuring that AI models are both interpretable and aligned with clinical practice. A team comprising two medical physicists, a physician, a radiologist, and two MDs collaboratively created a radiological/biological dictionary that connects the visual semantic features of PI-RADS with radiomics features, promoting a unified understanding among medical and AI professionals. In this study, six interpretable and seven complex classifiers, paired with nine feature selection algorithms focused on risk factors, were applied to segmented lesions in multiparametric prostate MRI sequences (T2-weighted (T2WI), diffusion-weighted (DWI), and apparent diffusion coefficient (ADC) imaging) to predict UCLA scores. The dictionary was then used to interpret the most predictive models. By combining T2WI, DWI, and ADC with FSAs such as ANOVA F-test, Correlation Coefficient, and Fisher Score, and using logistic regression, key features were identified: the 90th percentile from T2WI, indicating hypointensity linked to prostate cancer risk; variance from T2WI, representing lesion heterogeneity; shape metrics like Least Axis Length and Surface Area to Volume ratio from ADC, describing lesion shape and compactness; and Run Entropy from ADC, which reflects texture consistency. This approach achieved an average accuracy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.78 \pm 0.01$</tex>, significantly surpassing single-sequence methods (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{p}$</tex>-value <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<0.05$</tex>). The developed Prostate-MRI dictionary (PM1.0) provides a shared framework, fostering collaboration between clinicians and AI developers to create trustworthy, interpretable AI solutions that support reliable clinical decision-making.

title: Static PET Image Reconstruction Using A Pretrained Deep Kernel Method
authors: S. Li, X. Long, Y. Lv, R. Bayerlein, L. Nardo, J. Qi, S. R. Cherry, R. D. Badawi, B. A. Spencer, G. Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Kernel methods incorporate prior image information into the PET forward model to improve tomographic image reconstruction. However, existing kernel-based methods are constrained to single-subject applications and rely heavily on high-quality image priors. This condition is often satisfied in dynamic imaging or in a dual-modality PET/MR, where composite longer frames or the anatomical image prior (e.g., by MRI) can serve as good image priors. In contrast, the performance of these kernel methods can be significantly compromised in static PET imaging, where no high-quality image prior exists but only a single-frame MLEM reconstruction is available. To address this challenge and expand the applicability of kernel reconstruction for static PET imaging, we propose a pretrained deep kernel method by using a large database acquired from the ultrahigh-sensitivity uEXPLORER total-body PET scanner. The resulting pretrained model can be directly applied to static PET scans for image reconstruction by using the standard MLEM reconstruction as the image prior. We conducted evaluation experiments on datasets from the uEXPLORER and GE 690 scanners and compared the proposed method with the stateof-the-art deep-learning approach that is based on a 3D denoising diffusion probabilistic model (DDPM). The results demonstrate that the proposed pretrained deep kernel model outperforms the existing approaches for improving static PET image reconstruction. This work enables the use of the kernel method for static PET with potential applications to low-dose, fast, and delayed imaging.

title: Readout ASIC for Edge-On GaAs:Cr Detectors in High-Flux Clinical Photoncounting CT
authors: Y. Tong, B. Wang, J. Bai, G. Yu, H. Li, H. Ren, X. Lai
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This work presents the design and preliminary evaluation of a readout application-specific integrated circuit(ASIC) dedicated to an edge-on Cr-compensated GaAs (GaAs:Cr) detector, targeting high-flux clinical photon-counting computed tomography(PCCT). The ASIC is designed to address challenges arising from the high electron mobility and low K-edge escape energy of GaAs:Cr and the compact, elongated geometry of the edge-on detector. Preliminary electrical tests based on a single channel show excellent count rate performance, achieving up to 99.9 % at flux levels below 40 Mcps/pixel and maintaining 90 % at 50 Mcps/pixel. These results validate the proposed design and provide a solid foundation for developing a detector system with small pixel size and work under high flux.

title: First in-vivo IMPT Irradiation of Mice with Quasi-Real-Time Range Verification with the SIRMIO PET Scanner
authors: F. Evangelista, G. Lovatti, M. Pinto, J. Bortfeldt, Z. Huang, N. Bassler, P. R. Poulsen, J. A. Nijkamp, B. S. Sørensen, T. Yamaya, P. Thirolf, M. Nitta, K. Parodi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: As part of the SIRMIO project, we conducted the first in-vivo intensity-modulated proton therapy treatment of mice, integrating a dedicated beamline and an in-beam smallanimal PET scanner for quasi-real-time proton range verification. During an experimental campaign at the Danish Centre for Particle Therapy, 9 mice underwent targeted lung irradiation with proton beams, receiving median doses between 30 and 50 Gy (RBE). The PET scanner, developed at LMU (Germany) in collaboration with QST (Japan), comprises 56 detector blocks in a spherical layout, each with three layers of LYSO crystals providing depth-of-interaction information. To simulate PET imaging response during irradiation, a dedicated Monte Carlo simulation framework integrating positron-emitter maps from Micro-RayStation was implemented. An in-house developed software handled data streaming, data processing, and image reconstruction, enabling quasi-real-time feedback from the PET system. Both simulated and acquired PET images were co-registered with a fixed CT image, accounting for translation and rotation of the mouse holder between pencil-beam spots via a novel reconstruction algorithm that included sensitivity and motion corrections. Preliminary analysis revealed promising agreement between predicted and measured PET signals. The system also captured washout dynamics of positron-emitting isotopes in quasi-real-time, offering valuable insights into the biological response of irradiated tissue. These findings highlight the precision of online PET-based range verification in pre-clinical proton therapy. Overall, this study demonstrates the feasibility of integrating in-vivo PET imaging with proton irradiation, enabling quasi-real-time monitoring and supporting the development of advanced molecular image-guided radiotherapy for pre-clinical research.

title:
MC
                    <sup>2</sup>
                    - 1K, a New 1024-Pixel CdTe Hybrid Detector for Space Science
authors: A. Meuris, D. Baudin, D. Chesnais, J. Chauveau, O. Garel, J.-M. Guinet, M. Prieur, D. Renaud, F. Soufflet, E. Tan, O. Limousin
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper presents the design, the fabrication and the performance characterization of a new hybrid detector based on CdTe Schottky pixel detectors bump bonded on the 2D ASIC IDeF-X <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{D}^{2} \mathrm{R}_{2}$</tex> with a full-custom interconnect room-temperature process. The pixels are <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$250 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> pitch and contain each a full spectroscopic channel up to a peak detector to read the matrix with a triggered logic. First spectral tests were performed in full frame readout mode with 32 rows read out in parallel and column data multiplexed one by one towards the OWB-1 ADC ASIC. The first prototype shows a yield of pixel interconnects greater than 98.5 %. Analysing the aggregated spectrum over all pixels, we measured an energy resolution of 0.8 keV FWHM at 59.54 keV at room temperature. Spectral characterization tests based on single and multiple events will be presented on the two first samples. Perspectives for new large-size fine-pitch imaging spectrometers for hard X-ray astrophysics will be addressed.

title: A Real-Time Scintillating Fiber-Based Beam Profile Monitor for Ion Therapy Beams
authors: L. Qin, B. Leverington, M. Dziewiecki
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: A real-time scintillating fiber-based beam profile monitor (BPM) has been developed for ion beams and tested at the Heidelberg Ion Beam Therapy Center (HIT). It is designed to measure the beam position and width in real time. Each BPM plane consists of four components: a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$25 ~\text{cm} \times 25 ~\text{cm}$</tex> low-mass scintillating fiber mat, five Hamamatsu S11865-64ch silicon photodiode arrays, a custom ADC board, and a MAX10 FPGA development board. Together, these components measure the 1Dprojection of the pencil beams. Firmware has been developed to control the photodiode arrays and ADCs, reconstruct the beam position and width in real time, and stream the signals and results to the control PC via Ethernet. Additionally, software has been developed to communicate with the firmware, visualize the beam profile in real time, and store the data for offline analysis. Beam tests at HIT have been performed with proton and carbon ion beams at a 10 kHz readout rate, demonstrating a position resolution better than 0.1 mm for proton beams above 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">9</sup> protons per second. The integration time and readout rate are adjustable between 92 Hz and 13.5 kHz. The performance at the lowest intensities benefit from an increased integration time. In addition, only the lower 10% of the dynamic range has been used, indicating that the BPM can be used for higher-intensity applications.

title: DTMOS Feedback Network for Dynamic Signal Compression in Low-Noise Charge Amplifier
authors: M. Manghisoni, L. Ghislotti, P. Lazzaroni, L. Ratti, V. Re, E. Riceputi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This work discusses the design and the experimental results of a low-noise analog readout channel that exploits the non-linear features of a Dynamic Threshold MOS capacitor in the feedback network of the Charge Sensitive Amplifier to achieve dynamic signal compression. The design is implemented in a commercial 65 nm CMOS technology and is developed for the readout of the lithium-drifted silicon, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Si}(\text{Li})$</tex>, detectors of the General Antiparticle Spectrometer experiment to search for dark matter. The charge amplifier also includes an improved Krummenacher restoration network that, thanks to an additional bulk control terminal, is able to comply with detector leakage currents up to 200 nA . The paper will outline the design criteria and the architecture of the readout channel with a focus on the Dynamic Threshold MOS capacitor and on the improved charge restoration network used in the CSA feedback. A summary of the channel characterization results is also provided.

title: Towards Brown Adipose Tissue Prediction from CT Scans Using Gaussian Splatting
authors: M. Béguin, E. Erdil, E. Konukoglu, B. Martinez-Tellez, J. R. Ruiz
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Brown adipose tissue (BAT) plays a key role in energy metabolism and is closely linked to metabolic disorders such as obesity. While PET imaging provides precise BAT quantification via standardized uptake values (SUV), its use remains costly and invasive. A recent approach using convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to predict BAT activity from CT scans has shown potential, but it relies on large datasets and sometimes suffers from limited generalizability. In this work, we investigate a novel, data-efficient alternative using Gaussian Splatting-a neural scene representation technique originally developed for real-time rendering and recently adapted to medical imaging. We first train a dual-channel Gaussian model on a single CT/PET pair. For new patients, this Gaussian representation is fine-tuned using only the CT image. Preliminary results suggest that the model captures general PET structure and some BAT regions, despite limitations due to CT-only supervision. Upcoming work will incorporate prior-guided learning to improve anatomical accuracy and generalization.

title: A Modular Multimodal Language Model for Radiation Oncology
authors: J. Xu, J. Luo, N. Haouchine, S. Raymond
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Multimodal language models (MLMs) have the potential to integrate and interpret heterogeneous data sources, such as clinical text and medical imaging (e.g., CT, PET), to support diagnosis and treatment planning in radiation oncology. Despite their promise, existing general-purpose MLMs often fail to consistently provide accurate and clinically relevant information. Even if domainspecific MLMs are developed at select research institutions, they are likely inaccessible to the broader clinical community for use in practice, due to barriers such as the need for programming expertise, lack of access to high-performance computers, and the impracticality of keyboard-based interaction within hands-occupied clinical workflows. To address this gap, we propose a modular MLM framework designed to improve accessibility, usability, and clinical relevance of MLMs for practitioners in radiation oncology. Our framework offers three key features: (1) a web-based deployment, making it broadly accessible via any internet-connected computer; (2) Integrated voice input and text-to-speech output modules enable clinicians to interact with the AI system hands-free, accommodating scenarios in which manual keyboard use is impractical; (3) our framework currently supports several pre-trained general-purpose MLM modules, with the capacity to incorporate additional domain-specific MLMs in future iterations. By lowering the barrier to experiencing advanced MLMs, our modular framework aims to increase clinician familiarity with emerging AI tools and accelerate their translation into routine clinical practice.

title: Evaluation of Event Positioning Strategies to Optimize Contrast Recovery in a TOFPET Brain Insert for Simultaneous PET/MRI
authors: F. Desai, M.N. Ullah, J. Fisher, C. S. Levin
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Simultaneous PET/MRI offers important advantages for neurological imaging, demanding high spatial resolution and contrast recovery. This study evaluates multiple event positioning strategies within the scintillation crystals of a Time-of-Flight (TOF) PET brain insert (PETcoil) designed for PET/MRI imaging. Using GATE Monte Carlo simulations and a custom contrast recovery phantom with embedded hot spheres, we test four positioning approaches-front face, back face, center, and average depth of interaction (DOI)-for their impact on contrast recovery. Simulation data was reconstructed using OSEM and analyzed across two axial positions. Results demonstrate that event positioning significantly influences percent contrast, with center and back face strategies yielding the highest performance <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(84.6 \pm 3.2 \%$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$84.3 \pm 3.6 \%$</tex>, respectively), while the front face strategy resulted in the lowest contrast (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$68.8 \pm 2.5 \%$</tex>). These findings inform future optimization of the PETcoil system and other high-performance brain PET systems.

title: Investigation of Tracking Performance of the Recoil Electron in the Electron Tracking Compton Camera
authors: R. Kiuchi, R. Iwasaki, K. Tanaka, K. Yoshida, H. Matsushita, H. Kimura, M. Asai, Y. Kitamura, T. Kozaka, H. Kawashima, A. Takada, T. Oka, T. Fukuzawa, J. Kushida, S. Kabuki, K. Nishijima, E. Kunieda
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Compton cameras are emerging as a promising candidate for nuclear-medical imaging detectors. The Electron Tracking Compton Camera (ETCC) consisting of a time projection chamber (TPC) as the scatterer and pixel scintillator arrays (PSAs) as absorbers, measures not only the scattered gamma rays but also the recoil electron from the Compton scattering point, which reduces the Compton circle to an arc. The ETCC offers several advantages, such as significant background reduction and hence achieving a high signal-to-noise ratio, compared with other types of Compton cameras. The performance of the precise electron tracking clearly affects the final reconstructed images. Among several key issues, we have focused on ambiguity in determination of the recoil electron's initial momentum direction and the scattering point. For this purpose, we have conducted measurements using the ETCC, where the PSAs were placed in the direction with the angle of dozens of degrees to accumulate the Compton scattering events with relatively long track length. The obtained track images range from a relatively straight line shape to a complicated pattern that is caused by the multiple scattering effect and it suggests that implementing a suitable filter may improve the tracking accuracy. In order to evaluate the uncertainty of the determination of the Compton scattering point from the track images, a Monte Carlo simulation tool has been developed for the ETCC detector system.

title: Feasibility Study on Material Decomposition Using Neutron and Gamma-Ray
authors: G. Song, J. Hwang, J. Hwang, J. Park, S. Lee, D. Kim, S. Jang, U. Lee, G. Cho
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Early detection of hazardous materials is essential for homeland security. Conventional X-ray radiography or computed tomography (CT) reveals internal structures, whereas dual-energy X-ray imaging exploits energy-dependent attenuation to classify materials but can only determine whether a sample is metallic or polymeric. To overcome this limitation, recent approaches combine gamma rays and fast neutrons, leveraging their distinct attenuation responses. We demonstrate the feasibility of material decomposition with a single stilbene organic scintillator intrinsically sensitive to fast neutrons and gamma rays optically coupled to a photomultiplier tube and using pulse-shape discrimination to separate the radiation types. Using neutrons from the spontaneous fission of Cf-252 and gamma rays from Cs-137, we obtained the attenuationcoefficient ratio, R-value (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu / \Sigma$</tex>), for acrylic (0.34), Teflon (0.72), aluminium (1.08), PVC (0.47), stainless steel 304 (2.07), iron (2.15), copper (2.15), brass (2.22), and lead (3.82). Further work will involve Monte Carlo simulations to model detector responses to neutrons and gamma rays and quantitatively validate the experimental R-values.

title: Scintillator-Integrated MCP-PMTS: Ultrafast Timing with Energy Information from keV to GeV Scale
authors: R. Ota, Y. Onishi, D. Lee, Y. Ichikawa, K. Kuramoto, K. Shimano, Y. Hasegawa, E. Berg, S. R. Cherry, S.I. Kwon
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Radiation detection is one of the most necessary techniques in several fields, such as high-energy physics experiments for exploring new physics and positron emission tomography for diagnosis of life-threatening diseases. Radiation detection with highly precise timing performance is important along with the evolution of scintillators and photodetectors to maximize exploratory and diagnostic capabilities. In our previous study, Cherenkov radiator-integrated microchannel plate photomultiplier tubes (CRI-MCP-PMTs) were developed, and a coincidence time resolution (CTR) of a pair of them achieved 30 ps full width at half maximum (FWHM). However, the CRI-MCP-PMT focused solely on timing performance, and other important characteristics as a radiation detector, e.g., detection sensitivity and energy resolution, were compromised. We have therefore developed scintillator-integrated MCP-PMTs (SCI-MCP-PMTs) to address these challenges. Barium fluoride (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{BaF}_{2}$</tex>) and bismuth germanate (BGO) were employed and integrated with MCP-PMTs as window faceplates considering their potential capabilities of high timing performance with energy information. In this study, we focused on their timing performance over a wide energy range, from 511 keV using a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{22} \text{Na}$</tex> source to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>1 \text{GeV}$</tex> using cosmic ray muons, to evaluate the applicability of the developed SCI-MCP-PMTs. Coincidence experiments using the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{22} \text{Na}$</tex> demonstrated CTRs of 51.4 and 46.4 ps FWHM for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{BaF}_{2}$</tex> - and BGO-MCP-PMTs, respectively, while having energy resolutions of 35.1 % and 37.5 % FWHM at 511 keV, respectively. In addition, the coincidence experiments using cosmic ray muons demonstrated CTRs of 25.1 and 16.2 ps FWHM for a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{BaF}_{2}\text{BaF}_{2}$</tex> and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{BaF}_{2}$</tex>-BGO pair, respectively, when the energy threshold was set to 1500 keV equivalent. In this way, we have experimentally demonstrated ultrafast CTRs using SCI-MCPPMTs while maintaining energy information.

title: Strategic Contract Offering and Channel Choices in Live Streaming E-Commerce_supp1-3637005.pdf
authors: Yong Zha
abstract: The emergence of live streaming has revolutionized retail, altering how e-tailers engage with their customers. However, incorporating a live streaming channel may intensify channel competition and profit-sharing losses, potentially eroding the e-tailer's overall profitability. A streamer faces a trade-off in contract provision: it must balance maximizing its profits with expanding its market. This paper investigates a streamer's contract offering decisions and an e-tailer's channel selection strategy. We analyze two types of contracts that a streamer can offer—agency and reselling contracts—and three channel strategies for an e-tailer: not adopting live streaming, self-streaming, and third-party streaming. Our findings reveal that the streamer offers contracts aligned with its profit preferences only when the network effect is strong and the hassle cost is low. Otherwise, the streamer may deviate from its preferred contract and choose a suboptimal strategy. From the e-tailer's perspective, no single strategy dominates all scenarios. The e-tailer should avoid opening a live-streaming channel when the hassle cost is very high. If the network effect is low and the hassle cost is moderately high, the e-tailer should choose self-streaming; otherwise, it should opt for third-party streaming. Interestingly, our research also shows that neither the e-tailer nor the streamer necessarily has to lower the live streaming channel price. Furthermore, implementing live-streaming does not always cannibalize the traditional channel demand or lead to an expansion of total market demand. This paper provides practical guidance for both streamers and e-tailers in making strategic contract and channel decisions in the live-streaming retail landscape.

title: Geometric Calibration Between Source and Detector for Mobile Tomosynthesis Without Additional Scans
authors: K. Hori, T. Hashimoto
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Mobile tomosynthesis enables quasi-tomographic imaging using a limited projection angle range, offering diagnostic advantages in settings such as home care and nursing facilities. However, since mobile systems are manually positioned for each scan, accurate geometric calibration between the x-ray source and detector is essential for image reconstruction. Existing calibration methods require additional scans, then we propose a novel geometric calibration method that requires no additional scans. By attaching a board with pin-shaped reference markers to the detector, the proposed method estimates the x-ray source location by analyzing the gravity centers and directions of the projected markers. Numerical simulations varying marker sizes and materials were conducted to evaluate the proposed method accuracy. Results show that marker thickness significantly affects gravity center accuracy, while material type does not. X-ray source position was more accurately calibrated in the xz plane than in the xy plane, due to a theoretical discrepancy in projected center alignment. Reconstructed images confirmed effective separation of overlapping structures. The proposed approach simplifies mobile tomosynthesis calibration, enhancing accessibility and utility in clinical and non-clinical environments. Future work includes correcting the projected center discrepancy to improve xy plane accuracy.

title: Adaptive Frequency-Based Constructive Wavelet Neural Network for Nonlinear Dynamic Systems_supp1-3642820.pdf
authors: Dong SHEN
abstract: Neural networks (NNs) have gained significant popularity for modeling complex, nonlinear systems due to their powerful approximation capabilities. However, designing an appropriate network structure and tuning parameters remains challenging, especially for nonlinear dynamic systems where offline training data are unavailable and poor approximations from badly tuned NNs can cause instability. This article presents a novel adaptive frequency-based constructive wavelet NN (AFBCWNN) for tracking reference trajectories for a class of unknown nonlinear dynamic systems. Using online measurements, the AFBCWNN integrates adaptive weight updating, adjustable network structures, and rigorous stability analysis using Lyapunov techniques. Unlike conventional methods, the proposed AFBCWNN leverages frequency-domain analysis to estimate the energy distribution of the unknown nonlinear mapping from measured data. This frequency-based approach provides a uniform design guideline for network initialization, enabling the network to dynamically add wavelet bases when the desired accuracy is not achieved and prune nonenergy-active (low-energy) bases, reducing computational cost without compromising accuracy. Rigorous stability analysis establishes conditions for uniformly bounded trajectories, and simulation results confirm the AFBCWNN’s superior performance in capturing complex, nonlinear dynamics compared to the existing adaptive methods.

title: Light CNN-Transformer Dual-Branch Network for Real-Time Semantic Segmentation
authors: Yongsheng Dong, Siming Jia, Xuelong Li
abstract: Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) have widely used in semantic segmentation, and can effectively extract local hierarchical information while being unsatisfactory in extracting global information. By contrast, Transformer is good at extracting long-distance dependencies in semantics while it is time-consuming. In this work, we propose a Light CNN-Transformer Dual-Branch Network (LCTDBNet) for real-time semantic segmentation. It consists of a longer CNN branch to extract local hierarchical information and a shorter Transformer branch to extract global contextual information. The CNN branch uses a lightweight encoder-decoder structure to further extract more local hierarchical information. We propose a Deep Strip Aggregation Pyramid Pooling Module (DSAPPM) to extract contextual and strip information. We further propose a Feature Pooling Refinement Module (FPRM) to optimise the feature representation at different stages. Finally, we propose a CNN-Transformer Fusion Module (CTFM) to fuse the features of two branches. Experimental results demonstrate that our proposed LCTDBNet is effective and achieves satisfactory results. Specifically, the base version of LCTDBNet achieves 80.3% mean intersection over union (mIoU) at 78.6 frames per second (FPS) on Cityscapes, 80.0% mIoU at 137.5 FPS on CamVid and 40.9% mIoU at 253.7 FPS on ADE20 K.

title: BRFL: A Blockchain-based and Ring Signature-empowered Privacy-preserving Federated Learning Scheme for Low-altitude Networks
authors: Linsheng Liu, Jiahui Chen, Haonan Fan, Keyu Xu, Peifeng Zhang, Xiaoguo Li, Tao Xiang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: In low-altitude networks, federated learning (FL) with unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) faces significant privacy threats—notably membership inference attacks (MIAs) that correlate multi-round gradients to infer client participation. To cope with the stringent latency, mobility, and energy budgets of UAV swarms, this work proposes Blockchain- and Ring-signature-empowered Federated Learning (BRFL), a privacy-preserving framework tailored to aerial networks. BRFL uses a decentralized ledger for auditing and storage, and a no-pairing elliptic curve ring signature to anonymize client uploads by forming a random UAV ring each round. Smart contracts further verify the signatures and invoke a lightweight ring-internal supervision voting mechanism to filter malicious updates. Experiments on MNIST and CIFAR-10 demonstrate that BRFL converges stably on non-IID data even when 40% of UAVs behave Byzantinely. Theoretical analysis further bounds the adversary’s cross-round-linking probability by (1/n)T . Overall, BRFL preserves UAV anonymity with negligible overhead, offering a practical solution for privacy-aware and scalable FL in large-scale aerial networks.

title: Torque Lever-based Gear-shifting Strategy of a Novel 3-Speed Transmission for Electric Vehicles
authors: Yang Tian, Hanlong Zhang, Peng Dong, Yahui Zhang, Xiaorun Tian
abstract: Although multi-speed transmissions in electric vehicles (EVs) offer advantages over the single-speed ones, they can also introduce shifting problems. To achieve higher shifting quality and streamline the development, this study investigates the torque lever-based gear-shifting strategy of a novel three-speed transmission for EVs. Initially, a novel powertrain based on a 3-speed Ravigneaux transmission is proposed as the foundation for the transient analysis of gear shifting. Meanwhile, the equivalence of the idealized gear arrangements in Ravigneaux gearsets is demonstrated. Based on the analysis, we employ the Torque Lever Approach (TLA) to design 3 power-on shift control strategies according to different torque controls. This approach features less theory computation than algebra. Subsequently, the hardware-in-the-loop (HiL) validates all the strategies for upshift and downshift between adjacent and nonadjacent gears. The results show the effectiveness of the strategies designed by TLA, and their features are discussed in these shifting conditions.

title: A New Information Theoretical Measure for Node Similarity in Complex Networks_supp1-3630179.pdf
authors: Ricky X.F. Chen
abstract: Measuring the similarity of nodes is a topic of significance in network science. The effectiveness of a method depends on how well it captures both the local and global features. In this article, we propose a new method for measuring node similarity based on <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$[t,p]$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-spectra of nodes induced by <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$[t,p]$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-separate chain decompositions of graphs, a recently introduced framework both preserving the interaction information of local neighborhoods and implicitly capturing the higher-order associative features of nodes by iteratively filtering subgraph chains. Specifically, the structural profile of a node is represented by its adjacency <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$[t,p]$</tex-math> </inline-formula>-spectrum and the Jensen–Shannon divergence is used to quantify the similarity of the profiles of two nodes. The difference of the spreading powers under the susceptible-infected (SI) model of node <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$v$</tex-math> </inline-formula> and the most similar node of <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$v$</tex-math> </inline-formula> identified in this way is then used as a validation of our method. Extensive statistical analyses on disparate real-world networks from social, biological, and transportation domains show that the proposed method achieves higher accuracy in quantifying node similarity in most networks than five benchmark methods.

title: Quantum Codes: A Comprehensive Survey of Techniques, Challenges, and Future Directions
authors: Istiak Mahmud, Ahmed Abdelhadi
abstract: Quantum error correction is fundamental to enabling reliable quantum computation and communication in the presence of noise and decoherence. Over the years, a diverse range of quantum coding strategies has been developed, each offering distinct approaches to mitigate quantum errors and achieve fault tolerance. This paper presents a comprehensive survey of major quantum code families, including stabilizer codes, topological codes, quantum LDPC codes, convolutional codes, turbo codes, Reed-Muller codes, continuous-variable bosonic codes, and subsystem codes. For each class, we discuss their construction principles, operational strategies, advantages, and inherent limitations. In addition to reviewing existing methodologies, we compare different coding techniques through structured tables and highlight the practical challenges that persist, such as resource overhead, decoding complexity, and scalability. Furthermore, we identify future research directions aimed at overcoming these challenges, including hybrid error correction approaches, machine learning-assisted decoders, and fault-tolerant architectures without magic state distillation. By consolidating the landscape of quantum error correction research, this work aims to serve as a foundational reference for researchers and practitioners working toward scalable, robust quantum technologies.

title: Stability Performance Characterization of Rhizo-PET (R-PET): A Dedicated PET Scanner for Dynamic Rhizosphere Imaging
authors: M.N. Ullah, D. Hastings, S. Lee, D. Innes, D. Weisenberger, W. Cheng, S. Abbaszadeh, C. Levin
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Rhizo-PET (R-PET) is a dedicated positron emission tomography (PET) scanner developed for noninvasive imaging of root and rhizosphere processes in soil. In this study, we evaluated the temporal stability and performance of the R-PET system over an 8-hour continuous acquisition using a surrogate 22 Na point source. This is important, since we need to perform dynamic plant studies for multiple hours as the roots and soil slowly uptake and metabolize 11C gas. To correct for detector gain shifts, an energy peak alignment algorithm was applied across all modules, improving global energy resolution from 15.00 ± 0.28 % to 11.95 ± 0.18 % (FWHM at 511 keV). The energy resolution remained stable throughout the study, with a standard deviation of only 0.0124, and the coincidence count rate averaged 7.79 × 103 counts per 30 -minute segment with less than 5% variation. These results confirm the R-PET scanner's high stability and performance, supporting its suitability for long-term, high-resolution imaging of carbon transport and interactions in the rhizosphere.

title: Multi-Scale Mesh Fitting Filtering Based on Adaptive Clustering Segmentation and Gradient Compensation
authors: Zitao Lin, Guoliang Chen, Chuanli Kang, Zhenghua Zhang, Hu Liu
publish: IEEE Journal of Selected Topics in Applied Earth Observations and Remote Sensing
abstract: Point cloud filtering serves as a core step in point cloud data processing, which is critical for constructing high-precision Digital Elevation Models (DEMs) and conducting terrain monitoring. However, existing filtering methods encounter two key challenges. First, they exhibit strong reliance on threshold parameters and limited adaptability, necessitating manual parameter adjustment to suit different scenarios—this often results in misclassification or under-classification of ground and non-ground points. Second, their adaptability to complex terrains is inadequate: in regions with drastic slope variations or dense buildings, issues such as the loss of terrain details or confusion between terrain points and feature point clouds frequently arise, making it difficult for a single method to meet the requirements of diverse application scenarios. To address this problem, this article proposes a multi-scale mesh fitting filtering based on adaptive clustering segmentation and gradient compensation. First, the existing clustering segmentation algorithm is improved to propose an adaptive clustering segmentation method. Then, by combining Delaunay triangulation and local feature parameters, an outlier cluster is constructed. On the basis of the clustering segmentation results and the distribution of outliers, the building feature areas are effectively separated. After that, grids are constructed by separating the point clouds of the building clusters. The point clouds within the grids are judged by using planes and slope angles to remove most non-ground points, and establishes a secondary grid. The elevation threshold is determined on the basis of the fitted grids and gradient compensation. Finally, carrying out a secondary check according to the cluster edges obtained by clustering. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method has wide applicability without the need to switch feature parameters, and its filtering accuracy is significantly higher than that of existing methods in most point cloud scenarios.

title: Reinforcement Learning-Based Policy Optimisation for Heterogeneous Radio Access
authors: Anup Mishra, Čedomir Stefanović, Petar Popovski, Israel Leyva-Mayorga
abstract: Heterogeneous services such as broadband and latency-constrained internet-of-things (IoT), with diverse requirements, make efficient resource sharing challenging. Two canonical strategies are radio access network (RAN) Slicing, which allocates disjoint resources per service, and RAN Sharing, where services coexist on a common resource. Under either regime, grant-free repetition-based access is a key enabler of IoT connectivity prompting latency-aware policies tuned to the regimes’ density and interference profiles. Prior work on repetition-policy optimisation mainly employs base station (BS)-centric reinforcement learning (RL) or irregular repetition slotted ALOHA (IRSA)-based approaches focused on throughput/packet loss rate (PLR) in asymptotic regimes. The former requires central orchestration, leading to high control overhead and reduced adaptability; the latter typically degrades when targeting performance at finite frame lengths. This motivates decentralised multi-agent RL (MARL), where each IoT device learns its own policy to meet latency targets in dense, finite frame-length, mixed-service deployments. To this end, we investigate an uplink scenario where a broadband user coexists with multiple latency-constrained IoT devices employing grant-free access. We formulate IoT access policy optimisation as a decentralised, model-free MARL problem, enabling devices to learn their transmission strategies under finite frame length structures and strict latency requirements. Under both RAN Slicing and RAN Sharing regimes, the proposed scheme outperforms baseline decentralised approaches; in each regime it achieves substantial IoT latency gains while sustaining broadband throughput and energy efficiency (EE). Furthermore, the results highlight and compare regime-specific trade-offs.

title: Techno-empathy 2.0
authors: Yoyo-Yiyao Zhang, Aven-Le Zhou
publish: Proceedings of the 18th International Symposium on Visual Information Communication and Interaction

title: Mitigating Hallucinations in Large Vision-Language Models via Grounded-Contrastive Decoding
authors: Zhiyun Zhang, Haotian Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) have achieved remarkable progress in bridging vision and language, enabling applications from captioning to visual question answering. Yet their deployment is hindered by hallucination-outputs that sound plausible but contradict the visual input. Unlike hallucinations in text-only large language models, LVLM hallucinations stem from entangled visual-textual representations, over-reliance on language priors, and instability in visual features during decoding. To address these issues, we introduce GroundedContrastive Decoding (GCD), a novel training-free framework. GCD integrates a lightweight disentanglement module in the latent space with a multimodal contrastive decoding strategy that actively suppresses language priors. This approach reduces object, attribute, and relational hallucinations while preserving general visual understanding, yielding substantial gains on benchmarks such as MME, MM-Vet, and MMMU.

title: Cluster-Based I/O Analysis of Scientific Workflows
authors: Jingxian Peng, Jiaqiang Ma, Yixin Zhang, Weizhao Lin, Lihua Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Scientific workflow serves as a critical framework supporting large-scale scientific discovery. However, their I/O performance has become the bottleneck in Exascale computing environment. Existing analysis methods either examine the I/O behavior of jobs in isolation, or rely on expert to manually interpret complex data dependencies, making it difficult to efficiently uncover I/O patterns in workflows. To address this, we propose a cluster-based automated I/O analysis approach. This approach constructs two types of clustering objects, intra-job and inter-job, and designs multi-dimensional I/O features to characterize them. The Clustering results are mapped onto the workflow structure for intuitive I/O pattern identification. We conduct a case study on real scientific workflow, demonstrating that our method can effectively identify job clusters with similar I/O behaviors. In particular, we can automatically detect data transfer patterns such as aggregation and broadcast in workflow, which pinpoint the I/O bottlenecks. This reduces the workload of domain experts and automates the analysis of I/O patterns.
