title: Two-Branch Boundary Map Consistency Network for Weakly-Supervised Temporal Forgery Localization in Videos
authors: Yancheng Li, Xiaofeng Cai, Xu Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Weakly-supervised temporal forgery localization (WS-TFL) seeks to pinpoint the start and end timestamps of manipulated segments within untrimmed videos using only modality-level labels. However, the absence of fine-grained annotations poses a significant challenge: how to effectively extract and utilize informative cues from limited supervision to bridge the gap between training and testing. To address this issue, we propose a pseudo label-driven framework, termed Two-branch Boundary Map Consistency Network (TBMCN). The framework is composed of two synergistic components. First, the Pseudo Boundary Map Generation (PBMG) branch capitalizes on frame-level prior knowledge derived from pre-trained models, and produces reliable pseudo labels through a Forgery Attention Selector (FAS) and a Forgery Attention Filter (FAF). Second, the Actual Boundary Map Prediction (ABMP) branch exploits intrinsic modal-level temporal relations within the video via a cross-attention mechanism and a self-attention module, yielding forgery localization predictions. Consistency constraints are imposed between the two branches to harmonize information across different granularities. The pseudo labels generated during training serve as intermediate products to narrow the training-testing discrepancy.In addition, we introduce a Boundary Sensitivity Module (BSM) to compel the model to generate a strong response at the temporal forgery boundary by ensuring temporal invariance in predictions across different real contexts. Extensive experiments conducted on the LAV-DF dataset validate the efficacy of our approach, with our method achieving 46.9 for AP@0.5. Our code is available at https://github.com/garfield5200/TBMCN.

title: Real-Time Embedded Signal-Processing for Time-of-Flight Computed Tomography ASIC
authors: D. Roshani, G. Bélanger, W. Tremblay, R. Espagnet, Y. Bérubé-Lauzière, A. C. Therrien, M.-A. Tétrault, R. Fontaine
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The advancement of Time-of-Flight Computed Tomography (ToF-CT) demands high-resolution timing and efficient data handling to improve image quality and reduce radiation dose. This work presents the implementation and verification of a mixed-signal ASIC for TOF-CT. The ASIC integrates 25 channels, each responsible for capturing and processing fast-timing signals from photo-detectors. Each channel includes a time-walk correction block, and a circuit to 3D histogram time-of-flight and energy of events. A serializer sends the processed data from all <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$25 \sim$</tex> channels to an a FPGA through LVDS link.

title: Quadrature Demodulator Characteristics Investigation
authors: Aleksey A. Bakulin, Aleksey S. Zavgorodniy
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This article introduces an investigation of a cost-effective quadrature demodulator. This device is used for the demodulation of modern quadrature-compressed navigation signals. The investigation includes two general parts. The first part of the investigation describes the influence of various types of jammer-like signals. This section presents simulation results obtained using a quadrature demodulator simplified mathematical model. Additionally, it provides the results of a laboratory study that was conducted with a specially developed method employing specialised precision equipment, including a universal signal simulator. Besides, analytical investigation also performed. Analytical conclusions compared with simulation and experimental results. The second part of this study introduces the impact of navigation signal phase and frequency offset on demodulation results. As in the previous part, in this part model simulations and laboratory investigations using a real device were performed. For the laboratory study, a special method and test stand using two vector signal generators were designed. This part introduces analytical conclusions about input channel and reference channel de-phasing. This conclusions compared with simulation results. This ws also performed to frequency offset analytical and simulation results. All experimental and simulation results of both parts introduced graphically.

title: Influence of Substrate Temperature on Structural and Electrophysical Properties of Thin Mo Films Obtained by DC Magnetron Sputtering
authors: Andrii Dobrozhan, Leonid Konotopsky, Anton Drozdov, Viktor Nikitin, Mykola Harchenko, Eduard Andriushchenko
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: This study explores thin molybdenum (Mo) films deposited by DC magnetron sputtering on polycrystalline Al<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> substrates for microelectronics. Mo films exhibit high conductivity, thermal stability, and corrosion resistance, making them suitable for semiconductor contacts, such as in CdTe-based devices. Two sample sets were prepared: at room temperature and with substrate heating (130°C). XRD confirmed a cubic Mo phase, with heated substrates showing improved crystallinity and reduced microstrains. SEM revealed smooth surfaces, while EDS detected minor oxygen at grain boundaries without oxide formation. Heated substrates yielded films with resistivity of 0.4×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-4</sup> Ω•cm lower than room-temperature films (2.5×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-4</sup> Ω•cm)—approaching bulk Mo values (5.2×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">-6</sup> Ω•cm). The enhanced performance is attributed to better adatom mobility and adhesion. These results demonstrate the potential of DC magnetron-sputtered Mo films as low-resistance, high-quality contact layers for microelectronics and photovoltaics.

title: Does Covert Cerebral Small Vessel Disease Modulate Early Change in Glymphatic Flow from DTI-ALPS?
authors: Julia Chu, Rachel J Sharkey, Cheryl R McCreary, Feryal Saad, Eric E Smith, Richard Frayne
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Diffusion tensor image analysis along the perivascular space (DTI-ALPS) has emerged as a method for non-invasively assessing glymphatic flow from magnetic resonance diffusion-weighted images. This index has been applied to the study of neurodegenerative and other brain disorders. It has been found to decrease in most studies of neurodegenerative conditions. Decreases in DTI-ALPS also have been found in healthy adults with age. Changes by sex are less consistently observed but seem to suggest females have higher indices. We explored in a healthy adult cohort whether DTI-ALPS is affected by age and sex, or serves as a surrogate/biomarker of the presence of early, covert small vessel disease (SVD) (white matter hyperintensities, lacunes, microbleeds or enlarged perivascular spaces), and vascular risk factors (VRFs) like diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia, or smoking. Separate linear regressions found a slower decrease in DTI-ALPS with age in females than males (-0.0034±0.0013 units/year vs -0.0048 ±0.0011 units/year, p<0.020 between slopes). DTI-ALPS was associated with SVD in one-way ANOVA testing (F=4.72, p=0.032) but not the presence of one or more VRFs (F=0.955, p=0.330). However, in a multivariable linear model only age was significant (-0.0041 units/year, p = 0.007). The other examined factors (sex, presence of SVD or VRF, and age×sex interaction) were all not significant. In conclusion, only older age was significantly associated with lower DTI-ALPS, suggesting a reduction in glymphatic flow with age. However, male sex, the presence of mild-to-moderate SVD pathology nor VRFs were linked to decreased glymphatic flow in a sample drawn from healthy community-dwelling adults.

title: Robust Federated Learning via Stable Cosine Similarity
authors: Rakib Ul Haque, Panagiotis Markopoulos
publish: 2025 IEEE International Carnahan Conference on Security Technology (ICCST)
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) remains vulnerable to performance degradation in the presence of non-IID data distributions, noisy updates, and adversarial clients. Existing robust aggregation methods often depend on heuristic thresholds, computationally expensive pairwise similarity matrices, or trusted data held by the server-limiting their scalability and practicality. In this work, we introduce FedSCS, a novel aggregation framework built around a new client trust score: Stable Cosine Similarity (SCS). This metric captures both geometric alignment and temporal stability, enabling dynamic and interpretable trust assessment. FedSCS is fully unsupervised, hyperparameter-free, and computationally efficient, avoiding pairwise operations and external validation data. We evaluate the method on CIFAR-10 classification and DOTA-v1 object detection under clean, non-IID, and noisy-client settings. Across all scenarios, FedSCS consistently outperforms strong baselines, achieving higher test accuracy in the most challenging regimes.

title: Spatial-temporal weed segmentation method based on SAM
authors: Zhongcheng Xie, Linli Zhou, Youqiang Sun, Xueyou Wei
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: In the process of modern agricultural production, how to effectively distinguish the location of crops and weeds and precisely apply medicine to cut grass is a difficult problem. Image segmentation in computer vision can be disturbed by different problems such as weather and false detection caused by similar weed and crop morphology, and the Segmentation Anything Model proposed the year before showed excellent performance in the zero-sample cue segmentation task. In this paper, a time-space dual flow architecture and dynamic cue generation combined with the SAM segmentation model were proposed, and the crop phenological stages were coded as spatial heat maps to segment. The method guided SAM to pay attention to sensitive areas, integrated the temporal difference map and phenological heat map, and dynamically selected the cue type (point/frame/mask) according to the growth stage to improve segmentation accuracy.

title: Design and Optimization of Low Power Persistent Logging System Based on Embedded Linux
authors: Caiwei Wu, Fengrui Zhang, Huangyin Chen, Junlin Zhu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Aiming at the demand for reliable storage of logs during the operation of AR/VR and smart glasses devices, this paper designs and implements a persistent logging system based on AOSP logd-persist. The system adopts a multi-threaded production-consumption model, and introduces a file rotation mechanism, a write throttling algorithm and a cache optimization strategy, which significantly reduces power consumption while ensuring system stability. Test results on the Smart Glasses platform show that the architecture saves more than 30 minutes of standby power consumption, improves system debuggability and extends flash memory lifetime. The results show that the logging framework has good engineering utility and platform portability.

title: IRSTD-SAM: Segment Any Infrared Small Target with Parallel Attention
authors: Qian Wang, Huilan Luo
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: Infrared small target detection (IRSTD) is challenging due to targets’ small size, low contrast, and complex backgrounds. We propose IRSTD-SAM, which adapts the SAM2 vision model for IRSTD by inserting lightweight adapters into Transformer MLP layers for efficient task-specific tuning. A dual-branch decoder with multi-scale fusion, spatial–channel attention, and Canny edge-guided refinement further enhances small-target features. Experiments show improved localization accuracy and background suppression in complex scenes.

title: Students’ Digital Readiness, Institutional Strategies and Global Frameworks: A Comprehensive Approach to Education Transformation
authors: Sanobar Khakimova, Uktam Madaminov, Nilufar Raxmonova, Nasriddinov Salakhiddin
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The digital transformation of education has emerged as a global priority, reflecting the growing importance of technology in ensuring inclusive, high-quality, and future-oriented learning. Its effectiveness, however, depends on the careful alignment of student digital readiness, institutional strategies, and internationally recognized frameworks. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis that brings together multiple perspectives: global policy insights from OECD surveys, conceptual contributions from Russian scholarship emphasizing humanistic values, student perspectives from Indian higher education, and the structural guidance of the UNESCO Six Pillars framework. The study argues that meaningful transformation requires bridging policy, institutional practices, and student experiences through a human-centred and evidence-based approach. Findings reveal that while governments and institutions are investing heavily in infrastructure and digital strategies, persistent gaps remain in student digital literacy, teacher preparedness, parental involvement, and sustainable financing. By synthesizing international evidence, the paper develops a multi-level model linking student readiness with institutional strategies and global frameworks, offering practical recommendations for policymakers, educators, and stakeholders to ensure a sustainable and equitable digital transformation in education.

title: IndoBERT for Multi-Class Sentiment Classification of Student Aspirations: The Role of Stopword Removal and Stemming
authors: Adelfia Milka Novtagravina, Ardytha Luthfiarta, Adhitya Nugraha, Defri Kurniawan, Ainur Rahma Miftakhul Rizqi, Talitha Olga Ramadhani
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: This dataset contains student aspiration texts written in Indonesian, which are automatically labeled using the pseudo-labeling technique to reduce manual annotation effort. Two preprocessing scenarios are compared: with and without stemming. The IndoBERT model was adapted using the same hyperparameters to ensure a fair comparison. It shows the model with stemming reached an 81.98% accuracy and F1-score 0.81, compared to the version without stemming, which had an accuracy 79.65% and an F1-score 0.73. In addition, stemming improved the model's capability in detecting positive sentiment, especially in unbalanced datasets. These findings suggest that stemming can improve sentiment classification performance in morphologically rich languages such as Indonesian. These results highlight the significance of adapting preprocessing strategies for the language characteristics in the dataset, and they suggest that stemming should not be universally excluded in transformer-based NLP tasks for non-English languages. This research provides new insight into improving sentiment analysis performance in low-resource.

title: The Impact of Player Type Based Gamification to Student Engagement in OSS Project
authors: Regy Renanda Rahman, Mira Kania Sabariah, Jati H. Husen
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: Contributing to open source software (OSS) projects can provide valuable insights and experiences for students in the field of software engineering, such as learning the codebase, collaborating with other developers, and more. However, students often face various barriers in contributing that cause them to not engage further, which emphasizes the importance of strategies to reduce student dropout in OSS projects. This study investigates the impact of personalized gamification on student motivation and engagement in OSS projects. By applying the Hexad Framework, game elements were tailored to match diverse student preferences, creating a more engaging and supportive OSS contribution experience. An evaluation was conducted involving students in real OSS projects to examine their engagement and motivation toward both the projects and the environments. Through semi-structured interviews, the results show that personalized gamified environments can maintain engagement by facilitating the onboarding process of students into OSS projects and motivating them using elements that match their individual preferences, such as points, achievements/badges, and leaderboards. Although intrinsic aspects still play a role in motivating students, gamification elements are able to motivate students with different player types in OSS projects. These findings suggest using gamification as a strategy in OSS projects to retain new contributors, particularly among students.

title: Analysis of Modulation Modes Based on Multi-User Direct Sequence Spread Spectrum Underwater Acoustic Communication
authors: Jianzhou Lu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: The underwater acoustic channel exhibits multipath effects, propagation loss, and Doppler frequency shift that are far more significant than those in radio communication, making them key issues to be addressed. In this paper, a simulation model of a multi-user direct sequence spread spectrum communication system based on the underwater acoustic channel is built using the Simulink platform. Through the simulation results of this model, the bit error rate (BER) and transmission rate of basic digital modulation modes under the underwater acoustic channel are analyzed. The simulation results show that when the number of users increases, the BER of 2PSK rises significantly, while the deterioration of 2FSK is milder due to its frequency diversity characteristic. When SNR $\gt0 \mathrm{~dB}$, 2PSK performs better in scenarios with a small number of users ($\boldsymbol{\leq} \mathbf{3}$ users), but multi-user interference will damage phase coherence. The hybrid scheme of frequency division multiple access (FDMA) and code division multiple access (CDMA) can significantly improve the antiinterference capability of 2 FSK. By setting a 10 kHz carrier interval to form a guard band, the multi-user BER is effectively reduced.

title: Technological Innovations in Delivering Human-Centric Mental Health and Moral Ethics for Agenda Civil Servant Candidates in BRIN
authors: Riskiyana Prihatiningsih, Arvi Sekar Varenta, Diniy Hidayatur Rahman, Widya Multisari
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: This study reports the development and expert validation of a Google Classroom based instructional model designed to deliver a human-centric learning approach focused on mental health and moral ethics for civil servant candidates within the Indonesian National Research and Innovation Agency (BRIN). The platform combines multimedia content including videos, case studies, and reflection prompts with key learning objects such as a lesson plan, handout, and slide presentation. Grounded in life-based and humanistic education principles, the model aims to enhance empathy, ethical reasoning, and mental resilience. Expert evaluations from both media and material specialists gave scores mostly 3 (good) and 4 (very good) across assessed aspects. According to the interpretive scale (3.1–4.0 = Very High), the developed media and materials fall into the "Very High Worth Using" category. The highest scores were achieved in usefulness, interactivity, and motivation, indicating that the Google Classroom–based materials meet core expectations of interactive, human-centric learning. Slightly lower scores (3) were recorded for visual contrast, colour combination, font readability, and integration across handout, slide, and assessment tools, signalling areas for refinement especially in the slide presentation and visual design to optimise learner experience. These results confirm the platform’s potential to deliver meaningful and scalable human-centric professional education in the public sector. Future research should focus on measuring learning outcomes and the long-term effects of this training on civil servant behaviour and well-being.

title: Recent Advances in 3D Optical Microsurface Profiling
authors: Sergey Tyryshkin
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This paper presents a comprehensive review of contemporary advancements in the field of 3D optical profiling of microsurfaces. By exploring various techniques such as confocal microscopy (ICM), focal variation (FV), and coherent scanning interferometry (CSI), we highlight their applications, strengths, and limitations. Key achievements include improved methods for measuring surface roughness, topology, and microstructural characteristics across diverse sample types, from ultra-smooth optical surfaces to coarsely textured 3D-printed materials. We also discuss emerging hybrid approaches like structured illumination and conoscopic holography, which offer enhanced performance and versatility in real-world industrial settings. Our findings emphasize the critical role of advanced 3D optical profilometry in enabling rapid, accurate, and cost-effective characterization of microscale surfaces. Moreover, ongoing innovations in optical hardware design, computational algorithms, and integration with machine learning techniques promise to broaden the scope and utility of this technology across multiple sectors, including manufacturing, biomedicine, and materials science. Despite remaining challenges related to material compatibility, scale constraints, and post-processing requirements, our work underscores the immense potential of modern 3D optical profiling tools to transform scientific discovery and industrial productivity alike.

title: A 500MHz-5GHz Low Jitter Phase-Locked Loop with Adaptive-Bandwidth Technique
authors: Jingwen Li, Shaohui Pan, Huachao Xu
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Semiconductor Devices and Integration Technology (ASDIT)
abstract: Conventional PLLs face a fundamental limitation where the loop bandwidth must remain below 1/10 of the reference frequency to ensure stability, resulting in prolonged locking times at lower input frequencies and large division ratio. To overcome this challenge, we propose an innovative adaptive-bandwidth control circuit that dynamically optimizes the loop parameters (charge-pump current and filter characteristics) across varying reference frequencies, ensuring robust stability while minimizing locking time. Key innovations include a programmable charge pump and a damping factor adjustment algorithm that ensures optimal loop dynamics across the entire operating range. The proposed PLL achieves an input frequency range of 3–100MHz and an output frequency range of 500MHz–5GHz, with a typical fast-locking time of 2μs. The design maintains excellent power efficiency, consuming only 2.2mA at 3GHz output under a 0.8V supply with a compact area of 0.047mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>.

title: Comparative Analysis of Magnetic Compatibility of Two Variants of the Design of Electromagnets of the Orientation Control System of Micro-Satellites
authors: Andriy Getman
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The magnetic interference created by the electromagnets of the orientation control system inside a small spacecraft is considered. Depending on the two variants of the electromagnet design, an analysis of the magnetic field strength in the central part of five satellite models was comply. It was established that the level of magnetic interference created by a cylindrical electromagnet is 2-4 times lower than the magnetic field of a square current winding under the condition of the same magnetic moments and length. It is shown that the specific magnetic moment per unit of mass and electric power of a cylindrical electromagnet is approximately ten times higher than that created by a square current winding.

title: Development of a Lemmatization Algorithm: Interpreting Open Compound Words
authors: Abdusobir Saidov, Maksud Sharipov
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Open compound words pose significant challenges in the lemmatization process for morphologically rich and low-resource languages such as Uzbek, where multi-word expressions often carry unified meanings but appear as separate tokens. This research aims to address this issue by developing a lemmatization algorithm tailored specifically for Uzbek open compound words, which are underrepresented in existing NLP resources. The method relies on a dictionary-based approach supported by a finite-state machine (FSM) to recognize and normalize compound words without requiring prior tokenization. The compiled lexicon includes over 900 compound units across various parts of speech, including verbs, adverbs, pronouns, interjections, and auxiliary verb constructions. Evaluation of the algorithm on structured textual data demonstrates its ability to accurately identify compound forms and map them to their base lemmas with high precision. The approach does not require large annotated corpora or complex machine learning models, making it transparent, reproducible, and adaptable for resource-scarce languages. These findings highlight the potential of rule-based lexical methods combined with finite-state modeling in improving lemmatization performance and suggest promising directions for further development of NLP tools for the Uzbek language and other agglutinative languages with similar structural characteristics.

title: Improved Uni-Modal Chinese Fake News Detection Leveraging User Comments
authors: Le Zhang, Xin Zhao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: Relying solely on the textual content of news pieces is often insufficient for effective fake news detection (FND), as misleading information is frequently crafted with the intent to deceive readers. However, related discussions on social media platforms such as Weibo and X (formerly Twitter) often provide valuable context through user comments. These responses can serve as a critical signal in evaluating the authenticity of news. In this paper, we demonstrate that incorporating user comments into a uni-modal FND pipeline significantly enhances its performance. Specifically, we leverage the [CLS] token representation obtained from a BERT-based encoder for the target news piece and combine it with the vector representations of associated user comments using a Transformer-Based fusion module. This simple yet effective integration sets a new state-of-the-art on the largest Chinese FND dataset, Weibo-21, improving the previous best macro F1-score from 0.943 (BERT-EMO) to 0.97748. Code is at https://github.com/lezhang-thu/Chinese-Fnd-weibo21 to facilitate further research.

title: A Label Extension-Based General Skill Prediction Algorithm for Resume Completion
authors: Jinrui He, Li Cheng, Canmei Huang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: This paper addresses the prevalent issue of information incompleteness in resumes, particularly in the critical work skills section, which the key part of a resume. Current approaches predominantly focus either on extracting named entities from text for skill prediction or conducting fixed-label classification, both of which lack generalizability when encountering novel skill categories. To overcome these limitations, we propose a Label Extension-Based General Skill Prediction (LEGSP) algorithm. LEGSP innovatively reframes skill prediction as a universal binary classification problem, endowing the model with theoretical adaptability to diverse skill types. The framework incorporates a standardized skill library construction method based on inclusion relations and semantic similarity, combined with a hybrid label sampling strategy, achieving effective skill completion for resume enhancement. Experimental results demonstrate that LEGSP significantly outperforms baseline methods in both prediction accuracy. The algorithm exhibits particular advantages in handling low-frequency skills and previously unseen skill categories, establishing its practical value for online recruitment systems.

title: Underwater Acoustic Image Enhancement Algorithm Based on Luminance Difference Fusion
authors: Jianfeng Yang, Hao Geng, Xiyun Ge, Junbo Zhao
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: To address the issue of poor quality in underwater acoustic images, this paper proposes an underwater acoustic image enhancement algorithm based on luminance difference fusion to improve sonar images. By integrating bicubic interpolation, the Contrast Limited Adaptive Histogram Equalization (CLAHE) algorithm, and a luminance correction model, the proposed method enhances both the detail visibility and overall visual quality of acoustic images. The bicubic interpolation preserves high-frequency details, CLAHE enhances local contrast, while the luminance correction model accurately adjusts non-uniform illumination. This collaborative processing mechanism significantly improves both detail visibility and overall visual quality of the images, demonstrating superior performance in both objective metrics and subjective evaluations. Furthermore, a pool experiment was conducted in which a multibeam sonar mounted on a Remotely Operated Vehicle (ROV) was used to acquire acoustic images of underwater targets. The performance of the proposed method was compared with that of the Histogram Equalization (HE) algorithm, CLAHE algorithm, Relative Global Histogram Stretching (RGHS) algorithm, Block-Matching and 3D filtering (BM3D) algorithm, Rayleigh algorithm, and Singal Scale Retinex (SSR) algorithm. The experimental results demonstrate that the proposed image enhancement technique not only improves the overall image quality but also preserves the richness of image details and the integrity of information, showcasing its comprehensive enhancement capabilities.

title: Analysis of the Laws of Distribution of Gases Growth Rates in Serviceable Normally Operating 110-330 kV Transformers of Non-hermetic Construction
authors: Oleg Shutenko, Volodymyr Dovgalyuk
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The paper presents the results of analyses of the laws of distribution of gases growth rates for 432 serviceable 110 kV transformers and 330 kV autotransformers of non-hermetic construction, which are operated by five different energy companies of Ukraine. A detailed description of the proposed procedure of statistical analysis of the results of periodic tests is given. The significant influence of duration and operating modes of transformers, peculiarities of their design, as well as the type of transformer oils on the values of gases growth rates is established. The performed researches have shown that in serviceable normally operating transformers of non-hermetic construction the gases growth rates can be described by double exponential distribution, which adequately takes into account the mechanisms of gases formation in serviceable non-hermetic equipment.

title: Low Voltage Modular Inverter System For Mining Applications
authors: Joshua Jagnanan, Terry Voigt
publish: 2025 IEEE IAS Petroleum and Chemical Industry Technical Conference (PCIC)
abstract: Underground potash mines present many challenging work areas, some of which have low heights. These conditions pose significant challenges for manufacturers of adjustable speed drives, as their cabinets tend to be taller at larger power ratings. This height issue often results in the installation of drives with long cable lengths between the drives and their motors. Over time, this can lead to damaging dV/dt voltage spikes impacting the motor windings. A potential solution to these specific low-height areas is the implementation of a modular drive system housed within a mining sled. This technical paper presents an in-depth analysis of such a system, specifically installed on a highspeed loadout conveyor belt within an underground potash mine located in Saskatchewan, Canada. The study’s primary focus is on the replacement of existing adjustable speed drives and switched reluctance motors. The new installation features a modular drive system and standard induction motors, all operating on a common drive pulley. The paper provides details of the technical specifications of the modular drive system. It includes comprehensive information on its unique design and power platform, both of which contribute to its suitability for underground mining applications. Additionally, the paper discusses technical programming aspects in detail. These include the setup of the master-follower configuration, calculations for acceleration and deceleration, motor tuning procedures, and the implementation of dynamic braking.

title: Research on Abnormal Water Quality Monitoring Based on PCA_SVM
authors: Ting Yu, Pengfei Jiang, Ziyue Wang, Jichang Guo, Zhiliang Chen, Chang Liu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: The issue of lake water safety has become increasingly prominent. Although traditional water quality monitoring methods such as cluster analysis are widely used, there is strong nonlinearity and randomness among water quality parameters, making it difficult to meet the requirements of precise monitoring. Support Vector Machine (SVM) is widely used in the modeling of nonlinear systems, but it has the problem of serious time-consuming training for large samples. Principal Component Analysis (PCA) can enhance computational efficiency through dimensionality reduction. To this end, this paper proposes the PCA-SVM algorithm, aiming to combine the advantages of both to optimize the monitoring effect of abnormal water quality. The study takes the water quality operation data collected by the coastal monitoring stations in China since January 2016 as the experimental dataset. This dataset contains 13 feature dimensions and 2,880 samples, and the linear correlation of the samples is poor, which meets the requirements of multi-dimensional nonlinear datasets. The experiment compared the PCA-SVM model with the traditional K-means model to evaluate the model performance in terms of monitoring accuracy and computational efficiency. The training of the Kmeans model took 6.3625 seconds. According to the "Environmental Quality Standards for Surface Water" (GB 3838-2002), among the 144 outliers monitored, only 94 were actually outliers, with an accuracy rate of only 65.28%. The training time of the PCA-SVM model is only 1.0375 seconds, which is 83.69% shorter than that of the K-means model. A total of 143 outliers were detected in the same dataset. After standard determination, 106 actual outliers were found, with an accuracy rate of 74.13%, which was approximately 8.85 percentage points higher than that of the K-means model. Studies show that the PCA-SVM model ingeniously combines the dimensionality reduction advantage of PCA with the dynamic monitoring ability of SVM. It is significantly superior to the traditional K-means method in both computational efficiency and monitoring accuracy, and can provide more powerful technical support for water quality detection. However, there is still room for improvement in the accuracy of this model. In the future, further exploration of optimization paths can be conducted to enhance the precision of alerts.

title: Comparative Analysis of the Efficiency of Entropy Codes and Recommendations for Their Use
authors: Boris Ryabko, Andrey Fionov, Ivan Baksheev, Vyacheslav Zhuravlev
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Entropy codes<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">1</sup>, i.e. methods of lossless data compression, are widely used in various systems for transmitting and storing audio and video data and for many other information systems. However, despite numerous works, the choice of an entropy code for a specific task requires extensive theoretical and experimental research. The purpose of this paper is to analyze known entropy codes, allowing to simplify the choice of a method for a specific data compression system, paying special attention to the transmission of video and audio signals. We show that letter-wise entropy codes can be useful only for small blocks of letters.So we focus our analysis on stream codes, namely, arithmetic coding, range coding and asymmetric numeral systems coding. The Huffman code is used as a point to comparison.The carried out analysis allows us to develop recommendations that significantly simplify the practical application of entropy codes and their subsequent assessment. We start with binary codes which are widely used in audio and video compression and then show thatlarge alphabet codes can provide a noticeable increase in coding speed, at least for the case of small source memory.

title: Digital Calibration Certificate Level 1 Automation in BSN BRIN Indonesia
authors: Aldrik Ciaputra, Arya Wicaksana
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on New Media Studies (CONMEDIA)
abstract: The National Standardization Agency of Indonesia (BSN) has set the objective of adopting international Digital Calibration Certificate (DCC) standards up to Level 2. Document formats within BSN exhibit considerable variability, with more than 40 templates currently in use. To address this challenge, this study introduces a rule-based automation framework utilizing Document Layout Analysis (DLA). The proposed heuristic approach extracts and classifies data blocks (forms, tables, and paragraphs) from Excel files, and subsequently maps and populates them into Microsoft Word templates. The evaluation, conducted on 10 authentic BSN calibration documents obtained from three distinct laboratories, demonstrated a 100% F1-score in identifying Region of Interest (ROI). Furthermore, the extraction of Entity of Interest (EOI) achieved a precision of 94.4%, with a single failure arising from the handling of a multi-line form structure. These findings indicate that the proposed DLA-based method provides a robust foundation for advancing BSN’s implementation of Level 2 DCC standards.

title: Blockchain-Based Trusted Data Exchange Framework for Real-World Asset Digitalization: An Integrated Approach to Data Integrity and Cross-Border Compliance
authors: Yangcheng Hu, Wei Xiong
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Digital Management (ICAIDM)
abstract: Digital asset management (DAM) represents a transformative shift in the global economy, redefining how realworld assets (RWA) are digitized, traded, and governed. This study addresses critical challenges in blockchain-based DAM, including data verifiability, regulatory compliance, and cross-border interoperability. By integrating trusted data spaces with adaptive regulatory protocols, we propose a novel framework that balances technological robustness with legal validity. A mixed-method approach analyzing 251 RWA projects reveals that implementing trusted data protocols reduces audit discrepancies by 37 % and enhances settlement efficiency by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{4 2 \%}$</tex> compared to conventional methods. This research advances academic and practical discourse by establishing a standardized DAM framework that harmonizes innovation with regulatory requirements, particularly addressing global financial complexities.

title: Adjustment of Limit Values of Transformer Oil Indicators Considering the Presence of Correlation Relationships Between Them
authors: Oleg Shutenko, Serhii Ponomarenko
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The article proposes a method for determining the limit values of transformer oil indicators simultaneously for a set of parameters, taking into account significant stochastic relationships between them, using the minimum risk method. The proposed method is distinguished by the fact that the limit values of the indicators are determined by minimizing the mean risk function for several oil indicators that are stochastically interrelated, using the Nelder-Mead method. A comparative analysis showed that the use of limit values obtained through the proposed method allows risk reduction by a factor of 1.2 to 7.8 compared to the risks associated with using the limit values specified in the standards IEC 60599:2022, IEEE Std C57.106-2015, and SOU-N EE 43-101:2009 for 110 kV transformers and 330 kV autotransformers. Moreover, the limit values obtained by minimizing the risk function for two indicators are accompanied by risk levels 1.3 to 23.7 times lower than those associated with the use of limit values also obtained by the minimum risk method, but for one-dimensional distributions. The obtained results indicate the high reliability of the proposed method.

title: Arc Flash Anaysis for Electrication Projects How Far Upstream and Downstream Should Be Re-Evaluated a Refinery Case Study
authors: Tony Acayan, Albert Marroquin, Jimmy Singh, Varsha Rajpurohit, Sina Ghods
publish: 2025 IEEE IAS Petroleum and Chemical Industry Technical Conference (PCIC)
abstract: This paper will review the implementation and share lessons learned of an arc flash analysis study that was performed in support of a large infrastructure refinery project in Southern California. This paper is a follow-up to PCIC2024-5 paper titled "THE PATH TO DECARBONIZATION TROUGH ELECTRIFICATION, A REFINERY CASE STUDY AND LESSONS LEARNED" [1] presented in the General session in Orlando, FL.Because of the extensive modifications to the existing refinery facilities, short-circuit and arc-flash (AF) incident energy (IE) values were re-evaluated. This paper will review how far upstream and downstream the re-evaluation took place. The goal of this paper is to serve as a reference and refresher guide for protection engineers performing arc-flash analysis.The goal of arc-flash analysis is to ensure full compliance with the project criterion established with the latest standards and regulations. The arc flash levels identified in the study and NFPA 70E allow the facilities to classify the IE at various locations to help identify the proper personal protective equipment (PPE) rating to ensure personnel safety.

title: SCoralESC: Lightweight Underwater Coral Detection Algorithm Based on an Improved YOLO11n
authors: Baojiang Ye, Wenbin Wang, Haifeng Wang, Tianyi Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: In response to the current challenges in coral monitoring and conservation, this paper proposes a lightweight underwater coral detection algorithm—SCoralESC—designed to tackle detection difficulties such as color shift, low contrast, small object size, and target occlusion in complex underwater environments. The method replaces the traditional YOLO11n backbone with EfficientNet to enhance fine-grained feature representation; it introduces a SlimNeck module that integrates the VoV GSCSP structure and GSConv lightweight convolution to achieve efficient multi-scale feature fusion and discriminative feature generation. Additionally, the CARAFE content-aware upsampling module is incorporated to improve small object detection performance while preserving spatial details. Ablation studies and model comparisons were conducted on a coral dataset collected in Sanya, China (comprising six coral categories, 1,204 images, and 2,838 annotated instances). SCoralESC demonstrates superior overall performance in terms of GFLOPs, Precision, Recall, mAP@50, and mAP@50:95, with a particularly notable mAP@50:95 of 0.593, outperforming models such as YOLOv8n, YOLOv10n, YOLO12n, and RT-DETR. These results highlight the model’s outstanding capabilities in small object recognition, computational efficiency, and deployment feasibility. The proposed model is well-suited for real-time, large-scale coral ecosystem monitoring and long-term marine ecological research tasks.

title: Application Research of Computer Simulation Technology in the Development of Unconventional Oil and Gas Resources
authors: Yingrui Ma, Xiaoyu Wang, Dongping Yang, Zhou Yu, Jinjie Xu, Chen Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: This paper explores the pivotal role of computer simulation technology in the development of unconventional oil and gas resources. The reservoirs of unconventional oil and gas are structurally complex and difficult to develop, with traditional production tests being costly. Numerical simulation methods can significantly reduce research investment. The article provides a detailed introduction to the modeling process, including three stages: data collection, model construction, and prediction optimization, and analyzes the application effects of simulation technology in various extraction methods of natural gas hydrates. In addition, the role of computer simulation in the in-situ conversion process of low maturity shale oil and the application of intelligent optimization algorithms in improving development efficiency are also studied. It is ultimately pointed out that computer simulation technology can optimize development strategies and increase recovery rates, and is a core support tool for achieving efficient and sustainable development.

title: Reflectarray Antenna with Hat-Feed for Ku-band DBS Receiving
authors: Dmitriy Shabanov, Konstantin Lemberg, Nikita Sivov, Daniil Rimatsky, Nikita Marushchenko
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This paper presents the design, fabrication, and experimental characterization of a reflectarray antenna operating in the Direct Broadcast Satellite frequency band (11.7 – 12.5 GHz). The reflectarray is fed by a compact hat-feed designed for the Ku-band receive and transmit frequencies (10.7 – 12.75 GHz and 13.75 – 14.5 GHz, respectively) with septum polarizer, enabling the reception of circularly polarized signals. The unit cells, based on ring slots with variable inner diameters, were optimized to provide a 320-degree phase shift range. The antenna, based on a 3 mm-thick aluminum composite panel, was manufactured using computer numerical control milling, and its performance was validated through near-field measurements. The results demonstrate a high gain, exceeding 35 dBi at the center frequency and above 32 dBi across the entire band, with side lobe levels below -15 dB and cross-polarization discrimination better than 15.5 dB. The measured results confirm that the antenna system is suitable for satellite communication applications.

title: Comparison of Hilbert and Foucault-Hilbert Spatial Optical Filtering Methods
authors: Eduard Arbuzov, Yuri Dubnishchev, Olga Zolotukhina
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The inhomogeneities study in transparent media is important in many areas of science and industry. Over more than an existence century, shadow devices have become widely used to solve this problem. Hilbert optics is an optics branch that uses the Hilbert transform over functions of two spatial coordinates on a plane. The Hilbert transform made it possible to visualize optical inhomogeneities with extremely high contrast simultaneously for all spatial frequencies transmitted by the optical system, in contrast to the Foucault-Hilbert transform, which is implemented using the amplitude "Foucault knife". Also, the Hilbert optics elements are simple in design, have high noise immunity when handled carelessly, and the visualization images of optical inhomogeneities can be easily interpreted by an operator without special training. However, Hilbert diagnostics has not received due distribution to date, despite the indicated advantages. A visual comparison of the two research methods under consideration using numerical models as an example is performed in this paper. Mathematical justifications for the Hilbert and Foucault-Hilbert transforms are given. Some applied tasks that were accomplished using Hilbert visualization and are difficult to implement using the classical shadow method are noted in the conclusion.

title: Dual-Channel Heterogeneous Graph Neural Network with Relation-Meta-Path Collaborative Interactions
authors: Yimeng Chen, Lei Qu, Sami Mohammed Ahmed Ghanem, Wenke Zang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning, Pattern Recognition and Automation Engineering (MLPRAE)
abstract: The Heterogeneous Graph Neural Network (HGNN) model has gained wide-spread application due to its powerful heterogeneous graph information processing capabilities. However, extant methods frequently neglect fine-grained relationship interactions in graphs and encounter difficulties in simultaneously capturing low-order and high-order semantic features. In order to address this issue, the present paper proposes a dual-channel heterogeneous graph neural network model (RMPC-HGNN) based on relationship-meta-path collaborative interaction. The model first calculates dynamic attention weights within the relationship subgraph by integrating source node features, target node features, and edge features. This enables cross-node-type semantic-aware message passing. Secondly, the model facilitates interaction between different relational subgraphs through an attention weight fusion mechanism. Concurrently, the GATv2Conv operator is applied on the metapath subgraph to capture node interactions within paths, and a semantic attention mechanism is employed to fuse multi-path features. Subsequently, the model introduces learnable parameters to dynamically balance the output features of the relationship channel and meta-path channel, and generates the final node representations through L2 norm normalization. Node classification experiments on three real-world heterogeneous datasets demonstrate that RMPC-HGNN significantly outperforms existing baseline methods.

title: Application of EMSA for Condition Monitoring of Medium-Voltage Motors, Generators, Transformers, Bus and Cables, Case Studies
authors: James E. Timperley, José M. Vallejo, Peter O. Longo, Eratsi E. Alonso
publish: 2025 IEEE IAS Petroleum and Chemical Industry Technical Conference (PCIC)
abstract: Case studies of EMSA (ElectroMagnetic Signature Analysis) for condition assessment of process critical assets is presented. Several warning identifier conditions for motors, generators, transformers, isolated phase bus and power cables are discussed.

title: Beyond The Thermal Model: Motor Protection in Specialized Applications, Soft Starters, Synchronous Motors, and VFDs
authors: Alexander Novoa, David K. Kimbrough
publish: 2025 IEEE IAS Petroleum and Chemical Industry Technical Conference (PCIC)
abstract: The motor thermal protection model in commercial electronic relays is optimized to protect motors in the most common industrial installation, an induction motor starting across the line. Using these relays in different applications, such as soft starting, variable frequency drives, and synchronous motors, requires special attention to ensure the motor is properly protected during both starting and running conditions. While some manufacturers address these special situations with different relay options and newer relay models, an engineering assessment is still required. This paper presents several real-world examples common in the oil and gas and petrochemical industries that require consideration and offers solutions to ensure that critical machines are properly protected.

title: Image Representation by Atomic Functions: Features for Classification
authors: Viktor Makarichev, Vladimir Lukin, Sergii Kryvenko, Iryna Brysina, Andrii Vorobiov, Nadiia Kozhemiakina
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: Digital images are widely used in many technologies that are an integral part of various systems. Compared to other types of data, their specific feature is a relatively large size that restricts the use of different machine learning (ML) and computer vision (CV) methods. A large data processing time and image spatial complexity become additional blockers for applying many ML and CV algorithms if real-time results are required or if the main computations must be performed on autonomous systems with limited capabilities. For this reason, the problem of the development of a compact image representation, which contains features useful in ML/CV techniques, is relevant. In this paper, we consider the use of discrete atomic transform (DAT) based on atomic functions for solving this problem. Our previous investigation had proven that DAT provided a combination of data compression and encryption features. This research shows that DAT representation is ML/CV-oriented with respect to image classification using state-of-the-art convolutional neural networks. Thus, its application in different methods for image analysis is promising.

title: FedGCN-GRU: a federated learning method for multi-region power load forecasting with spatiotemporal correlation
authors: Jingjia Chen, Na Li, Xingbo Liu, Ju Liu, Xiaoyun Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Multi-regional power load forecasting is essential for effective grid dispatch and energy management. Traditional forecasting methods often fail to capture cross-regional spatiotemporal correlations effectively, and concerns about data privacy hinder centralized training approaches. In this paper, we propose FedGCN-GRU, which is a federated GCN-based model that integrates Spearman correlation analysis to quantify inter-regional load dependencies. The proposed method introduces a Spearman adjacency matrix that replaces conventional distance matrices, which enhances the characterization of nonlinear inter-regional relationships. After that, a federated GCN-GRU architecture to facilitate distributed training and mitigate risks associated with data centralization. Evaluations across multiple regional power datasets reveal that our model reduces the MAE by 19.9%, 28.2%, and 37.4% compared to the existing methods, which provides a novel approach for collaborative multi-regional load forecasting.

title: Deep Learning-Based Security Monitoring Technology for 5G Computer Network Traffic
authors: Lijuan He
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: This paper proposes a bidirectional recurrent neural network-based 5G traffic security monitoring model that integrates time series embedding and spatial convolutional features to construct an end-to-end attack identification framework. The model enhances modeling capabilities for highdimensional dynamic traffic features by incorporating multi-head attention mechanisms and residual connections within the LSTM architecture. Experiments conducted on CIC-IDS2017 and UNSW-NB15 datasets demonstrate an F1 score improvement of $4.2 \%$ and $6.8 \%$ over SVM and shallow neural networks, respectively. Inference latency is controlled within 3.5 ms, validating the method’s comprehensive advantages in accuracy and real-time performance.

title: A Novel Smart False Target Jamming Method for FDA-MIMO Radar via Orthogonal Signal Delay Modulation
authors: Pinpin Lv, Nae Zheng, Xiukun Ren, Sheng Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Focusing on the application scenario where aerial targets implement self-defense jamming against ground-based Frequency Diverse Array - Multiple Input Multiple Output (FDAMIMO) radars, this paper deduces and analyzes the signal model when FDA-MIMO radar signals are intercepted. Subsequently, it proposes a novel smart false target jamming method.This method generates multiple false target jamming signals by applying multiple delay modulations to the multi-channel orthogonal signals of the FDA-MIMO radar. In this study, we derive the output expressions of the generated jamming signals after they pass through the matched filters of each radar channel and analyze the specific false target jamming effects. Simulation results validate the effectiveness of the proposed jamming method. It can generate multiple false targets with intensities greater than those of real targets in multiple receiving channels of the FDA-MIMO radar, thereby disrupting the radar’s detection of real targets. Meanwhile, this method enables flexible control over the generation positions of false targets, facilitating its application in various radar jamming strategies.

title: Prevention of Attacks Using QR Codes Based on Cryptographic Approaches and Machine Learning Methods
authors: Shohida Yusupova, Otabek Khujaev, Ogabek Matyaqubov
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: QR codes have become a ubiquitous tool in modern society, widely used in mobile payments, authentication, marketing, and e-government services; however, their increasing adoption has also introduced new security challenges, as attackers exploit QR codes to distribute malicious software, conduct phishing attacks (QRishing), and steal sensitive user data. Since the first reported malicious QR code attack in 2011, the number and sophistication of such threats have steadily grown, particularly targeting smartphones and other mobile devices. Existing protection mechanisms, including URL verification tools, visual markers, and traditional cryptographic methods, often fail to provide a comprehensive and scalable solution, making advanced defense strategies essential. This paper provides a systematic overview of current QR code security threats and countermeasures, with a particular focus on cryptographic approaches and machine learning-based detection methods, while critically analyzing the limitations of existing solutions. Furthermore, we propose a secure architectural framework that integrates modern cryptographic algorithms with intelligent threat detection to achieve a balance between security, performance, and usability, thereby enhancing the resilience of QR codes against emerging attacks. Our findings contribute to the ongoing discussion on mobile security and highlight the necessity of robust, scalable mechanisms for protecting future applications.

title: Evaluation of Local Prediction Intervals with Locart, Loforrest, XGBoost, and Stacking Regression: An Empirical Study on Used Car Price Prediction
authors: Jarot Muchtar, Guruh Fajar Shidik
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Prediction intervals are critical for quantifying uncertainty in regression tasks, yet many standard methods such as Locart and Loforest often yield suboptimal results on small, complex datasets. This paper addresses the following research question: Can the integration of advanced off-the-shelf models, specifically XGBoost and Stacking Regression, within a conformal prediction framework, improve the reliability and precision of prediction intervals for used car price estimation? Unlike prior work, this study does not propose a new theoretical framework or algorithm, but rather provides a transparent, empirical comparison of established methods. The rationale for selecting XGBoost is its proven ability to handle mixed data types, regularize against overfitting, and efficiently model nonlinear relationships. Stacking Regression is included for its meta-learning capability, combining strengths of multiple base models. The evaluation uses Conditional Coverage Absolute Deviation (CCAD), Standard Mean Interval Score (SMIS), and Coverage Percentage, with bootstrapped confidence intervals and paired t-tests to assess statistical significance. Results show that while XGBoost and Stacking Regression can reduce CCAD and SMIS compared to Locart and Loforest, the improvements are not always statistically significant due to the small sample size (n=150). The study also discusses time complexity, sensitivity to noise, and robustness to outliers. Overall, this work is best categorized as an incremental application study, highlighting tradeoffs between precision and coverage, and providing practical guidance for practitioners rather than introducing methodological innovation.

title: Human and Animal Detection Using YOLO Algorithms: A Comparative Study of YOLOv8, YOLOv9, YOLOv10, and YOLOv11
authors: Ahmad Yogi Kulumul Ilham, I Gede Putra Kusuma Negara
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: Monitoring wildlife using UAV based thermal imagery is an effective approach for conservation, anti poaching, and human wildlife conflict mitigation. This study benchmarks four recent YOLO versions (YOLOv8–YOLOv11) on the BIRDSAI thermal UAV dataset to detect five categories: human, elephant, lion, giraffe, and unknown. Models were fine-tuned and evaluated on validation and unseen test datasets using mAP, F1-score, and inference speed. While validation results showed strong learning performance, test results revealed a sharp drop due to noise and class imbalance, with YOLOv11 maintaining the highest robustness and YOLOv10 delivering the fastest inference. These findings highlight trade offs between accuracy and speed, and provide practical insights for deploying AI-based wildlife monitoring systems under real-world conditions.

title: Research on game data security verification method based on multimodal fusion
authors: Song Liu, De Li, Xun Jin
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: As cheating in games has developed, various plug-in programs that rely on technological progress have emerged. These programmes involve illegal data tampering, thereby disrupting the fair competitive environment of the game. This article focuses on game data security and introduces the Multi-Modal Semantic Collaborative Attention Fusion Model (MSCAFM). The model extracts image and label features through a specific backbone network. It then employs the Multi-Modal Feature-Aligned Fusion Attention (MFAF) and Adaptive Residual Gathering Fusion (ARGF) modules to achieve feature fusion. Finally, it transforms the features through a multilayer perceptron. This allows the model to fully learn the features for securing the verification of game data. MSCAFM’s most significant contribution is its use of the MFAF attention mechanism to enhance the interaction of multimodal features and capture complex intra-modal relationships. This effectively enhances the model’s ability to express the features of multimodal data, providing better processing capabilities. Experimental results also validate the effectiveness of the proposed MSCAFM. On the Minecraft Screenshots Dataset, its area under the curve (AUC) is 0.8961 and its accuracy (ACC) is $92.73 \%$.

title: Analyzing Hidden Sources in Soil Sensors Using Independent Component Analysis (ICA) and Principal Component Analysis (PCA) Algorithm
authors: Cian Ramadhona Hassolthine, Fenina Adline Twince Tobing
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on New Media Studies (CONMEDIA)
abstract: This study aims to analyze hidden factors that influence soil sensor measurement results, including nitrogen, phosphorus, and pH levels. In this analysis, the Independent Component Analysis (ICA) Algorithm was used. This study applied the FastICA technique with the assumption that compost, irrigation, and microbes are hidden factors that influence nitrogen, phosphorus, and pH levels. The research stage used preprocessing, centering, and whitening techniques to normalize the data. The analysis results show the distribution of independent components that successfully separate the influence of these hidden factors. This study also calculated the kurtosis and negentropy values for each component, and visualized them with scatter plots and heat maps to identify correlations between ICA components and observed variables. The first plot depicting the relationship between IC1 and IC2 shows a positive pattern indicating a correlation between the two components, with a correlation coefficient of 0.824. The second plot depicting the relationship between IC2 and IC3 also shows a positive pattern, although this relationship is weaker with a correlation coefficient of 0.375. This scatter plot illustrates the distribution of data points that show a linear relationship between components, helping in identifying clearer patterns in the separated data.

title:
Giant magnetoresistance in Bi
                    <sub>88.08</sub>
                    Mn
                    <sub>11.92</sub>
authors: Andrii Terekhov, Valerii Yarovyi, Krzysztof Rogacki, Ivan Zolochevskii, Erkki Lähderanta, Andrii Solovjov
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: Magnetoresistance (MR) measurements in Bi88.08Mn11.92 showed that the MR remained positive over the whole range of magnetic fields. At 90 kOe, the maximum magnetoresistance reached about 3169 % when the magnetic field was perpendicular to the current (H ⊥ I) and about 379 % for the parallel orientation (H // I). For comparison, previous results on Bi95.69Mn3.69Fe0.62 - characterized by a lower Mn content - showed much higher MR values under identical conditions: almost 3877 % for H ⊥ I and 742 % for H // I. It is proposed that the main reason for the difference in magnetoresistive properties between Bi88.08Mn11.92 and Bi95.69Mn3.69Fe0.62 is the effect of the intrinsic magnetism of the Į-BiMn inclusions, which significantly affects the transport behavior of electrons and holes within the bismuth-based matrix.

title: Substation Transformer Failure - Case Study
authors: Brian J Cassidy, Tanis Reed, Orlando Chavez, Gary Krigbaum, Juan Cruz Massari
publish: 2025 IEEE IAS Petroleum and Chemical Industry Technical Conference (PCIC)
abstract: This paper will present a case study, the root cause analysis findings, and the lessons learned on a substation transformer that failed shortly after initial energization. The substation transformer had passed all factory tests, all site acceptance tests, all commissioning procedures and checklists, and a Through Fault Test process, yet it still failed eight hours after it was placed on potential without load. The paper will describe the methodology used to review the relay files to determine what happened during the fault, it will review the site inspection results after the fault and the repairs that were performed, it will review the factory and site acceptance testing process, the commissioning process and checklist, and it will present valuable lessons learned on how to mitigate this issue from occurring in the future.

title: Magnetic Pulse Complex for Attraction of Thin-Walled Metals with Resonant Charge of a Capacitive Energy Storage Device
authors: Svitlana Shinderuk, Yuriy Batygin
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The purpose of this work is to propose and substantiate the workability of a magnetic-pulse complex for attracting thin-walled metals, consisting of two successive circuits with a common capacitive energy storage device, the first of which is a resonant charger powered by an industrial voltage and frequency network, and the second unit is a discharge circuit with an inductor-tool for performing the assigned production task. When deriving the main analytical relationships for calculating the characteristics of the proposed resonant magnetic-pulse complex designed to attract sheet metals and operating as a resonant amplifier of the energy of an electric signal from an industrial voltage and frequency network, the mathematical apparatus of the theoretical foundations of electrical engineering and methods of integrating differential equations were used. The high efficiency of resonant formation of charge characteristics of a capacitive electric energy storage device from an industrial network of ~ 220 V at a frequency of ~ 50 Hz for ~ 0.1 s to a voltage of ~ 4595.85 V (gain is ~ 14.78 times) with a stored energy of ~ 2640 J (energy of the source ~ 8.47%, resonant energy ~ 91.53%) is shown. For a discharge circuit at a frequency of ~ 1500 Hz, it was obtained that the maximum energy in the inductor-tool is ~ 8.25 times higher than the energy consumed from an external power source. The discharge current in the inductor-tool is ~ 45270.4 A. With this current value there should be a sufficiently effective force impact on the workpiece.

title: Physics-Guided Multi-Scale Adversarial Learning for Hardware-Efficient Low-Light Image Enhancement
authors: Xinliang Yu, Zhicheng Dong, Yuantao Zhang, Weiliang Chen, Chengyu Shi, Jie Li
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: Low-light image degradation—manifested as poor contrast, amplified noise, and color distortion—remains a pressing challenge in computer vision. This study proposes a novel framework that integrates physics-guided Retinex decomposition, multi-scale feature fusion, adversarial training, and GPU-based acceleration to enhance low-light images efficiently and robustly. The method employs Gaussian pyramids for spatial feature integration and adversarial examples during training to improve generalization. Evaluations on six benchmark datasets (LOL, LIME, MEF, DICM, HDR, NEP) show that the proposed approach achieves state-of-the-art performance, with a PSNR of 23.02 and SSIM of 0.867 on LOL, and the lowest NIQE (3.320) across all comparisons. Additionally, GPU acceleration yields a 5–7% speed improvement, supporting real-time applicability. These results confirm the framework’s capability to balance visual quality, robustness, and computational efficiency, making it suitable for embedded and mobile vision systems.

title: A Resilient, Multi-Layered RAG Framework for High-Fidelity Retrieval in Complex Technical Manuals
authors: Tianjin Huang, Xingdong Zhu, Kai Liu, Peng Zhao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) systems are widely adopted to enhance Large Language Models (LLMs) with external knowledge, particularly in domains requiring up-todate and precise information. However, conventional RAG approaches often fail in safety-critical industrial domains like aviation, where documents possess rigid hierarchical structures (e.g., Technical Instruction Manuals(TIMs)). These exhibit contextual disintegration, resulting in semantic ambiguity, overspecialization, and critical hallucination risks. This paper introduces DeepPerception-RAG, a novel framework designed to address these limitations by integrating document hierarchy awareness directly into the retrieval process. The core innovation lies in a Parallel Depth-Aware Retrieval engine, where sparse (BM25) and dense (vector) retrieval pathways independently apply a sophisticated, logarithmic depth-aware scoring function to re-rank candidates. This function intelligently balances semantic relevance with hierarchical preference. The optimized results from both paths are merged, and a final, standardized LLM-based arbitration mechanism with robust fault tolerance resolves topranked conflicts. A confidence-based fallback guarantees system resilience. Rigorous evaluation on the newly constructed AeroRef150 benchmark - 150 queries across five question types demonstrates that DeepPerception-RAG achieves 91.3% Gold Path Coverage (GPC) and reduces hallucination rates by over $\mathbf{8 0 \%}$ compared to baselines. This work contributes a state-of-the-art, resilient RAG framework, a hierarchical benchmark methodology, and a novel dataset for high-fidelity retrieval in complex industrial documentation.

title: The Application of Kalman Filter in Fabric Defect Detection with Multiple Cameras on FPGA
authors: YuXuan Chen, ZhaoXiang Zong
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: To address the challenge of velocity fluctuations and sensor noise in high-speed, large-width fabric surface defect detection, this study develops an FPGA-based multi-camera image acquisition and intelligent control system with embedded Kalman filtering. Multiple industrial cameras are integrated within a cooperative hardware architecture, while the FPGA’s parallel processing capability supports real-time, multi-channel image acquisition and analysis. The core contribution lies in the hardware-level integration of the Kalman filter into synchronization control and defect tracking modules, enabling continuous estimation and prediction of fabric motion states. This predictive capability allows adaptive trigger timing and precise defect position compensation, effectively suppressing measurement noise and motion-induced misalignment. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed system improves detection accuracy from 93% (without Kalman filtering) to 97%, reduces synchronization error to the sub-millimeter level, and decreases defect localization error from 10 mm to approximately 2 mm. These results confirm that embedded Kalman filtering substantially enhances the robustness and spatial – temporal precision of fabric inspection, providing a practical and high-performance solution for intelligent quality control in textile production lines.

title: Human Activity Recognition: Innovations, Impacts, and Implications for Society
authors: Bilal Ahmed Reshi, Vijay Kumar
abstract: The rapid development of emerging technologies has elevated human activity recognition (HAR) into a field with unprecedented capabilities for monitoring and understanding human behaviors across diverse contexts. Powered by machine learning algorithms and extensive datasets from wearables, smartphones, and smart environments, HAR systems now achieve high accuracy in recognizing and predicting activities. Beyond technical progress, however, the integration of HAR into everyday life raises critical sociocultural, ethical, and privacy concerns. While HAR supports healthcare interventions, elderly care, safety monitoring, and quality-of-life improvements, it also introduces risks of data misuse, algorithmic discrimination, and pervasive surveillance. These challenges highlight the need for transparent, fair, and accountable implementation strategies. Our review highlights three main findings: 1) HAR technologies demonstrate strong potential in domains such as healthcare, safety, and smart environments; 2) ethical risks—particularly privacy, surveillance, and fairness—remain pressing concerns; and 3) responsible deployment requires updated regulatory frameworks and collaboration among researchers, policymakers, and practitioners. This article presents a holistic perspective that bridges technical innovations with societal, ethical, and policy dimensions. Unlike prior HAR surveys focused mainly on algorithms or applications, our work emphasizes the dual role of HAR, as both a technological innovation and a societal challenge, offering a multidimensional guide for future development.

title: Multimodal Driver Fatigue Recognition Using Facial Dynamics and Attention Mechanisms
authors: Taotao Sun, Nor Anis Asma Sulaiman, Thian Seng Lee
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: This paper presents a multimodal driver fatigue detection framework that integrates facial dynamics from eyes, mouth, and head pose with channel and temporal attention. From in-cabin video, we extract Eye Aspect Ratio (EAR) and PERCLOS, Mouth Aspect Ratio (MAR) and yawning events, and 3D head orientation. A temporal encoder models sequential patterns, while channel attention emphasizes informative modalities and temporal attention highlights fatigue-critical moments. The system also produces concise language explanations by coupling attention weights with event statistics. Experiments on the NTHU Drowsy Driver Dataset show that our method outperforms unimodal eye-/mouth-/head-only baselines and a naïve multimodal variant without attention, achieving 92.8% accuracy, 0.91 F1-score, and 0.94 AUC. Visualization indicates robustness under occlusion (e.g., sunglasses) by shifting focus from eye cues to mouth and head dynamics. These results suggest that attention-assisted multimodal fusion provides accurate and interpretable fatigue recognition suitable for driver monitoring systems.

title: Semi-Supervised UAV-Based Succulent Plants Classification Detection with Efficient Teacher-Student Framework
authors: Ledong Bao, Tianqiang Yue, Yue Zhang, Zhijie Zhang, Jianghan Tao, Yong Sun, Xiaoyu Zhang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: Accurate classification of succulent plants is vital for applications in intelligent horticultural management. However, traditional methods relying on manual observation or fully supervised learning are limited by high annotation costs and the scarcity of large, high-quality labeled datasets. To address these challenges, this study proposes a semi-supervised learning framework for UAV-based succulent classification. The method first involves fine-tuning a teacher model on a small, labeled dataset, which then generates pseudo-labels for a large volume of unlabeled UAV imagery. These pseudo-labels are iteratively refined to train a student model, effectively reducing dependence on manual annotation while enhancing model generalization.
