Experimental results show that as unlabeled data was incorporated, the mean Average Precision (mAP@50) increased from 83.1% to 85.5% with negligible impact on inference speed. Among evaluated architectures, YOLOv12x achieved the best overall performance. The proposed framework offers cost-effective solution for large-scale succulent classification in real-world environments.

title: An Improved PSO Algorithm Incorporating 2-opt Neighborhood Search for Solving CVRP Problems
authors: Zhiwei Liu, Yan Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: In response to the complexity of the Capacitated Vehicle Routing Problem (CVRP) and the limitations of traditional algorithms in solving it efficiently, this paper proposes an improved Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm integrated with 2-opt neighborhood search. To overcome PSO's tendency to fall into local optima and its insufficient capability for multi-objective collaborative optimization, a dual-phase hybrid optimization framework is designed: the first phase employs PSO to generate a set of feasible initial solutions that satisfy capacity constraints; the second phase introduces the 2-opt operator to perform topological reconstruction of path segments and conduct in-depth optimization. This dual optimization mechanism effectively coordinates the two major objectives of minimizing total path cost and balancing vehicle loads. Simulation experiments based on standard benchmark instances demonstrate that the proposed algorithm exhibits strong performance in both solution quality and convergence efficiency, providing an efficient and robust new method for optimizing CVRP.

title: Situational Management and Multi-Agent Self-Learning Systems for SpaceFibre Network Resources Real-Time Allocation
authors: Suvorova Elena, Polyakov Vadim
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Most modern networks for high-performance computing systems (HPC) for aerospace systems are hierarchical structures of relatively autonomous subnets. Many data flows (streams) are transmitted via multiple subnets in such systems. The characteristics of data flows vary significantly over time, so subnets should be considered as aggregates of resources that can be redistributed over time by different data flows. This article proposes a methodology for resource redistribution (load balancing) based on situational management and multi-agent self-learning systems with a reinforcement learning scheme. Network resources are organized into groups – potentially possible data transmission paths for data flows. The same resources can be included in paths belonging to different flows and used depending on the current situation in network. Resource allocation (path selection) is carried out by self-learning agents located in the edge routers of the subnet. A distributed system of agents acts to achieve a common welfare (common good) – to reduce the number of data packet losses. One of the main problems in such systems is communication: delays in the distribution of information about the state of the system and information between agents necessary for decisionmaking. The article proposes a methodology that ensures the distribution of network resources in conditions of time-varying delays in the propagation of information necessary for making management decisions; changes in the subnet associated with changes in the number of resources, the number of data transmission paths, and data flows. Estimates of achievable characteristics obtained using this methodology are given.

title: Application of Z-Stacking Technology in Non-Destructive Testing Systems for Integrated Circuit Fabrication
authors: Alexandr Golitsyn, Andey Golitsyn, Natalia Seyfi
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This conceptual article proposes a method for improving non-destructive testing systems applied in the fabrication of integrated circuits and semiconductor devices. It proposes the use of z-stacking technology when obtaining digital images of the devices at the stage just after wire bonding but before the packaging stage. The layer-by-layer scanning technology and subsequent analysis of the images using appropriate algorithms both allow determining the quality of the die to substrate assembly, the quality of wire bonding, correct welding in places, the presence or absence of wire breaks and other deficiencies like missing bonding, lift-up, the presence of contamination. In addition, it becomes possible to determine such a defect as exceeding the maximum wire loop height value. The article provides a description of what the corresponding installation should look like, what main parts it consists of, and how the image scanning is performed. The use of technology allows to reduce the number of manufacturing defects and shorten the time of setting up the integrated circuits production line.

title: Global Channel Attention-Augmented Conditional Diffusion for Low-Light Image Enhancement
authors: Xiuqi Tang, Ming Wang, Shiyu Shen, Pengfei Fan
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: Low-light image enhancement plays a critical role in facilitating vision tasks under poorly illuminated conditions while existing diffusion-based approaches often suffer from excessive sampling steps and blurred edge details. In this work, we propose Global Channel Attention-Augmented Conditional Diffusion, dubbed GCAA-Diffusion, a novel conditional diffusion framework augmented with global channel attention (SE) and spatial attention modules inserted into each ResBlock to capture both "where" and "what" to enhance. Comparative experiments on LOL benchmarks demonstrate that our model matches and some even outperforms state-of-the-art methods, and reduces inference time by 27%. These results suggest GCAA-Diffusion’s strong potential for real-time low-light enhancement in resource-constrained environments.

title: Optimization of Hospital Consultation Process Based on Intelligent Algorithm
authors: Yujiao Wang, Gao Lan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: To address high patient flow, critical-area congestion and infection risk in large hospitals, an AnyLogic 3-D model of Jilin University First Hospital couples SEIRD dynamics with LSTM arrival forecasts and Physarum-based dynamic routing that reinforces high-flow corridors and prunes low-flow ones. Simulations show the method cuts peak density in the registration and respiratory-medicine zones by $\sim 20 \%$ and infections by 15%, guiding signage upgrades and resource allocation to streamline care and curb transmission.

title: Mobile explosive object detection system for humanitarian demining needs
authors: Andrii Podorozhniak, Nataliia Liubchenko, Oleksandr Skorlupin, Serhii Korolenko, Artem Stas
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: This work details an AI-driven framework designed for explosive object identification, leveraging unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) and a fusion of deep learning techniques. The core of the system combines the YOLOv8n architecture with transformer networks. To ensure relevant and effective training, we curated a bespoke dataset mirroring the explosive hazards present in the Ukrainian context. Performance metrics revealed a strong capability: the model scored 92.3% accuracy while maintaining 18 frames per second during real-time detection assessments, even under adverse conditions. Practical field deployments validated its applicability for rapid integration into existing emergency response protocols. Comparisons highlighted its advantages, surpassing numerous existing commercial solutions in terms of cost-effectiveness, operational efficiency, and ease of customization. Plans for further enhancements encompass the incorporation of ground-penetrating radar data and improvements to offline computational speed.

title: A Targeted Password Generation Scheme Based on Deep Neural Networks
authors: Xianhan Cui, Qingbing Ji
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: Passwords remain the most widely used form of user authentication in modern information systems and online services. However, empirical studies have shown that users often rely on personally identifiable information (PII) or perform simple modifications of historical passwords, which significantly increases password predictability and exposes severe security risks. Traditional password generation models, such as Markov models and Probabilistic Context-Free Grammars (PCFG), have demonstrated effectiveness in general password guessing but fail to leverage contextual information in targeted guessing scenarios. With the rapid advancement of deep learning, new opportunities have emerged for password modeling and generation. In this paper, we propose a personalized targeted password generation scheme based on deep neural networks. Our approach incorporates a Transformer-based architecture enhanced with a pointer-copy mechanism and an edit prediction module, explicitly modeling password reuse and modification behaviors. Experimental results on multiple real-world datasets demonstrate that our scheme significantly outperforms traditional and deep learning baselines, including Markov, PCFG, TarGuess, and PassGAN, achieving higher Hit@k rates and better cross-domain generalization. This study not only provides a novel technical path for targeted password guessing but also offers valuable insights for password strength evaluation and the design of defensive strategies.

title: A Study on the Dynamic Performance Optimization of LLC Resonant Converters Based on ALADRC Control
authors: Renjie Ma, Zhaoliang Meng, Likui Xiao, Tao Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: LLC resonant converters are widely applied in new energy power generation and electric vehicle charging due to their high efficiency and low electromagnetic interference characteristics. However, their dynamic performance is susceptible to load transients and input voltage fluctuations. Traditional PID control exhibits limitations such as long regulation time and significant output voltage fluctuations under disturbance conditions. This paper proposes an Adaptive Linear Active Disturbance Rejection Control (ALADRC) strategy, which significantly enhances the system’s anti-disturbance capability by dynamically adjusting the bandwidth of the Extended State Observer (ESO) and controller parameters. This technology provides an innovative solution for high-reliability power electronic systems.

title: Dual-Mode Control Strategy for Single-Phase Boost Inverter Based on Bus Voltage Waveform Optimization Regulation
authors: Liang Han, Liangzong He
publish: IEEE Open Journal of Power Electronics
abstract: Aiming at the problems of low power density and limited efficiency of the traditional two-stage single-phase Boost inverter, a high-frequency and low-frequency dual-mode control strategy is proposed. By dynamically adjusting the bus voltage waveform (partial sinusoidal form/constant DC form), the alternating high-frequency operation of the front-stage Boost converter and the rear-stage inverter is realized. When the Boost converter operates in high-frequency to match the peak/trough of the output sinusoidal voltage, a pair of power switches in the inverter is directly turned on at low frequency, which reduces switching losses. When the inverter performs high-frequency modulation on the middle section of the output sinusoidal voltage, the power switch of the Boost converter is turned off, which reduces conduction losses, and the system efficiency is improved. and improves the system efficiency. Furthermore, based on the bus voltage waveform under dual-mode control, the minimum power loss of the single-phase Boost inverter is calculated, so as to obtain the dual-mode switching point with optimal efficiency and further enhance the efficiency. This work pioneers a time-domain power processing paradigm that intelligently allocates high-frequency switching operations. Validated by a 500W prototype, it achieves a record-high efficiency of 97.1% for its class while virtually eliminating the bulky electrolytic capacitor (96.3% volume reduction).

title: Cost-Effective Empirical Performance Modeling
authors: Marcus Ritter, Benedikt Naumann, Alexandru Calotoiu, Sebastian Rinke, Thorsten Reimann, Torsten Hoefler, Felix Wolf
publish: IEEE Transactions on Parallel and Distributed Systems
abstract: Performance models help us to understand how HPC applications scale, which is crucial for efficiently utilizing HPC resources. They describe the performance (e.g., runtime) as a function of one or more execution parameters (e.g., problem size and the degree of parallelism). Creating one manually for a given program is challenging and time-consuming. Automatically learning a model from performance data is a viable alternative, but potentially resource-intensive. Extra-P is a tool that implements this approach. The user begins by selecting values for each parameter. Each combination of values defines a possible measurement point. The choice of measurement points affects the quality and cost of the resulting models, creating a complex optimization problem. A naive approach takes measurements for all possible measurement points, the number of which grows exponentially with the number of parameters. In our earlier work, we demonstrated that a quasi-linear number of points is sufficient and that prioritizing the least expensive points is a generic strategy with a good trade-off between cost and quality. Here, we present an improved selection strategy based on Gaussian process regression (GPR) that selects points individually for each modeling task. In our synthetic evaluation, which was based on tens of thousands of artificially generated functions, the naive approach achieved 66% accuracy with two model parameters and 5% artificial noise. At only 10% of the naïve approach's cost, the generic approach already achieved 47.3% accuracy, while the GPR-based approach achieved even 77.8% accuracy. Similar improvements were observed in experiments involving different numbers of model parameters and noise levels, as well as in case studies with realistic applications.

title: UAV-enabled Massive MIMO Two-Way Full-Duplex Relay Systems with Non-Orthogonal Multiple Access
authors: Gongping Li, Qiang Li, Xingwang Li, Liping Li, Arumugam Nallanathan
abstract: In this paper, we propose an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV)-enabled massive multiple-input multiple-out (MIMO) non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA) two-way relay (TWR) system, where multiple pairs of ground users (GUs) aim to exchange their information via an amplify-and-forward (AF) UAV relay. We consider that deploy a hovering rotary-wing UAV equipped with multiple antennas and operating in full-duplex (FD) mode, to provide reliable links to the GUs with emergency communications needs during periods of temporary damage to ground base stations. Minimum mean-square error (MMSE) channel estimation is employed by the UAV to obtain the air-ground channel state information (CSI), while maximum ratio combining/maximum ratio transmission (MRC/MRT) is adopted to process the signals of GUs. Analytical general closed-form expressions are derived for the sum spectrum efficiency (SE) and total energy efficiency (EE) of the proposed system in the case of imperfect CSI, as well as their respective asymptotic expressions. Based on the obtained expressions, the power scaling laws are presented. The numerical results suggest that the proposed system can achieve higher SE performance than terrestrial massive MIMO relay system due to strong line-of-sight (LoS) links, and the advantage is more obvious with more number of antennas. Furthermore, the optimal hovering height of the UAV is explored, which increases as the number of antennas increases. Also, to achieve a trade-off between SE and EE, it is desirable to increase the transmit power of the GUs when increasing the number of antennas at the UAV. Finally, we confirm the proposed scheme can better enhance the SE of multiple GU pairs communication system by comparing NOMA with orthogonal multiple access (OMA), FD and half duplex (HD) schemes.

title: Explicit Model Predictive Direct Speed Control Method for PMSMs Based on High-Adaptability Flux-Weakening Chord Constraint
authors: Shiyu Lin, Ranran Zhang, Mengyuan Zhao, Guoqiang Han, He Cheng, Dongsheng Yu
abstract: Explicit model predictive direct speed control (EMP-DSC) for permanent magnet synchronous motors can achieve excellent control performance with high dynamics and high precision. However, the universality of existing circular-constraint linearization and the flux-weakening region’s current distribution strategy is limited, making it difficult to fully exploit the extreme operating capability of motors with different parameters. Therefore, this paper fully combines the EMP constraint linearization principle and the motor’s flux-weakening mechanism, and proposes an EMP-DSC method based on “chord constraint” that is highly adapted to flux-weakening operation. The proposed method first obtains the extreme slopes of lines connecting the intersection points of the voltage and current limit circles with the center of the voltage limit circle across the entire speed range in the dq-axis current plane. Then, a single, fixed arc on the voltage limit circle that participates in the entire flux-weakening process is determined and its corresponding chord is used as a boundary to construct the optimal voltage constraint polytope and used as the flux-weakening trajectory to determine the current distribution. The proposed universal method enables full utilization of the extreme operating capabilities of motors with different parameters under the EMP-DSC framework, and its feasibility is validated by experimental results.

title: Optimal Error Analysis of Channel Estimation for IRS-assisted MIMO Systems_supp1-3645629.pdf
authors: Zhen Qin
abstract: As intelligent reflecting surface (IRS) has emerged as a new and promising technology capable of configuring the wireless environment favorably, channel estimation for IRS-assisted multiple-input multiple-output (MIMO) systems has garnered extensive attention in recent years. Despite the development of numerous algorithms to address this challenge, a comprehensive theoretical characterization of the optimal recovery error is still lacking. This paper aims to address this gap by providing theoretical guarantees in terms of stable recovery of channel matrices for noisy measurements. We begin by establishing the equivalence between IRS-assisted MIMO systems in the uplink scenario and a compact tensor train (TT)-based tensor-on-tensor (ToT) regression. Building on this equivalence, we then investigate the restricted isometry property (RIP) for complex-valued subgaussian measurements. Our analysis reveals that successful recovery hinges on the relationship between the number of user terminals and the number of time slots during which channel matrices remain invariant. Utilizing the RIP condition, we establish a theoretical upper bound on the recovery error for solutions to the constrained least-squares optimization problem, as well as a minimax lower bound for the considered model. Our analysis demonstrates that the recovery error decreases inversely with the number of time slots, and increases proportionally with the total number of unknown entries in the channel matrices, thereby quantifying the fundamental trade-offs in channel estimation accuracy. In addition, we explore a multi-hop IRS scheme and analyze the corresponding recovery errors. Finally, we have performed numerical experiments to support our theoretical findings.

title: tACS of the Cerebellum and the Motor Cortex Entrains the Spiking Activity of the Cells in Motor Thalamus in a Frequency Dependent Manner_supp1-3644746.docx
authors: Mesut Sahin
abstract: Transcranial AC stimulation (tACS) of the cerebellum can entrain spiking activity in the Purkinje cells (PCs) of the cerebellar cortex and, through their projections, the cells in the cerebellar nuclei (CN). In this paper, we investigated if the cells in the motor thalamus (Mthal) can also be modulated (i.e. spikes entrained) via the CN-Mthal projections in rodents. A total of 82 thalamic cells were found, presumably in the Mthal by their stereotaxic coordinates, that were modulated by tACS of the cerebellum. Out of the 346 cells isolated, the thalamic cells with shorter action potentials and regular firing patterns had a higher probability of modulation by cerebellar stimulation than the cells with wider action potentials. The modulation level had a tuning curve with a maximum around 100-200 Hz. Spike histograms over the stimulation cycle transitioned between unimodal and bimodal distributions depending on the frequency. Most cells had a unimodal distribution at low frequencies, a bimodal distribution for frequencies between 80-125 Hz, and then a unimodal one for frequencies above 150 Hz. In addition, tACS of the motor cortex (MC) was also tested in a subset of thalamic cells. Unlike cerebellar stimulation, modulation levels peaked at two distinct frequencies, presumably due to entrainment through multiple MC-Mthal pathways with different preferred frequencies. The results demonstrate the feasibility of modulating a deep brain structure such as the thalamus through multi-synaptic pathways by stimulation of the cerebellar cortex (and the motor cortex) using a non-invasive neuromodulation method.

title: Electro-Thermal Analysis of NI/PI DEMO TF Coils with Fixed and Non-Linear Inter-Layer Bridges
authors: M. Ortino, N. Bykovskiy
abstract: This paper presents an extension of previous numer ical analyses on Non/Partially-Insulated (NI/PI) DEMO Toroidal Field (TF) coils by introducing fixed resistance bridges between coil layers (RL) and non-linear RMIT resistance models. Using an upgraded 3D MATLAB electro-thermal model with refined mesh discretization, the effect of RL and RMIT bridges on temperature maxima (T<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</sub>), coil maximum voltage (Vcoil), and current redis tribution is assessed. Results show that implementing RL bridges in place of RT ones yields modest reduction in Tmax (10–30%), while coupling these with RMIT provides stronger thermal flat tening (∼35% T<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</sub> reduction) and faster redistribution, at the cost of increased V<sub xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">coil</sub>. These findings confirm the potential of partial-insulation strategies in improving the thermal stability of large-scale fusion magnets, while highlighting design trade-offs requiring further mechanical and experimental validation.

title: Feasibility Study on Ultra-Thin Coating Layer for Improved Light Collection in Scintillator
authors: S. Hyeon, M.S. Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Use of bright and fast scintillator can improve the performance of radiation detectors in a wide range of applications, including medical imaging, nuclear security, and industrial inspection. However, a significant number of photons are lost at the interface between the scintillator and the photosensor due to the refractive index mismatch, which can degrade the performance of the system. Conventional coupling methods such as optical grease or air gaps are limited by long-term stability or severe reflection losses due to large refractive index mismatch. In this study, we propose and evaluate the feasibility of applying an ultra-thin coating layer on scintillator surfaces as a simple and effective alternative for improved light collection. In this study, we used finite-difference time-domain (FDTD) simulations to evaluate how the thickness and refractive index of an optical coating layer influence photon transmittance in GAGG, BGO, and LYSO scintillators. Coating thicknesses ranging from 50 nm to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> and refractive indices from 1.4 to 1.9 were tested. The resulting photon transmittance and light extraction gain from scintillator to photosensor was compared against conventional coupling configurations using a 100 nm air gap and a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$26 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> layer of optical grease. As a results, thin layer coated scintillator showed better photon transmittance over all photon incident angle compared to that of optical grease. Compared to air gap configurations, optimized layers thickness <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(50 \sim 100 ~\text{nm})$</tex> and with refractive index <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(1.7 \sim 1.8)$</tex> showed light extraction gains of up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\times 1.48, \times 1.54$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\times 1.44$</tex> for GAGG, BGO, and LYSO, respectively. Simulation results showed that at least 80 % coating transparency is needed for performance improvement. This study demonstrates the potential of thin coating layer in enhancing performances of various scintillator-based detector systems.

title: Polycrystalline Based Semiconductors (PBS) for High Energy X-Ray Detection and Imaging
authors: A. Kargar, M. Muller, M. Squillante, C. Fritz, B. C. Malkmus, L. Stracuzzi, M. Zhuravleva, C. Melcher, J. Glodo
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Polycrystalline based semiconductor (PBS) ceramics are potentially low-cost highenergy x-ray detectors. In this presentation we will discuss examples of PBS samples based on InTaO <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }_{4}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Ga}_{2} \mathrm{O}_{3}$</tex> compositions. The samples were prepared through a combination of pressureless sintering and hot-isostatic pressing. Several planar detectors were fabricated for characterization and x-ray detection and imaging applications. Current-voltage (I-V) characteristics were recorded for all samples. All fabricated detectors exhibited high resistivity (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10^{11} \Omega ~\text{cm}$</tex> and greater), and good stability under bias. The samples demonstrated excellent sensitivity to 70 kVp from an x-ray generator. This work presents a general description of detector fabrication, and characterization. High energy x-ray characterization at UTK's linac (Linatron M9A) is planned to be performed on detectors with 6 MeV and 9 MeV photons.

title: Comparing Thermal Neutron Scintillators for SiPM-Based Scattering Detectors
authors: M. Loyd, A. Moustafa, E. Hoegberg, E. Lukosi, J. Wang, V. Nagarkar, L. Pandian, A. Khaplanov, Y. Diawara
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Scintillator detectors for thermal neutrons have found a wide usage at neutron scattering facilities all over the world. These detectors utilize scintillators that contain isotopes with a high probability for thermal neutron absorption (most commonly 6Li). Currently there are three main methods of detecting the scintillation light produced by an absorbed neutron: indirect readout with wavelength shifting fibers and photosensors such as photomultiplier tubes (PMTs), direct light collection by high-resolution sensors through a 90 -degree mirror, and direct light collection via coupled photosensors. This paper will describe characterization of thermal neutron scintillators for this latter type of detector, specifically silicon photomultiplier (SiPM) based Anger cameras developed at Oak Ridge National Lab (ORNL).

title: Observation of At-211 Incorporation Into Cells Expressing the Na-Iodide Symporter Using a High-Resolution Alpha-Particle Imaging System
authors: M. Yoshino, A. Sugiyama, T. Tatsumi, S. Nomura, K. Shimazoe, S. Yamamoto, A. Taguchi, T. Tanaka, M. Kobayashi, Y. Wada, K. Kamada, A. Yoshikawa
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This study focuses on the development and utilization of a high-resolution, real-time alpha-particle imaging detector for visualizing alpha particles emitted from At-211 within cells. The key development involves using a GAGG:Ce scintillator single-crystal plate, which allows the acquisition of clear optical images of cells and alpha particles' distribution. Initially, mesenchymal stem cells, with or without transduction of the Na-Iodide symporter (NIS), were cultured and subsequently treated with NaAt to facilitate At-211 uptake. Following a 30-minute incubation period, the cells were fixed, and optical images were acquired through a GAGG:Ce scintillator. Thereafter, under conditions of complete darkness to eliminate ambient light interference, alpha particles emitted from within the cells were imaged within the identical field of view. Alphaparticle imaging was conducted through 600 one-second exposures, processed by stacking and projecting along the Z-axis. Composite images integrating optical and alpha-particle data were generated to visualize the distribution of alpha particles within cells. The study further explored the integrated density (product of the particle image area and the mean gray value), representing the light intensity emitted by the scintillator corresponding to alpha particles' energy. Histograms of integrated density revealed two peaks, suggestive of alpha particles from At-211 with energies of 5.87 MeV and 7.45 MeV. This energy information was successfully obtained from image data, providing critical insights into alpha-particle behavior. The findings highlight the effectiveness of the developed imaging detector in real-time visualization of alpha particles on an event-by-event basis. Future research aims to establish a methodology for quantifying radioactivity from the acquired images, contributing substantially to the development of At-211-based therapeutic agents.

title: Simulation Studies of a Brain PET Insert for the Total Body J-PET Tomograph
authors: M. Rädler, E. Y. Beyene, A. Bilewicz, J. Choiński, N. Chug, C. Curceanu, E. Czerwiński, M. Das, J. Hajduga, S. Jalali, T. Kaplanoglu, Ł. Kapłon, A. Khreptak, G. Korcyl, K. Kubat, D. Kumar, A. Kunimmal Venadan, E. Lisowski, F. Lisowski, J. Mędrala-Sowa, S. Moyo, W. Mryka, S. Niedźwiecki, P. Pandey, S. Parzych, A. Porcelli, B. Rachwał, E. P.D. Río, S. Sharma, M. Skurzok, A. Stolarz, T. Szumlak, S. Tiwari, P. Tanty, K. Tayefi Ardebili, K. Valsan Eliyan, R. Walczak, E. Ł. Stępień, P. Moskal
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The J-PET collaboration (Jagiellonian positron emission tomography) is working towards the realization of a large field-of-view (FOV) total body J-PET (TB-J-PET) scanner [1], [2] enabling, among others, low dose imaging, short scan times, and dynamic imaging. The key distinctive feature, i.e., the utilization of cost-effective plastic scintillators [3], [4], could facilitate a wider adoption of large FOV scanners [5]. Simultaneously, dedicated brain PET imaging has shown various exciting applications, hence in this work we study the combination of the TB-J-PET with a brain PET insert via Monte Carlo simulations. For the latter we employ the software package GATE v9.3, enabling multi-detector geometries (including in-house corrections of the Compton interactions). The main motivations are higher sensitivity and higher spatial resolution, which is analyzed through MLEM reconstructions of the Derenzo pantom. The CASToR software platform has been used to reconstruct the activity with the present unconventional geometry. For the brain insert, we investigate two detector configurations with different scintillator dimensions: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$6 \times 30 \text{mm}^{2}$</tex> vs. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 18 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex> (lateral size × depth). We find that the former enhances the sensitivity by 140 % at the brain PET center vs. only 80 % for the latter. On the contrary, the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 18 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex> configuration improves the image quality within the brain insert reconstructed with coincidences originating from both, mixed only, and brain only detectors by more than 25 %. Therefore, pairing a higher spatial resolution brain scanner (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 18 ~\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>) with the TB-J-PET leads to an overall higher sensitivity and higher spatial resolution, which we conclude to be the superior configuration.

title: Subversion-Resistant Autonomous Path Proxy Re-Encryption With Secure Deduplication for IoMT
authors: Jiasheng Chen, Zhenfu Cao, Lulu Wang, Jiachen Shen, Zehui Xiong, Xiaolei Dong
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: The Internet of Medical Things (IoMT) consists of many resource-constrained medical devices that provide patients with medical services anytime and anywhere. In such an environment, the collection and sharing of medical records raise serious security concerns. Although various cryptographic schemes have been proposed, most fail to address two critical threats simultaneously: (i) sensitive data exposure caused by external cloud servers and/or open network environments; (ii) algorithm substitution attacks (ASAs) by internal adversaries. Furthermore, when data owners (e.g., delegators) are inconvenient to process their data, it is desirable to establish a more fine-grained way to delegate encryption rights. To tackle these issues, we propose a subversion-resistant autonomous path proxy re-encryption with an equality test function (SRAP-PRET). Specifically, our scheme allows the delegator to create a multi-hop delegation path in advance with the delegator's preferences, effectively preventing unauthorized access. By deploying a cryptographic reverse firewall zone, SRAP-PRET addresses the problem of information leakage caused by adversaries initiating ASAs. Additionally, SRAP-PRET also supports secure deduplication and efficient data decryption. Security analysis shows that SRAP-PRET provides resistance against ASAs and security against chosen plaintext attacks. Performance evaluations demonstrate that SRAP-PRET offers enhanced security properties without sacrificing efficiency.

title: Evaluation of Small Lesion Detection Capability in Low-Count PET Imaging Using Diffusion Models
authors: L. Zhan, Y. Lv, M. Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Positron Emission Tomography (PET) is a functional imaging technique based on the metabolic distribution of radioactive tracers. In clinical practice, reducing tracer dose and detecting small lesions are beneficial to patients. Current PET reconstruction methods mainly include traditional filtering approaches (e.g., Gaussian filtering [GF], Block-Matching and 3D filtering [BM3D]), deep learning models (e.g., Unet), and generative methods (e.g., diffusion model [SR3]). Among these, the stochastic nature of diffusion model's reverse process may introduce lesion morphology variations, potentially causing false positives or negatives in small lesion detection. To address this, our study systematically evaluated the reconstruction performance of different methods (GF, BM3D, U-Net, SR3) at gradient count levels (100 %, 50 %, 25 %, 10 %, 5 %), quantifying SR3's advantages in lesion contrast recovery and noise suppression. By analyzing the convergence of noise prediction error after 1400 inference steps, we verified SR3's stability and determined the minimum detectable lesion sizes that can be stably identified at each dose level.

title:
High-Temperature Enhancement-Mode Ga

                    <sub>3</sub>
                    Monolithic Bidirectional Switch with >6.5 kV Breakdown Voltage
authors: Yuan Qin, Chongde Zhang, Matthew Porter, Xin Yang, Zineng Yang, Hongchang Cui, Han Wang, Jiandong Ye, Yuhao Zhang
abstract: This work demonstrates an enhancement-mode (E-mode) Ga2O3 monolithic bidirectional switch (MBDS) capable of high-temperature operation, achieving breakdown voltages (BV) exceeding 6.5 kV in both polarities at 150 °C and maintaining 4.7 kV at 200 °C. The device incorporates two highly doped NiO heterojunction gates, each connected to a lightly doped NiO junction termination extension (JTE) for electric field management. It exhibits symmetric conduction characteristics with a threshold voltage (VTH) of 1.9 V and a specific on-resistance (Ron,sp) of 1755 mΩ·cm2. Even at 200 °C, VTH remains positive while Ron,sp increases by only 1.3×. This represents the best performance reported for ultra-wide bandgap (UWBG) E-mode MBDS devices and the first demonstration of a kilovolt MBDS operational up to 200 °C. These results suggest the potential of Ga2O3 MBDS for high-temperature, high-voltage applications.

title: Extension of the NEMA NU-4 Na-22 Point-Source Sensitivity Methodology to Clinical PET Tomographs
authors: S. Siegel, Y. Bercier
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: System sensitivity is an important performance parameter for any imaging modality, and particularly so for molecular imaging modalities such as positron emission tomography (PET). To accommodate the diverse system designs of small animal PET tomographs, as well as consistent errors in the application of the then current NEMA NU-2 methodology, the small animal PET standards group elected to use a Na-22 point source rather than the specified F-18 line-source with attenuating sleeves. The NU-4 standard was released in 2008 and, since then, there has been an explosion in the variation of clinical PET tomographs. This work extends the NU-4 standard to support any tomograph geometry and makeup, by spatially windowing on the source, and demonstrates that the results are equivalent to those resulting from the NU-2 methodology by applying both methods to tomographs of 16,26 and 106 cm axial extent. The sensitivity reported by the proposed and NU-2 methods differed by less than 2.5% relative.

title: Experimental Validation of a Method to Solve Inter-Crystal Scattering in PET Arrays Based on Light Sharing
authors: M. Pizzichemi, G. Terragni, L. Arnone, L. Cassano, A. Polesel, I. Cortinovis, E. Auffray
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: High spatial resolution in PET detectors is required to improve image quality and enable early diagnosis. This is often achieved by utilizing arrays of pixellated crystals coupled to photodetectors. Typically, in over half of the coincidence events recorded by such detectors, one of the two 511 keV gamma rays deposits its energy in two scintillators. These occurrences are referred to as Inter-Crystal Scatter events (ICS). This introduces an ambiguity in the lines of response, due to the impossibility of determining which of the two crystals has been hit first, which can degrade the spatial resolution.

title: Development of a Collimator-Detector Setup for Measuring Prompt Gamma Rays and Identifying B-10 Distribution in BNCT
authors: H.-D. Liu, T.-H. Lin, H.-Y. Tsai, M.-W. Lin
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT) is a form of targeted radiotherapy that delivers <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</sup>B to tumors via an injected drug, followed by irradiation of the tumor region with an epithermal neutron beam. Through the nuclear reaction between <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</sup>B and thermal neutrons, the emitted alpha and <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">7</sup> Li particles selectively destroy tumor cells while sparing normal tissue, due to their short range and high linear energy transfer. Therefore, developing a technique of real-time monitoring of <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</sup>B distribution in tissue can greatly enhance both dose control accuracy and treatment safety in BNCT. Using a 1-inch LaBr<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> scintillator with a collimator featuring a 1.5 mm -wide slit, this study validates that the intensity distribution of 0.478-MeV prompt gamma rays (PGs) emitted from excited <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">7</sup>Li nuclei can be scanned to characterize variations in <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</sup>B concentration within a target. A thermal neutron beam with a flux of 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup>n/cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>/s was used to irradiate a polymethyl methacrylate (PMMA) phantom containing a cubic cavity filled with boric acid solution. An unfolding method was applied to separate the photopeaks of the 0.478-MeV PGs and the 0.511-MeV annihilation gamma rays. The intensity of 0.478-MeV PGs was measured at various depths when <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</sup>B concentrations set to 1000, 250, and 62.5 ppm in a series of experiments. The results confirm that the <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</sup>B-enriched region in the phantom can be identified even at a low <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</sup>B concentration of 62.5 ppm, demonstrating the potential of this collimator-detector setup for monitoring <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</sup>B distribution in BNCT.

title: Estimation of Carbon Ion-Induced SEU Rate of FPGAs on ISS-Orbit
authors: M. Tominaga, Y. Sunada, H. Iwashita, R. Kiuchi, Y. Hiroshima, N. Uchida, T. Ikeda, H. Sato, T. Kamiyama, M. Furusaka, Y. Kiyanagi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: With the increase in private companies operating in space, the evaluation of commercial off-theshelf devices for use in space is becoming important. In this study, the occurrence of Single Event Upsets (SEUs) in two Field Programmable Gate Array (FPGA) devices were evaluated at multiple energies of carbon ion. The effective SEU rates in space were estimated by convolving the obtained SEU rates with the radiation flux on the International Space Station orbit for comparison with the case of protons. The energy-integrated effective SEU rate was order of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10^{-5}[/ \mathrm{s} / \text{Mbit}]$</tex> for carbon ions, which was larger than the value for proton order of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10^{-6}[/ \mathrm{s} / \text{Mbit}]$</tex>. The effect at the energy around the Bragg peak is most noticeable for carbon.

title: Assessing Scatter Phantom Suitability and Recommending an Appropriate Length for LAFOV and Total-Body PET Based on Human Data
authors: B. A. Spencer, E. Shanina, R. Bayerlein, K. J. Chung, S. Li, X. Duan, B. Mehadji, Y. G. Abdelhafez, E. K. Leung, C. Mingels, T. Jones, S. R. Cherry, A. Chaudhari, G. Wang, J. S. Karp, L. Nardo, R. D. Badawi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: With the growing adoption of long-axial field-of-view (LAFOV) and total-body PET scanners, appropriate system characterization protocols are increasingly important. Conventional NEMA standards recommend a 70 cm scatter phantom, but this does not adequately represent human imaging conditions on LAFOV scanners. This study evaluates the suitability of the conventional NEMA scatter phantom and an extended 175 cm long phantom by comparing them to human data acquired on the uEXPLORER total-body PET scanner over the past six years of operation. Data from numerous clinical patients and research participants were analyzed, to calculate average scatter fraction, human count rates at various activities, and the predominant axial activity distribution in humans. The average human scatter fraction (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$37 \pm 3 \%$</tex>) closely matched those of both the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$70 ~\text{cm}(36.3 \%)$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$175 ~\text{cm}(37.4 \%)$</tex> phantoms. Axial activity distributions indicated that 90 % of total-body activity was contained within an average length of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$112 \pm 7 ~\text{cm}$</tex>, indicating that a phantom longer than 1 meter would better reflect clinical imaging. Count-rate comparisons between human and phantom data further supported the conclusion that an extended phantom configuration is warranted although more analysis is required. Based on the results of this preliminary study we recommend extending the scatter phantom length to at least 1 meter to allow for improved performance evaluations of LAFOV and total-body PET systems.

title: A Robust Hybrid-constrained Adaptive Algebraic Reconstruction Technique for Water Vapor tomography
authors: Xi Chen, Debao Wen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Water vapor tomography (WVT) is often ill-posed due to sparse Global Navigation Satellite System (GNSS) signals and uneven station distribution, which impedes the acquisition of accurate and unique solutions. To overcome these challenges, this study proposes a robust hybrid-constrained adaptive algebraic reconstruction technique (RHCAART), which integrates robust estimation principles to reduce the impact of observational errors and enhances solution robustness. To evaluate its performance, validation experiments were conducted using Hong Kong continuously operating reference station (CORS) observations from June 2020. The results demonstrate that the proposed RHCAART method improves tomographic accuracy over the Adaptive Algebraic Reconstruction Technique (AART), reducing bias by 23.81%, mean absolute error (MAE) by 17.39%, and root mean square error (RMSE) by 23.04%. Moreover, the reconstructed water vapor density (WVD) fields show high correlation with radiosonde profiles and align more closely with ERA5 reanalysis data in spatial comparisons than conventional techniques. These results validate the reliability and superior performance of the RHCAART, highlighting its potential for high-accuracy WVD reconstruction in complex terrains under challenging conditions.

title: Optical Characterization of Low-Gain Avalanche Diodes
authors: T. Tsang, M. Boukhicha, G. Giacomini
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We characterized a type of Low-Gain Avalanche Diode (LGAD) fabricated at the Brookhaven National Laboratory. LGADs are a type of silicon avalanche photodiodes originally developed for the fast detection of minimum ionizing particles for high-energy particle detectors. We study its detection capability on different types of ionization particles, such as X-rays, gamma-rays, alphas, and examine its intrinsic quantum efficiency with non-ionization optical photons. The thin substrate with a moderate internal gain <100 is sufficient to compensate for the reduced charge deposition and overcome the noise of a read-out system. Here, using near infrared photon pulses, we demonstrated LGAD can accurately measure a nearly 1-MIP equivalent minimum ionizing particles with picosecond timing resolution. The capabilities of this new type of LGAD allow us to probe the underlying physics of the multiplication process and to provide fast timing for particle detection in a variety of applications.

title: Development of Particle Detector Using 3D Printing Scintillator
authors: K. Ueno, S. Takami, T. Yoshioka, M. Shoji, C. Yamada
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Plastic scintillators are widely used in the fields of particle physics, nuclear physics, and cosmic ray research due to their excellent performance and ease of handling. Recent advances in 3D printing technology offer a new approach for developing plastic scintillators with reduced costs and customizable geometries. In this study, we have developed a compact detector using a UVcurable resin-based 3D-printing scintillator, evaluated its performance, and explored its potential for future particle detection applications.

title: FastPET With AI Estimated Scatter Correction
authors: D. Bharkhada, M. Millardet, V. Panin
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: FastPET algorithm implicitly estimates scatter which can lead to some quantification inaccuracy as compared to gold standard MLEM reconstruction. In this article we propose a FASPET algorithm with scatter correction to improve quantitative accuracy. A low resolution scatter in 10 view histo-image form is first estimated using a CNN network. This estimated scatter is used as an input to FastPET network in addition to the trues histo-image. This method is applied to a patient data to assess the quantitative accuracy. We found that the average activity in images generated using FastPET is within 6% of gold standard MLEM reconstruction.

title: Feasibility Study of a Prototype Muon Radiography System Based on a Three-Layer Muon Tracker
authors: S. Lee, Y.S. Chung, J. Kang, J. Ra, Y.H. Chung
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: A non-destructive testing (NDT) technique utilizing cosmic ray muons, known as muon radiography, has been employed to inspect internal density and structural integrity of large and dense objects for infrastructure safety assessment. In this study, the feasibility of a prototype muon radiography system, comprising a three-layer muon tracker, was experimentally verified. The three-layers were sequentially rotated by 45 degrees around the shared central axis, with a fixed distance of 30 cm between each layer. Each 1D detector layer was fabricated using a 50 × 50 × 1 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> sized plastic scintillator (BC-408), Enhanced Specular Reflector (ESR) films, 64 wavelength shifting (WLS) fibers (0.3 × 50 × 0.3 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>, BCF-91A), and 64 silicon photomultipliers (SiPMs, 0.3 × 0.3 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> MICROFJ-30020-TSV-A1), with each SiPM optically coupled to a corresponding WLS fiber. The pitch between adjacent WLS fibers is 0.69 cm. Signal processing was performed using the TOFPET data acquisition system (DAQ, PETsys Electronics). The system's performance was evaluated by reconstructing a 2D image of 20 × 5 × 10 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> blocks made of wood, aluminum and lead. These results demonstrate the feasibility of the proposed muon radiography system for monitoring and inspecting the structural integrity of architectural constructions.

title:
Multi-Isotope Whole Gamma Imaging:
                    <sup>89</sup>
                    Zr-Anti-Cd38-Antibody and
                    <sup>18</sup>
                    F-NaF Imaging of Multiple Myeloma Mouse
authors: G. Akamatsu, M. Takahashi, H. Tashima, Y. Iwao, E. Yoshida, H.G. Kang, S. Takyu, F. Nishikido, F. Obata, H. Wakizaka, A. Sugyo, H. Sudo, A. Tsuji, S. Ito, K.J. Kim, K. Kamada, A. Yoshikawa, M. Ishibashi, Y. Imai, T. Yamaya
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Whole gamma imaging (WGI) is a novel imaging concept combining PET and Compton imaging by using a dual-ring geometry. The 4<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> WGI prototype (WGI-4), which was developed for highsensitivity mouse imaging for <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">89</sup>Zr, was introduced in IEEE MIC 2023. <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">89</sup>Zr emits a 909 keV γ-ray after the positron decay with a time lag. With the improved performance of Compton imaging, WGI may allow for the separate visualization of positron emitters and single γ-ray emitters in a simultaneous measurement. This study demonstrates <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">69</sup>Zr/<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">18</sup>F multi-isotope imaging by using the WGI-4 prototype. The WGI-4 prototype is composed of HR-GAGG-based scatterer rings (79 mm diameter) and fast-LGSO-based absorber rings (304 mm diameter). A <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">89</sup>Zr-filled rod phantom (rod diameters: 1.0-4.8 mm) was measured to compare the spatial resolution between PET and Compton images. The 2.2 - and 3.0-mm rods were resolved in PET and Compton images, respectively. Then, we conducted <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">89</sup>Zr-anti-CD38-antibody and <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">18</sup>F-NaF multi-isotope imaging for a multiple myeloma model mouse. The combined distribution of <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">89</sup>Zr and <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">18</sup>F was visualized by PET, whereas Compton imaging visualized only the distribution of <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">89</sup>Zr. In addition, the <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">18</sup>F distribution could be extracted by subtracting the Compton image (<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">89</sup>Zr) from the PET image (<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">89</sup>Zr and <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">18</sup>F). We successfully demonstrated <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">89</sup>Zr/<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">18</sup>F multi-isotope imaging using the WGI-4 prototype. Our WGI can evaluate different molecular information with other PET tracers even after a <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">89</sup>Zr tracer is injected.
