title: On-Line Measurement of Mechanical Properties of Cold Rolling Strips Based on Multiple Magnetic Parameters
authors: Siyu Tong, Gongzhuang Peng, Dong Xu, Weiming Shen
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: The real-time and accurate assessment of product performance is crucial to ensure production stability and product quality in steel production. In this study, an electromagnetic non-destructive testing (ENDT) system for the mechanical properties (yield strength, tensile strength, elongation) of cold-rolled strip is developed, which incorporates four types of electromagnetic detection techniques, including Magnetic Barkhausen Noise, Tangential Magnetic Field, Magnetic Incremental Permeability, and Multi-frequency Eddy Current. A network-based model is proposed which consists of a Self-Adaptive Convolutional Channel Attention Mechanism (SACAM) module and an Extended Channel Depthwise Separable Convolution (EDSC) module to predict the mechanical properties of strips based on the extracted magnetic features. SACAM-EDSC takes advantages of channel attention mechanism in feature enhancement and depth-separable convolution in model lightness. An actual steel coil dataset collected from the ENDT system was used to evaluate the performance of the proposed approach, which consisted of 41 input dimensions and 1521 sample numbers. Three machine learning algorithms, namely Decision Tree Regression (DT), Support Vector Regression (SVR), and Neural Network (NN) and three deep learning algorithms, namely ShuffleNet, GhostNet, EDSC were implemented to conduct comparative studies on the same dataset. The experimental results show that the proposed method performs well in terms of accuracy and efficiency compared with the other approaches.

title: Design and Development of a Gamma Radiation Scanning System for Localization and Mapping of Distributed Sources
authors: R. Setso, C. O. Kureba, D. Jenkins
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The localization and mapping of radiation-contaminated hotspots have potential applications in nuclear decommissioning, environmental monitoring, and homeland security. However, localizing distributed sources is often challenging due to a blurring effect caused by the radiation spread. This exaggerates the edges of the radiation source. A scanning system and techniques are proposed in this study that will allow more accurate source localization and mapping. The scanning system features a commercial robotic arm, the Eva automata, fitted with a compact Bismuth Germanate (BGO) detector to scan across the area of interest in a raster pattern. To test the detection and mapping capabilities of the system, a radiation-contaminated environment was simulated using potassium-40, a naturally occurring radioisotope, as the radiation source. Potassium-40 emits 1460 keV gamma rays about 11% of the time during its decay. Directional detection of these gamma rays will give insight into the radiation intensity across the test area. From this, 2D radiation maps were generated by overlaying the positional data from the robot with the radiation data from the gamma radiation sensor. Furthermore, some image processing techniques, such as the Richardson-Lucy deconvolution algorithm and bi-cubic interpolation, were applied to the radiation maps to create sharp and smoother-looking maps with an accuracy of about 5 cm. The technical details of the proposed scanning system are presented.

title: Lightweight neural network with load condition regression for hybrid leakage fault diagnosis of hydraulic cylinder
authors: Haiqing Yao, Shaowen Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Instrumentation and Measurement
abstract: With the continuous expansion of automation and unmanned demand in industry, hydraulic cylinders, as one of the most important industrial actuators, urgently need the fault diagnosis solutions that can balance the key performance of execution efficiency, detection accuracy, and adaptability to working conditions. However, the existing hydraulic cylinder fault diagnosis methods have limitations in two main aspects: (1) tend to use signal processing methods, and have deficiencies in hybrid fault detection capability; (2) unable to adapt to changing working conditions, and thus have poor engineering adaptability. This work focuses on the hybrid leakage (including both internal and external leakage) fault diagnosis of hydraulic cylinder, and proposes a lightweight neural network with load condition regression. Firstly, simulation calculations under changing working conditions are used to analyze the pressure fluctuation characteristics of hydraulic cylinders under hybrid leakage. The results show that the leakage amounts caused by the same leakage conditions under different load conditions are different, the pressure fluctuation characteristics in the time-frequency domain also change accordingly, and the impact of internal leakage and external leakage on pressure characteristics is different. Then, the pressure fluctuation characteristics in the time-frequency domain are used to construct fault features for hybrid leakage of hydraulic cylinders. Specifically, the wavelet packet decomposition is used to extract the multidimensional time-frequency domain features, a neural network-based load regression is trained, and then an attention mechanism is involved to optimize the multidimensional time-frequency domain features by the load regression results. Next, a multi task neural network classifier identifying the leakage type and degree is trained. Finally, the experimental results verify the accuracy and robustness of this novel lightweight network in processing test bench data compared with several recently popular classification methods.

title: IodinePrint: Patient-Specific, IodineEnhanced Phantoms for Spectral CT Imaging
authors: F. S. Englbrecht, A. V. Popov, K. Mei, O.F. Sandvold, M. Geagan, P. B. Noël
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Iodinated contrast agents enhance anatomical detail and improve diagnostic accuracy in CT imaging. With advancements in spectral CT, the ability to accurately quantify iodine has further elevated its role as a potential imaging biomarker. However, CT system validations still rely on simplistic, non-anthropomorphic phantoms, and there are currently no anatomically realistic, iodine-enhanced phantoms available. To address this gap, we expand upon our previously developed PixelPrint 3D-printing method by introducing a novel iodine-infused Polylactic Acid (PLA) filament (IodinePrint). This filament enables the fabrication of anatomically accurate phantoms with clinically relevant iodine enhancement. Iodine-rich compounds were embedded into PLA pellets using a dual-solvent technique. Following solvent evaporation, modified pellets were extruded into 1.75 mm filament. As an initial test, we printed four calibration cubes with varying infill ratios (30-90%) and compared them to commercially available iodine inserts. A cylindrical calibration phantom was fabricated using a dual-extruder 3D printer, featuring pie-slice segments with iodine concentrations ranging from 0.7 to 10.4mg/mL. Based on this calibration, a section of a pancreatic CT scan was printed using IodinePrint filament to generate a lifelike, iodine-enhanced phantom. Spectral CT imaging demonstrated a similar spectral match between the printed cubes and commercial inserts and a linear correlation between Hounsfield units and iodine concentration in the calibration phantom. The pancreatic phantom exhibited contrast levels within physiologically expected ranges and presented realistic textures and anatomical detail in conventional and iodine images. The introduced 3D-printing technology will aid in standardizing contrast-enhanced imaging protocols and optimizing spectral CT parameters for improved diagnostic accuracy.

title: Cell-Type Specific Responses to Low-Activity Copper-64: Implications for Safe and Effective Theranostic Approach
authors: M. A.G. Mikhail, N. Hayashi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Copper-64 is recognized as a promising theranostic radionuclide due to its dual functionality: it enables positron emission tomography (PET) through positron (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\beta^{+}$</tex>) emission, while also offering therapeutic potential owing to its emission of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\beta^{-}$</tex> particles and Auger electrons. This study investigates the therapeutic impact of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{64} \text{Cu}$</tex> administered at low activity levels within the kilobecquerel range, with a focus on the effects of gradually increasing doses on cancer cells, thereby expanding its utility in targeted radiopharmaceutical therapy under conditions of minimal radiation exposure. In vitro studies were conducted to assess the biological effects of low-dose <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{64} \text{Cu}$</tex> radiation at activity levels of 27,54, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$94 \text{kBq} / 100 \mu ~\mathrm{L}$</tex> on normal (HaCaT) and cancerous (HSC-3, Hep-G2, MCF-7) cell lines. HaCaT cells showed increased proliferation with rising <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{64} \text{Cu}$</tex> activity, indicating a proliferative influence of copper. In contrast, HSC-3 and HepG2 cancer cells initially proliferated, but their growth declined with increasing <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{64} \text{Cu}$</tex> activity, suggesting a radiation-mediated inhibitory effect. Notably, MCF-7 cells showed marked cytotoxicity at 94 kBq, indicating a strong dose-dependent effect. These results support the dose- and cell-type-specific cytotoxic potential of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{64} \text{Cu}$</tex> in cancer treatment. Further research is required to determine the cytotoxic activity threshold of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{64} \text{Cu}$</tex> in HSC-3 and HepG2 cancer cell lines. In addition to the in vitro experiments, a radiolabeling study was performed using DOTA as a chelating agent to assess its complexation efficiency with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{64} \text{Cu}$</tex>. The results confirmed successful radiolabeling and demonstrated increased encapsulation efficiency when the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{64} \text{Cu}$</tex>-DOTA complex was incorporated into nanocapsules. These findings substantiate the use of nanocarriers for the targeted delivery of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{64} \text{Cu}$</tex> in radiopharmaceutical therapy.

title: Joint Synthesis and Uncertainty Quantification for Deep Learning-Based PET Reconstructions Using Single-Pass Variance Propagation
authors: S. Z. Liu, M. Zhang, D. Bharkhada, M. Millardet, Y. Zheng, V. Panin, M. Conti
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Deep learning (DL)-based image synthesis has been widely explored for PET reconstruction, offering the ability to convert low-quality inputs into high-quality images with high computational efficiency. However, clinical adoption remains limited due to the lack of fast and reliable methods to quantify prediction uncertainty - an essential metric for safety and interpretability. In this study, we propose an uncertainty-aware extension of FastPET, a DL model that synthesizes MLEM-like PET images from multi-angle time-of-flight histo-images. Our approach introduces a novel inference framework based on Variance Propagation (VP) for joint estimation of (i) image reconstruction, (ii) aleatoric uncertainty (data variance) and (iii) epistemic uncertainty (model confidence). Unlike conventional uncertainty estimation methods that typically require multiple stages or stochastic passes and are computationally expensive, VP analytically propagates mean and variance through the network in a single forward pass, enabling efficient estimation with minimal overhead. We evaluated the proposed method on a clinical pilot study of 5 whole-body 18F-FDG PET/CT scans. Compared to the standard Monte Carlo dropout-based FastPET, our VPbased model achieved equivalent reconstruction accuracy and uncertainty estimates, with <0.02% SUVmax error and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<5.3 \%$</tex> deviation in both uncertainties. Inference time was reduced by up to 95 %, showing a significant gain in computational efficiency. These results suggest that VP enables fast, uncertainty-aware PET reconstruction. It potentially provides a practical pathway toward clinically reliable deployment of DL, and facilitates more informed decision-making in clinical workflows.

title: Simulation of Deep Level Effects on Gaas Detector Under Clinical Flux
authors: B. Wang, H. Li, T. Zhong, Y. Yang, X. Lai
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Gallium arsenide (GaAs) has broad application prospects as a material for photon counting detector (PCD). In this study, using physical modeling and the TCAD simulation tool, we analyzed the role of deep energy levels in GaAs. The results indicate that both the intrinsic defect level EL2 and the Cr-induced deep level in GaAs significantly affect the detector properties. The EL2 level strongly traps holes, thus increasing resistivity. The Cr-related level captures excess electrons, which further enhances resistivity and, by neutralizing charge accumulation induced by high-flux radiation, effectively mitigates polarization effects.

title: FlexiBlock: Experimental Development of a Modular Gamma Camera for High-Resolution and Flexible Imaging
authors: L. Liu, Z. Lyu, Y. Zhang, Y. Pan, Z. Sun, Y. Liu, T. Ma
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We present FlexiBlock, a modular gamma camera system designed to address limitations in existing imaging technologies in terms of spatial resolution, energy range, and field-of-view flexibility. Each FlexiBlock unit integrates self-collimating GAGG(Ce) scintillator arrays and tungsten needle absorbers into a compact cubic module, enabling reconfigurable imaging configurations. An experimental prototype comprising four blocks was constructed and evaluated in two operational modes. In the wide field-of-view (WF) mode, the system achieved omnidirectional imaging with angular resolutions of 4° for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{137} \text{Cs}$</tex> and 6° for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{60} \text{Co}$</tex>, successfully resolving multiple point sources across full azimuthal coverage. In the high-resolution (HR) mode, it resolved dual sources separated by 1° (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{137} \text{Cs}$</tex>) and 1.5° (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{60} \text{Co}$</tex>), and successfully visualized extended line-source distributions. These results demonstrate FlexiBlock's ability to adaptively switch between panoramic and high-precision imaging. A complete 16 -block system is currently under construction, and comprehensive imaging performance results will be presented at the conference.

title: Novel Methodology for MOSFET Parameter Extraction From Weak to Strong Inversion Range in Ohmic Operation at Very Cryogenic Temperatures
authors: Bogdan Cretu, Abderrahim Tahiat, Anabela Veloso, Eddy Simoen
abstract: In this article, a new methodology is proposed for MOSFET parameter extraction and modeling of transfer behavior from weak to strong inversion range in ohmic operation at cryogenic temperatures. The propounded methodology is based on an empirical mobility law which considers that the Coulomb scattering mechanism prevails in weak inversion, while it is the surface roughness mechanism in strong inversion at temperatures lower than 30K. It permits to extraction of the inversion charge from weak to strong inversion range through <inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$I$</tex-math> </inline-formula>–<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$V$</tex-math> </inline-formula> measurements. It appears that the estimated inversion charge behavior may concur with the one analytically constructed using the Lambert-W function approach. The new methodology can be employed when the conventional mobility law, through a negative first-order intrinsic mobility attenuation factor, fails to model the Coulomb scattering mechanism in weak inversion at very cryogenic temperatures.

title: In-Situ Activity Measurements of Microliter Droplets Using Cerenkov Radiation
authors: D. L. Prout, R. Carmichael, W. Deng, A. L. Doblado, R. Taschereau, T. Weerakkody, E. Dodson, M. Van Dam, A. Chatziioannou
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Development and validation of new imaging and therapeutic radiopharmaceuticals takes years of research due to the complexity, cost and limited throughput of conventional radiochemistry. To address this limitation, we devised a high-throughput radiochemistry system for rapid development of radiotracers for imaging and radiotherapeutics for cancer therapy. The core of the system is a silicon wafer that contains a 4×4 array of 3mm diameter microdroplet reaction sites allowing simultaneous droplet-based radiosynthesis. A critical requirement for these systems is that the activity of the droplets must be repeatedly measured to monitor the efficacy of each radiosynthesis step. Previously, we presented at this conference a method to rapidly measure radioactivity for positron imaging isotopes. Quantification of radioactivity in droplets is complicated by variations in overall positron energy deposition depending on the stage of synthesis, including the volume of the droplet. We showed that we could determine the activity in the droplets but required measuring both the intrinsic but weak Cerenkov light produced by positrons inside droplets and measuring the stronger scintillation light generated above the reaction sites from positrons that exit the droplets and interact in a scintillator. In this work, we demonstrate a simpler method to determine the droplet activity using only Cerenkov light by introducing a custom made “converter” layer covering the droplets that allows collection of Cerenkov light from the positrons that is less dependent of the droplet volume and geometry. Here we seek to determine the sensitivity and efficacy of this method to measure the activity in the droplets via Monte Carlo simulations of positrons emanating from arrays of droplets. We also present preliminary data from a 3D printed plastic converter place over radioactive droplets.

title: A Novel Neutron and Gamma Imaging System Based on a Dual-Layer Detector
authors: Y. Yu, Y. Liu, X. Liu, Z. Qiao, N. Jiang, Q. Wei, Y. Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: As the demand for the detection of special nuclear materials increases, the use of imaging instruments that can sensitively image both gamma-ray and neutron signatures has become necessary. The radioactive waste streams can contain neutron-emitting radioactive materials, hence localisation of neutron sources plays an important part in nuclear decommissioning. Neutron detector design based on the MURA revealed promising results when tested in security applications. To improve the detection efficiency while enhancing angular resolution, we propose a novel neutron detector based on a dual-layer design. In this paper, the Monte Carlo simulation is carried out by using GATE. The simulation data obtained is processed and the maximum likelihood expectation maximization method is used for reconstruction. The results of point sources in different positions are compared. The dual-layer design has a better imaging performance and less artifact. The system can accurately locate the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{241} \text{Am}$</tex>-Be <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\left(3.7 \times 10^{5} \mathrm{n} / \mathrm{s}\right)$</tex> neutron source in the range of 2 meters far FOV in 300s. The angular resolution at the center is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{3}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$</tex> and other coded field of view is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$</tex>.

title: Positron Lifetime Imaging Using a Gamma Ray Beam: The First Experiment
authors: S. Takyu, Y. Taira, T. Hirade, F. Nishikido, H. G. Kang, H. Tashima, F. Obata, K. Matsumoto, M. Takahashi, T. Yamaya
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Since positron lifetime varies with the surrounding electron density, it may be applicable, for example, to oxygen partial pressure sensing for hypoxia imaging. Therefore, we are aiming to realize quantum PET (Q-PET), in which diagnosis is based on positron lifetime rather than positron distribution. However, in living organisms, there are few basic data that correlate positron lifetime values with diagnostic information. In order to establish such a database, in this work, we proposed a positron lifetime imaging method that enables 3D analysis of tissue samples. The key technology is a MeV-order gamma ray beam available at the Ultraviolet Synchrotron Orbital Radiation Facility (UVSOR) in the National Institutes of Natural Sciences (NINS). Specifically, inside a sample irradiated with the beam, positrons are produced by pair production. With a pair of PET detectors mounted in the beam line, the positron lifetime is imaged in three dimensions, by considering the beam generation time as the start signal and the detection time of annihilation photon pairs as the stop signal. As the first experiment, we used one pair of detectors consisting of a 3.2 mm square <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 8 \text{LGSO}$</tex> scintillator array coupled to a 3.2 mm pitch <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8 \times 8 \text{MPPC}$</tex> array module. This detector pair was placed opposite each other at a distance of 10 cm, inclined at 15 degrees to the direction of the beam. A stainless steel plate (known lifetime value: 106 ps) and a polycarbonate plate (known lifetime value: 2.1 ns) were placed separately to check the difference in positron lifetime spectra during beam irradiation. We also placed two samples within the field of view of the detector pair and performed simple 2D PET imaging. Details of the experimental results will be reported in the conference presentation.

title: Back-Illuminated Single-Photon Avalanche Diode Optimized for Scintillation Detectors
authors: S. Yook, H.-S. Choi, J.D. Song, W.-Y. Choi, M.-J. Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Single-photon avalanche diodes (SPADs) are semiconductor photodetectors for next-generation scintillation detectors, which are highly beneficial for many biomedical applications such as fluorescence lifetime imaging microscopy (FLIM), X-ray imaging, and time-of-flight positron emission tomography (ToF-PET). Those applications generally require SPADs with high fill factors and strong sensitivities in the blue-green wavelength range, matching the emission spectrum of commonly used scintillators. While front-illuminated (FI) SPADs are advantageous for detecting blue-green wavelengths due to their shallow junction depth, they suffer from optical losses caused by stacked dielectric layers and low fill factors due to the peripheral region for the guard ring and anode/cathode. These can be addressed using back-illuminated (BI) SPADs, but those devices typically have deeper junctions and smaller pixel pitches, limiting blue-green sensitivity and suitability for biomedical applications. This study presents the optimized BI SPAD with aggressive backside thinning, active-area enlargement, and backside patterning. These structural optimizations reduce the epitaxial thickness, increase photon interaction volume, and enhance internal light scattering, leading to significantly improved photon detection probability (PDP) in the blue-green wavelength range. Experimental results exhibit a PDP increase rate of over 98.21 % at 3 V excess bias voltage with a low dark count rate of less than <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \text{cps} / \mu_{\mathrm{m}^{2}}$</tex>. This work demonstrates a viable BI SPAD for scintillation detectors, especially for biomedical imaging systems requiring large pixel pitches and high blue-green sensitivity.

title: Preclinical Imaging Scanner Based on Photon Counting Scintillator Detectors
authors: R. G. Oliveira, P. M.C.C. Encarnação, A. L.M. Silva, P. M.M. Correia, J. F.C.A. Veloso
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This study presents a novel photon-counting scintillator detector-based CT system for multimodal imaging integrated into the easyPET.3D platform. The system uses a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{241} \text{Am}$</tex> radioactive source, combined with the same LYSO:Ce scintillator-based detectors used for PET imaging, and the dualrotation acquisition method of easyPET.3D to achieve tomographic imaging. Comparative analysis of simulated experimental data showed strong agreement, confirming the system's capability to detect submillimeter objects and distinguish materials of varying densities. The overall consistency supports the validity of the proposed CT approach. The work will focus on 3D reconstruction algorithms for volumetric imaging with initial simulations and subsequent experimental validation using phantoms and in vivo studies.

title: Performance Evaluation of a Dual Headed Molecular Breast Imaging System
authors: K. Erlandsson, A. Cherlin, M. Exley, N. Atkins, I. Baistow, B. F. Hutton, K. Thielemans
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: A prototype dual-headed Molecular Breast Imaging (MBI) system has been developed at Kromek and UCL. Each head consists of an array of CZT detectors with sub-pixel resolution and depth-ofinteraction (DOI) capability equipped with multi-pinhole collimators, which allow multiplexing (MX). The system is stationary and provides limited-angle tomographic information. We have evaluated the performance of the prototype with phantom measurements in terms of lesion detection and dose reduction factor (DRF). We scanned a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{99 ~\mathrm{m}}$</tex> Tc-filled phantom containing 5-9 mm diameter spherical inserts and a uniform background phantom separately. We generated data sets with different count statistics for target-to-background ratios (TBRs) of 10 and 20 using bootstrapping. Images were reconstructed with OSEM, including DOI-based de-MX. We estimated the lesion detection capability using contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR) and the scan statistic (SS) method. The analyses were done w and w/o noise reduction using the non-local means (NLM) filter. The filter had a significant effect on the CNR values but not on the SS results. The CNR results suggest that, with a DRF of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$8,7-\text{mm}$</tex> lesions were detectable with TBR=10 w or w/o NLM filter while, for TBR <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=20,6-\text{mm}$</tex> lesions were detectable w/o and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5-\text{mm}$</tex> lesions w NLM filter. The SS evaluation resulted in AUC values of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.86,0.75$</tex> and 0.55 for DRFs of 1,2 and 4 with TBR <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=10$</tex>, while with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{TBR}=20$</tex>, all AUC values were in the range 0.97 to 0.73. Although the SS results may seem less encouraging than the CNR ones, many of the false positive lesions were close to the edges, so we would expect better performance with the full-size system or with a smaller phantom. In conclusion, our results show that a reduction in dose or scan time of up to a factor of 8 may be possible with our novel MBI system.

title: Development of a SiPM Readout ASIC for Photon Counting and Energy Integration Xray Imaging
authors: C. Liu, Z. Deng, X. Ran, H. Luo
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: A high-count-rate readout Application Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) named SHPIX-SIPM has been developed for SiPM detectors for photon-counting X-ray imaging applications. It integrates four channels and each channel consists of a single-end to differential amplifier, a successiveapproximation register analog-to-digital converter (SAR ADC), a digital trapezoidal filter, a multichannel analyzer for photon-counting and an energy integration module. The digital trapezoidal filter can convert a bi-exponential signal into a trapezoidal signal with much shortened pulse width. Pile-up signals can be further identified and decomposed except for those arrives at the rise time of the trapezoidal. The energy spectra and output count rates (OCRs) at different input count rates (ICRs) are simulated. The maximum OCR of 11 Mcps was reached at 30 Mcps ICR for LYSO crystals. The energy integration information was simply estimated by simply summation of the signal waveforms. Hence the dynamic range can be extended even if the OCR saturates. The chip was designed in TSMC 65 nm process and the power consumption is less 5 mW per channel. It has been submitted in April and will be received in August. Detailed circuit design and test results will be present in the paper.

title: Towards Simultaneous TOF and DOI Capabilities in BGOPET Systems using ASICs
authors: A. Gonzalez-Montoro, F. Loignon-Houle, N. Cucarella, F. Pagano, R. Latella, D. Guberman, A. Mariscal-Castilla, D. Mazzanti, S. Gómez, D. Gascón, A. J. Gonzalez
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Positron Emission Tomography (PET) is a powerful imaging technique with key applications in multiple medical areas. With the objective of providing better diagnosis and extending the use of PET to pediatrics, some research efforts have focused on improving the system sensitivity since this will allow for a reduction of the radiotracer dose and/or shorter acquisition times without impacting image performance. With this goal, we have proposed implementing a large axial coverage PET system including time-of-flight (TOF) capabilities. BGO-based detectors are suggested for the system because of their high detection efficiency. To achieve the required TOF performance, we will exploit the low Cherenkov yield produced in the BGO which requires implementing specific electronics to discriminate events based on their dynamics.

title: CPRE64: a Low-Noise 64-Channel Front-End Readout ASIC for 3-D Position-Sensitive CdZnTe Detectors
authors: H. Liao, K. Wang, N. Wang, J. Cai, Y. Liu, W. Wei, C. Wei, L. Wei, X. Li
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper presents a low-noise front-end readout application-specific integrated circuit (ASIC) optimized for three-dimensional position-sensitive Cadmium-Zinc-Telluride (CZT) detectors. The chip is capable of reading both cathode and anode signals, allowing it to accommodate both pixelated and virtual Frisch-grid CZT detectors. Each channel integrates a low-noise chargesensitive amplifier (CSA), a pole-zero cancellation (PZC) circuit, a high-order shaper, a peak detect-and-hold (PDH) circuit for energy measurement, and a sample-and-hold circuit for timing measurement, with power consumption below 5 mW per channel. The ASIC is designed using a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.35 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> CMOS process, resulting in a die area of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.10 ~\text{mm} \times 12.44 ~\text{mm}$</tex>. The chip layout features pins on three sides, permitting an expansion to 128 channels with minimal area loss. Simulations indicate that the equivalent noise charge (ENC) is <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$69 \mathrm{e}^{2}+6.5 \mathrm{e}^{2} / \text{pF}$</tex> (RMS).

title: Trustworthy Data-Driven Prefault Frequency Security Assessment for Power Systems Using Disturbance-Informed Learning
authors: Yutian Lan, Yurun Zhang, Wei Yao, Shanyang Wei, Tianjun Chen, Hang Shuai, Jinyu Wen
abstract: Frequency security assessment (FSA) is critical for the safe operation of modern power systems, particularly under increasing uncertainty and renewable integration. In online prefault scenarios, a large set of anticipated disturbances, such as generator tripping, load shedding, and HVdc blocking, must be evaluated rapidly and accurately. However, existing data-driven methods struggle to capture disturbance mechanisms and neglect the spatial influence of disturbance locations, resulting in reduced generalization and reliability. To address these limitations, this article proposes a trustworthy disturbance-informed learning (DIL) framework that incorporates location-sensitive disturbance features into data-driven FSA. By integrating steady-state power flow with power disturbance data into graph-structured representations, DIL leverages graph convolutional networks (GCN) to extract topology-aware features. To reflect disturbance location differences, DIL modifies the dropout process in GCN training by replacing random sampling with location-based sampling. This helps the model focus on critical nodes, improving accuracy and robustness. In addition, disturbance location information enhances trustworthiness by comparing model attention with actual disturbance positions. Case studies on the IEEE 39-bus system and a provincial power grid in China (3748 buses) demonstrate that DIL outperforms existing models in accuracy and robustness, while enabling more trustworthy predictions.

title: Optimizing Scintillator Thickness and GEB Parameters for Beta Spectroscopy in Plastic Scintillation Detectors
authors: D. Kim, W. Kim, J. Park, S. Lee, G. Song, H. Yun, S. Jang, U. Lee, H. Kim, J. Park, G. Cho
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Plastic scintillation detectors are widely used in beta ray monitoring systems, but accurate beta spectroscopy remains a challenge due to complex detector response and spectrum distortion. In this study, we propose an optimization framework for beta spectroscopy by selecting the appropriate scintillator thickness and refining the energy response function using a genetic algorithm. Monte Carlo simulations were performed using MCNP to evaluate beta spectra for five radionuclides (<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">14</sup>C, <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">147</sup>Pm, <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">99</sup> Tc, <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">36</sup>Cl, and <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">90</sup>Sr/<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">90</sup>Y) across varying scintillator thicknesses. A 0.7 cm thickness was identified as optimal for preserving full spectral information while minimizing gamma interference. To align simulated spectra with measured spectra, Gaussian Energy Broadening (GEB) was applied, and its parameters were optimized using a genetic algorithm. The optimized parameters significantly improved the match between simulation and experiment, achieving a total mean squared error of 9.59E-07. These results demonstrate the feasibility of using simulation driven methods for accurate beta spectroscopy and detector calibration. The proposed method provides a foundation for applying beta spectral analysis to real-time leakage detection in nuclear environments.

title:
Development of a Portable LaBr
                    <sub>3</sub>
                    Ce Detector System for Real-Time Wide Area Survey
authors: T. Takahashi, M. Koizumi, T. Mochimaru, Y. Yoshimi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: To enhance nuclear security at major public events, we have developed a portable radiation survey system capable of wide-area gamma-ray monitoring with real-time visualization. The system integrates a LaBr<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>Ce scintillation detector with a photomultiplier tube (PMT), offering high energy resolution suitable for radionuclide identification. To support field deployment, a compact high-voltage power supply (HVPS) and a USB-powered multi-channel analyzer (MCA) were implemented, enabling battery operation and periodic data acquisition synchronized with GPS coordinates. Custom software was developed to periodically log pulse-height histograms without interrupting signal processing, ensuring reliable time-correlated data. Measurement results are transmitted via a network module to a central monitoring station, where radiation levels and spectra are displayed on an interactive map using real-time mapping software. Field tests confirmed the system's ability to identify elevated radiation areas and extract corresponding gamma-ray spectra. This system supports efficient radiation mapping and rapid response in nuclear security operations.

title: Contactless Dielectric Liquids Sensing Using a Microwave Inverse Split-Ring Resonator
authors: Sergey Polevoy, Aleksey Girich, Sergiy Nedukh, Kateryna Sova, Sergiy Tarapov, Arthur Vakula
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The aim of this work is to present the features of a compact, non-contact dielectric liquid characterization sensor based on a planar microwave resonator. Both experimental and numerical studies demonstrate that an Inverse Split-Ring Resonator (ISRR), operating at about 6 GHz, can effectively characterize dielectric liquids inside of a plastic container. The sensitivity of the proposed sensor is compared with that of existing microwave non-contact liquid sensors, and its advantages are discussed.

title: Towards an AI-Assisted Speculative Narrative Design Workflow
