title: Integration of Drone Systems in the Construction Industry: Applications
authors: Merdan Törehan Turan
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The construction industry is one of the largest sectors in the global economy, characterized by complex, costly, and timeconsuming processes. In recent years, the integration of drone (Unmanned Aerial Vehicle UAV) systems into construction projects has created new opportunities for efficiency, safety, and precision. This study examines the applications of drone technologies in construction management, focusing on site monitoring, progress tracking, structural defect detection, and completion time estimation. A comprehensive review of the literature was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness of drones compared to conventional monitoring methods. Field studies and case analyses reveal that drones can reduce project monitoring time by up to 30%, minimize human errors, and enhance occupational safety by reducing the need for workers to access high risk areas. Additionally, drones equipped with photogrammetry and LiDAR sensors provide accurate 3D models for structural assessment and Building Information Modeling (BIM) integration. However, challenges remain in terms of data security, regulatory compliance, and operator training. This paper concludes that drone technologies, when systematically integrated into construction practices, offer significant advantages in time, cost, and safety, and proposes strategies for broader implementation in the industry.

title: Lung Nodule-SSM: Self-Supervised Lung Nodule Detection and Classification in Thoracic CT Images
authors: Muniba Noreen, Furqan Shaukat, Syed Muhammad Anwar
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Lung cancer remains among the deadliest types of cancer in recent decades, and early lung nodule detection is crucial for improving patient outcomes. The limited availability of annotated medical imaging data remains a bottleneck in developing accurate computer-aided diagnosis (CAD) systems. Self-supervised learning can help leverage large amounts of unlabeled data to build more robust CAD systems. With the recent advent of transformer-based architecture and their ability to generalize to unseen tasks, there has been an effort within the healthcare community to adapt them to various medical downstream tasks. Thus, we propose a novel "Lung Nodule-SSM" method, which utilizes self-supervised learning with DINOv2 as the backbone to enhance lung nodule detection and classification without the need for annotated data. Our methodology consists of two stages: first, the DINOv2 model is pretrained on unlabeled CT scans to learn robust feature representations; second, these features are fine-tuned using transformer-based architectures for lesion-level detection and accurate lung nodule diagnosis. The proposed method has been evaluated on the challenging LUNA 16 dataset, consisting of 888 CT scans, and compared with SOTA methods. Our experimental results demonstrate the superiority of our proposed method, achieving an accuracy of 98.37%, which explains its effectiveness in lung nodule detection. The source code, datasets, and preprocessed data can be accessed using the link: https://github.com/EMeRALDsNRPU/Lung-Nodule-SSM-Self-Supervised-Lung-Nodule-Detection-and-Classification

title: Risk Assessment Model Based on Multidimensional Sentiment Knowledge Graph
authors: Xiaorui Hu, Li Hao Chen, Anxue Yin, Mohan Li, Yanbin Sun
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Social networks accelerate the spread of information and public opinion in social networks. The public opinion risk assessment of complex public opinion events involving multidimensional elements such as users, topics, and space faces challenges. Many studies have used the knowledge graph to efficiently organize multi-source heterogeneous data and their associated characteristics to model social public opinion. This paper proposes a graph convolutional network model (TGatedGCN) for multi-dimensional public opinion knowledge graphs, which integrates text, attributes, and structure features, and encodes and fuses time features, uniformly represents heterogeneous node features, and efficiently aggregates multirelation information to capture the dynamic evolution of public opinion risks. Experiments show that the performance of this model for fine-grained public opinion risk assessment is high, the risk assessment effect of the model is significant with less data information, and it has strong robustness and generalization ability.

title: Research on Speech Emotion Recognition Based on Multi-Feature Fusion
authors: Xu Zhang, Lidong Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Speech emotion recognition, as an important research area, aims to automatically identify and classify the emotional state of the speaker from the speech signals. It is often difficult for a single feature to fully reflect the emotional information in speech, and multiple different features are complementary to each other, therefore, combining multiple features is often the key to improve the accuracy of speech emotion recognition. Based on this problem, this paper proposes a speech emotion recognition model SXANet based on multifeature fusion, which fuses three different features as inputs, and learns discourse-level features and frame-level features of the speech information through parallel spatial channel attentional convolution module and extended long and short-term memory network module, respectively. In addition, important channel and spatial features are also focused in the spatial channel attention convolution module due to the presence of spatial and channel attention mechanisms, thus providing richer features. In addition, the output of the parallel module is balanced by the weighted attention fusion mechanism, which improves the overall efficiency and effectiveness of the model. Extensive experiments are conducted on RAVDESS and EMODB datasets, and the experimental results show that the proposed method has an accuracy of $91.97 \%$ and $98.15 \%$ on the two datasets, respectively, which proves the effectiveness and superiority of SXANet.

title: Synthesis, Structural Characteristics, and Phase Transformations of Iron-Based Nanoparticles Obtained by Electric Spark Treatment and Their Application in Steel Modification
authors: Konstantin Lopatko, Oksana Zazymko, Volodymyr Nazarenko, Yevhenii Aftandiliants
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: This study investigates the synthesis, structural characteristics, and transformative properties of iron-based nanoparticles obtained via electric spark treatment of iron granules in water and organic liquids. Advanced analytical methods, including scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and differential scanning calorimetry (dsc), were utilized to evaluate nanoparticle size, shape, phase composition, and crystal lattice parameters. Results revealed nanoparticles predominantly in α-Fe, γ-Fe, FeO, and Fe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf> phases, demonstrating significant structural heterogeneity and increased lattice distortion due to high dislocation densities (2×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">14</sup>–6×10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">14</sup> cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−2</sup>). Thermodynamic analyses illustrated distinct phase transformation behaviors compared to bulk iron, characterized by reduced transformation temperatures and narrower intervals. Practical application as microstructural modifiers was explored by incorporating these nanoparticles into 45L steel, significantly refining ferrite and pearlite grain structures and enhancing structural homogeneity. This research underscores the electric spark method’s efficacy in tailoring iron-based nanoparticles' structural and energetic properties, highlighting their potential for advanced metallurgical applications and materials engineering innovations.

title: A Novel DFT-Based Two-Stage Precoding Algorithm for GFB-OFDM PAPR Reduction
authors: Haodong Li, Dongdong Wang, Rui Xue, Shiming Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Generalized Filter Bank Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (GFB-OFDM) employs a two-stage IFFT combined with subband filtering to directly modulate complex symbols, offering both flexible waveform configuration and terminal compatibility, thereby exhibiting broad application prospects in satellite-terrestrial integrated communications. However, the dual-layer superposition effect of GFB-OFDM inevitably results in a high peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR). In order to solve the above issue, a novel DFT-based two-stage precoding algorithm is proposed, integrating the inherent processing mechanism of GFB-OFDM. Unlike conventional DFT precoding, the proposed algorithm first introduces subband-level DFT precoding before the first-stage IFFT, followed by intersubband DFT precoding prior to the second-stage IFFT. This two-level spreading of input symbols effectively mitigates PAPR. Both theoretical analysis and simulation results demonstrate that, compared with conventional GFB-OFDM and OFDM systems, the proposed scheme not only achieves significant PAPR reduction but also maintains implementation simplicity with low complexity.

title: Improved Lightweight Cloud-Based Multiclass Cyber Intrusion Detection: Optimising FastViT with Boruta-SHAP and Class Balancing on CSE-CIC-IDS2018
authors: Nour Eldin Alaa Badr, Xing Liang, Jean-Christophe Nebel
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: Cloud environments have recently become increasingly exposed to the growing complexity and volume of network traffic, thereby elevating the demand for robust, scalable, and intelligent intrusion detection systems (IDS). This study introduces an effective deep learning-based IDS that integrates advanced feature selection with a lightweight, high-performing deep learning model, FastViT, to address critical limitations observed in prior work, particularly in handling multiclass classification and severe class imbalance. Many previous studies evaluate model performance on a limited subset of attack types or treat each attack in isolation, often neglecting dataset balancing techniques. This leads to poor generalisation and reduced effectiveness in detecting complex and infrequent attacks under realistic conditions. To address these limitations, this study proposes a FastViT-based approach, a hybrid convolutional-transformer architecture, trained and evaluated on the CSE-CIC-IDS2018 dataset, which includes all attack categories. A hybrid feature selection strategy combining Boruta and SHAP is employed to enhance interpretability and improve learning efficiency by identifying the most relevant features. Dataset balancing is achieved through a combination of the Synthetic Minority Over-sampling Technique (SMOTE) and undersampling, ensuring fair representation of minority classes. Comparative experiments on both balanced and imbalanced datasets demonstrate significant improvements, particularly in recall, for underrepresented and challenging attack types such as Web and Infiltration.

title: A Comparative Evaluation of Automatic Transcription Systems: Indonesian and American Accented English Using Wav2Vec2ForCTC and Turboscribe
authors: Celina Salsa Sadilla, Jeanette Hauw Chandra, Alexander Agung Santoso Gunawan, Rilo Chandra Pradana
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: In this era, Automatic Speech Recognition (ASR) systems have a very important role in various types of applications such as media transcription and online learning. High transcription accuracy in various languages and accents is crucial to support the development of inclusive technology. However, there is still not much research comparing the performance of ASR models in different languages and accents, especially for Indonesian and English with American accents. This study aims to compare the transcription accuracy of two ASR models, Wav2Vec2 for CTC and Whisper Turboscribe, by measuring the Word Error Rate (WER) on Indonesian and American English audio datasets. This study employs a quantitative experimental approach, with datasets collected from open sources and manually annotated. The results show that for American-accented English, Turboscribe achieved a lower WER of 0.15% compared to Wav2Vec2 with 0.64%, while for Indonesian, Wav2Vec2 outperformed Turboscribe with a WER of 3.58% versus 8.98%. Error analysis further indicates that English errors mainly involve names, places, and plural "-s" endings, whereas Indonesian errors are dominated by misrecognition of place names and verbs. These findings highlight the need for culturally and linguistically tailored ASR models, especially for under-resourced languages like Indonesian, and underscore the importance of dataset diversity and linguistic adaptation in improving transcription performance across languages.

title: Protection Challenges of Connecting A Third-Party Solar Farm to a Refinery Power System
authors: Duane Lescher, Vladan Bijeljanin, Alan Bishop
publish: 2025 IEEE IAS Petroleum and Chemical Industry Technical Conference (PCIC)
abstract: A number of challenges have been encountered in interconnecting a third-party solar farm to an existing refinery power distribution system over a pole line. There were limitations of the solar farm inverter fault sourcing ability, as well as operational challenges in maintaining appropriate system power factor. There were additional constraints imposed by the cyber-security requirements of interconnecting protection communications systems between multiple parties. The power transmission authority imposed additional constraints. And there were constraints due to the existing refinery infrastructure, both regarding inter-operability with existing switchgear relays and limitations of existing switchgear. These challenges and the implemented solutions will be discussed, along with possible alternate solutions to some of these challenges. We anticipate some of these challenges will be encountered by others in the pursuit of alternative power supply sources.

title: Improvement Of Melanoma Classification using MobileNet with Augmentation and AdamW Optimization
authors: Zulfikar Amri Ardiansyah, Guruh Fajar Shidik, M. Arief Soeleman
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Skin cancer is a type of cancer that affects the skin, with some cases being benign and others malignant. The number of skin cancer cases continues to rise, and with technological advancements particularly in the field of computer vision its application in the medical domain has become increasingly widespread. Several researchers have explored various methods, including the use of the CNN model MobileNetV2. Building on previous research, we aim to improve this method by employing the CNN architecture MobileNetV3, along with the integration of data augmentation techniques and the AdamW optimizer. This study utilizes three different melanoma datasets, namely from the ISIC Archive, DermIS (Dermatology Information System), and MED-NODE, comprising both benign and malignant cases. Compared to previous studies, which reported a maximum accuracy of 75%, our research demonstrates a significant improvement in accuracy, reaching up to 97,5%. It can be concluded that the CNN architecture model MobileNetV3, combined with augmentation and AdamW optimization, has a substantial impact, resulting in a 22,5% accuracy increase on the MED-NODE dataset

title: Study of the Problem of Forecasting Ice Loads on Overhead Power Transmission Line
authors: Veronika Cherkashyna, Halyna Omelianenko, Anton Shmatov
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: This study aims to address the issue of predicting the ice load on overhead power lines using neural network modeling. This issue was implemented on the basis of a forecasting model with a 12-8-1 architecture using the method of sliding time windows in the STATISTICA environment. The average relative error of the air temperature forecast was 12.9 %, which confirms the reliability of the forecast model and the feasibility of using neural network modeling to solve forecasting problems in the energy sector. The presented scientific research can be successfully used by operators of the power distribution system to adjust the operation of power grids in accordance with the meteorological situation along the overhead line route.

title: NeoPCB-YOLO: Next-generation Enhanced Optimization YOLO for PCB
authors: Anxu Wei
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Printed Circuit Board (PCB) defect detection plays a crucial role in quality control within the electronics manufacturing industry, yet traditional approaches often suffer from insufficient accuracy and limited generalization. To address these issues, this paper proposes a next-generation improved YOLO model, termed NeoPCB-YOLO, with contributions spanning algorithm design, dataset construction, and system application. First, we introduce the FDConv (Frequency Domain Convolution) module into the model architecture, which dynamically generates convolution kernels in the frequency domain and integrates channel, filter, spatial, and kernel attentions to achieve multi-scale adaptive feature modulation, thereby enhancing the representation capability for complex defect patterns. Second, we construct a high-quality PCB defect dataset covering multiple typical defect categories, including missing holes, mouse bites, open circuits, shorts, spurs, and spurious copper, providing a reliable foundation for model training and evaluation. Finally, we develop a visualized user interface based on PyQt5 to intuitively present detection results and support human-computer interaction, facilitating deployment in industrial scenarios and quality traceability. Experimental results demonstrate that NeoPCB-YOLO achieves an mAP50 of over $95.6 \%$, significantly outperforming the baseline model and validating its effectiveness and robustness in real-world applications. This study provides an efficient and deployable solution for automated defect detection in smart manufacturing and the PCB industry.

title: Hybrid Architecture of Deep Learning InceptionResNetV2 and Bidirectional LSTM for High Accuracy Plant Disease Detection
authors: Ananta Agil Nusantara, Guruh Fajar Shidik
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: This study presents a hybrid deep learning architecture designed to overcome challenges in plant disease detection. Our proposed architecture integrates the strengths of InceptionResNetV2, utilized as a spatial feature extractor, with a BiLSTM for performing contextual analysis. After fine-tuning an InceptionResNetV2 model that had previously been trained on ImageNet, we used transfer learning, to effectively extract rich visual details from leaf images. Subsequently, these extracted features were processed sequentially by the BiLSTM, enabling the model to understand the contextual relationships among them and thereby enhancing its capacity to differentiate between various disease types. Extensive testing on the Plant Village dataset, utilizing 5-fold cross-validation and comprehensive ablation studies, validated the model's superior performance. Consequently, we report an impressive average accuracy of 99.07%. Analysis further confirmed that the integration of the BiLSTM component and the fine-tuning process were crucial factors contributing to this high level of accuracy.

title: The Role of Gachacom in Fostering Appreciation for Human-Created Art amid AI Advancements
authors: Christine Then, Alexander Waworuntu, Marlinda Vasty Overbeek, Wirawan Istiono, Fenina Adline Twince Tobing, Angga Aditya Permana
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on New Media Studies (CONMEDIA)
abstract: The AI generator uses work created by humans without permission to produce an output. Therefore, AI art is not widely accepted by creative workers. Corporates are starting to switch to AI technology because they can save production costs and want to get work done in less time. This poses a threat to an illustrator's career in the creative field. As proof, BuzzFeed shares have risen by 200% since announcing that they would use AI to create content. Buzzfeed also laid off 12% of its company workforce. Public acceptance of AI generators, despite the questionable ethics of generative AI outputs, shows a lack of appreciation and interest in illustrators. Therefore, to increase people’s interest in illustrators, the Gachacom website was designed and built using the gamification method and the Octalysis framework. Based on the results of website testing conducted using HMSAM, the percentage was 93.75, indicating a high level of user acceptance of the Gachacom website because it helps attract public interest in supporting illustrators' work.

title: Beyond Accuracy: Evaluating Fairness in Deep Learning Models for Chest X-ray Classification
authors: Letícia Lopes Mendes Da Silva, Diedre Santos Do Carmo, Letícia Rittner
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Deep learning (DL) models have achieved remarkable results in chest X-ray classification. However, concerns remain regarding their fairness across demographic subgroups and variations in image acquisition. Evaluations that overlook these attributes may favor models that perform well overall but exhibit biased behavior, potentially harming underrepresented subgroups. In this study, we conduct a systematic fairness evaluation of DL models trained to detect 14 clinical findings in chest radiographs. Using three public datasets and EfficientNet-Based architectures, we assess both model performance and equity across sex and age groups, as well as different radiographic views, using specialized fairness metrics. To support this analysis, we developed an evaluation framework for multi-label fairness auditing, enabling direct comparison across different models, classes, and attributes. Our results reveal notable biases even in top-performing classifiers, particularly related to patient age and positioning during image acquisition, with class-dependent bias patterns. This demonstrates that performance metrics alone do not fully characterize model behavior or the risks associated with deployment in real-world scenarios. These findings highlight the need to incorporate fairness considerations when developing and selecting models for clinical use.

title: Deep Learning-Based Modelling of the Adsorption Mechanism and Dynamic Optimization of Lanthanum Adsorption Reactions
authors: Yi Zhang, Xiangni Pan, Xinglei Li, Juguang Ren, Xiangbiao Yin
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning, Pattern Recognition and Automation Engineering (MLPRAE)
abstract: Lanthanum, a rare earth element, is a critical resource in the fields of new materials and high technology. This study proposes a deep learning-based modelling method for the adsorption mechanism of lanthanum, designing a hybrid architecture combining graph convolutional networks and recurrent neural networks to achieve precise prediction of the adsorption process. A dynamic optimization algorithm based on deep reinforcement learning effectively improves lanthanum recovery rates while reducing energy consumption. Experimental validation demonstrates that the optimized process maintains high stability under feed fluctuations, and the developed MS-EDTA material exhibits excellent adsorption performance and selectivity, providing a new approach for efficient rare earth resource recovery.

title: Quality Assessment of Stereoscopic Panoramic Videos via Salient Viewport Extraction
authors: Wenyu Yang, Chunyi Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Existing stereoscopic panoramic video quality assessment methods often overlook the fact that viewers focus only on partial viewports and salient regions within them. To address this, we propose a full-reference quality assessment method based on salient viewport extraction. First, a Binocular Perception Model (BPM) is constructed to simulate the binocular fusion and rivalry mechanisms of the human visual system, generating a combined binocular perception map. This map is integrated with a recursive probability sampling strategy to generate pseudo-viewports sequence with viewing habits. Then, a lightweight mini-DenseNet predicts the saliency map of each viewport, and BPM masking information is fused to weight the error maps, emphasizing distortions in salient and binocular conflict regions. Finally, a regression model produces the overall video quality score. Experimental results show that the proposed method achieves higher consistency with subjective scores and better generalization than existing methods.

title: LLM-Powered Automated Detection and Optimization of Inference Bottlenecks in Distributed Systems: A Static Analysis Approach
authors: Xiaoying Li
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: This paper presents a novel approach to automating the detection and optimization of inference bottlenecks in distributed deep learning systems through the application of Large Language Models (LLMs). While traditional performance optimization in distributed environments requires extensive manual analysis across multiple components, this paper propose a static analysis framework that leverages LLMs' code comprehension capabilities to identify performance-critical patterns without execution.This system processes distributed model architectures and implementation code to generate an abstract syntax tree representation, which is then analyzed by a fine-tuned LLM trained on a curated dataset of 5,000+ annotated performance bottlenecks from production distributed environments. Experimental evaluation across 78 diverse distributed neural network deployments demonstrates that the approach identifies 93.7% of inference bottlenecks that would otherwise require dynamic profiling, while suggesting optimizations that yield an average 2.8x inference speedup on resource-constrained devices. A comparative analysis reveals this static analysis method reduces optimization time by 76% compared to conventional profiling-based approaches in distributed settings. Additionally, the system generates natural language explanations of detected issues and recommends contextually appropriate optimization strategies for distributed inference pipelines, facilitating knowledge transfer to practitioners. This research addresses critical challenges in deep learning deployment across distributed environments and enables more efficient utilization of computational resources in production systems.

title: CdTe Sensor Polarization in X-Ray Beam and the Effect of Side Illumination on the Electric Field Profile
authors: P. Praus, M. Betusiak, E. Belas, R. Grill, S. Kacenga, J. Jakubek, K. Sykorova
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We study the long-term stability of the electric field profile in CdTe sensor chips when exposed to X-ray beam to improve the parameters of ionizing/non-ionizing radiation imaging systems. Gradual polarization of the sensor is warping the electric field profile after applying a bias. The X-ray beam further worsens such deformation. It leads to instabilities and degrades both imaging performance and spectroscopic resolution. We measured the influence of the electric field profile in the biased CdTe sensor under X-ray beam exposition using various intensities and its stabilization by belowbandgap side illumination. We use Laser-Induced Transient Current Technique to characterize the electric field profile of the sensor. Synchronized pulsed bias is used to monitor the time evolution of sensor polarization. That enabled time evolution measurements of the polarization in a wide range from 10 s to 2000 s. The setup's detector and excitation parts were placed in a closed shielded box with an X-ray beam source and a shutter. The gradual evolution of the current waveforms shape is used to evaluate the electric field warping in all irradiation regimes.

title: Innovative Digital Practicum Simulator for Enhanced Technical Skills
authors: Siti Juliana Abu Bakar, Mohd Syafiq Abdul Rahman, Saiful Nizam Warris, Dyah Lestari, Harits Ar Rosyid, Samsul Setumin
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: The COVID-19 pandemic sped up the shift to online learning and highlighted the need for teaching tools that keep students engaged in remote settings. Digital Electronics courses usually depend on hands-on sessions, which makes it hard to recreate those learning experiences online. A common issue for students was their difficulty in assembling electronic circuits, a skill that is usually developed through physical lab work with instructional kits. To address this gap, we developed a mobile-based digital practicum simulator that aims to improve students’ motor skills and hands-on learning. The simulator is available on smartphones and allows for interactive circuit assembly that mimics real-world lab conditions. The prototype includes decoder and encoder content modules, creating a solid framework for ongoing development. Early feedback from users shows significant improvements in students’ technical skills and engagement. These results support the simulator’s ability to enhance remote engineering education, especially when access to traditional labs is limited. Furthermore, the system effectively incorporates encoder and decoder features, laying a strong foundation for further progress.

title: Target trajectory segmentation and compression based on improved ant colony algorithm
authors: Wentai Yang, Yang Cao, Jianfei Zhao, Zhihong Ouyang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: In the face of the storage, transmission and processing pressure brought about by the surge in the number of air targets and the explosive growth of trajectory data, trajectory segmentation and compression technology has become the key to improving the efficiency of situational analysis. Aiming at the problem of inaccurate feature point selection in the existing line segment simplification methods, a segmented compression method of air target trajectories based on the improved ant colony algorithm is proposed. Based on the solution framework of the 0-1 backpack problem, the method innovatively introduces the dynamic update mechanism of trajectory point value and pheromone global optimization strategy: firstly, the trajectory point weight is initialized based on the value evaluation function, and the value of non-feature points is dynamically adjusted through the iteration process to strengthen the screening ability of key feature points. Secondly, the pheromone update mechanism is improved to avoid local optimization by equilibrium path selection probability. Experiments show that when the compression ratio is 21.57%, increasing the number of ants and the number of iterations can significantly improve the segmentation accuracy. Compared with the traditional algorithm, the segmentation accuracy of the proposed method is better than that of TRACLUS and TCSS algorithms under the same compression ratio, and is significantly improved compared with the DP algorithm in the low compression scenario. The research results provide an efficient solution for the real-time processing of massive trajectory data, which has both engineering practicability and algorithm superiority.

title: Comparative Performance of YOLOv10, YOLOv11, and YOLOv12 Models for Helmet Violation Detection in Motorcycle Riders
authors: Miftahur Rizki, Gamma Kosala
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Helmet violations among motorcycle riders remain a major safety concern in Indonesia. While existing systems like Electronic Traffic Law Enforcement (ETLE) help address the issue, they are often constrained by limited coverage and human-related inefficiencies. This study explores the use of object detection models to automate helmet violation detection from CCTV footage, focusing on three recent YOLO variants: YOLOv10, YOLOv11, and YOLOv12. The models were trained and evaluated using a total of 1,185 annotated CCTV images to ensure robust performance across diverse visual scenarios. Each model introduces architectural innovations aimed at improving detection accuracy and inference efficiency. Experimental results show that YOLOv10 achieved the fastest inference time (23.3 ms) with a mAP@50 of 0.942, making it suitable for low-latency environments. YOLOv12 offered slightly higher accuracy with a mAP@50 of 0.943, but at the cost of a longer inference time (41.4 ms). YOLOv11 demonstrated the best overall trade-off, attaining the highest accuracy with a mAP@50 of 0.952 and a reasonable inference time of 30 ms. These findings suggest that YOLOv11 offers the most practical balance between detection quality and computational efficiency, making it a strong candidate for real-world helmet violation detection systems.

title: Development of Operational Module Scale Options and Assessment of their Expert Weighting Coefficients
authors: Yevgen Sokol, Kostyantyn Kolisnyk, Pavlo Shchapov, Volodymyr Nehoduiko, Tatyana Bernadskaya, Serhii Tertyshnyi
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The use of information technologies and methods of mathematical statistics is currently a very promising direction for improving decision-making methods in medical practice. In particular, these narratives have shown quite capable results in the formation of analytical information in the diagnosis and treatment of patients with gunshot and mine-explosive injuries. Recently, the authors have conducted a number of field studies and collected statistical information, which allowed them to obtain mathematical dependences of treatment results on biomedical indicators, on the basis of which mathematical models of the rehabilitation processes of patients with gunshot wounds were obtained. For further formation of the methodology for choosing the most informative prediction of the course of surgical operations, scales of operational modules and an assessment of their expert weight coefficients are necessary, which were obtained by the authors as a result of this work.

title: Gallium-Arsenide Operational Amplifier for High Temperature Applications without Current Mirrors
authors: Marsel A. Sergeenko, Dmitriy V. Kleimenkin, Nikolay N. Prokopenko
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Current mirrors introduce significant errors into the static and dynamic parameters (the systematic component of the zero offset voltage, attenuation factors of common-mode input signals, power supply rejection, slew rate in the mode of a large pulsed input signal, unity gain frequency, etc.) in classical operational amplifiers with direct coupling of cascades. A gallium-arsenide operational amplifier that does not contain current mirrors, as well as resistors that establish the static mode of gallium-arsenide field-effect and gallium-arsenide bipolar transistors is studied in the article. A promising gallium arsenide technological process, mastered by the Minsk Research Institute of Radio Materials, ensures the creation of only p-n-p BJT and nJFet transistors. The absence of n-p-n transistors creates problems in the construction of high-temperature gallium-arsenide operational amplifiers, which are in demand in a number of important branches of science and technology - space instrumentation, oil and gas, automobile and aviation industries. It is shown that the proposed circuit solutions minimize the systematic component of the zero offset voltage and can be recommended for practical use in analog interfaces designed to operate at elevated temperatures.

title: Adversarial Defense for Face Recognition via Identity-Embedded Features
authors: Chenkai Xiao, Qingyan Duan, Xiaowei Guo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Face recognition systems based on deep neural networks remain susceptible to adversarial samples. Input reconstruction is a widely adopted defense due to its independence from the target model. However, most of these methods focus on removing the adversarial perturbation rather than preserving identity-related features, which limits their effectiveness in defense. To address this problem, we propose Identity-Embedded Features Defense (IEFD), a novel framework that transforms the adversarial facial images to clean samples by leveraging identity-embedded features extracted. During the feature extraction stage, the Highlight Identity-Relevant Regions Module (HIRM) works in collaboration with the encoder through an enhanced attention mechanism, enabling more targeted extraction of identity-relevant features. Besides, to further preserve identity information in the feature representation, the Adaptive Channel-Reduction Convolution (ACC) is introduced in the image reconstruction stage, which enriches more identity information into the extracted features by combining adaptive channel-reduction convolution operations with identity loss. Through the collaborative optimization of these two modules, the resulting identity-embedded feature serves as the foundation for facial image reconstruction to improve the recognition accuracy of target models. Experimental results on the LFW dataset demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms existing approaches under several adversarial attacks, effectively preserving identity semantics while mitigating adversarial noise.

title: Exploring Indonesian Mothers' Digital Learning Experiences: A Preliminary Research on Technology Use in Self-Directed Learning
authors: Ridha Hidayani, Annisa Dinata, Bunga Claudya
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: Self-Directed Learning is a key competency that provides the necessary foundation for individuals to adapt to changes in social contexts. This study employed a quantitative research design using a structured survey method involving 100 married women. Data was collected using Pop Survey, a self-service online survey platform developed by Populix. The technique of data analysis engaged in this study is descriptive statistical analysis in order to illustrate the survey data which is in the form of frequency distribution or percentage. Based on the result of the research, the most frequently used device by mothers for self-directed learning is smartphones. The results also showed that mothers are at the level of "very often" for the use of technology in self-directed learning. The presence of technology itself is in the level of "highly motivated" for mothers to develop their skills. The study found that technology for education gives positive impacts to strengthen SDL practices and enable women with multiple social roles pursuing their personal and professional growth. Based on these insights, the further research can consider the development of learning programs aimed at enhancing married women self-development.

title: Some Features of the Implementation of the Cognitive Radio Algorithm on the Board of the SDR Device Module
authors: Alexander Stenin
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This paper deals with a topic within the field of wireless telecommunications-cognitive radio systems. These systems provide best-effort service, enabling unlicensed users to access part of the radio spectrum. Many users, regardless of the technology or radio spectrum frequencies used, face limited resources such as radio spectrum or computing time. Technologies such as cognitive radio provide a specific approach using “spectrum white spots” for secondary (unlicensed) users. The cognitive radio method allows secondary users to avoid interference, capture free channel timeslots, and transmit and receive data. Many algorithms have been proposed for best-effort service, including machine learning algorithms (a subset of artificial intelligence). As a result of our investigations, we propose the same system with a software-defined radio device prototype to analyze experimental data. This paper examines the results of the most effective machine learning with a reinforcement algorithm received from the software-defined radio board. In addition, we consider the peculiarities of implementing cognitive radio on an experimental board and analyze the probability of spectrum occupancy in different design models.

title: Cebesla Application: Solution-Focused Counseling Platform Based on Pancasila Values for Students' Cultural Intelligence
authors: M. Ramli, Nur Mega Aris Saputra, Nur Hidayah, Nur Eva, Nail Hidaya Afandi, Alivia Eka Arianti
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: This research was conducted to develop a counseling model that can answer racial issues high school students face when using social media through increasing cultural intelligence. The development was carried out through the ADDIE development design. Based on the results of the needs analysis, it was concluded that the model was developed using website media in the form of short videos. The model is implemented through four main stages, namely: (1) Phase I Filling in the description of the initial condition of students; (2) Phase II Scheduling counseling; (3) Phase III Implementation of counseling; and (4) Phase IV reflection and self-description of post-counseling counselees. The results of the model acceptance test on counseling material experts, media experts, and potential users found that the developed model has a good acceptance value. Statistically, it was found that there was an increase in the cultural intelligence of high school students after participating in counseling with the developed model. This happened because the model was developed by the underlying theories. A concise cybercounseling model with a solution focus based on Pancasila values can improve the cultural intelligence of high school students when they use social media.

title: Application of a Simple Port Scanner for Security Detection in Small Local Area Networks
authors: Ruiyang Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Small Local Area Networks (LANs), such as those in educational institutions, small businesses, and branch offices, often lack dedicated security teams and enterprise-grade monitoring tools, making them vulnerable to service exposure and configuration-based attacks. To address this gap, this study designs and implements a lightweight, Python-based port scanning tool tailored for security assessment in resource-constrained environments. The tool employs optimized SYN-style connect scanning to efficiently detect open TCP ports within the wellknown range $(\mathbf{1}-\mathbf{1 0 2 4})$, with a $\mathbf{2}$-second timeout to balance accuracy and performance. Deployed in a campus network testbed, the scanner successfully identified five high-risk service exposures, including cleartext protocols (FTP on port 21, Telnet on port 23), unsecured web services (HTTP on port 80), and improperly exposed database services (MySQL on port 3306). Based on these findings, targeted security hardening measures-such as protocol migration to encrypted alternatives, service minimization, configuration hardening, and firewall-based access control-were implemented, reducing the number of high-risk ports from five to one. The results demonstrate that systematic port scanning, when integrated into routine network hygiene, serves as an effective first-line defense for exposure mapping and attack surface reduction. This lightweight scanner features easy deployment, low resource consumption and ease of use, making it particularly valuable for small networks without advanced security infrastructure. We recommend regular scans (for example, weekly or biweekly) combined with active configuration management to enhance overall network resilience.

title: Evaluation of Deep Learning Algorithms to Predict Multiple Dementia-Related Neuropathologies from Brain MRI, Clinical and Genetic Data
authors: Tamoghna Chattopadhyay, Rudransh Kush, Pavithra Senthilkumar, Christopher Patterson, Conor Owens-Walton, Emma J. Gleave, Sophia I. Thomopoulos, Sterling C. Johnson, Elizabeth C. Mormino, Timothy J. Hohman, Paul M. Thompson
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Alzheimer’s disease and related dementias (ADRD) involve overlapping neurodegenerative and vascular pathologies—such as amyloid-β (Aβ), tau, cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA), TDP-43, and alpha-synuclein—that complicate diagnosis and treatment. While PET and CSF biomarkers are useful for detecting Aβ and tau, they are invasive, expensive, and not widely available. In contrast, magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is non-invasive and widely accessible, offering an opportunity for pathology prediction when combined with deep learning. Most prior studies have focused on single-pathology detection, but there remains a need for models that can jointly predict multiple co-occurring pathologies. In this work, we evaluate deep learning models that integrate structural MRI with demographic, clinical, and genetic data to classify six autopsy-confirmed neuropathologies: Aβ, tau, CAA, TDP-43, hippocampal sclerosis, and dementia with Lewy bodies. We compare our hybrid deep learning model to AutoGluon, an automated machine learning framework. Our findings support the potential of multimodal AI to enable non-invasive, comprehensive neuropathological profiling in ADRD.

title: An Apple Varietal Recognition Method Based on Artificial Olfactory System and Stacking Ensemble Learning
authors: Shuxian Li, Xiaozhen Ma, Qi Zhou, Sa Xiao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: An artificial olfaction system was created for discerning visually similar apple varieties such as Huanau and Akitsu. Tailored sensors were chosen pragmatically, and circuits designed for their odor responsiveness. Signals were sent to a machine learning algorithm on a host computer for variety identification. Stacking algorithm integration of machine learning models achieved a peak recognition accuracy of $97.14 \%$. This study affirms that the proposed electronic nose system, incorporating stacking, accurately identifies apple varieties based on odor, providing precise and non-destructive apple classification.

title: A Synergistic Deep Learning Optimization Framework for Energy-Efficient HPC Clusters
authors: Yuet Dong, Donovan Li, Peter Sun
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: The escalating energy consumption of HighPerformance Computing (HPC) facilities, driven by dataintensive applications like Large Language Models, poses a significant sustainability challenge. This paper addresses the critical need to align computational throughput with environmental responsibility. We propose a novel framework that uses a neural network autoencoder for task clustering, followed by a multi-objective optimization model to intelligently allocate tasks across a heterogeneous network of 92 HPC centers. While a single-minded focus on speed reduces makespan by $58.5 \%$ compared to a FIFO scheduler, it offers no energy savings. In contrast, our multi-objective approach reveals a Pareto front of optimal solutions, demonstrating that a minor $10 \%$ concession in makespan can yield a significant $25 \%$ reduction in energy consumption, which directly translates to a reduction in carbon emissions based on the regional energy mix. This provides a practical framework for operators to select a scheduling policy that aligns with both performance targets and sustainability goals.

title: A Pattern Recognition Method Based on ISSA to Optimize SVM
authors: Hongwei Shi, Yutao Deng, Huanyu Qian, Shuang Yin
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: To address the problems of existing pipeline monitoring and recognition models, which are prone to dropping into local optimality and relatively slow convergence, resulting in low pipeline monitoring efficiency and prediction accuracy, we present a machine learning approach that enhances SVM classification performance via ISSA-based hyperparameter tuning. The proposed methodology employs the Improved Sparrow Search Algorithm (ISSA) to globally optimize SVM hyperparameters, including the penalty factor and kernel parameters, resulting in the ISSA-SVM recognition and classification model. Experimental results show that the ISSASVM recognition and classification model can accurately identify different types of vibration events with strong real-time performance and high accuracy. It can also promptly issue alarms for pipeline anomalies such as pipeline leaks and oil theft, greatly improving pipeline monitoring efficiency.

title: Enhancing Cancer Information Access with a Retrieval-Augmented Generation Chatbot
authors: Komang Andika Wira Santosa, Choirul Huda
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: Cancer is one of the leading causes of death worldwide, with millions of new cases and deaths reported each year. As cancer-related research and guidelines progress at a fast pace, both patients and healthcare professionals face difficulties in accessing trustworthy and up-to-date information. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) architecture is introduced using the LangChain framework to solve this problem by combining generative capabilities of LLM and vector-based retrieval. The knowledge used in this chatbot consists of cancer-related articles from NIH and hundreds of research abstracts related to cancer from PubMed. Users can ask the chatbot about cancer-related questions, such as symptoms, diagnosis, and treatment. The chatbot generates responses using the retrieved information from the vector database and provides the retrieved sources. RAGAS framework and 50 questions from the MedQuAD dataset are used to evaluate the chatbot’s performance in faithfulness, context precision, answer relevancy, and context recall. The retrieval showed robust performance, but the generation component still struggles. This can be further improved by using pre-trained LLMs and better prompting techniques. Future work will focus on developing better knowledge base and better chunking strategies.

title: Verification Methods for BPF-based DPU
authors: Danila Lisovsky, Valery Slizkoy, Egor Kuznetsov
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The gap between central processing units’ performance and network transmission speed is ever increasing, leading to performance bottlenecks in modern computing systems. To address this issue, hardware accelerators are being developed to offload tasks such as network traffic filtering, packet classification, load balancing, and data processing from the CPU. However, the design of such accelerators must be accompanied by thorough verification to ensure correctness and reliability. Unfortunately, there are very few established solutions for verifying data processing units, as this area of research is still emerging. This paper presents functional verification methods applicable to the design of hardware network traffic accelerators, with a focus on a Berkeley Packet Filter virtual machine-based architecture. The proposed approach adapts simulation-based functional and behavioral verification techniques commonly used in general-purpose processor development. We describe the construction of a test bench environment, the generation of meaningful test stimuli, and the use of coverage-driven verification to assess design completeness. Results demonstrate effective detection of design errors and high functional coverage. Additionally, suggestions for improving code coverage, introducing custom verification metrics, and accelerating the verification process through automation are discussed. The presented methodology contributes to more robust and efficient development of hardware accelerators in high-speed networking applications.

title:
Experimental Verification of Contact Resistance Reduction in Monolayer MoTe
                    <sub>2</sub>
                    FETs Enabled by Semimetal Contacts Compared to Metals
authors: Xi Cheng, Mingzhu Long, Xinming Li, Qingyi Shao, Zefeng Chen
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Semiconductor Devices and Integration Technology (ASDIT)
abstract: The strong Fermi-level pinning (FLP) effect at metal–semiconductor interfaces remains a key obstacle to achieving low-contact-resistance electrodes for atomically thin transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs). In this work, monolayer MoTe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> was employed as the channel material, and the performance of field-effect transistors (FETs) with metallic electrodes (Au, Ag) was systematically compared to those with semimetallic electrodes (WTe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>, PdSe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>). The results reveal the unique advantages of semimetal contacts in improving the contact properties of MoTe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> devices. Experimental data show that semimetal contacts effectively alleviate the interfacial FLP effect, leading to a significant reduction of the Schottky barrier height, down to 29 meV. Devices with WTe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> contacts achieved a contact resistance as low as 18.72 kΩ•μm, markedly superior to conventional metallic contacts. Furthermore, the extracted pinning factor S (0.02 for metal contacts and 0.93 for semimetal contacts) confirms that the semimetal–MoTe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf> interface approaches the ideal Schottky–Mott limit, whereas metal contacts exhibit strong pinning. Under VDS=1V, WTe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>-contacted devices demonstrated excellent p-type unipolar transport characteristics with a field-effect mobility of 100.81 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>/(V•s). This study provides an important contact-engineering strategy for the development of high-performance MoTe<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>-based electronic devices and offers valuable guidance for advancing two-dimensional semiconductors in the post-Moore era.

title: Master-Slave Game Based Trading Strategy Modeling for New Energy Enterprises
authors: Jian Tang, Pan Wang, Jun Li, Yanjun Ding, Junfu Lv, Guangxi Yue
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Digital Management (ICAIDM)
abstract: In the process of global energy transition, new energy generation enterprises face trade challenges arising from price volatility, renewable energy intermittency, and dynamic policies. We propose a Master-slave Game based Trading Strategy Modeling (MGT) framework, which addresses the gap in existing studies on electricity market trading strategies that insufficiently consider the decision-making role of new energy power generation enterprises. This framework deeply integrates the master-slave game theory with electricity market trading scenarios, enabling the simulation of electricity sales enterprises (leaders) setting optimal electricity selling prices, new energy power generation enterprises (followers) optimizing quotation strategies and electricity sales volumes, thermal power generation enterprises (followers) optimizing power generation volumes, and electricity users (followers) optimizing electricity consumption volumes. Additionally, a hierarchical algorithm can efficiently solve this game equilibrium problem, effectively reducing the risks caused by market uncertainty. Finally, detailed simulation experiments show that under market fluctuation scenarios, when new energy power generation enterprises adopt our proposed optimized trading strategy model MGT, compared with adopting high or low quotation strategies, their profit growth rate can reach up to 202.4%, and daily profits can reach a maximum of 88.041 million yuan. This provides a practical decision-making tool for new energy generation enterprises to respond to complex market environments during the low-carbon transition.

title: Transmission Line Fault Cause Identification using Large Language Models
authors: Xiaojiang Duan, Xiaoyu Shen, Shunan Li, Shuang Liu, Zhong Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Transmission lines are constantly exposed to outdoor environments, making them susceptible to damage from various natural and human factors. Accurately identifying and promptly addressing the cause of a fault is crucial for restoring power supply. As a classification task, the mainstream methods for identifying the causes of transmission line faults are machine learning-based and deep learning-based methods. However, these approaches exhibit limitations, such as reliance on single-modal data and inadequate feature representation. In this paper, we propose to utilize large language models (LLM) for transmission line fault cause identification. Specifically, we introduce two strategies: (1) A multi-template prompt engineering method, which leverages diverse templates to guide LLM outputs, fully utilizing multi-source fault case data and the generative capabilities of LLM. (2) A hierarchical feature extraction method, where the hidden-layer outputs of the LLM serve as effective feature representations for fault cases. Extensive experiments on the real cases of transmission line fault case identification demonstrate the effectiveness of these two methods.

title: Intelligent Pipeline Crack Detection Robot Based on Triaxial Balancing Technology
authors: Taiyuan Zhang, Qi Tian, Yifei Chen, Zhugege Yuan, Shiying Zhang, Zheming Zhao
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: In the industrial field, pipelines, as critical facilities for transporting energy and water resources, their safe operation is vital to the national economy and people’s livelihood. However, due to long-term fluid scouring, corrosion, and external stress, cracks on the inner wall of pipelines have become major hidden dangers leading to major accidents such as leaks and explosions. According to statistics from the Pipeline Research Council International (PRCI), there are over a thousand leakage accidents caused by pipeline cracks worldwide every year, with direct economic losses reaching billions of dollars. At the same time, they will also trigger chain reactions such as environmental pollution and energy waste. Traditional methods such as manual visual inspection and ultrasonic testing are not only inefficient and costly, requiring a lot of manpower and time for a single inspection, but also have the problem of high missed detection rates, especially being difficult to detect tiny cracks below the millimeter level. With the advancement of Industry 4.0 and intelligent development, the demand for real-time monitoring of long-distance pipelines under complex working conditions in scenarios such as oil and gas fields and urban pipe networks is increasingly urgent. Traditional detection technologies can no longer meet the requirements of high-precision and high-efficiency detection, and more efficient and accurate detection methods are urgently needed. Centering on the actual needs of pipeline crack detection, this paper develops a fully sealed spherical self-balancing robot. The robot integrates a control system, a driving system, and a detection system, dedicated to achieving flexible movement, zero-radius steering, and operation in liquid environments within long curved pipelines. Meanwhile, it breaks free from the constraints of traditional cables by means of 2.4 GHz WiFi wireless control technology, thereby improving the work efficiency of pipeline detection. In terms of control, a combination of a three-axis active stabilization system and PID control is adopted, which, together with the IMU (Inertial Measurement Unit) and Unscented Kalman Filter (UKF), processes sensor data. By optimizing state estimation, the stability of the robot’s movement is ensured. In terms of the detection model, a lightweight network L-YOLOv5s is constructed based on YOLOv5s. The network introduces the Ghost Conv module to reduce the number of parameters, combines the SENet module to enhance sensitivity to features, and adds the Channel group structure to optimize feature fusion. Finally, on the premise of ensuring detection accuracy, the model parameters are reduced from $\mathbf{7. 2 M}$ to $\mathbf{4. 1 M}$, with the Average Precision (AP) reaching 85.9%.

title: Short-Term Spectrum Situation Prediction Using 3D Transformer with Geographic Priors
authors: Kun Yin, Shengliang Fang, Feihuang Chu, Junhao Fen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: The accurate prediction of electromagnetic spectrum dynamics is essential for enhancing operational efficiency in wireless communication and defense systems. However, conventional prediction techniques reliant on physical modeling or ray tracing are often hindered by high computational load and limited adaptability in complex propagation environments. To overcome these challenges, this chapter introduces a 3D Transformer-based model termed 3D-STP for short-term spectrum situation prediction. The model effectively integrates geographic structural priors through a novel location encoding mechanism, maintains 3D structural integrity to capture fine-grained spatial-spectral features, and employs hierarchical temporal aggregation for efficient multi-step prediction. Experimental evaluations demonstrate that the proposed approach not only achieves high predictive accuracy with naturally smooth spectral transitions, but also significantly reduces inference time compared to conventional numerical methods. These contributions collectively advance the deployment of AI-aided spectrum management in practical dynamic scenarios.

title: A Method for Secure Communication Based on CNN Chaotic Encryption
authors: Xi Wang, Yijia OuYang
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: Traditional encryption techniques face security risks that are easily cracked and weak resistance to attacks. This paper proposes a method for secure communication based on CNN chaotic encryption. This method first selects a third-order cellular neural network system that generates chaotic behavior, and defines an encryption function. Then the sender selects multiple state variables from the CNN chaotic system as a continuous stream of real-time keys input into the encryption function. The confidential information is encrypted using the encryption function to obtain a ciphertext with noise like spectral characteristics. The ciphertext is then sent to the receiver through a public channel. After receiving the ciphertext, the receiver first constructs a full dimensional state observer based on the output signals of the CNN chaotic system and the CNN chaotic system from the sender. Through the feedback and modulation of the full dimensional state observer, the CNN chaotic system for the receiver synchronized with the sender is obtained. Multiple state variables synchronized with the sender are selected as the decryption key of the decryption function, and the inverse operation of the encryption function is performed to decrypt the ciphertext and obtain the recovered confidential information. The experimental results indicate that the method proposed in this paper is correct and feasible. The method proposed in this paper provides good theoretical guidance and technical support for the application of CNN chaotic systems in secure communication, and has good practical value.

title: Study on Dense Coding of Quantum Information Transmission Process at Different Orders
authors: Changjiang Xie
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: This paper first employs the mathematical framework of quantum mechanics, including Hilbert space theory and the superposition principle of quantum states, to analyze the processing methods and transmission processes of quantum information under second-order conditions. It delves into the core role of quantum gates as orthogonal operators and their correspondence with information transmission results through matrix multiplication. Subsequently, it investigates quantum information transmission and dense encoding techniques based on controllable non-qubit gates (CNOT) at different orders. The CNOT gate is represented by a second-order tensor product matrix: when the control qubit is $\mid 1\gt$, it performs a Pauli-X operation on the target qubit (matrix: [$[0,1]$, [1, 0]]), otherwise remaining unchanged. By defining the CNOT matrix, Hadamard matrix, maximum entangled state and corresponding multi-order unitary operations (described using elements of the $\mathbf{S U}(\mathbf{n})$ group for higher-order quantum system transformations), this study combines density matrix representations of quantum states with quantum measurement theories (such as the mathematical description of projection measurements). It reveals the mechanistic principles underlying quantum information transmission and decryption processes. Through computational verification of quantum state fidelity and transmission success rates across different orders, the effectiveness of cross-order information transmission is demonstrated.

title: A Hybrid Deep Learning and Evolutionary Optimization Model for Accurate Traffic Matrix Estimation of Optical Networks
authors: Shengjie Guo, Yanxian Bi, Yushan Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Accurate traffic matrix estimation (TME) is essential for efficient optical network management, yet existing approaches often struggle with complex traffic dynamics and scalability. To address this challenge, we propose a hybrid LSTM-BiLSTMGA framework that integrates temporal learning models with optimization techniques. Experiments on the Abilene dataset show that our method achieves the lowest errors (RMSE $=0.009$ for traffic matrices and MAE $=\mathbf{0. 0 3 1}$ for traffic matrices), with 68.8% of predictions within 20% deviation from ground truth, and consistently outperforms baselines even under tidal traffic patterns, demonstrating superior accuracy and robustness.

title: A Forward Calorimeter in ALICE at LHC
authors: T. Chujo
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The FoCal is a high-granularity forward calorimeter that will be newly installed in the ALICE experiment at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) during the Long Shutdown 3 and is scheduled to collect physics data in LHC Run 4 starting from 2030. It will cover a pseudo-rapidity range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.2 <\eta<5.8$</tex>, enabling the exploration of quantum chromodynamics (QCD) at extremely low Bjorken- <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\chi$</tex> values down to 10<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">−6</sup> - a regime where non-linear QCD effects are expected to play a significant role. The FoCal comprises a high-granularity silicon-tungsten sampling electromagnetic calorimeter (FoCal-E), featuring both pad and pixel readouts to provide the high energy resolution and the spatial resolution necessary for distinguishing between isolated photons and closely spaced decay photon pairs. The hadronic section (FoCal-H) is constructed using copper capillary tubes or sheets embedded with scintillating fibers. This detector system is designed to operate near the room temperature, and the maximum expected radiation dose is approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7 \times 10^{13}(1 \text{MeV}$</tex> neutrons) <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$/ \text{cm}^{2}$</tex> at the end of LHC Run 4. In this paper, we present the longitudinally full-scale prototype detector performance from the test beam campaigns conducted between 2022 and 2023 at CERN-PS/SPS at CERN. We also report on the FoCal mass-production status.

title: Exploring $LaCl_{3}$ and $LaBr_{3}$ Scintillators' Performance as Neutron Thermometers
authors: J. O'Neill, J. Heery, J. Henderson, M. Bunce, G. Lorusso
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper presents enhanced pulse shape analysis of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{LaCl}_{3}(\text{Ce})$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{LaBr}_{3}(\text{Ce})$</tex> scintillator detectors, demonstrating their capabilities as neutron thermometers. These detectors exhibit neutron- <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\gamma$</tex> discrimination across the neutron energy range <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0-20 \text{MeV}$</tex>, a regime of interest for industry, fusion reactors, and nuclear security applications. We report the application of a Fourier transform technique to improve particle species discrimination and characterise the detector responses to neutron sources and monoenergetic neutron beams across the energy range <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.5-15.5 \text{MeV}$</tex>, demonstrating distinct peaks arising from (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{n}, \mathrm{p}$</tex>) and (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{n}, \alpha$</tex>) reactions. Further studies will systematically measure cross-sections across a range of neutron energies and compare the results to theoretical predictions.

title: Regularised Richardson Lucy Deconvolution for PET PVC
authors: S. Porter, K. Erlandsson, D. Deidda, K. Thielemans
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We introduce a kernelised Richardson-Lucy (KRL) deconvolution framework for postreconstruction partial-volume correction in PET, leveraging anatomically informed kernels to constrain solution space. We benchmark KRL against classical Richardson-Lucy (RL) and a directionally regularised RL (DRL) incorporating a directional total-variation prior. On a six-sphere phantom, KRL reduced RMSE at 100 iterations from 0.702 (RL) to 0.417, outperforming DRL (0.476). These results demonstrate that KRL enhances quantitative accuracy and edge preservation in PET PVC with minimal additional computation.

title: RETIMAGER: A 128-Channel SiPM Read-Out System for Time-of-Flight Measurement
authors: A. Haddar, M. Morenas, F. Perez, J.-B. Cizel, C. Derrien, S. Ahmad, J. Fleury, L. Batres Mongil, D. Perez Benito, J. J. Vaquero Lopez
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: A readout system has been designed for high precision time-resolved measurements between hexagonal Silicon Photomultipliers (SiPMs) used in RETIMAGER project. The readout architecture incorporates a Xilinx ZC702 FPGA evaluation board, customdesigned interface board, a front-end board housing a TEMPOROC ASIC coupled with a hexagonal SiPM. An intrinsic Coincidence Time Resolution (CTR) of 83 ps FWHM is achieved by the readout system when using inputs coming from external waveform generator, demonstrating exceptional timing capabilities. We describe the hardware system components, hardware architecture, firmware implementation, and data acquisition protocols. Performance analysis includes dark count rate characterization, timing distribution, and energy spectrum acquisition using Na-22 sources. The stability and reliability of the system are validated through reproducible results in multiple data collection sessions.

title: Design Considerations for Mixed-Signal ASIC Readout in Time-of-Flight Computed Tomography
authors: D. Roshani, J. Rossignol, G. Bélanger, Y. Bérubé-Lauzière, A. C. Therrien, M.-A. Tétrault, R. Fontaine
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Time-of-Flight Computed Tomography (ToF-CT) relies on high-speed digital processing to extract precise timing information, which is then used in image reconstruction. In typical configurations, TOF-CT generates raw data at rates exceeding <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \text{Gbit} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> per <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{mm}^{2}$</tex>, creating significant challenges in managing this large data volume. Additionally, the processing must fit within the limited silicon area of a densely packed, multi-channel ASIC. To address these issues, this paper explores adaptive binning along with asynchronous counters to design a histogram circuit for implementing low-area, real-time data compression for TOF-CT applications. We evaluated the trade-offs between compression efficiency and essential data needed to maintain image quality. A case study shows a reduction by a factor of six in data size and silicon area compared to a standard histogramming. The embedded signal processing has been tested with GATE simulations data and demonstrate a minimal impact on image quality, resulting in a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.2 \backslash \%$</tex> loss in CNR.

title: 3-D Contamination Mapping System with Quadruped Robot and Gamma-Ray Imager
authors: J. Lee, J. Kim, S. Jeong, Y. Cho, M. Jeong
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In the event of a nuclear power plant accident, workers must manage radiation exposure considering site characteristics and the as low as reasonably achievable (ALARA) principle. Visualizing radiological characteristics and contamination distribution of such sites would enable efficient exposure management. Gamma-ray imager can measure dose rates, acquire spectrum, and visualize contamination distribution through hotspots. Recent research has focused on combining gamma-ray imager with light detection and ranging (LiDAR) to create three-dimensional contamination maps. Additionally, research is being conducted on mounting this equipment on robots for autonomous navigation to prevent human radiation exposure. This study developed a system integrating the miniaturized mini-EPSILON-G which is derived from the previously developed energetic particle sensor for identification and localization of originating nuclei-gamma (EPSILON-G) with LiDAR and a color camera mounted on a quadruped robot. Using this system, we created and evaluated three-dimensional contamination maps by registering 3-D structural information with gamma-ray data. As a result of the experiment, the developed system was able to successfully detect and visualize the location of a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3.512 \text{MBq}{ }^{137} \text{Cs}$</tex> source and demonstrated stable 3-D mapping capabilities even in complex indoor environments. Through the utilization of this system, users can easily identify the structure of objects surrounding the robot and locate the position of gamma-ray sources. This system is expected to enable efficient mapping of radioactive contamination distribution in complex structures or areas with limited human accessibility.
