title: Extraction of Medial Axes from CT Volumes by Approximation with Spherically Supported Functions
authors: Y. Nagai, K. Uemura, Y. Shimomura
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In the analysis of objects exhibiting with thin and elongated shape features, such as blood vessels or plant roots, the extraction and utilization of their medial axes prove advantageous. A medial axis is defined as the set of sphere centers that touch a surface of the object at two or more points. Since the media axis of an elongated objects shows a curve-like appearance, it is possible to compute the object's thickness and topology with it. Many existing methods for extracting medial axes from 3 dimensional images (volumetric data) obtained from, for instance X-ray CT scanning, perform voxel-based computation on the data. However, a voxel-based image processing for extremely elongated objects poses challenges, due to its diameter of just a few voxels and tendency of low contrast. It ends up to instabilities in computation of medial axes or generation of unsmooth curves. For overcoming these difficulties, we propose to first approximate the intensities of volume data with spherically supported functions to generate a continuous scalar field. Spherically supported functions is a set of local approximation functions whose supports have spherical shapes and cover the entire region of interest. The global continuous approximation function of intensity is obtained as a weighted sum of the local approximation functions. Nest, the medial axis is extracted which is defined as the set of maximum points of the global approximation function. This approximation strategy achieved a medial axis computation with noise robustness. We applied this algorithm to simulation data of cylinders and X-ray CT data of plant roots. The results indicated that the medial axes were successfully extracted for isolated objects, while some erroneous detections occurred around parts in close proximity.

title: Maximum Likelihood Motion and Activity (MLMA) Reconstruction in SPECT Imaging
authors: E. Waterink, R. José Santo, H. W.A.M. De Jong, C. A.T. Van Den Berg, R. Van Rooij, C. Beijst
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Motion may lead to misleading uptake values in single photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) imaging. Gating techniques often struggle with compensating for irregular motion, as they assume periodicity of motion and often require hardware (e.g. belts). To this end, we have developed a maximum likelihood motion and activity (MLMA) reconstruction method for gate-less non-rigid motion correction. The MLMA method alternates between motion estimation and image correction steps. Motion is estimated using the MOTUS framework. The motion model (i) compresses motion with B-splines bases, (ii) exploits spatiotemporal correlation of motion with a low-rank model, and (iii) enforces smoothness with spatial motion-field regularization. The MLMA method can estimate and correct irregular 3D motion at high frequency (500 ms), and was validated in silico and on patient acquisitions. The contrast recovery was improved in silico, with visual improvements in simulations and clinical images.

title: Personalized Internal Dose Prediction Using Consistency Model
authors: J.-R. Wang, K.-H. Lin, B.-H. Yang, Y.-H. Liu, T.-H. Wu, C.-T. Shih
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Accurate and personalized voxel-level dosimetry remains a significant challenge in radionuclide therapy. Although Monte Carlo simulations provide accurate and reliable dose estimation, considerable computational time and cost limit their clinical application. In this study, the generative diffusion framework of a consistency model (CM) was applied to generate whole-body voxel-level internal dose maps from 3D PET/CT images through one-step sampling. PET and CT images were adopted as the input of the CM to provide the required information of radioactivity and physical density distributions for internal dose calculation. Whole-body dose maps calculated using the multiple voxel S-value method with 24 tissue-specific voxel dose kernels derived using MCNP simulations were used as the ground truth for model training and validation. Quantitative evaluation showed a mean absolute percentage error of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.0170 \pm 0.0122$</tex> and a mean structural similarity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.9891 \pm 0.0066$</tex>, reflecting the consistency between the generated and reference dose maps. Even in tissue heterogeneous regions, such as lung boundaries, relative percent errors between the generated dose maps and ground truth remained lower than 10 %. The results indicated that the CM accurately modeled the complex interaction between radionuclide distribution and patient anatomy, providing a rapid and clinically feasible solution for personalized internal dosimetry in targeted radionuclide therapy.

title: Data Driven Motion Detection, Estimation and Correction for Brain Pet Scanners
authors: V. A. Dao, E. Mikhaylova, D. Lesnic, R. G. Aykroyd, C. Tsoumpas
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We present a data-driven motion correction method for brain positron emission tomography (PET) using Monte Carlo simulations of a Derenzo phantom and measure FDG patient data. Our approach performs motion detection from listmode allowing us to remove motion while minimising the number of frames. Motion estimation is performed in image space while reconstruction of PET images is done using STIR library. The line profile results demonstrate recovery of the resolution for the motion-corrected images even for the 2 mm diameter spheres. Furthermore, the motion corrected patient images recovers more defined brain structures that originally suffered from motion.

title: AddrProbe: An Internet-wide Active IPv6 Address Probing System with Limited Seeds
authors: Daguo Cheng, Lin He, Qilei Yin, Guangxing Han, Yizhen Zhang, Boran Jin, Ying Liu, Guanglei Song, E Jinlong, Tiankai Yang, Jiahai Yang
abstract: With the large-scale deployment of IPv6, it is becoming more and more important to probe active IPv6 addresses on the global Internet. However, the vast address space and the random distribution of active addresses make the probing process full of challenges, especially for the probing of IPv6 prefixes without seed addresses. Furthermore, the widespread existence of IPv6 aliased prefixes also causes significant trouble for probing. In this paper, we present AddrProbe, an active IPv6 address probing system, which dynamically probes all global routing prefixes based on learned fine-grained address patterns from limited seed addresses and quickly detects aliased prefixes during probing. The evaluation results show that AddrProbe achieves a hit rate of 23%-45% with all routing prefixes announced by the BGP system, which is 6.6-13× that of current state-of-the-art approaches (no more than 4%). Moreover, we find 1.2×1033 aliased addresses characterized by the detected aliased prefixes, covering 6,412 routing prefixes, which is a 107× and 5.9× improvement over existing methods, respectively. Finally, an IPv6 Hitlist is constructed based on the long-term probing results, which contains 562M addresses covering 190K routing prefixes and 29K ASes. These widely distributed addresses are meaningful for analyzing IPv6 address assignments and some other IPv6 measurement activities.

title: An E-Linac Based Spent Fuel Cladding Radionuclide Content Inspection Method Using Neutron Resonance Transmission Analysis
authors: S. Qi, Y. Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The radioactivity of spent fuel cladding determines its radioactivity level and thus is important for spent fuel reprocessing. Neutron resonance transmission analysis (NRTA) is a non-destructive analysis method for determining the mass density of certain isotopes, especially high-Z isotopes. Photoneutron sources driven by e-Linac can provide high neutron yield and good stability for practical industrial applications. In this paper, a spent fuel cladding radionuclide inspection system based on a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$9 \text{MeV}-0.9 ~\text{kW}$</tex> e-Linac and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{3} \text{He}$</tex> proportional counter tube is considered. The transmission neutron spectrum is measured by combining the detected time provided by a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{3} \text{He}$</tex> detector and trigger time given by the accelerator, and the mass thickness of isotopes is determined via a two-step algorithm. Optimal mass thickness of spent fuel cladding is considered, and experiments are carried out to calibrate the energy resolution of the TOF (time of flight) spectrometer. The theoretical precision of different measuring durations is also given by simulations. This work shows the potential of applying photoneutron sources for spent fuel reprocessing.

title: LLM-Driven Multicast Network Slicing for 6G Non-Terrestrial Networks
authors: Zexuan Jing, Junsheng Mu, Yan Zhu, Lexi Xu, Fei Qi
abstract: Non-terrestrial networks (NTNs) will play a central role in 6G broadcasting by providing ubiquitous coverage and the ability to offload media processing to space-borne compute. The next generation of immersive media services will require multicasting data from satellites to large groups of receivers with stringent latency and quality-of-service (QoS) demands. This paper proposes a large-language-model (LLM)-driven orchestration framework that translates broadcaster intents into optimized multicast network slices spanning ground and space resources. Building on the concept of computing-power networks (CPNs), the framework integrates compute-aware routing across GEO, MEO and LEO links, enforces delay-aware multicast constraints using an integer-linear-program formulation, and leverages LLM to adaptively admit multicast groups under resource constraints. A federated fine-tuning mechanism combined with a blockchain audit layer enables continuous improvement of the LLM while preserving data privacy and providing human-interpretable audit trails. Simulations demonstrate that the proposed method reduces end-to-end latency and energy consumption compared to traditional heuristics, while increasing the number of admitted multicast requests.

title: Simultaneous Photon Counting and Energy Integration in X-Ray Imaging: Proof-Ofconcept and Initial Results
authors: X. Ran, Z. Deng, H. Gao, Y. Song
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The photon-counting X-ray imaging system exhibits superior spatial resolution, minimal noise, and reduced radiation exposure; however, its performance degrades under high flux rates. To overcome this limitation, we have developed a dual-mode imaging readout chip, which is compatible with both cadmium telluride (CdTe) and cadmium zinc telluride (CZT) crystals and is capable of simultaneously performing integration and photon counting. Building upon this chip, an X-ray imaging detector was constructed, incorporating a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$32 \times 32$</tex> channel array. At 25° C, the integration channel demonstrated a leakage current on the order of 4 nA. A detailed analysis of the simultaneously acquired photon counting and integration data revealed a robust correlation between the two output mode. The system's dual-mode imaging function was confirmed using a basic PMMA projection image based on their correlation, which performed similarly to a reference CsI panel detector. Additionally, computed tomography (CT) successfully reconstructed an image of a walnut phantom.

title: Bit Inversion Probabilistic Shaping Enabling Performance Tradeoff in Photonics-Aided Millimeter-Wave OFDM Integrated Sensing and Communication Systems
authors: Zhiguo Wang, Wei Ji, Hengtai Chang, Yunxiao Li, Jiao Zhang, Mingzheng Lei, Min Zhu, Ju Liu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Microwave Theory and Techniques
abstract: The integration of photonics-aided millimeter-wave (MMW) and terahertz systems with orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM) waveforms is emerging as a crucial pathway toward realizing the integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) for 6G wireless communication systems. However, the random communication data carried by OFDM results in variability in the sidelobes of its ambiguity function (AF), which severely restricts the improvement of the overall performance of ISAC systems. To tackle this challenge, we propose a bit inversion probabilistic shaping (BI-PS) scheme for photonics-aided MMW ISAC systems. By employing an amplitude bit mapping mechanism innovatively, the scheme dynamically adjusts the probability distribution of constellation points, allowing for seamless conversion between quadrature amplitude modulation (QAM) and phase shift keying (PSK). To validate the effectiveness of the BI-PS scheme, the photonics-aided 40-GHz MMW ISAC simulation and experimental systems were established. Results show that adjusting the shaping strength effectively regulates the communication rate and the sidelobe level. Furthermore, a unified metric, sensing estimation rate (SER)-generalized mutual information (GMI), is intended for the quantitative analysis of ISAC, which clearly reveals the dynamic tradeoff between the communication and sensing rate.

title: Experimental Evaluation of Artefacts and Mitigation with TOF in Partial-Ring PET Image Reconstruction
authors: J. Wehr, F. C.A. van de Werff, J. Nuyts, G. Schramm, D. R. Schaart, M. C. Goorden
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Limited-angle positron emission tomography (PET) has several applications, including breast PET and range verification in proton radiotherapy. Artefacts in reconstructed images from PET detectors with partial-ring geometry can be mitigated with excellent timing resolution. This work experimentally studies the effects of the loss of angular information on reconstructed Derenzo phantom images for a monolithic-scintillator time-of- flight PET setup with a 212 ps FWHM coincidence resolving time, a 1.7 mm full-width-at-half-maximum (FWHM) spatial resolution,, and 4.7 mm FWHM depth-of-interaction (DOI) resolution. Different system geometries were emulated by removing detector modules corresponding to specific positions in the ring from a full-ring dataset. The images reconstructed were then analysed, and several metrics were calculated, including the structural similarity index measure, normalized root mean square deviation, signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), and the eccentricity and peak-to-valley ratio of hot rods in the phantom. It was found that a detector angular coverage of two-thirds yielded images of comparable quality to a full-ring detector.

title: A Method for Time Walk Correction in the Timing Process of PET Detectors Based on Cherenkov Radiator-Integrated Window MCP-PMT
authors: W. Pan, Y. Wang, X. Huang, T. Wang, Z. Zhang, L. Wei
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The detection of annihilation photons using microchannel plate photomultiplier tubes (MCP-PMTs) based on Cherenkov radiation can theoretically break through the time resolution limitations of positron emission tomography (PET) detectors. However, the signal amplitude fluctuations of this detector scheme are relatively large, making it susceptible to the Time Walk effect in advanced timing applications based on this scheme. In this study, we developed a dual-module platform based on self-developed lead glass integrated window multi-anode MCP-PMTs combined with matched electronics, and investigated a Time Walk correction method feasible for system-scale applications. Based on the pulse width difference between coincidence events, we obtained the time walk correction parameters and performed time walk correction on the time-of-flight (TOF) information. Without any event loss or additional calibration process, the coincidence time resolution (CTR) was improved from 285 ps to 128 ps full width at half maximum (FWHM), and the reliability of this correction method was verified.

title: Fast, Non-Quantitative Imaging for Near Realtime Scan Assessment Using End-To-End Deep Learning
authors: N. Murthy, M. Millardet, Y. Zheng, D. Bharkhada, V. Panin, P. Schleyer
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Near real-time assessment of a PET scan is an important way to improve patient throughput. Technologists typically use reconstructed images to decide if they need to potentially re-acquire the scan. Current reconstruction methods (based on iterative algorithms) can take several minutes (especially for long axial FOV scanners) to complete, leading to an increased waiting time postacquisition. This abstract explores the use of end-to-end deep learning (DL) as a fast and nonquantitative method to potentially display near real-time updates during the acquisition. We investigate the use of a network (which we call ultraFastPET) that has been trained to take histoimages as input, and with non-attenuation corrected (NAC) MLEM reconstructions as targets. We show results for step-and-shoot data as well as near real-time updates for a continuous bed motion (CBM) scan in progress. We show that the ultraFastPET inference time is fast (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 4$</tex> seconds on an NVIDIA RTX 3090 for a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$220 \times 220 \times 645$</tex> histo-image), and this could potentially be optimized further and included in the current acquisition workflow for scan assessment.

title:
Fast Nanoparticle ZnS:Ag/
                    <sup>6</sup>
                    LiF Scintillators: Challenges and Applications
authors: S. Mann, E. Schooneveld, G. Mauri, N. Rhodes, G. J. Sykora
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: High performance neutron detectors are required for a wide range of industries, from nuclear security to fundamental research. Given the limited availability of 3He and the many advantages of ZnS:Ag/<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup>LiF, these scintillators are widely used in thermal neutron applications. ZnS:Ag/<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup>LiF, however, suffers from poor rate capability caused by inherent afterglow. As a solution, a novel scintillator employing nanoparticle ZnS:Ag was produced and studied. Nanoparticle ZnS:Ag/<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup>LiF was measured to have a primary decay under 20ns and minimal afterglow leading to dramatic improvements in count rate capability, achieving linearity beyond 1Mcps. With the added benefit of pulse shape discrimination, this scintillator can be used in high rate applications such as neutron resonance transmission and reflectometry. The main disadvantage has been identified as the low detection efficiency of the nanoparticle scintillator. This work addresses the efficiency problem by investigating its inherent causes. Samples of different thicknesses with constant <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup>LiF to nanoparticle ZnS:Ag ratios were produced and characterized. Thinner screens showed at least 40% increase in light output leading to a thermal neutron trigger efficiency of 70%, 2 times greater than in the original work. Energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy also revealed aggregation of the nanoparticle ZnS:Ag suggesting even further improvements can be achieved with optimisation of the scintillator composition. The capability of nanoparticle ZnS:Ag/<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup>LiF scintillator for use in neutron scattering applications such as neutron reflectometry and resonance measurements was assessed and compared to standard ZnS:Ag/<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">6</sup>LiF. Further improvements required for deployment of the nanoparticle scintillator at neutron scattering facilities will be discussed and the ongoing developments to enhance performance will be presented. Ultimately, results of this work demonstrate the high potential for nanoparticle ZnS:Ag in demanding applications.

title: Sub-250 Ps TOF/DOI-PET Detector Using Multiplexed 45° Tilted SiPMs and Fast Timing Circuit
authors: M. Seo, G.B. Ko, J.S. Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: A previous study demonstrated that the 45° tilted SiPM configuration with sparse arrangement effectively reduced the number of SiPMs while maintaining good DOI resolution. However, its ability to achieve sub-250 ps timing resolution has yet to be verified. We developed a TOF-PET detector based on 45° tilted SiPMs with a multiplexed readout scheme and a high-frequency timing circuit. The detector comprises a 44 LSO crystal block optically coupled to 23 top and 3 2 bottom SiPM arrays. A resistive charge division circuit was used to reduce the number of readout channels, and summed timing signals were amplified through RF amplifiers and balun transformers. To minimize light loss from the uncovered regions of entrance surfaces due to the sparse SiPM arrangement, an enhanced specular reflector (ESR) film was applied. Furthermore, depth-of-interaction (DOI) correction was applied to improve timing performance. The 45° tilted detector achieved clear identification of all 16 crystal elements regardless of ESR coverage. The configuration with ESR demonstrated improved energy and timing resolution, yielding an average coincidence timing resolution (CTR) of 246.8 ps FWHM and energy resolution of 18.7 % FWHM at bias voltage of 48 V. Compared to a previous non-multiplexed design (CTR <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$CTR ~411 \text{ps}$</tex>), the proposed design significantly enhanced timing performance with only slight degradation in energy resolution. These results demonstrate the feasibility of a simplified, cost-effective TOF-PET detector using multiplexed 45° tilted SiPMs.

title: Dual-Beam Excitation of Scintillator Detectors for Multiple Photon Emission
authors: C. Campbell, S. Rand, J. Glodo, M. Muller, D. Wehe
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The energy resolution of scintillators is limited by their light yield. Optical re-excitation of activator ions in inorganic scintillators provides a theoretical pathway for amplifying the scintillation light yield. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Lu}_{3} \text{Al}_{5} \mathrm{O}_{12}$</tex> (LuAG) with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Ce}^{3+}$</tex> activator ions is a good candidate host-dopant pairing to experimentally verify this re-excitation mechanism. The impacts on the Ce valence state caused by co-doping with Ca and Mg are evaluated using emission and excitation spectra of LuAG samples with various doping concentrations. These optical spectra indicate the co-dopants force the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Ce}^{3+}$</tex> to convert to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Ce}^{4+}$</tex>, which is necessary so the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Ce}^{3+}$</tex> activator ion is available for reexcitation only in the event of radiation interactions. Evidence of photoconversion with 3.54 eV photons indicates viability of re-excitation mechanism. A dual-beam optical and x-ray excitation experiment using a chopper wheel and lock-in amplifier was designed and assembled which allows comparison of the scintillation response to both single- and dual-beam excitation. Single-beam optical experiments were conducted to demonstrate the response of LuAG doped with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Ce}^{3+}$</tex> to a chopped optical beam, along with single-beam x-ray measurements which demonstrate successful chopping of the x-ray beam and readout of the scintillation signal. The responses of the LuAG samples with varied doping ratios will be tested in this setup to verify the re-excitation mechanism and identify preferred doping ratios for this process.

title: RADIUMA: A Shareable Executable Workflow Generator for Medical Image Analysis
authors: M. R. Salmanpour, M. Oveisi, I. Shiri, A. Rahmim
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We present RADIUMA, an open-access, zero-code, and shareable workflow generator for medical image analysis and machine learning model development. RADIUMA comprises multiple tools for 2D/3D image processing and machine learning, and supports a wide range of imaging modalities, including PET, SPECT, CT, MRI, Ultrasound (US), and Xray, with compatibility for various image formats such as DICOM, NIfTI, and NRRD. The integrated image viewer enables multi-planar visualization, and supports interactive segmentation and exporting segmentation in different formats, including RT-Struct. Moreover, RADIUMA includes multiple image registration and fusion algorithms to facilitate multimodal image analysis. It also offers comprehensive image preprocessing options using various filters, and supports advanced radiomics analysis, extracting radiomics features including shapes, intensity, texture, and deep learning features. RADIUMA includes a full suite of machine learning tools, supporting the entire executable and graphical pipeline, from feature preprocessing and selection to the development of tools for classification, regression, and clustering. Each tool can be used independently or integrated into a complete workflow. Users can construct workflows that begin with loading multi-modality DICOM images, and continue through processing, diagnosis, and prognostic modeling. Executable and graphical workflows can be saved, modified, or extended later, and most importantly, shared with other researchers and users. This allows reproducible analysis using the same parameters and settings across datasets. RADIUMA supports the principles of open science by providing a usable, reusable, reproducible, shareable, and executable workflow generator environment for the full pipeline of medical image analysis and machine learning.

title: MSPNet: A Multi-Scale Pyramid Network for Semantic Segmentation of Urban-Scale Photogrammetric Point Clouds
authors: Ziyin Zeng, Honglin Chen, Jian Zhou, Bijun Li, Ruili Wang
publish: IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing
abstract: Photogrammetric point clouds have emerged as a cost-effective solution to urban environment perception and scene understanding, significantly advancing recent research in urban-scale 3D semantic segmentation. In contrast to well-explored indoor and road scenes, urban-scale photogrammetric point clouds exhibit more complex spatial geometries, richer texture details, and pronounced multi-scale disparities between background environments and foreground objects. These challenges demand neural networks with enhanced spatial, low-level, and multi-scale learning capabilities. To address these issues, we propose the Multi-Scale Pyramid Network (MSPNet), a conceptually streamlined, end-to-end network for semantic segmentation of urban scenes. The proposed MSPNet comprises three key components: (i) the Ellipsoid Spherical Position Embedding (ESPE) module, which leverages learnable ellipsoid queries and spherical harmonics, rather than using a fixed ball query and a linear combination of spatial coordinates, to explicitly model position embeddings and effectively capture intricate geometric relationships; (ii) the Top-Down Information Retrospection (TDIR) module, which establishes hierarchical semantic guidance through retrospective pathways, enhancing structural consistency across features at different levels, and (iii) the Low-Rank Adaptation (LoRA) Fusion module, which applies matrix rank constraints during multi-scale feature fusion to decompose high-level semantics into low-rank subspaces, alleviating multi-scale semantic confusion. We have conducted extensive experiments on several established urban-scale photogrammetric point cloud segmentation benchmarks, including, HRHD-HK, SensatUrban, and UrbanBIS. The experimental results demonstrate that MSPNet achieves significant improvements across these benchmarks, highlighting the superior ability to accurately segment urban scenes and the potential to advance urban environment perception and scene understanding.

title: Development of 2-Dimensional SiPM-Based Photon-Counting CT for Dynamic Imaging
authors: M. Oshima, T. Ro, M. Arimoto, F. Lucyana, Y. Furuta, J. Kataoka, R. Minagawa, S. Terazawa, Y. Maeno
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Photon-counting computed tomography (PC-CT) is a next-generation medical imaging technology that can accurately count individual photons and acquisition of X-ray energy information. Previously, we developed a one-dimensional PC-CT system consisting of multipixel photon counters (MPPCs) and yttrium-gadolinium-aluminum-gallium garnet (YGAG) scintillators. This system successfully demonstrated material discrimination and concentration estimation within an object. However, its long acquisition times limited its applicability to biomedical and dynamic imaging. In this paper, we developed a two-dimensional PC-CT system employing a pixel array of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$64 \times 16$</tex> (1024 pixels in total) with a pixel size of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1 \times 1 ~\text{mm} 2$</tex> to enable practical biomedical and dynamic imaging. Two signal processing systems were developed: a custom-designed LSI with and without a differential circuit. Performance evaluation revealed that the system equipped with the differential circuit exhibited improved counting capability, with minimal impact from the scintillation decay time of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 70 ~\text{ns}$</tex>, whereas the system without the circuit had a dead time of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 230$</tex> ns. Both systems achieved comparable energy resolutions of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 40 \%$</tex> (FWHM at 59.5 keV). These results demonstrate the feasibility of the developed two-dimensional PC-CT system for dynamic imaging. Furthermore, preliminary results of CT imaging obtained with this system are presented in this paper.

title: Nonunique Mappings of Water and k-edge Contrast Agent Pathlengths in Single-Energy CT Material Decomposition
authors: J. Phillips, B. Chen, E. Sidky, Z. Zhang, D. Xia, X. Pan
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The goal of this work is to investigate the existence of nonunique mappings of fluence transmission to material pathlength in conventional computed tomography (CT) projection material decomposition. Previous studies have demonstrated that a unique inversion of the nonlinear dual-energy CT (DECT) imaging model is only guranteed if the Jacobian determinant of the system is nonvanishing. Projection based basis material decomposition, which traditionally requires measurements with two different x-ray spectra, can be done with a conventional CT dataset supplemented by a pathlength conservation constraint. The Jacobian determinant for the single-energy CT system is derived and data is simulated for an object containing water and either iodine (25 mg/ml) or gadolinium (39.5 mg/ml) contrast agent. Vanishing determinant values are identified for multiple source spectra which are realistic to clinical diagnostic x-ray tube settings. The result indicates nonunique mappings from tranmission fluence measurements to material pathlengths are likely to exist and can diminish the accuracy of reconstructed basis images.

title: Structural Uncertainty Quantification in Low-Dose CT Image Reconstruction
authors: K. Murata
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This work presents an evaluation method for assessing the significance of a structure in a reconstructed image for low-dose CT. Due to severe noise, the reconstructed images often contain artifacts. It is important to distinguish real structures from such artifacts. For this purpose, quantifying structural uncertainty is required. One way to evaluate the structural uncertainty is to estimate the covariance matrix of the pixel values. However, it is computationally intractable especially for high-dimensional images, i.e., large-format images. Previous studies suggested the use of the highest posterior density (HPD) to define a credible region. Using the credible region, significance of the structure in the reconstructed images can be evaluated through hypothesis testing: If images without the structure fall outside the credible region, the hypothesis that the true image does not contain the structure is rejected, confirming its significance. The present work expands this method and adapts it more appropriately for low-dose CT. To determine the threshold with which the significance of the structure is evaluated, the chi-square distribution was adopted. In addition, the chi-square was calculated using only the area related to the structure under scrutiny. These modifications provide a more stringent threshold, allowing for more appropriate evaluation of image structures. The feasibility of this method was evaluated and confirmed through image reconstruction simulations.

title:
Development of an Omnidirectional Rotating Compton Camera for Imaging Radioactive Contamination in Peptide Receptor Radionuclide Therapy With [
                    <sup>177</sup>
                    Lu]Lutetium-Oxodotreotide
authors: H. Tsukamoto, H. Muraishi, R. Enomoto, H. Katagiri, M. Kagaya, T. Watanabe, T. Mizoguchi, K. Okubo, D. Kano, Y. Watanabe, K. Sakaguchi, H. Ishiyama
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We report the development of an omnidirectional rotating Compton camera based on 3.5 cm cubic <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{CaF}_{2}(\text{Eu})$</tex> scintillator crystals for environmental radiation monitoring. This detector is designed to visualize low-energy gamma rays (113 and 208 keV) emitted by [<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{177} \text{Lu}$</tex>] Lutetium-oxodotreotide, a radiopharmaceutical used in peptide receptor radionuclide therapy. The rotating Compton camera technology, as described by Muraishi et al. (Jap. J. Appl. Phys., 2020), enables shift-invariant, highsensitivity gamma-ray imaging. The prototype detector demonstrated effective visualization of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{177} \text{Lu}$</tex> even in the presence of technetium-99m (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{99 ~\mathrm{m}} \text{Tc}$</tex>), a commonly used radioisotope in nuclear medicine. Notably, the detector distinguished between areas contaminated with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{177} \text{Lu}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{99 ~\mathrm{m}} \text{Tc}$</tex>. The study also presents a detailed evaluation of detection efficiency, including the influence of photomultiplier tube scattering and source self-absorption. These results highlight the potential of the developed Compton camera for enhancing environmental radiation monitoring and contamination control in nuclear medicine facilities.

title: A Custom-Built, Benchtop, and Tunable Micro-CT System for Soft Tissue Imaging Applications
authors: T. Okamoto, T. Ueda, K. Izumitani, K. Takagi, N. Nagano, M. Sekine, H. Haneishi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Micro X-ray computed tomography (micro-CT) is a non-destructive three-dimensional (3D) imaging technique that enables visualization of internal structures at micrometer-scale resolution. MicroCT has recently attracted attention as a complementary tool for conventional histopathological examination. The high-resolution 3D morphological information provided by micro-CT has the potential to supplement two-dimensional observations of tissue sections using optical microscopy. However, the practical application of micro-CT in histopathological examination faces several challenges, including limited soft tissue contrast and long scanning times, requiring improvements in both hardware and software. However, commercial micro-CT scanners are generally closed systems and not optimized for soft tissue imaging, making customization difficult. We aim to develop a custom-built, highly tunable micro-CT system designed to enable soft tissue imaging. Furthermore, to enhance accessibility and promote potential clinical application, the prototype was constructed as a compact, benchtop-sized, and cost-effective system. We evaluated the effectiveness of the system using a custom-designed lymph node-mimicking phantom. Experimental results demonstrated sufficient visualization of 2-mm spheres, suggesting that the system has the potential for future applications in imaging metastatic tumors.

title: Tool-Aided Evolutionary LLM for Generative Policy Toward Efficient Resource Management in Wireless Federated Learning
authors: Chongyang Tan, Ruoqi Wen, Rongpeng Li, Zhifeng Zhao, Ekram Hossain, Honggang Zhang
publish: IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications
abstract: Federated Learning (FL) enables distributed model training across edge devices in a privacy-friendly manner. However, its efficiency heavily depends on effective device selection and high-dimensional resource allocation in dynamic and heterogeneous wireless environments. Conventional methods demand a confluence of domain-specific expertise, extensive hyperparameter tuning, and/or heavy interaction cost. This paper proposes a Tool-aided Evolutionary Large Language Model (T-ELLM) framework to generate a qualified policy for device selection in a wireless FL environment. Unlike conventional optimization methods, T-ELLM leverages natural language-based scenario prompts to enhance generalization across varying network conditions. The framework decouples the joint optimization problem mathematically, enabling tractable learning of device selection policies while delegating resource allocation to convex optimization tools. To facilitate the evolutionary process, T-ELLM interacts with a sample-efficient, model-based virtual learning environment that captures the relationship between device selection and learning performance. This developed virtual environment reduces reliance on real-world interactions, thus minimizing communication overhead while refining the LLM-based decision-making policy through group relative policy optimization. Theoretical analysis proves that the discrepancy between virtual and real environments is bounded, ensuring the advantage function learned in the virtual environment maintains a provably small deviation from real-world conditions. Experimental results demonstrate that T-ELLM outperforms benchmark methods in energy efficiency and exhibits robust adaptability to environmental changes.

title: Implicit Knowledge and Emotional Cues-Enhanced Multimodal Sarcasm Detection Model
authors: Yi Zhai, Jin Liu, Xingye Li, Yuxin Liu, Huihua He
abstract: Multimodal sarcasm detection aims to determine whether sarcasm exists in the interplay between text and accompanying images or audio. Effectively exploiting commonsense knowledge is crucial in multimodal sarcasm detection. However, previous methods only utilize the inherent attributes within modalities to construct superficial inconsistencies. They fail to fully leverage commonsense knowledge and implicit sarcasm cues and cannot uncover the deep contradictions between modalities. Accordingly, we propose a novel model named the Knowledge and Emotion Enhanced (KEE) model, which enhances sarcasm detection by integrating commonsense reasoning and cross-modal emotional contrast. Specifically, the KEE model leverages a generative language model to infer commonsense knowledge from the visual modality. It then selects highly relevant knowledge phrases through an attention mechanism and integrates them with text embeddings via a gated weighting mechanism to reveal sarcastic clues behind literal semantics. Additionally, the model captures emotional polarity inconsistencies across modalities and optimizes detection through a joint distribution framework. Experimental results demonstrate that the KEE model outperforms state-of-the-art methods on benchmark datasets.

title: 50 Mm × 50 Mm Cesium Atomic Vapor Cell for Terahertz Imaging: Implementation and Application
authors: Bin Zhang, Jun Wan, Tao Li, Xian-Zhe Li, Yu Wu, Qi-Rong Huang, Xin-Yu Yang, Wei Huang, Kai-Qing Zhang, Hai-Xiao Deng
publish: IEEE Transactions on Terahertz Science and Technology
abstract: Rydberg atomic sensors offer transformative potential for high-speed, high-sensitivity terahertz (THz) imaging. However, previous systems are hindered by restricted imaging areas, largely due to the compact dimension of atomic vapor cells and inefficient beam-shaping methodologies. We present a THz imaging system with a 50 mm × 50mm area, enabled by a custom-engineered scaled-up atomic vapor cell and an optimized beam-shaping optical architecture. Experimental validation confirms that this system achieves near-diffraction-limited, high-resolution THz imaging at 0.55 THz under ambient conditions. Furthermore, its capabilities are demonstrated through real-time visualization of the diffusion dynamics of a deionized water droplet in anhydrous ethanol. This work not only expands the boundaries of Rydberg atomic sensors but also establishes a critical foundation for advancing THz imaging technologies toward into real-world, large-scale applications.

title: Gamma-Ray Spectroscopic Performance of 1 cm Thick Pixelated TlBr Detectors with Tl Electrodes at Room Temperature
authors: K. Hitomi, M. Nogami, T. Nojima, S. Maruyama, K. Watanabe
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Thallium bromide (TlBr) is a compound semiconductor with a wide bandgap energy of 2.68 eV and high photon stopping power originating from its high atomic numbers (81 and 35) and high density (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$7.56 ~\mathrm{g} / \text{cm}^{3}$</tex>). These physical properties are attractive for the fabrication of roomtemperature gamma-ray detectors. Recently, the long-term stability of TlBr detectors with Tl electrodes has been significantly improved. In this study, the spectroscopic performance of 1 cm thick pixelated TlBr detectors with Tl electrodes fabricated using the latest detector fabrication technology was characterized. The TlBr detectors were fabricated from the crystals with the dimensions of approximately <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12 ~\text{mm} \times 12 ~\text{mm} \times 10 ~\text{mm}$</tex>. The detectors had a planar cathode and 3 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\times 3$</tex> anode pixels surrounded by a guard electrode. The pixel size was <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2 ~\text{mm} \times 2 ~\text{mm}$</tex>. The cathode of the detector was irradiated with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{133} \text{Ba},{ }^{137} \text{Cs}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{60} \text{Co}$</tex> gamma-ray sources to characterize the spectroscopic performance. Energy resolutions of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.8,1.2$</tex>, and 1.0 % full width at half maximum for 356,662, and 1332 keV gamma rays, respectively, were obtained from a pixelated anode of a 1 cm thick TlBr detector for the single pixel events at room temperature using a depth correction and rejection method based on the cathode-to-anode signal ratio.

title: Activity Estimation of Gamma-Ray Sources with Coded Aperture Quantitative Imaging Method
authors: X. Liang, H. Liu, L. Shuai, X. Hu, X. Wang, Z. Zhang, C. Wei, L. Wei
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In this study, we have developed a quantitative imaging method adapted to far-field gamma-ray sources, capable of estimating the strength of radioactive sources indicated by radiation hotspots, giving their activity values. A multi-messenger 3D imaging system was devised that incorporates multiple sensors, including coded aperture gamma-ray images, optical video and 3D point clouds from LiDAR, which realizes 3D imaging and gives the distance to radiation hotspots rather than just a 2D image. We first give the relationship between the flux and the values of radiation hotspots in the decoded reconstructed images by Monte Carlo simulation, and then derive the activity values of the radioactive sources based on the distance-decay characteristics of the gamma-ray intensity. The experimental results support that our method can quantitatively measure the activity for both single-point sources and multiple-point sources, with activity estimation errors of 14.7 % for a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$17 \mu \text{Ci}{ }^{137} \text{Cs}$</tex> single-point source at a distance of 1 m, and 7.2 % and 16.3 % for two <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$890 \mu \text{Ci}{ }^{137} \text{Cs}$</tex> sources at a distance of 3 m, respectively. Our imaging strategy is based on the conventional coded aperture method and LiDAR scanning, which enables both realtime 3D vision and quantitative measurement of gamma-ray sources.

title:
Gamma-Ray Energy Estimation and Dose Evaluation of
                    <sup>137</sup>
                    Cs Based on Scintillation Light Output Ratios
authors: S. Kim, S. Lee, J.H. Park, S. Song, J. Kim, B. Lee
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In this study, we proposed a gamma-ray energy estimation methodology based on the ratio of scintillation light outputs (SLOs) from GAGG:Ce and plastic scintillators. Theoretically, scintillators emit visible light proportional to energy deposition, which depends on both energy and activity of gamma-ray emitting radionuclides. By normalizing the SLO of the inorganic scintillator with that of the plastic scintillator, the activity dependence can be eliminated. Since the resulting SLO ratio becomes exclusively dependent on gamma-ray energy, radionuclide identification can be achieved through simultaneous measurement of SLOs from both scintillator types. To validate this methodology, we have developed fiber-optic radiation sensors incorporating these dual scintillation materials. Additionally, Monte Carlo N-Particle (MCNP) transport code simulations were performed to establish correlation between experimental and computational SLO ratios. The relationship between experimentally measured SLO ratios and simulation-calculated values was established using three gamma-emitting radionuclides: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{109} \text{Cd},{ }^{133} \text{Ba}$</tex>, and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{60} \text{Co}$</tex>. The proposed methodology was applied to measure the energy of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{137} \text{Cs}$</tex> gamma emissions, yielding an estimated energy of 0.66138 MeV. Additionally, the developed sensor demonstrated capability for simultaneous energy measurement and radiation dose evaluation through calibration with a commercial dosimeter.

title: Characterization and Radiation Hardness of the Mu2e Calorimeter Readout Electronics
authors: E. Pedreschi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The Mu2e experiment at Fermilab intends to search for the neutrino-less charged-lepton Flavor violating conversion of a negative muon into an electron in the presence of a nucleus. According to the Standard Model of Particle Physics this process, in which a muon transforms into an electron without a neutrino, is predicted to be extremely rare, practically non-existent through the usual forces. Therefore, if this process were observed it would indicate the presence of new physics beyond the SM. The goal of the Mu2e experiment is to improve the current experimental limit on the neutrino-less muon-to-electron conversion by four orders of magnitude. The measurement will be performed at Fermilab (USA) where the detector, which comprises a tracker followed by an electromagnetic calorimeter and is surrounded by a cosmic ray veto, is under construction. The calorimeter will be located inside the cryostat and, the readout electronics are housed in crates mounted on the external surface of it. This is a very harsh environment. Monte Carlo simulations were used to estimate the expected radiation levels on the individual components by integrating the expected fluxes for the entire Mu2e data taking period and applying appropriate safety factors as requested. The readout it has been subjected to numerous test campaigns to survive and to operate reliably of up to 5 years. The Mu 2 e calorimeter readout electronics was validated for operation in high-vacuum and under 1 Tesla magnetic field. An extensive radiation hardness qualification campaign, carried out with photons from Co-60, 14 MeV neutron beams, and 200 MeV protons certified the read-out design to substain doses up to 30 krad, neutron fluences up to 10E12 n (1 MeV eq.) /cm2 and very low numbers of single-event effects occurrences. The detector is currently being installed. This paper reviews the qualification campaigns and quality assurance procedures performed on the readout electronics

title: System Level Assessment of SiPM External Cross-Talk
authors: F. Retiere
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Single Photon Avalanche Diodes (SPADs) emit photons whenever an avalanche occurs. These photons are mostly re-absorbed within the same SPAD or region of the device that are inactive, but a few of them may trigger avalanches in neighboring SPADs or escape the device. The former case is referred as (internal) cross-talk and the latter can lead to the external cross-talk phenomenon should one or more escaping photons be detected by another device. The case where an escaping photon is detected by the same device is folded into (internal) cross-talk in our context. External cross-talk is a system level phenomenon because it involves several processes: photon emission, transport and detection, and as such it is detector dependent. In this paper, we will focus on a test experiment called Light only Liquid Xenon (LolX), We will show what we understand and don't understand about external cross-talk and attempt to extrapolate to any detector system.

title: 3DCZT in Space: Gamma Ray Spectroscopy Measurements from the International Space Station Using the Cadmium Zinc TElluride Radiation Imager (TERI)
authors: M. Streicher, D. Shy, J. Mason, F. Zhang, W. Kaye, D. Goodman, A. Thompson, Z. He, B. Phlips
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The cadmium zinc TElluride Radiation Imager (TERI) successfully launched to the International Space Station (ISS) in April 2025 as a part of the Department of Defense's (DOD) Tenth Space Test Program (STP-HX) mission. TERI is made up of four ruggedized detector platforms, each containing a single, monolithic <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4 \times 4 \times 1.5 ~\text{cm}^{3} \text{CdZnTe}$</tex> detector. Monolithic detector modules were selected due to concerns related to shock and vibration at launch. TERI also contains a coded-aperture mask for imaging low energy photons. The primary mission of TERI is to spacequalify this iteration of CdZnTe for future missions, with a secondary focus on detecting and localizing astrophysical phenomena including supernovae. The radiation hardness of the CdZnTe detectors used in TERI were studied, and techniques to mitigate damage were implemented. The primary method to reduce radiation damage included biasing the detector down as the ISS passes through the South Atlantic Anomaly (SAA). The energy resolution of TERI at 662 keV is better than 1.1% FWHM with each of the four 4 × 4 × 1.5 cm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> CdZnTe detectors demonstrating energy resolution between 0.9% FWHM at 662 keV and 1.2% FWHM at 662 keV, measured at the final, pre-launch test campaign at Kennedy Space Center (KSC) in February 2025. TERI is in the Launch and Early Orbit Phase (LEOP) of the mission with imaging and spectroscopic results expected at the conference.

title: Application of Spectral CT in Quantitative Imaging of Iodized Oil
authors: Y. Wang, Y. Liu, S. Zhu, Z. Gu, C. Wei, L. Wei, Q. Xu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In radiation therapy, iodized oil is utilized for its strong X-ray attenuation capability, which can enhance the absorption of radiation by tumor cells. The diffusion behavior and retention time of iodized oil within the tumor significantly influence the effectiveness of radiosensitization treatment. Therefore, in practical applications, it is desirable to quantitatively analyze the dynamic distribution and concentration changes of iodized oil within the tumor in order to evaluate its efficacy in radiosensitization. The development of spectral CT provides an effective approach for the quantitative analysis of iodized oil. In this study, spectral CT was employed to perform quantitative imaging of iodized oil. Based on material decomposition algorithms, two groups of iodized oil with different concentrations were compared over time to observe sedimentation changes and to quantitatively estimate the distribution and concentration of iodized oil. The results demonstrated good accuracy, thereby confirming the feasibility of spectral CT in quantitative imaging of iodized oil and providing both theoretical and experimental foundations for further research.

title: A Quali-Quantitative Analysis of Biosensing and Biotransducing Systems for Cardiovascular Monitoring: Pacemakers Active and Passive Stress
authors: J. Tene Koyazo, Aimé Lay-Ekuakille, Michele Bellino, Gennaro Galasso, Ornella Piazza, K. Srinivasa Rao
abstract: The global health burden of cardiovascular diseases, including MI (myocardial infarction), CAD (coronary artery disease), heart arrhythmias, cerebrovascular disease, and HF (heart failure), is substantial. As a primary cause of mortality, there is a pressing need for continuous and real-time heart monitoring to identify and treat irregular heart rhythms. PPMs (permanent pacemakers) constantly monitor the heart’s spontaneous electrical activity and only activate when it is either defiant or absent. The PPMs under investigation in our research are special implantable biosensors and biotransducers with nanoscale components. The PPMs do not generally contain biochemical reactants but they interact with physiological fluids to be considered as biosensors, and nanobiosensors if they encompass nanomaterials, as for our case. The objective of this study is to determine the reliability of PPM structures that have been implanted in patients who are suffering from one of the cardiovascular diseases over time. Even though the PPMs have been certified for the above use, however, natural patient conditions such as changes in body posture, temperature, or even changes in metabolic demand, can affect their operating modes. The sidewall roughness surface of PPMs is analyzed using atomic force microscopic 3D structural reconstruction, which is based on the grey images of PPMs from CT scanning for each patient. The angular equivocation (also known as angular entropy) approach is implemented to quantify the uncertainty in the distribution of edge or gradient orientation in PPMs images. Then, in order to address nonlinearities and interactions caused by metallic components in the PPM that introduce harmonic and distortions from biological tissues and device motion, we have conducted a bispectral analysis followed by contour representation plots. Different results obtained are of interest for monitoring the state of implantable devices in activity based on CT cardiac examinations in order to preserve the patient’s extended life.

title: Molecular Communication in Bounded Spherical Region With Anomalous Diffusion Phenomenon_supp1-3645247.pdf
authors: Lokendra Chouhan
abstract: In this work, we develop the channel model of a molecular communication (MC) system with molecules propagating via anomalous diffusion in a confined environment, in particular, inside a spherical region. The MC system consists of an absorbing receiver located at the center of the region and a point transmitter along whereas the outer boundary is fully reflecting. We first obtain the concentration profile of molecules inside the region at a given time. Further, we derive the hitting rate and hitting probability to characterize the channel.

title: Ziv-Zakai Bound for DOAs Estimation under Arbitrary-bit Quantization
authors: Zongyu Zhang, Zhiguo Shi, Jiming Chen, Maria Sabrina Greco, Fulvio Gini, Yujie Gu
abstract: The distribution of quantized observations is inherently non-Gaussian and often implicit, rendering conventional Ziv-Zakai bounds (ZZBs) and other global mean-squared error (MSE) lower bounds inapplicable to direction-of-arrival (DOA) estimation under quantized measurements. To overcome this limitation, we derive a closed-form ZZB for DOA estimation by leveraging the additive quantization noise model (AQNM). The proposed bound yields a unified expression that encompasses fully quantized, mixed-resolution, and unquantized observation scenarios. Furthermore, we introduce a generalized approximation framework based on a beamforming perspective, which enables the proposed ZZB to capture both linear quantization gain and quantization noise effects. Unlike existing bounds, the derived ZZB is valid for arbitrary quantization resolutions and reveals the distinct influence of both the quantization bit depth and the number of low-resolution analog-to-digital converters (ADCs) on the overall MSE. Numerical results demonstrate the accuracy and practical relevance of the proposed bound, highlighting its superiority over existing lower bounds.

title: Implementing Feed-Forward Neural Networks to Accelerate the Analysis of Complex Gamma Spectra
authors: J. G. Wroe-Brown, C. Shenton-Taylor
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The analysis of gamma spectra for nuclear forensic purposes is a labor-intensive task performed under severe time constraint. Feed-forward neural networks, with highly pre-processed inputs, are proposed to accelerate analysis by identifying the most appropriate causal radioisotope from a library of known gamma emissions. This method compares the possible assignments of a spectral peak in pairs, then aggregates the results of all comparisons to reach a final decision. Inputs to the neural network are highly pre-processed to highlight the characteristics most relied on by analysts when making a manual assignment to give an overall accuracy of 88.3 %. This accuracy shows a 6 % decrease when analyzing peaks with multiple possible solutions. The neural network has been shown to be radionuclide insensitive, with minimal accuracy loss when exposed to radionuclides that were not included in its training dataset. Alongside testing on historical data, an opportunity to assess the efficacy of this approach on a live trial will be considered and presented.

title: Improving Energy Resolution of Largevolume SiPM Detector Arrays
authors: A. Giaz, S. Riboldi, S. Brambilla, C. Boiano
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In nuclear physics experiments that study the collective motion of nuclei, large-volume (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>15 ~\text{cm}^{3}$</tex>) scintillators are used to detect high-energy <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\gamma$</tex> rays up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20-30 \text{MeV}$</tex>. In the past, scintillation light readout was done with photomultiplier tubes (PMTs); with the availability of silicon photomultiplier (SiPM) arrays of enough size (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>2^{\prime \prime} \times 2^{\prime \prime}$</tex>), the transition to SiPMs is ongoing. SiPMs have several advantages, but also potential issues that must be considered, such as: i) temperature-dependent gain, ii) a finite number of cells, and iii) high output capacitance. This transition requires an in-depth study, to build high-performance arrays. In the first phase of our work, we modeled and simulated the generation of photons from radiation detectors and their interaction with a SiPM matrix. We quantitatively identified aspects of non-linearity due to the finite number of cells and the non-homogeneity of the breakdown voltage to understand why, at high energy, the energy resolution that we measure is always worse compare to the one predicted by the Poisson statistical model. We determined that, in addiction to the electronics noise and the dark count rate of the SiPMs, an energy-proportional error becomes significant for energies higher than a few MeV. This non fundamental error term maybe associated with at least three factors: SiPMs temperature variation, SiPMs breakdown voltage non-homogeneity, and finite number of SiPM cells. We performed experimental measurements to establish the relative importance of each of those factors. The results show that the most significant contribution comes from the often neglected SiPM breakdown voltages variations. As the next step towards the development of our large-volume, SiPM based, scintillator array, we are going to design a SiPM readout system able to compensate these unavoidable variations in the breakdown voltage levels, to minimize this effect.

title: A Void-Avoidance and PSO-Based Non-Uniform Dynamic Clustering Routing Protocol for UASNs
authors: Shen’ao Tu, Yougan Chen, Yihao Zhao, Yanhan Dong, Xuchen Wang, Yi Tao, Lei Wan, Xiaomei Xu
abstract: Underwater Acoustic Sensor Networks (UASNs) have attracted significant research interest due to their broad range of marine applications. However, challenges such as limited battery replacement capability and unstable underwater communication severely constrain their reliability and efficiency, with the routing void problem emerging as a key bottleneck. To address this issue, this study presents VPNC, a Void-avoidance and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO)-based Non-uniform Dynamic Clustering routing protocol. The proposed method embeds void node evaluation into the PSO fitness function, jointly optimizing cluster-head selection and void avoidance by considering residual energy, node depth, and node degree. A cooperative inter-cluster transmission mechanism between cluster heads and gateway nodes ensures balanced load distribution and extends network lifetime. Moreover, an accelerated Dijkstra algorithm incorporating hop count, residual energy, and distance metrics is developed, along with a traversal termination principle to enhance routing efficiency. Simulation results show that VPNC achieves substantial improvements over existing clustering protocols, reducing the proportion of void nodes and improving network lifetime and throughput by at least 20.40% and 37.38%, respectively. These results confirm the effectiveness and robustness of VPNC in maintaining energy efficiency and long-term stability under challenging underwater acoustic environments.

title: Hybrid Neural Network and Gradient Boosting Approach for Air Pollution Level Classification
authors: Andrey S. Semenov, Anna A. Aletdinova
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Air pollution monitoring remains a critical environmental challenge requiring reliable analytical tools. This study evaluates a hybrid CatBoost–CNN framework for multi-class air-pollution level classification, applying a well-established ensemble learning concept to the environmental monitoring domain. The novelty of this work lies in adapting and validating feature-level stacking for heterogeneous, imbalanced ecological data and demonstrating its applicability within automated air-quality measurement systems. The study is based on open data from the Central Pollution Control Board of India covering 2015–2020, with over 29,000 daily observations across 26 cities. Data preprocessing included missing-value imputation, log-transformation of skewed features, scaling, and class balancing with SMOTE. Three classical models (logistic regression, SVM, CatBoost) were implemented and compared with neural network architectures. CatBoost achieved the best performance among classical algorithms (F1-macro = 86.4%). The hybrid CNN model reached an average accuracy of 90.1% and F1-macro of 89.4% across five stratified folds, surpassing both standalone CatBoost and CNN baselines. The results confirm that combining boosting-based probabilistic outputs with convolutional feature extraction enhances classification stability and accuracy for noisy, imbalanced air-quality data, supporting the integration of such hybrid analytics in environmental monitoring workflows.

title: Hybrid Radio-absorbing Coatings Using Glasscrystalline Microspheres of Technogenic Origin
authors: Olena Fedorenko, Ruslan Kryvobok, Ludmila Shchukina, Sergii Monakhov, Viktoriia Taranenkova, Stanislav Lihezin
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: In the current conditions of rapid radar detection and guidance means development, the importance of measures to reduce military facilities' effective scattering surface is growing. One of the key ways in this area is creating and improving radioabsorbing coatings (RAC), which reduce the electromagnetic radiation reflection in the radio wave range. In modern conditions of rapid radar detection and guidance development, the importance of measures to reduce the effective scattering surface of military objects is increasing. One of the key directions in this field is the creation and improvement of radio-absorbing coatings (RACs), which reduce the reflection of electromagnetic radiation in the radio wave range. The paper discusses the research results on hybrid (polymer matrix) coatings obtained using technogenic microspheres as a filler. The effectiveness of using low-temperature short-term heat treatment of microspheres for targeted crystallization of magnetically active phases (maghemite, hercynite, hematite) is shown.

title: A Digital-Based Assessment Model for Evaluating Students’ Analytical Thinking in Geography
authors: Hasan Argadinata, Wahyu Putra, Elis Dwi Wulandari, Ahmad Bagus Perkasa, Novika Adi Wibowo, Faiz Hilmawan Masyfa, Ababil Karhoma Wijaya, Arin Ika Puspitaningsih
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: The fast pace of digitalization in education requires new forms of assessment that would develop higher-order thinking skills including analytical, which is a crucial competence of geography education. However, traditional tests may focus on knowledge recall and fail to represent problem-solving skills. his study developed and validated a digital-based instrument to measure Grade 10 students’ analytical thinking within the Kurikulum Merdeka. Cognitive indicators based on the revised Bloom’s Taxonomy of Anderson were used to develop the instrument. The process of development included content validation by six experts, reliability testing with 50 students, and item analysis. The results showed the scale had strong validity (Aiken’s V = 0.84), good reliability (Cronbach’s Alpha = 0.81) and reasonable item discrimination and difficulty. Analysis of distractors also provided evidence for the functionality of most test items. The electronic format facilitates interactive and scalable evaluation according to national curriculum objectives and worldwide trends in geographic education. This instrument fills a longstanding void in geography assessment by providing a deep theoretical and methodological instrument to assess analytical thinking, and by providing support for incorporating the assessment in digital environments. Further research should extend application to varied educational settings and integrate more process-oriented assessment forms to enhance the development of digital assessment in geography.

title: A Service Mesh-Driven Continuous Delivery Strategy for Microservices with Intelligent Decision Models
authors: Wenya Zhang, Xin Ji, Hanyuan Li, Yifan Mao, Zhi Yang, Fang Peng, Junle Wang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning, Pattern Recognition and Automation Engineering (MLPRAE)
abstract: With the rise of cloud-native technologies, containers, microservices, and service mesh have become the foundation of digital business transformation. Unlike traditional monolithic systems, microservice architecture enables finer service granularity, higher availability, and stronger scalability, yet it also brings challenges for efficient continuous delivery under massive and frequent updates. To address this, this paper investigates the design and implementation of a continuous delivery strategy based on service mesh. We first propose a multi-indicator evaluation model using a multivariate sigmoid function and an intelligent decision-making model based on Thompson sampling, which integrates service performance evaluation with delivery decisions to support multi-version, multi-indicator scenarios and enhance automation. Furthermore, we develop service mesh-based tools for traffic control, including customizable routing rules through proxy container mode, traffic injection with parameterized settings, and service call relationship discovery for visualized control. Finally, we design a microservice platform controller for declarative management of delivery experiments, together with a Git-based synchronization repository and a GitOps-driven workflow covering deployment, updates, and decision-making. Overall, the proposed approach improves the accuracy of performance evaluation, optimizes resource usage, strengthens traffic flexibility and visualization, and achieves efficient, reliable, and automated continuous delivery for microservice applications.

title: A Sparse Bayesian OTFS Channel Estimation Method Based on Gibbs Sampling
authors: Huawei Zhang, Zexun Luo, Jianli Xie, Kewei Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: To tackle the challenge of time-varying channel fading induced by Doppler spread in Orthogonal Time Frequency Space (OTFS) systems under high-mobility scenarios, this paper proposes a Gibbs sampling-based Sparse Bayesian Learning (SBL) channel estimation algorithm.By leveraging the inherent channel sparsity in the delay-Doppler domain, the algorithm establishes a hierarchical Bayesian model. Initially, Gibbs sampling is employed to efficiently explore the posterior distribution of the sparse channel. This approach yields a precise estimation of channel gain statistics while circumventing the computationally intensive matrix inversions required by conventional methods. Furthermore, a Minimum Mean Square Error (MMSE) estimator is seamlessly integrated with the sampling outputs, enabling the adaptive adjustment of the prior model via a dynamic hyperparameter optimization mechanism. Lastly, a modular design facilitates parameter optimization and effectively mitigates error propagation. Simulation results demonstrate that the proposed method significantly enhances channel estimation accuracy and lowers the system’s Bit Error Rate (BER) when compared with existing approaches. It exhibits superior robustness, particularly in complex channel environments, effectively resolving the estimation challenges posed by Doppler shifts in OTFS systems.

title: High-Sensitivity MEMS Capacitive Microphone Based on Heterogeneous Integration
authors: Bing Zhang, Guoqing Yang, Yang Dong, Yanfeng Jiang, Duoduo Gao, Encheng Zhu, Genlan Rong, Ziyang Wang, Kai Yan, Shaoping Li
publish: 2025 International Conference on Advanced Semiconductor Devices and Integration Technology (ASDIT)
abstract: Capacitive MEMS microphones have attracted considerable attention in consumer electronics and IoT applications owing to their compact form factor and superior performance. However, conventional designs encounter fundamental challenges in simultaneously achieving high sensitivity and miniaturization. This study presents a theoretical investigation of sealed multi-membrane MEMS microphones based on heterogeneous 3D integration technology. By employing a hybrid methodology that integrates lumped-element equivalent circuit modeling with finite element analysis, we systematically characterize the acoustic performance of the multi-membrane architecture. The proposed approach demonstrates significantly enhanced computational efficiency compared to conventional FEM-only methods while maintaining rigorous analytical accuracy. Simulation results reveal that the multi-membrane configuration achieves remarkable performance metrics, with a sensitivity of -30.67 dB V/Pa and an SNR of 80.18 dB(A), representing substantial improvements over traditional microphone designs. The developed methodology provides an effective framework for optimizing high-performance MEMS microphone architectures, offering valuable insights for both academic research and industrial applications.

title: LLM-Driven Framework for Knowledge Graph Construction, Completion, and Alignment
authors: Wei Tang, Xun Mao, Kai Lv, Ming Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Large Language Models demonstrate remarkable capabilities in various natural language processing tasks, yet they often struggle with factual accuracy, knowledge reasoning, and suffer from “hallucinations” in knowledge-intensive scenarios due to fragmented or insufficient knowledge. To address these limitations, this research proposes a comprehensive framework for domain knowledge graph construction, completion, and linking based on large language models. The core technology encompasses two main modules for construction: knowledge graph generation from unstructured text using prompt engineering, and a multi-layered verification mechanism including semantic alignment with authoritative sources and a multi-agent verification system.
