For enhancing the knowledge graph, two completion methods are introduced: random sampling completion to address initial sparsity, and multi-hop path-based completion to uncover deeper, latent relationships. Furthermore, to integrate knowledge across diverse domains, novel semantics-based and structure-based linking technologies are developed, enabling the establishment of connections between knowledge graphs from different fields. To rigorously evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed methods, a specialized multi-task dialogue test dataset was constructed, comprising Entity Attribute Question Answering, Multi-hop Question Answering, and Cross-domain Question Answering. Experimental results, utilizing Qwen2.5-7B and Qwen2.5-72B models, demonstrate significant performance improvements across all tasks, particularly for smaller models, showcasing the framework’s ability to enhance LLM accuracy, reduce hallucinations, and improve reasoning capabilities in knowledge-intensive dialogue.

title: Feature Reconstruction-based Fine-grained Access Control for Audio
authors: Xu Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: The growing demand for multiparty voice communication and data sharing exposes the limitations of traditional holistic encryption schemes, which often require maintaining multiple encrypted versions in multi-privileged environments, leading to excessive storage and management costs. To address this issue, we present a fine-grained voice access control architecture that integrates large language model-driven detection with feature-level encryption. The proposed design consists of three layers: a detection layer that leverages large models to capture both explicit and implicit sensitive information for dynamic privilege management; an encoding layer that transforms speech into a high-dimensional feature space to enable fine-grained control; and a reconstruction layer that employs an enhanced generative adversarial network to produce speech reconstructions aligned with user privileges. In contrast to conventional methods, our approach applies a single feature-level encryption, thereby reducing storage and transmission overhead while maintaining flexibility and efficiency. Experimental results demonstrate robust sensitive content detection, high-fidelity speech reconstruction, and an effective balance between privacy protection and usability, offering novel insights into secure and adaptive voice access control.

title: Study of the Dynamics of Resonant Converter with Variable Output Current Polarity for Degaussing Systems
authors: Gennadiy Pavlov, Andrii Obrubov, Irina Vinnichenko, Yuri Korol
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The paper investigates the dynamic characteristics of a series-resonant converter with a cycloconverter and LR- or LRC-load, intended for a ship degaussing system, with small changes in the input value, within which the converter can be approximately considered a linear dynamic link. A simulation model of the converter is created, the equivalent transfer function is determined, the parameters of which are optimized using experimental transient characteristics. The dependences of the parameters of the equivalent transfer function of the converter on the input control value are determined.

title: Trustworthy Summarization via Uncertainty Quantification and Risk Awareness in Large Language Models
authors: Shuaidong Pan, Di Wu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: This study addresses the reliability of automatic summarization in high-risk scenarios and proposes a large language model framework that integrates uncertainty quantification and risk-aware mechanisms. Starting from the demands of information overload and high-risk decision-making, a conditional generation-based summarization model is constructed, and Bayesian inference is introduced during generation to model uncertainty in the parameter space, which helps avoid overconfident predictions. The uncertainty level of the generated content is measured using predictive distribution entropy, and a joint optimization of entropy regularization and risk-aware loss is applied to ensure that key information is preserved and risk attributes are explicitly expressed during information compression. On this basis, the model incorporates risk scoring and regulation modules, allowing summaries to cover the core content accurately while enhancing trustworthiness through explicit risk-level prompts. Comparative experiments and sensitivity analyses verify that the proposed method significantly improves the robustness and reliability of summarization in high-risk applications while maintaining fluency and semantic integrity. This research provides a systematic solution for trustworthy summarization and demonstrates both scalability and practical value at the methodological level.

title: Expected energy recognition of Tandem accelerator operation data based on newly constructed features
authors: Yin Tong, Kangning Li, Chaoxin Kan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Establish a new data analysis method for tandem accelerator operation data, innovatively constructing a feature extraction matrix for the operational data while particle accelerating, forming a training dataset through matrix dimensionality reduction, constructing new features for particle running datasets using the KNN model, based on the particle running dataset which be constructed, train a CART decision tree classification model to complete the analysis of expected particle energy labels for real-time operation data parameter combinations of the tandem accelerator, assist in making daily operational task decisions for the tandem accelerator.

title: Performance Study of the Farneback Algorithm for Optical Flow Tracking in Video and Images
authors: Olesia Barkovska, Tetiana Filimonchuk, Dmytro Nikolaienko
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: This paper presents a performance study of the Farneback algorithm for optical flow tracking in video and images. With the growing need for efficient video processing technologies, optical flow analysis plays a critical role in fields such as sports, medicine, gaming, and smart home systems. The study compares the performance of the Farneback algorithm on different computing architectures, specifically focusing on a CPU (AMD Ryzen 9 4900H) and a GPU (nVidia GeForce GTX 1660 Ti). The results demonstrate that GPU-based parallel computing significantly enhances the speed and efficiency of the algorithm, achieving speed improvements of up to 8.791 times compared to CPU processing, particularly in real-time applications with varying video complexities. For example, videos processed with a static camera and a small number of moving objects showed a frame rate increase from 0.953 frames per second on CPU to 7.431 frames per second on GPU. The study provides insights into the practical implications of using GPUs for optical flow analysis, emphasizing their superiority in processing high-complexity video data compared to traditional CPU-based systems. These findings are crucial for developing more responsive and energy-efficient systems in real-world applications. Future research will explore broader hardware configurations and further optimization of optical flow algorithms to enhance their applicability in diverse scenarios.

title: Graph Convolution Combined with Image Pixel Information Networks for Multi-Scale Action Recognition
authors: Wenlong Huang, Jianguo Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Action recognition in videos remains a formidable challenge due to the intricacies of modeling multi-scale spatial and temporal dynamics. This study introduces a novel dual-path network architecture, termed Graph Convolution Combined with Image Pixel Information Networks (GCCIN), which synergistically integrates pixel-level image features and graph-based structural representations to achieve robust multi-scale action recognition. This approach provides a new paradigm for combining graph convolutional networks with pixel-based feature extraction. The proposed framework processes video frames through two complementary pathways, a convolutional pathway that employs ResNet18 to extract pixel-level features from a randomly sampled subset of grouped video frames, thereby reducing computational complexity while enhancing model robustness. A graph-based pathway that leverages Spatio-Temporal Graph Convolutional Networks (ST-GCN) to model spatio-temporal relationships, incorporating a novel joint partitioning strategy to handle multi-scale joint inputs. The features extracted from both pathways are fused to perform action classification. To further improve accuracy, an enhanced variant, GCCIN-A, transforms the graph neural network outputs of ST-GCN into an attention mechanism, which is applied to the convolutional pathway to augment its comprehension of spatio-temporal regions. This method capitalizes on the efficient computation of adjacency matrices in joint processing and transfers this advantage to the convolutional pathway, enabling it to capture spatio-temporal attributes and achieve feature alignment during fusion. Extensive evaluations of benchmark datasets demonstrate that GCCIN-A achieves top-1 accuracy of 80. 27%, 96. 31%, 87. 62%, and 65. 95% on the test sets of HMDB51, UCF101, Sports-1M, and Something-Something v2, respectively, surpassing state-of-the-art methods.

title: A Lightweight Two-Stage Refinement Framework for Small Object Detection in UAV Images
authors: Yuhang Gao, Hanasi Guo, Alexander Nedzved
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Small object detection remains a major challenge in computer vision, especially in UAV-based scenarios where targets are often tiny, blurred, and surrounded by clutter. In this paper, we propose a lightweight two-stage refinement framework built upon YOLOv8n to improve its performance on small objects. First, we introduce a P2 detection head with bilinear upsampling to enhance shallow features and increase the recall of tiny targets. Second, we design a Refine Head that adjusts classification scores and bounding-box regression of the first-stage proposals, improving precision and localization stability. Experiments on the VisDrone2019 dataset show that our method achieves comparable overall mAP to the YOLOv8n baseline while providing higher recall on small objects and more reliable detection results. These findings suggest that even lightweight detectors can achieve competitive performance on small-object detection with carefully designed architectural refinements. Looking ahead, we plan to extend this framework with transformer-based refinement and embedded deployment for real-time UAV applications.

title: Design of Fine-Grained Sentiment Analysis Model for Taobao Commodity Reviews
authors: Xiehua Yu, Joey Aviles
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Artificial Intelligence and Digital Management (ICAIDM)
abstract: With the rapid development of e-commerce, users increasingly rely on review information to assist in decision-making during the shopping process, and thus the sentiment analysis of review texts has significant value. This paper selects Taobao product reviews as the research object and proposes a new analysis method for problems such as the refinement of emotional dimensions, the complexity of semantics and the imbalance of categories in the reviews. The research involves cleaning and enhancing comments in the data processing stage and integrating deep learning techniques and attention mechanisms in model design to better capture users' attitudes towards different product attributes. The experimental results show that this method outperforms the traditional methods in terms of accuracy, recall rate and F1 value, especially in the recognition of neutral and negative comments, and has good stability and generalization ability.

title: CBAM-Enhanced Tri-Scale Synergistic Fusion for Tomato Disease Identification
authors: Wenxue Sun, Wenbo Zhang, Siqi Luo, Na Yu, Mengfei Wu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Tomato disease identification is critical for precision agriculture, yet existing deep learning approaches struggle with background noise interference and inadequate integration of fine-grained lesion details with global disease patterns. To address these limitations, we propose a CBAM-enhanced Tri-Scale Fusion framework(CTSF) based on ResNet50. It integrates the Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) to suppress background noise and sharpen lesion focus, and introduces a Tri-Scale Synergistic Feature Fusion (TSFF) module that captures fine local details and global context across network layers. Experiments were conducted on a tomato disease subset of the public plant village dataset after image screening and data augmentation. Experimental results demonstrate that CTSF achieves an accuracy of 98.62% on the test set, indicating a 2.2 percentage point improvement over the original ResNet50. Ablation studies fully validate the effectiveness of both the CBAM and TSFF modules. Based on these empirical experiments, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach to tomato disease identification.

title: Data-Driven Urban Traffic Injury Profiling Using Machine Learning and Spatiotemporal Analytics in Muntinlupa City, Philippines
authors: Mc Joben R. Reyes, Cristoper N. Rabino
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Road traffic injuries remain a critical concern in low- and middle-income countries, where data-driven approaches to urban mobility safety are often underutilized. This study applies the Cross-Industry Standard Process for Data Mining to analyze a three-year incident-level dataset (2021–2023) from Muntinlupa City, Philippines, integrating spatiotemporal analytics, supervised machine learning, and association rule mining. Injury incidents clustered in high-traffic barangays—Alabang, Putatan, and Tunasan—and during weekday morning rush hours, with motorcycles consistently emerging as the most injury-prone vehicle type. Among the classifiers evaluated, Naïve Bayes achieved the most robust performance, with 96.74% accuracy and no false negatives, although some models exhibited perfect scores that may reflect overfitting or data leakage, warranting caution in interpretation. Association rule mining identified frequent vehicle co-occurrence, particularly between motorcycles and private cars, though low lift values suggest weak statistical dependence—indicating that their joint presence in crashes may result from shared exposure in congested traffic rather than direct interaction effects. Cross-validation was performed with care to avoid data leakage, maintaining temporal consistency and excluding post-incident variables from training features. These insights support barangay-level interventions such as motorcycle-exclusive lanes, helmet enforcement, and speed regulation. The study contributes a reproducible, open-source framework for city-level traffic injury profiling and aligns with Sustainable Development Goal 11 by promoting data-informed, inclusive urban transport policies.

title: ARSAGON: An Integrated Approach Combining Symmetric, Asymmetric, and Hashing Algorithms for Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
authors: Mursalim, Yulaikha Maratullatifah, Nevin Shera Adji
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: The implementation of the single-model method often fails and is even inadequate in countering various cyber threats. This study proposes an approach using the ARSAGON method for both at-rest and in-transit scenarios. This method integrates the Argon2 hashing algorithm for at-rest security and implements the standard TLS/HTTPS protocol as an in-transit protocol, equipped with RSA and AES encryption for security. Experimental results show that this method has an average computational cost of 278.03 ms for hashing, which significantly slows down attacks. In a brute-force evaluation of 10,000 trials, the method achieved a total time of 374.76 seconds, which is still a solid defense. In the latency test of the system login process, the method achieved a total login time of 186.49 ms, which is acceptable for users during the system login process. Although the ARSAGON method does not generally outperform other methods, it remains a solid approach for practical security. The code is available at:

title: CA-HRNet: A Novel Approach for Yak Image Segmentation in Complex Environments
authors: Wang Zhang, Jiayi Xing, Shilei Xing, Haozhuo Cao, Yuting Qi, Boyang Sun, Qiangqiang Yao
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: Semantic segmentation of yaks in high-altitude environments faces challenges including morphological diversity, complex coat textures, and environmental variations. This research introduces the Progressive Coordinate Attention Embedding Strategy (PCAES), strategically integrating Coordinate Attention mechanisms within HRNet at critical transitional nodes. Three key innovations are presented: (1) Position-specific embedding theory for optimal CA integration through systematic feature learning analysis; (2) Dual spatial enhancement framework with pre-preservation before downsampling and reconstruction optimization before upsampling; (3) Computational-performance balance achieving superior accuracy while maintaining deployment efficiency. The method addresses yak-specific challenges through targeted spatial-channel modeling for morphological variations, directional encoding for coat pattern recognition, and environmental robustness enhancement. Evaluation on a plateau yak dataset demonstrates CA-HRNet achieves 81.65% MIoU with significant improvements in boundary precision. Comparative visualization reveals substantial improvements in texture delineation and background discrimination compared to baseline methods. The framework enables efficient deployment for remote high-altitude livestock monitoring applications.

title: Adaptive Firepower Allocation Intelligent Optimization Algorithm for Dynamic Battlefield Environments
authors: Jian Lin
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: The dynamic and complex nature of modern warfare imposes extremely high requirements on the allocation of firepower. This paper, in response to the dynamic battlefield environment, constructs an accurate environmental model and integrates the particle swarm optimization algorithm and the deep Q-network to design an adaptive intelligent optimization algorithm for firepower allocation. Through simulation experiments, in complex scenarios, the average allocation time of this algorithm is shortened to less than 2 seconds, which is approximately 70% less than the traditional greedy algorithm; the target destruction rate is increased to over 85%, which is approximately 20% higher than the unimproved particle swarm algorithm; the weapon utilization rate reaches 90%, significantly outperforming the comparison algorithm. The results show that the proposed algorithm has significant advantages in terms of allocation efficiency, combat effectiveness, and resource utilization efficiency, and can effectively adapt to the dynamic battlefield environment, providing strong support for combat command.

title: Image Edge Detection and Contour Extraction Using FPGA
authors: Guanlin Li, Chengxi Xia, Tianze Yang, Mingze Gong, Li Chai, Houkun Xv, Shiya Yao, Lee Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: To address the limitations of traditional image edge detection systems-such as slow processing speed and inaccurate edge detail extraction-this paper presents a system for image edge detection and contour extraction based on FPGA. The system employs an EG4S20 FPGA as the control core, an OV5640 camera for image acquisition, and SDRAM for data buffering, enabling real-time processing results to be displayed on a monitor. In terms of algorithm design, an improved edge detection method is proposed. The process begins with image preprocessing through boundary point filling and fast median filtering. Next, gradient calculation is performed via multi-directional convolution, followed by edge thinning using non-maximum suppression. Finally, edge determination is achieved using an adaptive thresholding method based on histogram statistics. This approach effectively mitigates the instability in detection performance caused by fixed thresholds in conventional Sobel algorithms.

title: Assessment of the Influence of Geomagnetic Disturbances (Kp index) on the Parameters of Remote Calibration of GNSS Receivers
authors: Vladimir M. Pukhov, Dmitry S. Pecheritsa, Vyacheslav D. Lebedev
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Space weather is widely recognized as a critical factor influencing many aspects of modern human activity, particularly in the fields of communication, navigation, and power supply systems. Its impact is primarily associated with solar events, including coronal mass ejections, variations of the solar wind, and solar radio bursts. These phenomena can induce geomagnetic disturbances, typically quantified by the global Kp-index. One of the most important consequences of disturbances is the occurrence of ionospheric scintillations and geomagnetically induced currents. Both of these effects can significantly degrade the performance of technological systems, with satellite-based navigation being especially vulnerable. This paper presents the results of remote calibration of navigation equipment carried out by the differential method during different time intervals and under varying levels of geomagnetic activity. A comparative analysis of calibration outcomes based on pseudorange measurements is provided. The results clearly demonstrate that the accuracy and stability of remote calibration of GNSS-based navigation equipment are highly sensitive to geomagnetic conditions, highlighting the necessity of considering space weather effects in practical applications.

title: Mathematical Model of the Process of Gas Displacement in Multilayer Systems
authors: Normakhmad Ravshanov, Shikhnazar Ismailov, Mohiniso Mahmudova
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: A mathematical framework is proposed for studying the process of gas displacement in multilayer systems within a gas reservoir, and a model problem is solved. In the considered problem, the boundaries of the section are unknown, and the boundary conditions are rather general; therefore, it is not possible to directly apply all the previously published methods discussed in the article. Since it is impossible to simultaneously capture both boundaries at a network node, the coefficient-smoothing method is applied. Numerical simulations have shown that the most efficient gas extraction occurs when the initial boundaries of the section are equidistant from the production well. A computational experiment has also demonstrated that, with increasing flow rate, the influence of differences in layer permeability becomes more pronounced. Furthermore, when the boundaries of the section are equidistant from the production well, the residual gas content after water breakthrough is higher compared to cases with unequal initial interface positions.

title: CRISP: Constrained Risk-aware Integration of Supervision & Policy Learning
authors: Hao Gong
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: We present CRISP, a single-stage alignment framework for mathematical reasoning that optimizes one policy under two complementary signals: an explicit, verifiable reward and an implicit imitation score derived from relative log-likelihood. Rather than heuristic loss mixing, CRISP enforces hard budgets for distributional stability (KL-to-demo) and tail-risk control (CVaR). A lightweight primal–dual controller adapts these budgets online, and a contextual bandit routes mini-batches to RL or SFT to focus interaction where it helps most. In evaluations on MATH500, OlympiadBench, AMC, AIME-2024, Minerva and OOD suites (ARC-C, GPQA-D, MMLU-Pro), CRISP matches or surpasses strong single-stage baselines (e.g., +7.5–8.9 points on ID and +8.1–9.7 on OOD averages), while lowering tail risk (e.g., 7% tail-failure in our default gate) at comparable interaction budgets. This suggests risk-controlled single-stage training is a practical, interpretable alternative to two-stage pipelines for math reasoning.

title: Exploring Indonesian Mothers' Digital Learning Experiences: A Preliminary Research on Technology Use in Self-Directed Learning
authors: Ridha Hidayani, Annisa Dinata, Bunga Claudya
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: Self-Directed Learning is a key competency that provides the necessary foundation for individuals to adapt to changes in social contexts. This study employed a quantitative research design using a structured survey method involving 100 married women. Data was collected using Pop Survey, a self-service online survey platform developed by Populix. The technique of data analysis engaged in this study is descriptive statistical analysis in order to illustrate the survey data which is in the form of frequency distribution or percentage. Based on the result of the research, the most frequently used device by mothers for self-directed learning is smartphones. The results also showed that mothers are at the level of "very often" for the use of technology in self-directed learning. The presence of technology itself is in the level of "highly motivated" for mothers to develop their skills. The study found that technology for education gives positive impacts to strengthen SDL practices and enable women with multiple social roles pursuing their personal and professional growth. Based on these insights, the further research can consider the development of learning programs aimed at enhancing married women self-development.

title: Functional connectivity topology in EEG of Comatose Patients
authors: Maria Camila Espinal, Steven Laureys, Michel van Putten, Jeannette Hofmeijer, Francisco Gómez, Prejaas Kavish Baldewpersad Tewarie
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Post-cardiac arrest coma, is a consequence of post-cardiac arrest anoxic brain injury (PCABI) that significantly impacts patient survival, with neurological prognosis guiding withdrawal of life-sustaining therapy (WLST). Continuous electroencephalography (EEG) facilitates real-time monitoring of brain activity. However, there is no consensus on which EEG-based patterns may link with recovery or deterioration. In this study, we applied Topological Data Analysis (TDA) to analyze EEG-derived functional connectivity (FC) networks, revealing that patients with poor outcomes exhibit higher network density and efficiency. These findings suggest that a network reorganization may be linked to worse prognoses, highlighting the potential of TDA as a complementary approach for brain network characterization in coma assessment.

title: AttentionMamba: A Hybrid Model Combining Mamba and Transformer for Time Series Anomaly Detection
authors: Mengyang Shen, Gang Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Deep learning has been widely applied to anomaly detection, yet unsupervised time series anomaly detection remains challenging due to limited temporal context capture and inefficient modeling of long sequences. Existing Transformer-based methods excel in short-term dependency modeling but suffer from quadratic time complexity, while Mamba, a state space model (SSM), efficiently handles long sequences but has not been applied to anomaly detection. We propose AttentionMamba, a hybrid framework integrating Transformer and Mamba to capture both short- and long-term dependencies. Experiments show it outperforms existing methods in unsupervised time series anomaly detection.

title: Understanding Effects of Scan Mode, Tilt, and Radiation Dose on CT Radiomic Metrics
authors: Neha Yadav, Xiaomeng Lei, Dighvijay Giri, Steven Cen, Joshua Levy, Kristin Jensen, David Goodenough, Bino Varghese
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Radiomic features derived from CT images can be significantly influenced by varying acquisition settings, posing a challenge to disease phenotype analysis in multicenter studies due to potential confounding effects. This study aimed to systematically evaluate how changes in CT acquisition parameters, including scan mode, tilt, and radiation dose, affect radiomic metrics.A phantom containing 3D-printed textures was scanned on a GE Revolution Apex CT scanner. 12 distinct imaging parameter combinations were explored by varying scan mode (axial vs. helical), image tilt (0 vs. 5 degrees), and dose, with each acquisition repeated once. Volumes of Interest (VOIs) encompassing the texture inserts were manually segmented. From these VOIs, 93 radiomic features, categorized into six subgroups of texture methods, were extracted using Pyradiomics, with a specific focus on first-order features for this analysis.Our findings indicate that helical scanning, when the image tilt was 0 degrees, resulted in lower first-order dispersion metrics compared to axial scanning. The introduction of a 5-degree tilt was associated with reduced first-order dispersion metrics in axial scanning compared to the non-tilt scenario. However, introducing tilt to helical scanning complicated the effect of scan mode; unlike the non-tilt scenario, axial scans with tilt did not consistently exhibit higher first-order dispersion metrics than helical scans with tilt.Understanding the influence of imaging parameter variations—particularly less-explored ones such as tilt—on radiomic metrics is crucial. This knowledge empowers clinicians and researchers to select metrics that are robust and largely unaffected by these variations. In clinical practice, this robust selection is essential for accurately distinguishing true disease diagnoses from false positives that may arise due to differences in image acquisition parameters across studies or centers.

title: A Comparative Analysis of Machine Learning Algorithms for Spam Email Classification with Explainable AI Insights
authors: Md Saimul Hoque Sawon, Shuvo Chakraborty, Riadul Islam Rabbi, Tze Hui Liew, Ummay Ayman Tushe, Ekramul Haque Tusher
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on New Media Studies (CONMEDIA)
abstract: Spam emails, or emails that you didn’t ask for, are a big problem for digital communication systems because they fill up inboxes, waste time, and put users at risk for phishing and viruses. To keep communication safe and productive, especially for people and businesses that rely heavily on email, spam must be found and filtered quickly. Taking care of this problem can boost productivity, keep private information safe, and make it easier to filter emails by hand.This paper performs a comparative analysis of six machine learning methods for spam email detection: Support Vector Machine (SVM), Random Forest (RF), Naive Bayes (NB), Decision Tree (DT), Logistic Regression (LR), and K-Nearest Neighbors (K-NN). We utilize a dataset of 20,000 tagged emails from Kaggle, with 80% of them for training and 20% for testing. We compare how well the models work by looking at their accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.The Support Vector Machine (SVM) model did better than the others, with an accuracy of 97.18%, a precision of 95.87%, a recall of 98.26%, and an F1-score of 97.05%. To make it easier to understand, Explainable AI (XAI) methods like SHAP values and LIME were used. These methods showed that the existence of particular terms and phrases that are often linked to spam was very important in making classification decisions. This made the model’s predictions more clear.The results show that SVM is better at spotting spam and that using XAI approaches can help make models that are more dependable and easier to understand for real-world use.

title: Analysis and Segmentation of Hip Cartilage in MR Arthrography
authors: Elina Huerfano, Manuel Huerfano, Miguel Barreto
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: The quality of hip cartilage is crucial in treating deformities such as femoroacetabular impingement (FAI), which can progress to osteoarthritis if left untreated. This study outlines a workflow for analyzing articular cartilage in 3T hip MR arthrography. The process includes image preprocessing with an anisotropic diffusion filter, segmentation using region-growing methods with manual seed selection, and region-of-interest (ROI) extraction. From a database of preoperative images of 136 patients with FAI, 15 cases were selected. The mean cartilage volume segmented using ITK was 2114.8 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>, compared to 2135.3 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> from manual segmentation (p = 0.9032). The intraclass correlation coefficient (ICC) was 0.86 for cartilage volume and 0.99 for total voxel count, and the mean Dice coefficient was 0.905 ± 0.066. These results suggest a strong agreement between the proposed workflow and manual segmentation. Limitations and potential improvements are discussed to enhance segmentation accuracy.

title: A Comparative Analysis of the Technologies for Moving Element Formation in a Resonant Pressure Sensor
authors: Alena Talovskaia, Ivan Kulinich, Evgenij Barbin, Denis Mokhovikov, Sergey Vtorushin, Andrei Esipov
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The article presents methods for fabricating composite resonators for resonant-frequency pressure sensors using surface and bulk microfabrication technologies. The study analyzes technological challenges related to the uniformity and removal of the sacrificial layer and discusses possible solutions. Classical and anchor-type movable element configurations, the application of chemical-mechanical and mechanical polishing, and a combined metallization process employing a copper sacrificial layer are examined. The chemical-mechanical polishing (CMP) approach provides superior surface planarity and stable geometric parameters of the resonator but requires costly equipment. The copper-based sacrificial-layer technology significantly reduces production cost and can be integrated into standard microelectronic fabrication cycles, although it exhibits lower planarity in bridge regions and demands higher alignment precision and etching control. A comparative evaluation of both fabrication routes demonstrates their applicability for next-generation MEMS pressure sensors, where the choice of process strongly depends on the required trade-off between geometric accuracy, fabrication complexity, and long-term reliability. The obtained results define optimal conditions for forming composite resonators considering the balance among, process reproducibility, and overall manufacturing efficiency.

title: Meeting Corona Free And Partial Discharge Free Requirements As Per Ieee And Csa Standards For Medium Voltage Switchgears
authors: Aniket Shirode, Gary Haynes, Amar Kini, Harsh Karandikar
publish: 2025 IEEE IAS Petroleum and Chemical Industry Technical Conference (PCIC)
abstract: Ensuring the reliability and longevity of electrical insulation systems in medium-voltage (MV) equipment is critical for the petroleum and chemical industries, where equipment downtime can cause significant operational and financial losses. One of the primary factors affecting the performance of such insulation systems is partial discharge (PD), a phenomenon that can lead to insulation degradation and, ultimately, failure. Furthermore, corona discharge, a form of electrical discharge brought on by ionization of the surrounding air, also poses significant risks to the safety and reliability of MV systems. This paper explores the critical requirements for corona-free and partial discharge-free performance in medium voltage switchgear, as specified by IEEE C37.20.2 (Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers) and CSA 22.2 No. 31:23 (Canadian Standards Association) standards. It provides a comprehensive analysis of the technical guidelines and testing protocols outlined in these standards, focusing on the criteria for PD inception voltage, permissible PD levels, and the conditions for declaring equipment as corona-free. By providing insight into the standards and best practices for controlling partial discharge and corona phenomena, this paper aims to assist engineers and industry professionals in enhancing the reliability and safety of MV switchgear within their facilities.

title: PET Brain Imaging Motion Correction Using External Camera
authors: J. Fisher, M.N. Ullah, C. S. Levin
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This work presents the most recent experimental demonstration of our fully autonomous, end-toend camera-based motion correction (MoCo) solution, designed to improve PET image quality in the presence of head motion. The system was evaluated using a patient head phantom scanned with our second-generation MR-compatible PETcoil insert.

title: Research on Joint Optimization of Static Charging Point Layout and Path for Urban Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) in PAD under Remote Sensing Image Feature Extraction Task Points
authors: Wentao Zhang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: This paper addresses the joint optimization problem of static charging point layout and path planning for urban UAVs tasked with remote sensing image feature extraction. A mixed integer linear programming (MILP) model is proposed to minimize total operational costs while satisfying UAV energy constraints and task requirements. The model integrates charging infrastructure deployment, UAV trajectory design, and task allocation. Simulation results based on real-world urban datasets demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach, achieving a 9.1% reduction in energy consumption compared to conventional heuristics.

title: Research on the Application of Computer Vision Technology in Smart Archives
authors: Xiangling Ma, Xiangyang Ma, Weichen Zhao, Anxing Zhao
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: Computer vision technology has made groundbreaking advancements across multiple domains in the development of smart archives. Its core technical repertoire encompasses mechanisms for image acquisition and preprocessing, algorithms for feature extraction and pattern recognition. The system architecture is composed of a two-tier edge-cloud visual perception network, a multimodal data fusion framework, an intelligent application support platform, and core algorithms. The automated management of smart archives adheres to a "perception-parsing-decision-making" closed-loop workflow. Taking the warehouse visual tracking system as a case study for scenario analysis in smart archives, it integrates a data preprocessing module, a model construction and training framework, a core algorithm library, visualization and evaluation tools, and an API interface layer. This system enables real-time tracking of the dynamic positions of archives, thereby providing pivotal technical support for the efficient circulation and security supervision of smart archives.

title: Computational Algorithm for Alculating a Formal Quality Criterion for Stratigraphic Correlation of Wells
authors: Lapkovsky Vladimir Valentinovich, Ilyinykh Sergey Petrovich, Sheludko Vasilisa Ivanovna
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Stratigraphic correlation of wells, performed based on geophysical research data (GRD), is a cornerstone in the process of building reliable structural models of hydrocarbon deposits. Its main task is to accurately match homogeneous geological layers exposed by different wells, which allows for the restoration of their spatial position and formation history. The correlation procedure is based on the analysis of geophysical method curves, such as resistivity logging, gamma logging, acoustic and neutron logging. These data serve as a kind of "passport" for the section of each well, reflecting the lithological and physical properties of the rocks. Geologists identify reference horizons – stable, well-expressed layers on GPR curves (for example, clay or carbonate), which can be traced over a large area. By comparing these reference points between wells, specialists "stitch" disparate sections into a single stratigraphic scheme. Thus, stratigraphic correlation serves as a fundamental link between primary drilling data and comprehensive interpretation. It transforms point information from wells into a holistic geological picture, which is critically important for assessing reserves, optimizing the location of new wells, and planning field development.

title: Development of a p-HEMT Frequency Multiplier Working in Positive Conditions
authors: Dan Hu, Li Li, Ruheng Cai, Qi Fu
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Computer Science and Network Technology (ICCSNT)
abstract: This paper presents an active frequency multiplier based on GaAs p-HEMT technology, capable of operating solely with a positive power supply. By adopting source RC biasing and a gate high-pass structure, the multiplier eliminates the need for negative bias voltage. Based on this approach, a monolithic microwave integrated circuit (MMIC) frequency multiplier chip was fabricated with an input frequency range of 3 GHz to 4 GHz. On-wafer measurements using a probe station demonstrate fundamental harmonic suppression better than 19 dBc, third harmonic suppression better than 28 dBc, and conversion loss better than -13 dB across the operating bandwidth.

title: Evaluation of Accuracy and Performance of Neural Network and Machine Learning Models for Flood Damage Prediction
authors: Kuan Madiyarov, Andrey Pestunov
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Flood damage prediction is essential for planning mitigation strategies and allocating resources. This study compares four regression models. The models considered in this study include Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, XGBoost, and a feedforward neural network – for predicting flood damage (in thousand USD) using a historical disaster dataset (1900–2025) based on EM-DAT records. We evaluate each model’s accuracy and performance (training time and memory usage). The dataset includes multifaceted features (hazard intensity, socio-economic indicators, etc.), and all models are trained and tested under a consistent pipeline with standardized preprocessing (including numeric feature scaling and one-hot encoding of categorical variables). Model quality is reported using the canonical regression criteria—Mean Absolute Error, Root Mean Squared Error, and the coefficient of determination. Across experiments, tree-ensemble approaches, with gradient boosting in particular, delivered the strongest predictive accuracy, whereas the feedforward neural network was less competitive on this tabular dataset. Gradient Boosting slightly outperforms Random Forest in coefficient of determination (0.74 vs 0.73) with the lowest RMSE, and also trains an order of magnitude faster than the neural network. The XGBoost model also exhibits strong performance, comparable to Random Forest. We discuss the implications of these findings in the context of existing literature and outline how model choice can impact flood risk assessment.

title: Simulation Analysis of an Intelligent Operations and Monitoring Data Indicator Warning and Diagnosis System Based on a Large Language Model-Enhanced Transformer
authors: Pan Hui, Pang Peng, Deng Churan, Zhao Shuang, Ma Guanxiong, Luo Xuan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: With the widespread application of cloud computing and modern microservice architectures, the data from intelligent operations and maintenance (AIOps) for information technology systems exhibit complex characteristics such as high dimensionality, massive volume, and dynamic correlations. Traditional warning methods based on static thresholds or simple statistical models are insufficient for the early detection of subtle anomalies and the precise diagnosis of complex faults. To address this challenge, this paper proposes an intelligent operation and monitoring data warning and diagnosis framework based on a Large Language Model enhanced Transformer (LLM-Enhanced Anomaly Transformer, LEAT). This framework adopts a twostage structure: In the first stage, the cutting-edge Anomaly Transformer model is utilized to perform efficient unsupervised anomaly detection by leveraging its innovative “Association Discrepancy” metric to capture early deviations in system operation patterns. In the second stage, for the detected anomalous data segments, carefully designed Prompt Engineering techniques are used to encapsulate their contextual information and numerical dynamics, and a Large Language Model (LLM) is invoked for Zero-Shot inference to achieve interpretable Root Cause Analysis. To validate the effectiveness of the proposed framework, comprehensive simulation experiments were conducted on the public large-scale Server Machine Dataset (SMD). The results show that the LEAT framework achieves an F1-score of 0.930 in anomaly detection, which is on par with the current state-of-the-art. In the more critical task of root cause diagnosis, its Top-1 diagnosis accuracy (Precision@1) reaches 0.891, significantly outperforming baseline methods. This research confirms the great potential of the LEAT framework in enhancing the automation and intelligence of intelligent operations and monitoring.

title: Design of Product Category Management Algorithm Driven by Computer Vision
authors: Qinghui Ran
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: The management of product categories on e-commerce platforms faces difficulties in multimodal data fusion and poor adaptability to dynamic categories. It is therefore evident that the purpose of the present article is to propose a computer vision-based algorithm for the management of product categories. The construction of a multimodal feature encoder is achieved by enhancing ResNet-50 and bidirectional LSTM, with a contrastive learning framework being utilised to optimise the feature space. Simultaneously, the iCaRL memory replay mechanism and the ADWIN algorithm are introduced with the objective of achieving online model learning and concept drift detection, respectively. Consequently, a dynamic category tree is constructed in order to adapt to the iterative requirements of commercial products. Utilising e-commerce product data as experimental samples, the proposed model demonstrates superiority over traditional benchmark models in terms of both classification accuracy and real-time performance. It has been demonstrated that the system is capable of adapting effectively to the core requirements of product category management in e-commerce business scenarios, and providing technical support for multi-modal data-driven category optimisation.

title: Dynamic Role Learning in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning: Hypernetwork-Based Agent Net with Contrastive Learning Representations
authors: Yirui Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: In nature, advanced organisms often complete complex tasks collaboratively through rigorous role division. In recent years, roles have been widely applied in multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) to enhance the behavioral diversity of agents. However, most existing role-based MARL methods require predefining the number of roles, which not only demands extensive prior knowledge but also leads to suboptimal performance. To address these limitations, we propose a novel Dynamic Role Learning in Multi-Agent Reinforcement Learning (DRoL) approach. Specifically, we take learnable role representations as inputs to the hyper agent network and adopt contrastive learning to adaptively learn the role representations of different agents, thereby achieving adaptive role learning. Experiments conducted on the hard and super hard scenarios of StarCraft II micromanagement tasks demonstrate that DRoL can reach the state-of-the-art performance level.

title: Optimizing BiLSTM with Particle Swarm Optimization and Context-Aware Features for Movie Review Sentiment Classification
authors: Yudha Rizqia Grafer, Guruh Fajar Shidik, Bambang Putra Amsal Gautama, Filipus Arif Kristiyan, Chandra Lukita Buana, Edi Jaya Kusuma
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: This study presents a hybrid model for sentiment analysis by integrating ALBERT for feature extraction, BiLSTM for sequential classification, and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) for hyperparameter tuning. Unlike conventional methods such as TF-IDF and Bag-of-Words, ALBERT generates contextualized word embeddings that capture deeper semantic relationships within text. Through bidirectional processing, BiLSTM allows the model to incorporate both preceding and succeeding contextual cues, leading to enhanced comprehension of sequential data. To further optimize performance, PSO is utilized to efficiently search for the best hyperparameter configurations. Based on experimental evaluations, the model initially reached 84% accuracy, which was further enhanced to 87% through PSO-based hyperparameter optimization. These results underscore the capability of the hybrid approach to enhance sentiment classification performance and indicate its strong potential for advancing future natural language processing applications.

title: Wi-Echo: Lightweight Human Activity Recognition in Non-line-of-sight Environments
authors: Yuanhang Hu, Jiacheng Li, Chenlu Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: In recent years, with the advancement of wireless technology, Human activity recognition (HAR) has been widely studied by utilizing the WiFi channel state information (CSI). In non-line-of-sight (NLOS) scenarios, the enhanced multi-path effect leads to more complex channel noise compared to line-of-sight(LOS) conditions. Existing methods often suffer from complex architectures, redundant parameters, and reliance on filtering or other preprocessing operations. To address these issues, this paper proposes a lightweight HAR network, Wi-Echo, which integrates residual shrinkage and depthwise separable convolution modules to suppress noise without explicit denoising, and introduces the bidirectional temporal convolutional network (BiTCN) for efficient temporal feature modeling to achieve accurate activity recognition. Experimental results show that Wi-Echo achieves recognition accuracies of 99.05% and 99.04% in through-wall and around-the-corner scenarios, respectively, demonstrating robust performance.

title: Research on Facial Recognition Based on Gaussian Kernel Principal Component Analysis and ASMS
authors: Zihong Chen, Junhua Wu, Liangyan Wang, Ming Wei
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Principal Component Analysis (PCA) is a classic linear dimensionality reduction method that has been widely used in data processing, but is limited by linearity in high-dimensional and complex data. Gaussian Kernel PCA is its nonlinear extension, which extracts nonlinear features by mapping data to high-dimensional space through kernel functions. This study reviewed the theories of PCA and Gaussian Kernel PCA, with a focus on pre image reconstruction using Gaussian Kernel PCA, and analyzed the role of PCA in active shape models (ASMS). A Gaussian Kernel PCA based ASMS optimization method was proposed, and a Gaussian Kernel PCA-ASMS face model was constructed. The results indicate that the improved method enhances the accuracy and reliability of facial expression recognition, providing applications for human-computer interaction and emotion computing.

title: Comprehensive Integrated Protection Efficiency-Cost Optimization Model for Protective Engineering Based on Particle Swarm Optimization Algorithm
authors: Chengxiang Tian, Xinyan Liu, Minghao Geng, Yihong Ding
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: When Carrying Out Comprehensive Integrated Protection Work for National Defense Engineering. How to efficiently allocate limited resources to the construction of various modules in comprehensive integrated protection, and build a protection system with optimal benefits at the minimum cost, is a key indicator for measuring the effectiveness of the comprehensive integrated protection system. This study aims to achieve the most reasonable allocation of protective resources. It constructs a combined optimization model for the comprehensive integrated protection effectiveness and cost of national defense engineering based on the Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) algorithm. Furthermore, through MATLAB simulation and empirical analysis, the feasibility and effectiveness of the efficiency-cost optimization model are verified, providing a reference basis for the rational allocation of protective resources in the comprehensive integrated protection of national defense engineering.

title: BMGANet: Implementation of a Multi-Granularity Attention Network for Vulnerability Detection
authors: Xiangshan Qu, Erzhou Zhu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Deep learning has become a prominent approach for automated code vulnerability detection. However, state-of-the-art models often struggle with complex vulnerabilities due to their inability to simultaneously capture both fine-grained token-level semantics and function-level structural features. To address this limitation, we propose BMGANet, a novel deep learning model that integrates multi-granularity features for effective vulnerability detection. Our framework begins by using Joern to construct Program Dependence Graphs (PDGs) and Abstract Syntax Trees (ASTs), followed by cross-function slicing and code normalization. A BERT-based network then extracts token-level and function-level features, which are further refined by an LSTM and a multi-head attention mechanism to model complex code contexts. These enhanced features are subsequently fused for final prediction. Furthermore, BMGANet is pre-trained on two auxiliary tasks—masked token prediction and inter-code-line logical correlation prediction—to improve its semantic understanding of code syntax and logic. Evaluated on widely-used benchmarks, BMGANet demonstrates superior performance and significantly outperforms existing methods.

title: Development of Nuclear Emulsion Track Recognition Using Machine Learning
authors: K. Nakano, N. Kitagawa, K. Morishima
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Nuclear emulsions are three-dimensional tracking detectors with sub-micron spatial resolution, consisting of photographic emulsions where <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 200 ~\text{nm}$</tex> silver bromide crystals are dispersed on a transparent substrate. When a charged particle passes through the emulsion, it leaves a latent image that becomes a trail of silver grains-called a “track”-after development. In cosmic-ray imaging, used for non-destructive visualization of large structures, muon tracks are recorded as straight lines. To obtain the angular distribution of incoming muons, it is essential to distinguish signal tracks from noise caused by environmental electrons or isolated grains.

title: Persona Description Augmented for Personalized Dialogue Generation
authors: Peiguo Lin, Yaojie Zhang, Bo Hu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: In conversational AI, role profiles are crucial for personalization, yet directly integrating free-form descriptions into large language models (LLMs) remains challenging. Our analysis of existing datasets reveals that unstructured role descriptions can be systematically mapped to standardized labels, a potential largely overlooked in prior work. To address this, we propose a structured role label extraction and description enhancement framework for personalized dialogue generation. We convert unstructured role descriptions into standardized labels across six dimensions, refine them via a scoring–regeneration mechanism, and expand fragmented descriptions into coherent narratives for clearer persona representation. Fine-tuning LLMs on the augmented dataset yields significant gains in factual correctness, consistency, and personalization, demonstrating the effectiveness of structured and enhanced role modeling in conversational AI.

title: BJT-Based Temperature Sensor With ±0.3°C Inaccuracy From -55°C to +125°C in 0.5-μm CMOS
authors: Jianshu Wang, Jing Zhang, Qi Wei
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: This paper presents a temperature sensor based on the $0.5-\mu \mathrm{m}$ CMOS process with a 5 V supply voltage. Covers a temperature range from $-55^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ to $125^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. It consumes 1.6 mA during normal operation, while the current drops below $1 \mu \mathrm{~A}$ in power-down mode. To suppress low-frequency noise and process mismatch errors, Chopping techniques and Dynamic Element Matching (DEM) are adopted in the sensing front-end. A second-order Σ-Δ ADC with Correlated Double Sampling (CDS) structure is used to digitize the temperature-dependent voltage. Operating at 400 KHz, the circuit achieves a low-frequency noise floor of $115 \mathrm{~dB} / \sqrt{ } \mathrm{Hz}$ in the SDM output spectrum. Across the full sensing range, the temperature resolution is $0.008^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$ with a maximum temperature error of $\pm 0.3^{\circ} \mathrm{C}$. The Σ-Δ modulator operates in incremental mode, each conversion takes 2.56 ms.

title: Nonlinear Optical Properties of the Compositional Material of Single-wall Carbon Nanotubes and Nickel Phthalocyanine with a Cyclotriphosphazene Substituent
authors: Mikhail Savelyev, Pavel Vasilevsky, Ekaterina Otsupko, Alexander Tolbin, Alexander Gerasimenko
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The optical limiting effect was studied for a solution of Ni phthalocyanine with a cyclotriphosphazene fragment, a dispersed medium with single-wall carbon nanotubes, and a suspension of the composite material after mixing them in dimethylformamide. The values of nonlinear absorption and refractive index coefficients, the threshold exposure of laser radiation was obtained from Z-scan data at a power of 550 mW at a wavelength of 1070 nm with pulse repetition rate of 50 kHz and duration of 4 ns using a mathematical model based on the radiation transfer equation. The effect of single-wall carbon nanotubes functionalization with Ni phthalocyanine with a cyclotriphosphazene fragment was analyzed under the same experimental conditions. As a result, an increase in the optical limiting for the composite material was shown compared to its original components. A three-fold increase in the nonlinear absorption coefficient and a two-fold increase in the nonlinear refractive index were obtained at a threshold exposure of laser radiation comparable to that of the original Ni phthalocyanine. This composite material is suitable for use in optical limiters to reduce transmission at high intensity or fluence and reduces potential hazard to the eyes and various optical sensors such as chargecoupled device, complementary metal-oxide semiconductor and other light-sensitive detection systems.

title: Network-Aware Bidirectional Clock Synchronization for Wireless Power Transfer Systems
authors: Xiangbing Yin, Chuanqun Sun, Yu Yin, Junliang Ye
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Wireless charging system is not only a technological innovation, but also a significant force driving the transformation of social life and industrial development towards higher efficiency, safety, and environmental friendliness. To optimize the wireless charging performance of the system, the receiving devices need to provide real-time feedback on its own status information, including its impedance and energy demand. Compared to out-of-band communication methods, network communication mechanisms can avoid additional hardware costs, energy consumption, and spectrum occupation, making them more suitable for large-scale application scenarios in future intelligent IoT. However, existing research has either overlooked or neglected the issue of clock synchronization of receiving devices prior to in-band parallel communication. This significantly impacts the accuracy of parallel decoding in practical systems. Therefore, this paper proposes a network-aware bidirectional clock synchronization mechanism for wireless charging systems. By seamlessly integrating the identification and clock synchronization processes of receiving devices, it not only simplifies the design of network communication mechanisms but also eliminates the need for separate and time-consuming device clock synchronization steps. Simulation results demonstrate that this mechanism not only achieves efficient clock synchronization of receiving devices but also effectively guarantees the success rate of system communication decoding.

title: Motif-GNN: A Novel Method for Key Node Identification in Complex Networks
authors: Xiuming Zhao, Qinsheng Wang, Pengfei Pan, Wanping Zhu, Haowei Shen, Kang Chen, Yiwen Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Critical node identification is vital for network function, structural optimization, and risk management. Existing methods are inaccurate, as they overlook local structural features and inadequately model higher-order linkage patterns. This paper proposes Motif-GNN—a framework integrating motif structure analysis and convolutional neural networks: it enumerates network higher-order motifs to build a node-level weighted motif adjacency matrix, uses a balanced mechanism to fuse multi-scale topological information, designs a multi-channel convolutional layer for local structural feature extraction, and finally applies supervised learning to predict node importance scores. Tested on communication, power, and aviation network datasets against benchmark algorithms, Motif-GNN outperforms baselines significantly in ranking consistency and propagation influence prediction, offering a new feature-driven solution for critical node mining in complex networks.

title: The Control System for Coriolis Mass Flowmeter under Two-Phase Flow. The Simulation Results
authors: Dmitry Goncharov, Ivan Fedosov, Semen Koptyaev, Alexey Nezhurbida
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Coriolis mass flowmeters (CMFs) provide precise measurements of mass flow rate and density in single-phase flows. However, their accuracy degrades significantly under two-phase flow conditions, with errors reaching up to 80%. This paper proposes a new control system for CMFs that incorporates a fast signal-processing algorithm. The control system implements direct digital synthesis method (DDS) for drive signal formation and matrix pencil method (MPM) for tracking signal parameters. The performance of the control system was validated using mathematical models simulating both single-phase and two-phase flow conditions. Crucially, the two-phase flow conditions were modelled via modified random walk model applied to the natural frequency and the damping coefficient in CMF tube movement equation. The parameter ranges for the model correspond to experimental data for CMF with 15 mm tube diameter operating with a liquid-gas flow at a gas volume fraction (GVF) from 0 to 50%. The results demonstrate that the proposed control system ensures high dynamic performance and accurate operation under both single-phase and two-phase flow conditions across all tested GVF values.

title: Improving the Accuracy of Coffee Bean Quality Detection Using Manhattan Distance Method in the Loss Function of You Only Look Once V4
authors: Zuhal Mujaddid Samas, Novy N. R. A Mokobombang
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on New Media Studies (CONMEDIA)
abstract: Coffee is a major export commodity that plays an important role in the economies of developing countries, including Indonesia. However, owing to the decline in quality and quantity of production caused by environmental factors, an efficient quality evaluation system is required. This study aims to improve the accuracy of coffee bean quality detection by modifying the You Only Look Once version 4 (YOLOv4) algorithm by combining the Complete Intersection over Union (CIoU) and Manhattan Distance Intersection over Union (MIoU) methods in the loss function. CIoU considers the aspect ratio and midpoint distance, but CIoU itself has obstacles, one of which is convergence at the beginning of training, causing a slow training process because of the use of the Euclidean distance method. To obtain the most accurate results, it is necessary to integrate MIoU, which uses the Manhattan distance method, an improved gradient stability, and a faster training process. The dataset consisted of 400 original coffee bean images (100 per class), which were augmented using Roboflow to 2,000 images to enrich visual variation and improve model generalization. The dataset was collected by taking images of coffee beans using a high-resolution digital camera. The images were taken in a controlled lighting environment, using a neutral background and a top-view angle. Each image contains coffee beans with a variety of shapes and real conditions as found in the field. Experimental results show that the YOLOv4 model with the CIoU+MIoU joint loss function achieves a 7.4% improvement in mAP compared to the baseline model, with significant improvement at high-precision levels. This study contributes a new approach to the development of loss functions for object detection in the field of computer vision.

title: University's Engagement in Fostering Students' Entrepreneurial Intentions in Technopreneurship
authors: Stella Callista, Jennifer Evelyn, Stella Ivana Gosal
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: This research explores how university involvement influences a student’s entrepreneurial intention, specifically focusing on technopreneurship. The rapid development of digital technology has drastically transformed the global business landscape and raised the demand for innovation-driven economic contribution. Universities respond to these demands as vital institutions in fostering and nurturing entrepreneurial mindset among students. This research was initiated to investigate the degree to which a student's motivation in pursuing a technopreneur endeavor is influenced by university-led entrepreneurship programs. A quantitative approach was done, involving 100 students who have an entrepreneurship program initiated by their universities, and the studies show that student’s entrepreneurial intentions have a positive and significant impact by their university’s involvement, mainly through hands-on learning opportunities given and support service. This research contributes to the economic literature by identifying the key factors that influence technopreneur motivation, adds to the body of knowledge and provides guidance for creating more successful entrepreneurship education programs in universities.

title: Achieving Sub-20 ps Resolution in Large Arrays of μSiPMs for the DIGILOG Project
authors: S. Bisi, K. Herweg, D. Schug, V. Schulz, S. Gundacker, C. Bruschini, E. Charbon
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In time-of-flight PET, coincidence time resolution (CTR) of gamma ray detection is essential, with the recent aim of reaching better than 10 ps CTR [1]. Prompt photon emission, e.g. Cherenkov radiation in BGO crystals, has been heralded as a solution to this conundrum. However, Cherenkov detection has low photon yield, prompting high photon detection efficiency and low dark count rate, while achieving fast response with high single-photon time resolution (SPTR) in detectors [2].

title: Comparative Analysis of CNN and Fine-Tuned InceptionV3 With and Without Transposition Layer for Chest X-ray Image Pneumonia Detection
authors: Erna Amalia Widhiyanti, Guruh Fajar Shidik, Aisyah Nuraini, Talitha Olga Ramadhani, Edi Jaya Kusuma
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Pneumonia detection through chest X-ray imaging plays a critical role in enabling swift and accurate clinical assessments. However, it remains a complex task, particularly due to the challenge of capturing subtle spatial patterns in medical images. This research examined the performance of various neural network models in tackling these challenges. The findings indicate that applying a combination of transfer learning, model fine-tuning, and structural modifications can significantly enhance diagnostic performance. To further advance this field, future work should consider the use of more diverse datasets from multiple clinical environments and explore a broader range of architectural innovations to improve model adaptability and reliability.

title: HV Circuit Breakers in Extreme Electrical Conditions : Using the New Ampere-Second Criteria in Non-Standard Systems
authors: John Webb, Jan Weisker, Victor Savulyak
publish: 2025 IEEE IAS Petroleum and Chemical Industry Technical Conference (PCIC)
abstract: Circuit breakers designed and tested under IEEE Std C37.04 / C37.09 and IEC 62271-100 assume electrical networks with a time-constant of 45 ms or less, minimum relay delays of 1/2-cycle and which are electrically ‘far’ from generators or large synchronous machines. Increasingly, systems have evolved which exceed these parameters and users struggle to properly apply circuit breakers with catalog and test data conforming to only these more moderate conditions. The most recent revisions to the cited IEEE and IEC standards have changed their testing methodology to provide results which assist in these applications and the IEEE Guide for applying high voltage circuit breaker, IEEE Std C37.010, encompasses this methodology. This paper explains the basis for these changes and provides practical examples on employing this new methodology.

title: Along-Tract Mapping of White Matter Microstructural Abnormalities in Bipolar Disorder using Diffusion MRI
authors: Leila Nabulsi, Bramsh Q. Chandio, Melody JY Kang, Yanghee Im, Genevieve McPhilemy, Fiona M. Martyn, Gloria Roberts, Brian Hallahan, Udo Dannlowski, Tiana Borgers, Susanne Meinert, Jonathan Repple, Elisabeth J. Leehr, Dominik Grotegerd, Tim Hahn, Tilo Kircher, Lea Teutenberg, Benjamin Straube, Olaf Steinstraeter, Frederike Stein, Florian Thomas-Odenthal, Nina Alexander, Paula L Usemann, Andreas Jansen, Bartholomeus C.M. Haarman, Philip B. Mitchell, Colm McDonald, Dara M. Cannon, Sophia I. Thomopoulos, Ole A. Andreassen, Christopher R. K. Ching, Paul M. Thompson
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Identifying alterations in white matter (WM) circuitry in bipolar disorder (BD) may offer crucial insights into the neurobiology of the illness and support biomarker discovery for interventional and genetic studies. Although prior diffusion MRI (dMRI) studies have reported WM abnormalities in BD, few have used fine-scale spatial mapping along tracts (tractometry), and most rely solely on fractional anisotropy (FA), overlooking complementary dMRI metrics related to other microstructural properties. Large-scale multisite tractometry studies remain scarce, limiting power to detect subtle effects and generalizability. Here, we applied BUndle ANalytics (BUAN) to conduct along-tract tractometry of FA, and axial, radial, and mean diffusivity (AD, RD, MD) across 37 major WM tracts in 148 individuals with BD (mean age=36.8 ± 13.5 years; 48% female) and 258 healthy (37.9 ± 13.7 years; 58% female) controls from 6 international sites from the ENIGMA Bipolar Disorder Working Group. Larger samples led to better detection of group-level effects, supporting the benefits of large-scale data harmonization. We identified spatially localized WM microstructural differences in BD across visual, limbic, interhemispheric, language, and sensorimotor pathways including the optic radiation, uncinate and arcuate fasciculi, forceps major of the corpus callosum, extreme capsule, and brainstem tracts. In the largest study to date, our findings demonstrate the value of large-scale, multidimensional tractometry for mapping WM alterations along brain circuits in psychiatric illness.

title: Application of an Integrated Approach Based on a Petrophysical Invariant and Rate Superposition for Well-Test Analysis in Low-Permeability Reservoirs
authors: David Yu. Shengeliya, Irina G. Zakharova
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Pressure transient analysis of data from low-permeability reservoirs remains challenging due to weak signals, pronounced early-time effects and strong sensitivity to storage-related terms. We present an integrated approach based on a petrophysical dimensionless invariant that links transmissibility and storage; the invariant is dimensionalized to permit direct comparison with field tests and standard type-curves. The workflow reconstructs bottomhole pressure histories under variable flow-rate schedules by applying the principle of superposition in time and by explicitly treating early-time regimes (wellbore-storage and pre-radial behavior). For gas wells the formulation uses the standard pseudo-pressure m(p) transform and, where appropriate, pseudo-time scaling to account for real-gas effects. Model parameters (transmissibility – k<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">h</inf> and storage (storativity, φc<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">t</inf>), are inferred by fitting the reconstructed pressure to observed data; fit quality is reported quantitatively and parameter uncertainty is assessed via sensitivity and bootstrap-style resampling. Validation on synthetic cases and several field datasets shows close agreement between modeled and measured pressure histories and yields stable, physically interpretable estimates of transmissibility and storativity across a range of rate schedules and boundary conditions. The approach bridges regionally used «filtration-capacitive» terminology and internationally standard pressure transient analysis parameters, improving reproducibility and facilitating comparison with conventional well-test analysis for reservoir characterization and operational decision making.

title: Dynamic management model for hierarchical domain-wide converged services based on Link16
authors: Liang Chen, Zhigang Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: We study the service framework construction theory of the Link16-based full-domain fusion system, put forward the service scheduling management model method, shield the realization process and mechanism of its internal functions, and encapsulate the virtualization abstraction of the Link16-based full-domain fusion system resources into services with a unified structure and standard invocation specification, so as to achieve the purpose of accurate description, good management and effective classification of the resources, and realize the goal of on-demand service and dynamic scaling of the resources in the Link16-based full-domain fusion system. The goal of on-demand service and dynamic scaling of resources in the Link16-based global fusion system is realized. Abstract, encapsulate and standardize the definition of services with specific functions to form service components, and then provide a framework for the development and management of service components, based on which data chain applications can be developed quickly and efficiently. On this basis, it carries out theoretical research on service organization and management, realizes unified management and collaboration of services, and jointly achieves efficient completion of tasks.

title: Photovoltaic Module Defect Detection Based on Convolutional Neural Networks and Residual White Noise Testing
authors: Yiliang Liu, Fucheng Huang, Yongjia Yang, Jiyu Zhao, Xinyi Yang, Jinchan Liu, Yipu Wang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
