abstract: During the manufacturing and long-term operation of photovoltaic (PV) modules, defects such as micro-cracks, dark spots, and hot spots frequently occur, significantly affecting their performance and lifespan. To enhance the accuracy and reliability of defect detection, this paper proposes an innovative method based on Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and Residual White Noise Testing. The proposed approach integrates CNN with residual white noise analysis, where the CNN is utilized to extract deep features from infrared or electroluminescence (EL) images of PV modules, and the residual white noise testing is introduced to perform real-time analysis of the feature maps. This effectively suppresses background noise and false detections, thereby improving defect detection accuracy. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method achieves high precision and robustness in PV module defect detection, providing a novel technical approach for quality assessment and fault diagnosis of PV modules.

title: Comparative Analysis of YOLO-Based and Hybrid Detection Pipelines for Safety Helmet Monitoring on Construction Sites
authors: Radhitya Marendratama, Adhitya Nugraha, Ardytha Luthfiarta, Erwin Yudi Hidayat, Filipus Arif Kristiyan, Muhammad Naufal Ubaidillah
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Ensuring safety helmet compliance on construction sites is vital for minimizing head injury risks. This study conducts a comparative evaluation of two vision-based deep learning strategies for automated helmet detection. The first is a single-stage object detection approach using YOLOv8n and YOLOv11n, while the second is a two-stage hybrid pipeline that combines YOLOv11n with pretrained convolutional neural networks (MobileNetV2 and ResNet50) for post-classification. The dataset, sourced from the Hard Hat Workers Computer Vision Project, was relabeled into "helmet" and "no_helmet" categories for binary classification. YOLOv8n achieved the highest F1-score of 93%, while YOLOv11n delivered comparable results with strong accuracy and real-time detection capability. In contrast, hybrid pipelines underperformed, with F1-scores not exceeding 48%, despite MobileNetV2 producing high-confidence predictions, indicating overconfidence and misclassification. ResNet50 showed more balanced results but still lagged behind YOLO-only detectors. YOLO models also required under nine minutes of training, compared to significantly longer CNN training times. Overall, the YOLO-only approach offers superior accuracy, efficiency, and deployment simplicity, making it highly suitable for real-time safety monitoring in construction environments.

title: Data Quality Maturity Evaluation of Vehicle Tax Using DQM and DMBOK in Bengkulu
authors: Aulia Rahman Thoharsin, Yova Ruldeviyani, Basrah Nasution, Fathan Muhammad, Mahmud Ali Asykar
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: Data quality is a critical component of public information systems, particularly in the management of motor vehicle taxes, which constitute a major source of regional revenue. However, significant challenges persist, including incomplete or duplicated records, invalid identifiers, and limited interoperability with external databases. These issues remain despite various improvements since 2018, such as the integration of Population Identification Numbers (NIK) and the recording of taxpayer phone numbers. Although recent tools such as automated validation mechanisms and real-time quality dashboards, are available, they have not been widely implemented to address systemic deficiencies in regional taxation systems. This study seeks to assess the data quality maturity level of the motor vehicle tax system at the Regional Revenue Agency (Bapenda) of Bengkulu Province using David Loshin’s Data Quality Management Maturity Model (DQM). It further aims to develop actionable recommendations grounded in the Data Management Body of Knowledge (DMBOK). Data were collected through a survey of six key respondents using a 133-indicator questionnaire, with analysis conducted across five maturity levels. The findings indicate that most domains fall within the Defined level, with the highest score in Performance Management (4.23) and the lowest in Data Quality Protocols (3.38). Recommendations include implementing automated validation via the Dukcapil API, developing internal regulations, establishing a data governance team, standardizing data formats, and integrating data quality monitoring into the operational dashboard. This study contributes to the enhancement of data governance in the public sector, particularly within motor vehicle tax administration.

title: Improve CNN Architecture using Layer Normalization and Convolution Transpose Layers with Adagrad Optimization for Pest Detection
authors: M. Saipul Arifin, Guruh Fajar Shidik, Pulung Nurtantio Andono, Pujiono
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Pests on green mustard are one of the main problems affecting harvest productivity. Pest detection systems are a relevant alternative solution. CNN have become popular models used for detection systems. In pest detection systems, common CNN models often have limitations in training stability and lack of spatial detail in images, especially in varied pictures. In this study, the authors propose Layer Normalization and Transposed Convolution Layer as alternative solutions to these problems. Layer Normalization can improve training stability and robustness of the model against data variations. The Transposed Convolution Layer is then used for learnable upsampling, making pest detection more precise at the pixel level and enriching spatial features. The researchers also propose the Adagrad optimizer, which focuses on adaptive learning rates that can speed up convergence and model generalization. The dataset come from previous research on kaggle with a total of 1000 records categorized into with pest and without pest, each consisting of 500 data. The results of this research indicate an increase in accuracy for the base model by 4% from 92% to 96%. To strengthen the contribution, the researcher applied architectural solutions into the VGG-16, Nasnet Mobile, and Xception transfer learning models. The use of Layer Normalization and Transpose Convolution with the Adagrad optimizer resulted in an accuracy increase of 1% and 2.5% respectively, from 95% to 96% and then from 93% to 95.5%. Overall, the improvement of the CNN architecture model with Layer Normalization, Transpose Convolution Layers, and Adagrad optimization significantly enhances accuracy for pest detection.

title: Fastrich: A Precise Timing Detector Readout ASIC for the LHCb RICH Detector
authors: G. Bergamin, R. Ballabriga, D. Ceresa, J. Kaplon, F. Keizer, M. Lupi, D. Peninon-Herbaut, A. Pulli, S. Scarfi, K. Wyllie, F. Bandi, D. Gascon, S. Gomez Fernandez, R. Manera, J. Mauricio, A. Paterno, M. Salanti, W. Bialas, C. D'Ambrosio, V.-M. Placinta, G. Wegrzyn
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper presents FastRICH, a 16-channel, radiation-tolerant front-end ASIC developed for the LHCb RICH detector upgrade at the High-Luminosity LHC. Designed for precise timestamping of single-photon signals in high-rate environments, FastRICH achieves timing resolutions better than 30 ps RMS and supports peak hit rates up to 40 MHz per channel. The ASIC is compatible with various photodetectors, including PMTs, SiPMs, and MCPs, and handles both positive and negative sensor signal polarities. Each channel integrates a low-noise analog front-end, constantfraction (CFD) and leading-edge (LED) discriminators, and a time-to-digital converter (TDC) based on a 1.28 GHz multi-phase ring oscillator. The front-end contributes less than 10 ps RMS random jitter, while the CFD stage maintains jitter below 30 ps RMS for typical input signals. Time-ofArrival (ToA) and Time-over-Threshold (ToT) are measured with bin sizes of 24.4 ps and 390 ps, respectively. The digital back-end features Triple Modular Redundancy (TMR), shutter-based filtering, a programmable hit selection mechanism, and time sorting of events to ensure efficient data handling in demanding conditions. Output is serialized using a radiation-tolerant implementation of the Aurora 64b/66b protocol over up to four high-speed links operating between <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$320 \text{Mbit} / \mathrm{s}$</tex> and 1.28 Gbit/s. First silicon is expected in May 2025, and testing will be conducted to validate its performance under realistic operating conditions. This paper presents FastRICH architecture together with initial characterization results. FastRICH is a key component of the LHCb RICH timing upgrade, offering enhanced particle identification performance in highluminosity scenarios.

title: Improving Diagnostic Imaging for Obese Populations: Dose Efficiency of PCCT
authors: L. P. Liu, K. Mei, S. Sharma, S. Ross, S. S. Halliburton, N. Akino, A. H. Dhanaliwala, L. Roshkovan, P. B. Noël
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Photon-counting CT (PCCT) offers key advantages over energy-integrating detector CT (EID-CT), especially low-dose scans and imaging larger patients. As obesity rates rise, maintaining diagnostic image quality is critical for diagnostic accuracy. This study evaluated the dose efficiency of a PCCT prototype using phantoms representing a range of patient sizes. A 3D-printed anthropomorphic pancreas phantom and inner section of a multi-energy CT phantom were scanned with extension rings representing the 50<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup>, 75<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup>, 85<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup>, and 95<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> percentiles of adult waist circumference in the U.S (water equivalent diameters of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$32,34,37$</tex>, and 39 cm, respectively). Scans were performed on an EID-CT (Aquilion One Insight Edition, Canon Medical Systems Corporation) and a CZT PCCT (Canon Medical Systems Corporation) at a tube voltage of 120 kVp and different dose levels (CTDI<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">vol</sup> 0.5-19 mGy). Noise was measured on FBP images to compare the noise-dose relationship between scanners. Additional images were acquired for each phantom size to determine dose reduction with PCCT. At matched dose, PCCT demonstrated greater noise reduction as dose decreased and phantom size increased. With the 95<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> percentile phantom, noise was <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 \pm 9 \text{HU}$</tex> less with PCCT compared to that of EID-CT at 19 mGy. Difference in noise between scanners increased to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$64 \pm 23 \text{HU}$</tex> at 2 mGy. To match PCCT noise of the 95<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> percentile phantom at 15.5 mGy, radiation doses of 7.6,5.4, and 2.7 mGy were required for 85<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup>, 75<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup>, and 50<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">th</sup> percentile phantoms, respectively. Corresponding noise-matched doses in EID-CT were 27.6, 11.8, 7.7, and 4.3 mGy, respectively, highlighting an average dose reduction of 36 % and indicating enhanced dose efficiency. This improvement is particularly impactful at larger phantom sizes and lower dose settings, enabling effective imaging of obese patients without compromising the image quality necessary for precise disease diagnosis and monitoring.

title: Weighted Time-Delay Estimation-based Proportional-Integral-Derivative Control for High-Order Time-Delay Nonlinear Systems
authors: Syeda Nadiah Fatima Nahri, Shengzhi Du, Barend J. Van Wyk, Oluwaseun Kayode Ajayi, Tawanda Denzel Nyasulu, Hui Yu
abstract: In real-world applications, time delays and uncertain nonlinearities are inevitable and impose significant challenges in modern control systems. The uncertainties commonly include nonlinear backlash-like hysteresis, external disturbances, parameter perturbation (internal disturbance), measurement noise (white noise), and varying time-delay components. Recently, time-delay estimation (TDE) techniques have gained widespread traction for compensating for nonlinearities in various time-delay control systems. This study evaluates the performance of weighted TDE-based proportional-integral-derivative (PID) control on a complex, high-order system comprising a third-order system with a repeated pole structure. The concerned system can be regarded as analogous to a conveyor belt or a real-world thermal system. Experimental analyses are conducted to validate the effectiveness of integrating the TDE mechanism and the PID controller, with their respective weighting coefficients, during controller operation for a high-order time-delay nonlinear system under the effects of hysteresis, white noise, system parameter perturbation, external output disturbance, and varying time-delay scenarios. The simulation results, compared with the traditional PID controller, demonstrate that the proposed weighted TDE-PID control method outperforms in terms of improved transient performance characteristics, resilience, and robustness, with negligible steady-state errors. Moreover, stability and sensitivity analyses for the selection of the weighted coefficients are performed for the weighted TDE-PID-controlled high-order time-delay system, thereby further substantiating the validity of the proposed weighted control law. Hence, the results corroborate the applicability of this improved TDE-PID control method for high-order time-delay nonlinear processes encountered in realistic industrial settings.

title: Satellite-aided Low-altitude UAV Service Migration with Semantic Extraction and Generated Graphs
authors: Qiongqiong Jia, Jie Zheng, Ling Gao, Jinping Niu, Rui Cao, Jie Ren
publish: IEEE Transactions on Cognitive Communications and Networking
abstract: Satellite-aided low-altitude UAV networks utilize satellites to support low-flying drones with communication and navigation for tasks like sensing, surveillance, and delivery. A critical challenge is offloading UAV communication traffic and migrate services to satellites during network congestion. The decentralized structure, changing link conditions, and limited local visibility make it hard to coordinate service migration and request routing in such dynamic environments. To address these challenges, we propose a semantic graph-based multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) framework for satellite-aided UAV networks. We formulate service migration and routing as a semantic graph optimization problem, with the objectives of reducing communication delay and increasing network throughput. The framework incorporates two key components: a cyclic message-passing model that enables nodes to infer global network states from limited local observations, and a discrete denoising diffusion model that generates realistic, and dynamic topologies. Our framework leverages semantic feature extraction to further enhance decision-making in routing and service placement. Extensive simulations show that our approach achieves significant reductions in average transmission delay and improvements in the network throughput.

title: Commutation Angle Closed-loop-based Average Torque Control Method of High-speed Doubly Salient Electromagnetic Motor for Torque Capability Improvement
authors: Xu Chen, Zhuoran Zhang, Li Yu, Yongtao Guan, Yao Sun
abstract: The effect of the field current and commutation angle parameters on average torque of doubly salient electromagnetic motor (DSEM) is highly mutual coupled at high-speed operation. Hence, it is hard for the conventional methods to realize the simultaneous adjustment of field current and commutation angle to fully utilize the torque capability of the DSEM at high-speed operation. In this paper, a commutation angle closed-loop (CAC) based average torque control method is proposed. Firstly, the effect of the field current and commutation angle parameters on the average torque is analyzed. The characteristics of optimal commutation angle parameters are derived, and the CAC method is proposed to adjust the commutation angle parameters by aligning the phase current intersections with phase back-EMF intersections adaptively. Then, the relationship between the field current and average torque is investigated under the proposed CAC method. On this basis, the variable-step perturbation and observation algorithm and average torque control are proposed to adjust the field current by maximizing the average torque. Finally, the proposed CAC-based average torque control method is verified on the high-speed DSEM drive system. The experimental results indicate that the proposed control method can adaptively obtain the optimal commutation angle parameters and field current simultaneously and realize the maximum torque operation of high-speed DSEM drive system.

title:
A 64-Channel, 77 e
                    <sup>-</sup>
                    (rms), 17.4 Mcps, Energy-Resolving Photon-Counting Readout ASIC in 130-Nm Technology for Deep Silicon Photon-Counting Detectors
authors: T. Gao, Y. Dou, Y. Zhang, G. Zheng, T. Lu, J. Zhang, W. Zhang, X. Cao, W. Gao
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper presents a 130-nm CMOS readout ASIC addressing critical performance trade-offs in deep silicon photon-counting detectors for next-generation CT imaging, focusing on performance enhancement from first-generation (V1) to second-generation (V2) implementations. The V1 prototype demonstrated <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$250 \mathbf{e}^{-}$</tex> baseline noise (ENCo) with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$12.4 \mathbf{e}^{-} / \mathbf{p F}$</tex> noise slope under 20 pF parasitic capacitance, limited by PCB-induced interference and insufficient noise optimization. The redesigned V2 ASIC achieves breakthrough improvements through three critical upgrades: 1) Hierarchical noise suppression combining deep N-well shielding (layout), CSA transconductance optimization (circuit), and enhanced statistical modeling (system), reducing ENC to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$77+10.6 e^{-} / pF-69.2 \%$</tex> lower than V1; 2) Dual-stage automatic reset architecture (CSA + shaper) eliminating baseline drift through BLH circuits, enabling stable counting rates up to 17.4 Mcps compared to V1's rate-limited operation; 3) Centralized power distribution reducing IR drop by 25 % versus V1's peripheral layout through geometric PAD reorganization. Comparator offset variation reduced from 2.55 mV to 0.39 mV via in-channel DAC calibration pulse pileup tolerance enhanced with < 5 % counting loss at 15 Mcps under Poisson-distributed inputs (V2) vs. significant baseline collapse in V1 Post-simulation ENC vs. C_det characteristics demonstrating 3.2 × noise improvement over V1. The V2 ASIC outperforms existing designs in noise-counting rate product, establishing new capabilities for photon-counting CT applications.

title: Artifact Reduction in Undersampled 3D Cone-Beam CTs Using a Hybrid 2D-3D CNN Framework
authors: T. Dorosti, J. Thalhammer, S. Peterhansl, D. Pfeiffer, F. Pfeiffer, F. Schaff
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Undersampled CT volumes minimize acquisition time and radiation exposure but introduce artifacts degrading image quality and diagnostic utility. Reducing these artifacts is critical for high-quality imaging. We propose a computationally efficient hybrid deep-learning framework that combines the strengths of 2D and 3D models. First, a 2D U-Net operates on individual slices of undersampled CT volumes to extract feature maps. These slice-wise feature maps are then stacked across the volume and used as input to a 3D decoder, which utilizes contextual information across slices to predict an artifact-free 3D CT volume. The proposed two-stage approach balances the computational efficiency of 2D processing with the volumetric consistency provided by 3D modeling. The results show substantial improvements in inter-slice consistency in coronal and sagittal direction with low computational overhead. This hybrid framework presents a robust and efficient solution for high-quality 3D CT image post-processing.

title: A Metal-Hydride Based Gas Detector for Tritium Quantification Measurement
authors: M. Van Zile, J. Sklebar, M. Kim, S. Zhai, A. Co, P. Kandlakunta, R. Cao
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Due to the high mobility of tritium, its ability to form tritiated water, and its radiological significance, low-level tritium monitoring is critical for nuclear safeguards, regulatory compliance, and environmental protection. Detecting trace amounts of tritium remains challenging, driving the need for field-deployable systems offering high sensitivity, selectivity, and minimal false positives. We present a technique for high-sensitivity, high-selectivity tritium measurement, which integrates metal-hydride and gas-detector concepts into a compact field-deployable tritium sensor, referred to as MEGA detector. In this detector, sampled-air containing tritium in one of its chemical forms is flown into a gas-proportional counter embedded with a hydrogen-storage metal. Metal-hydride forms from selective absorption of hydrogen/tritium into the metal at optimized isotherms. A quick gas purging flushes out residual air containing any background radionuclides after which the counter is backfilled with working gas. Tritium desorption occurs from appropriately heating the metal-hydride, which releases it back into the counter. Subsequent detector operation in proportional counting mode generates signals induced solely by tritium betaparticles, enabling its selective measurement at 100% detection efficiency. Preliminary studies conducted with palladium thin films coated on stainless-steel substrates demonstrated tritium absorption and metal-hydride formation, and tritium desorption upon heating the metal-hydride. These processes were confirmed using data from both a commercial tritium monitor and a custom MEGA detector. The MEGA detector successfully acquired the pulse height spectrum of tritium beta-emissions.

title: Latest Results from XL-Calibur - A Balloon Borne Hard X-Ray Polarimetry Mission
authors: M. Pearce
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The linear polarisation of hard X-ray emission from the Crab pulsar/wind nebula and black-hole binary Cygnus X-1 has been measured by XL-Calibur. Observations took place in July 2024 during a week-long stratospheric balloon flight between northern Sweden and Canada. The addition of polarimetry to the standard high-energy measurement techniques of spectroscopy, timing and imaging, allows systematically new tests of source emission and geometry models. XL-Calibur incorporates an X-ray mirror, which focusses X-rays onto a polarimeter comprising a beryllium rod surrounded by Cadmium Zinc Telluride detectors. The polarimeter is housed in a thick <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Bi}_{4} \text{Ge}_{3} \mathrm{O}_{12}$</tex> anticoincidence shield to mitigate measurement backgrounds. The mirror and polarimeter-shield assembly are mounted at opposite ends of a 12 m long lightweight truss, which is pointed with WASP - the Wallops Arc Second Pointer. XL-Calibur is the most sensitive hard X-ray polarimetry mission to date, offering an order-of-magnitude improvement in signal-to-background performance compared to preceding missions. The energy range (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$15-80 \text{keV}$</tex>) complements the NASA/ASI IXPE mission (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$2-8 \text{keV}$</tex>), allowing broadband studies. I will describe the XL-Calibur mission, and summarise latest results from observations. Plans for future flights of XL-Caliburwill also be discussed.

title: Routing in Hierarchical Hybrid Satellite Networks: A Survey
authors: Zeyu Liu, Shuai Wang, Rui Zhang, Zhe Song, Gaofeng Pan
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: With the deep evolution of satellite communication technologies and hierarchical hybrid networks (HHSNs), modern communication satellites have transformed from single-function relay nodes into core hubs enabling global interconnectivity. The dynamic topology, open-channel environment, and resource limitations inherent to HHSN expose satellite routing protocols to the challenges of the Reliability-Security-Efficiency (RSE) trilemma. In this paper, we provide a systematic review of advancements in HHSN routing research, analyzing core technical challenges through the lens of typical application scenarios while highlighting the divergent performance of various solutions under the RSE trilemma. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to analyze the performance of HHSN routing protocols within the framework of the RSE theory. Existing reviews either treat routing merely as a component of broader surveys or lack analysis based on the RSE trilemma framework. Building on our review of HHSN routing protocols, we discuss the topology description and security aspects of HHSN and propose potential directions for future HHSN routing research.

title: Portable African Neutron-Gamma Laboratory for Innovative Nuclear Science
authors: P. Jones, S. Hart, M. Johnson, O. Mahgoub, S. Meyer, L. Pellegri, M. Rahman, N. Stodart, G. Taylor, F. Van Niekerk, C. Van Tubbergh, S. Woodborne, D. Wyngaard
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: iThemba LABS has pioneered a mobile gamma-ray detection unit [1] which allows a user to operate in the field and chart the location, strength and energy of gamma radiation. The system incorporates a sensitive scintillation detector \cite{bib2} typically used for accelerator-based spectroscopy at the SSC laboratory and was integrated into a backpack incorporating a fast 125 MHz digitiser for readout and a GPS enabled Raspberry Pi microprocessor system, allowing in situ measurements of radiation around the Cape Town site, with collected data streamed to the cloud and analysed offline. The Portable African Neutron-Gamma Laboratory for Innovative Nuclear Science (PANGoLINS) project aims to investigate measurements of both gamma rays and neutrons which forms an important component part on site or in transit and the detection of both fissile material for the use in decarbonised energy sources or disposal thereof. A core component of the project is be to miniaturize the weight of the gamma-ray detection device and associated infrastructure so that it can be loaded on an uncrewed aerial vehicle to enable access to, and enhance performance of radiation monitoring measurements at remote sites leading to autonomous operations. PANGoLINS incorporates commercial detector assemblies of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{LaBr}_{3}(\text{Ce}),\ \text{SrI}_{2}(\text{Eu})$</tex> and/or CLYC(Ce) for spectroscopy. In addition, the project encompasses the instrumentation of other scintillation detectors with silicon photomultiplier technologies. The coupling of these to readout devices such as high-density ADC readout are planned for applications for nuclear science, medical imaging or astronomy.

title: Prototype of Ultra-Low-Power Readout Electronics for the Large Area ${ }^{3}He$ Tube Array Detector at China Spallation Neutron Source
authors: W. Yin, Y. Lai, H. Liu, Q. Li, J. Ren, Q. Xiu, L. Xiao, S. Chen, L. Zeng, L. Yu, X. Wang, Y. Zhao, Z. Sun
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The China Spallation Neutron Source (CSNS) is currently upgrading to CSNS-II, increasing the proton beam power to 500 kW and constructing several new neutron spectrometers. The CSNS-II upgrade poses significant challenges for detector and electronics systems, including higher counting rate, improved position resolution requirement, and vacuum operating environment. In this paper, we present an ultra-low-power front-end readout electronics prototype designed for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{3}\text{He}$</tex> tube detectors in CSNS-II spectrometers. The circuit design, FPGA algorithms, and laboratory test results of the prototype will be discussed. Experimental results demonstrate that the new electronics system can achieve a single-tube counting rate of 100 K/s while maintaining a position resolution better than 8 mm. Test also confirmed the system's capability to operate under vacuum conditions. These results meet the requirements for neutron signal readout in CSNS-II spectrometers.

title: Planning of current transients to follow MTPA trajectory
authors: Anton Dianov, Alecksey Anuchin, Igor Litvinchev, Xiaodong Sun, Galina Demidova, Vladimir Prakht
publish: IEEE Open Journal of the Industrial Electronics Society
abstract: The efficient operation of synchronous motors requires the implementation of techniques for loss decreasing. In the overwhelming majority of control systems, the developers use maximum torque per ampere (MTPA) control, which is a trade-off between simplicity and loss minimization. The developers mainly pay attention to MTPA control in steady-state modes, which are usually the main operating modes of motor drives. However, motors in some applications like automotive, machine tools, etc., operate with numerous transients, thus the implementation of MTPA control in transients is crucial for efficient control in those applications. Therefore, this paper proposes an algorithm for the planning of current transients, which aims for the provision of the trajectory closer to motor MTPA curve. In steady state mode the proposed technique is inactive, however when the control system detects significant change of current command, it activates the planning algorithm. The algorithm detects transient direction (raising or falling current) and defines initial and target points. Then it calculates the ratio between cutoff frequencies of d- and q-axis current PI controllers and changes the gains of the slowest controller. When that transient is over, the algorithm restores the modified gains and becomes inactive. The experimental part proves the feasibility of the proposed technique and demonstrates improved trajectories.

title: Integrated Encoding and Quantization to Enhance Quanvolutional Neural Networks
authors: Daniele Lizzio, Beatrice Portelli, Giuseppe Serra
abstract: Image processing is one of the most promising applications for quantum machine learning (QML). Quanvolutional Neural Networks with non-trainable parameters are the preferred solution to run on current and near future quantum devices. The typical input preprocessing pipeline for quanvolutional layers comprises of four steps: optional input binary quantization, encoding classical data into quantum states, processing the data to obtain the final quantum states, decoding quantum states back to classical outputs. In this paper we propose two ways to enhance the efficiency of quanvolutional models. First, we propose a flexible data quantization approach with memoization, applicable to any encoding method. This allows us to increase the number of quantization levels to retain more information or lower them to reduce the amount of circuit executions. Second, we introduce a new integrated encoding strategy, which combines the encoding and processing steps in a single circuit. This method allows great flexibility on several architectural parameters (e.g., number of qubits, filter size, and circuit depth) making them adjustable to quantum hardware requirements. We compare our proposed integrated model with a classical convolutional neural network and the well-known rotational encoding method, on two different classification tasks. The results demonstrate that our proposed model encoding exhibits a comparable or superior performance to the other models while requiring fewer quantum resources.

title: A Robust Mechanical Sensorless Control Strategy for Active Rectification of Small Wind Turbines
authors: Adrien Prévost, Vincent Léchappé, Romain Delpoux, Xavier Brun
publish: IEEE Transactions on Control Systems Technology
abstract: This article proposes a mechanical sensorless control strategy for the synchronous rectification of small wind turbines (SWTs) equipped with a surface-mounted permanent magnet synchronous generator (PMSG). By means of Lyapunov theory, the global asymptotic Stability of the closed-loop system is proven. It allows the use of a classical sliding mode observer (SMO) to remove the mechanical sensor in the control loop despite uncertainties on the resistance and inductance parameters. The analysis of the equilibrium points has made it possible to propose an analytic model of the angular misalignment between the true and the observer rotating frames, responsible for current tracking errors. Experimental tests on a wind turbine emulator (WTE) show that despite up to 100% of error on the resistance and inductance parameters, the impact on the energy production is negligible, proving that the strategy’s performance is robust to high uncertainties.

title: A Simulation Study of Ultra-High-Dose-Rate High-Energy X-Rays Induced Acoustic Imaging for Flash Radiotherapy Dosimetry
authors: X. Hu, J. Wang, Q. Wang, Y. Zhang, X. Nie, J. Huo
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Flash radiotherapy (Flash-RT) is an emerging radiotherapy technique whose uniqueness lies in the ability to deliver ultra-high doses to the tumor site in a fraction of a second, which can significantly reduce the damage to normal tissues while ensuring the tumor treatment effect. In order to carry out dosimetric evaluation and verification during X-ray Flash-RT, it is necessary to visualize the spatial dose distribution in the irradiated target. However, as the ultra-fast dose delivery characteristics of Flash-RT, traditional dose measurement and monitoring techniques face significant challenges such as signal saturation effects and substantial measurement deviations. The imaging technique of dose delivery based on the X-ray acoustic effect provides a feasible strategy for online dose monitoring during Flash-RT. By detecting the acoustic wave signal induced by ultra-high-dose-rate high-energy X-rays irradiating the target, the absorbed dose distribution in the target can be quantitatively reconstructed. In this study, the Geant4 program based on the Monte Carlo method is used to simulate the process of single-pulse X-rays generated by a 10 MV medical linear accelerator irradiating three representative phantoms composed of different materials, and then the propagation and attenuation process of the induced acoustic wave are approximated based on k-space pseudospectral method. Subsequently, the delivered dose distribution in the phantoms will be quantitatively reconstructed by the acoustic signal sequences collected by an annular array transducer with 128 -element. The experimental results verify the feasibility and effectiveness of this online dosimetry technique in the X-ray Flash-RT.

title: A Prototype of Digital Trigger System for Cherenkov Telescopes of HADAR
authors: M. Han, Z. Cao, Y. Hua, K. Chen, J. Qin, J. Li, L. Zhao
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The High Altitude Detection of Astronomical Radiation (HADAR) experiment is aimed at detecting cosmic gamma rays from 10 GeV to 10 TeV energy ranges. The HADAR is an array of four wide-field-of-view Cherenkov telescopes based on refractive lenses. Each telescope comprises a camera of 18,961 photomultiplier tubes (PMTs). The telescopes require a real-time hardware trigger system to select images induced by cosmic rays, while rejecting images induced by the night sky background (NSB) to reduce the random trigger rate. This paper proposes an FPGA-based digital trigger system for HADAR, featuring a novel trigger algorithm that exploits the measured charge of neighboring pixels, and a low-complexity system structure that is capable of implementing the algorithm. A prototype trigger system is developed to verify the trigger algorithm, and the hardware performance is tested. The results show that the design achieves a trigger efficiency of 98.02% for valid event samples and an error rate of only 0.7% for invalid background samples with reliable high-speed hardware, indicating that the design is a feasible and efficient solution for the HADAR experiment.

title: Improved Reconstruction Quality of PGET Through Spectrum Unfolding
authors: M. Fang, P. Dendooven, R. Virta, Y. Altmann, A. Di Fulvio
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The Passive Gamma Emission Tomography (PGET) instrument has received authorization from the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA) for inspecting spent fuel assemblies (SFAs) to detect any diversion of fuel rods. Our approach frames the image reconstruction process as an inverse problem, allowing a direct estimate of the fuel rod activity. In this work, we incorporated spectrum unfolding to reconstruct the gamma-ray emission spectrum of the spent fuel rods based on gamma-ray spectra measured by CZT detectors, which eliminated the algorithm's dependence on prior burnup data to avoid potential bias in the verification process. We applied the reconstruction algorithm to a VVER-440 fuel assembly and successfully imaged all the fuel rods. We observed a 24 % increase in the difference between the reconstructed activity of water channel and fuel rods when the reconstructed emission spectrum was used.

title: From Ultra-Short Timeframes to Ultra-Fast Motion: Maximum-Likelihood Motion and Activity (MLMA) Reconstruction for Cardiac Gateless TOF-PET
authors: R. José Santo, E. Waterink, C. A.T. Van Den Berg, H. W.A.M. De Jong, C. Beijst
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: PET imaging typically requires long acquisitions to obtain images of sufficient quality. This is a consequence of the low radiotracer doses and not an inherent limitation of PET, as scanners process events at the millisecond timescale for list-mode protocols. However, conventional reconstruction methods do not exploit this high sampling rate, failing to correct for fast irregular motion, such as in cardiac PET. We hereby propose a method to estimate and correct for motion at an ultra-high-frequency <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(10 ~\text{Hz})$</tex>, utilizing the projection data of ultra-short timeframes <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(100 ~\text{ms})$</tex>. It builds upon the Maximum-Likelihood Motion and Activity (MLMA) reconstruction method, incorporating time-of-flight (TOF) on motion estimation for more accurate and local motion. The method is validated on projection data for the XCAT phantom and on patient data. The results show that MLMA is robust, resolving the physiological motion of the heart. We conclude that PET intrinsically has a high encoding of motion even for ultra-short timeframes (100 ms), that MLMA exploits for gateless motion estimation and correction at ultra-high frequencies (10 Hz).

title: Towards Real-Time Scatter Estimation Directly From Time-of-Flight Signals Using Embedded Neuromorphic Computing
authors: B. Gouin-Ferland, R. Fontaine, A. Corbeil Therrien
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Time-of-flight measurement enhances X-ray imaging and reduces radiation dose but challenges data handling and thermal limits. To address this, a spiking neural network approach is proposed for embedded real-time scatter rejection from time-of-flight X-ray signals. In simulations, the spiking neural network achieves a mean absolute percentage error over the full image of 7.1 %, compare to 23.6 % for the threshold-based scatter rejection method, significantly outperforming it. By shifting complex processing tasks to the detector level, this method not only reduces raw data generation but also redefines the role of traditional front-end electronics - from passive signal acquisition to active data processing - marking a key step toward deploying low-power, embedded intelligent processing directly within detectors.

title: Analysis of Crab Pulsar Profiles Utilizing GRID Data
authors: F. Sha, X. Long, X. Zheng, X. Pan, H. Gao, Y. Liu, M. Ge, H. Feng, M. Zeng
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The Crab pulsar is notable for its extremely high radiation power and stable period, which make it a valuable target for X-ray astronomical studies. The GRID project is designed to monitor the transient gamma-ray sky at energies from 10 keV to 2 MeV. Meanwhile, its large field of view enables continuous observation of the Crab pulsar. This study utilizes GRID data to construct pulse profiles of the Crab pulsar, and the results are consistent with those obtained from other detectors, thereby verifying the timing accuracy of the GRID detector design. Additionally, this study establishes an efficient data processing workflow for achieving precise astronomical data timing, which will support future scientific analyses in the GRID project.

title: An Independent and Portable Multiparameter Detection System With Environmental Adaptability_supp1-3642884.docx
authors: Jun-Ge Liang
abstract: Microwave sensors are widely used due to their noninvasiveness and high sensitivity. Most of the studies focus on the design of sensor components and, however, lack exploration on how to build an independent sensor system. This study proposes a microwave multiparameter detection system (MMDS) based on a phase-locked loop (PLL) and dual-AD8302. A modified complementary split-ring resonator (MCSRR) works as the passive sensor component. The system is specially designed to handle the environmental influence and work for multiple parameter detection. The PLL driving circuit generates a 0.9–1.4-GHz sweep signal to drive the MCSRR. Then, the insertion loss and phase curve are read out during the sensing process. We quantify and optimize the system noise by establishing a contribution model and propose a compensation model using a neural network for offsetting the influence of environmental temperature and humidity. An evaluation system is built with six indicators: accuracy, linearity, sensitivity, limit of detection (LOD), repeatability, and humidity calibration coefficient (HCC). The measured results show that the MMDS can detect frequency, amplitude, and phase change with an accuracy of 98.7%, 97.2%, and 85.2%, respectively. Empowered by its integrated humidity compensation model, the system demonstrates superior robustness against ambient humidity variations, with an HCC exceeding 92% for frequency, amplitude, and phase detection.

title: Real-Time High-Accuracy Digital Wireless Time, Frequency, and Phase Calibration for Coherent Distributed Antenna Arrays_supp1-3639461.pdf
authors: Jeffrey A Nanzer
abstract: This work presents a fully-digital high-accuracy real-time calibration procedure for frequency and time alignment of open-loop wirelessly coordinated coherent distributed antenna array (CDA) modems, enabling radio frequency (RF) phase coherence of spatially separated commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) software-defined radios (SDRs) without cables or external references such as the global navigation satellite system (GNSS). Building on previous work using high-accuracy spectrally-sparse time of arrival (ToA) waveforms and a multistep ToA refinement process, a high-accuracy two-way time transfer (TWTT)-based time–frequency coordination approach is demonstrated. Due to the two-way nature of the high-accuracy TWTT approach, the time and frequency estimates are Doppler and multipath tolerant, so long as the channel is reciprocal over the synchronization epoch. This technique is experimentally verified using COTS SDRs in a lab environment in static and dynamic scenarios and with significant multipath scatterers. Time, frequency, and phase stability were evaluated by beamforming over coaxial cables to an oscilloscope which achieved time and phase precisions of ~60–<inline-formula xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink"> <tex-math notation="LaTeX">$\mathbf {\mathrm {70~\text {p}\text {s} }}$</tex-math> </inline-formula>, with median coherent gains above 99% using optimized coordination parameters, and a beamforming frequency root-mean-square error (RMSE) of 3.73 ppb in a dynamic scenario. Finally, experiments were conducted to compare the performance of this technique with previous works using an analog continuous-wave two-tone (CWTT) frequency reference technique in both static and dynamic settings.

title: Fast Timing of Photon Detectors Using the picoTDC
authors: B. Seitz, A. Cheyne, C. Maggio, R. Montgomery, F. Thomson, C. Tintori, Y. Venturini
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Modern experiments are pushing for the best timing resolution achievable when detecting visible light photons. Applications range from imaging Cherenkov detectors, Time-of-Flight detectors and calorimeters in fundamental physics to applications in the nuclear and medical sectors. Recent advances in photon detection technology need to be accompanied by a parallel development in read-out electronics to optimise the response of the system. A variety of photon detection systems ranging from a single channel photo multiplier tube (Hamamatsu R14374), a multi-anode photo multiplier tube (Hamamatsu H8500) to SiPM (OnSemi J series) and MCP-PMT (Incom LAPPD) have been tested using a 405 nm pico-second PiLas laser system. Compactness, scalability and applicability to thousands of channels is required for the readout electronics. CAEN A5203 board, part of a synchronizable and distributable Front-End Readout System (FERS), integrates the CERN picoTDC Application-Specific Integrated Circuit (ASIC) into a small unit for highresolution time measurements of Time of Arrival (ToA) and Time over Threshold (ToT). This readout has been used throughout these experiments. The time resolution using a leading edge discrimination algorithm without walk corrections was found to be 63 ps for the R14374, 44 ps for the H8500 and 8 ps for the SIPM.

title: Noise Suppression in Ultra-Low-Dose CT for LAFOV PET/CT via Unpaired CycleGAN Training
authors: S. Mostafapour, J. van Sluis, J. H. van Snick, M. Greuter, K. P. Koopmans, A. H. Brouwers, A. A. Lammertsma, C. Tsoumpas
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Reducing radiation dose in positron emission tomography / computed tomography (PET/CT) is critical, and recent advances in ultra-low-dose (ULD)-CT protocols have enabled up to a 98% reduction in CT radiation exposure. However, this comes at the cost of increased image noise and reduced anatomical detail, which may hinder visual interpretation in some clinical indications. While low-dose (LD) CT, typically used in PET/CT, is not of diagnostic quality, it provides adequate anatomical information for attenuation correction and localization. This study introduces a deep learning-based denoising approach using a cycle-consistent generative adversarial network (cGAN) to enhance ULD-CT image quality. A total of 70 patient scans were used: 51 for training and internal validation and 19 for external validation. Due to slight anatomical mismatches, the model was trained on unpaired two-dimensional slices. Performance was assessed using signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR), and multiple image similarity metrics. Results showed that synthetic cGAN-CT images improved SNR and CNR across the lung, liver, and bone, with relative differences to LD-CT under 16%, while ULD-CT deviated by over 60%. Image similarity metrics confirmed that cGAN-CT achieved structural quality comparable to LD-CT. This approach supports substantial dose reduction while preserving image quality for clinical PET/CT interpretation.

title: Simple Neural Network Predictor for Inter-Crystal Scatter Recovery in Ultra-High Resolution PET Imaging
authors: A. Bernier, J. Lambert, S. Carneiro Esteves, M. Toussaint, M. Gaudreault, J.-F. Beaudoin, É. Auger, C. Thibaudeau, R. Lecomte, J.-B. Michaud
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Inter-crystal scatter (ICS) events pose a significant challenge in ultra-high resolution positron emission tomography (UHR-PET), particularly as detector crystals become smaller. Current approaches either reject these events, reducing sensitivity, or accept them with inaccurate positioning algorithms, degrading image quality. We propose a simple machine learning approach to optimize ICS event recovery based on a feed-forward neural network constrained by physical conditions with an hardware-ready architecture. Our approach was validated using Monte Carlo simulations and experimental data from the LabPET II scanners. Results demonstrate a 105% increase in sensitivity while maintaining spatial resolution. This enables reduced scan times or radiation doses while preserving image quality, representing a significant step forward in UHRPET imaging.

title: Thermal Neutron Flux Measurement Using the Activation of a CLLB(Ce) Scintillator
authors: Y. Tonosaki, K. Kiura, M. Shimazu, G. Wakabayashi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: A new technique to measure thermal neutron fluxes was developed. This technique uses a CLLB(Ce) scintillator as an activation detector for neutron irradiation. Taking advantage of the fact that the neutron flux spectrum of a well-moderated neutrons is approximated by the sum of a Maxwellian distribution and 1/E distribution, the thermal neutron flux is deduced from the activities of Cs-134m and Br-80m produced in the scintillator without using the cadmium filter method. The applicability of this technique was tested by measuring a thermal neutron flux using a Pu-Be neutrons source and a paraffin moderator. The result was agreed well with the known thermal neutron flux measured by another method. Thermal neutron fluxes in a thermal reactor can be measured without cadmium filters by irradiating a single CLLB(Ce) scintillator.

title: Image Quality Enhancement Method for Active Coded-Apeture Gamma Imager for Omnidirectional Detection
authors: D. Kim, J. Lee, C. Ko, S. Lee, M. Song, H. Lyu, M. Jeong
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This study presents a method for reconstructing images using data acquired from an active codedaperture gamma imaging system developed for omnidirectional in-situ radiation detection. Image reconstruction was performed using the maximum likelihood expectation maximization (MLEM) algorithm. However, since the MLEM algorithm is based on point estimation, it tends to converge to a specific point as the number of iterations increases. While it responds accurately to point sources, it may produce point-like artifacts when applied to volume sources. In this study, a geometrical model of the active coded-aperture gamma imaging system was developed using MCNPX-PoliMi to support system design and evaluation. A pseudo-random pattern was designed to serve as the coded aperture, with scintillator pixels positioned at the activated region to induce active shadow formation. The system features a cylindrical geometry, and the system matrix was constructed along eight radial directions 45 degree intervals from the center of the cylinder toward its lateral surface. Images were reconstructed using data obtained from each of the eight directional system matrices and then fused to assess the system's capability in detecting and characterizing volume sources with defined shapes.

title: The Improvement Discrete Point Tracker for Tracking Prostate Using Fourier Calculation and LBP
authors: H. M. Lee, J. G. Yang, M. A. Maslamani, G. H. Song, S. K. Woo
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper shows the computer vision technology to track the prostate in the human body. In the case of the existing computer vision technology about tracking system, these technologies such as KCF, CSK, and MOSSE have low accuracy. In contrast, the computer vision technology about tracking system in this paper shows higher accuracy than the existing computer vision technology. The computer vision technology has Discrete Point tracking based on Fourier Calculation and Local Binary Pattern. The Discrete Point tracking is the computer technology to follow the movement of specific points. But the Discrete Point tracking has disadvantage about the computation speed. So, the Discrete Point tracking in this paper used Fourier Transform to improve the computation speed. The Local Binary Pattern is texture-based region detection technology which analyzes the texture of image captured by camera. So, the Local Binary Pattern is the good method for recognizing the organ part as shown in this paper because it distinguishes the boundaries of the image based on the texture composed of pixel values. Furthermore, this paper shows the different accuracy result between Discrete Point tracking based on Fourier Calculation with Local Binary Pattern and Discrete Point tracking based on Fourier Calculation without Local Binary Pattern. The results in this paper show that using LBP yields higher accuracy than not using it. The mean value about Discrete Point Tracking with Local Binary Pattern is 0.6775. But the mean SSIM value about Discrete Point Tracking without Local Binary Pattern is 0.7472. Therefore, the computer vision technology having Discrete Point tracking based on Fourier Calculation with Local Binary Pattern shows the highest efficiency in terms of accuracy. The tracking accuracy was measured by SSIM.

title: Performance of High-Resolution PET Detectors Based on Long Semi-Monolithic GAGG Scintillator
authors: Z. Kuang, S. M. Kinyanjui, L. Zhang, N. Ren, Q. Tan, Y. Li, Z. Liu, Y. Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Depth of interaction (DOI) encoding detector is vital for a PET scanner to achieve high imaging quality. Semi-monolithic scintillator detectors have the inherent DOI encoding capability of monolithic scintillator, and can also improve the spatial resolution of the detector by reducing the edge effect. In this work, the performance of three semi-monolithic scintillator detectors consisting of gadolinium aluminum gallium garnet (GAGG) was measured for the first time. The three detectors consisted of 12 slabs of 0.96 × 56 × 10 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> in size, with different reflectors between the slabs and different treatments on the front and two end surfaces. The detectors were single-ended read out by a 4 × 16 silicon photomultiplier (SiPM) array with a row and column summimg circuit. Different monolthic (y) and DOI (z) positions of the detector were irridiated by using a 0.3 mm Na-22 point source and a reference coincidence detector consisting of a single LYSO crystal of 1 × 1 × 20 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup>. The squared COG method was used to obtain the y position, and inverse standard deviation method was used to obtain the DOI information. Placing black paint on the front and two end surfaces of the semi-monolithic arrays improved both the y and DOI resolutions, but degraded the energy resolution. Detector using the ESR reflector provided similar y and DOI resolutions, and better energy resolution as compared to the detector using the BaSO<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">4</inf> reflector. The two detectors with the front and two side surfaces black painted provided a clear identification of all scintilator slabs of 0.96 mm, y resolutions of ∼ 1.6 mm, DOI resolution of ∼ 2.35 mm and energy resolutions of ≤ 14.8 %, and can be used to develop high resolution small animal and organ specific PET scanners. Machine learning based positioning algorithms will be developed in the upcoming work to improve the current results.

title: Advancing Radiation Tolerance in Monolithic Pixel Sensors: Recent Findings From MALTA2
authors: M. Van Rijnbach, I. Asensi Tortajada, P. Behera, D. V. Berlea, D. Bortoletto, C. Buttar, V. Dao, G. Dash, L. F. Sanz De Acedo, M. Gazi, L. Gonella, V. González, S. Haberl, T. Inada, L. Li, H. Pernegger, P. Riedler, W. Snoeys, C. Solans Sanchez, P. Jana, A. Vijay, M. Vazquez Nunez, J. Weick, S. Worm, T. Chembakan, L. Fasselt
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This work presents recent results and the future outlook of the MALTA monolithic active pixel sensor, developed in 180 nm CMOS technology for operation in high-radiation, high-rate environments. The MALTA2 sensor has been extensively characterized under irradiation up to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$5 \times 10^{15} \mathrm{n} \_\text{eq} / \text{cm}^{2}$</tex>. By using various process modification, such as the very high doping of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{n}^{-}$</tex> implant and incorporating backside metallization to push the bias voltage, efficiencies exceeding 95 % are achieved at <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3 \times 10^{15} \mathrm{n} \_\text{eq} / \text{cm}^{2}$</tex>. Ongoing efforts aim to further improve performance through the development of a new MALTA2 prototype featuring ultra-high doping of the n-layer, pushing the sensor's potential in extreme radiation environments. To support these advancements, comprehensive studies have been conducted to characterize the depletion region using both grazing angle measurements and edge-TCT. Additionally, a novel technique using digital testbeam data enables in-pixel seed amplitude reconstruction, providing detailed insights into charge collection dynamics across the pixel, also after irradiation. These investigations are essential for understanding radiation-induced charge loss and guiding the path for further optimization of the sensor layouts. Ultimately, these developments reinforce MALTA's potential for next-generation precision tracking applications where radiation hardness and timing performance are critical.

title: A Scintillator-Driven Imaging Approach for an Electron-Beam-Based Magnetometer
authors: M. Turqueti, O. Aggarwal
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This study presents the design, development, and evaluation of an electron beam imaging system intended for integration into a novel magnetometer platform based on a micro cathode ray tube (mCRT) architecture. The magnetometer employs a low-energy electron beam, operating within the energy range of 500 to 2000 electronvolts <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\mathbf{e V})$</tex>, as a critical component for detecting minute variations in magnetic fields. Accurate spatial and temporal detection of the electron beam within this energy range is paramount to the functionality and precision of the magnetometer. To address this challenge, we investigated and characterized multiple scintillating materials in conjunction with a high-sensitivity complementary metal-oxide-semiconductor (CMOS) imaging sensor. Scintillators serve as the electron-to-photon conversion layer, enabling the visualization of the electron beam profile and dynamics. The materials were selected and tested based on several performance metrics, including their scintillation efficiency as a function of incident electron energy, light spread (diffusion) within the scintillator, spatial resolution, afterglow characteristics, and susceptibility to electron-induced degradation over time.Both pixelated and monolithic scintillator architectures were fabricated and subjected to systematic comparative analysis. Pixelated scintillators, typically constructed using optical isolation techniques to confine photon spread, were assessed for their potential to enhance image sharpness. In contrast, monolithic scintillators were evaluated for their fabrication simplicity and higher light yield, though potentially at the cost of reduced resolution due to diffusion. The outcome of this work contributes not only to its target application but also to the growing field of low-energy electron detection and imaging, particularly in configurations where electron sensing via direct detection is impractical due to shallow penetration depths.

title: Attenuation and Scatter Correction for Dedicated Myocardial SPECT Using Deep Learning
authors: S. Inaba, K. Ogawa
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Myocardial single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) is an essential imaging modality for evaluating myocardial viability. In recent years, high-resolution SPECT systems employing pinhole collimators have been introduced to improve image quality. A notable example is the Discovery NM 530c (GE Healthcare, USA), which features a dedicated cardiac imaging configuration and semiconductor detectors, providing high spatial and energy resolution along with reduced acquisition time. However, this system does not include an integrated X-ray CT scanner for generating the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu$</tex>-map required for attenuation correction, and image artifacts caused by the detector geometry remain a challenge. In this study, we propose a novel attenuation and scatter correction method that does not require a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{\mu}$</tex>-map, based on a convolutional neural network (CNN). A simulation replicating the system geometry of the Discovery NM 530c was conducted to validate the proposed method. Additionally, a conventional correction method using a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{\mu}$</tex>-map was implemented for comparative evaluation. The simulation results demonstrated that the proposed CNN-based method achieved correction accuracy comparable to that of the conventional method, despite not utilizing a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mu$</tex>-map. These results suggest that the proposed method is a practical solution for attenuation and scatter correction in dedicated SPECT systems without X-ray CT.

title: Alternating Update Expectation Maximization Method of Multiplexed PET Reconstruction
authors: J. W. Foster, W. He, C. S. Levin
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We propose a completely new approach for reconstructing individual tracer images in multiplexed PET (mPET). In mPET using positron plus prompt gamma emitters, missed gamma photons cause crosstalk between the reconstructed images. Previous reconstruction methods account for the missed gamma photons but take very long to converge due to simultaneous estimation of both radiotracers' distribution. This leads to very noisy reconstructed images where there is a tradeoff between achieving low crosstalk and low noise. We present an alternating update method for multiplexed PET reconstruction that alternates between reconstructing the pure positron (e.g. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{18} ~\mathrm{F}$</tex>) and positron plus prompt gamma emitter (e.g. <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{44} \text{Sc}$</tex>) -labeled tracer distributions in order to reduce convergence time and improve image quality. Using Monte Carlo simulated data of an IQ phantom with varying size spheres, we see similar contrast recovery in <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{18} ~\mathrm{F} /{ }^{44} \text{Sc}$</tex> of 0.60/0.47 and 0.56/0.47 for the second smallest spheres between the previous simultaneous estimation and proposed alternating update methods, respectively, at their optimal iterations. The same spheres show improved contrast-to-noise ratios for the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{18} ~\mathrm{F} /{ }^{44} \text{Sc}$</tex>, increasing from 17.0/12.5 with the previous method to 36.1/30.8 with the proposed method. The crosstalk between the two tracers is below the threshold of visual inspection, with measured crosstalk ratios of 0.15 / 0.43 for the previous and 0.06/0.20 for the proposed method. Thus, the alternating update method shows over 2 x the CNR for similar CR while achieving about half of the level of crosstalk between the tracers compared to the previous simultaneous estimation method. It also requires about half the number of total iterations, yielding around 1.5-2x faster reconstruction.

title: A Liquid Argon Scintillation Detector for Nuclear Safety and Security Applications
authors: D. Perez Loureiro, A. Erlandson, D. Godin, B. Jigmeddorj, O. Kamaev, L. Li, E. Rand, R. Sammon, L. Vlasenko Mischenko, L. Yaraskavitch
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Noble liquid scintillators, and liquid argon in particular,present a potentially disruptive alternative to conventionalradiation detectors, offering several distinct advantages. One of its most valuable features is the ability to efficiently distinguish between hadronic (neutron) and electromagnetic (gamma) interactions using pulse-shape discrimination (PSD) of the scintillation light. This capability makes these type of detectors particularly well-suited for identifying complex, mixedfield radiation sources, including special nuclear materials. Additionally, liquid argon detectors are highly scalable, allowing for the construction of large-volume systems. The combination of broad detection coverage and strong neutron/gamma discrimination positions this technology as a compelling candidate for radiation portal monitors (RPMs) and a wide range of nuclear security applications,including safeguards and non-proliferation. A Liquid Argon Radiation Monitor (ALARM) is a prototype detector developed at Canadian Nuclear Laboratories, targeting nuclear safety and security applications. In this contribution, we present a detailed description of the detector system and its performance in the detection of gamma-rays and fast neutrons. Excellent separation between gamma rays and neutrons from a <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{252} \text{Cf}$</tex> source was obtained, demonstrating the potential of this detector technology.

title: Monte Carlo Simulation of Cherenkov-Radiator-Integrated MCP-PMT with Full Modeling of Optics and Waveform
authors: T. Ishikawa, R. Ota, H.G. Kang, F. Nishikido, H. Haneishi, T. Yamaya
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: In positron emission tomography (PET), time-of flight (TOF) information partially localizes source positions along lines of response. Cherenkov-radiator-integrated microchannel-plate photomultiplier tubes (CRI-MCP-PMTs) have achieved 30 ps coincidence time resolution (CTR). Precise simulation modeling is necessary to optimize design of CRI-MCP-PMTs for practical use in TOF-PET systems. In this study, we developed a Geant4 Monte Carlo simulation model of a CRI-MCP-PMT with detailed parameters. The detector geometry and photocathode material were determined based on the commercially available MCP-PMT (R3809U-50, Hamamatsu Photonics K. K.), and a 3.2 mm -thick lead fluoride crystal was used as a Cherenkov radiator. Our model incorporated single photon time resolution (25 ps full width half maximum (FWHM)), measured single photon waveform, electrical noise, and fluctuation of the waveform amplitude to generate an analog output signal for timing pick-off. The waveform amplitude fluctuation and electrical noise were modeled with Gaussian functions based on the measured data. We scanned the pulse area window and threshold level of the constant fraction timing to obtain the best CTR. As a result, the simulated CTR was improved as the pulse area increased and the timing pick-off threshold decreased; the best CTR was 29.6 ps FWHM. This result showed good agreement with the experimental result of 30.1 ps previously obtained with almost the same parameters. Our simulator enabled generation of the analog output signal for timing pick-off using the selected CRI-MCP-PMT, which is useful for the design optimization of ultrafast TOF-PET detectors using CRI-MCP-PMTs.
