title: N2PW: Research on Service Composition Method Based on Node Mining and Pointer Network
authors: Xueqi Jiang, Zhichun Jia, Xing Xing
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: As an advanced method for combining various services to fulfill intricate functional and non-functional requirements, service composition has garnered widespread interest in recent studies. Traditional service composition methods usually overlook the deep connections between services and tasks and cannot effectively utilize the historical composition experience of low-frequency services. To overcome the identified limitations, this work presents a new service composition strategy, N2PW. Firstly, a detailed service task association graph is constructed through node mining to accurately locate the potential connections between services. Then, an initial solution is constructed via a two-layer pointer network (2PN) to enhance the algorithm’s generalization ability and solution efficiency. Finally, the algorithm leverages the local exploitation ability of WOA to optimize the initial solution, further improving the utilization efficiency of low frequency services. Results confirm that the proposed technique outperforms conventional methods with respect to both the quality of solutions and the efficiency of composition.

title: A Breast PET/MRI Insert Integrated into a Whole-Body PET/MR: Design Concept, Evaluation of current Limitations for Breast Imaging and MR Compatibility Considerations
authors: J. Hohnholz, L. U. Rauscher, M. Judenhofer, E. Olyaei, H. P. Vo, C. la Fougère, M. Rafecas, B. Pichler, F. P. Schmidt
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We are developing a PET/MR breast insert to be integrated into the Biograph mMR (Siemens Healthineers) whole-body PET/MR to improve diagnostics in hybrid breast imaging. The insert comprises two cylinders <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$(\boldsymbol{\varnothing}=175 \text{mm}$</tex>, height <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$=95 \text{mm})$</tex> with 64 crystal blocks arranged in five rings. A dual-layer, depth-of-interaction capable configuration with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$10 \times 10 / 9 \times 9$</tex> LSO crystals with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.6 \times 1.6 \times 9.8 / 5.2 \text{mm}^{3}$</tex> ensures uniform resolution. The need for this high-resolution/sensitivity insert was underlined by a breast cancer case, where sequential [<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${}^{18}$</tex> F]FDG scans in identical prone positioning on the mMR and a high sensitivity total-body (TB) PET system showed lower image noise on the latter, however, a higher spatial resolution could be beneficial for lesion visualization. To assess limitations of current systems, a F-18 filled phantom (spheres <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\varnothing=3.90-7.82 \text{mm}$</tex> mimicking breast lesions, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4: 1$</tex> contrast) was scanned on the mMR, a TB-PET scanner, and a high-resolution preclinical PET/CT. In simulated scans at a typical breast position (offcenter), spheres <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$<6.2 \text{mm}$</tex> were not detectable (mMR), with image noise increasing from <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5. 9} \boldsymbol{\%}$</tex> to 8.9% and contrast recovery degraded by <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 6 \%} \boldsymbol{(} \mathbf{7. 8 m m}$</tex> sphere) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2 \%} \boldsymbol{(} \mathbf{6. 2 m m} \boldsymbol{)}$</tex> due to parallax error. High contrast and resolvability of the 3.90 mm sphere was only enabled by the small crystal preclinical system - confirming the need for a breast insert. Operation of two detector units within the mMR was feasible and preliminary MRI compatibility tests attest stability of flood maps, count rate, and timing/energy spectra while stressed with various sequences e.g. indicated by a comparable energy resolution of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5. 9} \boldsymbol{\pm} \mathbf{0. 9} \boldsymbol{\%}$</tex> (reference), <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5. 8} \boldsymbol{\pm} \mathbf{1. 1 \%}$</tex> (gradient switching), <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 6. 1} \boldsymbol{\pm} \mathbf{1. 0 \%}$</tex> (RF pulse emission, FA: <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 8 0}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$</tex>) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 5. 6} \boldsymbol{\pm} \mathbf{0. 8 \%}$</tex> (spin echo (SE), FA:90 <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${}^{\boldsymbol{\circ}}$</tex>). Bo homogeneity was stable (0.254 ppm), SNR and image homogeneity (SE) was 18%/81% (without) and 19%/83% (with detectors). Ongoing work focuses on advanced shielding/RF filter to minimize interference close to a MR breast coil.

title: Analytical Upper Bound on the Intensity of Cherenkov Radiation at a Planar Interface Between Media
authors: Anatoliy Poyedinchuk, Nataliya Yashina, Kostyantyn Sirenko, Petro Melezhik
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: This work focuses on one specific aspect of phenomena associated with the electromagnetic radiation generated when a plane, density-modulated electron beam moves parallel to a vacuum-medium interface. In the considered case of a planar interface, such an electron beam gives rise to Cherenkov radiation. Within this configuration, by means of an exact analytical approach, we have derived an upper bound for the intensity of Cherenkov radiation. This theoretical finding is corroborated by the presented results of numerical experiments, which match the predicted intensity limit across a range of beam parameters and material properties. Obtaining a closed-form analytical solution to an electromagnetic problem of this complexity is quite rear and thus constitutes a significant result. Not only it deepens our understanding of diffraction radiation phenomena, but also provides a rigorous benchmark for testing and validating various numerical methods.

title: A Post-Processing Verifier-Reranker Architecture for Efficient Hallucination Reduction in Generative Question Answering
authors: Jessie Natalie Wibowo, Guruh Fajar Shidik, Amalia Putri Dwi Mareta, Edi Jaya Kusuma
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Generative Question Answering (QA) models often "hallucinate," producing factually incorrect content, a critical issue for real-world reliability. This problem is particularly acute for unanswerable questions, where models invent answers instead of admitting ignorance. To address this, we introduce a lightweight Generator-Verifier-Reranker pipeline. Our post-processing framework uses a FLAN-T5 model to generate answer candidates, which are then validated by an efficient S-BERT verifier that measures semantic similarity against the source context. A reranker then sorts the verified candidates. Experiments on the SQuAD 2.0, the method achieves a 57.3% Exact Match score at a 0.75 similarity threshold, balancing precision and recall. Results demonstrate significant reductions in false positives, offering a practical solution for deployable, reliable QA systems in resource-constrained environments.

title: An Experimental Study on SQL Query Structure Optimization Performance in MySQL, PostgreSQL, and Microsoft SQL Server Using Apache JMeter
authors: Gladys Tanujaya, Suryasari
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on New Media Studies (CONMEDIA)
abstract: Nowadays, businesses generate large volumes of data that must be stored in a reliable database. Among the available options, relational database management systems (RDBMS) are widely adopted across organizations. This study uses transaction data from PT. GKT and applies the Database System Development Lifecycle (DSDLC) with a bottom-up approach, evaluating performance with Apache JMeter. Benchmarking focuses on response time, throughput, and error rate as captured by the Summary Report listener. The results show that Microsoft SQL Server provides the best performance for unoptimized queries, whereas after optimization PostgreSQL achieves lower response times, higher throughput, and fewer errors under light workloads; however, Microsoft SQL Server remains superior as the number of threads increases.

title: A Broadband Ultrasensitive Gamma Imager (BUGI) Technology for Simultaneous PET-SPECT Imaging
authors: L. Cai, S. Aggarwal, Y. Chen, S. Komarov, D. Thorek, A.K. Jha, Y.-C. Tai
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Alpha-emitting radiopharmaceutical therapy (α RPT) delivers high-LET radiation to induce DNA double-strand breaks in metastatic prostate cancer. Tumor resistance may arise through PARP upregulation, making PARP-PET imaging a valuable non-invasive tool to assess DNA repair and guide personalized αRPT.

title: Epitrochoids in Goniometry and the Possibility of their Experimental Diagnostics
authors: Alexey Kiryanov, Valeriy Kiryanov
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: In a number of works by the authors of the report, a hypothesis was put forward that in the presence of a dynamic imbalance in the rotation unit of an image generator with circular scanning, parasitic oscillations of the rotor axis of its precision spindle may occur with a high probability. The probable trajectories of the movement of a spot of focused laser radiation along the surface of an object during the synthesis of precision structures are associated with a family of curves, which in mathematics and mechanics have received the common name of epitrochoids. The report analyzes the issues of experimental confirmation of the stated assumptions about the forms of the most probable trajectories of the spot's movement. The report claims that recently published results by researchers from the renowned German metrology institute (PTB, Braunschweig, Germany) actually demonstrate loop-like patterns in the recorded trajectories of parasitic movements of the rotor axis of the spindle of the precision angular comparator WMT-220, characteristic of the so-called shortened epitrochoids. The sizes of the recorded parasitic structures are at the level of several nanometers.

title: GRU-PatchTST-Based Feedforward Compensation for High-Precision Motion Control
authors: Zongwei Tian, Fan Yang, Jixing Jiang, Jialing Du, Fanxing Li, Wei Yan
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: To provide the wafer stage with a motion control method that ensures both excellent tracking accuracy and strong generalization capability, a neural network-based feedforward control strategy is proposed that employs a gated recurrent unit-patch long term transformer network (GRU-PatchTST) to accurately predict feedforward compensation signals. First, a GRU-PatchTST network is constructed, which utilizes data collected from the wafer stage to precisely predict the feedforward compensation term corresponding to the reference trajectory. Essentially, the GRU-PatchTST network can be regarded as a data-driven model that accurately characterizes the inverse dynamics of the system, thereby serving as an effective feedforward controller. Comparative experiments demonstrate the effectiveness of the prediction capability of the GRU-PatchTST and verify the superior tracking performance of the proposed feedforward control method. The proposed approach not only achieves control accuracy comparable to iterative learning control but also eliminates the need for a cumbersome iterative process. The optimal feedforward compensation term can be obtained from a single rediction, which highlights the practical applicability of the method.

title: Non-autoregressive Any to Many Voice Conversion
authors: Yansen Zhou, Lejun Peng, Qi Chen
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Computer Science and Network Technology (ICCSNT)
abstract: The voice conversion (VC) model based on autoregression has favorable performance in predicting the Mel spectrum. However, predicting the Mel spectrum of the current frame relies on the Mel spectrum of the previous frame, which results in slower prediction speed and potential frame duplication or omission. In view of the above problems, a non-autoregressive voice conversion model based on Transformer is proposed. The model is mainly composed of multi-head self-attention and Conv1D, which effectively improves the training speed of the model and the speed of predicting the Mel spectrum. However, the model has many problems, such as a large number of parameters and high memory occupation. Aiming at the problems of the Transformer model, a voice conversion model based on the gated attention unit (GAU) is proposed. The gated attention unit integrates the gated linear unit (GLU) and the self-attention mechanism. Compared with the Transformer model, the model has fewer parameters, lower memory occupation, and faster training speed. The subjective and objective evaluation of the two proposed models is carried out on the CSTR VCTK and CMU ARCTIC speech data sets. The experimental results indicate that the proposed two models have faster training speed, faster prediction speed, and more stable prediction quality while ensuring the quality of the Mel spectrum.

title: Detecting Allusions in the Karakalpak Language Using mBERT
authors: Davlatyor Mengliev, Raima Shirinova, Temur Khudayberganov, Shaxnoza Abdukayumova, Xilola Yunusova, Intizor Djumaniyazova
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This paper investigates the problem of allusion detection in Karakalpak texts using neural network technologies such as mBERT. Although this problem has been studied well enough for such world languages as English, Russian, Chinese, etc., there are almost no studies for low-resource languages. The proposed solution includes not only the preparation of a language model, but also the formation of a corpus of literary texts from more than 5,000 sentences. To prevent overfitting, an early stopping mechanism was used, which allowed us to identify the most optimal model indicators. Empirical results on two different test sets show that the model works reliably on literary texts, but demonstrates a noticeable drop in performance when working with texts of various topics. In addition, a comparative analysis of existing solutions is carried out in order to emphasize the relevance of the work done. Moreover, the authors note that they plan to expand the dataset with a variety of literary topics, as well as informal genre texts, in order to further actualize the developed solution in applied.

title: QoS-Driven Resource Allocation in LEO Satellite Edge Computing System
authors: Zhixin Zhan, Min Wu, Jiayang Li, Yongqi Teng, Qi Su
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: As the pace of deployment of large-scale low-orbit satellite systems continue to accelerate, how to efficiently use this new network architecture to provide edge computing power has became a core issue of concern in industry and academia. Different from traditional terrestrial communication networks, LEO satellite networks, with the unique spatial coverage advantages, can provide a near-instantaneous response of high-bandwidth computing and storage resources for users in any corner of the world, showing great application potential. However, the current research on edge computing in LEO satellite networks are generally based on the idealized assumption that each satellite is equipped with standardized computing resources and service capabilities. This assumption will not only lead to a significant increase in the initial construction cost, but also may lead to unnecessary redundancy and over-allocation of resources. To solve this problem and achieve efficient and low-cost utilization of computing resources at the edge of LEO satellite networks, this study focuses on the optimal design of server placement strategies. Specifically, we aim to meet the service while avoiding resource wastage by carefully selecting a subset of satellites as server nodes. On this basis, this study deepens and expands the previous research results by innovatively abstracting the LEO satellite network into a 2D ring topology model, which is closer to the actual deployment scenarios and provides a solid theoretical foundation for the subsequent analyses. Furthermore, we extend and optimize the discrete resource allocation method under the constraint of Quality of Service(QoS). The method comprehensively considers multiple factors, such as user distribution, service demand, satellite orbit characteristics and resource cost, and iteratively searches for the optimal or near-optimal server placement scheme through algorithms.

title: Microscopic Identification of Bursaphelenchus xylophilus via Deep Learning with Key Feature Extraction
authors: Yifeng Zhu, Kaiwei Yu, Yufei Wang, Xiaofeng An
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Bursaphelenchus xylophilus (pine wood nematode, PWN) is a major threat to global forest ecosystems and forestry economies, yet it remains difficult to accurately distinguish from the morphologically similar Bursaphelenchus mucronatus under microscopy. To address the limitations of traditional morphology-based diagnosis, which relies heavily on expert experience, and the high cost of molecular detection, this study proposes a “two-stage + dual-ROI” framework. In the first stage, YOLOv12 is employed to detect adult females and crop the tail and vulval flap regions. In the second stage, CoAtNet is applied to perform fine-grained classification on reconstructed images with fused features, enabling integration of complementary local information. Experimental results show that YOLOv12 achieved an mAP@0.5 of 0.995 in nematode body detection, maintaining overall stability despite challenges in small-object recognition. For classification, CoAtNet achieved an accuracy of $94.00 \%$, a precision of $94.80 \%$, a recall of $93.05 \%$, an $\mathbf{F 1}$-score of $93.86 \%$, and an AUC of 0.96, demonstrating strong discriminative capability. Ablation studies further confirmed the essential role of object detection and dual-ROI complementarity. In summary, the proposed approach effectively combines morphological priors with deep feature representations, providing a feasible solution for rapid identification of PWN and supporting forestry quarantine.

authors: Ron B. Goldfarb

title: AI-Powered IoT Security: Multi-Dataset Evaluation of a Deep Learning Intrusion Detection Framework
authors: Salahaldeen Duraibi, Saahira banu Ahamed, A.Salman Maricar
publish: 2025 IEEE International Carnahan Conference on Security Technology (ICCST)
abstract: Due to the fast growth of the Internet of Things (IoT), which has caused major security problems, more advanced Intrusion Detection Systems (IDS) are needed to find new cyber threats. This paper proposes an optimized Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) for IoT security as part of an improved deep learning (DL) framework. Unlike most IDS models, this framework uses Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE) to choose the best features is employed for classification. This step makes sure that the best input is used. In addition, this hyperparameters optimization, includes adjusting critical parameters including learning rate, dropout rates, kernel size, and activation functions, to get the best possible detection accuracy. To improve transparency, this work uses a type of Explainable AI (XAI) called Shapley Additive Explanations (SHAP) to figure out what the model said and highlight the most important features for finding attacks. The proposed CNN-based IDS do better than other machine learning (ML) models on two benchmark datasets, such as UNSW-NB15 and CICIDS2017. With improved accuracy, recall, and F1-score, the proposed optimized CNN framework is a reliable and scalable option for practical IoT security applications, according to experimental findings.

title: Exposing and Mitigating Adversarial AI Threats in IoT/5G Intrusion Detection Systems Using Random Forest and Feature Reduction
authors: Harika Rama Tulasi Karatapu, Shafeeq Ur Rahaman, Sudheer Patchipulusu
publish: 2025 IEEE International Carnahan Conference on Security Technology (ICCST)
abstract: The proliferation of Internet of Things (IoT) and 5G networks has dramatically expanded the attack surface for cyber threats, necessitating intelligent and scalable intrusion detection systems (IDS). This study investigates the performance and adversarial robustness of a Random Forest (RF) classifier in detecting botnet-based intrusions across diverse IoT telemetry domains. A balanced training dataset was utilized to develop an initial RF model, achieving a near-perfect out-of-bag error rate of 0.14%. Feature importance analysis revealed that packet ordering and connection-level metrics were the most predictive features. To improve generalization and reduce model complexity, Recursive Feature Elimination (RFE) was employed which identified a three-feature subset that maintained high classification performance (Accuracy: 99.73%, Kappa: 0.9946). A defensive RF model trained on this minimal feature space exhibited excellent sensitivity and specificity on internal and external test sets. However, a significant drop in precision across domains (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{1 2 \%}$</tex>) indicated a high false positive rate, particularly when evaluated on datasets with benign-majority labels, revealing an aggressive bias in attack prediction. Adversarial robustness was evaluated using the HopSkipJump (HSJ) black-box attack. The RF classifier failed to detect any of the adversarial perturbed attack samples, resulting in 0% accuracy, precision, and recall. These findings expose a critical vulnerability in decision-tree-based IDS models when exposed to decision-boundary manipulation. In conclusion, while Random Forest classifiers demonstrate high baseline accuracy in detecting IoT-based intrusions, they remain highly susceptible to adversarial evasion. The study emphasizes the need for incorporating adversarial defenses such as robust training, input preprocessing and hybrid architectures in future IDS design to safeguard evolving 5G-enabled infrastructures. The findings advocate for a shift toward adversarially-aware machine learning pipelines in security-critical environments.

title: Factors Influencing Blockchain Adoption Intention among MSME in Jakarta
authors: Fiandry Jeremy, Tuga Mauritsius
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: Blockchain is a transformative innovation of technology that offers benefits from its use such as increased transparency, security, and efficiency. However, its adoption by Micro, Small, and Medium Enterprises (MSMEs) in developing countries like Indonesia remains under-researched. This study analyzes the intention of MSMEs to adopt blockchain technology in Jakarta, Indonesia by utilizing the Technology-Organization-Environment (TOE) model along with institutional factors. A quantitative survey in the form of questionnaire regarding these variables, consisting of 27 questions using a likert scale, involving 100 MSME owners and managers of various industries, shows that Top Management Support (β=0.716) and Competitive Pressure (β=0.155) are the most influential factors driving blockchain adoption. Relative Advantages and Regulation and Legislation have smaller but significant effects while Technological Readiness does not show significance. This suggests that for Jakarta's MSMEs, strategic leadership and market dynamics currently outweigh internal technological capabilities in the decision-making process. The model explains 99.2% of the variation in adoption intention highlighting the significance of leadership commitment, market-driven strategies, and regulatory clarity to drive blockchain adoption. By filling the research gap regarding blockchain adoption in MSMEs in developing countries, this study offers practical insights for MSME owners and policymakers to foster an ecosystem that encourages technological innovation in Indonesia.

title: A Meta-heuristic Method for Cumulative Vehicle Routing Problem
authors: Adrain Jun Hong Lim, Yit Yin Wee
publish: 2025 8th International Conference on New Media Studies (CONMEDIA)
abstract: Vehicle routing problems (VRPs) have long been a key area of research in logistics, but their relevance has grown considerably in the post-COVID-19 era due to the increasing demand for efficient and cost-effective delivery services. Among the various extensions of the classical capacitated VRP, the Cumulative Vehicle Routing Problem (Cum-VRP) introduces cumulative constraints that substantially increase the problem’s complexity. Tackling such challenges necessitates advanced optimisation methods capable of producing high-quality solutions within practical computational times. Although heuristic techniques are frequently employed, they often become impractical for large-scale instances. In this study, the Artificial Bee Colony (ABC) algorithm is enhanced through the incorporation of local search strategies and neighbourhood operators to address the Cum-VRP effectively. Comparative experiments against the Variable Neighbourhood Search (VNS) algorithm demonstrate the superiority of the proposed ABC approach, delivering improvements in solution quality, computational efficiency, and feasibility.

title: Analysis of the Effect of Dielectric Substrate Material on the Performance of Multiconductor Stripline Protection Devices
authors: Valerii Kosteletskii, Alexander Lakoza
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: In this paper the effect of dielectric substrate material on the performance of protective devices is assessed. The substrate materials were selected based on their commercial availability from printed circuit board manufacturers. This study establishes the dependencies of the device performance on the substrate material properties. The analysis includes RT/Duroid 5870 (with a relative permittivity, ε<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r1</inf> = 2.3), FR4 (ε<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r1</inf> = 4.6), WL-CT615 (ε<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r1</inf> = 6.15), TP720 (ε<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r1</inf> = 7.2), FSD1020T (ε<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r1</inf> = 10.2), TP1600 (ε<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r1</inf> = 16), TLX2200H (ε<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r1</inf> = 22), and TP2500 (ε<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r1</inf> = 25). It was found that materials with a higher ϵr are preferable; however, their available thicknesses do not provide significant attenuation. The FSD1020T material, with ε<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">r1</inf> = 10.2 and a thickness h1 = 0.254 mm, was identified as the most suitable for both structures. Simulations with these parameters showed that for the 6-conductor structure, the maximum voltage (U<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</inf>) was 0.062 V in common mode and 0.061 V in differential operation of a transmission line, which is 8 times lower than half the electromotive force. For the 8-conductor structure, U<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">max</inf> was 0.054 V in common mode and 0.114 V in differential mode, corresponding to a reduction of 9.2 and 4.38 times, respectively, compared to half the electromotive force.

title: ACA-IMTG: Adversarial Causal Augmentation for Imbalanced Multi-Aspect Text Generation
authors: Yaojie Zhang, Peiguo Lin, Bo Hu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Multi-Aspect Controllable Text Generation aims to control generated text attributes across multiple dimensions, such as “positive/negative” (sentiment), “technology/sports” (topic), and “detoxification” (content). To ease training sample acquisition, existing works usually reuse single-attribute annotated datasets, ignoring attribute correlations from mutual entanglement between attributes. Notably, imbalanced attribute co-occurrence in real data leads to stereotypical biases, which significantly harm the effectiveness of multi-aspect control. This paper proposes ACA-IMTG, a novel method adopting an adversarial causal augmentation strategy. It generates counterfactual feature vectors for attributes via an adversarial causal mechanism to alleviate imbalanced attribute co-occurrence during attribute representation learning, thereby enhancing low-frequency attribute combination representation. Experiments show ACAIMTG matches current state-of-the-art baselines in both imbalanced and balanced attribute co-occurrence scenarios, while effectively mitigating attribute imbalance-induced stereotypical biases and improving model generalization.

title: Computational Efficiency of an Artificial Neural Network in Calculating the Rresonant Frequencies of Patch Antennas
authors: Serhiy Butov, Vladimir R. Tuz
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: This paper explores the impact of artificial neural network architectural and training parameters on the accuracy and convergence of resonance frequency prediction for rectangular patch antennas. A series of experiments were conducted where key parameters, such as the number of hidden layers, neurons per layer, batch size, and optimizer, were systematically varied. The goal is to determine which configurations provide the best balance between prediction accuracy and training efficiency. The results demonstrate that neural networks can effectively approximate the resonant frequency based on physical antenna dimensions and material properties, while also highlighting configurations that either hinder or improve generalization. These findings contribute to the optimization of machine learning models for electromagnetic structure analysis.

title: A New Protocol for Modeling Human Factors in B2B E-commerce Projects: A Multi-Case Study Based on Experimental Observations
authors: Stéphane Nimsgern, Olivier Kubler, Chaima Khalfaoui, Manal Ratnane
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: This paper explores the contribution of human factors to performance in B2B e-commerce projects, where success increasingly depends on organizational coordination and interpersonal dynamics. Despite their critical role, human factors are often excluded from decision-support systems due to their perceived heterogeneity and subjectivity. We address this gap through a multi-case experimental study grounded in the hypothesis that human factors function as interdependent variables with measurable effects on project outcomes. A structured protocol was applied across five real-world B2B e-commerce projects, combining qualitative observations and evaluation metrics. Human factors were categorized into experience-based and behavioral dimensions, then tracked longitudinally and analyzed through co-occurrence mapping. Results validate the hypothesis, confirming that human factors form observable interaction patterns that influence project performance. These findings support the integration of human dimensions into formal project governance models and decision-support systems, offering a foundation for future interdisciplinary research bridging organizational behav-ior and systems engineering.

title: Intelligent Interfaces and Their Application in Rehabilitation Systems for Patients with Limited Mobility
authors: Eldar A. Magerramov, Valery D. Yurkevich
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The purpose of this article is to conduct a review analysis of intelligent interfaces used in rehabilitation systems and assistive technologies for patients with upper limb impairments. The review covers the main classes of interfaces: voice, switches and sip-and-puff, gaze and head movement tracking systems, myoelectric and neurointerfaces, and telerehabilitation. Particular attention is paid to the concept of shared control, which reduces cognitive load and increases the reliability of human- device interaction. An analysis of recent publications shows the active development of intelligent technologies, but reveals a lack of randomised clinical trials, limited reproducibility of results, and a shortage of assistive devices focused on the upper limbs. Additionally, barriers to implementation are highlighted: insufficient digital literacy of users, fatigue when using interfaces, and a high probability of abandoning assistive technologies in the absence of support service. Based on the identified gaps in the literature, a task is formulated to develop a concept for a multimodal interface that combines voice input with alternative control channels.

title: Machine Learning Methods for Particle Identification in a TPC
authors: Haozhi Wei, Yuanfan Chen, Tianzhu Yin, Yanming Loong
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: In this article, three machine learning methods: Gradient Boosting Classifier, k-means clustering algorithm and Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) are introduced to identify particles in a TPC. After using the Bethe-Bloch function for curve fitting to obtain the characteristics of different particles, machine learning methods are applied to identify particle types by measuring physical quantities like energy loss rate dE/dx and particle momentum P. By processing the sPhoenix simulation data, the results show that our methods are effective and workable.

title: GAIN: GATv2-based Adaptive Framework for Innovative Topic Mining in Patent Knowledge Graphs
authors: Chunhui Wang, Yuheng Li, Ning Luo
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: With the exponential growth of scientific and technological patents, efficiently identifying key “technical topic” nodes in large-scale patent knowledge graphs is crucial for enhancing research decision-making. To address this, we propose GAIN: a GATv2-based Adaptive Framework for Innovative Topic Mining in Patent Knowledge Graphs. GAIN tackles challenges such as high computational complexity in graph robustness calculations, the limitations of traditional centrality measures in heterogeneous graphs, and inadequate semantic differentiation in existing graph neural networks (GNNs). The framework integrates GATv2 with graph robustness metrics, incorporates a dynamic hop mechanism and DiGRAF adaptive activation function to improve node embedding, and uses changes in graph robustness as a supervisory signal for ranking-based optimization. Experimental results on four real-world patent knowledge graphs (AD-KG, ML-KG, CS-KG, AI-KG) show that GAIN outperforms existing methods in Top- 5% node identification accuracy, achieving up to 96.65%, while also demonstrating scalability and inductive capability. GAIN provides an efficient, accurate, and interpretable solution for key node identification in complex heterogeneous graphs.

title: Machine Learning for Dynamic Price Adjustments in Digital Marketing
authors: Ihor Ponomarenko, Volodymyr Pavlenko, Olena Bondarenko, Oksana Morhulets, Dmytro Ponomarenko, Maryna Melnyk
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The peculiarities of artificial intelligence and machine learning algorithms development in modern minds have been observed. The importance of the influx of hardware and software in the evolution of mathematical algorithms that are used for processing and analyzing big data has been brought to light. The importance of globalization and digitalization influx on the business environment in the countries of the world has been established. It has been proven that innovative technologies lead to a transformation in marketing and the need for modernization of current marketing tools. Digital marketing is an effective way to establish close and long-term communication with the target audience. A significant number of current generations (Y, Z, and Alpha) actively use the Internet and buy various goods and services from the digital environment. The relationship between digital marketing and e-commerce, with the method of increasing sales on the Internet, is described. The importance of developing dynamic pricing in modern minds has been brought to the fore, and the main types of economic activity in which automated systems for setting prices are presented. It is indicated that machine learning algorithms will be used to determine the effectiveness of dynamic pricing systems. The Internet serves as a medium for collecting diverse data that is used in the implementation of various machine learning algorithms. The research included detailed information about the price dynamics of the Apple iPhone 16 Pro Max 256GB (premium segment) and the Motorola Moto G04 (economy segment). With the help of a parser, relevant data was collected on a price aggregator, transformed based on feature engineering, and various machine-learning algorithms were implemented. It was found that the CatBoost approach allows one to obtain the best results for price modeling. For each smartphone model, the quality of the resulting CatBoost model was assessed based on quality metrics. It has been established that for the Apple iPhone 16 Pro Max 256GB the results are more accurate, which is explained by the presence of a large array of data. The research also included information about the flagship smartphone model from Apple, which is highly popular among people living in Ukraine. Highly based on the presented model of calls for a large number of proposals on the price aggregator, which made it possible to provide a clear database of prices.

title: Research on Active Control Techniques of Laser Communication Transmitters for Atmospheric Turbulence Mitigation
authors: Honghuan Ji, Xiaonan Yu, Chao Dai
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: With the increasing demand for wireless communication and the growing scarcity of spectral resources, Free-Space Optical (FSO) communication has attracted significant attention as a solution offering high bandwidth and low latency. However, FSO systems are susceptible to atmospheric conditions and other interfering factors, which lead to fluctuations in signal quality and transmission distance. To achieve reliable optical communication, atmospheric turbulence suppression techniques have become crucial.This paper aims to investigate an active control method for mitigating atmospheric turbulence based on laser communication transmitters to optimize the performance of FSO systems. We analyze the characteristics of the atmospheric transmission channel and the light intensity attenuation model to establish a system framework. Furthermore, an active control approach utilizing the laser transmitter is proposed to suppress atmospheric turbulence. This method employs a feedback mechanism from a bidirectional transceiver system to adjust the transmit power in real-time, adapting to varying channel conditions and transmission distances.Experimental results demonstrate that under conditions of weak atmospheric turbulence, the scintillation index can effectively reflect the intensity of turbulence. After activating the active control of the laser transmitter, the scintillation index decreased from 0.067 to 0.033, and the system’s bit error rate (BER) was reduced by two orders of magnitude. Extensive tests ultimately verified that the active control method of the laser transmitter can effectively mitigate atmospheric turbulence by suppressing the fluctuation of optical power caused by turbulence during atmospheric propagation. Consequently, it maximizes signal quality and transmission range, enabling the system to cope with changes in atmospheric conditions and variations in communication distance. This approach significantly enhances the stability and reliability of the communication system.

title: A Hybrid CBAM-Vision Transformer for Enhanced Classification of Retinal Diseases in Optical Coherence Tomography Imagery
authors: Najma Amira Mumtaz, Ardytha Luthfiarta, Adhitya Nugraha, Ika Novita Dewi, Ulima Muna Syarifah, Dzawil Uqul
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Timely and accurate diagnosis of retinal diseases from Optical Coherence Tomography images is crucial for preventing irreversible vision loss, yet automated classification is challenged by low image resolution and significant class imbalance in public datasets such as OCTMNIST. While Vision Transformers offer a powerful alternative to traditional models, their application to these specific challenges, particularly when enhanced with targeted attention mechanisms, remains underexplored. This research addresses this gap by developing and validating a robust classification model that enhances ViT-tiny architecture with a Convolutional Block Attention Module (CBAM) to improve diagnostic accuracy. Our methodology integrates CBAM to refine feature embeddings, which are then optimized using a full fine-tuning strategy, weighted cross-entropy loss to counteract class imbalance, and on-the-fly data augmentation. The proposed CBAM-ViT model established a new state-of-the-art performance on the OCTMNIST test set, achieving an accuracy of 86.40%, a macro F1-score of 85.97%, and a mean Area Under the ROC Curve (mAUC) of 0.9760, surpassing both a baseline ViT and previously published benchmarks. These findings demonstrate that integrating a CBAM attention mechanism into a fully fine-tuned ViT provides a highly effective strategy for classifying low-resolution, imbalanced medical images, establishing a new, robust performance benchmark and highlighting the value of hybrid attention architectures for challenging diagnostic tasks.

title: Using of Chernov Face Diagrams to Identify Incorrect Results of Experimental Research
authors: Andrew V. Goonko, Yakov S. Kutovenko, Gennady V. Seroklinov
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The paper, which is part of a study on the development of a method for phenotyping wheat varieties based on measuring the biopotentials of their seedlings, addresses the problem of preparing a data set by excluding incorrect values from the results obtained during experimental studies. In addition to the results of sample clustering, the possibility of using data mining by visualizing the results by a method known as "Chernov faces" to identify significantly different results of biopotential measurements is being investigated. The reasons leading to obtaining incorrect data, typical for this method and the automated system of experimental studies, are briefly indicated, a description of the diagrams used for visualization is presented, the results of the study and their analysis are presented. It is concluded that it is possible, with some limitations, to apply the described approach. Studies have been carried out to optimize the amount of data taken for visualization by Chernov’s face diagrams. Methods are proposed for modifying the program used for research in Python, as well as other approaches to solving the problem of identifying incorrect results of experimental research. To improve the considered method of preparing data for plant phenotyping, the direction of further research to identify incorrect results has been determined.

title: Analyzing the Characteristics of a Differential Transmission Line with Single Modal Reservation Before and After Failures
authors: Sergey Vlasov, Sergey Morozov
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Differential transmission lines, commonly used in high-speed data interfaces such as USB and low-voltage differential signaling, are susceptible to electromagnetic interference. This includes ultra-wideband and narrow-band interferences, which can disrupt data transmission. A technique called modal reservation is used to address this issue. It involves placing a redundant transmission line next to the primary one, creating strong electromagnetic coupling between them and effectively filtering out ultra-wideband and narrow-band interferences. This significantly increases the resistance of data transmission to these disturbances. However, articles on devices using differential transmission lines or differential transmission lines with modal reservation have not yet reported measurements of their performance after failure. Therefore, this paper presents pre- and post-failure measurements of a single- modal reservation differential transmission lines device. Electrodynamic simulations in the frequency domain show that the passband shift after failure does not exceed 2%. In the time domain, ultra-wideband and narrow-band interference changes after failure is less than 1.1%. Signal integrity analysis shows that signal-noise ratio increases from 19.234 under no-fault conditions to 22.153 under short-circuit conditions, indicating increased immunity to interference. Quasi-static simulations validate these findings, revealing discrepancies of no more than 7% in time-domain measurements and less than 3% in frequency-domain measurements. These results indicate that ultra-wideband and narrow-band interferences do not affect the operation of differential transmission lines -based systems, making them highly resistant to these disturbances.

title: Features of the Implementation of an Obstacle Detection System for the Blind
authors: Viktor Smirnov, Andrey Nikulin, Anna Kazmina
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This paper presents an improved version of an assistant device for the blind and visually impaired. The device allows blind and visually impaired people to navigate in space, which reduces the risk of injury and promotes social integration. The work provides a comprehensive solution to the key problems of previous prototypes: low efficiency in recognizing small ground-level obstacles, short battery life, and significant vibrational interference affecting sensor accuracy. Solutions developed and experimentally tested include optimization of the component base to reduce power consumption, the use of constructive damping for the vibration motor, and the creation of an ergonomic housing with a pistol grip. The proposed approaches reduced vibration interference affecting the gyroscope by up to 15 times, increased battery capacity to 5000 mAh, and extended operation time from 40 minutes to 5 hours. The results demonstrate a significant increase in the reliability, autonomy, and usability of the device, confirming the practical value of the proposed engineering solutions.

title: Mathematical Models of Centrifugal Compressor and Anti-Surge Methods
authors: Denys Tomin, Alina Kazurova, Kostiantyn Sknar, Yevhen Potapenko, Iryna Meleshko
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The paper discusses methods of mathematical modeling of the surge mode in centrifugal compressors, which is one of the most serious problems that can disrupt their stable operation. Various approaches to modeling are described, including an improved Moore-Greitzer model. Particular attention is paid to the application of computational fluid dynamics (CFD), machine learning and fuzzy logic methods for predicting and preventing surge. It is shown that the integration of various modeling approaches allows increasing the reliability and stability of compressor operation, as well as minimizing the risk of surge. The article also discusses the limitations of the proposed models and prospects for further research to create more accurate and adaptive solutions. The presented findings are of great practical importance for improving the efficiency and safety of centrifugal compressors in industrial conditions.

title: CodeCrafters: Game-Driven Learning for Web Design Beginners
authors: Harwin C. Mendoza, Adrian Lee G. Magcalas, Ronielle B. Antonio, Rafaela Mae M. Landayan, Edward Allen B. Manaloto, Gerald A. Escleto, Mark Lagman
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: The study focuses on developing and evaluating CodeCrafters: Game-Based Basic Learning and Exercise for Web Design, an offline application aimed at teaching HTML and CSS through gamified learning. The system incorporates elements like unique characters, challenges, multiple modes, and a coin-and-reward system to make web design education interactive and enjoyable. Built with tools such as Unity, Visual Studio 2019, C#, and PHP, CodeCrafters allows users to learn and practice web design in a portable environment without needing an internet connection. Evaluations confirmed that the application meets user expectations, enhancing knowledge and skills effectively. The study concluded that CodeCrafters serves as a reliable and interactive learning tool for CSS and HTML. Future recommendations include adding game modes, expanding support for languages like PHP and JavaScript, and transitioning to an online platform to increase accessibility. These improvements could make the application easier to use and improve the learning experience.

title: Analyzing the Impact of Depth Features on Point Track Performance
authors: Khadijah Alkandary, Ahmet Serhat Yildiz, Hongying Meng
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: The multi-object tracking and segmentation task in urban traffic scenes in for improving autonomous driving, poses ongoing challenges from occlusions, lighting variations, and background noise interferences. We tackle the issue of identity switches by enhancing the existing PointTrack framework, by incorporating raw and monocularly estimated depth information into the color-offset tracking pipeline. By combining depth cues directly into the offset features, our approach strengthens geometric reasoning and leads to improved object association in cases of occlusions and reappearances. On the KITTI multi-object tracking and segmentation dataset, our method reduces identity switching by 21.11% compared to PointTrack baseline, showing increased robustness of tractlet association in challenging scenes. Overall, the approach evaluated notably reduces the occurrence of excessive ID switches, which are a major handicap in real, complicated settings. Numerically, our model performs better by having fewer ID switches while maintaining and in certain cases, enhancing the overall MOTSA score.

title: The Influence of Statistics and Probability in Developing Disaster Preparedness Skills among Senior High School Students
authors: Eubert R. Tagupa, Loreen Roa, Aisa Sevilles, Maris T. Lasco
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: In disaster-prone regions like the Philippines, integrating Statistics and Probability into senior high school curricula presents a strategic opportunity to improve students’ disaster readiness. This study explores how statistical literacy influences preparedness by examining the relationships among five constructs: Perceived Risks (PR), Analytical Thinking (AT), Decision-Making Skills (DMS), Level of Knowledge in Statistics (LK) and Probability, and Disaster Preparedness Skills (DPS). Quantitative research design is use collected data from 214 senior high school students at Bayugan City Senior High School through a structured Likert-scale questionnaire. Structural Equation Modeling via SmartPLS revealed that Analytical Thinking significantly predicts students’ Level of Knowledge (β = 0.464, p < 0.001), which in turn strongly influences Disaster Preparedness Skills (β = 0.472, p < 0.001). Perceived Risks also demonstrated a significant indirect effect through knowledge acquisition. These findings indicate that enhancing students’ analytical and statistical skills can prepare them to handle calamities competently and confidently. This study advocates for the curriculum to design contextualized statistical concepts within disaster scenarios to strengthen data-driven decision-making and build community resilience.

title: Enhancing OFDM System Performance over Correlated Double Ring Channel
authors: Dona Fatmawati, Wahyu Pamungkas, Anggun Fitrian Isnawati
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: This study investigates the performance of a mobile communication system using a Correlated Double Ring (CDR) channel model, where both the transmitter and receiver are surrounded by scatterers and exhibit mobility, leading to time-varying channel conditions and Doppler effects. These effects introduce Inter-Carrier Interference (ICI) and Inter-Symbol Interference (ISI), which degrade signal integrity. To mitigate these impairments, Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiplexing (OFDM) combined with Zero Forcing (ZF) equalization is employed at the receiver. System performance is evaluated using Binary Phase Shift Keying (BPSK) modulation, with Bit Error Rate (BER) as the performance metric. At an AB/No of 10 dB, ZF equalization consistently reduces BER across various speeds: at 5 m/s from 0.1042 to 0.0545 (47.75% improvement), at 25 m/s from 0.1057 to 0.0548 (48.11%), and at 55 m/s from 0.1084 to 0.0544 (48.79%). These findings demonstrate the effectiveness of ZF equalization in mitigating Doppler-Induced degradation in high-mobility wireless channels.

title: Design and Analysis of the Use of Heart Rate and SpO2 Monitoring System based on an RFID-integrated Pulse Oximeter PPG Reflector using System Usability Scale
authors: Muhammad Ragil Maulana S, Hilal Huda, Mohammed Thabet Saleh Jibran
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: This study aims to overcome the limitation of conventional Internet of Things (IoT)-based health monitoring systems by developing a portable, accurate, and user-friendly device for measuring heart rate and blood oxygen saturation (SpO2). The system incorporates the MAX30100 reflective PPG pulse oximeter alongside RFID technology to enable automatic user identification. Measurement data are transmitted and stored in a centralized database to support continuous and long-term monitoring. Usability evaluation was conducted using System Usability Scale (SUS), and the results are expected to indicate a high level of usability, with the average SUS score classified as "good". These findings highlight the system’s potential for implementation across various healthcare settings, including hospital patient monitoring, fitness center assessment, and personal health tracking applications. The system integrates the MAX30100 sensor, the RC522 RFID module, and the ESP8266 microcontroller. After user identification through RFID scanning, physiological parameters are measured, processed, and sent via Wi-Fi to a centralized database, with results accessible through a web interface that enables real-time monitoring. Beyond accuracy, usability testing confirms practicality and simplicity of operation, while the SUS score considered the system reliable and convenient. However, it indicates positive acceptance, showing that most participants does not rule out the possibility that the system will receive a negative response from respondents. Overall, combining RFID with IoT-based pulse oximetry demonstrates an effective, user-friendly, and portable solution suitable for diverse healthcare applications.

title: Acoustic-Based Environment Recognition for SLAM Using First-Order Echoes
authors: Denys-Roman Rudyk, Oleksii Kushnir
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: An acoustic-based SLAM approach is presented that uses first-order sound echoes to recognize indoor environments. In contrast to LiDAR and vision-based methods, our method exploits an impulse acoustic signal and multiple microphones to infer wall locations via echo time-of-flight. We formalize echo delay and mirror-source geometry, using the Cayley–Menger determinant to validate echo labeling. The simulation results in a shoebox room (scale 5-6 m) show that four microphones (spacing 0.2 m) can reconstruct wall positions with 0.1–0.2 m accuracy and wall orientation within a few degrees. We demonstrate echo detection times on the order of 5–20 ms for typical wall distances, and discuss performance metrics such as wall detection accuracy ( 95% in simulation) and algorithm runtime. The paper is structured into Introduction, Related Work, Methodology, Results and Discussion, Conclusion, and References, focusing on simulation outcomes and practical design considerations.

title: Medium Voltage PWM ASD Waveform Effects on Large Motors
authors: Frank DeWinter, Richard Paes, Mukul Rastogi, Gerald Scheuer
publish: 2025 IEEE IAS Petroleum and Chemical Industry Technical Conference (PCIC)
abstract: This paper addresses the effects that modern Medium Voltage (MV) adjustable speed drives (ASDs) have on the large motors they control. Most published technical literature on ASDs describe the issues associated with Low Voltage (LV) ASDs, their voltage waveforms and how they affect small or medium sized motors. This information is not accurate for MV ASDs applied to large motors. The larger horsepower motors utilized on MV ASDs are designed differently (insulation systems, windings, air gaps and bearings) than smaller LV motors, which changes how they react to the PWM waveforms. Specific topics addressed include voltage waveform effects on motor insulation, common mode bearing currents, partial discharge, and harmonic heating of the motor. This paper presents the differences of MV PWM ASDs compared to LV ASDs with respect to output voltage characteristics such as dv/dt, step voltage, and PWM switching frequency. MV ASDs require different guidelines to prevent damage to motors than their LV counterparts. The effect of these factors on motor heating, peak terminal voltage, output filter requirement and bearing currents are discussed. Data from technical papers, standards, and test data are referenced. The goal of the paper is to reduce the confusion on the application of MV ASDs.

title: Radiomic Features Extraction from CMR perfusion imaging to evaluate ischemic damage and ventricular function in coronary artery disease
authors: Cristina Jiménez-Jara, Rodrigo Salas, Rienzi Díaz-Navarro, Julio Sotelo
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: This study aimed to assess the prognostic value of radiomic features extracted from cardiac magnetic resonance (CMR) perfusion imaging, both alone and in combination with clinical variables, for mortality prediction in patients with coronary artery disease (CAD). Logistic regression and random forest models were trained with class weighting and stratified cross-validation across the three main coronary territories: left anterior descending, right coronary, and left circumflex arteries. Models based solely on radiomic features achieved moderate predictive performance, with AUC values between 0.64 and 0.69. When clinical variables such as leukocyte count, C-reactive protein (CRP), BNP, infarct location, and ejection fraction were included, model performance improved significantly, reaching AUCs between 0.83 and 0.85. These findings demonstrate that integrating radiomic and clinical information enhances predictive accuracy and supports the use of CMR radiomics as a complementary tool for non-invasive prognosis assessment in CAD. Future multicenter studies and deep learning approaches are warranted to validate and generalize these results.
