title: Implementation of a Novel Multimeasurement Scheme in FPGA-Based Time-to-Digital Converter
authors: W. Duan, C. Feng, J. Wang, S. Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This paper presents a high-precision FPGA-based time-to-digital converter (TDC) targeting applications such as high-energy physics and positron emission tomography (PET), where fine time resolution is essential. The proposed architecture, termed the Wave Union D TDC, employs a novel multi-measurement scheme that combines the respective benefits of Wave Union A and Wave Union B approaches. Upon receiving the rising edge of a signal, a ripple signal with multiple transitions is generated and sampled over multiple consecutive clock cycles using a D flip-flop (DFF) bank. Each cycle captures an independent snapshot of the ripple's propagation through a tapped delay line (TDL), and the timing is derived from the transition edge positions within each snapshot.

title: A Bidirectional APF-RRT* Path Planning Algorithm with Multi-Strategy Adaptive Expansion
authors: Guoliang Cheng, Jiuxiang Yan, Qian Li, Yongguo Zhao, Malgat Mazakov, Kaliyeva Kulyash
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning, Pattern Recognition and Automation Engineering (MLPRAE)
abstract: For intelligent systems such as mobile robots and unmanned aerial vehicles, path planning is a core component, and path quality and time efficiency are important indicators for evaluating path planning. Currently, Rapidly-exploring Random Tree (RRT)-based algorithms used for mobile robot path planning still face issues such as high randomness in the search space, slow convergence, and resulting curvy paths. To address these problems, this paper proposes an improved Bidirectional Artificial Potential Field-RRT* (IBi-APF-RRT*) path planning algorithm. In node expansion, the method first combines random tree expansion with a goal-biasing strategy to eliminate the randomness of the tree and rapidly direct the search toward the goal. Additionally, based on bidirectional exploration, an optimized artificial potential field (APF) method is employed to guide the tree expansion toward the goal region while avoiding obstacles. Experimental results show that the proposed IBi-APF-RRT* algorithm outperforms several popular RRT* variants in terms of both path length and runtime. Compared to RRT*, APF-RRT*, Bi-RRT*, and Bias-RRT*, the average path length is reduced by 15.22%, 5.46%, 17.17%, and 11.25%, respectively, and the average runtime is reduced by 95.39%, 94.20%, 52.47%, and 51.01%, respectively, demonstrating the efficiency and adaptability of the improved algorithm.

title: Enhancing False Alarm Reduction in Network Traffic Anomaly Detection Using Ensemble Machine Learning
authors: Elkaf Rahmawan Pramudya, Edi Nur Sasongko, Affandy Affandy, Fikri Budiman
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: This study proposes a robust ensemble learning framework to significantly reduce false alarms in binary intrusion detection using the CICIDS2017 dataset. The approach integrates mutual information-based feature selection, SMOTE-Tomek resampling to address class imbalance, and a weighted soft voting ensemble comprising Logistic Regression, Decision Tree, and LightGBM classifiers. Class-wise threshold tuning is employed to optimize the trade-off between false positives and false negatives, achieving a classification accuracy of 99.76%, with precision, recall, and F1-scores consistently above 99.5%. Notably, the false positive and false negative rates were both reduced to approximately 0.021%, marking a substantial improvement over existing benchmarks. The framework’s effectiveness was validated through 5-fold stratified cross-validation, demonstrating strong generalizability.

title: The influence of reverberation, equalization and compression methods on speaker recognition
authors: Olesia Barkovska, Anton Havrashenko, Pavlo Botnar
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The subject of the study is to analyze the impact of reverberation, compression and equalization methods on the accuracy of speaker speech detection. In recent years, the significance of audio preprocessing has grown considerably due to its crucial role in tasks such as data compression, filtering, and noise reduction. With the increasing demand for audio information classification, evaluating and comparing different preprocessing techniques has become essential to assess the accuracy and efficiency of the resulting solutions. This study focuses on examining how various audio preprocessing methods affect the accuracy of speaker speech detection, which is critical for subsequent neural network training. Particular emphasis is placed on methods of transforming audio signals into features, specifically using low-frequency cepstral coefficients. To achieve this objective, the study involved analyzing signal-to-feature transformation techniques and mathematical models used for audio sequence analysis based on the extracted features. A generalized real-time speaker speech translation model was developed, and an experiment was designed according to the selected audio preprocessing stages. The experiment was simulated by training and testing a convolutional neural network. The following methods were used: mel-frequency cepstral analysis, spectral analysis, mathematical methods of artificial intelligence. The following results have been obtained: depending on the chosen methods of pre-processing voice information and different ways of converting the signal into features, 86% accuracy of speaker’s language detection was achieved. The practical value of this work lies in expanding the range of audio files that can be used for training neural networks, as well as enabling translation of the resulting text into a selected language, including constructed or artificial languages. This study explored how different audio preprocessing techniques influence the accuracy of detecting a speaker’s speech, which is vital for subsequent neural network training involving various signal-to-feature transformation methods. The findings indicate that, in cases where audio recordings contain echoes, applying equalization can help reduce the echo effect.

title: Ecosystem Entry Strategy Patterns and Resilience of Electrical and Electronic Industry Multinational Corporations under High Market Volatility
authors: Taras Danko
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: In the context of accelerating technological dynamism and recurring market volatility, electrical and electronic industry multinational corporations (EEI-MNCs) increasingly engage in global innovation ecosystems to secure long-term competitiveness. These dynamics underscore a growing corporate imperative to architect ecosystem entry strategies that strengthen organizational resilience. Building on an extended strategic tripod framework that integrates ecosystem-specific advantages with resource- and institution-based views, we analyze a sample of EEI-MNCs active in key innovation ecosystems. Abnormal returns during major volatility events (2015-2022) are used as indicators of firms’ historical resilience trajectories. These trajectories are then compared with the current architectural patterns of ecosystem entry strategies, assessed across three pillars: strategic discovery, structural support, and selective participation. The results support a typology distinguishing "Proactive Leaders," "Pivots," "Naturals," and a "Lucky Star" based on resilience trajectories, ESG performance, and strategic coherence. Our findings underscore the growing strategic centrality of ecosystem participation and offer implications for resilience-oriented international business strategies in turbulent environments.

title: Edge-AI Based Rat Monitoring in Food Warehouse using YOLOv11 and Raspberry Pi
authors: M. Irwan, Khairun Saddami, Rizka Ramadhana, Ramzi Adriman
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Rice field rats (Rattus argentiventer) are the primary cause of post-harvest rice yield losses in Indonesia, with potential losses reaching up to 37% per hectare and a decline in grain quality. Traditional control methods, such as traps and rodenticides, are often ineffective on a large scale and have negative environmental impacts. This study developed a real-time rat detection system based on deep learning using the YOLOv11 algorithm, implemented on a Raspberry Pi 5 for early monitoring in rice storage warehouses. A total of 410 rat images were collected and processed through Roboflow for segmentation, then divided into training (328), validation (41), and testing (41) datasets. The YOLOv11 model was trained for 500 epochs with a learning rate of 0.002, batch size of 4, and the AdamW optimizer. To prevent overfitting, early stopping was applied with a threshold of 100 epochs without performance improvement. Training results showed the model achieved a precision of 0.955, recall of 0.86, mAP@0.50 of 0.87, and mAP@0.50–0.95 of 0.39. The prototype system, consisting of a Raspberry Pi 5, webcam, and buzzer, was capable of real-time rat detection and provided audible alerts. This research demonstrates that integrating YOLOv11 with low-power computing devices offers an effective, sustainable, and applicable solution for rodent pest detection in agricultural storage environments.

title: Analysis and Measurement of Readiness in the Telkom University Campus Environment for Online Delivery Services
authors: Kania Ayu Natya Lakshita A Ajid, Rahmat Yasirandi, Isa Mulia Insan
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: This study examines the readiness of the Telkom University campus environment for implementing online delivery services, focusing on the perspectives of dormitory students, non-dormitory students, and campus staff. The research employs the Technology Readiness and Acceptance Model (TRAM) to examine how optimism, innovativeness, discomfort, and insecurity influence users’ perceived usefulness (PU), perceived ease of use (PEOU), and intention to use (ITU) delivery applications. A quantitative approach was used, with data collected from 392 respondents through structured questionnaires. The analysis was conducted using Structural Equation Modeling (SEM) to test the relationships among the constructs. The findings reveal that optimism and innovativeness have a positive and significant effect on PU and PEOU, while discomfort and insecurity show negative impacts. Furthermore, both PU and PEOU significantly influence ITU. Model accuracy is supported by the R Square values, with PU showing the strongest explanatory power, R Square value 0.642, followed by R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> of PEOU, a value 0.577, and R Square of ITU, a value 0.472, indicating that these key constructs are well-accounted for by the proposed psychological predictors. The adjusted R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> values remain stable, confirming the robustness of the model. These results suggest that improving digital literacy and trust in technology among campus communities can enhance the adoption of online delivery services. The study provides practical insights for universities aiming to develop infrastructure and policies aligned with students' and staff's needs in increasingly digital campus ecosystems.

title: Logarithmic Conditional Diffusion Model for SAR Training Data Augmentation
authors: Ting Chen, Xinlong Liu, Guangchao Wang, Rongxin Li, Bin Chen
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: The interpretation of Synthetic Aperture Radar (SAR) images based on deep learning relies heavily on a large number of annotated training samples. However, the acquisition of annotated SAR image samples is challenging due to the high labor costs and the stochastic nature of the coherent imaging mechanism. To address this issue, we propose SarDDPM, a conditional denoising diffusion probabilistic model (DDPM) for SAR image generation. In the proposed SarDDPM, to align with the multiplicative degradation pattern, the input SAR image is first logarithmically transformed, and then the forward diffusion and reverse denoising processes are defined on this transformed data. In addition, SarDDPM is a conditional diffusion model, where the class labels of SAR images are used as classifier-free guidance for conditional generation. Experimental results on the TerraSAR-X and Orchard dataset demonstrate that SarDDPM outperforms generative adversarial network (GANs)-based baselines in terms of image quality and diversity. Furthermore, augmenting the training set with the samples generated by SarDDPM yields improvement in SAR image classification accuracy.

title: A Dataset of Homonymous Affixes in Uzbek for Improving Lemmatization and Question Answering Systems
authors: Ogabek Sobirov, Bobur Shermatov, Shaxodat Qodirberganova, Dilshodbek Allashkurov, Umarbek Rakhmatullayev
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This paper presents a manually compiled dataset of Uzbek homonymous affixes aimed at advancing natural language processing (NLP) research in morphologically rich languages. The dataset, titled Uzbek Homonym Affixes, contains 56 entries, each representing a unique affix and its occurrences across multiple parts of speech, including nouns, adjectives, verbs, adverbs, and auxiliary words. The resource captures both derivational (so‘z yasovchi) and inflectional (shakl yasovchi) uses of affixes, enabling detailed morphological and lexical analysis. It was manually collected from lexical sources and structured into six columns, allowing straightforward integration with NLP frameworks such as morphological analysis, part-of-speech tagging, and word sense disambiguation. Beyond descriptive linguistics, this dataset provides valuable input for computational applications like lemmatization and question-answering systems, where handling homonymy and morphological ambiguity is critical. By offering a structured linguistic foundation, the dataset contributes to the broader development of Uzbek language technologies and serves as a cornerstone for future research in morphology-based natural language understanding. The dataset is publicly accessible on the Hugging Face platform at https://huggingface.co/datasets/dasturbek/uzbek_homonym_affixes.

title: Physics-Informed Passive Motion Paradigm for Parallel Robots: A High-Precision Motor-Primitives Framework_supp1-3645663.mp4
authors: Fuli Wang
abstract: Complex embodied systems, whether biological or robotic, must continuously generate goal-directed behaviors while preserving coherence between motor intention and physical feasibility. In parallel robots, this link between intention and mechanics becomes particularly challenging due to their nonlinear, over-constrained kinematics and the absence of intuitive motor primitives. This letter introduces a passive motion paradigm for parallel robots using self-supervised physics-informed neural networks, which reformulates motion generation as the dynamic unfolding of motor primitives driven by attractor fields in actuator space. Unlike traditional forward or optimization-based formulations, the framework integrates analytical kinematics with neural fields to ensure both physical consistency and adaptive motion generation. The method estimates the Jacobian matrix as a physically constrained neural field, merging analytical structure with data-driven learning to achieve robust and interpretable behavior without relying on iterative numerical solvers. Theoretical analysis, simulations, and physical experiments demonstrate the framework's accuracy, stability, and adaptability across different parallel mechanisms.

title: On Complex-Valued Zeroing Neural Networks Driven by Fuzzy Logic for QP Problems With Applications
authors: Qiuyue Zuo, Haibing Fan, Lin Xiao, Ping Tan
abstract: This paper addresses the time-varying complex-valued quadratic programming problem by designing a fuzzy adaptive complex-valued zeroing neural network (FACZNN) with fuzzy control factors. Based on a fuzzy logic system and a zeroing neural network, three types of the FACZNN model are constructed in different forms. While the first two FACZNN models utilize existing activation functions, we design a novel sinh-power-sign activation function for the third FACZNN model, enabling the FACZNN model to achieve predefined-time convergence. The model's efficiency is validated through theoretical discussion and numerical simulations in both noise-free and noisy environments. Additionally, the FACZNN model is applied to color image fusion and target detection. We process RGB images using quaternion representation based on complex values, framing the color image fusion and target detection as a complex-valued quadratic programming problem. The results demonstrate that the model exhibits strong robustness and practical effectiveness.

title: Underwater Acoustic Channel Estimation Via Accelerated TMSBL With KSVD-Based Denoising and Robust Initialization
authors: Chuanxi Xing, Yiwen Hou, Yihan Meng, Tinglong Huang, Weiqiang Li, Minglinhan Hu
abstract: To address the high complexity and noise sensitivity of the Temporal Multiple Sparse Bayesian Learning (TMSBL) algorithm in shallow-sea environments, this paper proposes a novel and robust channel estimation scheme. Our proposed scheme first denoises the received pilot matrix using the K-Singular Value Decomposition (KSVD) algorithm and then leverages the Stagewise Orthogonal Matching Pursuit (StOMP) to acquire a robust sparse prior to initializing the TMSBL framework. This structured approach leverages the temporal correlation between channels for joint estimation, while noise variance is estimated directly from OFDM null subcarriers to enhance stability and efficiency. The simulation results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed method. At an SNR of -10 dB, it reduces the normalized mean square error (NMSE) by more than 94% compared to the standard TMSBL algorithm and reduces the computation time by approximately 95.87%, ensuring higher accuracy and efficiency for underwater acoustic communications.

title: A Class of Axis&#x2013;Angle Attitude Control Laws for Rotational Systems_supp1-3645665.mp4
authors: Francisco Goncalves
abstract: We introduce a new class of attitude control laws for rotational systems, which generalizes the use of the Euler axis–angle representation beyond quaternion-based formulations. Using basic Lyapunov’s stability theory and the notion of extended K∞ functions, we developed a method for determining and enforcing the global asymptotic stability of the single fixed point of the resulting closed-loop (CL) scheme. In contrast with traditional quaternion-based methods, the proposed generalized axis–angle approach enables greater flexibility in the design of the control law, which is of great utility when employed in combination with a switching scheme whose transition state depends on the angular velocity of the controlled rotational system. Through simulation and real-time experimental results, we demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed approach. According to the recorded data, in the execution of high-speed tumble-recovery maneuvers, the new method consistently achieves shorter stabilization times and requires lower control effort relative to those corresponding to the quaternion-based and geometric-control methods used as benchmarks.

title: Optimal Battery Sizing for Real-Time Renewable Energy Bidding Based on Reinforcement Learning
authors: Taiyo Mantani, Hikaru Hoshino, Eiko Furutani
publish: IEEE Transactions on Energy Markets, Policy and Regulation
abstract: With the increasing penetration of Variable Renewable Energy (VRE) sources such as photovoltaic and wind power, effective market integration of VRE is essential to minimize market distortions and support new business models. Battery energy storage systems enhance operational flexibility by mitigating imbalance penalties and enabling energy arbitrage. However, accurate battery sizing is challenging due to its strong coupling with operational strategies, making it a multi-scale optimization problem. Additionally, uncertainty in renewable generation and market prices increases the computational complexity, as is typically the case for stochastic programming approaches. This paper proposes a computationally efficient method for optimal battery sizing for renewable producers participating in real-time markets. We leverage Reinforcement Learning (RL) as a stochastic sequential decision-making framework and extend it to co-optimize the battery capacity with the bidding strategy. Unlike existing bi-level optimization approaches, our method integrates battery sizing directly into the bidding policy training process. This one-shot optimization framework improves computational efficiency by eliminating the need for repeated RL trainings across candidate battery capacities. Numerical simulations demonstrate that the proposed method effectively optimizes battery investment and operational performance over a target year.

title: Transformer Fault Diagnosis Based on Hybrid-Weighted and Multi-Scale One-Dimensional Convolutional Neural Network_supp1-3645718.docx
authors: Hongyin Zhu
abstract: To address the issues of low accuracy and imbalanced datasets in transformer fault diagnosis, this paper proposes a fault diagnosis model based on a multi-scale one-dimensional convolutional neural network (M1DCNN) and a hybrid-weighted sparse categorical cross-entropy (HWSCCE) loss function. Firstly, data preprocessing and feature selection are employed to significantly enhance the discriminative capability of features. Then, M1DCNN is utilized to extract multi-scale information, overcoming the limitations of traditional one-dimensional convolutional neural network (1DCNN) in handling complex features. Meanwhile, the integration of HWSCCE enables dynamic adjustment of sample weights, effectively mitigating the issue of class imbalance. The effectiveness of combining M1DCNN with HWSCCE is validated through ablation and comparative experiments. Ablation experiments demonstrate that the combined model of M1DCNN and HWSCCE achieves an mF1 of 93.07%, representing a 3.21% improvement over the baseline 1DCNN model, indicating a significant performance enhancement. In comparative experiments, the proposed model outperforms other benchmark algorithms on the collected dataset. Furthermore, generalization tests on different datasets constructed based on the IEC TC 10 dataset show that the model maintains consistently high performance, with mP, mR, and mF1 mostly exceeding 86%. The results indicate that the proposed method effectively improves the accuracy and reliability of transformer fault diagnosis, exhibits strong generalization capability, and provides robust support for the safe and stable operation of power systems.

title: Characterisation of a Mixed-Signal Readout ASIC for Continuous-Wave X-Ray Applications
authors: P. Lazzaroni, M. P. Hammer, M. Manghisoni, A. Miceli, L. Ratti, V. Re
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Fourth-generation light sources present novel challenges for detector technology, particularly when a continuous-wave x-ray source is leveraged. Mixed-signal readout channels must simultaneously minimise noise, achieve low power consumption, and support high frame rates, requiring significant advances in both analog and digital design. The pFREYA16 ASIC is a readout channel optimised for pixelated detectors in continuous-wave x-ray applications, such as x-ray ptychography. Fabricated in a commercial 65 nm CMOS process, pFREYA offers single-photon sensitivity at 5,9,18, and 25 keV, with a power budget of 220 uW, and a pixel size of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$150 \text{um} \times 150 \text{um}$</tex>. The architecture features 2-bit selectable peaking times for signal-to-noise ratio optimisation, signal-over-threshold detection for efficient zero-suppression, and 10-bit per channel analog-to-digital conversion. This summary details the first results from the characterisation of the analog channel including the signal-over-threshold detection. The conference contribution will add on the sample and hold performance and the SAR ADC.

title: Initial Imaging Performance of a Small Animal PET Scanner Consisting of Long Semi-Monolithic Scintillator Detectors
authors: Z. Kuang, S. M. Kinyanjui, L. Zhang, N. Ren, Q. Tan, Y. Li, Z. Liu, Y. Yang
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Depth of interaction (DOI) encoding detector is vital for a small animal PET scanner to simultaneously achieve a high spatial resolution and a high sensitivity. Semi-monolithic scintillator detectors have the inherent DOI encoding capability of monolithic scintillator, and can also improve the spatial resolution of the detector by using thinner slabs and reducing the edge effect. Two detectors consisting of 12 LYSO slabs of 0.96 × 56 × 10 mm<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</sup> in size, with black-painted on the front and two end faces were constructed. The detectors were single-ended read out by a 4 × 16 silicon photomultiplier (SiPM) array with a row and column summimg circuit. The squared COG method was used to obtain the position in the monolithic direction (y), and inverse standard deviation method was used to obtain the DOI information. First, an ultra-micro hot-rod phantom with rods diameter of 0.75,1.0,1.35,1.7,2.0, and 2.4 mm was simulated on a full-ring small animal PET scanner consisting of 20 semi-monolithic detectors using the GATE software. Second, a prototype small animal PET scanner consisting of two semi-monolithic detectors and a rotation platform were constructed. Na-22 point source with a diameter of 0.3 mm placed at the center and a radial offset of 5 mm was measured. For each position, the point source was measured at 10 angles with an interval of 18 degree. The images were reconstructed by using an ordered subsets expectation maximization (OSEM) algorithm with PSF modeling. Rods with a diameter of 0.75 mm were clearly resolved form the image of the ultra-micro hot-rod phantom using the simulated data. A spatial resolution of better than 0.65 mm was obtained on the prototype PET scanner using measured data.

title: Wireless Power Transmission for Left Ventricular Assist Devices: In-vivo Trials, Challenges, and Future Directions
authors: T. Campi, S. Cruciani, F. Maradei, A. Montalto, M. Feliziani
abstract: This paper aims to provide an overview of research achievements in the application of wireless power transfer (WPT) technology to power left ventricular assist devices (LVADs). These devices are implanted cardiac pumps designed to support patients with severe heart failure. LVAD implants are currently powered through a percutaneous cable that is often the cause of critical infections known as driveline infections (DLI) that require device explantation. The innovative WPT technology to power LVAD systems is a particularly attractive solution to overcome the criticality related to DLI and to improve patient comfort. The focus is on in vivo trials of a transcutaneous wireless LVAD power system, providing details in terms of architecture, specifications and data collected during experimental tests. Finally, future directions are presented, emphasizing that WPT technology is poised to make LVADs a viable long-term or destination therapy rather than a simple bridge-to-transplant option.

title: Multi-View Cross Attention for Guiding Surgical Planning in Rotator Cuff Repairs with Limited MRI Data
authors: Yong Oh Lee, Hankyeol Lee, Jong-ho Kim
abstract: Accurately determining surgical strategies, such as complete or partial repairs, is essential for effective treatment planning in rotator cuff injuries. This study proposes a novel two-stage framework leveraging multi-view cross attention to analyze magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) data from coronal and sagittal views, addressing the challenges posed by limited datasets. In Stage 1, segmentation of six clinically relevant regions from each view was performed for feature extraction. In Stage 2, segmentation results were combined with original MRI images using cross-view transformers, enabling the extraction of interdependencies between segmented and original data. To further enhance prediction accuracy, multi-head cross attention was employed to merge features from both views, capturing their spatial and anatomical relationships. The proposed framework achieved an area under the curve (AUC) of 0.95 in predicting surgical repair types, effectively distinguishing between complete and partial repairs. While segmentation performance in Stage 1 showed variability (Intersection over Union, IoU: 0.45–0.83) due to the limited dataset size (211 samples), the incorporation of multi-view cross attention significantly enhanced prediction accuracy by leveraging complementary information from both sagittal and coronal views. This demonstrates the framework’s capability to mitigate the challenges of limited data in segmentation tasks by improving overall classification performance.

title: Singularity-Avoidance Flexible Predefined Performance Control of Hypersonic Vehicles Subject to Multiple Actuator Faults
authors: Ruining Luo, Guangjun He, Tianhao Peng, Xiangwei Bu
publish: IEEE Transactions on Aerospace and Electronic Systems
abstract: Hypersonic vehicles (HVs) are confronted with various uncertainties and increased actuator failure risks during highly maneuverable flight operations, which may result in the singularity issues associated with conventional prescribed performance control (PPC) methods. To effectively mitigate these challenges, this study proposes a flexible prescribed performance-based fault-tolerant control framework specifically designed for HVs experiencing multiple actuator faults. First, a dual-component fault-tolerant control strategy is introduced, combining robustness enhancement with active control compensation to address a broad spectrum of potential fault modes, thereby ensuring system reliability in complex fault scenarios. Second, an innovative flexible PPC scheme is developed to proactively avoid the control singularity problems commonly encountered in traditional PPC approaches under actuator failures. Moreover, the proposed control architecture is streamlined to eliminate the need for external disturbance observers or neural network approximations, significantly improving its practical feasibility. Finally, comprehensive numerical simulations are conducted to validate the effectiveness and performance superiority of the proposed control methodology.

title: The Effect of Interrogating Neutron Spectrum on Delayed Neutron Temporal Analysis
authors: C. R. Wilson, O. Searfus, S. Clarke, S. Pozzi, I. Jovanovic
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Verification of international safeguards agreements relies on the ability to measure special nuclear material, such as <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{235} \mathrm{U}$</tex>. Most common techniques that measure <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{235} \mathrm{U}$</tex> rely on the easily shielded, spontaneously emitted gamma rays. As an alternative, active interrogation can be used to probe uranium with penetrating external radiation. This induces fission, creating signatures that are more resilient to high-Z shielding, such as delayed neutrons. Delayed neutron temporal profiles can be used to identify the composition of fissionable material because they are unique to each fissionable isotope. This work proposes to enhance the sensitivity of delayed neutron temporal measurements to <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{235} \mathrm{U}$</tex> by softening the interrogating neutron spectrum. An analytical model based on the eight-group delayed neutron yields of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{235} \mathrm{U}$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{238} \mathrm{U}$</tex> is fit to the measured data to quantify the isotopic composition. A large volume active well coincidence counter (LV- AWCC) was retrofitted with an MP320 D-D neutron generator to allow for in-situ measurement during irradiation. The delayed neutron emissions of uranium samples ranging from 0.2 % to 93 % of 235 U were measured. Polyethylene in the LV-AWCC significantly increases the delayed neutron emission from 4.5% enriched uranium. The model fit for 4.5% enriched uranium shows excellent agreement with measured data.

title: Class-Aware Diversified Augmentation for Open-Set Single Domain Generalization
authors: Jian Hu, Shaogang Gong, Weitong Cai, Junchi Yan
abstract: In Open-Set Single Domain Generalization (OS-SDG), one only has access to a single labeled source domain for training. It assumes that the learned model generalizes well to target samples belonging to the source label space whilst classifies target samples outside the source label space into a single “unknown” class. The current method synthesizes new samples that are semantically unrelated to known classes to simulate target unknown classes. This ignores that unknown classes actually may semantically correlated to known classes, making it difficult to discriminate samples at the margins of class decision boundaries as “unknown”. In this work, we introduce a Class-Aware Diversified Augmentation (CADA) method to overcome this problem. Our key idea is to synthesize explicitly new multiple unknown target classes with diversified semantic and learn the inherent correlation among the known and unknown classes, so to both increase the coverage of multiple target unknown classes and to optimize class margin separation. CADA is optimized by enhanced diversity maximization and class-aware minimization. The former synthesizes more novel classes by considering both semantic relationships to known classes and domain shift between the source and target domains. The latter employs class-agnostic clustering with synthesized samples to simulate class correlations among target classes, maximizing class margin separation. Theoretical analysis and experiments on five benchmarks show the efficacy of our CADA.

title: In Array Time-to-Digital Converter with 10 ps LSB and 43 μM × 35 μM Area in TSMC 65 nm
authors: G. Théberge-Dupuis, R. Scarpellini, R. A. Giampaolo, N. Roy, T. Rossignol, S. Lavoie-Drainville, J. Pratte, S. A. Charlebois
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Many applications in nuclear science and medical imaging use scintillators to convert high-energy photons or particles into multiple photons that can be detected with silicon light detectors. For applications where the time of interaction matters, such as time-of-flight (ToF) positron emission tomography and ToF computed tomography, we need to timestamp the first photon detected. Unfortunately, single-photon detectors are subject to dark counts, which adds uncertainty to the measured timestamps. To better evaluate the time of interaction, we can use an estimator constructed on the first few timestamps. Thus, multiple time-to-digital converters (TDC) are required in the detector for the estimator to operate. Our team at the Universit'e de Sherbrooke is working on a 5 mm × 5 mm photon-to-digital converter (PDC). The detector is composed of 4096 single photon avalanche diodes (SPAD) 3D integrated with a TSMC 65 nm ASIC composed of an array of 4096 quenching circuits and 512 TDCs. As a stepping stone to the full-size PDC, we developed a test chip that includes 32 SPADs, 32 quenching circuits (QC), and 16 TDCs. The TDC is a 43 μm × 35 μm ring oscillator-based cascaded Vernier TDC with 2 stages. The TDC was characterised in multiple configurations: standalone, in group of 8, and in group of 16 running at the same time. Only a difference in the integral nonlinearity was observed at the target resolution of 10 ps. At this target resolution, we measured a precision of 4.1 ps rms, an average conversion time of 8.6 ns, and a power consumption of 28.6 μW at 1 Mcps. A test campaign will be done in Q3 2025 to evaluate the stability of the device and obtain a single photon timing resolution.

title: From 5G to 6G: A Survey on Security, Privacy, and Standardization Pathways
authors: Mengmeng Yang, Youyang Qu, Thilina Ranbaduge, Chandra Thapa, Nazatul Haque Sultan, Ming Ding, Hajime Suzuki, Wei Ni, Sharif Abuadbba, David Smith, Paul Tyler, Josef Pieprzyk, Thierry Rakotoarivelo, Xinlong Guan, Sirine Mrabet

title: Experimental Inter-Crystal Scattering Recovery in Semi-Monolithic TOF-PET Detectors
authors: F. Pagano, F. Loignon-Houle, N. Mouaouia, E. Elmoujarkach, N. Karakatsanis, S. Nehmeh, A. Gonzalez
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Inter-crystal scattering (ICS) represents a significant fraction of detected events in positron emission tomography (PET) systems. Accurately recovering the first interaction position of these events is challenging but crucial, as it allows correct line-of-response identification and reduces the degradation of image quality caused by ICS. Most ICS recovery studies have focused on pixelated detectors and relied primarily on Monte Carlo simulations. In this work, we apply, for the first time, ICS recovery to experimental data from semi-monolithic detectors, using both analytical and deep-learning based approaches. Measurements were performed using collimated irradiation of 8 - and 16 -slab arrays, read out with a 64 -channel SiPM array and TOFPET2 ASIC together with a row-column channel reduction. We demonstrate that ICS affects both positioning and timing performance, and propose a time-walk correction improving time resolution by about 10 %. The deep learning approach yielded the highest prediction accuracy for first interactions, reaching <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$87.7 \pm 4.3 \%$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$73.3 \pm 4.0 \%$</tex> for the 8 - and 16 -slab detectors, respectively. These results establish the first steps towards fully integrated, deep learning-based, 3D positioning of the first interaction in semi-monolithic detectors, accounting for ICS and compatible with a multiplexing readout.

title: A Task-Based Evaluation of Lesion Detectability in a Deep Learning Reconstruction Algorithm for PET
authors: M. Gao, D. Bharkhada, V. Panin, M. Millardet, Y. Zheng, J. Raj, M. Conti, J. S. Karp, S. Surti
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: FastPET<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[1]-[3]</sup> is a novel neural network-based reconstruction that is computationally efficient for fully-3D PET reconstruction using a simple architecture with the fewest network parameters. Clinical task-based evaluations are critical to enable the application of FastPET in clinical practice. In this work, we study lesion quantification and detectability, key clinical tasks in oncology, for FastPET reconstruction relative to the conventional OSEM reconstruction. Patient data acquired from Biograph Vision and a well-developed lesion embbeding methodology<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">[4],[5]</sup> were used. Lesions were embedded at different uptake levels into patient data for varying scan durations. Results show comparable lesion contrast measurements for FastPET and OSEM images. For a fixed scan time, FastPET also has a narrower background nodule contrast distribution that is consistent with a visually smoother background. Detailed evaluation of lesion contrast recovery and lesion detection and localization as characterized by the area under the localization receiver operating characteristic curve (ALROC) metric will be presented as a function of scan time and lesion uptake value. Such task-based evaluation of small-lesion detection and quantification will provide clinical significance and evidence of introducing Deep Learning reconstruction for PET in clinical practice.

                    Molecular Beam Epitaxy for Photodetector-Based Authentication
authors: Hongliang Chang, Yanqing Jia, Yue Wang, Hang Lu, Abdullah Alquwayzani, Wenqing Niu, Tien Khee Ng, Boon S. Ooi
abstract: α-Ga<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</inf>O<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">3</inf> film grown by plasma-assisted molecular beam epitaxy was fabricated into metal-semiconductor-metal (MSM) based photodetectors. Leveraging the inherent variation of photocurrent, the photo-response under UV-excitation was demonstrated as a digital fingerprint for physical unclonable function (PUF), achieving a high authentication accuracy of 98.11%.

title: Cherenkov Radiator Study for dPET Detector Module Optimization
authors: O. B. Khanal, J. Seidel, M. V. Green, P. L. Choyke, S. S. Adler
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The timing properties of Cherenkov photon production are superior compared to scintillation photon production and may help to achieve a coincidence timing resolution suitable for direct PET imaging. Therefore, a study of Cherenkov photon production across three crystal radiators with varying lengths was performed with the goal of selecting the optimum crystal type and length to be used in designing a detector module for dPET imaging. Three crystals were tested, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{PbF}_{2}$</tex>, lead glass SF6 ( <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$70 \% \text{PbO}$</tex> ) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{PbWO}_{4}$</tex>, each having lengths of 3,6 and 12 mm . The crystals were read out using high speed Hamamatsu R5320 PMTs instrumented with a CAEN DT5751 1GHz digitizer. The photoelectron production from the PMTs was measured by calibrating the PMT with a Photek LPG-405 (405 nm) laser triggered with a 100 Hz gate and measuring both the integrated current and the efficiency of signal production from the PMT as a function of the laser pulse width. The photoelectron production for each crystal type and length was measured using a <sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">22</sup> Na source placed between the crystal pair and the photoelectron production recorded with the two crystal radiators recording Cherenkov radiation in coincidence. Of the three crystal types and lengths, the highest photoelectron production was <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{PbF}_{2} 6 \text{mm}$</tex> length radiator with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.05 \pm 0.35$</tex> photoelectron per 511 keV incident gamma. This was compared with about <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.50 \pm 0.15$</tex> photoelectrons per 511 keV incident gamma for SF6. The <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{PbWO}_{4}$</tex> had a much higher photoelectron production of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$4.9 \pm 2.0$</tex> photoelectrons per 511 keV , but this was due to low level scintillation photon production which degrades the timing properties of the radiator. From this work, 6 mm PbF 2 is the best performing radiator which will be used in the design of a multi-anode MCP dPET detector module.

title: Metal Artifact Reduction in Filtered Backprojection Reconstruction with Iterative Sinogram Updates
authors: L. Zeng
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Machine learning methods require large amount of training data, which may not be available for many applications. This paper proposes an effective metal artifact reduction method for x-ray computed tomography (CT) using the efficient filtered backprojection (FBP) algorithm. The proposed method is a not a machine learning based method. It is not a classic sinogram inpainting method either, because our proposed method does not estimate the metal corrupted data based on the neighboring data. The novelty of the proposed method is to use the energy of the image artifacts as an objective function and to convert this objective function calculation from the image domain into the sinogram domain. The proposed method is applied to some patient data with artificially introduced metals, and the metal artifacts are significantly reduced.

title: Investigation of a New Compton Camera Technology for Beam Monitoring During Proton Therapy
authors: T. Mizoguchi, H. Muraishi, R. Enomoto, H. Katagiri, M. Kagaya, T. Watanabe, H. Tsukamoto, K. Okubo, R. Honda, M. Shoji, M. Tanaka, D. Kano, H. Ishiyama
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We present a novel Compton camera technology for in-vivo beam monitoring in proton therapy. The proposed method targets prompt gamma-rays with an energy of 4.4 MeV, emitted by nuclear reactions between incident protons and atomic nuclei in the body. These gamma-rays exhibit spatial distributions closely aligned with the proton dose profile, making them suitable for beam range verification. To efficiently detect 4.4 MeV gamma-rays in high background environments, only the scatterer is placed near the subject, and the absorber is positioned behind a shield that blocks direct radiation from the subject. The method employs not only conventional two-hit coincidence events but also multiple Compton scattering events, in which gamma-rays undergo sequential interactions- first in the scatterer and then multiple times within the absorber. In this method, the position where the gamma-ray first interacts is limited to the scatterer, the order of interactions can be limited, allowing for more accurate imaging with high efficiency using the information of interaction positions and energy depositions. Monte Carlo simulations with a virtual detector system implemented in Geant4 confirmed that the feasibility of imaging 4.4 MeV gammarays using the proposed method.

title: Physical Layer Security for Practical RSMA-Based Hybrid Satellite-Terrestrial Relay Networks
authors: Xiao Jiang, Peishun Yan, Bin Li, Yulong Zou, Wanming Hao, Chunguo Li, Shuping Dang
abstract: This paper investigates the physical layer security for a rate-splitting multiple access (RSMA)-based hybrid satellite-terrestrial relay network (HSTRN) under the joint impact of hardware impairments (HIs) and channel estimation errors (CEEs). In the proposed RSMA-based HSTRN, a satellite communicates with multiple users via terrestrial relays in the presence of an eavesdropper. In order to improve the secrecy performance, we propose two relay selection schemes, namely, partial relay selection (PRS) and two-stage relay selection (TSRS). We derive exact closed-form expressions of outage probability (OP), intercept probability (IP), and effective secrecy throughput (EST) for the PRS and TSRS schemes. To further enhance the secrecy performance of proposed system, the relay selection schemes are extended to jammer-assisted HSTRN, and we propose the jammer aided PRS (JPRS) and jammer aided TSRS (JTSRS) schemes. The exact closed-form OP, IP, and EST expressions for the JPRS and JTSRS schemes are also obtained. Numerical results show that in the high signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) region, the TSRS scheme outperforms the PRS scheme in terms of EST, while in the low SNR region, the result is opposite. Additionally, in the high SNR region, the secrecy performance of jammer-aided relay selection schemes, i.e., JPRS and JTSRS schemes, outperform relay selection schemes without the support of a jammer, i.e., PRS and TSRS schemes. Moreover, it shows that the RSMA-based HSTRN achieves better secrecy performance than the non-orthogonal multiple access (NOMA)-based HSTRN in high SNR region.

title: Unsupervised Domain Adaptation in Gamma Spectroscopy
authors: P. Lalor
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Machine learning has the potential to improve the speed and reliability of radioisotope identification using gamma spectroscopy. However, meticulously labeling an experimental dataset for training is often prohibitively expensive, while training models purely on synthetic data is risky due to the domain gap between simulated and experimental measurements. In this research, we demonstrate that unsupervised domain adaptation can improve the generalization capabilities of machine learning models for gamma spectroscopy when unlabeled target domain data is available. We first pretrain a spectral classifier using a labeled synthetic dataset and subsequently leverage unlabeled target data to align the learned feature representations between the source and target domains. The motivation behind this approach is twofold: first, reducing the domain shift minimizes the performance drop when applying the model to target data; and second, learning domain-invariant latent representations helps avoid overfitting to features present only in the source domain. We adopt a proof-of-concept approach using GADRAS as our source domain and Geant4 as our target domain, with the Geant4 labels intentionally masked. We compare a range of different unsupervised domain adaptation techniques, finding that adversarial discriminative domain adaptation yields the most substantial improvement in test performance across all architectures considered (CNN, MLP, Transformer). The statistical significance of these conclusions is confirmed using a series of Wilcoxon signed-rank tests. Furthermore, we find that unsupervised domain adaptation reduces the maximum mean discrepancy between the sourceand target-domain features, demonstrating improved feature alignment. Overall, our results highlight the potential for unsupervised domain adaptation techniques to adapt a radioisotope classifier trained on synthetic data for use in real-world settings where data is abundant but labels are unavailable.

title: Feasibility of Multi-Material Decomposition in Dual-Energy CBCT on a LINAC System
authors: H. Lee, Y. Park, J. Kim, S.H. Kim, H.J. Yang, C. Kim
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: This study investigates the feasibility of applying a multi-material decomposition (MMD) algorithm to dual-energy cone-beam computed tomography (DE-CBCT) for enhancing image quality in linear accelerator-based radiotherapy. The MMD algorithm was compared with the conventional threematerial decomposition method commonly used in CBCT. Low- and high-energy CBCT scans were acquired using a digital phantom in simulation and a cheese phantom on a linear accelerator. The MMD algorithm decomposed the images into multiple basis material maps, which were subsequently recombined using energy-dependent linear attenuation coefficients to generate virtual monoenergetic (VM) images at specified energies. Image quality and decomposition performance were evaluated using volume fraction accuracy (VFA), structural similarity index measure (SSIM), and contrast-to-noise ratio (CNR). The MMD method improved the average VFA by 14.3% in the digital phantom and 5.2% in the cheese phantom compared to the conventional method. The average SSIM values of the VM images at five energy levels were 0.62 and 0.97 for the conventional and MMD methods, respectively. The most significant CNR enhancement was observed at 20 keV, with increases of 8.6% and 4.3% compared to the 80 kVp and 140 kVp images, respectively. These results demonstrate that the MMD algorithm enhances material decomposition accuracy and improves the quality of VM images relative to the conventional method. The VM images and basis material maps obtained through this method may provide valuable information for improving the accuracy of patient setup.

title: Thin Organic Scintillators for Neutron Measurements
authors: E. A. Schneider, S. Clarke, S. Pozzi
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Organic scintillators have many appealing qualities, including their dual particle sensitivity and fast timing. In high gamma-ray environments where neutron signatures need to be measured, a fast scintillator with reduced gamma-sensitivity is needed. We propose a new method that makes use of the different rates of energy deposition of recoil protons compared to recoil electrons to reduce gamma count rates. In this study, 1 mm thick stilbene and organic glass scintillators were compared to 6 mm cubes to observe the impact of electron leakage on PSD performance and gamma detection. There was a significant change to the Cs-137 gamma-spectrum of these detectors, due to recoilelectron escape in the thinner samples. Furthermore, there was no statistically significant decrease in pulse-shape discrimination performance between the two pairs of scintillators. The results demonstrate the use of thin scintillators for neutron detection in high-gamma ray environments.

title: Comparison of Modern Convolutional Neural Networks for Segmentation of Vascular Defects in Ventilation/Perfusion (V/Q) Scans
authors: A. Jabbarpour, S. Kaviani, E. Moulton, S. Ghassel, W. Zeng, R. Akbarian, A. Couture, A. Roy, R. Liu, Y. A. Lucinian, N. Hejji, S. AlSulaiman, F. Shirazi, E. Leung, R. Klein
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Interpretation of ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scintigraphy, primarily used to diagnose pulmonary embolism (PE), requires identification of V/Q mismatch defects, which is prone to interobserver variability. To overcome these challenges, we investigated three AI models for automated segmentation of vascular perfusion defects in planar V/Q scans and compared their performance with human annotators. We trained and validated three 2D neural networks models (a nnUnet, SwinUnet, and Bottleneck Transformer Unet [BTUnet]) on 1,313 patients and 329 patients, respectively. These data were previously annotated for V/Q mismatch defects by nuclear medicine physicians. Training was accomplished by minimizing a combined cross-entropy and Dice loss. BT-Unet featured a lightweight transformer within the U-Net bottleneck. Performance was measured on 46 high probability patients according to the original clinical report via Dice score and freeresponse receiver operating characteristic (FROC) curves relative to annotations by 8 readers. Segments whose centroid were within 1.95 cm of the ground truth were scored as true positives. BTUnet, SwinUnet, and Unet mean ± std Dice scores were <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.51 \pm 0.37$</tex>, <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$0.48 \pm 0.39,0.48 \pm 0.40$</tex>, respectively. FROC analysis showed large inter-observer variability among readers with BTUnet the only machine observer performing on par with human readers. Machine observers can provide rapid and consistent segmentations consistent with that of experienced human readers, potentially enhancing diagnostic efficiency and supporting non-expert readers for evaluation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{P E}$</tex>.

title: Context-Aware Density Estimation in Digital Breast Tomosynthesis
authors: S. Lim
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Digital Breast Tomosynthesis (DBT) improves lesion detectability by reducing structural overlap in breast tissue. Accurate segmentation is essential for density analysis and treatment planning. We propose a pipeline that enhances DBT segmentation using simulated data and voxel-level refinement via machine learning. DBT images are generated from MC-GPU simulations of the VICTRE phantom and reconstructed into volumes. Segmentation labels are created by assigning mean linear attenuation coefficients for air, fat, and dense tissues based on phantom materials. A 3D UNet is trained on image-label pairs to produce coarse segmentation results. For refinement, we adopt a PointRend-inspired MLP strategy. Voxels with high uncertainty, estimated from softmax outputs, are selected. Their features—UNet high-resolution features, softmax probabilities, and spatial coordinates—are used to train an MLP to refine predictions. To ensure stability, we preserve the coarse prediction when the MLP output has low confidence. We also experiment with correcting only fat-dense boundaries to avoid unnecessary changes in well-classified regions. To enhance learning, the MLP incorporates gating, residual blending, and Squeeze-and-Excitation (SE) blocks, enabling the model to focus on informative features. A DenseCRF-based post-processing step is applied to enforce spatial consistency and structural smoothness. Experiments show that this pipeline effectively reduces common misclassifications—particularly air predictions near fat-dense boundaries—and improves segmentation accuracy. Our work establishes a simulation-to-segmentation framework with voxel-level correction, informed feature design, and post-refinement, with potential applicability to clinical DBT and adaptive radiotherapy.

title: Handwritten Text Recognition: A Survey
authors: Carlos Garrido-Munoz, Antonio Rios-Vila, Jorge Calvo-Zaragoza
publish: IEEE Transactions on Pattern Analysis and Machine Intelligence
abstract: Handwritten Text Recognition (HTR) has become an essential field within pattern recognition and machine learning, with applications spanning historical document preservation to modern data entry and accessibility solutions. The complexity of HTR lies in the high variability of handwriting, which makes it challenging to develop robust recognition systems. This survey examines the evolution of HTR models, tracing their progression from early heuristic-based approaches to contemporary state-of-the-art neural models, which leverage deep learning techniques. The scope of the field has also expanded, with models initially capable of recognizing only word-level content progressing to recent end-to-end document-level approaches. Our paper categorizes existing work into two primary levels of recognition: (1) up to line-level, encompassing word and line recognition, and (2) beyond line-level, addressing paragraph- and document-level challenges. We provide a unified framework that examines research methodologies, recent advances in benchmarking, key datasets in the field, and a discussion of the results reported in the literature. Finally, we identify pressing research challenges and outline promising future directions, aiming to equip researchers and practitioners with a roadmap for advancing the field.

title: MLP-Driven Beam-Hardening Correction Method for CT Metal Artifact Reduction
authors: S. Yun, S. Hyun, D.-I. Choi, S. Cho
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Metal artifacts in computed tomography (CT) arise due to photon starvation, beam-hardening, and partial volume effects, with severity varying depending on the type, number, and geometry of metallic implants. In this study, we propose an unsupervised metal artifact reduction (MAR) framework that integrates a multi-layer perceptron (MLP)-driven beam-hardening correction prior. The MLP module performs lightweight correction and provides task-specific conditioning, allowing the model to focus on refining residual artifacts. Additionally, we introduce a novel residual artifact simulation strategy that enables fully unsupervised training without requiring paired datasets. The proposed method is evaluated on synthetic data, demonstrating superior artifact removal and structural preservation compared to existing MAR techniques.

title: Si3: Spatial Resolution in Novel 3D Semiconductor Detector
authors: L. Terenzi, E. Rieger, M. Persson, M. Danielsson
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Semiconductor detectors are increasingly being explored in nuclear medicine imaging for their potential to improve spatial resolution, energy discrimination, and overall detection efficiency, especially in collimator-free system designs. This work investigates a novel detector concept based on a 3D semiconductor volume aimed at accurately localizing gamma-ray interactions within the detector. The simulated detector has a surface area of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$20 \times 20 ~\text{cm}^{2}$</tex> and a thickness of 5 cm for the photon simulations. A 511 keV photon source is placed at 10 cm from the detector surface and is enclosed in a 10 cm radius cylinder with a height of 60 cm. Once the spectrum of deposited energies is determined, the electron tracks are simulated in a smaller geometry with <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \mu ~\mathrm{m} 100 \mu ~\mathrm{m} \times 750 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> voxels to reduce computation time. Two algorithms are tested to estimate the initial in-plane electron track position: Gaussian fit and Gridsum. The results indicate that the Gaussian fit outperforms the Gridsum algorithm at interaction energies below 225 keV, while the opposite it is true for higher energies. By employing a combination of the two algorithms it is possible to achieve a standard deviation of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$57.63 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex> on the in-plane interaction position error when averaged across the spectrum of deposited energies with the corresponding weights. These findings provide insight into the spatial precision achievable with the investigated detector architecture, with potential for further optimization of the algorithms and enhancement of out-ofplane spatial resolution.

title: Experimental Evaluation of a Near-Field Small-Animal Compton Camera Based on Ultrahigh-Resolution CdTe Detectors and Latent Compton Sequence (LCS) MLEM Reconstruction
authors: Y. Jin, W. Zhang, L.-J. Meng
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: To address the longstanding gap in imaging radionuclides emitting higher-energy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$>400$</tex> keV) gamma rays, we developed a prototype full-ring small-animal Compton camera based on ultrahigh-energy-resolution CdTe detectors. To accurately model the real-world Compton response of the CdTe detectors, including the finite detector resolution and Doppler broadening, we developed a Monte Carlo-based numerical integration technique to derive the Compton system response function (SRF). To resolve the ambiguity in interaction sequence, we have also developed a Latent Compton Sequence (LCS) MLEM algorithm that jointly estimates the source distribution and interaction sequence in listmode reconstruction. The prototype system demonstrates a sensitivity of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\boldsymbol{\sim} \mathbf{0. 0 3 \%}$</tex> for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathbf{5 1 1} \mathbf{k e V}$</tex> photons. Using GEANT4 simulations, we evaluated the spatial resolution for 511 keV gamma rays and achieved <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\sim 3 ~\text{mm}$</tex> FWHM in the transverse (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$x$</tex> and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$y$</tex>) directions and 1.8 mm in the axial (z) direction. Additional experimental results, including phantom studies, will be presented to further assess the system's performance in realistic imaging scenarios.

title: Interpretable Multimodal Brain Image Fusion for Alzheimer's Diagnosis Via a Siamese Autoencoder
authors: J. E. Arco, J. Ramírez, D. Salas, F. J. Martínez-Murcia, J. M. Górriz
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: We propose a novel brain image fusion framework based on a siamese autoencoder, aimed at integrating the complementary information from Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) and 18FFDG Positron Emission Tomography (PET). The encoder learns low-dimensional embeddings for each modality, which are then merged and decoded into a fused image. The model is trained using a composite loss function combining reconstruction error (MSE), cosine similarity between modality-specific embeddings, and a differentiable approximation of mutual information via Parzen window estimation. The method is validated on data from the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative (ADNI) database in the context of Alzheimer's disease diagnosis. Classification experiments using a convolutional neural network show that fused images outperform individual modalities, achieving a balanced accuracy of 0.87 and AUC of 0.88. To evaluate explainability, we perform an occlusion test over 116 anatomical regions, revealing that performance drops most when masking areas known to be associated with cognitive decline. Furthermore, we compute region-to-region embedding distances across MRI-PET, PET-MRI, and fused-fused scenarios, confirming that our model preserves fine-grained structural-functional associations. These results confirm the method's diagnostic value and biological interpretability.
