title: Design of First Prototype of SymPET, a Waveform Digitizing “System on Chip” for Ultra-High Resolution TOF PET
authors: I. Mostafanezhad, L. Macchiarulo, C. Chock, H. Sabet, G. Uehara
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The primary goal of Time Of Flight PET (TOF-PET) is that of achieving very high spatial and timing resolution, but common readout systems rely on discrimination-based readouts (TDC) that captures one or few data points per interaction. Knowledge of the information on the entire waveform of the sensor outputs using Waveform Digitization (WFD) helps achieving the maximum performance, and overcoming dependency on signal variability and low level noise. Based on previous analysis of the advantages of WFD, we designed a first prototype of a Readout Integrated circuit (ROIC) called SymPETv1, that will be capable of capturing and converting waveforms information providing very good timing and energy resolution for an optimal TOF-PET readout system. We describe the specifications, architecture and design of the first prototype of such a readout component.

title: Study on the Mass Measurement Method of Plutonium Oxide by Gamma-Ray Coincidence Counting
authors: Y. Ye, G. Liu
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: The mass measurement of plutonium material is an important aspect in the field of nuclear material accounting and control. In this paper, a two-layer regular hexagonal ring devices, which is consisted of 12 liquid scintillation detectors with the size of diameter <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$127 ~\text{mm} \times 50.8 ~\text{mm}$</tex> thickness, was used to measure the gamma rays emitted by plutonium oxide samples. There is a good linear relationship between the gamma-ray double coincidence counting rate and the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{240} \text{Pu}$</tex> eff mass of the samples □ and the measurement relative deviation of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{240} \text{Pu}_{\text{eff }}$</tex> mass of samples is less than 5.0% in the range of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$1.36 \sim 27.22 ~\mathrm{g}$</tex>. The measurement method of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{240} \text{Pu}_{\text{eff }}$</tex> mass of plutonium oxide samples by gamma-ray coincidence counting rate is established.

title: Weighted Sum-Rate Maximization in Rate-Splitting MISO Downlink Systems
authors: Anh-Tien Tran, Thanh Phung Truong, Dongwook Won, Nhu-Ngoc Dao, Sungrae Cho
publish: IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering
abstract: Rate-splitting multiple access (RSMA) and successive interference cancellation (SIC) are essential approaches in the next-generation communication systems that boost spectrum efficiency by effectively managing and mitigating interference between multiple signals. However, a challenge arises in ensuring that users can distinguish the common message from the remaining non-decoded private messages without considering a separate SIC constraint per user. This imperfection cancellation leads to residual interference from the common stream that remains in the received signal. This work investigates the maximization of the weighted sum-rate (WSR) in single-layer RSMA multiple input single output (MISO) downlink network by proposing explicit SIC constraints. In particular, we suggest an approach that initially addresses the critical problem of allocating power and precoding vectors for streams using a deep reinforcement learning (DRL) method, and then determines the user-specific allocations within the common rate to meet the criteria of users' minimum rate by solving a linear programming problem. Simulation results exhibit the supremacy of the proposed DRL framework over SDMA and other DRL approaches in terms of spectral efficiency leading to an improvement of approximately 30% of WSR in several scenarios.

title: Tracking the Three-Dimensional Distribution of Growth Impurities in $\text{Cd}_{0.9} \text{Zn}_{0.1} \text{Te}$ Single Crystal
authors: E. Rahier, S. Koelling, S. Singh, L. Montpetit, O. Moutanabbir
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: CdZnTe (CZT) crystals have been the subject of extensive studies toward high-performance room temperature X-ray detectors. Despite decades of research, the atomic-level understanding of growth impurities in these materials remains conspicuously missing in literature despite its importance to elucidate the growth imperfections and their role in shaping the material behavior. Herein, this works combines Transmission Electron Microscopy (TEM) and Atom Probe Tomography (APT) to achieve the full atomic-scale analysis of the inclusions typically found in CZT crystals. The inclusions consist of Te single crystals containing CZT nanoscale crystalline precipitates. These precipitates reach tens of nanometers in diameter and contain <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\text{Cu}, \text{In}$</tex>, and Na impurities. Cu and In are found to decorate the surface of the precipitates. This atomic scale analysis gives unique insights into the three-dimensional distribution of growth impurities, which is highly valuable to understand the mechanisms underlying the crystallization process. These insights are also critical to model the basic properties of CZT semiconductors.

title: Development of a Cost-Effective Total Body J-PET From Plastic Scintillators: Definitive Design
authors: K. Tayefi Ardebili, E. Y. Beyene, N. Chug, C. Curceanu, E. Czerwiński, M. Das, J. Hajduga, S. Jalali, T. Kaplanoglu, Ł. Kapłon, K. Kasperska, A. Khreptak, G. Korcyl, K. Kubat, A. Kunimmal Venadan, D. Kumar, E. Lisowski, F. Lisowski, J. Mędrala-Sowa, S. Moyo, W. Mryka, S. Niedźwiecki, P. Pandey, S. Parzych, A. Porcelli, B. Rachwał, E. P.D. Río, M. Rädler, S. Sharma, M. Skurzok, T. Szumlak, S. Tiwari, P. Tanty, K. Valsan Eliyan, E. Ł. Stępień, P. Moskal
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Total-body Positron Emission Tomography (TB-PET) is now being used in clinical practice; however, wider adoption in hospitals requires a reduction in construction costs [1]. We are developing a cost-efficient TB-PET system utilizing plastic scintillators [2,3]. This study discusses the current development status, including tests of individual detectors with SiPMs and new simulation results based on the finalized design. During the experimental phase, we tested individual detector units using SiPMs connected to the axial ends of plastic scintillator strips with a collimated beam of 511 keV photons from a Na-22 isotope source. We characterized the detector performance using two types of SiPMs, from Hamamatsu and Onsemi. Based on these characterization results, we evaluated performance across different scintillator lengths and selected two lengths for use in the final design of the total-body Jagiellonian PET (TB-J-PET). With these selected lengths (33 cm and 60 cm), the TB-J-PET geometry was redesigned, and simulations were conducted using GATE [4] to evaluate system sensitivity, scatter fraction, and spatial resolution. TB-J-PET will be built using the latest generation of J-PET technology, which is presented and discussed in this study. The first generation of the J-PET scanner was built using 192 plastic scintillator strips, each 50 cm long, and read out by PMTs [5,6]. The second generation is a modular, portable PET scanner constructed from 312 plastic strips, also with an AFOV of 50 cm, and read out by SiPMs [7,8]. In this work, we report on a 254 cm long system currently under construction, funded by the Polish Ministry of Science and Higher Education.

title: Adversarial Robustness of Vision in Open Foundation Models
authors: Jonathon Fox, William J Buchanan, Pavlos Papadopoulos
abstract: With the increase in deep learning, it becomes increasingly difficult to understand the model in which AI systems can identify objects. Thus, an adversary could aim to modify an image by adding unseen elements, which will confuse the AI in its recognition of an entity. This paper thus investigates the adversarial robustness of LLaVA-1.5-13B and Meta’s Llama 3.2 Vision-8B-2. These are tested for untargeted PGD (Projected Gradient Descent) against the visual input modality, and empirically evaluated on the Visual Question Answering (VQA) v2 dataset subset. The results of these adversarial attacks are then quantified using the standard VQA accuracy metric. This evaluation is then compared with the accuracy degradation (accuracy drop) of LLaVA and Llama 3.2 Vision. A key finding is that Llama 3.2 Vision, despite a lower baseline accuracy in this setup, exhibited a smaller drop in performance under attack compared to LLaVA, particularly at higher perturbation levels. Overall, the findings confirm that the vision modality represents a viable attack vector for degrading the performance of contemporary open-weight VLMs, including Meta’s Llama 3.2 Vision. Furthermore, they highlight that adversarial robustness does not necessarily correlate directly with standard benchmark performance and may be influenced by underlying architectural and training factors.

title: Time Window Optimization and Effect of D-T Generator Pulse Parameter Changes on Gamma Spectra in a Neutron Interrogation System for Contraband Detection
authors: K. Joshi, L. Drouet, S. Bogetic, X. Wen, J. P. Hayward
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Illegal diversion of shielded contraband like explosives, chemical weapons, and drugs in cargo can be non-destructively detected by observing the gammas rays produced during active neutron interrogation. The active gamma background produced during the neutron irradiation of such setups has signatures that interfere with the gammas produced by contraband, making rapid detection a challenge. The gamma spectra produced in neutron interrogation environments are time-dependent, and this time-dependence can be observed especially when using a pulsed neutron source. Gating the gamma spectra over time can help reject background gammas and improve the signal-noise-ratio of contraband gammas. In this work, we use a pulsed Sodern Genie <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$16 \mathrm{D}-\mathrm{T}$</tex> generator and a large 6 x 6 array of <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$3^{\prime \prime} \times 8^{\prime \prime} \text{NaI}(\text{Tl})$</tex> detectors to exploit the time-dependence of the neutron-induced gammas in our cargo inspection setup, for identification of optimized timing windows and improve the detection of contraband gammas like the nitrogen 10.8 MeV and chlorine 6.1 MeV signals. We also investigate the effect of changing the pulse width and repetition rate of the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\mathrm{D}-\mathrm{T}$</tex> generator on the time window optimization.

title: Low-Latency Secure Data Sharing in IoV: A Smart Contract-Based Framework with Parallel Outsourced Computing
authors: Siyuan Chen, Longfang Wen, Chenchen Zhang, Liangliang Wang, Weiwei Li
abstract: With the rapid development of the Internet of Vehicles (IoV), the need for reliable real-time communication and secure data sharing has become increasingly critical. However, existing solutions struggle with high computational demands and limited vehicle processing capability. While attribute-based encryption enables fine-grained data sharing, its high decryption overhead requires outsourcing to Roadside Units (RSUs), which introduces reliability risks such as ciphertext decryption errors, threatening system integrity. To address these issues, we propose a smart contract-based data sharing framework with parallel outsourced computing in IoV. Unlike most existing outsourced ABE (OABE) schemes that rely on serial decryption and lack robust parallel verification, and blockchain-integrated approaches that focus on general trust without tailored parallelism, our system uniquely combines MapReduce-based parallel decryption (dividing RSU tasks into distributed Map and Reduce stages) with a ciphertext verification mechanism (achieving 99.95% error detection with under 2% communication overhead) and smart contracts for auto-auditing (2 blocks, 0.003 ETH cost, preventing 98.7% malicious behaviors). Blockchain integration ensures service quality guarantees by providing accountability and ensuring that computation results are auditable, with responsible parties held accountable. Experiments and SUMO simulations show that our system maintains a decryption time of nearly 1 second with 100 attributes, improving by 1.6 seconds over serial decryption, while reducing transformation key generation complexity from O(n) to O(1). These results confirm that our system achieves efficient data sharing with computational correctness and security in IoV.

title: Pixellated Scintillators for Ultra-High Resolution Flat-Panel Detector Cone-Beam CT
authors: W. Zbijewski, V. Nagarkar, B. Singh
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: To overcome the loss of spatial resolution in Flat-Panel Detector (FPD) cone-beam CT (CBCT) due to light spread in the scintillator, we propose to use laser ablation in conjunction with Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD) to pixelate the scintillator film and coat the pixelation grooves with reflective/absorptive materials. Our earlier studies have demonstrated the feasibility of this approach in 700 µm-thick CsI: Tl suitable for body imaging. By enacting barriers to lateral light spread, we were able to improve the limiting spatial resolution compared to CsI:Tl of the same thickness by ~ 20% (frequency at 10% modulation, f<inf xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">10</inf>=4.7 lp/mm). We report on ongoing modeling and experimental work to improve detection efficiency and spatial resolution of this technology by new ablation and ALD processes to (i) reduce grove thickness (to minimize loss of CsI:Tl volume), and (ii) enhance the reflectivity of inter-pixel coatings (to mitigate absorptive light loss.) Cascaded system analysis assuming a 100 µm CMOS photodiode readout array and a 20 cm object indicates 2x fold improvement in high-frequency (5 lp/mm) Detective Quantum Efficiency (DQE) using the new film compared to the current unpixelated CsI:Tl. The pixelated scintillator will enhance visualization of features at the ~ 150 µm scale - for example, lung microvasculature, breast microcalcifications, complex endovascular devices, and bone trabeculae - especially in large body sites. Our experimental validation using a CBCT test bench focuses on trabecular bone to support improved imaging of osteoporosis and osteoarthritis.

title: Development and Flight Trial of a UAV based Gamma and Neutron Detection System for Large Area Monitoring
authors: L. Miller, A. Chapman, R. Hebden, S. Hardiman, J. M.C. Brown
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) based radiation sensor platforms enable efficient large area coverage while minimizing operator exposure to the harmful effects of radiation. A UAV-mounted dual-mode gamma ray and neutron detection system was developed, experimentally benchmarked for <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{137} \text{Cs}$</tex> (gamma source) and <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{252} \text{Cf}$</tex> (gamma-neutron source), and flight tested in a controlled environment to locate a single <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{137} \text{Cs}$</tex> source. These flight tests illustrated that this developed UAV radiation sensor platform was able to locate the <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">${ }^{137} \text{Cs}$</tex> source to within 0.25 m of its true location through the use of a linear least squares source distribution estimation method. Improvements to the estimation method, detailed characterization of the radiation detection system, and advances in UAV path-planning for this application will be presented.

title: IoT Data Mining of Air Cargo for Autonomous Artificial Intelligent Raising of Import Duties by Revenue and Customs
authors: Kareem Ali, Georgios Ioannou, Panos Lovieris, John Cosmas, Marcus Taylor, Georgios Dimitrakakis, Edward Chome, Sahin Mete, Taskin Kizil, Semih Celik, Betul Bulut
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: The vision presented by OECD’s Forum on Tax Administration proposes a digital transformation of tax administration by embedding tax collecting process into the everyday activities that taxpayers use to service their needs rather than being an add-on process. The ATTACC project demonstrates how this could be achieved through Generic Radio Access Network (GRAN)-IoT-enabled cross-border trading. This project seeks to reduce frictions in international trade that stem from data duplication and complex administrative processes to deliver an automated cross-border tax and customs compliance capability and apply AI to analyze large datasets to spot discrepancies between declared income and actual financial activity.

title: Evaluation of Machine Learning Models for Solar Energy Forecasting with DTBoost Improvement
authors: Feri Nur Hendi, Guruh Fajar Shidik
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Solar energy forecasting is crucial to support the reliability and efficiency of photovoltaic (PV) systems. However, most existing approaches either lack generalization due to limited temporal modeling or require complex deep learning models with high computational cost. This research addresses the gap by proposing a lightweight yet effective hybrid model called DTBoost, which combines XGBoost and Decision Tree Regressor in a two-stage framework to improve prediction accuracy. The model is evaluated using a public dataset from solar power plants in India, covering 34 days with 15-minute intervals. The evaluation uses standard metrics (MAE, MSE, RMSE, and R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup>) and comparative experiments against baseline models including ANN, SVR, GAM, and XGBoost. Experimental results show that DTBoost achieves the best performance with an R<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">2</sup> score of 0.99 and the lowest error rates, outperforming both classical and deep learning models. These results indicate that DTBoost offers a practical and interpretable solution for solar energy forecasting with limited data and low computational resources.

title: A Barzilai–Borwein Adaptive Learning Rate Enhanced Conjugate Gradient Algorithm for First-Order Takagi–Sugeno Fuzzy Neural Networks
authors: Jinru Cui, Jian Li, Yan Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: This paper presents Adaptive Learning Rate Polak-Ribiere-Polyak Conjugate Gradient Neuro-Fuzzy (ALR-PCGNF), an advanced hybrid optimization algorithm specifically designed for training first-order Takagi-Sugeno fuzzy neural networks. The methodology incorporates a Barzilai-Borwein adaptive learning rate mechanism within a Polak-Ribiere-Polyak conjugate gradient optimization framework. This integrated approach enables automated and dynamic step-size determination throughout the optimization process, effectively addressing the limitations of conventional gradient-based methods, including slow convergence rates and hypersensitivity to learning rate configurations. Comprehensive experimental evaluation conducted on multiple University of California, Irvine (UCI) classification benchmarks demonstrates that the proposed ALR-PCGNF algorithm achieves statistically superior generalization performance and accelerated convergence characteristics compared to state-of-the-art optimization techniques, including Fractional-Order Gradient Descent Method (FOGDM) and Integer-Order Gradient Descent Method (IOGDM).

title: Road Similarity-Based BEV-Satellite Image Matching for UGV Localization
authors: Chuang Yang, Zhenping Sun, Yafeng Bu, Bokai Liu, Xiaohui Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: To address the challenge of autonomous unmanned ground vehicle (UGV) localization in Global navigation satellite system (GNSS) denied off-road environments, this study proposes a matching-based localization method that leverages bird’s-eye view (BEV) perception image and satellite map within a road similarity space to achieve high-precision positioning. We first implement a robust LiDAR-inertial odometry system, followed by the fusion of LiDAR and image data to generate a local BEV perception image of the UGV. This approach mitigates the significant viewpoint discrepancy between ground-view images and satellite map. The BEV image and satellite map are then projected into the road similarity space, where normalized cross correlation (NCC) is computed to assess the matching score. Finally, a particle filter is employed to estimate the probability distribution of the vehicle’s pose. By comparing with GNSS ground truth, our localization system demonstrated stability without divergence over a long-distance test of $\mathbf{1 0 ~ k m}$, achieving an average lateral error of only 0.89 meters and an average planar Euclidean error of 3.41 meters. These results demonstrate superior performance compared to existing state-of-theart methods in the field. Furthermore, it maintained accurate and stable global localization even under nighttime conditions, further validating its robustness and adaptability.

title: Implementation of Cloud-Edge Collaborative Task Offloading Algorithm Based on Particle Swarm Optimization
authors: Zheng Hong, Yuan Huang, Xin Wu, Yan He, Zhengdong Li
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: Aiming at the problems of large amount of data in terminal devices and insufficient local computing power in virtual reality and auto drive system, while cloud computing has transmission delay and network disturbance, this paper constructs a three-tier architecture model of terminal devices, edge servers, and cloud servers. The optimization of computing unloading strategy is modeled as a comprehensive model to optimize task delay and equipment energy consumption. Particle swarm optimization algorithm is used to calculate the minimum system cost and obtain the best unloading strategy. The simulation results show that the algorithm reduces the computational complexity by $17.5 \%$ to $42.2 \%$ compared to the fully local offloading strategy algorithm and by $\mathbf{1 0} \boldsymbol{\%}$ to $\mathbf{2 5 . 1 \%}$ compared to the random strategy algorithm, effectively improving the computational efficiency.

title: Comparative Evaluation of Traditional Machine Learning and Deep Learning Models for Early Detection of Breast Cancer
authors: Yuyang Ding, Yiren Pan, Xiexin Hu
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: Early and accurate diagnosis of breast cancer is critical for patient outcomes. This study conducts a comparative evaluation of traditional machine learning models (Logistic Regression, Random Forest, XGBoost) and a deep learning Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) model applied to clinical breast cancer data. We perform comprehensive exploratory data analysis and assess model performance through metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, F1-score, and AUC. Results indicate that the deep learning MLP achieves the best classification performance. Visualizations of data distributions and model evaluation metrics aid interpretability and analysis.

title: Ensemble Model Combination-Based Method for Marine Temperature Data Quality Control
authors: You Luo, Xuhu Ren, Yanfeng Wan, Xinfang Li, Canming Huang, Ling Pang, Tianyun Su
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Marine temperature data play a pivotal role in global ocean observation and climate research, and quality control is critical to ensure the reliability of these data. This study proposes a multi-model ensemble-based method for marine data quality control. Specifically, common classification algorithms are selected as base learners to generate preliminary predictions for data quality labels, and then the identifier of the marine data quality is given by the stacking method. To address class imbalance, adaptive under-sampling is employed to mitigate imbalance ratios, while climatological data are incorporated to enhance anomaly detection capabilities. Evaluated using Argo data from the South China Sea, the results show that the accuracy, recall and F1 index of the stacking method in the test set are 0.90, 0.78 and 0.84, respectively, which are better than other models compared in this study.

title: Comparative Analysis of Power Losses in Different Network Topologies and Identification of Optimal Configurations
authors: Andrii Shkrebela, Igor Khomenko, Viktor Orlov
publish: 2025 IEEE 6th KhPI Week on Advanced Technology (KhPIWeek)
abstract: The paper presents a comparative analysis of power losses in electrical distribution networks with different topologies: ring and radial. Using a fragment of a real network scheme with voltage levels of 110, 35, and 10 kV, operating mode calculations were performed under normal conditions and with various line disconnection scenarios. The influence of network configuration on the redistribution of currents and on power losses in lines and transformers is investigated. Based on the obtained results, the technical and economic performance of radial and ring configurations is compared, indicating general conditions for their preferable use. An increase in losses in transformers and lines is identified as a result of current redistribution under certain network configurations. The findings of the study can help improve the efficiency of designing and operating distribution networks.

title: Photoluminescence vs Scintillation in Ultrathin BGO and GAGG: Initial Studies Towards a Super-Scintillator
authors: M.S. Lee, G. Chinn, D. Jeong, C. S. Levin
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: To develop next-generation “super-scintillators,” a promising approach is to enhance light emission from scintillators by exploiting plasmonic nanostructures and ultrathin geometries. In this study, we explored the feasibility of using <tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$100 \mu ~\mathrm{m}$</tex>-thick single-crystal GAGG and BGO slabs as initial studies of super-scintillator platforms, comparing their photoluminescence (PL) and radiation-induced scintillation characteristics.

title: Dynamic Total-Body Imaging of Therapeutic Alpha-Emitters and their Daughters in Mice With the Alpha-SPECT-Mini-II: A Spectral-SPECT System with Total-Body/Microscopic Dual-FOV Apertures
authors: C. Yang, E. Zannoni, C. Fong, A. Qin, X. Huang, Z. Ouyang, B. Deleon, Y. Du, S. Ray, G. Sgouros, L.-J. Meng
publish: 2025 IEEE Nuclear Science Symposium (NSS), Medical Imaging Conference (MIC) and Room Temperature Semiconductor Detector Conference (RTSD)
abstract: Over the past decade, alpha-emitter radiopharmaceutical therapy (<tex xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">$\alpha$</tex>-RPT) has attracted tremendous attention as a powerful cancer treatment approach in both preclinical and clinical applications. Dosimetry is the key to understanding the toxicity and efficacy profiles of αRPTs. Accurate knowledge of the distribution of the parent and daughter radionuclides is essential for precise dosimetry. For conventional radiopharmaceuticals, SPECT imaging provides a means to measure the in vivo biodistribution of radionuclides.

title: Domain-Enhanced SimCSE with Lexicon Injection for Semantic Representation of Technical Texts
authors: Zhida Song, Xiaotong Guan, Naijun Zhao, Jingbo Zhao
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning, Pattern Recognition and Automation Engineering (MLPRAE)
abstract: This study proposes an enhanced semantic representation model for Airbus Service Bulletin (SB) texts by integrating an improved SimCSE framework with domain-specific lexicon injection. To address the challenge of accurately capturing highly technical and standardized terminology within SBs, we first construct a specialized aerospace maintenance dictionary. This lexicon is then utilized to generate domain-aware positive samples during the contrastive learning process of SimCSE, forcing the model to learn invariant representations for technical terms and their synonyms. The resulting model generates high-quality sentence embeddings that are both semantically rich and domain-sensitive. Evaluated on downstream tasks such as SB retrieval and classification, our approach demonstrates superior performance compared to baseline models, providing a robust foundation for automated processing and knowledge discovery in aerospace maintenance documentation.

title: Deep Learning for Enhanced DDoS Detection in Software-Defined Networks: A Review
authors: Abdinasir Hirsi, Abdirahman Hassan Mohamud, Mohamed Ahmed, Mohamed Jama, Lukman Audah, Abdirizak Abdullahi Khalif, Abubakar Abdi Warsame, Jafar Ismail Mohamed, Hafso Mohamed Mohamoud, Mohamed Elmi Ahmed, Mohamed Osman Omar, Salman Ahmed
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: Software-Defined Networking (SDN) has revolutionized network management and scalability by enabling centralized control and programmability. However, this centralized architecture also exposes SDN to significant security vulnerabilities, with distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks posing one of the most severe threats. These attacks exploit SDN flow tables and disrupt critical network operations, thereby affecting both stability and performance. This paper presents a comprehensive review of supervised, unsupervised, and hybrid deep learning (DL) techniques for DDoS detection in SDN. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first study to provide a detailed analysis of these approaches in a single study. This study examined the effectiveness of DL models, highlighting their capabilities, advantages, and limitations in securing SDN environments. State-of-the-art methods are reviewed, with a focus on performance metrics such as detection accuracy, scalability, and computational efficiency. Additionally, this study identifies key research challenges and explores future directions for advancing DDoS detection using deep learning in SDN. The structure includes a review of related works, a taxonomy of DL techniques, and a conclusion summarizing the key insights and implications.

title: Comprehensive Methodology for Relay Protection Coordination in Distribution Networks with Distributed Generation
authors: Ivan Burdukov
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The increasing penetration of distributed generation in distribution networks poses significant challenges for protection coordination due to bidirectional power flows, variable fault contributions, and transformer magnetizing inrush currents. This paper presents a microgrid model with IEC-type configuration developed in ETAP software, including synchronous machine-based sources, wind turbines, and realistic relay settings. Initial analysis demonstrated that conventional inverse time-current characteristics and nonstandard tripping curves could not ensure both sensitivity and selectivity, leading to miscoordination when transformer inrush currents were present. To address these limitations, a set of enhancements was introduced, including blocking functions against transformer inrush currents, the transition to definitetime characteristics, and the integration of voltage-supervised directional overcurrent protection. Autonomous automatic circuit reclosers were employed to avoid dependence on centralized communication-based schemes. Simulation results confirmed that the proposed approach improves protection reliability under grid-connected, islanded, and parallel modes of operation, while maintaining robust performance across a wide range of fault scenarios. The methodology simplifies implementation by eliminating complex communication infrastructures and provides a scalable framework for future power systems, including interconnected microgrids and data center infrastructures. These results demonstrate that high levels of protection dependability and selectivity can be achieved with practical, cost-effective solutions tailored to distributed generation networks.

title: Improved Model-Free Predictive Current Control with Novel Nonlinear Integral Sliding Mode Observer for DT-PMSM
authors: Ran Tao, Yufeng Jiang, Siyu Wang, Wei Wang
publish: 2025 IEEE International Conference on Predictive Control of Electrical Drives and Power Electronics (PRECEDE)
abstract: This paper proposes a novel nonlinear integral sliding mode observer (NNI-SMO)-based model-free current predictive control method for dual three-phase Permanent magnet synchronous motor (DT-PMSM). The NNI-SMO is designed based on Lyapunov stability theory to ensure the stability of the proposed method. In addition, this paper analyzes and compares the NNI-SMO method with conventional deadbeat predictive current control and standard ISMO methods. The results demonstrate that the proposed NNI-SMO effectively eliminates high-frequency harmonic disturbances without relying on inverter nonlinearity information. Moreover, the NNI-SMO significantly reduces torque ripple and mitigates current distortion caused by inverter nonlinearity and system disturbances. Finally, simulation results validate the robustness of the proposed method, highlighting its effectiveness in reducing torque ripple and suppressing harmonic disturbances.

title: Development of Hybrid Algorithm for Named Entity Recognition in Uzbek Public Administration Texts
authors: Nilufar Abdurakhmonova, Nilufar Adizova, Dilnoza Jamolitdinova, Abbos Begimov, Aydin Sultanova, Gulkhayo Juraeva
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The accelerating digital transformation of public administration in Uzbekistan generates large volumes of unstructured legal text that needs to be indexed, verified, and searched in real time. This paper presents a hybrid named entity recognition framework adapted for text analysis in this area. The algorithm starts with two rule-based preprocessing steps — alphabet standardization (Cyrillic → Latin) and dialect normalization — that mitigate orthographic variability and regional lexical drift. In addition, Bidirectional LSTM coupled with convolutional neural networks and a conditional random fields layer were used as neural network technologies for the named entity recognition language model. The system is trained on a curated, manually annotated corpus of Uzbek government documents that covers five main entity types: date/ time, organization, location, person, and money. It is worth noting that the sentences in the corpus are marked up using the BIOES scheme, which provides comprehensive marking of the entire text. Experiments show that each preprocessing component provides measurable performance improvements and that the hybrid architecture outperforms the baseline Transformers.

title: Large Language Models: Principles, Applications, and Cutting-edge Advances
authors: Xuefei Bian, Yingchun Zhang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning, Pattern Recognition and Automation Engineering (MLPRAE)
abstract: In recent years, large language models (LLMs) have become a cornerstone of artificial intelligence, advancing natural language processing, multimodal interaction, and intelligent agent development. This paper reviews the theoretical foundations, training methods, and representative applications of LLMs. It outlines the basics of machine learning and neural networks, analyzes the Transformer architecture and its variants, and surveys applications in scientific research, programming, and healthcare. The integration of LLMs with reinforcement learning and knowledge graphs is also discussed. Current challenges—such as hallucination, scalability, interpretability, and alignment—are summarized, alongside prospects for future development. The paper makes three main contributions: it proposes a "task– context–risk" taxonomy of application scenarios, synthesizes methodological frameworks for alignment and integration, and offers a forward-looking perspective on embodied LLMs, highlighting their trajectory toward autonomous decision-making agents.

title: HyDiabNet: A Hybrid Neural Network Architecture for Enhanced Multi-Class Diabetes Classification
authors: Yue Wang
publish: 2025 2nd International Conference on Machine Learning, Pattern Recognition and Automation Engineering (MLPRAE)
abstract: This paper presents HyDiabNet, a hybrid neural network for multi-class diabetes classification (non-diabetic, prediabetic, diabetic) using biomedical markers. Integrating multi-path feature processing, attention, and ensemble learning, it achieves 94.2% accuracy, outperforming traditional methods. Feature analysis highlights HbA1c, triglycerides, and BMI as key predictors, showing HyDiabNet’s promise in diabetes screening and risk stratification.

title: Application Specifics of Fractional-Order Controllers for Electric Drive Control System Tuning
authors: Rodion Ketov, Andrey Swarovsky, Ilya Sherstobitov, Stepan Sukhinin, Ilya Ivanov, Denis Kotin
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: The paper discusses the development of a control system for the position control of an electric motor using fractional-order controllers. It is suggested to modify the controllers obtained by classical tuning methods to a modular and symmetrical optimum in order to achieve changes in the qualitative and quantitative characteristics of the transient behavior of the system. As a result of computer simulation, asymptotic Bode magnitude plot with a logarithmic scale were obtained for the proposed variations of the controller synthesis, and the shapes of transients were in the form of a trapezoid for the work program. The experiment demonstrated that fractional-order controllers significantly affect the speed and steady-state errors of the control system, which directly influences the settling time. When a derivative term is used in the control law and the system is set to a symmetrical optimum, the overshoot decreases while the transient time decreases. However, the experiment also demonstrated the limitations of using fractional-degree controllers, as self-oscillation occurs in the output variable at a certain point.

title: Multiperspective Geo-AI for Optimizing Public Transportation in West Jakarta
authors: Christian Daniel Wiranata, Juandito Sugiyanto, Nicander Jevon Delano, Said Achmad
publish: 2025 International Seminar on Application for Technology of Information and Communication (iSemantic)
abstract: This Research utilizes artificial intelligence and geospatial (Geo-AI) to optimize the efficiency of public transportation in West Jakarta, addressing traffic jam and urban mobility challenges. By integrating geospatial data and machine learning, this research analyzes the population density, road network, and public transportation stops. Data sourced from Portal Geo Spasial Indonesia, Badan Informasi Geospasial, and Open Street Map processed using QGIS and Python. The processing of the data focuses on administrative boundaries and the transportation infrastructures in West Jakarta. Data processing, spatial visualization, K-means clustering to cluster the district based on the population density and stop points of the transportation services. Analysis shows that the population distribution is not evenly distributed, with districts like Petamburan, Tambora, and Taman Sari showing high density, while others are less populated. Stop points data also shows that there are districts with an imbalance ratio of population density and the stop points. K-means Clustering, with Silhouette Score of 0.336 and an elbow point at K= 3 determined by the Elbow Method is used for the clustering process. Clustering results show districts with inadequate transportation services; this result could help in optimizing public transportation by increasing its efficiency and equalization of transportation services and access. Analysis results show that artificial intelligence and geospatial can be used to increase the user experience and optimize the services of public transportation. Future research could incorporate additional parameters and expand the scope to larger area; refining research methods could increase accuracy and the quality of result.

title: Natural Language Processing for Pedagogical Insight: A Study of User Reviews in Teacher Training Simulators
authors: Rudi Susilana, Cepi Riyana, Gema Rullyana, Dadi Mulyadi, M. Ridwan Sutisna, Della Amelia
publish: 2025 11th International Conference on Education and Technology (ICET)
abstract: This study applies sentiment analysis and aspect-based classification to evaluate pedagogical dimensions in five teacher training simulator applications available on the Google Play Store. Utilizing a fine-tuned BERT model and a rule-based keyword-matching approach grounded in the UNESCO teaching competencies framework, user reviews were analyzed across dimensions such as Pedagogical Practices, Assessment and Feedback, and Classroom Management. WordCloud visualizations identified dominant instructional terms such as teach, student, and question, reflecting strong associations with direct teaching experiences. Sentiment analysis revealed a predominance of positive feedback, particularly in High School Teacher Games Life. In contrast, the Planning and Preparation aspect was consistently underrepresented, suggesting limited simulation support for instructional design. These findings expose pedagogical imbalances in current applications and offer a data-driven basis for enhancing teacher training simulations.

title: From Tokens to Channels: Language Models for High-Frequency CSI Prediction in Cell-Free FDD Systems
authors: Yutian Cheng
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Electronic Information Engineering and Computer Science (EIECS)
abstract: In wideband high-frequency (mmWave/THz) FDD cell-free massive MIMO systems, the uplink and downlink channels are decoupled in frequency, making it highly challenging for distributed access points (APs) to estimate downlink channels without explicit user feedback. To address this, we propose a novel inference-based method that treats the uplink-to-downlink channel relationship as a logical reasoning process. Specifically, we design a lightweight Transformer model that takes uplink channel estimates as logical premises and infers downlink coefficients as conclusions. This is motivated by the short-tap nature of high-frequency wideband channels in the time domain, which induces strong frequency-domain correlations in fading and phase across subcarriers. Building on this, the approach leverages a lightweight Transformer integrated with an SNR-adaptive multi-component loss. The loss dynamically optimizes training against SNR-varying error dominance. This obviates predefined mappings or iterative refinement, enabling efficient and generalizable channel estimation. Simulation results demonstrate that our method not only achieves higher estimation accuracy, but also reduces computational complexity by up to 40% and lowers memory usage, making it well-suited for practical wideband FDD deployments.

title: Research on Site Reliability Optimization Technology Based on Synthetic Monitoring in Cloud Environments
authors: Yifan Yang
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: This paper proposes a site reliability optimization technique based on synthetic monitoring. By simulating the user behavior to build an active monitoring mechanism, combined with anomaly detection, root cause analysis and fault prediction methods, it realizes real-time mastery of site operation status and fault self-healing. A Kubernetes-based experimental environment is constructed, and a variety of typical failure scenarios are designed for comparative experiments. The results show that synthetic monitoring outperforms traditional monitoring in terms of failure detection timeliness, recovery efficiency, and alarm accuracy. The relevant technical solutions have strong scalability and practical value, and provide technical support and theoretical basis for improving the business continuity of cloud platform.

title: Algorithms for Defining Phase Modulation Laws Radar Systems Exposed to Passive Noise
authors: Vladimir Mikhaylovich Artyushenko, Vladimir Ivanovich Volovach, Evgeny Kimovich Samarov
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Algorithms for defining the phase modulation law to reduce the influence of passive noise are proposed and analyzed. The structure and algorithms of the bleaching filter exposed to passive noise in the form of a discrete Gaussian-Markov random process are determined. It is shown that the optimization problem of the phase modulation law can be formulated as the problem of determining the sequence of values of the initial phases of the probing signal by the criterion of minimum variance of the uncompensated passive noise residue at the output of the bleaching filter. It is advisable to choose the variance estimate as a quality indicator. It is shown that fulfilling the optimality condition leads to the choice of a phase modulation law that reduces the frequency of passive noise. The optimization conditions of the phase modulation law are determined. A numerical illustration of the proposed method for synthesizing the phase modulation law when two passive noise are superimposed is given. The structures of the bleaching filter are described for two practically significant cases. The values of the suppression coefficient of the bleaching filter are determined for different values of the Doppler phasing constants. It is shown that optimization of the phase modulation law in accordance with the proposed algorithms provides a significant gain in the value of the passive noise suppression coefficient compared to the case of using the unmodulated signal only at different values of Doppler phasing constants.

title: Optimization of image anomaly recognition model for avian health monitoring
authors: Mingyu Guo
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: Facing the current problem of lack of efficient health monitoring means in avian farms, a method based on two-branch network for recognition of abnormal avian behaviors is proposed. The feature extraction capability is enhanced by designing a multi-level hybrid attention mechanism, the model training process is optimized by using an adaptive weighted multi-task loss function, and the model is lightweighted by combining structured pruning and knowledge distillation. The method significantly improves the accuracy and real-time performance of abnormal behavior recognition and provides a new technical solution for intelligent breeding monitoring.

title: A Multi-Algorithm Fusion Framework for Unsupervised Anomaly Detection in Employee Account Behavior
authors: Xiang Chen, Min Lin, Xiaodong Zhang, Yuxia Cheng, Wanjiang Gao, Jinfeng Li, Yao Chen, Jitao He
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Within the context of enterprise informatisation, anomalous employee account behaviour poses significant risks of data breaches. Traditional approaches relying on manual rules and static thresholds suffer from poor adaptability and inadequate detection of latent anomalies. This paper proposes an unsupervised multi-algorithm fusion anomaly detection framework.This framework integrates five machine learning algorithms, including Isolation Forest and Local Outlier Factor (LOF), to automate feature extraction. This significantly enhances the representation and modelling capabilities of high-dimensional features, effectively addressing the shortcomings of traditional single-method approaches in detection efficiency, model robustness, and result interpretability. Consequently, it achieves high-precision identification and rapid response to complexdata distributions and dynamic anomaly patterns. The key innovations include: (1) adaptability to unlabeled data, eliminating the dependency on supervised learning; (2) a collaborative multi-algorithm mechanism that enhances coverage of diverse anomalies; and (3) a closed-loop optimization ecosystem that outputs labeled data to drive iterative model improvement. Deployed in the Guangdong Unicom AI security project, the framework effectively identified hidden anomalies such as "high-frequency nighttime operations in sensitive areas," demonstrating its practical value in intelligent account security management.

title: An efficient hybrid uncertainty propagation method for black-box problems via P-box
authors: Xinyu Sun, Liang Yan, Xiaojun Duan, Jiaqi Liu
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: The probability box (P-box) provides a robust framework for characterizing hybrid uncertainty by defining bounds on the cumulative distribution function (CDF) of a random variable, making it highly significant for uncertainty propagation analysis in engineering and computational modeling. Current methods for computing P-box boundaries are mainly divided into sampling methods and analytical methods. Sampling methods suffer from low computational efficiency in high-dimensional complex models, while analytical methods are not applicable to black-box models. This paper proposes a novel parametric P-box uncertainty propagation method based on the separation of aleatory and epistemic uncertainties. The method efficiently computes P-box boundaries by first determining the range of expected values for each variable to identify the function's maximum and minimum values, which serve as the midpoints of the P-box bounds. Subsequently, sampling points are generated based on the minimum and maximum standard deviations of each variable at its minimum and maximum values. These sampling points are then input into the model to obtain the corresponding CDF curves for the four combinations of function outputs. The boundaries of these CDF curves are used to define the P-box of the function output. This algorithm is computationally efficient and applicable to black-box models. Its effectiveness is demonstrated through a numerical simulation test for the HEG shock tunnel cylindrical model experiment, where the proposed method shows advantages over the Optimization via Simulation (OPS) approach in both computational accuracy and efficiency.

title: A Steganography Framework Based on Residual Feature Extractor and Conditional Discriminator
authors: Ning Wu, Xiaolong Chen
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: Digital image steganography plays an important role in copyright protection and covert communication. However, existing approaches often struggle to balance high-quality image generation with low computational overhead. In this paper, we propose a tri-party adversarial steganography framework based on a residual feature extractor and a conditional discriminator. Specifically, the secret image is first compressed into a low-dimensional feature vector to reduce memory consumption; then the vector is fused with cover image features at the bottleneck of a U-Net generator to produce high-quality stego images; finally, a conditional discriminator is introduced to enforce consistency between the stego image and the hidden secret. Experiments on the BOSSBase dataset demonstrate that the proposed method outperforms existing approaches in terms of PSNR and SSIM, while achieving superior resistance to steganalysis and higher computational efficiency.

title: RefFace: Generating 3D Speech-Driven Animation with Reference
authors: Zhuoliang Jiang, Lanfang Dong
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Speech-driven facial animation has a wide range of applications in entertainment, education, virtual reality and telecommunications. Present state-of-the-art methods primarily concentrate on creating realistic lip movements using audio signals, while neglecting facial animations unrelated to the audio. To tackle this issue, we present RefFace, a novel speech-driven 3D animation model capable of synthesizing high-fidelity 3D motion sequences of talking heads from audio signals. Our proposed method demonstrates capabilities in synthesizing both realistic lip movements and facial expressions based on predefined landmarks as reference. We investigate the generation mechanism of different face regions controlled by audio and landmark, and introduce an innovative surface normal vector loss to enforce geometric coherence across facial components. Notably, experiment shows that our model generates lip motions comparable to the state-of-the-art models, while capable of reproducing target facial expressions through cross-sequence reference adaptation. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first work that utilizes facial landmarks as extra condition to generate realistic and high-quality talking heads, marking an advance in the field of speech driven 3D animation.

title: Cloud Classification using Millimeter-wave Cloud Radar Observations and Cloud Images via Visual Language Models
authors: Yuzhu Chu, Zeyu Yu, Zhongxiang Deng, Zhong Zhang, Shuang Liu, Chaojun Shi
publish: 2025 5th International Conference on Artificial Intelligence, Automation and High Performance Computing (AIAHPC)
abstract: Clouds play a significant role in the Earth’s climate system and meteorological forecasting, and cloud classification is of great importance. In present, millimeter-wave radar and ground-based cloud image are widely employed for cloud classification. However, existing methods only use one type of data. In this paper, we propose to use Visual Language Model (VLM) for cloud classification with both radar data and cloud images. The experimental comparisons verify that our multi-modal method achieves a performance improvement of 10.6% and 8.2% over the best results obtained from the radar-only and image-only modalities, respectively.

title: Design and Analysis of the Use of an IoT System for Monitoring Body Temperature Based on the DS18B20 Sensor with RFID Integration Using System Usability Scale (SUS)
authors: Rinaldi Saragih, Hilal Huda, Muhammad Faris Fathoni, Milankumar Rana
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Software Engineering and Information Technology (ICoSEIT)
abstract: The advancement of the Internet of Things (IoT) has significantly impacted the healthcare sector, particularly in body temperature monitoring. This study aims to design an IoT-based body temperature monitoring system that integrates the DS18B20 sensor, Radio Frequency Identification (RFID) module, and ESP8266 microcontroller as the central processor and data transmitter to the server. The use of the DS18B20 sensor enables high-accuracy temperature measurements. The integration of RFID technology enhances data management efficiency through fast and precise automatic identification. Furthermore, the system's effectiveness is evaluated using the System Usability Scale (SUS) to assess user satisfaction and ease of use. The expected outcome is the development of an efficient and accurate temperature monitoring solution that contributes to improving overall service quality.

title: Development of Algorithm for Classification of Financial Texts in the Uzbek Language
authors: Nafisa Ganijanova, Mukhiddin Shakarov, Sadokat Nurmanova, Salomat Otamurodova, Minavar Tilavova, Jasur Isroilov
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This article proposes a method for automated text classification by document type based on logistic regression and N-gram vectorization. The goal of the study is to create an algorithm that can reliably process both “simple” corpora with a clear structure and “complex” collections with heterogeneous topics, spelling errors, and informal speech elements. The algorithm includes preprocessing (normalization, tokenization), N-gram feature extraction (unigrams and bigrams) using TF-IDF, and training a multi-class logistic regression classifier (one-vs-rest). Three datasets of varying complexity were prepared for objective validation; metrics are evaluated in terms of Accuracy, Precision/Recall, and F1 (macro/micro), confusion matrices and PR curves are constructed, allowing for analysis of model behavior at class boundaries. Experiments have shown that the algorithm demonstrates high accuracy on structured texts (e.g., official business documents), with the best results achieved by using early stopping and careful hyperparameter tuning. Predictions are returned as categories with probabilities, simplifying threshold tuning and integration into real-world systems such as banking applications, electronic document management, and legal pipelines. A comparative review of alternative solutions was also conducted, highlighting key challenges in the field: sensitivity to code-switching and dialectal forms, dependence on the completeness of the feature dictionary, and degradation on “dirty” data. Planned development areas include expanding the training/test corpora, adding normalization modules (morphology, spelling, dialect), probability calibration, and transitioning to neural network architectures and contextual representations (e.g., transformers and sentence embeddings) for working with large, multidimensional data and increased language variability.

title: Robust Instance Segmentation with Dynamic Gating Fusion and Adaptive Matching for Stable Training
authors: Zhimeng Jiao, Jinnan Zhang, Yutao Shi, Zheyu Liu, Xiaotian Yang, Zhenhai Li, Haitao Zhang, Xia Zhang
publish: 2025 IEEE 13th International Conference on Computer Science and Network Technology (ICCSNT)
abstract: Instance segmentation has become a key task in computer vision with broad applications in autonomous driving, medical imaging, and intelligent surveillance. Recent mask embedding-based transformers combine spatial features with compact embeddings to reconstruct object masks. However, existing designs rely on static fusion and fixed matching strategies, which limits adaptability across diverse scenarios. In this work, we propose two lightweight and plug-and-play improvements. First, a Dynamic Gating Fusion (DGF) module adaptively balances spatial and embedding features through learnable channel-wise and spatial gates, enabling the model to emphasize fine details or semantic cues depending on context. Second, an Adaptive Matching and Loss Weighting (AMLW) scheme dynamically re-weights Hungarian matching costs and loss terms via a lightweight predictor, improving consistency between box and mask supervision. Both modules are training-stable and easy to integrate into existing frameworks without altering objectives or pipelines. The experimental results on the COCO dataset demonstrate that the proposed method significantly enhances training stability through the DGF and AMLW modules, effectively addressing the common convergence issues in deep learning and providing a reliable training framework for instance segmentation tasks. These results highlight the potential of dynamic mechanisms to enhance the robustness and stability of transformer-based instance segmentation in real-world intelligent systems, improving its adaptability in complex environments.

title: Logical Environment for Intelligent Robot Control
authors: Evgenii Cherkashin, Nadezhda Nagul, Artem Davydov, Yingjie Wang, Haojun Teng
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: This paper proposes a concept of an integrated logical environment, specifically engineered for the formalization, solving, and practical implementation of complex control tasks for autonomous robots, with a particular focus on autonomous underwater vehicles, as well as coordinated groups of robots. The control architecture considered is supposed to be hierarchically structured, featuring a discrete event system as its core, which serves to seamlessly interconnect all decision-making and execution levels within the hierarchy. To process asynchronous events and ensure critical behavioral constraints within the framework of supervisory control theory, we employ a non-Horn calculus of positively-constructed formulas powered by an intuitionistic inference engine. A pivotal element of the environment is a novel Domain-Specific Language (DSL), developed to allow for the intuitive and natural expression of the control system's logic in a manner that is directly aligned with problem-solving objectives. This DSL facilitates the description of system components and their interactions, which are then automatically translated for processing by the logical engine. The approach is illustrated through a case study of the classic Box Pushing problem.

title: Multimodal Radiomic Profiling Can Distinguish AT1- and AT2- Cell of Origin Lung Adenocarcinoma Models
authors: Sophia Hai, Minxiao Yang, Xiaomeng Lei, Dighvijay Giri, Steven Cen, Crystal Marconett, Bino Varghese
publish: 2025 21st International Symposium on Biomedical Image Processing and Analysis (SIPAIM)
abstract: Lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD) is a highly heterogeneous disease with diverse biological behaviors and clinical outcomes, which complicates diagnosis and treatment strategies. Recent research has demonstrated that LUAD can originate from multiple alveolar cell types, including GRAMD2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup> alveolar type I (AT1) cells and SFTPC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup> alveolar type II (AT2) cells, each giving rise to tumors with distinct histological features and transcriptomic profiles. Activation of the KRAS<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">G12D</sup> oncogene in either AT1 or AT2 cells leads to the development of multifocal LUAD, but it is not fully understood how the cell of origin affects tumor characteristics observable through imaging techniques. In this study, we investigated the influence of cell origin on radiomic signatures by comparing LUAD models derived from SFTPC<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup> AT2 cells (SKTG) and GRAMD2<sup xmlns:mml="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">+</sup> AT1 cells (GKTG). Using fast spin echo (FSE) MRI sequences, we identified distinct and cell-of-origin–specific radiomic profiles, with the SKTG tumors showing a greater number of significantly (p < 0.05) different features, indicating unique imaging phenotypes between the two tumor types. Notably, SKTG tumors exhibited increasing radiomic heterogeneity over time, which may correlate with a more aggressive tumor behavior and progression compared to GKTG tumors. These findings underscore the diagnostic and prognostic potential of radiomics to non-invasively differentiate LUAD lesions based on their cellular origin. By capturing tumor heterogeneity and progression longitudinally through imaging, radiomic analysis offers promising avenues for personalized treatment planning and improved patient management tailored to AT1- versus AT2-derived LUAD. This approach may ultimately enhance early detection, therapeutic response monitoring, and clinical outcomes in lung cancer patients.

title: Prevention of Dynamic Instability During Capacity Deficits via Enhanced Voltage-Frequency Regulation
authors: Zagdkhorol Bayasgalan, Gankhuleg Davaasambyy, Tsetsgee Bayasgalan, Bat-Undral Baasan, Erdenetuya Myagmar, Anastasia Rusina
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Mongolia's power system increasingly risks dynamic instability because of persistent capacity shortfalls, weak interconnections, and the rapid growth of variable renewables. These factors make frequency and voltage control difficult, especially during peak demand and seasonal shortages. This study proposes a coordinated voltage–frequency (V–F) regulation framework designed to limit instability during capacity-deficit conditions. We begin with a system diagnosis that treats the present crisis as a multidimensional vulnerability spanning structural, operational, and climatic stressors. Building on this, we introduce a region-wise Dynamic Stability Index (DSI) that supports real-time resilience assessment and prioritization of control actions. We validate the framework on detailed models of the Central Energy System, with case studies centered on the Khangai region. Across representative contingencies, the approach delivers faster recovery of the frequency nadir, tighter voltage profiles, and stronger damping of inter-area oscillations. The findings translate into actionable guidance for system operators and planners seeking to maintain stability as Mongolia's grid expands and its resource mix evolves.

title: Neural Network Technology in Classification of Objects of Critical Information Infrastructure
authors: Anton Kiselev, Victor Belov, Natalia Voronina
publish: 2025 IEEE XVII International Scientific and Technical Conference on Actual Problems of Electronic Instrument Engineering (APEIE)
abstract: Categorizing critical information infrastructure objects is the initial stage in organizing their protection, and, therefore, the timeliness and correctness of the classification directly determines how quickly and effectively the protection against information security threats will be implemented. The paper presents an algorithm and software for classifying critical information infrastructure objects. To develop the classifier, neural network technology was used, which comprises several stages: determining the data formats that the classifier must support; identifying the operations that need to be performed with the data; establishing the functions that must be available to the user. The software structure consists of two parts: the function of training the neural network model and the function of classifying a new file. The interface of the critical information infrastructure object classifier contains the following elements: a button for loading training data; a button for classifying files; a window for outputting model estimates; a window for outputting classification results. The classifier was tested on prepared data.

title: Intelligent Diagnosis of COVID-19 from Chest X-ray Images Based on Vision Mamba: Comparative Analysis and Performance Evaluation of Mainstream Models
authors: Xiangwen Huang
publish: 2025 3rd International Conference on Algorithm, Image Processing and Machine Vision (AIPMV)
abstract: Accurate identification of pulmonary diseases is of great clinical significance and public health value, as it facilitates early intervention, improves clinical outcomes, and reduces the overall disease burden. This study focuses on Chest X-ray (CXR) imaging and systematically evaluates the image classification performance of several mainstream visual models in the task of pulmonary disease recognition. Leveraging the advantages of CXR—namely its low cost, high efficiency, and minimal radiation—the research selects representative models across different architectural paradigms, including conventional Convolutional Neural Networks (CNNs) such as VGG, ResNet, and DenseNet; the Transformer-based Swin Transformer model; and the lightweight state space model Vision Mamba. A unified experimental framework is established to comprehensively compare these models on a public COVID-19 CXR dataset. The evaluation considers four dimensions: classification accuracy, weighted F1-score, computational complexity (measured in Floating Point Operations), and the number of trainable parameters. In addition, an ablation experiment is conducted to analyze the impact of training epochs, batch size, learning rate, and transfer learning strategies on model performance. The results demonstrate that Vision Mamba achieves superior classification performance (accuracy of 92.88%) while significantly reducing computational resource requirements, highlighting its strong potential for real-world deployment. This work provides valuable insights for the selection and optimization of artificial intelligence models in pulmonary disease diagnosis.

title: Calculation and analysis of low voltage distribution network based on quantum particle swarm optimization
authors: Hao Luo, Yongfeng Shen
publish: 2025 6th International Conference on Computer Vision and Data Mining (ICCVDM)
abstract: The loss of low-voltage distribution lines in the power system is analyzed. In order to overcome the shortcomings of existing methods such as low accuracy and local extreme values, this project will use the quantum particle swarm algorithm (QPSO) to calculate and analyze power line losses. Firstly, the topology, load distribution characteristics and line correlation coefficient of the power grid are analyzed, and the global optimization performance is improved by using QPSO, spatial information and adaptive threshold. QPSO and genetic algorithms are used to compare the measurement data. The simulation results show that the proposed method has high efficiency and good convergence, and can be used for precise positioning of line loss, thus providing an accurate decision-making reference.
